DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Dec. 1, or the first day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1640: Portugal becomes independent again after the Portuguese under the leadership of John IV drive out the Spaniards.
1887: Portugal secures the secession of Macau from China's Ching court.
1918: The Danish parliament passes an act giving independence to Iceland.
1921: With the United States and Britain as mediators, representatives of China and Japan hold negotiations on the issue of the Shantung dispute on the sidelines of a meeting in Washington.
1922: Henry Pu Yi, the last emperor of the Manchu dynasty, and Wan Yung, daughter of Yung Yuan, a former minister in the Ching court, hold their wedding ceremony in Beijing's Forbidden City.
1927: The Republic of China's Chiang Kai-shek and Soong Mayling hold a wedding ceremony witnessed by Tsai Yuan-pei in Shanghai.
1932: The government of the Republic of China, which was moved to Loyang on Jan. 30 due to the Japanese invasion, moves back to Nanjing.
1935: Chiang Kai-shek is elected chairman of the Kuomintang, the ruling party of China.
1936: Chinese Communist Party leaders, including Mao Tse-tung, Chu Teh, and Chou En-lai, send a letter to Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek asking him to allow the CCP to join the war against Japan to save the country.
1951: Communist Chinese troops enter Lhasa, Tibet.
1956: Chiang Kai-shek finishes his book titled "Soviet Russia in China."
1959: Twelve members of the United Nations, including the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain, Japan, and France, sign a treaty in Washington stipulating that the South Pole region will be used for peaceful purposes such as scientific exploration and that no military bases will be allowed.
1961: The first nuclear reactor in the Republic of China, installed by scientists from the National Tsinghua University campus in Hsinchu, is put into operation.
1962: India rejects mainland Chinese proposals for a cease-fire and negotiations over disputed territory.
1969: The ROC government sets up the Armed Forces University, with Yu Po-chuen serving as commandant and Chiang Wei-kuo as vice commandant.
1971: A total of 43 miners of the Keelung Coalmine Company are killed in an accident at the Chisingkeng mine in northern Taiwan.
1972: The ROC and Ivory Coast sign a trade agreement.
1973: A total of 14 seamen go missing when the Tatung, a freighter plying the route between the southern Taiwan city of Kaohsiung and Makung, in the Penghu archipelago, sinks.
1973: The Kuomintang selects 45 candidates for the Taipei City Council election. Sixty-three candidates fight for 49 seats.
1976: A metalworking trade mission representing leading U.S. companies arrives in Taipei for an eight-day visit.
1979: Jurisdiction of the Central Bank of China is moved from the Presidential Office to the Executive Yuan.
1987: Eight people are killed in a fire blamed on arson at a job-training center on the ROC-controlled Green Island.
1987: The Ministry of Education announces that National Chungcheng University will be established in Minhsiung Village, Chiayi County and will begin admitting students in the 1989 academic year.
1988: Benazir Bhutto is nominated to be prime minister of Pakistan, becoming the first woman elected to govern a Muslim nation.
1988: The Executive Yuan announces guidelines governing unofficial participation in international academic conferences and cultural and athletic activities held in mainland China, as well as regulations governing visits to Taiwan by overseas mainland Chinese scholars and students.
1989: Mikhail Gorbachev becomes the first Soviet leader to visit the Vatican and meet the Pope, ending 70 years of mutual hostility between the USSR and the Vatican.
1999: The first batch of the two-in-one lottery tickets issued by the Central Bank of China go on sale, causing a buying spree around the island.
2001: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) loses its position as the largest party in the legislature at the legislative election, winning only 68 seats as compared with the 87 seats won by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
Motse's lesson of the day: "There are many rulers in the world but few are magnanimous. For everybody to imitate the ruler is to imitate the unmagnanimous. Imitating the unmagnanimous cannot be taken as following the right standard."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NOT AGAINST UNIFICATION IF CHINA BECOMES DEMOCRACY: ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Nov. 31 (CNA) (By Y.L. Lin and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan does not exclude the possibility of unification with China at some point in the future if the latter becomes a democratic country, Taiwan's top envoy in Germany said Wednesday.
Speaking in an interview on German television, Shieh Jhy-wey said that what he is opposed to is the threats posed by China's totalitarianism to Taiwan's freedom and democracy.

The envoy also questioned the restrictions imposed by German authorities on the designation used by Taiwan's representative office in the country. He pointing out that the two countries share a close economic and trade relationship, with Germany being Taiwan's most important trading partner in Europe and Taiwan being Germany's fourth largest trading partner in Asia.
"The designation of Taiwan's representative office in Berlin as 'the Taipei Representative Office' does not adequately represent Taiwan," he said.

Shieh further said that he respects Germany's "One China" policy and its position of not officially recognizing Taiwan, adding, however, that he hopes Berlin will at least pay proper attention to the fact of Taiwan's existence in order to have exchanges with the island in a fairer and more open manner.
Talking about cross-Taiwan Strait relations, the envoy said that Taiwan does not exclude the possibility of unification with China at some time in the future if China becomes a democratic country.
In the interview, Shieh also invited German tourists to come visit Taiwan, pointing out that Taiwan now offers visa-free treatment to German citizens for stays of up to 30 days.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF TAIWANESE STUDYING IN U.S. DROPS

TEXT.P: The number of Taiwanese studying in the United States totalled 25,914 for the 2004-2005 school year, marking a decline of 1 percent over the previous year's level, the American International Education Foundation's (AIEF's) Taiwan office reported Thursday.

India topped the list with 80,466 citizens studying in the U.S. in 2004-2005, followed by China with 62,523 citizens, South Korea with 53,358, Japan with 42,215 and Canada with 28,140. Taiwan ranked six on the list.
The AIEF news release said that the foreign students generated at least US$13 billion in economic benefits for the U.S. for 2004-2005.

The news release cited an annual report released last month by the New York-based Institute of International Education as saying that in 2004-2005, there were 565,039 foreigners studying in universities and colleges in the U.S., marking a decrease of 1.3 percent over the previous year's level.

The AIEF indicated that most of the foreign students study in the fields of science or business, with 18 percent in business and management, 17 percent in engineering, 9 percent in mathematics or computer engineering, and 9 percent in physics or the biosciences.

University of Southern California had the most foreign students, followed by the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, the University of Texas at Austin, Columbia University, and New York University.
In terms of states, California had the most foreign students at 75,032, followed by New York State at 61,944, Texas at 47,367, Massachusetts at 27,985, and Florida at 26,264, the AIEF said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 10 PEOPLE CONTRACT AIDS/HIV EVERYDAY IN TAIWAN: CDC

TEXT.P: A total of 10,414 cases of AIDS/HIV infection have been reported in Taiwan up to the end of November 2005, with the number increasing rapidly over the past year at a rate of 10 cases per day, according to data released Thursday by the Center for Disease Control (CDC) on World AIDS Day.
Of these AIDS/HIV cases, 9,872 are locals, CDC officials said.

Unprotected sex between heterosexual couples has been the main cause of these AIDS/HIV cases, which accounts for 49 percent of the cases. Intravenous drug users account for 41 percent, with 60 percent to 70 percent of the new cases reported this year being intravenous drug users.
While the AIDS/HIV cases include infants and elderly as old as 93, most of them fall in the 20-40 age group.

CDC Deputy Director-General Lin Ting attributed the fast spread of AIDS/HIV in Taiwan to the open attitude toward sex by the younger generation, the popularity of sex orgies, the seldom use of condoms during sexual intercourse, and the increase in the number of intravenous drug users.

Calling on the public to show their concern and care for AIDS patients, Lin said the transmissibility of HIV is much lower than that of bird flu and tuberculosis and that the public should not discriminate against AIDS patients because of fear or a misunderstanding of the disease.

DOC.HEADLINE: VISA-FREE PERIOD FOR JAPANESE VISITORS MAY BE EXTENDED TO 90 DAYS

TEXT.P: Taiwan is assessing whether or not to extend the existing 30-day visa-free treatment for Japanese tourists to 90 days as a reciprocal response to Japan's recent move of lifting visa requirements for Taiwanese tourists, a foreign affairs official said Thursday.

Liao Ching-pang, deputy chief executive officer of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs' Committee on Japanese Affairs, said that consular affairs officials are studying the case. At present, 30 days is the longest visa-free period that Taiwan grants to any country.

Japan announced in mid-September that it would offer permanent visa-free privileges to travelers from Taiwan starting Sept. 26 as a belated reciprocal measure since Taiwan has long offered visa-free treatment to Japanese tourists.

Liao also said that exchanges between Taiwan and Japan have been largely boosted in recent months, with Taiwan hosting eight Japanese parliamentarian delegations and 30 civil group delegations in the past two months.
The significant contact between the two nations recently includes the 30th Taiwan-Japan economic and trade conference which was held in Tokyo on Nov. 30 and Dec. 1.

Taiwan representatives attending the conference include officials from the committee and department of treaty and legal affairs, as well as officials from the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Environmental Protection Administration, and the Council of Agriculture.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 23.65 points to close at 6,179.82.
The bourse opened at 6,196.36 and fluctuated between 6,202.91 and 6,162.86 during trading. A total of 3.2 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$80.47 billion (US$2.39 billion).
Only one of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with cement stocks moving up 0.3 percent.

The other seven major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down the most at 1.3 percent, followed by plastics and chemicals shares at 0.5 percent, foodstuff issues at 0.4 percent, paper and pulp issues at 0.3 percent, and textile stocks, machinery and electronics shares and banking and financial shares all at 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 647 to 326, with 189 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: NCPFS TO DEAL CAUTIOUSLY WITH SUGGESTION ON CO-HOSTING 2008 OLYMPICS

TEXT.P: A high-ranking sports official said Thursday that the National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports (NCPFS) under the Executive Yuan will cautiously deal with China's suggestion that Taiwan and China jointly host the 2008 Olympic Games.
Chu Show-chien, vice chairman of the council, made the comments in response to a Chinese sports leader's recent proposal that certain events of the 2008 Olympic Games could be held on the island.
According to Yuan Weimin, honorary chairman of the Chinese Olympic Committee, Taiwan could host some events, such as baseball, archery and taekwondo.

Nevertheless, Chu said that if the two sides of the Taiwan Strait decided that they wanted to jointly host the Olympic Games, they would first have to seek approval from the International Olympic Committee. He added that "as the cross-strait issue is very complicated and politically sensitive, it wouldn't be simple for them to do what they wanted to do."
Besides, Chu also questioned whether Yuan's suggestion carries any weight, noting that the official has already retired.

China's Taiwan policy, which has always taken political factors into consideration, is aimed at downgrading Taiwan's position, Chu further said, claiming that Yuan's proposal "is only for political purposes."
"The NCPFS cannot make any decisions on issues related to China and Taiwan co-hosting the Olympic Games, but it will closely watch developments and deal with the matter cautiously," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: GET OUT AND VOTE ON DECEMBER 3: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian called on the country's citizens Thursday to turn out for the Dec. 3 "three-in-one" elections to enjoy their right to be their own masters and manifest the essence of democracy.

Addressing the issue in the latest edition of his online newsletter, Chen said people can have different opinions on different issues in a pluralistic, democratic society and that brainstorming can lead to progressiveness.
"It is not enough for us to sit down and talk; we also need to stand up and act to bring our power into full play. The best opportunity is to cast our sacred votes in every election, " Chen said.
According to Chen, the core value of democracy lies in the people, rather than the government or political parties, because the people are the true masters of the country.

As Taiwan is still a fledgling democracy, with its people having only started to learn to be their own masters, it is a priority to maintain the hard-fought democratic system and deepen the essence of democracy through elections, Chen said.
The president said he hopes that every voter will turn out for the upcoming elections to use their votes to express their stand, instead of thinking that politics is the business of politicians.
He pointed out that because many people are dissatisfied with the current political situation in Taiwan, they are reluctant to come out to vote for competent candidates.

These people only start to express their displeasure and put the blame on the government after those who were elected turn out to be so incompetent that they lower the government's overall efficiency, he said.
"Such an indifferent attitude is the greatest harm to democracy. Everyone should learn to play their roles as the masters of the country and of themselves," Chen said.

In addition to cherishing every opportunity to participate in an election, it is most important for voters to turn down any offers to buy their votes and reject candidates with gangster backgrounds who are trying to expand their influence into politics through taking part in elections, he said.

Noting that the ultimate goal of elections is to choose the virtuous and the capable, Chen said the people will only lead a happy life if they elect county and city chiefs, county and city councilors, and township and village heads who are serious about their jobs and about serving the public.

Although Taiwan's democracy still has room for improvement, the country will one day emerge to become a pioneer in global democratic reforms as long as more and more people in the country are willing to express themselves with their votes, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAD TO STEP DOWN IF PARTY DOESN'T WIN HALF OF SEATS IN ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday that he will step down if KMT candidates cannot take more than half of the seats -- 11 -- in the upcoming city and county chief elections.

Ma made the remarks when he attended a news conference convened by Chou Hsi-wei, candidate of the KMT for Taipei County magistrate, to drum up support for the Dec. 3 elections. Taipei County is considered the key battleground between the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the KMT.

Ma explained that the KMT currently rules in eight out of 23 cities and counties, but it has not nominated candidates in the outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu. For this reason, he said that by saying "more than half," he meant that if the KMT cannot win 11 seats on Taiwan proper, he will resign from his post.
He said that he has worked 18 hours a day, every day recently. Though the islandwide stumping trips are tough, he has received enthusiastic responses.

During the at least 300 campaign rallies, he has felt acutely the passion of the Taiwan people. Though these are local elections, they cover 99 percent of the island and affect 89 percent of the people, he added.

Ma, already tipped as the KMT's standard-bearer in the 2008 presidential election, pointed out that the DPP has performed poorly over the past five years, and has had to rely on smear tactics in these elections.
The more pathetic thing, according to Ma, is that bribery has been even more serious than he imagined, saying that it has been the most outrageous since he first took part in election campaigns.
He urged the public to vote for the KMT in the Dec. 3 elections if they want Taiwan to move upward and cast ballots for the DPP if they want the island to sink further.
But if people vote for the DPP, this also means that he has not done a good job, and he is willing to step down from his post.

With two more days to go before Saturday's "three-in-one" elections, Ma appealed to the public to see the elections as a "no-confidence vote" for the DPP, and expressed the hope that the KMT will gain seats to continue its reform platform.

DOC.HEADLINE: HALVING NUMBER OF STATE-OWNED BANKS CAN BE DONE: VICE PREMIER

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Wu Rong-i said Thursday that the government is confident of meeting the goal of halving the number of state-owned banks to six as part of the ongoing "second-phase financial reform" program by the end of this year.
Wu made the remarks after attending a seminar on financial reforms and strategies held at the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research, a local think tank.

When it was pointed out that there was still one bank yet to be dealt with, with only one month before the end of this year, he said that although there is rampant speculation, the government has made preparations and he is confident that the goal can be reached.
Meanwhile, Wu also dismissed reports that the government does not welcome the opposition parties to take part in a planned national economic development advisory conference.
He said that the government welcomes views from all quarters, saying that the economy can only develop with a national consensus.

He noted that compared with the previous economic development advisory conference when the economic situation was worse, this time, the government has made some strides in economic growth and reducing jobless rates.
The government will have to consider its next move for the nation's economy, he said. Cross-strait trade will also be addressed in the planned economic conference.

During the first meeting, which took place in August 2001, representatives from different sectors discussed a wide range of issues concerning industry, finance, investment, labor affairs and cross-Taiwan Strait relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT POLICY NOT SUBJECT TO CHANGE BY ELECTIONS: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that his administration has maintained a consistent cross-strait policy and it is not subject to any change by the results of the upcoming local government elections.

Answering journalists' questions during a breakfast meeting with Lo Wen-chia -- the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's candidate for Taipei County chief -- President Chen hinted that the DPP administration's China policy will remain pragmatic but slightly restrictive and conservative as it has been over the past five years after the Dec. 3 "three-in-one" elections.

Chen discounted allegations that Taiwan's China policy will become more open and more relaxed in the event of a sweeping victory by the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang, the People First Party and the New Party in the upcoming elections, arguing that the country's cross-strait policy, including economic and trade measures, will become even more restrictive should the "pan-blue alliance" win because, he said, he will have to tighten the policy to "safeguard the well-being and rights of the people."

Taking last year's legislative election as an example, Chen said that despite the victory of the "pan-blue alliance, " which is pro-unification with China, Beijing passed its Anti-Secession Law a few months afterward authorizing non-peaceful means if Taiwan edges toward formal independence. The law, which was legislated in defiance of opposition also from the United States, Japan and the European Union, has forced Taiwan to tighten its cross-strait policy, he added.

The Dec. 3 "three-in-one" elections are for city mayors and county magistrates, city and county councilors, and township and village chiefs in 21 cities and counties islandwide as well as the two outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOFT DELEGATION TO INSPECT INVESTMENT ENVIRONMENT IN BANGLADESH

TEXT.P: Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) Deputy Director-General Wu Hsin-hua led a trade delegation to Bangladesh Thursday.

Wu's delegation, comprised of local bicycle, shoe, and plastic product manufacturers, is expected to assess the feasibility of Taiwan businessmen investing in Dhaka, the capital of Bangladesh, and an export processing zone at Chittagong, the second-largest city and the commercial capital city of Bangladesh.

BOFT officials noted that Taiwan's bicycle manufacturers have focused their investments in China and Vietnam. With the European Union's recent imposition of an anti-dumping tax on Chinese and Vietnamese bicycles exported to Europe, the impact on Taiwan businessmen has been significant.
Wu's delegation will help Taiwan businessmen reach out globally and diversity their operational risks.
The EU announced in July that it would impose an anti-dumping tax up to 48.5 percent and 34.5 percent, respectively, on bicycles exporting to the EU from China and Vietnam.

The BOFT is actively wooing those high-priced bicycles (over US$200 per unit) manufacturers that have their own brand names to return to Taiwan and wants to help those Taiwan businessmen that produce medium-priced bicycles to diversify their investments. Bangladesh is one of the countries under consideration, the officials said.

They said that Bangladesh has an ample pool of laborers and low wages. As an underdeveloped country, its products exported to the EU, Japan and Canada enjoy quota and tariff-free treatment. The Dhaka government also provides tax incentives to lure foreign businessmen to invest in the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TAIEX Index futures for January moved down 11 points to end at 6,170, with 177 contracts traded, while March futures lost 35 points to finish at 6,150, with eight contracts traded. DOC.HEADLINE: FLUORESCENT PIGMENTS FOUND IN COFFEE FILTER PAPERS

TEXT.P: Seven out of 11 brands of coffee filter papers sampled by the Consumers' Foundation contain fluorescent pigment, a substance that can lead to cancer, foundation officials said Thursday.
The filters were collected by the foundation in September and October -- seven from hypermarkets and chain coffee shops in Taipei and four others from stores in Japan, the officials said.
Tests on the samples indicate that fluorescent pigment was contained in six of the products purchased in Taiwan and in one sample purchased in Japan, they said.
They said that although the fluorescent pigment did not dissolve into water in the tests, consumers should pay attention to the existence of the cancer-triggering substance.
They urged consumers to select paper filters that look light brown in color, because this was the color of the four samples that did not contain fluorescent pigment.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO ACADEMICIANS HONORED WITH PRESIDENTIAL SCIENCE AWARD

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office announced the winners of the 2005 Presidential Science Awards Thursday, with two academicians from Academia Sinica to be honored with awards in the categories of mathematical sciences and life sciences.

National Applied Research Laboratories President Lee Lou-chuang will be decorated with an award in mathematical sciences at a presentation ceremony Dec. 16 at the Presidential Office, while the award in life sciences will go to Chen Chien-jen, dean of the College of Public Health at National Taiwan University, officials of the office said.
President Chen Shui-bian will present the awards, they noted.

The Presidential Science Awards are presented in four categories -- mathematical sciences, life sciences, social sciences, and applied sciences. This year, no nominees were qualified to receive prizes in social sciences and applied sciences, the officials said.

They explained that preparation work for the 2005 awards began in March 2004, and until the selection process ended in September, two meetings of the selection committee have been held to examine the qualification of 13 nominees.
Lee, who was inducted into Academia Sinica in 2002, specializes in physics and geophysics. He also won an academic prize from the Ministry of Education.

Chen, an expert in epidemiology and human genetics, was minister of the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration. He was decorated with the distinguished research award by the National Science Council, and won the title of academician in 1998.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI ARENA EXPECTED TO BE A NEW 'SOUL-NOURISHING HUB' IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Witnessing the inauguration of the Taipei Arena sports center, Asia's synthesizing dance genius Lin Hwai-min said Thursday that he looks forward to seeing the dome become a "soul-nourishing haven" for Taipei residents.

Lin, founder of the widely acclaimed Cloud Gate Dance Theater and one of the "Asian Heroes" chosen by Time magazine in 2005, welcomed the opening of the NT$4.6 billion (US$139.4 million) domed stadium after five years of construction on the site of the former Taipei Baseball Stadium near the intersection of Nanking East Road and Tunhua North Road.

In his opening speech, Lin recalled that Cloud Gate Dance Theater maintained an office in a basement near the Nanking-Tunhua intersection many years ago and whenever he was at the office and heard the sounds from the baseball stadium, whether it was music, songs or baseball fans' jubilation over a home run, he thought it was the most beautiful sound in Taipei.
After a hiatus of five years, he said, Taipei's most beautiful sounds will be heard again after the 15,000-seat dome opens to concerts and other performances.

Also speaking at the inaugural ceremony, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said the arena will live up to the performance art circle's expectations by offering a venue more spacious and with longer contracts than the National Theater or the National Concert Hall, where even the world renowned Cloud Gate Dance Theater can get a reservation for only eight days each year.
"I believe the Taipei Arena will contribute to revitalizing Taipei residents' cultural and sports activities, consequently upgrading their quality of life in years to come," Ma added.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT URGES SWIFT DOH ACTION ON UNLAWFUL DISCLOSURE OF MEDICAL RECORDS

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Thursday urged the Department of Health (DOH) to set up a task force to investigate the disclosure of Taichung Mayor Janson Hu's medical records by a ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislator.

At a breakfast meeting with representatives from the DOH and the Taiwan Medical Association, KMT legislators said the DOH must take swift action to deal with the apparent violation of the Doctor's Law and medical ethics in order to restore public confidence in the nation's health service.

On Tuesday, DPP Legislator Lin Chin-hsin, who is a practicing physician, appeared at a news conference in Taichung with 11 other doctors and disclosed what they claimed to be Hu's medical history from the Taichung Veterans General Hospital.
They demanded that Hu withdraw from the Dec. 3 elections because they believed that his chances of having a stroke were 30 times that of a healthy person.

The DPP legislator did not explain how he obtained Hu's medical records, nor was he able to confirm that the records were genuine. He claimed that he did not violate medical ethics because Hu was not his patient.
Dr. Shao Ke-yung, director of the Taichung Veterans General Hospital, told KMT lawmakers Thursday that he did not see the document obtained by Lin and could not verify whether it was genuine.

Shao added, however, that his hospital is rigid on rules about the safekeeping of patients' health information, and that there was no record showing that anyone had gone through regular channels to look at the Taichung mayor's medical history.

Replying to KMT legislators' questions, Chen Tzay-Jinn, deputy head of the DOH, said the DOH has already asked the health authorities in Taichung City to establish whether the 12 doctors violated the Doctor's Law, and that it will be up to the local medical associations to determine if these doctors violated the ethics of the medical profession.

Asked to comment on the incident at a separate occasion, DOH Minister Hou Shen-mao said it was very inappropriate for doctors to publicize a patient's medical records. He stressed that it is a basic ethical tenant that the medical profession should protect a patient's privacy.

Dr. Wu Nan-ho, chairman of the Taiwan Medical Association, said in a statement Thursday that the behavior of the 12 doctors does not represent the position of the nation's medical profession, and that the association will take appropriate action according to medical ethics when the investigation on the incident is completed.

The DPP legislative caucus also distanced itself from Lin's conduct. Caucus whip William Lai admitted that Lin's disclosure of the Taichung mayor's medical records was against doctors' ethics. He said that if the KMT legislators want an apology from the DPP caucus, they should go directly to Lin.
Another DPP legislator, Hsu Kuo-yung, also said he does not approve of Lin's behavior. He urged Lin to face the consequences of his actions.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG MAYOR TAKING EXTRA SAFETY PRECAUTIONS

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu is taking extra safety precautions after receiving intelligence reports that threats have been made to remove him from the Dec. 3 "three in one" elections.
Speaking to the media Thursday, Hu, of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), acknowledged that the safety precautions include him bringing his own food and water to campaign sites on his daily itinerary.

Opinion poll results show that Hu, who is seeking re-election in the central Taiwan city, is slightly ahead of Lin Chia-lung, candidate of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, and Shen Chi-hui, candidate of the People First Party (PFP).

According to an estimate by Hu's aides, the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the PFP might get 30,000 more votes than the DPP in Taichung. If Shen receives more than 30,000 votes, Hu's chances of re-election could be in jeopardy.

On the DPP's attempt to focus public attention on his health, Hu said that while he does not mind discussion of the issue, he will not agree to the DPP's demand to publicize his medical records because they would be misused.

Hu said he will file a civil lawsuit after the elections against DPP Legislator Dr. Lin Chin-hsin and 11 other medical doctors for disclosing what they claimed to be his medical history, and that he will donate whatever compensation he might receive from the defendants to charity.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET ACCUSED OF CHEATING VOTERS WITH TAX DEDUCTIONS

TEXT.P: The Alliance of Fairness and Justice Thursday dismissed the tax rebates announced by the Cabinet a day earlier as a trick aimed at grabbing votes in the Dec. 3 "three-in-one" elections.
Premier Frank Hsieh announced Wednesday that the standard deduction for married couples filing their income tax jointly will be increased from NT$67,000 (US$2,000) to NT$88,000 this year

In line with the rise in consumer prices, the personal income tax exemption will be hiked from NT$74,000 to NT$77,000 starting next year. The standard deduction for married couples will be further increased to NT$92,000, while the special deduction on salaries and that for the mentally or physically challenged will each be raised by NT$3,000.
In addition, the exemptions and deductions for inheritance tax and gift tax will also be hiked, with the tax rate differentials widened.

Chien Hsi-chieh, convener of the alliance, said increasing the exemptions and deductions for inheritance tax and gift tax is similar to lowering the tax rate, which he said will benefit people who obviously are already very wealthy.

The alliance will only agree to lowering the inheritance and gift tax rates if overseas income and securities trading are made taxable in Taiwan to prevent rich people from evading paying tax, Chien said.

According to Tseng Chu-wei, a professor of public finance at National Chengchi University, the Cabinet is cheating the people by treating the tax deduction issue as if the government is granting some kind of a favor to the people.
Tseng pointed out that it is stipulated in related tax laws that the exemptions, deductions and tax rate differentials should be adjusted in accordance with the fluctuations of consumer prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEMINAR ON IMPROVING FISHING POLICIES SET FOR DEC. 5

TEXT.P: The Fisheries Administration is to hold a seminar Dec. 5 to discuss adopting a better fishery policy that will lead to improvements in the prospects for the aquaculture industry, the administration said Thursday.
Attendants at the seminar will discuss Taiwan's current aquaculture industry in four aspects: its structure, organization, management and legal framework.

According to the administration, under the supervision of the Council of Agriculture (COA), the aquaculture industry's productivity is roughly 300,000 tons worth NT$30 billion (US$857 million) each year.

The administration said that Taiwan's aquaculture industry has now reached a bottleneck. Naming a few examples, the administration cited the lack of fish breeding space, elevated costs, degradation of breeding environment and an imbalance between production and market demand.

During the seminar, the administration plans to outline their prospects in terms of regulating the fish breeding industry's scale, implementing appropriate management structures, and building an organization for the aquaculture industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG-CHINA CEPA MIGHT AFFECT TAIWAN NEXT YEAR: BOFT

TEXT.P: The Closer Economic Partnership Arrangement (CEPA) pact signed by Hong Kong and China might affect some Taiwan exports next year as the accord enters its third phrase, the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs warned Thursday.
Taiwan exports of spectacle frames and synthetic fabrics might be hindered after the Hong Kong-China CEPA enters its third year in 2006, BOFT officials said.

Under the terms of the third-phase CEPA, 261 items of Hong Kong exports to China will be granted zero-tariff treatment, including garment, synthetic fabrics, fruit juice, dried fish and some plastics and chemical products, the officials said.
Last year, Hong Kong exports of cotton fabrics and spectacle frames to China were worth US$5.99 million and US$8.65 million, ahead of Taiwan's US$1.59 million and US$3.17 million, respectively.

With the 10 percent custom duties to be removed from the additional 261 Hong Kong export items from next year, similar Taiwan outbound shipments to China will be further affected, the officials pointed out.

After the third-phase of the Hong Kong-China CEPD takes effect early next year, it will bring the number of Hong Kong export items eligible for China's zero-tariff privilege to 1,369, accounting for only 18.7 percent of the 7,316 items listed in its tariff code after China joined in the World Trade Organization by the end of 2001.

DOC.HEADLINE: 65 PERSONS IN TAINAN INDICTED FOR BUYING VOTES

TEXT.P: The Tainan District Prosecutor's Office has indicted 65 candidates or candidate's campaign aides suspected of vote-buying concerning the upcoming "three-in-one" local elections, according to a report released by the southern Taiwan office Thursday.
So far the office has received more than 700 items of information and tips on vote-buying, and has launched investigations in over 100 cases, the report said.

Voting for city and county chiefs, city and county councilors, as well as township administrators will take place simultaneously Dec. 3 nationdwide, except for Taipei and Kaohsiung municipalities. Officials of the office reiterated their determination to crack down on vote-buying, warning candidates of severe penalties, including invalidating their victory should they win an election.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-DPP CHAIRMAN URGES CANDIDATES TO CAMPAIGN IN DECENT MANNER

TEXT.P: Local people should not vote for candidates who kneel gratuitously to beg for ballots, former ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung said Thursday.

Lin, who is widely respected for his moral stature, said he would like to seeing the candidates running in the Dec. 3 "three-in-one" elections campaign in a decent manner instead of their normal tactics of mudslinging, begging and other negative tactics.

Lin's remarks were seen as a response to recent media speculation that Lin might go down on his knees to canvass votes for Chen Ding-nan, the DPP's standard-bearer in the hotly contested Ilan county magistrate election, just like the late DPP Legislator Lu Hsiu-yi did eight years ago for the then-DPP candidate for the Taipei county magistrateship, Su Tsen-chang, who is now DPP chairman.

Lu's kneeling at Su's last campaign rally ahead of the 1997 Taipei County election was believed to be among a constellation of factors contributing to Su's victory by a narrow margin against his then-ruling Kuomintang rival.

"Lu was then a terminally ill cancer patient. He could not speak for Su on that occasion. Therefore, he chose to kneel before the voters to solicit their support for Su. It was a solemn and moving moment, " Lin said.

It's a wholly different thing for a normal and healthy candidate or campaign aide to get on his knees and beg for ballots, Lin said, adding that local voters should pay no heed to candidates' gratuitous campaign gimmicks.

Speaking while accompanying Chen on a vote-canvassing tour of an open-air traditional marketplace in Lotung, Ilan County, Lin said he decided to come out of retirement to stump for Chen, mainly to show "warmth of friendship."

"Chen is a good friend of mine of more than 30 years. He is a respectable politician. I feel compelled to throw my support behind him. I'm hopeful that all eligible voters will make the right choice and elect a candidate who can serve the people selflessly," Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, JAPAN STRIKE BASEL PACT ON HAZARDOUS WASTE MOVEMENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Japan forged a bilateral agreement in Tokyo Thursday on international hazardous waste control under the spirit of the Basel Convention in an effort to jointly help conserve the environment.

On behalf of the Republic of China government, Yang Ching-hsi, director-general of the Solid Waste Management Bureau under the Environmental Protection Administration, signed the Taiwan-Japan bilateral agreement, which reflects the environmentally sound management of waste stipulated by the Basel Convention on the Control of Transboundary Movements of Hazardous Waste and its Disposal.
The agreement was signed as a final touch to the 30th Taiwan-Japan Economic and Trade Conference that opened in Tokyo Wednesday and was attended by some 90 officials from the two countries.
The agreement marked the first time Taiwan has entered a bilateral pact on environmental protection efforts with another country based on an international treaty.

Under the agreement, Taiwan and Japan will maintain a formal channel to jointly trace and control hazardous waste and will cooperate on the exchange of information, technology transfer, and the harmonization of standards, codes and guidelines on hazardous waste management.

Worldwide concern about the transboundary movement and disposal of hazardous waste was heightened in the late 1970s and early 1980s. The major concern was waste being exported from industrial nations for cheap disposal in inadequately prepared sites in developing countries.
This concern led to a new urgency in developing and implementing international controls. It culminated in the landmark global convention under the United Nations -- the Basel Convention.

The United Nations invited 116 countries to participate in the development of the convention and made them original signatories on March 22, 1989. It came into force May 5, 1992 after being ratified by 20 countries. As of February 2004, 158 countries, including the European Union, are party to the convention.
Nations that have ratified the Basel Convention are allowed to ship hazardous waste to, from or through only other parties to the convention.

The convention, however, permits an exception to this requirement if a separate bilateral agreement covers relations with a given trading partner that is not a party to the convention. It allows parties to the convention to develop such a bilateral agreement as long as the agreement reflects the environmentally sound management of waste.
Taiwan is not a Basel Convention signatory, but Japan is. The same thing happened between Canada and the United States, which is also not a signatory.

The Taiwan-Japan Economic and Trade conference -- co-sponsored by the Association of East Asian Relations (AEAR) and its Japanese counterpart, the Interchange Association -- was divided into three groups that exchanged views on more than 72 issues concerning general policy, agriculture, fishery, medicine and technology exchanges, and intellectual property rights protection.

The 42-strong Taiwan delegation was headed by AEAR President Lo Fu-chen with Huang Chih-peng, director-general of the Foreign Trade Bureau under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, serving as the supreme adviser to the delegation.

Other members of the Taiwan delegation included officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Ministry of Economic Affairs, Ministry of Transportation and Communications, Council of Agriculture, Environmental Protection Administration, Fair Trade Commission and Taiwan's Representative Office in Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: For New Court, Abortion Case Takes Old Path
The question that had drawn the crowds to the Supreme Court in a New Hampshire abortion case Wednesday morning had an answer. The abortion law was not about to undergo a major change in the hands of the new Supreme Court, at least not yet. Justices across the ideological s pectrum appeared inclined to send the case back to the federal appeals court that had declared the law unenforceable in all respects, and to instruct that court to render a narrower ruling. Such a ruling would permit the law to take effect except when a doctor had certified that an immediate abortion - without either notifying a parent or seeking approval from a judge, an option known as a judicial bypass - was necessary to preserve a girl's health. In South Africa,
Wall Street Journal: In South Africa, Corruption Charge Tests Democracy
Until recently South Africa's deputy president Jacob Zuma was charged with corruption stemming from a big arms deals. A former guerrilla ldeader, Zuma fought and was incarcerated by the defunct apartheid regime. Now he's facing the prospect of prison again, but this time he's battling completely different adversaries: state institutions of a new, democratic South Africa. A populist champion of the nation's increasingly frustrated poor, Zuma is also being investigated on allegations of rape. Zuma denies any wrongdoing; his left-wing followers were quick to blast the unfolding legal onslaught as political persecution orchestrated by President Thabo Mbeki. The case already is rattling the legitimacy of many institutions of the new South Africa, including its judicial system, its law-enforcement agencies, the media and the ANC itself.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-THAILAND ECONOMIC COOPERATION CONFERENCE TO BE HELD IN BANGKOK
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Dec. 1 (CNA) (By Wu Hsieh-chang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The the 16th Taiwan-Thailand Economic Cooperation Conference is slated to be held in Bangkok Dec. 21 with scores of business and industrial leaders from both countries taking part.

The Taiwan delegation is expected to be led by Chen Fei-lung, chairman of Namchow Chemical Co. and head of the Thailand Committee under the Taipei-based Chinese International Economic Cooperation Association (CIECA) -- one of the most influential business blocs in Taiwan.

During the conference, Thai and Taiwanese business and industrial leaders are expected to exchange views on Taiwan's industrial development, Taiwan's second "Go South" overseas investment policy, business and industrial cooperation between the two countries, and ways to help upgrade Thailand's industrial structure.

The conference attendees are also expected to talk about the implementation of a bilateral agreement on the exemption of double taxation that was signed by the two countries in 1999 but which Thailand has so far failed to implement.
Taiwan businesses channeled some US$6 billion into Thailand for various investment projects last year, marking an increase of 21 percent over the year-earlier level.
Taiwan, with its investment in Thailand totaling over US$10 billion to date, is currently Thailand's third-largest source of capital behind only the United States and Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: NANTOU COUNTY MAGISTRATE'S OFFICE SEARCHED FOR VOTE-BUYING EVIDENCE
DOC.DATELINE: Nantou County, central Taiwan, Dec. 1 (CNA) (By Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: Public prosecutors supported by riot police searched the office of Nantou County Magistrate Lin Tsung-nan and six other locations Thursday for evidence of vote buying and took away large piles of documents during the three-and-a-half-hour operation.

They also tried to summon Lin and about 20 of his associates for questioning, but the magistrate, who is seeking re-election in the Dec. 3 "three in one" elections, did not show up at the county's Prosecutor's Office and instead continued with his scheduled campaign activities.
Prosecutors were acting on tipoffs that Lin and his men were buying votes with cash and trying to win voter support through the awarding of contracts for miscellaneous construction projects.

Emerging from his campaign headquarters later that day, Lin questioned why the prosecutors waited until two days from the elections to search his office and summon him. He claimed it would be difficult to make people believe the operation was unrelated to political persecution.
Choking back tears, he pleaded that he be allowed to finish his election campaign and promised that he would report to the prosecutors after Dec. 3.
He also said that if he could have a second chance, he would finish his current term and quit politics forever.

Lin, of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), is running for re-election as an independent against DPP-nominated candidate Tsai Huang-lang and opposition Kuomintang candidate Li Chao-ching. He has been highly critical of President Chen Shui-bian for not returning the favor of supporting him, as he supported the president in the 2004 presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TONES DOWN SIGNIFICANCE OF DEC. 3 ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian attempted to tone down Thursday the significance of the upcoming "three-in-one" elections, saying that the elections are not the mid-term test of his presidency as seen by some observers.

"The Dec. 3 elections are local elections, not a mid-term test of the presidency. They have nothing to do with the transfer of power at the central government level, nor are they a confidence vote on the Cabinet, " Chen said in a pre-election interview with cable broadcaster ETTV.

Chen acknowledged that the outcome of the elections is significant in four ways -- it will decide interaction between central and local governments as well as whether the domestic political situation will remain stable in the coming two years, whether his various reform initiatives can be carried out smoothly and how the future policies on economic development and relations with China will take shape.
Even so, Chen insisted that the electoral results will not necessarily mandate a post-election Cabinet reshuffle.

"At the moment, I'm preoccupied with how to help the ruling party's candidates stand out in the weekend elections. I have not given any thought to issues regarding a reshuffle of the administrative team, " Chen said, adding that it will depend on the post-election circumstances, including interaction between the ruling and opposition camps, cross-strait relations and the general international situation.

With only two days to go before the elections for city mayors/county magistrates, city/county councilors and township/village chiefs, most media opinion polls have shown the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lagging behind the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) in more than half the constituencies, although one quarter of voters remain undecided.
Hitting the campaign trail for the DPP earlier in the day, Chen appeared to be turning up anti-China rhetoric to consolidate his party's core pro-independence support base.

The DPP advocates a separate identity for Taiwan, whereas the KMT and its allies oppose Taiwan independence. China claims the self-ruled island of 23 million as part of its territory and says Taiwan must be brought back to the fold, by force if
Chen told voters that an opposition win in local government elections this weekend would undermine the island's sovereignty.

"If the opposition parties win, Taiwan is finished. They will pass the Taiwan version of the anti-secession law, or a surrender law, " Chen told a rally in central Taiwan. "Taiwan will have to accept the one-China principle and become a part of China." He was referring to a bill proposed by the opposition to set up a commission responsible for talks with China. Critics say the bill would serve to legalize Beijing's "one China" policy. China's anti-secession law allows the use of "non-peaceful means" if Taiwan pushes for a permanent split from the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOI TO PROPOSE LAW REVISIONS TO MANDATE MORE JOBS FOR THE DISABLED

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior will draft law revisions to require more job openings for mentally or physically challenged individuals, Minister of the Interior Su Jia-chyuan said Thursday.
Su made the announcement ahead of the Dec. 3 International Day of Disabled Persons.

Under the terms of the present Disabled People Protection Law, public agencies with a staff of more than 50 must hire at least 2 percent of staffers with physical or mental disabilities. Meanwhile, private enterprises with a staff of more than 100 must hire at least 1 percent of staffers with disabilities.
As of the end of this past September, private and public agencies had employed a total of 45,400 disabled staffers, exceeding the mandatory number of 33,955.

Against this backdrop, Su said the MOI plans to revise the current law to offer even more job opening to the disabled. Su said the ministry plans to raise the disabled hiring ratio for public agencies to 3 percent and that for the private sector to 1.5 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY

TEXT.P: Today is Friday, Dec. 2, or the second day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1804: Monarchy returns to France when Napoleon Bonaparte crowns himself Emperor Napoleon I at Notre Dame, 11 years after King Louis XVI was guillotined.
1815: The Rajah of Nepal signs peace treaty with Britain.
1823: U.S. President James Monroe, introducing his "Monroe Doctrine," warns Europe to keep its hands off both American continents.
1901: King Camp Gillette markets a safety razor with a double-edged disposable blade in the United States.
1908: Henry Pu Yi, the last emperor of the Ching dynasty, is crowned emperor of China at the age of three.
1911: Chinese revolutionaries capture Nanjing.
1923: The Young China Party sets up in Paris, France.
1942: A nuclear chain reaction is demonstrated for the first time by American scientists working on a secret project in Chicago.
1954: Republic of China Foreign Minister George K.C. Yeh signs the Sino-American Mutual Defense Treaty with U.S. Secretary of State John Foster Dulles in Washington.
1965: The World Health Organization formally recognizes Taiwan as free of malaria.
1968: The Taiwan Power Company signs an agreement with the World Bank for a loan of US$50 million for construction of the Dachien Dam.
1971: Soviet Union spaceship "Mars III" lands on Mars.
1974: The Fifth Asian Congress of Pharmaceutical Sciences opens a four-day meeting in Taipei.
1974: The Young China Party celebrates its 51st anniversary.
1976: The Fourth Asian Composers' League Conference holds its closing ceremony, with more than 100 delegates and observers from 20 countries attending.
1976: The ROC's "Hai Kung" research vessel leaves Keelung for an expedition to Antarctica.
1988: A cyclone packing winds in excess of 177 kph hits Bangladesh, killing thousands and leaving more than 5 million homeless.
1986: The Chunghwa (ROC) Blues and the Chunghwa Whites win 1st and 2nd places, respectively in the Third International Baseball Tournament.
1989: V.P. Singh, leader of the Janata Dal Party, replaces Rajiv Gandhi as prime minister of India.
1989: Elections are held for the Legislative Yuan, Taiwan Provincial Assembly, Taipei and Kaohsiung municipal councils, county magistrates, and provincial-level city mayors.
1990: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's center-right coalition wins re-election in the first elections since 1932 involving all of Germany.
1994: A ferry carrying more than 600 people collides with a freighter and sinks in Manila Bay, the Philippines. Sixty bodies are recovered, and 85 people remain missing.
1995: The ROC elects 164 lawmakers to the Third Legislative Yuan.
1995: A Singapore court sentences former Barings Bank trader Nick Leeson to six-and-a-half years in prison for his part in the crash of Britain's oldest merchant bank.
1996: ROC Foreign Minister John Chang departs for South Africa.
1997: After a bitter power struggle with Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, President Farooq Leghari of Pakistan resigns.
1999: The Republic of China signs a formal aviation agreement with Palau as part of its efforts to facilitate exchanges between the two countries.

Motse's lesson of the day: "Heaven is all-inclusive and impartial in its activities, abundant and unceasing in its blessings, and lasting and untiring in its guidance. And so, when the sage-kings had accepted heaven as their standard, they measured every action and enterprise by heaven. What heaven desired they would carry out, what heaven abominated they refrained from."

a 30-year-old Peruvian man arrested for allegedly murdering a 7-year-old Hiroshima girl here has admitted killing the first-grader near the stairs of his apartment building, the suspect's lawyer said Thursday night.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REP TO U.S. TO RETURN TO TAIWAN FOR REGULAR REPORT ON WORK
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 1 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: David Lee, the Republic of China's representative to the United States, is set to return to Taiwan Dec. 8 to report in person the performance of his official duties.
At the invitation of the Legislative Yuan's External Relations Committee, the envoy will also report on the current state of Taiwan-U.S. relations to the members of the committee Dec. 14.

A great deal of effort has gone into the reestablishment of mutual trust between Taipei and Washington since Lee assumed his post as Taiwan's top official in the United States in July last year. Now, the channels for communication between the two countries are smooth,

U.S. President George W. Bush's remarks during his recent visit in Tokyo also indirectly affirmed the current good state of U.S.-Taiwan relations. While in the Japanese capital, Bush praised Taiwan's democratic achievement and said that it can be seen as a model for other Asian countries.
Talking about his return to Taiwan to report on his work, Lee said Thursday that the main theme will be to "frankly and truthfully state any problems that exist."

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET TO BE RESHUFFLED AFTER ELECTIONS: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Friday that the Cabinet will definitely be reshuffled after the "three-in-one" nationwide local government elections slated for Saturday.

Speaking while stumping for Chen Kuang-fu, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's candidate running for magistrate in the offshore county of Penghu, Hsieh said that there will be a Cabinet reshuffle and that the only question is what the extent of the shakeup will be.

Hsieh's comments were in response to President Chen Shui-bian's recent remarks that the question of whether there will be a Cabinet reshuffle doesn't necessarily have to be related to the results of the Dec. 3 elections and that the two issues should be 'de-linked.'

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
