The Straits Times: China, S'pore free up direct air services.
Singapore's airlines can look forward to an unlimited number of flights to all Chinese cities under a pact signed by the two countries, the Republic's Transport Minister Yeo Cheow Tong said in Beijing yesterday.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN TO QUIT IF PARTY FAILS TO KEEP 10 SEATS OR TAIPEI COUNTY

TEXT.P: The chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), Su Tseng-chang, announced Friday that if his party fails to keep 10 seats in Saturday's city and county chief elections or loses the key election in Taipei County, he will step down to take responsibility.
Su, who is tipped to be one of the party's standard bearers in the 2008 presidential election, made the solemn announcement in a press conference held at the party's headquarters.

Su put his post on line one day after main opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said he would quit if KMT candidates cannot take more than half of the seats -- 11 seats -- in the upcoming elections.
"The DPP plays a major role in Taiwan's path to progress and democracy, and if it fails to keep 10 seats, it will represent a major upset for the party," Su said.
"The opposition parties will become even more outrageous, and it will also send a wrong signal to China, " Su said, adding that Taiwan's political situation will become even more chaotic.

Su, who had been elected Taipei county magistrate twice, said that the county is now on the path of rapid growth, and that if Luo Wen-jia, the DPP's candidate, cannot continue as magistrate, this "process will be suspended."
If Luo loses, "I'll definitely resign from the chairmanship, " even if the DPP shines in other cities and counties, Su said. The DPP has held the Taipei County magistrate post for 16 years.
Taipei County -- the nation's largest with a population of 3.7 million -- is the key battleground for the DPP and the KMT. Luo is in a neck-and-neck race with Chou Hsi-wei, the KMT candidate.
Su said that since he hit the campaign trail, he has taken part in 480 rallies, stumping for candidates in every city, county, village and township.
The DPP has engaged in a uphill battle after a mass rapid transit construction corruption scandal involving a former presidential aide came to light in late August.

Seventy-seven hopefuls are vying for 23 city mayor and county magistrate posts. During the previous city and county chief elections in 2001, the DPP won nine posts, and the KMT also took nine, while the KMT's allies, the People First Party and the New Party, took a total of three seats, and independents took the other two.

Chang Jung-wei of the KMT was elected as Yunlin county magistrate in 2001. But he was sent to the prison for corruption early this year, and the central government sent Lee Chin-yung to take his place.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, SWISS INSTITUTES SIGN MOU ON MICROTECHNOLOGY COOPERATION
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Dec. 1 (CNA) (By C.H. Lu and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: Representatives of Taiwan's Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) and the Swiss Center of Electronics and Microtechnologies (SCEM) signed Thursday a memorandum of understanding on cooperation and exchanges in the fields of microelectronics and nanotechnology.

The ITRI is a primary research and development center for industry in Taiwan, while the SCEM specializes in the development, engineering and production of realizations in microelectronics, microtechnologies and bio-inspired systems for industry.

Dr. Shyu Jyuo-min, the ITRI's executive vice president, said after signing the memorandum that both Taiwan and Switzerland have made remarkable achievements in research related to microelectronics, microsystems and microtechnologies, adding that cooperation between the two organizations will certainly bring about fruitful and mutually-beneficial results.

Besides signing the MOU, an ITRI delegation headed by Shyu also visited the Swiss research center the same day and listened to a briefing given by staff of the center. In return, Su Tsung-Tsan, general director of the ITRI's NanoTechnology Research Center, briefed his Swiss counterparts on the development of nanotechnologies in Taiwan.

Pointing out that Taiwan's international high-tech cooperation projects have put more emphasis on such sectors as semiconductors and information technologies, Shyu said that naturally, this has made the island inclined to engage in cooperation with the United States rather than Europe which has only had an upper hand in biotechnology and precision machinery.

He further said that he sees future cooperation between the two institutions helping the research and development of both sides as Taiwan's R&D in microelectronics and microsystems is focused on information technology, while Switzerland's is focused on medical science.

Although Taiwan's budget for scientific research has been cut due to internal political factors, Shyu said that the private sector in Taiwan still attaches great importance to research and development. "All in all, the competitiveness of the island's high-tech R&D and industry has not been regressive," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF VISITS BY AMERICANS TO TAIWAN EXPECTED TO BE NEAR TARGET
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Dec. 2 (CNA) (By Lillian Lin and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: With extensive promotion by Taiwan's Tourism Bureau, the number of American tourists to Taiwan has shown modest growth this year, and the figure for the whole year is expected to reach 90 percent of the goal of 450,000 visits, statistics released Thursday showed.

The statistics showed that the number of visits to Taiwan by Americans in October was up 2.58 percent from the figure for the same month last year, while the number of visits in the first 10 months this year was up 2.56 percent from that of the same period last year.
Tourism Bureau officials recently invited tourism reporters from North America to visit Taiwan to learn more about the island's nature and landscape, its diversified culture, and exquisite cuisine.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: The Moscow Times: Yabloko Is Betting on NGO Activists Yabloko has included five leaders of nongovernmental organizations on its ticket for City Duma elections on Sunday, even while NGOs are at odds with the Kremlin over a bill that would tighten state control over their finances and activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: New D.C. Hospital Drawing Skepticism; Some Experts Doubt Financial Viability.
The medical and financial assumptions undergirding a 250-bed hospital complex planned for the city's eastern wards are highly unrealistic, according to some health care experts and an array of critics of the District's venture with Howard University.

DOC.HEADLINE: APPOINTMENT OF AIT HEADS TO BE 'LUMPED TOGETHER'
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 1 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The U.S. Government will "lump together" the appointment of American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) managing director and AIT Taipei office director in order for smooth operations, David Ta-wei Lee, the Republic of China representative to the United States, said Thursday.
The AIT is a quasi-official U.S. organization authorized to handle exchanges with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.

Lee made the remarks when asked why the appointment of AIT managing director has been stalled for so long. The post has been vacant for 19 months since the former AIT managing director, Therese Shaheen, resigned in April 2004.

Reports had said that the U.S. State Department would ask Raymond Burghardt, who served as the AIT Taipei office director -- the de facto U.S. ambassador to Taiwan -- from 1999 to 2001, to head the AIT, and that his appointment would be announced prior to President Chen Shui-bian's visit to Central America in September 2005.

After ending his AIT Taipei office director tenure in 2001, Burghardt took over as U.S. ambassador to Vietnam, serving in that post until last year. He assumed his current post as a department chief at the East-West Center in Hawaii early this year.
Lee said senior U.S. officials did tell him that the new AIT managing director would be announced prior to President Chen's visit, but he learned later that the appointment was shelved.

The reasons for shelving the appointment could be attributed to post-Hurricane Katrina relief efforts as well as differences over whether the AIT managing director should be a political appointee or a career diplomat.
To date, "the original planned candidate" has yet to be changed, Lee said.

As for the successor of Douglas Paal, the AIT Taipei Office director whose term will expire at the end of this year, Lee said the U.S. State Department has tentatively chosen one, but so far, the U.S. has not yet consulted with Taiwan on the candidate.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONWIDE LOCAL GOVERNMENT ELECTIONS ONLY ONE DAY AWAY

TEXT.P: The "three-in-one" local government elections are slated to be held nationwide Saturday, the Central Election Commission (CEC) announced Friday.

Between 8 a.m. and 4 p.m. Saturday, eligible voters, totaling 13,645,079, are expected to cast their ballots at some 12,000 polling stations scattered around 21 cities and counties in Taiwan proper and the two frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu, as well as the offshore county of Penghu, CEC officials said.
Saturday's "three-in-one" elections are for city mayors and county magistrates, city and county councilors, and township and rural township chiefs.

A total of 76 candidates are competing for 23 city mayor and county magistrate posts, while 901 city and county councilor seats are up for grabs among 1,690 candidates and 319 seats for township and rural township chiefs are up for grabs among 786 candidates, according to CEC tallies.

The ballots for the various elections will be in different colors, with white ballots for the city mayor and county magistrate elections, pale yellow ballots for the city and county councilor elections, pink ballots for the township and rural township chief elections, pale blue ballots for the low-lying areas' aboriginal city and county councilor elections, and pale green ballots for the mountain areas' aboriginal city and county councilor elections, the CEC officials said.

The officials called for the country's voters make note of the various regulations at the polling stations, including no mobile phone handsets allowed at the stations, no tearing or any other form of destruction of the ballots, and no removal of ballots from the stations. Violators could face fines of up to NT$50,000 (US$1,515) or even prison sentences of up to one year.

The elections are seen as a hot contest between the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the opposition "pan blue alliance" led by Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou. Both DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang and Ma have vowed to step down if their respective parties fail to win half of the seats up for grabs in the city and county chief elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 49.13 points to close at 6,228.95.
The bourse opened at 6,254.35 and fluctuated between 6,258.34 and 6,209.77 during trading. A total of 4.17 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$112.31 billion (US$3.34 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with cement stocks moving up the most at 1.6 percent, followed by banking and financial shares at 1.5 percent, textile stocks at 1.3 percent, paper and pulp issues at 1.2 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 1.1 percent, construction issues at 0.6 percent, and foodstuff issues at 0.2 percent.
The other major stock category lost ground, with plastics and chemicals shares moving down at 1.3 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 561 to 454, with 189 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SAYS 8 SEATS SECURE, 7 POSSIBLE IN DEC. 3 ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) is secure in eight of the 23 county and city chief races in the "three-in-one" elections set for Dec. 3 and is striving for another seven seats, party officials said Friday.

With KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou having announced that he will step down if the party fails to seize more than half of the seats, KMT officials said they expect this move to help boost voter support for the party.

KMT spokeswoman Cheng Li-wen said the KMT has stable leads in eight counties and cities that are currently held by the party, and also stands a good chance of seizing Changhua County, Chiayi City, Ilan County, Miaoli County, Nantou County, Pingtung County and Taipei County.

Six KMT incumbents who are seeking re-election, including Chu Li-lun in Taoyuan County, Cheng Yung-chin in Hsinchu County, Lin Junq-tzer in Hsinchu City, Huang Chung-sheng in Taichung County, Jason Hu in Taichung City and Hsieh Shen-shan in Hualien County, have stable leads, according to pollsters.

In Keelung City, KMT incumbent Hsu Tsai-li is facing a strong challenge from Liu Wen-hsiung of the opposition People First Party -- the KMT's ally in the "pan-blue alliance" that has a similar support base to the KMT. Ma is scheduled to accompany Hsu to cast his vote Saturday in an effort to prevent "pan-blue" voters from dumping Hsu for Liu.

In Penghu County, KMT candidate Wang Chien-fa has had a distant lead over his Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) opponent, Chen Kuang-fu, since President Chen Shui-bian promoted his promise to cut the retirement benefits for civil servants, military personnel and teachers, according to Liao Feng-teh, head of the KMT's Organization and Development Committee.
The KMT has also a stable lead in Miaoli County, where the support rate for KMT candidate Liu Cheng-hung is significantly higher than that of other candidates, Liao said.

In Taipei County, KMT candidate Chou Hsi-wei appears to enjoy good prospects, but the race in that county is unpredictable because there is a large number of supporters of the "pan-green camp" who tend not to disclose their preferences in opinion polls, Liao said.

In addition, neutral voters are expected to be influenced in the wake of allegations by DPP candidate Luo Wen-jia that Chou was involved in a series of scandals, including abusing his privilege during his term as a Taiwan Provincial Assembly member in 1997 to obtain a NT$15 million loan from the Taiwan Business Bank, Liao said.

In Ilan County and Chiayi City, the KMT is in the lead in terms of its performance in opinion polls and in mobilizing its voters, and it will enhance the KMT's morale if the party is able to seize these two places, Liao said.
Also, he said, it is very likely that the KMT will win in Nantou County, where DPP candidate Tsai Huang-liang and independent candidate Lin Tzung-nan are splitting the support of "pan-green" voters.
Meanwhile, the races in Changhua County and Pingtung County are too close to call, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE TO MAINTAIN ORDER FOR ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: The National Police Administration (NPA) announced Friday that police will rigorously maintain order prior to and during Saturday's "three-in-one" elections.

With the ruling and opposition parties gearing up in the final hours prior to the elections for city and county chiefs, city and county councilors and village and township heads, the NPA officials said that they will be on alert, especially between Friday night and the closing of the polls Saturday afternoon.
They said they have arranged for police presence at polling stations nationwide.
Based on the principles of "law and neutrality, " they said they will not allow anyone to create disturbances through illegal assembly or marches.

Although they are local elections, the chairmen of both the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the main opposition Kuomintang have put their posts on line if their parties fail to win the elections, adding that they will try to get as many voters as possible out to support them.

Victory for the DPP would be keeping 10 seats, including the key Taipei county chief post out of the 23 up for grabs, while the KMT needs to win 11 seats. The DPP and the KMT have locked horns in several constituencies, including Taipei County -- which is the largest constituency in Taiwan with a population of 3.7 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: HAUL OF COUNTERFEIT MEDICINE SOLD ONLINE SEIZED

TEXT.P: A big haul of counterfeit medicine, including the prized weight-loss drug Reductil, intended for online sale in Taiwan, has been seized, the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) announced Friday.

CIB investigators, led by Taipei District Prosecutor Tai Tung-li, raided the homes of two men, surnamed Wu and Chen, in Taichung, central Taiwan and seized more than 5,000 tablets of counterfeit medicine.

The haul included l2,000 tablets of the anti-obesity medicine Reductil (Sibutramine) , 1,500 tablets of Viagra, 280 tablets of Cialis -- another drug for the treatment of erectile dysfunction -- and 1,600 other unknown pills.

The investigators learned that the medicine was counterfeited in China and smuggled into Taiwan by people returning from China, aimed for sale to Taiwan customers via online transactions, CIB officials said.

The police also learned that the drug smugglers have sold the counterfeit medicine at lower-than-normal prices. For example, they said, a 30-tablet pack of Reductil, worth NT$3,500 over the counter if it is authentic, was sold for only NT$1,000 online.
CIB officials called for the Taiwan public to be alert against counterfeit medicine in Web site dealings.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO RECRUIT ENGLISH TEACHERS IN OHIO
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Dec. 1 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Ministry of Education has signed a memorandum of cooperation with the state of Ohio under which the state government will help recruit teachers to teach English in Taiwan elementary schools, Taiwan officials posted in the United States said Thursday.

The Ohio state government will also recruit Taiwan teachers to teach Chinese in the state next year, according to Hsu Hui-wen, chief of the cultural affairs division of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Chicago.
Ohio is the second U.S. state after Indiana to establish an educational cooperation agreement with Taiwan.

Hsu said that according to the terms of the memorandum signed Nov. 29, Ohio's Department of Education will help post a notice detailing Taiwan's plan to recruit teachers, with 15 openings available in the initial stage.

Native English speakers with a bachelor's degree and teaching qualifications are eligible to apply for the positions and the Taiwan authorities will provide the successful candidates with flight tickets, accommodation, salary and health insurance, Hsu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC WELCOMES HONG KONG, CHINESE MEDIA TO BE STATIONED IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Taiwan welcomes media outlets headquartered in Hong Kong and China to be stationed here to help bolster exchanges across the Taiwan Strait and among overseas Chinese, according to Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu.
Wu made the remarks Thursday at a seminar in which he announced that the MAC had agreed to an application from the Hong Kong-based Wen Hwei Daily to cover news in Taiwan.

The MAC gave its approval on the grounds that only through across-the-board exchanges can people in Hong Kong and China gain a better understanding of the latest developments in Taiwan, Wu said, adding that Taiwan welcomes the Wen Hwei Daily to post reporters here as soon as possible, as well as other Chinese and Macau media groups.

Electronic media organizations from Hong Kong will also be permitted to be stationed in Taiwan at some point in the future, Wu said, noting that "the government will not deviate from this policy despite some delays at present."

The Wen Hwei Daily is expected to dispatch reporters to Taiwan starting from next year, newspaper executives said, expressing the hope that the newspaper will be able to provide more detailed and comprehensive reports about Taiwan to Chinese people in China, Hong Kong and the rest of the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONCERNED ABOUT 'THREE-IN-ONE' ELECTIONS IN TAIWAN: DIPLOMAT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 1 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The United States is concerned about Saturday's "three-in-one" elections in Taiwan and their possible impact on future political developments, Republic of China Representative to the United States David Lee said Thursday.

Although Saturday's elections are local level, Lee said that various senior U. S. officials from different agencies he has met recently have all asked about and shown keen interest in the polls. He noted that he will make a briefing to U. S. officials after ballot counting ends Saturday evening.
According to Lee, it is natural that the United States would care about major activities in Taiwan due to the long-term good and close relations between the two countries.

To the United States, the elections of city mayors and county magistrates, city and county councilors and village and township chiefs this weekend are a very important political event in Taiwan, Lee said, noting that American Institute in Taiwan officials have periodically reported the newest developments to Washington, while Washington has also tried to gain information through media reports.

U. S. officials are actually quite familiar with the election developments, Lee said. But he pointed out that they will maintain neutrality toward the elections and care only about whether the process is democratic and whether the results will influence the future political situation.

There will be more than 12,000 polling stations set up around the country for the elections, in which 23 city mayors and county magistrates, 901 city and county councilors, and 319 village and township chiefs will be elected.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for December moved up 49 points to close at 6,223, with 21,991 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for January moved up 55 points to end at 6,225, with 350 contracts traded, while March futures gained 51 points to finish at 6,220, with eight contracts traded. June futures moved up 45 points to close at 6,210, with seven contracts traded, while September futures moved up 68 points to close at 6,128, with five contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 6,174 for December, 6,170 for January, 6,169 for March, 6,165 for June and 6,060 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.

December TE futures moved up 3.65 points to close at 271.25, with 4,394 contracts traded, while January TE futures gained 3.7 points to finish at 271, with 63 contract transactions. March TE futures moved up four points to end at 270.8, with two contracts traded, while June futures moved up 2.7 points to close at 269.8, with one contract transaction.
No transactions were recorded for September.

December TF futures gained 8.4 points to finish at 894.6, with 2,791 contracts changing hands, while January TF futures moved up 8.6 points to end at 893.6, with 43 contracts traded. March TF futures moved up 5.6 points to close at 889.8, with one contract transaction.
No transactions were recorded for June and September.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG TO REPRESENT TAIWAN IN BID FOR 2011 WORLD UNIVERSITY GAMES

TEXT.P: A screening team of the National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports has selected Kaohsiung to represent Taiwan in the country's bid to host the 2011 World University Games.

Council officials said that one of the government's major policies is to bid to host international athletic meets, noting that Taipei has been awarded the right to host the 2009 Deaflympic Games for athletes with hearing impairment, and that Kaohsiung has already been awarded the right to host the 2009 World Games.

In the near future, they have set the goal of bidding to host the World University Games with the aim of accumulating more experience in sponsoring international games to achieve the eventual goals of bidding to host the 2018 Asian Games and the 2020 Olympic Games.

To select the city that best represents Taiwan, as well as taking into consideration the international level, profile and related software and hardware facilities of various cities, the council boiled the possible choices down to Taipei and Kaohsiung and asked the screening team to provide the council with its views.

The team was inaugurated Nov. 22, with Academia Sinica member Lo Tung-pi serving as convener and 12 members, including Huang Ta-chou, chairman of the Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee. The team reviewed proposals submitted by both cities and made on-site inspections before making its decision.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, dropping NT$0.033 to close at NT$33.530.
A total of US$898 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at NT$33.615 and fluctuated between NT$33.490 and NT$33.648.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CHIEF TO VISIT WASHINGTON, D.C.
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 1 (CNA) (By Olive Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu, Taiwan's top China policy planner, will arrive in Washington, D. C. Monday for a three-day visit.
Wu will meet U. S. government officials and think tank members to exchange opinions and discuss issues regarding the current state of cross-Taiwan Strait relations.

The MAC head is also slated to give a keynote speech Wednesday, titled Taiwanese Efforts for Peace and Stability across the Strait, at the Center for National Policy, which is a non-profit, non-partisan public policy organization based in the U. S. capital that is devoted to the transfer of ideas and information from experts to public officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: TEMPORARY PART-TIME JOBS INCREASE IN DECEMBER

TEXT.P: A total of 25,000 temporary part-time positions were available online as of the beginning of December, which is 40 percent more than the same time last year, officials at the online employment service provider 104 Job Bank said Friday.
Opportunities for temporary part-time jobs have increased because a lot of business activities are being held in December ahead of the arrival of Christmas and New Year, the officials said.

One of these activities is a computer show set to open Dec. 3, which will require a large number of temporary salespeople. Most of these positions offer an hourly wage of NT$85 to NT$100, while others offer a daily wage of NT$1,000, they said.
Also on demand are models who will be responsible for warming up the atmosphere at the exhibition, they said, adding that such positions usually offer NT$1,500 to NT$6,000 per day.

According to tallies by the job bank, the industries in which most part-time positions are available are restaurant services (18 percent), schools and educational institutions (14.8 percent) and the retail sector (13 percent).
With the approach of Christmas, there are also advertisements for men to dress up as Santa Claus and for people who are good at decorating showcases, according to the tallies.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: European Central Bank raises interest rate to 2.25%.
The governing counil of the European Central Bank decided Thursday to increase the minimum bid rate on main refinancing operations of the Eurosystem by 0.25 percentage point to 2.25 percent starting from the operation to be settled on Dec. 6.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER SILENT ON WAFER FOUNDRY INVESTMENT IN CHINA

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh refused Friday to deny or confirm news reports that her ministry will allow two more local wafer foundries to invest in China this month.

Asked to comment on local newspaper reports that a panel authorized to review local wafer foundries' overseas investment plans is set to meet by the end of this month to give the nod to Powerchip Semiconductor Corporation (PSC) and ProMOS Technologies to invest in China, the minister said only that "the panel will be asked to meet when the time is ripe."
The Taiwan authorities have decided to allow three local wafer manufacturers to relocate outdated equipment to China to continue producing wafers there.
Thus far, only United Microelectronics Corp. has applied and been given permission to produce eight-inch wafers in China, while PSC and ProMOS have submitted applications and are awaiting approval.

Citing the current regulations, Ho said local wafer manufacturers that have invested in wafer fabs to produce 12-inch wafers in Taiwan can venture into the China six months after its local 12-inch wafer fabs have come on stream.
"The Ministry of Economic Affairs will not stop local businessmen from breaking into the Chinese market as long as they continue investing in Taiwan," the minister said.
In a related development Friday, PSC Chairman Frank Huang said his company is in no hurry to invest in China.

Huang said the government's policy of allowing local foundries producing eight-inch wafer with 0.25 um technology to relocate to China will not be of much benefit in any case, as only wafers produced with 0.18 um technology can survive in the Chinese market.

Claiming that Taiwan's wafer fabs are about five years ahead of their Chinese counterparts in terms of technology, Huang said PSC will wait until the government lifts restrictions on wafers using 0.18 um technology to invest in China even if it is given the green light.

Warning that the window of chance is narrow for local wafer manufacturers, Huang predicted the technological edge of 0.18 um will be closed in China within three years, by which time only 0.15 um technology will be able to survive.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH PROPOSES STRICTER LAWS ON TRADE IN FOOD PRODUCTS

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) has recently completed a proposed amendment to the laws concerning food product management in an effort to stop dishonest food producers from selling substandard food that is hazardous to health.
The problem of food safety is a perennial concern among consumers because of frequent news reports exposing the sale of dangerous food such as pork from sick hogs and contaminated cooked eggs.

In the proposed amendment, punishments for dishonest food businesses are more strict, allowing health authorities to ban problematic goods from being traded as soon as they are found to contain toxic or hazardous substance, or to carry no descriptions or incomplete descriptions of their contents.
Fines for health foods businesses that make false claims that their products have curative effects would also be raised from the existing level of NT$60,000-NT$300,000 to NT$200,000-NT$1 million.
Furthermore, businesses who are discovered to have produced and marketed hazardous food products will be stripped of their business certificates.

DOH Director-General of Food Sanitation Chen Lu-hung said Friday that so far, health authorities are only allowed to ask businesses to recall problematic food products from the market and ask them to improve. However, during the period of time allowed for improvement, consumers can still buy the products, he explained.
The amended laws can seal this loophole and give the authorities the power to confiscate suspect products and prevent them from entering the market until they are proved safe, Chen said.
The draft bill will be delivered to the Legislative Yuan for review in the near future, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO FACE CONSEQUENCES IF PFP CANDIDATE LOSES IN KEELUNG: PFP HEAD

TEXT.P: A chink is appearing the armor of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) , with PFP Chairman James Soong making a thinly veiled threat Friday that the KMT will have to fend for itself in the legislature if the PFP candidate for Keelung mayor is defeated in the Dec. 3 elections.

PFP candidate Liu Wen-hsiung is running for mayor of the port city of Keelung against KMT candidate Hsu Tsai-li, who is the incumbent mayor, and opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union candidate Chen Chien-min.

The KMT refused to give up fielding its own candidate, despite repeated requests from the PFP that the KMT should support the PFP candidate, who has a good chance of winning the election. KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said in an interview with ETTV that there is a "practical difficulty" for him to support the PFP candidate instead of the candidate from his own party.

Speaking in a rally in Keelung to boost Liu's campaign, Soong warned that if the incumbent Keelung mayor is re-elected, his close association with the "black gold" groups could become an obstacle in the KMT's future plan to crack down on corruption and crime.
Soong also claimed that he will go into seclusion or even overseas to reflect on what he did wrong in the elections if Liu is not elected as Keelung mayor.

The PFP chairman warned that in the event of Liu's defeat, the KMT, as the second-largest party in the legislature, will have to face the consequences of how to deal with the largest party -- the ruling Democratic Progressive Party -- without the assistance of the PFP. (Han Nai-kuo)

DOC.HEADLINE: ELECTION HOPEFULS HAVE TO ACHIEVE VOTE THRESHOLD TO BE ELECTED: CEC

TEXT.P: The Central Election Commission (CEC) said Friday that ballots garnered by uncontested candidates in Saturday's "three-in-one" elections for city and county chiefs, city and county councilors and village and township heads will have to achieve a certain threshold before the candidate can be counted as having been elected.

CEC spokesman Teng Tien-you noted that in 14 cities and counties where councilor candidates are running without any rivals and in 31 villages and townships where the candidates are running uncontested, the candidates will still have to get a certain number of ballots before they can claim victory.

He said that according to the Election and Recall Law, city and county councilor hopefuls will have to get at least 10 percent of the votes based on the total number of elected officials divided by the total number of the electorate in the constituency.
In the township and village elections, the hopefuls will have to get at least 20 percent of the electorate before claiming victory.

With some legislators leaving the legislature to run for posts as city or county chiefs in the election, the law also stipulates that if the legislators cannot complete their terms and if more than half of the legislative seats in a constituency are left vacant, the CEC will hold by-elections.

The CEC also updated the latest count of the "three-in-one" elections, listing 76 hopefuls running for city and county chief positions, 1,689 aspirants (one short of the original count 1,690) running for city and country council posts, and 788 (compared with the original 786) running for township and village chief positions.
The elected winners of the 23 cities and counties will be inaugurated Dec. 20, while the elected city and county councilors and village and township chiefs will be inaugurated March 1, 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT INFORMATION COMMUNICATION SYMPOSIUM TO OPEN DEC. 6

TEXT.P: A cross-strait symposium on digital television and information communications will be held in Taipei Dec. 6-7, with executive officials of Chinese broadcasting business groups invited to attend the event, said an official of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) on Friday.

MAC Vice Chairman Liu Te-shun said the symposium, to be hosted by the Management Committee of the Chinese Development Fund under the council, is organized to boost understanding on the current state of digital video industries of Taiwan and China, and to further promote cross-strait cooperation and exchanges in the field.

High-rank managers of influential broadcasting companies in major Chinese cities including Beijing, Shanghai and Qingdao, as well as scholars, have been invited to join the two-day discussions, Liu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHANG CHUN-HSIUNG TO REMAIN SEF CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chang Chun-hsiung will stay on as chairman to lead the semi-official organization after being elected to serve a new term at the post in a SEF board meeting Friday.

Michael You, Hsui Sheng-fa and Chang Chun-hung were also elected by board members and supervisors to continue serving as SEF vice chairmen. Sun Yun-suan, a much-respected former premier, also gained overwhelming support to continue serving as the SEF's honorary chairman. Chang Chun-hsiung also nominated You to double as SEF secretary-general during the meeting.

Chang Chun-hsiung asked SEF board members and supervisors to help revive the NT$100 million 2006 budget, which was allocated by the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) for the SEF but was withheld by legislators.

Lawmakers at the Home Affairs Committee cut much of the MAC's budget for next year because of discontent over what they called the MAC's inability to build constructive cross-Taiwan Strait ties. The MAC oversees SEF, which handles Taiwan-China exchanges in the absence of official contacts between the two sides.

Chang Chun-hsiung promised to do his best to advocate favorable and mutually beneficial dealings between Taiwan and China and called for the opening of systematic negotiations between the SEF and the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait to better maintain cross-strait peace, stability and exchanges.

In a related development, the SEF chairman will preside over the establishment of a legal counselling group Monday, which will provide voluntary services for Taiwan businessmen with operations in China.

The 23-member voluntary legal services group will be the third to be set up by the SEF to aid China-based Taiwan business people, following the creation of a Taiwan businessmen's service center in August and a financial consultation advisory group in September.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEARCH OF NANTOU COUNTY MAGISTRATE OFFICE JUSTIFIED: PROSECUTORS
DOC.DATELINE: Nanou County, central Taiwan, Dec. 2 (CNA) (By Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: Prosecutors' search of the office of the Nantou County magistrate Thursday in connection with allegations of vote-buying has rubbed incumbent Magistrate Lin Tsung-nan the wrong way, and has even upset one of his rivals running for the post.
Lin, of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), is running without the blessing of the party against DPP-nominated candidate Tsai Huang-lang and opposition Kuomintang candidate Li Chao-ching.

At a news conference in the magistrate's office Friday, a spokesman for Lin's camp charged that the search of the magistrate's office and six other locations, along with the questioning of 20 of Lin's associates by the public prosecutors only two days before the Dec. 3 election were obviously meant to make Lin lose the election.

Claiming that the actions of the prosecutors were in violation of the nation's Public Officials Election and Recall Law, the spokesman said that Lin's camp is considering filing a lawsuit against the Nantou County's Public Prosecutors' Office.
Meanwhile, the rival Tsai camp also blamed the prosecutors for searching Lin's office and campaign headquarters at such a sensitive time.
A spokesman for Tsai's camp expressed concern that the prosecutors' actions would create too much sympathy among voters at Tsai's expense.

Wu Tso-yen, chief prosecutor of Nantou County, explained that the actions taken by the prosecutors Thursday were all related to charges of vote-buying and allegations that voter support was being influenced through offers to award contracts for construction projects.
He said these actions could not wait until after the election and stressed that the investigations had nothing to do with any political force and were not connected with Lin's party affiliation.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA TO LAUNCH PUBLICITY DRIVE ON GARBAGE SEPARATION POLICY

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) will launch a publicity drive in December in preparation for the nationwide implementation of a garbage separation policy Jan. 1, officials said Friday.

The policy, which has been enforced in 10 cities and counties islandwide since the beginning of this year, requires the public to sort their garbage into three categories -- ordinary garbage, recyclables and food scraps -- before taking it out to the garbage truck.
Garbage that is not properly separated will be rejected, with offenders facing a fine of NT$1,200 to NT$6,000. The policy is set to expand to all 25 cities and counties nationwide next year.

According to Chang Hsu-chang, a section chief at the EPA's Department of Waste Management, local environmental protection staff will open garbage bags for inspection to see if the rules are being followed by the public.
During the first three months of the policy's implementation, offenders will not be fined but will be given advice and told to separate their garbage properly, Chang said.
Those who ignore the advice will be fined, he said.

In the 10 cities where the policy has been implemented, the amount of garbage in the first 10 months of this year decreased 10 percent compared with the same period of last year, Chang noted. While the amount of recyclables rose by 30 percent, the amount of food scraps increased by 65 percent, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: VOTER TURNOUT EXPECTED NOT TO FALL BELOW 66 PERCENT: CEC CHIEF

TEXT.P: Voter turnout for the hotly contested local government chiefs elections is not expected to fall below the level recorded in the preceding elections four years ago, Central Election Commission (CEC) Chairman Chang Cheng-hsiung said Friday.

Chang made the remarks while presiding over a vote-counting rehearsal at the CEC's computer operations center on the eve of the "three-in-one" elections for city mayors/county magistrates, city/county councilors and township/village chiefs.

Vote-counting in local-level elections has traditionally been handled by the election commission in each city and county. This time around, Chang said the CEC has been involved in overall planning with a view to upgrading efficiency.
As to voter turnout, Chang was reluctant to make a concrete forecast. He instead said that the last city mayor/county magistrate elections saw a 66 percent voter turnout.

"This time around, with three local elections taking place simultaneously and polls in many constituencies deadlocked, those who originally did not plan to vote may change their minds and go to the polls. Against this backdrop, I assume that voter turnout will not be below 66 percent," Chang said.

According to Chang, 12,081 polling stations have been set up around the country with the exception of the Taipei and Kaohsiung special municipalities where no elections will be held. The polling stations will be staffed by 162,811 workers.

After the voting ends at 4 p.m. Saturday, Chang said vote counting will proceed in the following order: city mayors/county magistrates, city/county councilors, and township/village chiefs. If the polling stations are spacious enough, vote counting for city/county chiefs and councilors will take place simultaneously.
Chang said ballots cast into the wrong boxes will remain valid. If all goes well, Chang said vote counting will be completed by 10 p.m. Saturday.
According to the CEC tallies, 13,587,635 citizens are eligible to vote in the city mayor/county magistrate elections.

For the township/village chief elections, the number of eligible voters stands at 11,484,871. Meanwhile, 13,281,916 citizens are eligible to vote in regional elections for city/county councilors, 168,024 people are eligible to vote for urban aboriginal city/county council seats and 112,979 people are eligible to vote for mountainous aboriginal city/county council seats.
Except for the nation's two largest municipalities -- Taipei and Kaohsiung -- all other local government top posts are up for grabs, including the two frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu.
A total of 76 hopefuls are vying for city and county chief posts, 1,689 aspirants for city and country council seats and 788 for township and village chief positions.
The elected five city mayors and 18 county magistrates will be sworn in Dec. 20, while the elected city and county councilors and village and township chiefs will not take office until March 1, 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HELPS PANAMA BUILD BETTER TESTING FACILITIES FOR FRUIT
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Dec. 2 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is helping Panama improve its food quality and safety by transferring technology and know-how on rapid inspection of vegetables and fruits for pesticides, a ROC technical mission member in the country said Thursday.

A pioneer facility capable of conducting efficient tests on pesticide toxicity and giving results in minutes, rather than days or weeks, was inaugurated Thursday at the central vegetable and fruit market in Panama City.
Training programs for local people to learn how to use the new facilities are underway. The testing station was built under the assistance of a technical mission from Taiwan.
Staff at the station will spend about a year making a nationwide survey of the use of pesticides and insecticides on crops.
Based on the results, the Taiwan mission will decide whether or not to set up more testing stations in other markets around Panama.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN OBSERVERS SAY MEDIA KEYING ON NEGATIVE ELECTION NEWS: DPP

TEXT.P: Foreign election observers invited by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to Taiwan say that local media spends too much time reporting negative aspects of campaigning and should work harder to verify stories before publishing or broadcasting them, Hsieh Huai-hui, deputy director of the DPP's International Affairs Department, said Friday.
Taiwan is holding "three-in-one" elections for local chiefs on Dec. 3 and there are about 20 delegations from various nations currently on the island to observe the voting process.
The 100 or so journalists and academics from the delegations have been mostly looking at how hopefuls canvass for votes and visiting campaign headquarters.

"Some of the people who the DPP invited to the island have said that Taiwanese media has too much leeway in its reporting and that they over-report allegations of misconduct and scandals by candidates. They said that the media here should remember that they are responsible for what they do and must verify their information, " Hsieh said.

Echoing the observers' views, Su Chi, a main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) lawmaker, said that negative campaigning, where people make ad hominem remarks at each other, is a sign of the degradation of democracy in Taiwan.
On the other hand, Hsieh noted that most delegation members were surprised and curious at the liberal atmosphere surrounding the campaigning in Taiwan.

"Some of them come from less-democratized countries, which explains why they are astonished at the very noisy and animated evening rallies organized in the run-up to the elections, and the way candidates go after each other," Hsieh said.

The election observers have been invited to Taiwan by a number of organizations, including the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Mainland Affairs Council, the DPP and civilian parties such as the Democratic Pacific Union (DPU).

Among the delegations, the one invited by the DPU, is the biggest with more than 20 members. The one invited by the DPP has 16 members made up of scholars and journalists from Japan, South Korea, the Philippines, Cambodia, Sri Lanka, Thailand, Indonesia and Singapore.
(By Taijing Wu) ENITEM/mw

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN MAKES FRESH PROMISES TO VOTERS IN ILAN COUNTY
DOC.DATELINE: Ilan County, northern Taiwan, Dec. 2 (CNA) (By Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian pledged Friday that he would speed up three major construction projects in Ilan County if Chen Ding-nan, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) candidate, is elected Ilan County magistrate in the Dec. 3 election.

Speaking at a rally to boost Chen Ding-nan's campaign, the president said the central government fully supports Ilan County's plans to build a science park, elevate the railway in Ilan City, and set up a marine biology science and technology park.

He promised that in the first year after Chen Ding-nan becomes county magistrate, the plan to build the science park will be finalized, followed by the inauguration of the railway elevation project in the second year, and the completion of the groundwork for the marine biology science and technology park in the third year.

Chen Ding-nan, who served two terms as Ilan County magistrate from 1981 to 1989 and was minister of justice from May 2000 to February 2005, is running against opposition Kuomintang candidate Lu Kuo-hua and an independent.

The DPP views Ilan County as its "democratic holy land" where the DPP should remain in power. However, opinion polls over the past two months show that Chen Ding-nan is slightly behind Lu in popularity.

The election battle has become so close that this is President Chen's third visit to Ilan County in a week. The DPP's desperation has become more apparent with the president's promise to speed up the county's three major construction projects on the condition of Chen Ding-nan being elected.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Profusion of Rebel Groups Helps Them Survive in Iraq
Iraqi and American officials in Iraq say the single most important fact about the insurgency is that it consists not of a few groups but of dozens, possibly as many as 100. And it is not, as often depicted, a coherent organization whose members dutifully carry out orders from above but a far-flung collection of smaller groups that often act on their own or come together for a single attack, the officials say. Each is believed to have its own leader and is free to act on its own. Highly visible groups like Al Qaeda, Ansar al Sunna and the Victorious Army Group appear to act as fronts, the Iraqis and the Americans say, providing money, general direction and expertise to the smaller groups, but often taking responsibility for their attacks by broadcasting them across the globe.
Wall Street Journal: Strained Relations; With Israel Gone, Election Splinters A Family in Gaza
When Beit Lahia in Gaza held elections in May, Mohammed Hamouda and his son, Ahmed, ran for very different reasons. In the end, they both won seats on the 13-member city council. But the bruising campaign tore apart a relationship already shaken by violence and Ahmed Hamouda's embrace of Hamas. The rift in the Hamouda family reflects a broader problem for the Palestinians. When Israel quit the Gaza Strip this summer, it did more than relinquish land to the Palestinians. The historic move also uncorked conflicts lurking just below the surface of Palestinian society. Before the withdrawal, these religious, political and economic divisions had been overshadowed by a much more powerful force: enmity toward Israel. Now in Gaza, and to a lesser extent in the West Bank, powerful businessmen are scrambling for control of the real-estate market. Crime and street violence is on the rise. Meanwhile, the Fatah-run Palestinian Authority is struggling to rein in armed groups belonging to religious extremists and rival factions out to settle scores.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP HEAVYWEIGHTS PULL OUT ALL THE STOPS ON EVE OF CRITICAL ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) heavyweights from President Chen Shui-bian on down pulled out all the stops to canvass voters Friday with the "three-in-one" elections entering the home stretch.

More than 13 million eligible voters from around the country except for those in Taipei and Kaohsiung special municipalities have the chance to go to the polls Saturday to elect city mayors/county magistrates, city/county councilors and township/village chiefs.

DPP political stars have focused their energies on the city/county chief elections because the outcome could provide momentum for the winning party ahead of the next legislative and presidential elections.

On the eve of the elections, President Chen continued shuttling around several critical constituencies, including Taipei County, Changhua County, Taichung County, Taichung City, Ilan County and Chiayi City.

Vice President Annette Lu, accompanied by Cheng Pao-ching, the DPP standard-bearer for the Taoyuan County magistrateship, went on a door-to-door vote-canvassing tour in the northern county early in the morning and joined street parades in Yunlin, Changhua and Taichung counties and Taichung City to solicit support for DPP candidates.

In the face of the opposition camp's assiduous efforts to draw attention to a major scandal involving the Kaohsiung mass rapid transit system project, the DPP has been fighting a tough battle from the beginning of the campaigning. Many media opinion polls have shown the DPP lagging the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) in more than half the constituencies, although one-quarter of voters remain undecided.

Through concerted efforts by all DPP politicians, party sources said, the prospects have improved in several constituencies. The party is striving to retain its current grip on the 10 mayoral and magistrate seats, the sources said, adding that the party's top goal is to win more than half of the 23 top local government posts up for grabs.
DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang vowed early Friday to resign if the DPP failed to secure 10 seats in Saturday's local elections.

"If the DPP can't take 10 seats in tomorrow's elections, it will be a serious setback...I will resign to take responsibility, " Su told reporters in Taipei County, the nation's most populous constituency, which is traditionally viewed as a testing ground for the presidential election.
"As a former Taipei County magistrate, I would also step down if Luo Wen-jia fails to win, " he said. The DPP's Luo is in a tight race against the KMT's Chou Hsi-wei for magistrate.
Su accompanied Luo on door-to-door vote-canvassing tours around Taipei County all day long and attended two large-scale campaign rallies in the evening.

Premier Frank Hsieh led his Cabinet team to stump for the DPP standard-bearer in the offshore Penghu County in the morning, joined street parades in the two southern counties of Pingtung and Kaohsiung in the afternoon to woo voters for the DPP candidates and attended a campaign rally in Tainan City before returning to Taipei to take part in Luo's last pre-election campaign rally in Taipei County.

According to a DPP election-eve assessment, the party enjoys stable leads in seven constituencies -- Changhua County, Yunlin County, Chiayi County, Tainan County, Tainan City, Kaohsiung County and Pingtung County -- while running neck and neck with the opposition KMT in six constituencies -- Ilan County, Taipei county, Miaoli County, Nantou County, Chiayi City and Penghu County.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR DECEMBER 3 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Saturday, Dec. 3:
08:15, Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun will cast his ballot for the Ilan County magistrate election at the county's No. 90 polling station.
10:20, Premier Frank Hsieh will attend the opening ceremony for the 2005 Information Month activities at the Taipei World Trade Center.
14:00, Vice President Annette Lu will receive a Russian State Duma delegation being here to observe the "three-in-one" elections.
15:00, Vice President Lu will hold an informal meeting with a Democratic Pacific Union delegation being here to observe the "three-in-one" elections.
17:00, Premier Frank Hsieh will make an inspection tour of the Central Election Commission's computer vote-counting center.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOJ HAILS ACHIEVEMENTS IN FIGHT AGAINST ELECTION BRIBERY

TEXT.P: Prosecution authorities have indicted a record number of 954 people allegedly involved in 320 suspected vote-buying cases in run-up to the "three-in-one" elections, the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) said Friday.
"Both figures are new records in the history of our campaign against election bribery," an MOJ official said.

Law enforcement authorities began the deployment against vote-buying in June, the official said, adding that as of Friday afternoon, prosecutor's offices around the country received 11,753 pieces of information about election bribery charges related with the Dec. 3 elections for city mayors/county magistrates, city/county councilors and township/village chief.
Suspects in 3,131 of those cases were questioned and 954 suspects in 320 charges have so far been indicted, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Dec. 3, or the third day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1808: Madrid surrenders to French forces led by Napoleon Bonaparte.
1810: Britain captures the island of Mauritius from France.
1818: Illinois becomes the 21st state of the United States.
1828: John Quincy Adams loses the U.S. presidential election to his arch-rival Andrew Jackson.
1894: Robert Louis Stevenson, Scottish writer of essays, poetry and novels, dies at the age of 44. He authored "Treasure Island," "The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde" and "Kidnapped."
1901: American film producer and film animator Walt Disney is born. He created such immortals as Mickey Mouse and Donald Duck.
1943: The Joint Declaration of the Cairo Conference is issued simultaneously in Chungking, Washington and London.
1944: U.S. forces advance across the Saar River in Germany during World War II.
1948: Republic of China government troops evacuate Hsuchow in eastern China.
1958: Dutch businesses are nationalized in Indonesia.
1960: Chou Tao-chi graduates from National Chengchi University and becomes the first student to earn a national doctorate in the Republic of China.
1966: The Kaohsiung Export Processing Zone is inaugurated.
1966: Macau imposes a curfew after massive riots allegedly incited by the Communist Chinese.
1967: South African surgeon Dr. Christiaan Barnard successfully performs a human heart transplant, the first of its kind in the world.
1971: Pakistani planes attack northwest India in a dispute over Kashmir. India responds by declaring a state of emergency.
1975: Communists take control of Laos, declare an end to the 600-year-old monarchy and set up the People's Democratic Republic of Laos.
1976: Rear Adm. James H. Morris, commander of the amphibious forces of the U.S. 7th Fleet, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1983: Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang (KMT) wins a landslide victory in supplementary parliamentary elections. The KMT captures 62 of 71 seats up for grabs in the Legislative Yuan. The opposition wins six seats and independents take three.
1989: U.S. President George Bush and Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev end a summit meeting on Malta in the Mediterranean Sea, signaling the end of the Cold War and entry into a new era of peace and cooperation.
1992: Millions of gallons of crude oil spill into the sea off the coast of La Coruna, Spain, threatening ecological disaster.
1993: Ukraine and the United States fail to resolve a dispute over Ukraine's stockpile of some 1,000 long-range nuclear warheads.
1994: The first popular elections for the governor of Taiwan Province and the mayors of Taipei and Kaohsiung municipalities are held. James C.Y. Soong is elected governor of Taiwan. Chen Shui-bian and Wu Den-yih win the mayorships of Taipei and Kaohsiung, respectively.
1995: Chun Doo Hwan, former president of South Korea, is arrested on charges of military rebellion stemming from a 1979 coup and a later massacre of civilians by the army.
1997: South Korea signs a letter of intent with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) for a loan of US$57 billion, the largest of its kind ever provided by the IMF, to help South Korea get through its financial crisis.
1999: Visiting Malawian President Bakili Muluzi and his ROC counterpart Lee Teng-hui sign a communique reconfirming the friendship between their two countries.
2000: Francis Ng wins the "Best Leading Actor Award," Maggie Cheung wins the "Best Leading Actress Award," and To Kei-Fung wins the "Best Director Award" at the 2000 Golden Horse Awards.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian says his party's dramatic win in legislative elections will not change his commitment to improving relations across the Taiwan Strait.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian says that he is willing to share political power and resources with other political parties on the basis of mutual respect, to promote political stability, national identity and democratic reform.
Motse's lesson of the day: "We are certain that heaven desires to have men love and benefit one another and abominates to have them hate and harm one another."

Manila Bulletin: GMA appeals to critics anew
Malacanang yesterday declared that the worst of the political crisis hounding the Arroyo administration is finally over as it appealed anew to the opposition groups to tone down the political noise, especially during the forthcoming Christmas season.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Military court finds retired general guilty

The Japan Times: State mulls insurancde for faulty condos
The Land, Infrastructure and Transport Ministry of Japan is consideringa new insurance plan that would compensate people with defective condominiums, ministry officials said Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN VOTERS GO TO POLLS TO ELECT LOCAL CHIEFS AND COUNCILORS

TEXT.P: More than 10 million eligible voters are expected to cast their ballots in the "three-in-one" local elections Saturday in Taiwan's 21 counties, in addition to the outlying island county of Penghu and the two islands of Kinmen and Matsu.
The elections start at 8 a.m. and will close at 4 p.m. Vote tabulations are expected by around 10 p.m. the same day.
According to the Central Election Commission (CEC), voter turnout is expected to be better than the 66 percent registered in the previous mayor and magistrate elections.
There will be more than 12,000 voting booths and the CEC has mobilized more than 162,800 election workers.
Voters will elect 23 mayors and magistrates, along with 901 city and county councillors as well as 319 township chiefs.

Calling for voters to fulfill their obligations, the CEC also requested that they respect the election law. The National Police Administration will do all it can to prevent unlawful behavior during the elections.
The elected mayors and magistrates will assume their posts Dec. 20, while those who win the other two elections will be sworn in March 1 next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT WILL WIN 11 SEATS IN MAYOR, MAGISTRATE ELECTIONS: WANG JIN-PYNG

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan speaker Wang Jin-pyng, a former Kuomintang (KMT) vice chairman, said it should be no problem for the party to win at least 11 posts in Saturday's mayor and magistrate elections.
Wang made the comments after voting in Kaohsiung County.

The "three-in-one" elections, which will elect 23 mayors and magistrates as well as 901 city and county councillors and 319 township chiefs, are being held in 21 counties, plus the outlying island county of Penghu and the two islands of Kinmen and Matsu.

Pointing out that the KMT candidates are taking stable leads into several of the county's elections, including Keelung, Taoyuan, Taichung and Hualien, Wang said, "The KMT will have no problem winning 11 mayor and magistrate seats."

He also predicted that the KMT will claim victory in the local councilor and township chief elections as the party has always had a big advantage over the other political parties from grassroots supporters.

Nevertheless, Wang warned that the KMT would have to be reform-minded in the future, saying, "Only by doing so, can the party give itself a 'fresh spirit' and adequately respond to the people's needs. Winning the 2008 presidential election is the KMT's top priority."

Asked whether KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou's Thursday pledge to step down from his post if his party cannot win more than half of the seats in the mayor and magistrate elections would affect the decision of voters, Wang said that the pledge might help consolidate the supporters of the "pan-blue alliance" and make an impact on the candidates of the People First Party, the KMT's ally.

As to whether he will run for the KMT chairmanship if Ma does step down, Wang said that it is quite out of the question for him to take this issue into consideration since "this problem does not exist now and I needn't think about the issue."
"Realizing that current developments favor the KMT, all party members should work together to win the elections, " he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'RIGHT TIME' IS KEY FOR TAIWAN-U.S. FTA: U.S. OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 2 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A free trade agreement (FTA) between Taiwan and the United States would have to come at the "right time, " a high-ranking U.S. trade official said on Friday.

Moreover, if Taiwan could be more supportive of World Trade Organization (WTO) talks on controversial agricultural issues, it might expect progress on the FTA issue, Timothy Stratford, assistant U.S. trade representative for China affairs, said in a speech at a lunch meeting of members of the U.S.-Taiwan Business Council in the U.S. capital.

Stratford said he will visit Taiwan at the beginning of next year to attend the already-postponed Taiwan-U.S. trade and investment framework agreement (TIFA) meeting, which was originally scheduled to take place in November. Asked whether or not talks at the vice-ministerial, technical-level TIFA meeting will touch the issues concerning preliminary Taiwan-U.S. FTA negotiations, Stratford said "no," adding that "the two are different."
Stratford explained that an FTA involves many factors, the most decisive being the "right time."
The U.S. side hopes Taiwan can back U.S. proposals to lower tariffs on agricultural products and decrease subsidies when it attends the WTO negotiations.
The support -- meaning Taiwan has to open further to imports of agricultural products -- is "very important" because it is "the key factor" for a Taiwan-U.S. FTA to see progress, Stratford stressed.
Asked whether there is a plan for the opening of FTA talks, the U.S. official said that "so far, no schedule has been set."

DOC.HEADLINE: SPAINISH OFFICIAL ATTENDS TAIPEI SYMPOSIUM ON WIND ENERGY
DOC.DATELINE: Madrid, Dec. 2 (CNA) (By Margarinta Chang & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan-Spain cooperation on the development of wind energy could be boosted with the participation of a Spanish official in charge of energy affairs at a Taipei wind energy symposium, an official of Taiwan's representative office to Spain said Friday.

Hugo Lucas Porta of the Spanish Institute for the Diversification and Saving of Energy is now in Taiwan for the one-day symposium, which was held Friday under the sponsorship of Taiwan's Industrial Technology Research Institute.

Jaime M.S. Chen, director of the representative office's economic division, said that Spain enjoys the world's second-largest capacity for wind power generation, behind Germany. Taiwan is delighted to have an expert from Spain in the field attending the wind energy event in Taipei, he noted.
During his stay in Taiwan, Porta is also scheduled to visit the Bureau of Energy under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: UPCOMING TIFA MEETING NOT LINKED WITH FTA ISSUE: U.S. TRADE OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 2 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: A high-ranking U.S. trade official said Friday that a Taiwan-U.S. Trade and Investment Framework Agreement (TIFA) meeting set to be held in Taipei next month will not touch on issues related to free trade agreement talks between the two countries.
Timothy Stratford, assistant trade representative for East Asia affairs, made the remarks after attending a luncheon gathering with members of the U.S.-Taiwan Business Council in the U.S. capital.
He also said the same day that the vice minister and technical-level TIFA meeting and FTA talks are "two separate issues."
The TIFA meeting, which was scheduled to be held last month in Taipei, was postponed due to personnel reshuffle issues at the U.S. Trade Representative Office.
According to Stratford, issues to be discussed in the upcoming TIFA meeting will include intellectual property rights, telecommunications and pharmaceuticals.

As Taiwan had made an important concession on relevant issues at last year's TIFA meeting to the United States, the official said that Washington hopes that the upcoming meeting will also be able to bring about some good results.

Taiwan promised last year to further open its telecommunications market and that move has made the United States remove the island from the "priority Watch List" of its Special 301 provision of the Trade Act and instead, place it on the "Watch list."

It is generally believed by some U.S. lawmakers that reaching an accord with the United States on the TIFA by reducing some trade barriers in such sectors as telecommunications, pharmaceuticals, financial services, electronics and agriculture is the first step for Taipei to establish free trade exchanges between the two countries.

Opposition Union leader Romano Prodi said Friday at a rally of the Leftist Democratic Party in Firenze that the union will become the majority and win the next general elections. The Leftist Demoratic Party is the largest of the political parties that form the opposition union.
