Although the sign-up period for the new Medicare prescription drug benefit is barely two weeks old, pressure is mounting in Congress to extend it so that senior citizens can have more time to understand a program many find dauntingly complex.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE APT TO USE CREDIT CARDS OVERSEAS

TEXT.P: Seventy-six percent of Taiwanese people often use credit cards when they are traveling abroad, according to the report by a major credit card company.

Taiwanese made far more overseas trips last year than they had since 1989 and in the first 10 months of this year, the number hit 7.09 million, representing a 6.9 percent growth over the level of the same period last year, the report said.

Credit card use by Taiwanese travelers in foreign countries was the third-largest in the Asia-Pacific region, behind the 91 percent by Japanese and the 82 percent by New Zealanders. Statistics show that most Asian women travel to foreign countries to shop, with Hong Kong their most favorite destination and Singapore coming second.

DOC.HEADLINE: TEXT MESSAGE OF HU GOING TO HOSPITAL FROM OVERSEAS CELL PHONES

TEXT.P: Taichung police said Saturday that the text message alleging Taichung Mayor Jason Hu was rushed to hospital due to serious illness was sent from cellular phones registered in the Philippines.
Police made the announcement after some Taichung residents received the text message at around 4 a.m. earlier in the day.
Hu, who is seeking another term in Saturday's election, voted in the central Taiwan city as scheduled, clearly putting to rest speculation about his health.

According to initial investigations, police said the text message was sent from cell phones registered in the Philippines and that there were at least two sources of the transmission, with one number being 639-163-946-821.

Police said that if the Filipino-registered cell phone was brought to Taiwan to send the text message, then it would be easier to track down, but if the text message was sent from the Philippines or via the Internet, then it will be hard to trace.

Lin Chin-hsin, a lawmaker of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) as well as a practicing medical doctor, together with 11 other doctors, recently revealed what they said were Hu's medical records during a news conference. Hu has twice had mild strokes. The doctors were attempting to show that Hu might not be healthy enough to serve another term. Lin and the 11 doctors are now being investigated whether they violated their ethical code of not infringing upon a patient's privacy by revealing his medical records.

Hu, who is generally believed to be ahead of his rival, Lin Chia-lung, a DPP candidate for the same post, took the matter in stride, saying tongue-in-cheek that he would live to be 95 and would invite President Chen Shui-bian to his birthday party then, although he wasn't sure if Chen would still be alive.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN DEFENDS HIS PRESENCE AT KEELUNG POLLING STATION

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou defended his presence at a polling station in the northern port city of Keelung Saturday, saying that he was merely accompanying his friend -- Keelung Mayor Hsu Tsai-li, who is seeking reelection -- and did not violate any law.

Ma went to Keelung early Saturday morning and walked with Hsu hand in hand to the polling station. He and Hsu both declined media requests for an analysis on the "three-in-one" local government elections, but said they encourage people to turn out and votes.

The KMT chairman was confronted by one woman who heckled him and questioned the justification of his presence. He told her that the Republic of China on Taiwan is a free country, and that its citizens can go anywhere they want.

Ma explained to the media that as the mayor of Taipei, he had in the past accompanied the former president and the former KMT chairman and presidential candidate to polling stations during presidential elections, and that there was no transgression against any law in doing so.

Liu Wen-hsiung, the opposition People First Party's candidate for Keelung mayor, who went to the polling station in the company of his wife, criticized Ma for setting a bad example by using his presence to influence Hsu's chances of winning. His criticism was dismissed as "sour grapes" by the candidate of the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), Chen Chien-min, who was accompanied to the polling station by TSU Chairman Su Chin-chiang.
Ma later also went to Taipei County and walked with KMT candidate for magistrate Chou Hsi-wei and his family to a polling station.

DOC.HEADLINE: ELECTION WORKER KILLED IN MOTORCYCLE ACCIDENT

TEXT.P: An election worker was killed in a car accident on her way to a polling station in Taichung County Saturday, the first and only casualty in Taiwan's first and keenly competitive "three-in-one" elections.
Chen Ching-yi, a 22-year-old junior high school teacher, was killed after her motorcycle collided with a van when she was going to a polling station in Tachia town, police said.
Magistrate Huang Chung-sheng, who is seeking reelection, visited a Tachia hospital to show his condolences to the bereaved family.
People in Taiwan, except Taipei and Kaohsiung municipalities, cast their ballots to elect city, county and township government leaders as well as council members on Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: STUDENTS FROM 12 COLLEGES VOW TO FIGHT AGAINST SMOKING

TEXT.P: Students from 12 colleges and universities around Taiwan released an anti-smoking declaration Saturday at a tobacco hazard control and prevention forum sponsored by the Bureau of Health Promotion.

Chao Kun-yu, deputy director of the bureau, thanked the young people for their efforts in the anti-smoking campaign, and encouraged them to spread anti-tobacco ideas to all campuses around the island.
In the past six months, the students attended international camps against smoking and chewing tobacco to help send the message to people in Taiwan that tobacco kills.

DOC.HEADLINE: IT INDUSTRY URGED TO REDUCE DIGITAL DIVIDE IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh on Saturday urged the information technology (IT) industry to do more software research and reduce gradually the nation's digital divide between urban and rural areas.
Hsieh made the remarks at the opening ceremony of a month-long information technology exhibition held at the Taipei World Trade Center.

The premier noted that the annual IT month celebrations usually coincide with Taiwan's different types of elections; however, the elections have not cooled down the public's passion to attend the computer show. Hsieh attributed the situation to the attractive and highly competitive IT products presented by the information industry.
The inauguration of this year's IT month coincide with the country's city and county chief elections.
Noting that last year's IT month attracted more than two million visitors, Hsieh said it was a good sign, but urged the public to pay more attention to the country's future.

Hailing Taiwan's IT industry for its brilliant performance in global markets, Hsieh said Taiwan has been the world's largest supplier of motherboards, PDAs, and monitors, and the second-largest producer of servers.

However, he added, it would be great if the information industry can focus more on software research and do more to allow people living in rural areas to have more access to computers and the Internet.
Knowing the tremendous power of the Internet, the premier cited the example of his recent visit to a village restaurant in Taiwan that was quite crowded.
While wondering why such a small restaurant in such a remote village could attract so many people, the restaurant owner told Hsieh that it was because of the word spread via the Internet.

Hsieh said now that the elections have passed, the pace of life can return to normal, and the legislature can reinstate the budget of NT$5.5 billion (US$164 million) designated for hi-tech development which it cut in the recent legislative session.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER HOPES POLITICS WILL STABILIZE AFTER ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh expressed the hope Saturday that the social and political situations in Taiwan will become peaceful and stable after the hotly contested "three-in-one" elections.
Hsieh said the outcomes of the elections will definitely make some people happy and some others sad, but this is how democracy works.

Hsieh made the remarks during an inspection of a computer center set up at the Central Election Commission to compile the results of the vote count of the elections for county and city chiefs, county and city councilors as well as township and village heads.

Hsieh pointed out that many people were worried that holding the three elections at the same time would make vote-buying even more prevalent but that the government decided to go ahead with the plan in order to reduce costs and the negative impact on the economy.
Fortunately, it turned out that vote-buying cases decreased this year compared with the past, which was good, Hsieh said.

Also commenting on the elections after participating in the opening of a computer exhibition, Hsieh said it is depressing that many candidates still resorted to mud-slinging to defame their rivals, Hsieh said.
He stressed that the public should be conscientious and avoid saying anything that is not based on evidence.

On the outcomes of the elections, he said it is hard to predict which party will be the biggest winner in light of the heated competition. But he said he is "cautiously optimistic" about the showing of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.
The premier noted that the government will start organizing the second economic development conference after the elections, with cross-strait relations and global issues included on the agenda.
He expressed the hope that consensus will be established soon between the ruling and opposition parties to remove the political barriers in the country's economic policies.

DOC.HEADLINE: KEELUNG MAYOR HSU TSAI-LI THANKS KMT AND CITIZENS FOR ELECTION WIN

TEXT.P: Keelung Mayor Hsu Tsai-li thanked Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and Keelung citizens for helping him win re-election Saturday.
Hsu said he would love to "let bygones be bygones" and shake hands with his "respected rivals" Chen Chien-ming of the Taiwan Solidarity Union and Liu Wen-hsiung of the People First Party.
He was referring to fierce campaigning by all contenders marred by mud-slinging, name-calling and overheated rhetoric, which he claimed caused "a lot of misunderstandings and complaints."

He said that now is neither the time to celebrate nor to reward campaign leaders and workers; rather, "Let's set our city government team immediately to work for the benefits of all Keelung citizens."
By 7:42 p.m., according to the Central Election Commission, Hsu had 72,942 votes, versus Chen's 55,926 and Liu's 46,066.

DOC.HEADLINE: REELECTED DPP TAINAN MAYOR URGES PARTY TO REFLECT ON ITS FAILURE

TEXT.P: Newly reelected Tainan Mayor Hsu Tain-tsair urged his ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Saturday to conduct a comprehensive self-examination in the wake of the party's drubbing in the elections for county and city chiefs.
Otherwise, the DPP's past efforts to realize its ideals will all be in vain, Hsu warned.
The DPP seized only six of the 23 seats up for grabs in the elections.
Announcing his own reelection, Hsu called this a "critical moment" in history and thanked Tainan residents for their support.
Hsu said the victory was achieved with much hardship because of the smear tactics adopted by his rivals.

According to Hsu, Taiwan Solidarity Union candidate Chien Lin Huei-chun and Kuomintang candidate Chen Jung-sheng used a great deal of misinformation to attack him during run-up to the election, and both of them should reflect on their behavior.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFEATED LUO WEN-JIA URGES SUPPORTERS NOT TO PROTEST

TEXT.P: Defeated Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) candidate Luo Wen-jia urged his supporters Saturday not to protest their defeat by the Kuomintang's (KMT) Chou Hsi-wei but rather should show their maturity as real democrats.
"The DPP has always insisted on a democratic culture and system. So let us all be quality voters and accept the election results," Luo told his supporters at his campaign headquarters.
By 8: 12 p.m., Central Election Commission vote counting showed Luo trailing far behind Chou with 795,664 votes to 985,378.

Luo congratulated Chou for his big win, saying that he hopes Chou will be a good magistrate for Taiwan's largest county. Luo also pledged that the DPP will act as a competent opposition party in monitoring the KMT leader's performance.
Luo said that he is proud to be an "entirely clean" candidate as he never tried to buy a single vote and "my campaign team never used any unreasonable methods" to solicit votes.

Soon after Luo conceded defeat, DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang also offered to quit to take responsibility for the resounding defeat suffered by the DPP, which won only six of the 23 city and county seats being contended.
Losing Taipei County alone was enough to force Su to step down as he had pledged if the ruling party failed to win over half of all local government posts including Taipei County.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIU CHENG-HUNG BECOMES FIRST NON-HAKKA COUNTY MAGISTRATE IN MIAOLI

TEXT.P: The success of Liu Cheng-hung of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) in the Miaoli County magistrate election can be attributed to his long-term efforts in the northern Taiwan county as well as on the strength of KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou, according to observers.
Liu has become the first Hoklo county magistrate in Miaoli, a Hakka-dominated county where two-thirds of the residents are Hakkas.

Liu, a four-time legislator, is a veteran in politics and maintained a steady lead in pre-election polls. As all KMT candidates were chosen via a party primary, Liu got the jump on his rivals on the campaign trail. He ran against outgoing Miaoli Mayor Chiu Ping-kun and Legislator Hsu Yao-chang of the People First Party (PFP), an ally of the KMT.

Chiu, originally a KMT member, made a U-turn shortly after the KMT primary where he trailed Liu. Chiu quit the KMT, joined the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and was recruited to serve as the DPP's candidate, stunning many Miaoli residents. Though President Chen Shui-bian went to Miaoli several times to canvass for Chiu, the DPP was well aware that it would be tough going in the stronghold of the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the PFP.

Liu also said that he would nominate Liu Chiou-hsiang, a former provincial assemblyman and the grandson of a former Miaoli County magistrate -- and a Hakka -- as deputy magistrate, thus assuaging some of the misgivings of the Hakkas about a non-Hakka county chief.
KMT Chairman Ma also helped as his presence in Miaoli created a positive stir.

Fu Hsueh-peng, the popular incumbent Miaoli magistrate, wanted to pass his baton to Hsu Yao-Chang, but Hsu refused to change his party affiliation despite the fact that it was the precondition for the DPP to choose him as its candidate.
Hsu was the last among the trio to throw his hat in the ring when he formally announced his bid to join the race as an independent in September.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT DEMANDS POLITICAL INTEGRITY COMMISSION FOR GOVERNMENT

TEXT.P: Claiming that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has defeated itself, opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou on Saturday demanded that the government set up a political integrity commission to clean up the nation's politics.

Ma made his demand while speaking to KMT supporters who helped the party win 14 out of 23 city and county government posts, including the largest, Taipei County, and the "most symbolic," Chiayi City. The DPP even lost Ilan County, which it had held for 24 years and nominated former magistrate and justice minister Chen Ding-nan to defend.
He said the people of Taiwan have cast a vote of no-confidence on the ruling DPP. "In a democracy, when you have not performed well, it's natural that you will be replaced," he added.

After going through "the worst ever campaign, " Ma said, "We must ensure that Taiwan's politics are conducted in such away that no vote-buying will be tolerated in any elections and no corruption will be allowed in the government."
He pledged that the KMT will offer a "clean, diligent and loving" government if given the chance to rule the country, adding that it can do that now in the newly mandated 14 local governments.
He advised the winning KMT candidates to "take your rivals' policy proposals seriously if you deem them feasible and beneficial to the public."

Ma praised Taiwan's people for having made a wise choice but hoped that in the future, all political parties and candidates will vie in a healthy environment marked by "law-abiding, cost-saving and sportsmanship."
Only when elections can be held in this way "can we hope to have all people, instead of just a certain party, win in the democratic competitions," Ma said.

He lauded the DPP leadership for promising to "look deeply into themselves" when they bowed three times in front of the people to show their determination to take full responsibility for the party's poor performance.

Ma said the government must not stop there but should continue to investigate all political corruption cases such as the Kaohsiung rapid transit scandal and other irregularities in order to return justice to the people.

Ma's call for leading a government of integrity was echoed by Chou Hsi-wei, who won the Taipei County election and promised to use his four years in office to make it "the most clean and efficient" government that cares about all citizens.

DOC.HEADLINE: RE-ELECTED TAICHUNG MAYOR JASON HU ATTRIBUTES VICTORY TO CITY

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu won his re-election battle Saturday despite strong doubts by a rival camp in the final week of the campaign over whether his health would allow him to serve a second term.
A spokeswoman for Hu's camp declared his victory at 6: 30 p.m. after a majority of the ballots were counted.

Hu led his opponents from the outset during the vote counting. Final figures released by the Central Election Commission showed that Hu, of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), captured 262,667 votes, about 58 percent of the total votes.

Hu's chief opponent from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), Lin Chia-lung, received 87,065 votes, representing 39 percent of the total votes. Another candidate, Shen Chi-hui, of the People First Party (PFP), got 10,061, or 2.2 percent, of the votes.
Hu's elated campaign staff set off firecrackers at his campaign headquarters to celebrate the victory as well-wishers congratulated him.

In his victory speech, Hu said that his re-election was not only his victory but also the victory of Taichung City. He promised that the future of Taichung will only be better, and that he would work even harder in his second term to make Taichung "one of the most shining cities in Asia."

Hu also expressed relief that there is no need for KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou to resign his post because the KMT won in 14 of Taiwan's 21 cities and counties contested. Ma had vowed before the election that he would quit the KMT chairmanship if the party could not win in more than half, or 11, of the cities and counties.

Lin formally acknowledged his defeat at 6:40 p.m. and offered his congratulations to Hu over the phone. He said he will remain a good citizen of Taichung and continue to make contributions to the city.

Analysts believe that the KMT chairman's vow to quit as party leader if his self-imposed goal was not met influenced the results of the election in Taichung considerably by attracting votes from supporters of the PFP candidate, because they would not like to see the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the PFP lose its star leader.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT WINS NANTOU MAGISTRATE ELECTION

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) candidate Lee Chao-ching was elected Nantou magistrate Saturday, defeating Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) candidate Tsai Huang-liang and incumbent magistrate Lin Tzung-nan who quit the DPP to seek re-election.

Political analysts said the union of the KMT-led "pan-blue alliance" and the split of the DPP-led "pan-green" camp were the main reasons why the "pan-blues" were able to regain control in Nantou County after a hiatus of eight years.
There are approximately 400,000 voters in Nantou County, with the support ratio between the "pan-blue alliance" and the "pan-green" camp registering six to four traditionally.

However, the ratio seems to have drawn closer in several recent elections. During the 2004 presidential election, the "pan-blue" ticket of Lien Chan and James Soong only won 8,000 votes more than the DPP ticket of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu. In the legislative elections held the same year, the "pan-blues" and "pan-greens" garnered two seats each out of the four legislative seats available in the county.

This situation indicates that neither the "pan-blues" nor the "pan-greens" can withstand a split without risking a defeat in an election, and the competition between Tsai and Lin for the limited "pan-green" support base foretold a hard battle in the county, analysts said.

By contrast, Lee managed to obtain the full support of the "pan-blue alliance, " with Chen Chih-pin from the People First Party deciding not to run after losing to Lee in opinion polls. Lin Ming-chin, who had quit the KMT to run for the post, also withdrew from the race eventually.

Lending to the "pan-blue" momentum was the wide-spread wish among Nantou residents for a new magistrate, as the unemployment rate in the county remains high six years after the 921 earthquake, analysts said.

Admitting defeat, the DPP's Tsai said there were three reasons for his failure. One was that he did not work hard enough to win the support of local residents. The other two reasons were the upset of morale of the DPP in the wake of a series of scandals involving officials in the DPP government and the division of the "pan-green" camp, Tsai said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG COUNTY MAGISTRATE RE-ELECTED BECAUSE OF HIS GOOD WORK

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) won re-election Saturday by winning nearly 60 percent of the vote.
Yang garnered more votes than he did four years ago, thanks to his outstanding performance during his first term, observers said.
Political analysts generally agreed that Yang's squeaky-clean image, down-to-earth work style and affable attitude have enabled him to drub his rival, Lin Yi-shih, of the main opposition Kuomintang.
After learning of his re-election, an emotional Yang expressed his heartfelt gratitude for the support of county residents.
Yang said he will work even harder during his second term so that he will not let down his supporters.

In the coming four years, Yang said the Kaohsiung County Government will carry out a number of major construction projects, including a cultural complex and four five-star hotels, to ensure the county's balanced development. Agriculture and industry have traditionally formed the backbone of the county's economy. In the future, Yang said he will give equal emphasis on cultural and tourism development.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOUL-SEARCHING MUST BEGIN, NOT FINGER-POINTING: DPP NEW TIDE FACTION

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) should begin soul-searching instead of blaming individual leaders such as President Chen Shui-bian or DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang for the party's dismal showing in local elections, a party stalwart said Saturday.
Tuan Yi-kang, convener of the DPP's New Tide Faction, said all party members must honestly face the party's poor election results in order to regain the confidence of the people.

The party won only six cities and counties, all in southern Taiwan, in a race for 23 local government seats, while the major opposition Kuomintang (KMT) won 14, including the largest, Taipei County, and the "most symbolic," Chiayi City.

Tuan attributed the DPP's failure to the "overall environment and the new election system of combining all three elections in a day of voting" -- the elections of city, county and town government heads as well as council members -- that he said are not to the advantage of the party.
He also blamed the party's election strategists for failing to give the public a new vision.
He refused to comment on DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang's resignation in the wake of the elections fiasco.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN TO STEP DOWN OVER POOR SHOWING IN ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Su Cheng-chang admitted that his party suffered a major setback in the city and county chief elections Saturday and said that he would step down to take responsibility.
Noting that the DPP garnered only six out of 23 posts up for grabs in the elections, Su said that "this is the people's warning to the DPP."

Although the DPP did poorly, he urged all party members and supporters not "to lose heart because of this one loss, " adding that the "love and responsibility for Taiwan" is everlasting and that only by believing that "the DPP will be better, will Taiwan be better."
"The DPP still has a long way to go, " Su said emotionally. "Because Taiwan people have high expectations for the DPP, the party has to begin serious soul-searching to attain higher standards.
"Our team has no place for members whose integrity is flawed, and we cannot disappoint the public through our mistakes," he added.
The DPP has fought an uphill battle since the Kaohsiung mass rapid transit corruption scandal involving a former presidential aide came to light in late August.

In a last-ditch attempt to boost support for the DPP, Su said Friday that he would step down if the DPP did not win 10 seats or if it lost the key Taipei county -- the largest constituency with 2.75 million voters. The main opposition candidate won the Taipei county magistrate race.
Premier Frank Hsieh said the DPP's drubbing can be attributed to an array of factors, and that the DPP chairman or anyone else shouldn't shoulder the responsibility alone.
"This big loss shows that the performance of the DPP falls far short of public expectations, " Hsieh said, adding that the DPP needs to engage in soul-searching and improve to "make a new start."

Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun, who concurrently serves as a vice chairman of the DPP's campaign committee, said that he felt sad and regretted the poor showing by the party, but "a defeat is a defeat, and there are no excuses." "This is because the people of Taiwan are disappointed and dissatisfied with the ruling party, and the DPP has some serious introspection to do, " he said.
He reaffirmed that the party has a responsibility to face all issues, and that it will not be defeated by this setback because the DPP is a party that is serious about pursing reforms.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUR LEGISLATORS WIN IN COUNTY, CITY CHIEF ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Out of the 13 legislators who ran for county magistrates or city mayors in Saturday's elections, four -- all from the Kuomintang (KMT) -- succeeded in shifting their career paths.
Many legislators consider that being a mayor or a magistrate is essential to advancing to a higher political position.

During the 2001 county and city chief elections, 20 legislators took part in the races. Twelve were elected, including six from the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), four from the KMT, one from the People First Party (PFP) and one from the New Party.
This year, 13 legislators were among the 76 candidates running for the 23 magistrate and mayor positions.
These legislators included the DPP's Tsai Huang-liang and Lu Po-chi, who ran for Nantou magistrate and Hualien magistrate, respectively, but both were defeated.

Of the six KMT legislators running in the elections, four won, including Chou Hsi-wei for Taipei magistrate, Liu Cheng-hung for Miaoli magistrate, Cho Po-yuan for Changhua magistrate and Huang Min-hui for Chiayi mayor.
The four PFP legislators who failed in their bids included Liu Wen-hsiung, Shen Chih-hwei, Fu Kun-chi and Hsu Yao-chang.
The other loser was independent Legislator Chen Chin-ting.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT WINS 14, DPP 6 OF 23 CITY/COUNTY GOVERNMENT POSTS

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) defeated the ruling Democratic Progressive (DPP) by winning 14 out of 23 city and county government chief executive posts in Saturday's "three-in-one" elections, outnumbering the DPP's six.
The People First Party (PFP) and the New Party won one county each, with the remaining one going to an independent candidate.
Voter turnout was 66.22 percent. Four years ago the turnout was 66.45 percent, according to the Central Election Commission.

The KMT garnered 4,523,775 votes or 50.96 percent of all valid votes, and the DPP won 3,724,290 votes or 41.95 percent. The PFP won 98,964 votes or 1.11 percent, and Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) got 100,243 votes or 1.13 percent. The New Party won 17,359 votes or 0.20 percent, and independents got 412,511 votes or 4.65 percent.

In the city and council elections, the KMT won 408 out of the 901 seats up for grabs, with the DPP getting 192, followed by the PFP with 31 and the TSU with 11. Independents scored 256 seats, with the remaining two going to other minor parties.

Of all 319 townships (including smaller towns called "hsiangs") , the KMT won 173 and the DPP a dismal 35. The PFP won three townships and another minor party won one. The remaining 107 went to independents.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CANDIDATE CHOU HSI-WEI ELECTED AS TAIPEI COUNTY MAGISTRATE

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) candidate Chou Hsi-wei was elected Taipei County magistrate Saturday, ending the Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) 16-year rule in Taiwan's most populous constituency.

Chou, a KMT legislator, defeated DPP candidate Luo Wen-jia by capturing 54.35 percent of the total votes. Final figures released by the Central Election Commission showed that Chou received 998,739 votes, ahead of Luo's 798,233 votes.
The figures also showed that the turnout rate for Taipei County's 2.75 million voters in the election was 66.35 percent.

In a victory speech at his campaign headquarters, Chou thanked the residents of the county and pledged that he would cooperate with friends from all political parties in the most humble manner and fulfill his campaign promises.
Chou said he would spend the next four years to make the Taipei County Government one of the "cleanest, most effective and most caring" local governments in Taiwan.

He also said he would not move into the existing office of the magistrate in the county government's high-rise building, but will find another location where he will be more accessible to his constituents.

One of Chou's major campaign promises is to push for the county to combine with Taipei City into one administrative area, so that residents of the county can enjoy the same resources as Taipei residents, instead of being treated as second-class citizens.
He said he will work with opposition legislators to have relevant laws amended to pave the way for the merging of the county and the city.

Chou's election is seen as the KMT's most important gain in the "three in one" local government elections, with the KMT holding sway over 21 cities and counties in Taiwan and two counties in outlying islands. The KMT won in 14 of the 21 counties and counties of Taiwan.

Political analysts believe that among the factors that contributed to the KMT's landslide victory were the series of recently exposed corruption scandals involving ranking DPP government officials and the people's hope for a clean, capable government through KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou because of his clean image and charisma.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT 'GRATIFIED' TO LEARN ELECTIONS ENDED SMOOTHLY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday that he was gratified to learn that the "three-in-one" elections came off without a hitch.

In a written statement, the president said that he thanked all who took part in election affairs, and law enforcers who helped maintain order, and that their efforts and contributions helped the elections proceed smoothly.
He expressed his congratulations to all who won in the elections for city and county chiefs, city and county councilors and township and village heads.
He also stressed that now that the frenzied elections have ended, and one should put behind the passionate campaigning and join hands for local development and work for the welfare of the nation.
The ruling Democratic Progressive Party fared poorly in the elections, garnered only six out of 23 seats up for grabs, compared with 14 seats for the main opposition Kuomintang.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCANDAL HURT DPP IN LOCAL ELECTIONS: SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: A corruption scandal involving a former presidential aide hurt the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), damaging the image of integrity and reform it has tried to project, a scholar said Saturday.

Hsu Yung-ming, an associate researcher at Academia Sinica, made the remarks regarding the outcome of the city and county chief elections which saw the DPP win only six seats out of 23 up for grabs, compared with the main opposition Kuomintang's 14 seats and another two seats for the People First Party and the New Party, -- allies of the KMT -- and another one for an independent.
"The outcome will affect President Chen Shui-bian's leadership, but as there is still no one who can replace him within the party, he won't become a lame duck for the time being."

As for the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the PFP, KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou has proved to be the standard bearer of the alliance, and the elections only accentuated the fact that "Ma is capable of living up to the expectations of the public."

Looking ahead, Hsu said that if President Chen can't make more positive and larger-scale reforms in response to the events of the day, a fresh call within the party will emerge, and "the voices could possibly challenge the power of the president."

Hsu said that second-phase financial reforms should be the top priority of the Cabinet after the elections. The planned national economic development advisory conference should have cross-strait issues as its focus, and it is expected that "Chen's policy will be moving toward being more open."
It is also expected that the Cabinet will undergo a major reshuffle, but whether the pressure will be strong enough to have Premier Frank Hsieh replaced remains to be seen.

DOC.HEADLINE: YUNLIN COUNTY GETS FIRST WOMAN MAGISTRATE

TEXT.P: Su Chi-fen of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) won the hotly contested Yunlin County magistrate election Saturday, making her the county's first woman chief.
Su's hard-fought victory also marked the first time that the DPP has managed to capture the helm in the southern Taiwan agricultural county.
Su beat the main opposition Kuomintang's (KMT) candidate Hsu Shu-po by more than 34,000 votes.
Saturday's elections also saw many other firsts. The DPP lost two key races in its traditional power bases -- Chiayi City and Ilan County.
The KMT's Lu Kuo-hua defeated his DPP rival Chen Ding-nan in the Ilan County magistrate election, ending the DPP's 24-year grip on power in the northeastern county.

Incumbent Chiayi Mayor Chen Li-chen of the DPP lost to the KMT's candidate Huang Min-hui. It marked the first time that the KMT has ever taken the helm of the southern city where opposition forces had been strong during the KMT's 55-year rule.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAITUNG COUNTY CHIEF-ELECT MAY BE STRIPPED OF POST

TEXT.P: Taitung County Magistrate-elect Wu Chun-li will have to relinquish his post after being sworn in unless he is acquitted before the Dec. 20 inauguration, the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) said Saturday.
Wu was sentenced to seven years and six months in a second trial for involvement in a corruption scandal during his stint as a Taitung County councilor.

Wu has appealed his case. If he is acquitted in the Supreme Court judgment before Dec. 20, he can take office. Otherwise, MOI officials said, Wu will be banned from assuming office after the swearing-in ceremony under the current Local Self-Government Law.

If the Supreme Court fails to mete out its judgment before Dec. 20, Wu's deputy can serve until a verdict is announced. If Wu is convicted in the third or final trial, he will be stripped of his magistrate post.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Blast in Falluja Kills 10 Marines; 11 Are Wounded
A year after marines led an American assault force in recapturing Falluja, 10 marines conducting a foot patrol on the edge of the city were killed at dusk Thursday by a bomb fashioned from several large artillery shells. Eleven other marines were wounded in the blast, the worst in a drumbeat of insurgent attacks on American troops in and around Falluja that never ceased after the Nov. 2004 offensive there that cost 60 American marines and soldiers their lives. The high casualty toll in the Falluja bomb attack brought to 205 the total number of American combat deaths in the western desert province of Anbar in the last nine months.
Wall Street Journal: Chemical Disaster In China Fuels Pollution Worries
China's slow and initially secretive response to a chemical disaster is threatening to turn the spread of environmental damage from the nation's fast-growing industries into a mounting international issue. As a massive, noxious chemical slick moved north to Russia, China's top environmental protection official was forced to step down Friday, the highest-ranking official to be removed from office for an environmental incident. A person familiar with the situation said more resignations were likely by local officials and possibly executives at China National Petroleum Corp., the government-owned oil giant that owns the factory that caused the disaster. And in what could be the first sign of a public backlash against China in the U.S. over the pollution issue, California's state treasurer urged its large teacher's pension fund to sell its roughly $24 million holding of PetroChina. China National Petroleum is the parent company of PetroChina, which is listed in New York and Hong Kong.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR DECEMBER 4 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Sunday, Dec. 4:

DOC.HEADLINE: '3-IN-1' ELECTIONS REFLECT TAIWAN'S DEMOCRATIC VITALITY: U.S.
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 3 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The U.S. State Department said Saturday the just-concluded "three-in-one" elections reflected Taiwan's democratic strength and vitality.

"The Saturday election is Taiwan's internal affair. It reflects the strength and vitality of the democracy in Taiwan. The United States strongly supports democracy worldwide, " the State Department said in a press release.
Taiwan voters went to the polls Saturday to elect city mayors/county magistrates, city/county councilors and township/village chiefs. The elections concluded smoothly without a hitch.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Dec. 4, or the fourth day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past.
1154: Nicholas Breakspeare becomes the first Englishman to become the pope.
1795: Thomas Carlyle, Scottish historian and essayist, is born. His works include "Sartor Resartus" and "The French Revolution."
1892: Gen. Francisco Franco, Spanish dictator from 1939 until his death in 1975, is born.
1893: Britain and France reach an agreement on Siam (Thailand).
1912: Turkey reaches an armistice with all the Balkan allies except Greece.
1947: Tennessee Williams' play "A Streetcar Named Desire" premiers on Broadway, with Marlon Brando and Jessica Tandy in the leading roles.
1936: Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek of the Republic of China leaves Loyang for Xian to meet with Chang Hsueh-liang.
1939: Wu Pei-fu, a noted Chihli faction general of the Peiyang army, China's first modern fighting force, dies of illness in Beijing at the age of 66.
1963: Pope Paul VI approves the decision of the Roman Catholic Vatican Council to authorize the use of vernacular languages instead of Latin in performing the sacraments.
1963: The Kuomintang Central Standing Committee approves the resignation of ROC Premier Chen Cheng, who is concurrently serving as the vice president, and names Yen Chia-kan as the new premier.
1965: The United States successfully launches "Gemini 7," which would orbit the earth for a record 14 days.
1966: Beijing's Red Guard arrests communist leaders such as Peng Chen, Tien Han and Wan Li.
1973: Jordanian Minister of Tourism and Antiquities Ghaleb Z. Barakat arrives in Taipei for a weeklong visit.
1975: The Third Conference of East Asia Economists opens in Taipei with 30 Japanese and 50 Chinese delegates attending.
1975: Defense Minister Kao Kuei-yuan announces that the fighting capability of the ROC armed forces has nearly quintupled over the last quarter of a century.
1975: Willem Pretorius, the new South African consul-general to the ROC, arrives in Taipei to assume office.
1976: The Central African Republic becomes the Central African Kingdom, and President Jean Bedel Bokassa is crowned king.
1976: A seminar on agricultural engineering and development is held at National Taiwan University to mark the 60th anniversary of the establishment of the Chinese Agriculture Society.
1977: A hijacked Malaysian airliner carrying 100 people crashes in Singapore, killing everyone onboard.
1989: Members of East Germany's Politburo and Central Committee resign, and Head of State Egon Krenz is forced to step down only six weeks after replacing a beleaguered Erich Hoenecker.
1994: U.S. Secretary of Transportation Federico Pena visits the ROC, becoming the first U.S. secretary to carry out the new U.S. policy governing high-ranking official visits to Taipei.
1998: A trial is held in Shanghai for a Chinese entrepreneur accused of providing e-mail addresses to an online democracy magazine.
1999: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian leaves for a five-day European visit.
2000: The fourth Global Semiconductor Industry Seminar opens in the Hsinchu Science-Based Industrial Park, with more than 200 of the leading lights of the global semiconductor sector participating.
2000: David Yen, one of Taiwan's most prominent anti-smoking activists, is granted a Thai royal decoration in Taipei for his contributions toward successfully controlling tobacco consumption in Thailand.
2001: Kinmen Deputy Magistrate Yen Ta-jen goes to Xiamen City opposite to the Taiwan-held frontline island aboard a passenger vessel for a four-day visit, the first of its kind for a Republic of China official in more than 50 years.
2001: The remains of 14 crew members of a surveillance aircraft affiliated with the former Republic of China Air Force's 34th Squadron, nicknamed the Black Bats Squadron, that was shot down by mainland Chinese fighters in Jiangxi province nearly four decades ago are airlifted back to Taiwan.
Motse's lesson of the day: "The interest of the wise ruler lies in carrying out what makes for order among the people and avoiding what makes for confusion. When the administration of the ruler answers the desires of the people, there will be order, otherwise there will be confusion."

The Japan Times: G-7 warns inflation puts growth at risk
The Group of Seven countries on Saturday warned that global growth is at risk from high oil prices, protectionism and inflationary pressures.

DOC.HEADLINE: ELECTIONS ANOTHER VICTORY FOR TAIWAN'S DEMOCRACY: VICE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Sunday that although the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) suffered a major setback in the Dec. 3 local government elections, the polls as a whole represented another victory for Taiwan's democracy.

Speaking during a colloquium hosted by the Democratic Pacific Union on Taiwan's elections and reforms, Lu said that she and President Chen Shui-bian are willing to take responsibility for the DPP's failure in Saturday's "three-in-one" elections, in which the ruling party garnered only 41.95 percent of the total votes while the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) won 50.96 percent.

The DPP's winning only six of the local seats to the KMT's 14 was a major setback for the ruling party, but the entire election process -- with a higher-than-expected turnout of 66 percent and no violence -- was a triumph for Taiwan's democracy, Lu noted.

Lu offered her congratulations to KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou for his party's sweeping victory and lauded him for his humble attitude in accepting victory. Upon winning Saturday's elections by a landslide, Ma told his party and KMT supporters that "we can celebrate for one evening, but that's all, as we must continue working to overcome the many challenges that still lie ahead."
Lu also saluted DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang for his courage in immediately offering to step down from the DPP chairmanship to take full responsibility for the party's failure in the elections.
The vice president said that although Su has offered to resign, DPP members can still consider whether they should accept the chairman's resignation.

Lu repeated President Chen's recent remarks that the question of whether there will be a Cabinet reshuffle doesn't necessarily have to be related to the results of the Dec. 3 elections. She appealed to the DPP members and the country alike to "give the president some more time" to ponder the issue.

Meanwhile, Lu stressed that failures can be transformed into strength leading to success. Citing the setback suffered by then Taipei City Mayor Chen Shui-bian in 1998 in his re-election bid as an example, Lu said that the 1998 failure was transformed into an invincible strength for Chen to win the 2000 presidential election.
The vice president exhorted all DPP members and supporters to be confident in the party's strength in winning back its mandate in next year's mayoral elections in metropolitan Taipei and Kaohsiung.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Thai deputy PM: 'Our friendship remains'
WITHIN hours after he arrived yesterday, Thailand's Deputy Prime Minister Suwat Liptapanlop saw with his own eyes how a Filipino tennis ace vanquished his rival from Thailand fair and square-and captured the gold medal.
The Philippine Star: It's judgment day at SEAG
For the Philippines, today is its moment of truth in its quest for the overall crown in the 23rd Southeast Asian Games, with close to 100 gold medals at stake in what has been described as the meet's "Judgment Day.
The Manila Times: Malacanang insists Games fair, square MAINTAINING that the Filipino athletes are winning the competition fair and square, Malacanang on Saturday refused to dignify Thailand' s allegations of biased officiating in the 23rd Southeast Asian Games.

DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Wrongful Imprisonment: Anatomy of a CIA Mistake; German Citizen Released After Months in 'Rendition'.
In May 2004, the White House dispatched the U.S. ambassador in Germany to pay an unusual visit to that country's interior minister. Ambassador Daniel R. Coats carried instructions from the State Department transmitted via the CIA's Berlin station because they were too sensitive and highly classified for regular diplomatic channels, according to several people with knowledge of the conversation, the paper said.

Los Angeles Times: Bomb Kills 10 Marines at Fallouja.
Ten Marines were killed and 11 wounded as a powerful makeshift bomb exploded near Fallouja in the deadliest insurgent attack on American troops in Iraq in almost four months, the Marine Corps said Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Bad weather paralyzes northern areas.
Heavy snow paralyzed northern areas Saturday with highways closed and railway services interrupted. Thousands of vehicles were trapped on highways. The public transport system in the metropolitan area of Milano was in tilt. A new bad weather system is to hit central and Adriatic coast, weathermen warned.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI COUNTY MAGISTRATE-ELECT ANNOUNCES THREE TOP PRIORITIES

TEXT.P: Taipei County Magistrate-elect Chou Hsi-wei of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Sunday that streamlining the county's finances, boosting business and industrial development, and taking care of the disadvantaged will be the three top priorities of his county government after he assumes office.

Chou, who ended the Democratic Progressive Party's 16-year rule in Taiwan's most populous county by garnering 998,739 votes in Saturday's election, said during a thank-you ride Sunday that he will see to it that a "transparent" and written account of Taipei County government's finances will be made public one month after he takes office on Dec. 20.

Taking heed of the imbalance in development among the 29 townships and rural townships around Taipei County, Chou said that he will see to it that various task forces and teams made up of experts and professionals are organized within three months to help him address the various issues that Taiwan's largest county is facing.
Chou said that he will also try to persuade Taipei City-based industrial conglomerates to relocate their operations to Taipei County to take advantage of the county's huge untapped hinterlands.

Chou, a KMT legislator, defeated Democratic Progressive Party candidate Luo Wen-jia by capturing 54.35 percent of the total votes. Final figures released by the Central Election Commission showed that Chou received 998,739 votes, ahead of Luo's 798,233 votes.

In a victory speech at his campaign headquarters Sunday, Chou thanked the residents of the county and pledged to cooperate with friends from all political parties in the most humble manner and fulfill his campaign promises.

He also said he will not move into the existing office of the magistrate in the county government's high-rise building and instead will establish "mobile" offices to make his county government's services more accessible to his constituents.

Noting that there are more than 3,000 artists around Taipei County, Chou said he will let the magistrate's office be refurbished into an activity center for the artists to help boost their creativity.

One of Chou's major campaign promises was to push for the county to combine with Taipei City into one administrative area, so that residents of the county can enjoy the same resources as Taipei residents, instead of being treated as second-class citizens.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET SHOULD FOCUS ATTENTION ON ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT: TSU

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) -- the partner of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the "pan-green camp" -- Sunday urged the DPP government to heed public opinion and devote more of its efforts to economic development.

Legislator Ho Min-hao, convener of the TSU's legislative caucus, said the DPP government should conduct an overall review of what led to its severe drubbing by the voters in Saturday's "three-in-one" local government elections.
Ho said the message from the people is clear: they want economic development and a clean government, but the Cabinet's performance apparently has not been up to their expectations.
He called on the DPP government to institute reform more resolutely, rather than being bent on giving the people more of the same, because the people have made their choice with their ballots.

On cross-Taiwan Strait relations, the TSU legislator said the DPP government should seek consensus with the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party on such issues as allowing direct transportation between Taiwan and China and permitting people from the Chinese mainland to come to Taiwan on sightseeing trips.

Reflecting on the elections, Ho acknowledged that the TSU did not do very well, as the party failed to win any of the 23 mayor and county magistrate races and only managed to obtain a total of 12 seats in all of the city and county council races.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN TO TRY TO REPAIR DAMAGED RELATIONS WITH PFP

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Sunday that he will try to mend fences with People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong, who had complained about the KMT's insistence on fielding its own candidate for mayor in Keelung City, where the PFP's candidate had a great chance of winning.

The KMT candidate, incumbent Keelung Mayor Hsu Tsai-li, won a second term by defeating PFP candidate Liu Wen-hsiung and the Taiwan Solidarity Union's candidate, Chen Chien-min, in Saturday's election. Before the election, Soong warned that the KMT would have to fend for itself in the legislature without the assistance of the PFP if Liu lost.

Basking in the glory of his party's landslide victory in the "three-in-one" local government elections over the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), Ma said in an interview with the CTV that if he were in Soong's position, he would also be unhappy about Liu's setback.
However, he explained that the KMT's nomination of Hsu had been finalized before he became the KMT chairman, and that, as the KMT leader, he had no choice but to support Hsu all the way.
Ma, who is also Taipei mayor, said he will follow Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng's suggestion to pay a visit to Soong and try to repair the damaged relations between the KMT and the PFP.

Ma said the "pan-blue alliance" should set its eyes on a wider horizon, as there is much room for the two parties to work together. He expressed the hope that the cooperative relationship between the two parties will continue unaffected.

KMT-PFP cooperation is facing new challenges, as the PFP is sliding down the road of being marginalized in Taiwan's politics. Some of the PFP's 34 legislators are indignant toward the KMT's unyielding stance toward PFP candidates. Other PFP legislators are pondering whether they should leave the PFP and join the KMT.

The number of seats held by the "pan-blue alliance" in the legislature has decreased to 110, including 76 for the KMT and 34 for the PFP, because four KMT legislators are set to assume their new posts after winning in the mayor and county magistrate elections. As a result, the alliance has lost its slight majority in the 220-seat legislature.

Analysts point out that KMT and PFP lawmakers not only need to work together even more closely, but also have to seek support from the independents if they want to maintain their checks and balances role of keeping the DPP government in line.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA POLICY TO BE LEGISLATIVE FOCUS FOLLOWING LOCAL ELECTIONSBy S.C. ChangCNA Staff Reporter

TEXT.P: With the local elections over and the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) a big winner, the party's initiatives about Taiwan's cross-strait policy are expected to become central issues to be debated at the Legislative Yuan, observers said Sunday.

Together with its "pan-blue alliance" ally, the People First Party (PFP), the KMT has been calling for direct transportation links across the Taiwan Strait and an opening of Taiwan's tourism market to Chinese visitors, policies that have the support of the business community but that the DPP government has been wary of because of national security concerns.

The DPP, in making its China policy, has put more emphasis on Taiwan's sovereignty and national security, sometimes to the point of hamstringing Taiwan's economic interests, as can be seen in reports by American and European chambers of commerce in Taiwan.

Pan Wei-kang, deputy secretary-general of the KMT's legislative caucus, said the city and county elections results show the "pan-blue alliance's" policy proposals enjoy popular support. Pan said she expects the KMT and PFP to cooperate further in pushing the alliance's relatively liberal China policy in the legislature.

Of the alliance's various policy proposals, the one that deals with direct transportation links across the strait is "the most important because it will play a locomotive role in Taiwan's economic development, " said Huang Yi-chiao, convener of the PFP legislative caucus.

Against this background, the "pan-blue alliance's" proposal to open Sungshan-Hong Kong/Macao direct flight routes has been put on the legislative agenda, a proposal that has won the signatures of even some DPP lawmakers.

Chen Ching-chun, secretary-general of the DPP legislative caucus, said President Chen Shui-bian had announced that a second national economic development conference would be organized to discuss such topics as launching direct shipping and air services between Taiwan and China and allowing Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan.

Within the "pan-blue alliance, " firm cooperation is not ensured because of election squabbles and division. However, Huang said improving cross-strait relations is a matter of ultimate importance and should not be used as a pretext for partisan conflicts.

Still, the DPP's Chen reminded his "pan-blue alliance" colleagues at the legislature to place the nation's overall interests above all else and discuss the issues connected with national security and sovereignty rationally.

He expressed the hope that lawmakers will also rationally debate other key issues, such as the arms purchase package and review of the president's nominations for the Control Yuan and the budgets for the Mainland Affairs Council and the Government Information Office, at the legislature which will resume meeting on Monday.

The public has given the KMT a new mandate in the just-concluded local elections to pursue economic and political reforms that include improving ties with China. It's not yet known how far the Chen Shui-bian government will go to resist the KMT's China initiatives for the sake of national security.

Lawmakers of both the ruling and opposition parties will have to show their wisdom to navigate between the public's demand for a more open China policy and the DPP's inclination toward a more conservative one.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEC. 3 ELECTIONS REFLECT DEEPENING OF TAIWAN DEMOCRACY: CHINA HAND
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 3 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has once again deeply impressed the international community as a shining example of democracy with the success of its "three-in-one" local elections Saturday, according to a Washington-based China hand.

Alan Romberg, director of the East Asia Program of the Henry L. Stimson Center, said during an exclusive interview with CNA Saturday that American political observers are impressed with the success of the elections, viewing it as a deepening of democracy in Taiwan.
"While, as also happens in American elections, there were features of some campaigns that were negative, the basic democratic process worked once again, " he said.

Romberg further said that Americans will remain attentive to whether there is good governance in Taiwan. "This is, obviously, first and foremost a matter for people in Taiwan to deal with. But given the deep level of involvement between our societies and our economies, it does matter to Americans whether Taiwan is successful at all levels," he added.

As to the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's major setback in the elections, he noted that many DPP officials have already said publicly that the party needs to reflect on why it was so broadly rejected by the voters.

At the same time, Romberg suggested that the triumphant Kuomintang needs to reflect on why it won and avoid the pitfall of assuming its impressive victory means voters will automatically support it in upcoming elections.
"It seems to me that the people of Taiwan will continue to look at performance in office as the basis for judging whether an individual or a party merits support in the future, " he added.

Romberg also said that Americans will remain committed to working with Taiwan to ensure that peace and stability are maintained in cross-strait relations. And, more than that, they will hope for continuing positive and mutually beneficial dealings between the two sides of the strait, he added.

"In my personal judgment, there is considerable room for greater flexibility on both sides in promoting cross-strait economic and other linkages that meet the needs of the people in Taiwan and on the mainland, " he said, adding that whether the Dec. 3 elections results will have an impact on Taiwan's cross-strait policies remains to be seen.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO MAJOR CHANGES TO CHINA POLICY FOLLOWING ELECTIONS SETBACK: MAC

TEXT.P: The government will not overhaul its China policy following the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's defeat in Saturday's "three-in-one" local elections, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman You Ying-lung said Sunday.

Speaking at a seminar on the impact of the elections on cross-Taiwan Strait relations, You said that Saturday's polls should not be viewed as a public referendum on the government's China policy, asserting that the government will not make any major changes to its current China policy despite the ruling DPP's poor showing in the elections.

The government must be coherent and consistent in drawing up stable policies, You said, adding that the MAC will continue promoting cross-strait charter flight services, as well as the opening of Taiwan to Chinese tourists, and a resumption of cross-strait negotiations.

You also played down the remarks made by President Chen Shui-bian while campaigning for a DPP candidate in Ilan County last week that the government would tighten its China policy to protect the interests of the Taiwan people should the opposition "pan blue alliance" win Saturday's elections. The president was just reminding the public that a "pan blue" victory would not necessarily mean an easing in cross-strait policy, he explained.

Asked whether Beijing would do anything against Taiwan after the elections, You argued that cross-strait relations have turned sour due to China's hard-line position toward Taiwan, rather than due to the DPP's strategy.
Expressing the hope for cross-strait peace and stability, he said that the MAC does not expect to see anything similar to the Anti-Secession Law produced by Beijing again.

The main opposition KMT won a landslide in Saturday's elections for city mayors and county magistrates, city and county councilors, and village and townships heads, dealing a heavy blow to the ruling DPP after President Chen Shui-bian won re-election in 2004 by a razor-thin margin.
The KMT won 14 of the 23 city mayor and county magistrate posts being contested, well ahead of the DPP's six, as well as a large majority of the councilor and township chief races.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP ELECTION FAILURE TO HARDEN BEIJING'S RESOLVE NOT TO HAVE DIALOGUE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 3 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) failure in Saturday's local elections will harden Beijing's resolve not to deal with it, although the DPP's China policy was not a factor contributing to its setback in the polls, a researcher at the Heritage Foundation said Saturday.

In a response to questions from a CNA reporter, John Tkacik, an American Chinese affairs expert at the Washington, D.C.-based think tank, said the elections represented a referendum on the DPP administration's performance, not a referendum on Taiwan's future with China.

Virtually every race was decided on local and domestic issues, and in every district, even in the constituencies where the DPP actually did manage to hold on to power, voters have been very disappointed with the DPP administration across-the-board, Tkacik said.

Nonetheless, he said, the KMT continually touted its ability to improve relations with China as its central theme in the campaign, and the DPP began to fall into the trap by warning that a loss for it in the elections would undermine the Executive Yuan's flexibility in dealing with China.

Tkacik said the bitter battle between the KMT and the DPP over China policy in the context of domestic elections led foreign media to view the results as an expression of support for the KMT's new vision for Taiwan's future with China.

With this incorrect view, Tkacik said, Beijing will be even more resolute about not engaging in any dialogue with the DPP and will wait until 2008 in the expectation that a KMT candidate will win and follow former KMT Chairman Lien Chan's policies of reaching out to it.
The DPP only won six of the 23 city mayor and county magistrate posts up for grabs in Saturday's elections, down from 10 in the 2001 elections, while the KMT won 14, up from eight last time.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT POLICY SHOULD BE RELAXED: KMT CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: The Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government should relax its cross-Taiwan Strait policy for Taiwan's own good, opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Sunday.

In a TV interview after his party's landslide victory in Saturday's "three-in-one" local government elections, Ma said he did not pay too much attention to President Chen Shui-bian's threat made before the elections that the cross-strait policy would be tightened if the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party won overwhelmingly because the president's logic did not make sense.

The KMT chairman, who is also Taipei mayor, pointed out that Taiwan is ideally located at the center of East Asia and next to China -- the world's largest consumer market and factory -- and that Taiwan should make good use of this advantage.

He said the "three direct links" between Taiwan and China in trade, post and transportation are necessary and should be implemented as soon as possible so that Taiwanese entrepreneurs can gain a foothold in China's emerging market and have access to its resources.

Asked whether the president should be blamed for the DPP's humiliating defeat in the elections, Ma said that because the president involved himself so deeply in the elections, he is of course responsible for the consequences.

He explained that the DPP lost the people's trust mainly because of a series of corruption scandals involving several senior officials at the Presidential Office and that the president's presence at every rally to boost the campaigns of DPP candidates was bound to remind the voters of those scandals.

Asked again whether the president should acknowledge the faults of his government and apologize to the nation, Ma said that doing so would be helpful not only to the president himself but also to reconciliation between the "pan-green camp" and the "pan-blue alliance."

On whether the KMT has in mind any hopefuls to be named as candidates for the mayoral elections in Taipei and Kaohsiung late next year, Ma said the nomination issue will be left to the party primaries.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT WIN MAKES MAJOR ARMS PROCUREMENT MORE UNLIKELY: U. S. SCHOLAR
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 3 (CNA) (By Olive Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The Kuomintang's (KMT) victory in the Dec. 3 "three-in-one" elections over the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will make it harder for a major U. S. arms procurement package to clear Taiwan's legislature, a U. S. scholar said Saturday.

The election results will push the ruling DPP to examine and adjust its policies, while the main opposition KMT is expected to further toughen its stance, thereby making it harder for the arms package to clear the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan, June Teufel Dreyer, a professor of political science of the University of Miami said.

The DPP administration's poor performance and a series of scandals seriously hurt its showing in the weekend elections, and the ruling party will be forced to re-assess its policies to fend off defeats in future elections, she said. On the other hand, the KMT's victory will boost party chairman Ma Ying-jeou's ambition to vie for presidency in 2008, she pointed out.

The election outcome has largely slashed the possibility of the arms bill's passage at the Legislative Yuan, a situation which might lead to more friction between Taiwan and the United States, she said.
She also predicted that major figures of the opposition "pan blue alliance" of the KMT, the People First Party (PFP) and the New Party, will visit China more frequently in the future.

The KMT won a landslide victory in the "three-in-one" elections by taking 14 of the 23 city mayors and county magistrates posts up for grabs, well ahead of 6 seized by the DPP. Of the 901 city and county councilors seats, the KMT won 408, while the DPP won just 192. The KMT also took a majority of the 319 village and township chief posts being contested, winning 173 to the DPP's 35.

The DPP has actively been advocating for the passage of the NT$350 billion (about US$10.5 billion) special budget for the major military procurement bill at the opposition-dominated Legislative Yuan since after President Chen Shui-bian narrowly won re-election in May 2004 against the "pan blue alliance" ticket.

The bill for the arms procurement, which includes eight diesel-fueled submarines and 12 anti-submarines aircraft, has been stalled at the Legislative Yuan since the middle of last year. However, lawmakers have agreed to include the budget for the purchase of six PAC III Patriot anti-missile batteries, the third item in the package, in regular annual budget for the Ministry of National Defense.

DOC.HEADLINE: ELECTIONS RESULTS SIGNAL POWER SHIFT: ANALYSTSBy Flor WangCNA staff writer

TEXT.P: The outcome of Saturday's "three-in-one" elections signaled a major power shift between the ruling and opposition camps, which is expected to have a significant influence on the 2007 legislative elections and the 2008 presidential race, political observers said Sunday.

The main opposition Kuomintang's (KMT's) strong performance over the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the local government elections preludes a KMT return in future elections in view of the noticeable expansion in its voter base in northern and central Taiwan, according to the analysts.

On the other hand, the DPP is set to undergo a power restructuring and party line adjustments in order to solidify its voter base, they predicted, adding that coming elections will pose severe challenges to the party now that the KMT will be able to allocate much greater resources in local governments.

The KMT seized 14 out of 23 city mayor and county magistrate posts in Saturday's elections, up from 9 in the previous elections in 2001. The DPP only managed to win six of the posts, and all of these are in southern Taiwan. The KMT also won a majority of the city and county councilor and village and township chief contests.
Further fueling its morale, the KMT also took Taipei county -- Taiwan's most populous administrative area -- as well as Ilan county and Chiayi city, which have long been DPP strongholds.

The KMT's landslide victory will also further cement the leadership role of KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou in the opposition "pan blue alliance" and boost his chances of winning the presidency in 2008, Wang Lee-yeh, a professor of political science at Tunghai University said, noting that Ma will face no other challengers from within the "pan blue alliance" in his quest to become Taiwan's next head of state.

Hsu Yung-ming, an Academia Sinica assistant researcher, opined that the DPP will be unable to turn the tide in its favor if it fails to implement sweeping reforms in the coming years ahead of the 2008 presidential race.
With the DPP's power base having contracted to southern Taiwan, a power struggle within the party is inevitable, keeping heavy pressure on party heavyweights vying for the presidency, he said.

Sheng Chih-jen, a political science professor at Soochow University, contended that the DPP must undergo serious soul-searching and thorough self-examination to regain the public's faith, which has been seriously shaken by a series of corruption scandals involving high-ranking officials in President Chen Shui-bian's administration.
The big question for the DPP at present is how the party can convince the people that Chen will promote clean politics and stay clean himself, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TURNS DOWN PREMIER'S RESIGNATION FOR NOW

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh offered to resign Saturday night but President Chen Shui-bian did not accept, telling him to stay on a while longer for the sake of political stability, a government spokesman said Sunday.

Hsieh made his "oral resignation" during a meeting with the president, when Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Su Tseng-chang also decided to step down, to take responsibility for the party's poor election results, said Cho Jung-tai, secretary general of the Executive Yuan.
The DPP won only six out of 23 city and county government posts in the "three-in-one" elections Saturday.
Cho said Chen met Hsieh again Sunday, asking Hsieh to wait until after an "internal review" has been conducted and after he has heard from "all sides."
Even if Hsieh stays on as premier, Cho said, the Cabinet will definitely be reshuffled to present a fresh face and a new team to the public who are so demanding.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAINAN MAGISTRATE ELECTION RESULT A WARNING FOR DPPBy Taijing WuCNA Staff Writer

TEXT.P: The result of the magistrate race in the southern county of Tainan in Saturday's "three-in-one" elections is seen as a serious warning for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
Although the DPP candidate Su Huan-chih won the election, his KMT rival Kuo Tien-tsai only fell 16,696 votes short of victory, which is rare in a region considered to be a traditional DPP stronghold.
The result represented a steep decline in support for the ruling party which garnered over 64 percent of the vote in the county in last year's presidential election.
The slim margin of victory Saturday left many high-ranking officials in the "pan-green camp" surprised.
"I never could have imagined such a scenario, where the DPP has lost many of its base supporters," Su said.

Su said that the poor showing is related to the Kaohsiung mass rapid transit scandal in which several high-ranking officials in President Chen Shui-bian's administration have been suspected of involvement as well as to the administration's plan to cut the preferential 18-percent interest rate for pension savings enjoyed by certain retired civil servants, military personnel and teachers.
"The DPP has to undergo some serious self-examination in the wake of this outcome," Su said.
He added that the DPP must figure out how to consolidate its support in the county as many of the party's base supporters could be leaning toward the opposing camp.
Otherwise, the party will have a difficult time winning the 2008 presidential election, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: H.K. COULD LEARN TAIWANESE COURAGE IN PURSUING DEMOCRACY: OBSERVER
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Dec. 4 (CNA) (By Kin-fai Lo & S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: Hong Kong people's dream for a general election of their government will be realized when they have the courage and enthusiasm of the Taiwanese, a political observer said Sunday.

Li Ping, writing for the Apple Daily, pointed out that the most important lesson for Hong Kongers to learn from Taiwan's democratic experience is Taiwan people's determination to safeguard their rights and dignity by electing whoever they like in spite of Beijing's military and non-military threats.

Commenting on Taiwan's "three-in-one" elections which saw the ruling Democratic Progressive Party suffer a great setback Saturday, Li said there have been criticisms about the mud-slinging tactics and "superstar stumpings" by major political figures that outshined individual candidates' policy proposals.
These shortcomings did not stop the international community from crediting Taiwanese for their enthusiasm to pursue democracy and courage to maintain their dignity, he noted.

Some people in Hong Kong are using Taiwan's example to claim that time is not yet ripe for Hong Kong to hold a general election, he said. However, he pointed out that Taiwan lifted the martial law in 1987 and the ban on forming new political parties in 1988, and then held its first general election to elect the legislature in 1992 and the first popular election of the president in 1996.

In Hong Kong, there are neither martial law nor a ban on organizing political parties, and it has returned to Chinese rule for eight years, "on what grounds do we say time is not ripe yet for a general election?" Li asked.
"Say we have to wait. But please tell me, for how much longer? " he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC CONFERENCE COULD BE PUT OFF TO INCORPORATE OPPOSITION VIEWS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian instructed Premier Frank Hsieh Sunday to "make thorough preparations" by inviting opposition leaders to a new round of national economic conference, a move that could delay the conference until after the lunar New Year holidays.

The government had earlier planned to hold the conference before the end of January, when the Chinese New Year holidays begin. Saturday's election setback for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) apparently has changed the government's plan.
After a lengthy discussion with the premier, the president said opposition views must be incorporated at the national economic conference, according to government spokesman Cho Jung-tai.
The two did not set a date for holding the important conference, but it's likely it will be postponed until after the lunar New Year, Cho added.

Hsieh had proposed to hold the conference in two stages, with representatives from the business, the government and the academia participating in the first stage and political party delegates joining the second stage.
Now the president wants an extensive coverage of topics and participants, both of which have yet to be specified, the conference may not have to be held in two stages, Cho said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC MINISTER TO ATTEND TAIWAN-PHILIPPINES MINISTERIAL CONFERENCE

TEXT.P: A ROC delegation led by Minister of Economical Affairs Ho Mei-yueh, arrives in Manila Sunday to attend the 13th Taiwan-Philippines ministerial conference on economical cooperation and look for an environment favoring future investment opportunities.
The Taiwan-Philippines ministerial economic cooperation conference has been held alternatively in Taipei and Manila since 1992.

The 70-member delegation which includes officials from the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) , Export Processing Zone Administration and ROC custom authorities, will attend the two-days conference starting Dec. 5. It is also scheduled to call on other Filipino economic officials as well as prominent personalities in the business field.
The conference will discuss on agreements to avoid double taxation between the two countries, co-training of Taiwanese-Filipino personnel and the protection of intelectual property rights.

As part of the schedule, Minister Ho will also visit the Clark Special Economic Zone (CSEZ) and the Subic Bay to see if favorable for Taiwanese investments. The delegation will return to Taiwan on Dec. 8.
Taiwan business leaders who accompany the minister on the visit will attend the 19th Joint Meeting of Chinese-Philippine Business Council and Philippine-Chinese Business Council in Manila.
