DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Health Coverage of Young Widens With States' Aid
The number of American children without health care coverage has been slowly but steadily declining over the past several years even as health care costs continue to rise and fewer employers provide insurance, creating a breach that states have stepped in to fill with new programs and fresh money. The overall ranks of the uninsured continue to swell, to nearly 46 million Americans at the beginning of this year. But a landmark federal program begun in 1997 to provide health coverage to poor and working-clas s children and additional measures taken by states have provided health insurance to millions of children who might otherwise go without.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Dec. 5, or the fifth day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1782: Martin Van Buren, the eighth president of the United States, is born.
1791: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, Austrian composer considered among the greatest and most prolific composers in history, dies in Vienna of kidney failure at the age of 35. He had written more than 600 works.
1792: George Washington is reelected president of the United States.
1904: The Russo-Japanese War breaks out, with Japanese troops occupying Height 203, the ideal position for capturing Lushun, west of the port city of Talien.
1906: Russian Adm. Niebogatov goes on trial on charges of surrendering ships to the Japanese.
1915: Chen Chi-mei, a follower of Dr. Sun Yat-sen, leads a revolt against Yuan Shih-kai by trying to seize the warship Chaoho. His attempt fails the following day.
1928: The Legislative Yuan of the Republic of China is formally established.
1933: The United States celebrates the end of 14 long years of prohibition when the government nullifies the 18th Amendment, which outlawed the production, transportation or sale of alcohol.
1945: Six U.S. Navy aircraft carrying 27 airmen go missing without a trace in the Atlantic Ocean near Bermuda.
1946: A strong earthquake hits southern Taiwan, killing 69 people and injuring 170.
1949: Li Tsung-jen, acting president of the Republic of China, leaves Hong Kong for the United States.
1950: North Korean and Communist Chinese troops recapture Pyongyang as United Nations forces are forced to withdraw southward.
1957: The Dachien to Lishan section of the Central Cross-Island Highway opens to traffic.
1957: The Indonesian government orders the expulsion of all Dutch nationals.
1968: The Taiwan Provincial Government launches a one-person-one-dollar movement to raise money for national sports development.
1972: The Chase Manhattan Bank of New York opens a branch office in Taipei.
1975: Campaign activities for the Dec. 20 legislative elections open with 61 candidates contesting 37 Taiwan area seats.
1976: Professional golfers Kuo Chi-hsiung and Hsu Sheng-san leave for Palm Springs, Calif., to take part in the 24th World Cup professional golf tournament.
1978: The Soviet Union signs a 20-year treaty of friendship with Afghanistan.
1984: Ninety-three miners are killed in an accident at the Haishanyikeng mining pit in Shanhsia township, Taipei County.
1984: The Central Standing Committee of the Kuomintang unanimously supports a bill to amend the Firearms Control Act, imposing heavy punishments on the unauthorized manufacture of deadly weapons, with a maximum sentence of death.
1985: The United States decides to pull out of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.
1985: Four businessmen are sentenced to prison terms ranging from two-and-a-half years to 12 years by a military court under the Taiwan Garrison General Headquarters for conducting direct trade with the Communist Chinese.
1995: Javier Solana, the Spanish foreign minister, is appointed the secretary-general of NATO.
1999: Vice Economic Affairs Minister Chang Chang-pang leaves for Miami to attend the annual Miami Conference on the Caribbean and Latin America.
2000: A total of 105 young Indonesians begin to receive two years of professional training in Taiwan as part of the ROC's efforts to help its major Southeast Asian trading partner develop small- and medium-sized enterprises.
2001: Beijing authorities sternly rejects Taiwan's proposal that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait commence dialogue on the "three direct links" issue under the framework of the World Trade Organization (WTO). The "three direct links" refers to direct cross-strait trade, postal and transportation links.
Motse's lesson of the day: "When the administration of the ruler answers to the desire of the subjects, it manifests an understanding of approvals and disapprovals of the people. When there is such an understanding, the good will be discovered and rewarded and the bad will be discovered and punished, and the country will surely attain order."

TEXT.P: An Republic of China delegation led by Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh arrived in Manila Sunday to attend the 13th Taiwan-Philippines ministerial conference on economic cooperation and to study the Philippines' investment environment.
The Taiwan-Philippines ministerial economic cooperation conference has been held alternatively in Taipei and Manila since 1992.

Besides attending the two-day conference which kicks off Dec. 5, the delegation is also scheduled to call on Philipinne economic officials as well as prominent members of the business community.

DOC.HEADLINE: ELECTION RESULTS NOT NECESSARILY INDICATOR FOR 2008 VOTE: U.S. SCHOLAR
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 5 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: A U.S. scholar said Sunday that the results of Taiwan's "three-in-one" elections over the weekend do not necessarily serve as an indicator for the outcome of the 2008 presidential election.
Arthur Waldron, a professor at the University of Pennsylvania, made the comments after the opposition Kuomintang claimed an overwhelming victory in the islandwide local government chief elections.
The KMT won 14 of the 23 mayor and magistrate posts up for grabs, as well as a majority of the seats in the council and township chief elections. The DPP only won 6 mayor and magistrate posts.
Despite the overwhelming KMT victory, Waldron stressed that there will be a lot of changes in the coming two years and that the KMT will also encounter many tough challenges.

"Now the onus will be on KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and his party to do what I think the people wanted the DPP to do and didn't, namely, push hard on reform, anti-corruption, and so forth, " he said, adding that "they will have some difficulty doing this, but if they do not, they will end up with the same problem as the DPP."

Waldron further said that "a lot can change in two years. The KMT has another difficult challenge. They have to show that they can do better in a lot of things than the DPP has done. The KMT is certainly not a party free of corruption. And it is rather divided."
He also said that the KMT having more confidence after winning the elections makes it less necessary for the party to seek China's support,

"Ma believes that if he does well, he can get Taiwan people to vote for him in 2008 without having to go over and being photographed in China, which would actually probably hurt his chances, " Waldron said.

Waldron, who also serves as the vice president of the International Assessment and Strategy Center, said that China will likely interpret the outcome of the elections as "a repudiation of President Chen Shui-bian's foreign policy."
Nevertheless, he said that he himself believes the big issues in the elections were domestic.

"Internal factors were key and in particular, the DPP has never really rooted out corruption as it had promised to do, but rather got distracted in start stop activities, endlessly shifting focus, " the professor added.

According to Waldron, the elections results are really an indication of the Taiwan voters' dissatisfaction with the DPP. He compared the outcome to that of the 1992 U.S. presidential election which Bill Clinton won. "A lot of people say that the (American) people did not mean to let Clinton win, they were just fed up with Bush. And I suspect that's part of the reason behind Saturday's elections results," he said.

Asked what the DPP can do after its defeat in the elections, the scholar suggested that the party should do "a very thorough self-examination and house-cleaning and decide what their core mission is going to be."

"The number one priority must be to improve Taiwan, making the education better, making the health system better, making the legal system better, making the civil service better, getting rid of the remaining corruption, that sort of thing. That's the way to win elections, and the same is true for the KMT, " he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP NEEDS TO REVIEW FUNDAMENTAL MATTERS: LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) should review some fundamental matters, including its administrative polices related to meeting the needs of the general public, in light of its defeat in the Dec. 3 local government elections, DPP Legislator-at-Large Tsai Ing-wen said Monday.

The DPP should not only face the cruel reality of being rejected by voters, it should also review and perhaps overhaul its systems fundamentally, such as the party's orientation, the distance between the DPP party apparatus and the people, the gap between the DPP and its supporters, as well as how it plays its role as the ruling party, Tsai said.

Tsai made the call during a meeting of the Legislative Yuan Finance Committee, where legislators and officials discussed matters mainly pertaining to implementation results of the first national economic conference, held Jan. 6, 2001, and the proposed holding of a second national economic conference.

Regarding the second national economic conference, Tsai, an academic-turned-legislator, said that dozens of issues can be tackled by the government and the private sector at the conference, slated to be held prior to the Chinese New Year, which falls on Jan. 29, 2006.

Tsai said the issues to be discussed at the conference should include how policies should be carried out, how the ruling DPP should seek to cooperate with the opposition parties, how to consolidate the people's will, and how to make members of the administration team more efficient and better trained.

In Saturday's "three-in-one" elections, the DPP took only six of the 23 city mayor and county magistrate posts up for grabs, while the opposition Kuomintang won 14, representing one of the biggest setbacks for the DPP since it became the ruling party in 2000.

: The Straits Times: Asean identity getting stronger, says regional poll.
A Region-wide poll has found that Asean's citizens and residents believe they share a common identity and want the pace of integration speeded up.
Respondents were asked a variety of questions on whether they planned or wanted to travel, live, study, invest and work in the region more freely.

DOC.HEADLINE: AEJ URGES U.N. TO STOP DISCRIMINATING AGAINST TAIWAN JOURNALISTS
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Dec. 4 (CNA) (By Y.S. Lo and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: The Association of European Journalists (AEJ) adopted a resolution Sunday calling for the United Nations to stop discriminating against Taiwan journalists and preventing them from covering the news at U.N. institutions, particularly the activities of the World Health Organization (WHO).
The association passed the resolution in its 44th General Assembly and Congress which is being held in Patras, Greece Dec. 1-5.

In the resolution, the association said that the U.N. authorities handling media affairs have no right to arbitrarily treat different media organizations differently or to decide which media organizations are allowed to cover U.N. institutions' activities.
"Adopting discriminating measures goes against the U.N.'s principle of protecting freedom of the press," the resolution says.

The association, which was founded in 1961 and which consists of 22 national sections each separately established in different countries in Europe, also said in the resolution that it was shocked by the fact that Taiwan journalists were refused permission by the U.N. to cover last year's annual meeting of the World Health Assembly, the highest decision-making body of the WHO.

Stressing that the European Union has never taken a prejudiced stance in its treatment of professional journalists, the association urged in the resolution the leading international organization not to adopt a double-standard in issuing press cards.
The draft resolution was jointly introduced to the assembly by the association's six members, who said they feel that the treatment received by Taiwan reporters from the WHA authorities was unfair.
During a meeting they had with President Chen Shui-bian in Taipei Nov. 23, the AEJ members were briefed on the WHO's discrimination against the island's reporters.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT-PFP MERGER MUST HAPPEN NATURALLY: KMT CAUCUS

TEXT.P: Collaboration between the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and its ally the People First Party (PFP) has always been welcomed by the KMT, but a merger of the two parties should happen naturally, a KMT legislative whip said Monday.

As Taiwan's political landscape changed drastically after the Dec. 3 local government elections in favor of the "pan-blue alliance" led by the KMT, cooperation between the KMT and the PFP at the Legislative Yuan has become even more pressing as the "pan-blue alliance" now holds barely half of the seats in the Legislature, said Tsai Ching-lung, a deputy convener of the KMT caucus.

Party politics have been shaped after the Dec. 3 "three-in-one" elections, in which the KMT won a sweeping victory, and the KMT will help accelerate a substantive consolidation of the "pan-blue alliance, " which also includes the PFP and the tiny New Party, Tsai said.
Tsai pointed out, however, that the much-talked-about KMT-PFP merger should be conducted naturally without causing any controversies that may widen rifts between the two brother parties further.

Meanwhile, Legislative Yuan speaker Wang Jin-pyng, also a KMT heavyweight, did not think a post-election merger between the KMT and the PFP would be instantly possible, saying that many substantive problems, including personnel arrangement, would be challenges to be tackled before such a consolidation becomes realistic.
For example, Wang said, how should PFP Chairman James Soong be positioned within the KMT-PFP merger is a challenging issue for the "pan-blue alliance."

Wang stressed that it is also imperative that the "pan-blue alliance" seeks collaboration with the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union now that the "pan-blue alliance" is a "weak majority" at the Legislative Yuan with at least four KMT legislators being elected local government heads.

Meanwhile, Huang Yi-chiao, a PFP party whip at the Legislative Yuan, said that the PFP would like to see a meeting between Soong and KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou -- as proposed by Ma Sunday -- prior to the Chinese Lunar New Year, which falls on Jan. 29, 2006.
The PFP will definitely give its supporters a "responsible" answer prior to the Chinese Lunar New Year regarding a KMT-PFP merger, Huang noted.
Huang denied news reports that some members of the PFP legislative caucus are seeking to return to the KMT fold after the elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN MUST HEED POSSIBLE IMPACT OF TAIWAN ELECTION RESULTS: EDITORIAL

TEXT.P: Japan needs to pay attention to the results of Saturday's local elections in Taiwan as they could signal a shift in the island's political landscape that could have an impact on Japan-Taiwan relations, according to an editorial published by the Nihon Keizai Shimbun Monday.

The editorial, titled "The Political Winds of Changes in Taiwan, "noted that the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , which won a landslide victory in the elections, is headed by a chairman, Ma Ying-jeou, who has had a tough attitude toward Japan on issues concerning historic and territorial problems.

The Japanese daily attributed the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's setback in the elections to a series of recent corruption scandals involving high-ranking officials close to President Chen Shui-bian.

The KMT's election victory has given a significant boost to KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou's chances in the 2008 presidential election, the editorial said. As Ma has been tough towards Tokyo on issues concerning territorial disputes between the two countries, it is necessary for the Japanese government to pay close attention to the KMT's future moves.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 119.36 points to close at 6,348.31.
The bourse opened at 6,280.81 and fluctuated between 6,244.49 and 6,348.31 during trading. A total of 4.45 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$120.29 billion (US$3.59 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up at 4.4 percent, followed by machinery and electronics shares at 2.6 percent, foodstuff issues at 2 percent, banking and financial shares at 1.1 percent, plastics and chemicals shares and paper and pulp issues both at 1 percent, and textile stocks at 0.5 percent.
Cement stocks remained unchanged.
Gainers outnumbered losers 910 to 167, with 129 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Red Cross Bolstering Minority Outreach; Recruitment a Priority After Storms Expose Sensitivity Gaps.
The American Red Cross has launched an aggressive effort to reach out to racial and ethnic minorities and add more of them to the charity's vast network of volunteers, in response to criticism that it treated them callously during the Hurricane Katrina relief effort.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Casini reopens question of leadership.
Speaker of the House of Deputies Pierferdinando Casini openly challenged again Premier Silvio Berlusconi's bid for a second five-year term Sunday by saying in a local television program that Berlusconi is the leader of the ruling coalition, but the next premiership will be decided by votes. Casini is of the Christian Democratic Union that forms together with Berlusconi's Forza Italia, the National Alliance and the Northern League the ruling oalition.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: United Russia Seizes a Huge Lead
United Russia was heading for a major victory in Moscow City Duma elections on Sunday, with preliminary results giving the party an overwhelming 48.17 percent of the vote.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMY SHOULD BE FOCUS FOLLOWING ELECTIONS: BUSINESS COMMUNITY

TEXT.P: The government should focus its efforts on improving Taiwan's economy now that the emotionally charged atmosphere of the elections has subsided, the business community urged Monday.

Now that Saturday's "three-in-one" local government elections have ended smoothly, the government should immediately stop campaigning and devote its energy to major economic issues, including the much-expected easing in its China policy which is of vital importance to Taiwan's economic development, business sources said.
They also expressed the hope of seeing political reconciliation at home, which they said is the key to fully reviving the economy.

It is necessary for the government to re-assess its "pro-active opening, effective management" policy regarding China-bound Taiwan investment, and the government should swiftly respond to the call for relaxed measures to further facilitate cross-Taiwan Strait trade and economic exchanges and restore public confidence, they pointed out.

A relaxation of a ban on relocation of certain categories of manufacturing to China is the top issue of concern to the high-tech sector, while traditional businesses are keenly hoping for the opening of direct air and shipping links between Taiwan and China and a full opening to Chinese tourists, they said.

The value of the new Taiwan dollar against the Chinese yuan is also another major issue to Taiwan's businesses, as the central bank's monetary policy will also influence domestic companies' competitiveness, they noted.
The central bank has always placed more emphasis on export-oriented businesses by keeping the local currency at a relative low value, leading to greater outflows of local capital, they pointed out.

At a time when an expected further appreciation of the Chinese yuan is just around the corner, the exchange rates among the New Taiwan dollar, the Chinese currency and the U. S. dollar has become a focal point for Taiwan enterprises, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF LEGAL COUNSELING GROUP SET UP

TEXT.P: A voluntary legal counseling group under the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) was set up Monday to offer free consultations to people from the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
SEF Chairman Chang Chun-hsiung presided over the inauguration ceremony of the 23-member group.

As an organization commissioned by the government to deal with cross-strait exchanges, the SEF has the responsibility to help resolve the many problems arising from cross-strait dealings and protect the interests of people on both sides, Chang said.

Despite the frequent two-way exchanges, people are not familiar with the legal systems on the two sides of the strait, Chang said, noting that the group is available to provide free legal counseling for people from either side.

The legal advisory group is the third set up by the SEF to aid the Taiwan people, in particular Taiwan business people with operations in China, following the creation of a Taiwan business people's service center in August and a financial consultation group in September.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG MAYOR WILL CONSIDER LEGAL REDRESS AGAINST ATTACKS ON HEALTH

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu said Monday he will use an even-handed and rational manner to deal with the attacks on him that were leveled during campaigning for his re-election.

Hu said he does not intend to file a lawsuit against President Chen Shui-bian for remarks he made alluding to the fact that Hu has had a couple of what doctor's have said were mild strokes. Chen asked Taichung residents to support Lin Chia-lung, the Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) candidate for mayor, since Hu could "drop dead at any time." Hu was re-elected Saturday.

DPP Legislator Lin Chin-hsin, a practicing physician, and 11 other doctors unveiled what they claimed was Hu's medical records at a news conference during the last days of the campaigning in an attempt to thwart Hu's re-election bid by saying that he might not be healthy enough for the post. Hu said he would consult his lawyer over this.

"Since the election is over and I have won, some think that this matter is over, " Hu said. "But I have to say that I am looking into this not for myself, but to try to put a stop to this kind of maliciousness.
"I have the social responsibility to do so, and I cannot act like a hypocrite," Hu added.

The city's Department of Health said that initial investigations showed that the alleged medical records may have been forged, and that the 12 doctors might have violated their ethical vows by infringing on the privacy of a patient.

The department is scheduled to convene a disciplinary committee meeting to handle the matter. Ironically, three of the 11 doctors present at the news conference are also members of the committee; therefore, they will not attend the meeting due an obvious conflict of interest.

Meanwhile, Hu also said that his administrative team will continue to work for the good of the city based on the principles of "integrity, efficiency and making residents' lives as convenient as possible."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN CANCELS MONDAY'S SCHEDULE TO PLAN STRATEGY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian bypassed his regular Monday work schedule and instead gathered high-ranking officials from his ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to brainstorm over the future path of the party after losing ground in the just-concluded "three-in-one" local elections.
The DPP won only six out of 23 city and county government chief posts. Moreover, it also lost its 16-year rule over in Taipei County, Taiwan's most populous constituency.
Canceling his meeting with awardees of the top 10 distinguished youth in the morning, Chen summoned Vice President Annette Lu, DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chan and others for discussions.

Ma Yung-cheng, deputy chief of staff to the president, said that Chen will collect a wide spectrum of opinions on the elections and the DPP's defeat before holding meetings with industrial and business leaders, referring to a planned national economic conference.

It is expected that the planned conference will be delayed until after the Chinese Lunar New Year holidays since the government had earlier planned to hold the event before the end of January. Chinese Lunar New Year's Day is Jan. 29, 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACTING KAOHSIUNG MAYOR HAS NO PLAN TO RUN FOR MAYOR NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: Acting Kaohsiung Mayor Yeh Chu-lan said Monday that she has no plan to run for mayor of the port city when her tenure ends late next year.

At a ceremony in Kaohsiung held to present citations to personnel who assisted in the preparations for the 2005 Golden Bell Awards for TV and radio broadcasting programs and professionals, Yeh denied media reports that she may reverse her previous position of not running in the next race for Kaohsiung mayor.
Yeh said she has no intention of running, and that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will field a mayoral candidate at the end of next year.
Commenting on the DPP's defeat in the "three-in-one" local government elections last weekend, Yeh said that all DPP members in the government need to think deeply on how this happened.
Asked by media if her position might be affected by a Cabinet reshuffle, she said the most important thing for the government now is to try and understand what the people's expectations are.
She added that the people want a clean government, and that the people's wellbeing must be the ruling party's first and foremost consideration.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, dropping NT$0.037 to close at NT$33.493.
A total of US$798 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$33.530 and hit a low of NT$33.455.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for December moved up 140 points to close at 6,363, with 35,180 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for January moved up 135 points to end at 6,360, with 971 contracts traded, while March futures gained 135 points to finish at 6,355, with 25 contracts traded. June futures moved up 109 points to close at 6,350, with 14 contracts traded, while September futures moved up 100 points to close at 6,210, with 14 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 6,223 for December, 6,225 for January, 6,220 for March, 6,241 for June and 6,110 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.
December TE futures moved up 8.65 points to close at 279.9, with 7,089 contracts traded, while January TE futures gained 8.9 points to finish at 279.9, with 128 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.

December TF futures gained 13.4 points to finish at 908, with 3,086 contracts changing hands, while January TF futures moved up 14.4 points to end at 908, with 130 contracts traded. September TF futures moved up 13.4 points to close at 896, with two contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT FINANCIAL BALANCE EXPECTED IN 2011: FINANCE MINISTER

TEXT.P: Under a Ministry of Finance plan, the government's income and expenditures are expected to be balanced by 2011, Minister of Finance Lin Chuan said Monday.

In a report to the Financial Committee of the Legislative Yuan, Lin said his ministry is pushing forward with reforms in finance and taxation, and is improving the management of the government's debts.

Noting that the government will have a debt of NT$3.68 trillion (US$109.87 billion) by the end of the 2005, the finance minister said the government's annual outlay as a percentage of the gross domestic product (GDP) has decreased from 17.3 percent in 2001 to 15.6 percent in 2005, which represents an slowdown in the accumulation of government debt.
Meanwhile, the government's annual revenue as a percentage of the GDP has decreased from 14.8 percent in 2001 to 12.4 percent in 2005.
Also, the minister said, his ministry is pressing ahead with 60 programs aimed to better the country's finance in the short, middle and long terms.

Tax reforms include a controversial program to strip military personnel and teachers of their tax-exempt privilege, which is still mired in the Financial Committee of the legislature, and the launch of a maximum tax system, which is pending final approval by the legislature, Lin went on.

He dismissed some lawmakers' concern that the plan to better the government's finances could fizzle out if he is removed from his job as the country's chief treasurer in a Cabinet reshuffle which seems to be likely in the wake of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's losses in the Dec. 3 local elections, saying the plan to balance finances will survive any personnel changes.

DOC.HEADLINE: DODGY ELECTED CANDIDATES COULD LOSE AFTER WINNING: JUSTICE OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The government will try to invalidate the elections of successful candidates who have been charged or are under investigation for involvement in vote-buying or other infractions, a senior justice official said Monday.

Deputy Justice Minister Wang Tien-sheng was commenting on the elections of a number of candidates in the Dec. 3 "three-in-one" elections who are under indictment or being investigated on suspicion of violating the election law.
Prosecutors are frustrated as their efforts to crack down on election irregularities have failed to stop the suspects from getting elected.

Wang said his ministry has targeted 10 elected town heads and 20 city or county council members whose elections might be nullified because of their suspected involvement in bribery or other irregularities.
In addition, he noted, prosecutors were continuing investigations into scores of newly elected officials, some or all of whom may also be indicted, he added.
According to the law, the prosecution must indict elected suspects within 15 days after the Central Election Commission announces the official results on Dec. 9.

Two examples are Chang Chi-hsun and Hsieh Wang-shan of Nantou County. Both were elected while they were being detained on charges of breaking the law -- Chang was charged with using violence and Hsieh, vote-buying.
The Nantou District Court's Prosecutor's Office said it will formally indict these people and their elections will be null and void.
People First Party (PFP) Legislator Lin Teh-fu said the prosecution seemed to have helped to promote those suspected candidates with its investigations, increasing their chances of getting elected.
Prosecutor-General Wu Ying-chao said Taiwanese are rather emotional when they cast their votes for detained or charged candidates who appeal for their "sympathy."

Another strange case in that of suspended KMT member running as an independent Wu Chun-li, who was elected Taitung County magistrate on Dec. 3-- when he was appealing the second trial ruling of seven-and-a-half years in jail for forgery and embezzlement.

In response to criticism as to why Wu was allowed to stand as a candidate while he had already been sentenced, Justice Minister Shih Mao-lin said he will talk with the Central Election Commission about amending the relevant law.

Kuomintang Legislator Lee Ching-hua said that the government must have been joking with Taitung residents by determining that Wu was eligible to run in the elections but must be suspended from his job after he is sworn in on Dec. 20.
Wu said, according to local government law, a local government leader must relinquish his job if he has been found guilty in the first trial.
However, whether or not to suspend Wu when he becomes magistrate is up to the Ministry of the Interior, which governs the Central Election Commission, Shih said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'I HAVE NO INTENTION OF SEEKING THE CHAIRMANSHIP OF THE DPP': CHANG

TEXT.P: Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chang Chun-hsiung said Monday that he "is not planning and has no intention" of serving as the chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Chang made the remarks after reports tipped him as the most likely person to take over the helm of the DPP after DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang resigned to take responsibility for the drubbing the party took in Saturday's city and county chief elections. The DPP managed to secure only six of 23 seats up for grabs, while the main opposition Kuomintang took 14 seats, including the key Taipei County magistrate position.
According to the DPP charter, the party's central standing committee will first nominate an acting chairman and then decide on a date for members to elect a new chairman.

Reports said that several other DPP heavyweights, including Premier Frank Hsieh and Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun, had their reputations damaged by the party's lackluster showing despite their strenuous stumping efforts, and that Chang, with his credentials including serving multiple terms as a legislator and premier, seems the most suitable person to take over the daunting task.
But in an interview with CNA Monday, Chang said, "I have no intention to take over the chairmanship of the DPP at the present time."
Chang denied that he went to the Presidential Office to discuss the possibility amid media reports that his limousine was spotted entering the Presidential Office earlier in the day.
He also praised Su's resignation as setting a good example for politicians, although "he is not to be blamed for the loss."

He attributed the DPP's losses to the party's betrayal of its founding goals of integrity, reform and national identity, as well as the effect of a corruption scandal involving a former top Presidential Office aide.

The DPP must respond to public expectations, face squarely the results the poor showing in the elections, and engage in serious soul- searching, Chang said, adding that this is the only possible path for the DPP, and the only way to touch the hearts of the people.

Looking ahead to cross-strait relations after the elections, he said the government's stance is consistent, and will take into consideration national security, national identity and current cross-strait trade and social exchanges.
He also said he hopes that a planned economic development conference will forge a national consensus on cross-strait policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL CHENG KUNG UNIVERSITY AERONAUTICS PROFESSOR HONORED

TEXT.P: Taipei, Dec. 5 (CAN) Hsiao Fei-bin, a pioneer in unmanned aircraft and a professor at National Cheng Kung University (NCKU) , has been elected a member of the prestigious American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronauts (AIAA) 2006, the University said Monday.
Hsiao is currently teaching at the university's Department of Aeronautics and Astronautics.

The university said that being a member of the AIAA is equivalent to being a member of Academia Sinica, Taiwan's highest academic research body. Being a member of the AIAA is considered to be the highest honor of scholars in this specific field, and only 30 people are selected each year.
Hsiao specializes in the research of unmanned aircraft, fluid dynamics, microfluids and nanotechnology. He has taught at NCKU for 20 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL ABORIGINAL EDUCATION CONFERENCE OPENS

TEXT.P: The International Aboriginal Education Conference covering issues regarding aboriginal education, the revival of indigenous languages and the significance of public institutes, opened at National Chengchi University (NCCU) in Mucha, Taipei Monday with the participation of 16 academics from around the Pacific Rim.

The two-day conference, organized by the NCCU Center for Aboriginal Languages, Cultures and Education, was highlighted by the presentation of a number of research papers authored by noted anthropologists, historical linguists and political sociologists from Fiji, Japan, China, Taiwan and the United States.

Presenters of the research papers included Kayano Sigeru, an anthropologist and curator of the Ainu Museum in Japan, and Steven Ratuva, a political sociologist with the Pacific Institute of Advanced Studies in Development and Governance under the University of the South Pacific in Fiji, the sponsors said.
Other prominent presenters included John Mayer, a professor in philology with the University of Hawaii, and Teng Xing, a professor in ethnic studies with China's Central University for Nationalities.

A roundtable discussion is scheduled to be held Tuesday, with several Republic of China officials and academics, including Walis Peilin, minister of the Council of Indigenous Peoples and Lee Yung-te, minister of the Council for Hakka Affairs, meeting the foreign academics to exchange views on matters of mutual concern and interest.

The conference attendees are also expected to travel to southern Taiwan after the discussion for field trips to a Rukai tribal village in Maolin township and the Hakka rural township of Meinung to gain a better understanding of the development and conservation of native languages in these two areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACTIVISTS URGE CHEN TO WIPE OUT CORRUPTION TO RESTORE PUBLIC'S FAITH

TEXT.P: A group of social activists urged President Chen Shui-bian Monday to step up the campaign against official corruption to regain the public's faith in government.

The activists, led by Chien Hsi-chieh, convener of the Alliance of Fairness and Justice, made the call after Chen's Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) suffered a drubbing in Saturday's local government chief elections.

Chien said the ruling party's poor showing in the "three-in-one" elections could primarily be attributed to a recent string of corruption scandals, including the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. scandal and the "vultures" insider-trading case.

"President Chen should demonstrate his determination to stamp out official corruption by pushing for a speedy and comprehensive inquiry into all corruption charges now that the emotionally-charged atmosphere has subsided with the conclusion of the elections, " Chien said.
He also urged President Chen to replace two top officials -- State Public Prosecutor-General Wu Ying-chao and Financial Supervisory Commission Chairman Kong Jaw-sheng.
Claiming that Wu was once involved in a Taiwan Pineapple Corp. profiteering scandal, Chien said Wu is not suitable for the top prosecutorial post.

Even though Wu was not given any sentence in that case, Chien claimed that the case has put Wu's integrity in question. "Moral integrity is the fundamental qualification of law enforcement officers," he stressed.

Chien said he is hopeful that the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan can pass a draft package of revisions to the Court Organic Law proposed by a local association of reform-minded prosecutors as soon as possible to ensure prosecutorial neutrality and independence.
As to Kong, Chien claimed that Kong is versed in marketing and public relations, not financial supervision.

Given Kong's previous professional background as a partner of a foreign financial group, Chien said he doubts that Kong has the guts to stand up to big financial holding groups and strictly carry out financial supervisory work, citing as proof the "vultures" stock insider-trading scandal earlier this year.

The DPP won just six of the 23 mayoral and magistrate posts up for grabs in the Dec. 3 elections, while the main opposition Kuomintang captured 14 seats, including the most populous Taipei County and two constituencies that used to be the DPP's strongholds -- Ilan County and Chiayi City.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEUTRAL MEDIA WOULD BOOST JUSTICE IN SOCIETY: CHEN CHU

TEXT.P: Biased media seriously influences Taiwanese politics and this should be rectified so that Taiwan becomes a just society, Chen Chu, a former labor affairs chief said Monday.

Chen made the statement during a speech at Chang Jung Christian University in the southern county of Tainan. She stepped down as the head of the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) after she was allegedly involved in the Kaohisung mass rapid transit scandal when Thai workers revolted against reported unreasonable management in August.

"It is normal that media has a stance. I also support them to keep on following government scandals. But media should remain neutral. It should not excessively beautify or uglify anything. It's not good for society if media is biased, influencing the country's politics," Chen said.

Mentioning the influence of media, she gave herself as an example and said that some media outlets that have a particular stance intentionally highlighted uncertain facts and make accusations using falsehoods to please the audience.
"The person accused will then have to spend even more effort in clarifying his integrity. But this part is often ignored by the public and the accused becomes the victim," Chen said.

Commenting on the recent elections, Chen said that as a member of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), she used to do all she could to avert the combination of the three local-level elctions because the more grass-roots elections there are, the more they reach the basic-level voters, which favors the main opposition Kuomintang.

"Combined with elections for city mayors and county magistrates, it can but be a burden to the DPP, " she said, but for the sake of saving social costs, she still went along with the policy of the Executive Yuan, the CLA's supervising authority.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANOTHER ACCIDENT HITS KAOHSIUNG RAPID TRANSIT RAILWAY PROJECT

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung rapid transit railway project was hit by another accident Sunday that could be described as the "most serious" accident affecting public safety since construction began in 2001, the chief executive officer of the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) admitted Monday.
KRTC President Fan Chen-po said no human error was involved in the accident and that it will take about NT$500 million to resolve the problem.

According to Fan, construction workers digging a retention pond 33 meters underground in the O7 station on the project's Orange Line apparently hit a high waterbed, causing water to spring up. A section of the tunnel measuring about 100 meters was ruptured by the force of the water.

The water also caused a 30-meter-long section of pavement on Kaohsiung's Chungcheng Road to cave in. As an emergency measure, KRTC workers worked nonstop for more than 12 hours and poured some 8,000 cubic meters of gravel and soil into the hole. By noon Monday, the water from the underground source had stopped.
Fan said that Chungcheng Road will need to be cordoned off for seven to 10 days for safety concerns because of the accident.

The latest mishap is believed to be the eighth major accident of the Kaohsiung rapid transit railway project that has affected public safety. In 2004, the director of the Department of Rapid Transit System under the Kaohsiung city government resigned to take responsibility for a series of accidents.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNREASONABLE FOR PRESIDENT TO APOLOGIZE FOR ELECTION DEBACLE: MOFA

TEXT.P: It is "unreasonable" to demand that President Chen Shui-bian apologize for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) poor performance in Saturday's local government elections, Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen claimed Monday.

Rather, society should give the president kudos for his boldness in reforming the election agenda by combining three elections in one when he knew it would be to the disadvantage of his party, he said.

He was responding to opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou's suggestion that it would help reconcile the nation's ruling and opposition parties if the president could offer an apology. Ma claimed that he made his suggestion for the sake of improved communication between the DPP and the opposition.
The DPP should do deep soul-searching after its ignominious defeat at the hands of the KMT, he said. The DPP won only six against the KMT's 14 of 23 city and county government seats.
According to the foreign minister, a popularly elected president "stands above party politics" and has no need to apologize for his party's failure in elections.
In Tainan City, Mayor Hsu Tien-tsai of the DPP said the party's dismal performance shows that there are serious problems within the party.
Hsu, who succeeded in his re-election bid, said President Chen's charisma has faded, but people should not blame him for his good intentions to help boost the campaigns of DPP candidates.
The effects of the president's stumping were "not so good as imagined, " probably because there was a gap between what he said and what the people wanted, said the mayor.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR TO VISIT BRITAIN IN FEBRUARY

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou is scheduled to visit Britain, Ireland and Belgium in early February next year, an official of the Taipei city government said Monday.
Lin Sheng-chung, director of the city government's Department of Economic Development, said Ma's trip will focus on trade and city development exchanges.
He will call on officials in charge of foreign relations in the European Union and the Taiwan British Business Council, as well as visiting London Mayor Aldeman Robert Finch.
As the City of London is Britain's financial hub, and as Finch met Ma in Taipei, a meeting between the two in London was arranged, Lin said.

Ma also plans to speak at Cambridge University, Oxford University or the London School of Economics and Political Science, Lin said, probably giving an introduction to Taipei's trade and investment environment.
He will also meet with academics from think tanks, research institutes, business councils during his visit, Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP URGENTLY NEEDS TO FIND A NEW LEADER

TEXT.P: The defeat of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the Dec. 3 elections has driven its chairman Su Tseng-chang to resign and one of the party's most urgent post-election tasks will be to find a new party chief at a time when the party is seriously marred by a series of corruption scandals, political watchers said Monday.

Although the miserable election results have critically hurt the DPP's power base, the party still needs to get back on its feet and prepare itself for next year's Taipei and Kaohsiung mayoral elections, analysts said, pointing out that the party cannot turn into a majority without a leader.

The DPP took only six -- all in southern Taiwan -- of the 23 city mayor and county magistrate seats in the local government elections, the same result as its poor showing in the 1993 elections, when the DPP was also at a low ebb.

To date, no DPP stalwart has displayed an interest in taking over the party's top post, although party insiders have that said there should be no lack of hopefuls for the position. The analysts said that this should provide a good platform from which the party can undergo a power restructuring and forge strategies to face the coming elections.

Whoever takes the DPP chairmanship will have an impact on the party's power center and its influence is expected to last through the 2008 presidential election, which is set to be a duel between the DPP and the main opposition Kuomintang, now led by the charismatic Ma Ying-jeou, whose leadership was vital to the party's landslide victory in the just-concluded local elections, analysts said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HOPEFULS FOR TAIPEI, KAOHSIUNG MAYORS DECIDED BY PRIMARIES: MA

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) candidates for next year's elections for Taipei and Kaohsiung mayors will be decided by party primaries, KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Monday.

Stressing that it is far too early to talk about the matter in detail, Ma made it clear that the party's hopefuls for the mayoral posts in the two special municipalities will be produced by party primaries and that the selection process will have nothing to do with his personal feelings.

Ma claimed that he has not heard anything about People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong's intention to run for Taipei mayor, but he said that he will arrange a meeting with Soong as soon as possible to clear up complex issues between the two leaders in the opposition "pan-blue alliance."
Ma also ruled out a reported plan to visit Washington, D.C. next year, saying that he has not received any invitation from abroad.

The KMT chairman made the remarks after his party scored a landslide victory in Saturday's local government elections by taking 14 of the 23 city mayor and county magistrate posts, well ahead of the six -- all in southern Taiwan -- taken by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.

The KMT's win, the first in a nationwide election since Ma took over the party's helm in August this year, heralds a comeback of the party in future elections, watchers said, noting that Saturday's election results are expected to influence the 2007 legislative elections and the 2008 presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FOSTER CARE CENTER OPENS IN GUATEMALA

TEXT.P: A Taiwan foster care center was opened late last month in Guatemala to take care of more than 700 children from poor families, a spokesman for the Taiwan Fund for Children and Families said Monday.

The center -- Corazon del Maiz -- is located in San Miguel Chicaj, some 65 km north of the capital, Guatemala City, to offer monetary aid and assistance in health and education to poor children and community services to families in the area, the spokesman said.
The Taiwan-based foundation sponsors more than 2,000 poor children in Guatemala -- one of Taiwan's diplomatic partners in Central America.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHIAO TUNG, CARNEGIE MELLON UNIVERSITIES FORGE COOPERATIVE TIES

TEXT.P: Hsinchu-based National Chiao Tung University and Carnegie Mellon University of the United States forged cooperative ties Monday to promote research and personnel exchanges.
Chiao Tung University President Chang Chun-yen and his counterpart from Carnegie Mellon University Jared L. Cohon signed the agreement at the Westin Hotel in Taipei.
Under the program, 10 students from each of the schools will be sent to their sister university for one semester of regular courses.

Chiao Tung University has organized a set of courses for Carnegie Mellon students, including seminars and practical training courses at science-based industrial parks around the island, the school said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-PHILIPPINES MINISTERIAL CONFAB KICKS OFF IN MANILA
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, Dec. 5 (CNA) (By Emerson Lim and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The 13th Taiwan-Philippines ministerial conference on economic cooperation kicked off Monday in Manila, co-hosted by Taiwan Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh and Philippines Secretary of Trade and Industry Peter B. Favila.

The conference was transformed from a vice-ministerial economic meeting between the two countries in 1992. Since then, it has been held alternately in Taipei and Manila in an effort to promote trade and economic relations between the two nations.

Ho attended the two-day conference accompanied by Republic of China Representative to the Philippines Wu Hsin-hsing, her deputy Chen Ruey-lung, as well as officials from the Bureau of Foreign Trade, the Export Zone Administration and ROC customs.

Welcoming Ho and her group at the opening of the event, Favila called Taiwan the Philippines' closest geographic neighbor and a close trade partner, saying the close ties can be proved by the fact that two-way trade registered an annual growth of 3 percent on average in the past five years, that Taiwan is the fifth-largest investor in the Philippines, and the signing of a memorandum on agricultural cooperation ties.

Ho said that Taiwan has invested around US$1.38 billion in the Philippines, a far smaller figure than the US$10 billion it has invested in Vietnam. In the future, efforts will be made to lobby more Taiwanese high-tech companies to invest in the Philippines, she said.

Topics of the conference include an agreement on the avoidance of double taxation, cooperation on personnel training and intellectual property protection rights, as well as the formation of an "economic corridor" between Taiwan and the Philippines that connects industrial zones in Taiwan's southern port city of Kaohsiung with the Philippines' Subic Bay and Clark industrial zones.

Ho arrived in Manila Sunday at the head of a 70-member delegation. She is scheduled to call on Philippines economic officials as well as prominent members of the business community and to inspect Subic Bay and Clark before returning to Taiwan Dec. 8.

DOC.HEADLINE: RULING PARTY TO ELECT NEW CHAIRMAN IN JANUARY AT EARLIEST

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will elect a new chairman in January at the earliest, party sources said Monday.

According to the DPP charter, if the incumbent president is a DPP member, he should concurrently serve as party chairman, but President Chen Shui-bian resigned from his post as party head in the wake of the party's lackluster performance in the legislative elections of late 2004.

DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang, who assumed the post in February this year, stepped down after the party's crushing defeat in Saturday's city and county elections. The DPP managed to take only six seats out of 23 up for grabs, compared with 14 seats taken by the main opposition Kuomintang.

The DPP will select an acting chairman in Wednesday's meeting of its Central Standing Committee. Possible acting chairman candidates include Vice President Annette Lu, Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun, Premier Frank Hsieh, acting Kaohsiung Mayor Yeh Chu-lan and Legislator Trong Chai.
The acting chairman will organize a bye-election for the party's next chairman and the party members will vote for the new leader in January at the earliest.
No one has yet to come forward to express interest in taking the helm of the party, although some DPP sources said Lu, Yu and former DPP Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung are all suitable candidates.

Media reports said Monday that Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chang Chun-hsiung is the most likely candidate, but Chang dismissed the reports, saying that he "is neither planning nor intending" to serve in that post.

DOC.HEADLINE: FLYING EYE HOSPITAL ORBIS VISITS KAOHSIUNG FOR FUNDRAISING

TEXT.P: ORBIS, the only flying eye hospital in the world, landed at Kaohsiung Monday for a two-day fundraising visit.

Since 1982, ORBIS, a DC-10 aircraft converted into a teaching facility specializing in ophthalmics, has conducted programs in 83 countries, through which more than 93,000 ophthalmologists, nurses, biomedical engineers and other health care workers have improved their abilities to treat and prevent blindness.

A group of around 20 school children led by acting Kaohsiung City Mayor Yeh Chu-lan visited the aircraft. Yeh encouraged visitors to the plane to buy ORBIS-shaped piggy banks in order to raise funds aiming at improving school children's eyesight.
She expressed her admiration for the ORBIS staff's devotion, and showed her support for their campaign to give hope to blind children.

Chien Wei-chia, executive director of the Taiwan affiliate office of Orbis said that there are currently 1.4 million children in the world suffering from blindness whose lives are at risk because of their blindness. "We hope they can be provided with help so they can see again," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Sunni Candidates in Iraq Find Enemies on All Sides
With just a little more than a week before the vote on Dec. 15 for a full, four-year Iraqi government, the Bush administration sees Sunni Arab participation as the most crucial aspect of this final stage in the political process it created after toppling Saddam Hussein. But perhaps no one has more enemies than the Sunni Arab politicians who have committed themselves to taking part in the elections. Claiming to speak for factions in the insurgency, they campaign by denouncing the Shiite-led government and American forces, yet are hounded by zealous Sunni militants like Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, who reject any involvement in the political process and brand the politicians as traitors.
Wall Street Journal: Health Crisis, Chinese Doctors Tell Patients To Pay Upfront, or No Treatment
The crisis in China's health-care system is already showing signs of holding the country back. Health-care costs are one of the main reasons Chinese save as much as 40 percent of their incomes. Fewer than one-third of China's 1.3 billion people have health insurance. More than half of all health spending is out of pocket. Health care is an issue vexing the world's most developed countries, including the U.S., where people without insurance can lose all their savings if they get sick. But in worst-case scenarios, people who need urgent care generally receive it. In the U.S., a poor family would be eligible for Medicaid. Japan and most European countries cover everyone through universal health-insurance programs. That's not the case in China, where patients are routinely denied care if they cannot come up with the money to pay for it in advance -- even in emergencies.

DOC.HEADLINE: TEACHERS UNION SUGGESTS EVALUATION OF MOE

TEXT.P: The National Teachers' Association (NTA) suggested Monday that its members be given a chance to evaluate the Ministry of Education (MOE) and its education policies.

The NTA said teachers are responsible for just part of the factors that decide a nation's quality of education, the other factors being education policy, school organization, education budget, size of the school and size of the class.

Most of these key factors that make up the educational environment are beyond the control of teachers, and therefore they should not be held accountable for the poor environment that might have been caused by poor policy, it said.

The association made the proposal after the ministry launched a program to evaluate teachers' professional performance, a program that it fears will not achieve its purpose because it fails to set clearly defined criteria for evaluating performance.
The association is also worried that evaluators might not be professional enough to assess teachers' performances and that procedures have not been properly set up to implement the program.
In fact, it said, a well-rounded "education evaluation system" should include evaluations of the MOE and its policies, as well as school administrations.

As to the program for evaluating teachers' performance, which requires those judged to be poor achievers to submit an "improvement plan" within one month of receiving the judgment, NTA officials said some of the problems leading to poor performance might not be caused by the teachers themselves but by the teaching environment or outside interference.

If the problems have been caused by non-teacher factors such as poor policy or inadequate administrative support, of which the suspected teacher cannot request an improvement, then this means the MOE is responsible for demanding performance from teachers without ever having to be held responsible, NAT noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP WHIP PUSHING FOR PFP-KMT MERGER BEFORE LUNAR NEW YEAR

TEXT.P: A whip of the opposition People First Party's (PFP) legislative caucus said Monday that he is seeking support from PFP legislators to sponsor a proposal that the PFP and its "pan-blue alliance" partner, the Kuomintang (KMT) , be merged before the next Lunar New Year, which falls on Jan. 29.

Sun Ta-chien, deputy convener of the PFP legislative caucus, told reporters that the proposal will be presented to the PFP headquarters to urge the party leadership to speed up the handling of the matter.
He said he raised a similar proposal shortly after he was re-elected legislator last year, but the party dismissed his proposal because his view was at odds with the policy line at the time.

Sun warned that the longer the merger is delayed, the more difficult it will be for the issue to be resolved, because the rift between the two parties will only become wider as a result of election friction.

He said that with the next mayoral elections for Taipei and Kaohsiung only a year away, the PFP and the KMT must work out their differences as soon as possible to allow enough time to prepare for the elections.

He also called on the KMT to demonstrate its sincerity for the idea of a merger. He said both parties should not think only about the benefits for themselves, or the issue will be trapped in a vicious circle.

The PFP was founded by James Soong in 2000 after he -- a member of the KMT at the time -- ran as an independent in the presidential election that year but failed. Like the KMT, the PFP is against Taiwan independence and favors Taiwan's eventual reunification with China.

The party has maintained a close working relationship with the KMT in the legislature, but the relationship is sometimes tense, especially in election years, because they have to compete for support from the same voters.

DOC.HEADLINE: RULING PARTY TO REFLECT UPON ITSELF FOR FRESH START

TEXT.P: Major factions within the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Monday they will accept the electorate's decision on the party with humility and engage in serious "soul-searching" before making a fresh start.

They made the remarks following the crushing defeat of the DPP in Saturday's city and county chief elections during which the party only managed to garner six seats out of 23 up for grabs, compared with 14 seats taken by the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT).

Gao Jyh-peng, secretary-general of the Justice Alliance faction, which is closely related to President Chen Shui-bian, said he supports reforms and that everyone in the party should pool their wisdom to try to bring the party out of the woods.

Legislator Lin Cho-shui of the New Tide faction said that whether the Cabinet is reshuffled or the premier changed, the party should respect the power of the president, although he expressed the hope that Chen will give the Cabinet a free hand to do what it sees fit so that he will have time to think about long-term matters.

Legislator Hsu Kuo-yung of the Welfare State faction said a Cabinet reshuffle should start after the Legislative Yuan completes its review of the government budget, and that the scale of the reshuffle should give the people a "fresh feeling" of the party.

President Chen had yet to make public appearance since Saturday's debacle. He canceled his scheduled itinerary Monday morning amid reports that he was discussing the post-election situation with high-ranking party and government officials.

Responding to Legislator Lin Chung-mo's suggestion that opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong serve as premier after the elections, Gao said there is zero possibility of such an outlandish proposal being made.
Gao noted that KMT candidate Lu Kuo-hua trampled DPP candidate Chen Ding-nan in the Ilan county magistrate election, breaking a DPP stronghold of 24 years in the northeastern county.
He said Chen Ding-nan garnered more votes than popular Ilan County Magistrate Liu Shou-cheng when he sought another term four years ago, but Chen still lost to Lu.

He attributed Lu's performance to what he described as the "Ma phenomenon, " referring to the new popular KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou, whose presence created a frenzy whenever he stumped for KMT candidates around the island.
"The future rival of the DPP is Ma, and the party should consider how to deal with this," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT WANTS PREMIER TO REMAIN IN POST: SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh offered to resign immediately after the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) suffered a humiliating defeat in Saturday's local government elections, but President Chen Shui-bian has rejected Hsieh's offer, a government spokesman said Monday.

Government Information Office Minister Pasuya Yao was responding to a call from the DPP's "pan-green camp" ally -- the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) -- that Hsieh should step down to assume the responsibility for the DPP administration's lackluster administrative record, which the TSU said has been a critical factor in the "pan-green camp's" drubbing in the elections.
The DPP won just six of the 23 mayoral and magistrate posts up for grabs, while the TSU came away empty-handed. DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang quit shortly after the electoral outcome became clear.

"Hsieh informed Chen of his decision to resign no later than Su, but the president rejected his offer. As keeping the administration afloat and maintaining domestic political stability are as important as taking the blame for the election defeat, Chen decided that the premier needs to stay to round off the DPP's unaccomplished reform initiatives," Yao said.
Hsieh took a day off Monday to undergo a long-scheduled physical checkup which gave him a clean bill of health, Yao said.
The premier had a working dinner with his close aides, including Cabinet Secretary-General Cho Jung-tai and Yao.
According to Yao, Hsieh will return to work Tuesday. High on his agenda is paying a visit to Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng to seek his support for the central government's 2006 budget bill.

DOC.HEADLINE: PLAN TO BUILD FAST-ATTACK MISSILE BOATS MIGHT BE DELAYED: MND

TEXT.P: A plan to build a fleet of 30 new fast attack missile boats might be delayed due to complaint by a private shipyard against the state-run China Ship Building Corporation (CSBC), which was awarded the construction contract, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) said Monday.

To date, only one prototype boat has been built out of the "Kuang-Hua Six" plan worth NT$13.2 billion (US$394 million) . The CSBC, winner of the tender in which private shipbuilding companies Jong Shyn and Ching Fu took part, was awarded a contract June 24 to build the remaining platforms.

However, Jong Shyn Shipbuilding contested the results of the tender, claiming that the procurement committee favored the CSBC, making the tender unfair. The plea was not accepted, so the company further appealed to the Public Construction Commission under the Executive Yuan, claiming that the decision attributing the contract to the CSBC was defective.
Navy Chief of Staff Vice Admiral Lee Hai-tung said the "Kuang-Hua Six" plan might be delayed following the Jong Shyn Shipbuilding company's contesting of the decision.
Lee explained that the MND assigned the case to the Bureau of Investigation under the Ministry of Justice (MJIB) in October, and the MND asked the CSBC to suspend the contract in November.
The MND's Procurement Center and Evaluation Committee evaluated the CSBC as the best tender following discussions in mid-November, Lee said.
Under current regulations, Jong Shyn can still file complaints with the procurement committee or the Public Construction Commission or even file a law suit, Lee said.
Against this backdrop, Lee said the plan may be delayed.
The "Kuang-Hua Six" plan is to build 150-ton fast attack missile that could be platforms for four Hsiungfung II surface-to-surface missiles.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO TOP 'PAN-BLUE ALLIANCE' LEADERS TO MEET SOON: LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong will meet with Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou in the near future to discuss future relations between the two "pan-blue alliance" parties, a PFP lawmaker said Monday.

Legislator Ko Shu-min made the remarks after paying a visit to Soong amid reports that many PFP lawmakers plan to quit the party in preparation for joining the Kuomintang (KMT) following the KMT's resounding success in Saturday's local government chiefs election.

According to Ko, Soong stressed during their meeting that he is not opposed to a merger between the PFP and the KMT. The two parties, known locally the "pan-blue alliance, " jointly control the Legislative Yuan and have boycotted the Democratic Progressive Party administration's major policy initiatives at every turn.
Soong also reaffirmed his commitment to a continued PFP-KMT partnership in the legislature, Ko said, adding that Soong doesn't harbor any preset stance on a long-talked-about merger.

Ko said Soong will meet with PFP lawmakers in coming days to consult and integrate their opinions on the coming days in preparation for talks with KMT Chairman Ma on the two parties' future relations.

The PFP is a KMT splinter party founded in 2000 after Soong lost his presidential bid by a slim margin. Soong, who used to be the KMT's all-powerful secretary-general, ran as an independent in the 2000 presidential race.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN URGES E.U. NOT TO LIFT ARMS BAN AGAINST CHINA
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, Dec. 5 (CNA) (By Huang Kwang-chun and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has urged the European Union in a recent interview with an Italian 24-hour satellite TV news channel not to lift its ban on arms sales to China.

In his interview with Pio D'Emilia of Italian satellite TV RAI News 24 broadcast Sunday, Chen said he was baffled as to why the E.U. would consider a removal of the arms embargo against China since human rights conditions there have not made any improvements and even deteriorated, citing as proof China's persecution against Falun Gong followers.
The European Union imposed the arms ban in 1989 over the Tiananmen massacre in which Chinese troops brutally crushed a pro-democracy demonstration in Beijing.
In the interview, Chen also expressed his deep regret over E.U. member countries' rejection to his visit for fears of offending China which has never ceased its diplomatic suppression against Taiwan.
Chen said the E.U.'s snub to Taiwan's popularly elected leader is an insult not only to him but also to its 23 million people.
Noting that Europe has been widely admired by the people of Taiwan as a "cradle of human rights, " Chen said he feels very bad about being put on the E.U.'s "blacklist" of persona non grata.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Dec. 6, or the sixth day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1774: Austria becomes the first nation to establish a state education system.
1889: Jefferson Davis, the first and only president of the Confederate States of America, dies at the age of 81. He was captured by Union soldiers in 1865 and imprisoned for two years. Although indicted for treason, he was never prosecuted.
1907: One of the worst coal mine disasters in U.S. history occurs at Mononagh, West Virginia, killing 361 people.
1911: Mongolia is declared a Russian protectorate.
1917: The Republic of Finland is proclaimed.
1917: The steamship Mont Blanc collides with the steamship Imo in Halifax, Canada, killing more than 1,500 people, injuring 8,000 others, and destroying a large part of the city.
1921: Britain signs a peace treaty with Ireland under which the Irish Free States is established and Ireland accepts Dominion status.
1941: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt appeals to Japan's Emperor Hirohito for peace.
1943: The United States, Britain and the Soviet Union issue the Joint Declaration of the Tehran Conference.
1957: The United States fails in the launching of its first satellite.
1960: Taiwan Province implements the use of media broadcasts for the first time in the history of Republic of China military service in order to muster the required number of reservists.
1971: India recognizes the Democratic Republic of Bangladesh.
1973: The United Nations decides to establish the United Nations University in Tokyo.
1975: U.S. President Gerald Ford arrives in the Philippines for talks on new terms for U.S. air and naval basses in the country.
1975: President Yen Chia-kan receives Mrs. Paul Norman Brown, national president of the American Legion Ladies' Auxiliary, at the Presidential Office.
1979: The Communist Chinese ban the sticking of "big character posters" on Beijing's wall of democracy.
1980: The 1980 Supplementary Parliamentarian election sends 70 members to the Legislative Yuan and 76 to the National Assembly.
1986: Eighty-four members are newly elected to the Legislative Yuan and seventy-three members are newly elected to the National Assembly in the 1986 legislative by-elections. Voter turnout is 65.4 percent of the 11.8 million eligible registered voters.
1988: The ROC Legislative Yuan is paralyzed by fist-fighting, as the chairman for the first time asks police to maintain order.
1989: The worst mass killing in Canadian history takes place when a gunman shoots 13 female students to death at the University of Montreal before killing himself.
1990: President Saddam Hussein announces that all 3,400 foreign hostages held in Iraq since the invasion of Kuwait are now free to leave.
1990: Gen. Hussain Mohammed Ershad steps down at the height of a pro-democracy movement in Bangladesh.
1996: The Legislative Yuan revises the Labor Standards Law so that employees in nearly all industries will be covered by the end of 1998.
1999: The ROC-Japan Economic Conference opens in Tokyo.
2000: The Republic of China's Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs removes restrictions on workers from the Philippines, with the change effective retroactively to Dec. 1.
2000: Salvadoran President Francisco Guillermo Flores Perez arrives in Taipei for an official visit.
2001: Taiwan's two largest opposition parties, the Kuomintang and the People First Pary, decide not to participate in the "national stabilization alliance" that has been proposed by President Chen Shui-bian.
2001: The computer virus "Goner, " first found in the United States, is rampant in Hong Kong with at least 16 companies' computer systems being hit.
Motse's lesson of the day: "When the administration of the ruler does not answer to the desires of the subjects, it shows a lack of understanding of the approvals and disapprovals of the subjects. When there is no such understanding, then the good will not be discovered and rewarded and the bad will not be punished."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PEOPLE WANT LEADERS TO PROMOTE CROSS-STRAIT PEACE: STATE DEP'T
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 5 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: Although it is too early to say what impact the results of Taiwan's "three-in-one" elections will have on cross-Taiwan relations, Taiwan voters will continue to request that their elected leaders promote cross-strait peace and stability, a U.S. State Department deputy spokesman said Monday.

"As far as the elections go -- obviously, they're an internal matter for Taiwan -- we certainly see in them a reflection of the strength and vitality of democracy in Taiwan, " Adam Ereli also said at a regular press briefing.
In Saturday's local elections, the opposition Kuomintang won 14 of the 23 mayor and magistrate posts up for grabs, as well as a majority of the seats in the council and township chief elections.
In response to a question regarding what impact the election results will have on cross-strait relations, Ereli said that it's a little too early to tell.

"But I would say that we certainly hope and are confident that the people of Taiwan will continue to hold their elected leaders, from whatever party, accountable for promoting peace and stability across the strait in keeping with Taiwan's interests, " he added.

Asked whether the United States is concerned about a possible split within Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party in the wake of the elections, Ereli declined to give any comment, saying only that "the progress and process of internal Taiwanese politics is something that we don't opine about, and it's a matter for the Taiwanese people to decide."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. SEES ELECTIONS AS DISPLAY OF TAIWAN DEMOCRACY'S VITALITY: ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 5 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: The United States affirms Taiwan's "three-in-one" elections held Saturday as well as encourages both sides of the Taiwan Strait to solve their problems through dialogue and hopes the island will reinforce its determination to defend itself, Taiwan's top envoy in Washington, D.C. said Monday.
David Lee, the Republic of China's representative to the United States, made the comments after exchanging views with relevant U.S. State Department officials in the wake of the elections.

The opposition Kuomintang claimed an overwhelming victory in the islandwide local elections by winning 14 of the 23 mayor and magistrate posts up for grabs as well as a majority of the seats in the council and township chief elections.

Pointing out that U.S. President George W. Bush had praised Taiwan's freedom and democracy as a model which others, including Beijing, could learn from in a speech he delivered during his visit to Tokyo last month, Lee said that the U.S. officials think the elections once again demonstrated the vitality of Taiwan's democracy.

The envoy, who will return to Taiwan soon to give a regular report on his official work, also said that current U.S.-Taiwan relations are relatively good and stable and that the channels of communications between the two countries are also smooth and "quite better than a year ago."
Lee also said that there are three main issues that might affect whether the relationship between Taiwan and the United States will continue to be strengthened or not.

The first is the arms procurement bill which has been stalled in the Legislative Yuan for months. Washington has expressed concerns about the bill's fate and hopes Taiwan will reinforce its determination to defend itself, according to Lee.
In addition, the U.S. side is also concerned about the development of cross-strait relations and hopes Taipei and Beijing can engage in a dialogue.

Furthermore, the United States hopes that Taiwan's Department of Health experts can complete their examination work related to a mad cow disease case in the U.S. and resume imports of American beef as soon as possible. Taiwan suspended U.S. beef imports after a second case of mad cow disease was confirmed in the U.S. in June of this year.
