DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 2.21 points to close at 6,350.52.
The bourse opened at 6,319.13 and fluctuated between 6,364.17 and 6,318.95 during trading. A total of 4.54 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$114.21 billion (US$3.41 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with banking and financial shares moving up the most at 1.3 percent, followed by textile stocks at 1.1 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.7 percent, paper and pulp issues at 0.6 percent, foodstuff issues at 0.5 percent, and construction issues at 0.4 percent.
The other two major stock categories lost ground, with cement stocks and machinery and electronics shares both moving down at 0.5 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 555 to 490, with 167 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S.-TAIWAN FTA NOT LIKELY WITHIN NEXT FEW YEARS: USTR OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 6 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: A ranking U.S. Trade Representative Office (USTR) official said Tuesday it is not likely that the United States and Taiwan will be able to reach a free trade agreement within the next couple of years as talks on many bilateral trade issues have yet to be completed.
Matt Niemeyer, assistant U.S. trade representative, made the remarks in response to a media question raised regarding the issue.

Taiwan has been working hard toward signing a free trade agreement with the United States, and several U.S. congressmen have requested recently that the Bush administration accelerate its steps towards the establishment of a free trade accord with Taiwan.

For instance, Pete Sessions (R-Texas), a member of the U.S. House of Representatives, urged in a letter sent to U.S. Trade Representative Rob Portman last week that the administration should establish a free trade relationship with Taiwan as soon as possible as "the island is the United States' ninth largest trading partner and a longstanding political ally whose democratic achievement is a model for the international community."

However, Portman said that Washington and Taipei are currently holding talks on a series of issues related to intellectual property rights and the opening of Taiwan's telecommunications and pharmaceutical markets, stressing that the island must first resolve these problems before it can be placed on the U.S. list for FTA talks.

The two countries resumed in November of last year their Trade and Investment Framework Agreement (TIFA) talks, and they are set to hold a similar meeting next month in Taipei to discuss issues regarding further liberalization of the Taiwan market.
According to Portman, the TIFA talks are a prelude to the holding of FTA negotiations between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTRY TO ASSIST MAYOR MA IF HE VISITS UNITED STATES

TEXT.P: If Taipei mayor and opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou decides to take a trip to the United States next February, the ministry will provide necessary assistance, Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen said Tuesday.

Chen made the remarks after reports quoted Chang Ta-tung, deputy representative of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and its ally, the People First Party, stationed in the U.S. as having said that Ma might visit the U.S. in February.
Chang also said that given the mayor's hectic schedule, he might incorporate the visit with one already planned in the same month to Britain, Ireland and Belgium.

Chang said that during his visit to the United States, he will call on U.S. government officials, lawmakers, the think tanks as well as members of the Taiwanese community. His stay in Washington, D.C. should not exceed four days, he added.
In Europe, Ma is scheduled to call on officials in charge of foreign relations in the European Union and the Taiwan British Business Council, as well as visiting London Mayor Aldeman Robert Finch.

Ma also plans to speak at Cambridge University, Oxford University or the London School of Economics and Political Science, probably giving an introduction to Taipei's trade and investment environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD INVITES EUROPEAN EXPERTS TO TAIWAN SPATIAL PLANNING SYMPOSIUM

TEXT.P: The government has invited a dozen European architects and scholars in national spatial development to take part in a symposium and share their experience, an official of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Tuesday.

The four-day International Seminar and Panel on European Experience and Innovation in National Spatial Planning organized by the CEPD kicked off the same day in Taipei City, On the final day of the event, the guests from France, Holland, Germany, Britain and Portugal are expected to share their opinions and ideas for Taiwan in its pursuit of high-quality urban planning and living space development.

CEPD Vice Chairman Chang Jing-sen said Taiwan hasn't adjusted its national comprehensive plans since 1996 when it mapped out a general land development plan. Over the past several years, Taiwan has experienced rapid changes in many areas, including society, economy and living environment.
To maintain its regional competitiveness in the new knowledge-based economy, the island needs to make adjustments to its out-of-date industrial and land development projects, Chang said.

The CEPD has set 2030 as the year for national spatial planning. The council hopes the foreign experts attending the seminar, including Michael Sudarskis, executive director of the International Urban Development Association, can share their experience and knowledge to help the island in its efforts to map out strategies for creating integrated living spaces with aesthetic quality.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: SEAG win just the beginning -- GMA
The 23rd Southeast Asian Games closed last night with an abundance of great expectations as the Philippines started to look forward to the future following a breast-beating overall victory that left the entire country brimming with joy and confidence.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Garcillano turns tables on solons
Accusing lawmakers of hypocrisy, the lawyer of Virgilio Garcillano yesterday named eight out of 20 to 30 congressmen who, he claimed, had talked to the former election commissioner during the 2004 polls.
The Philippine Star: 'Farewell, see you in Thailand'
The 23rd Southeast Asian Games ended the way it started -- in a burst of light and colors. Only this time, it heralded the coming of host Philippines as the new sporting king of the region.
The Manila Times: Escudero named as Garci circus begins
Former Comelec commissioner Virgilio Garcillano is scheduled to testify Wednesday at a joint hearing of the five committees that made the "Hello Garci" tapes a sensational topic that triggered a national political crisis.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Opposition Union achieves consensus on withdrawal from Iraq and rights of de facto couple.
Opposition Union leader Romano Prodi said in a rally in Umbria Monday that members of his union had achieved consensus on programs of withdrawing Italian troops from Iraq and recognizing rights and interests of the de facto couple. He said that his union will make a radical reform in Italy if they win the next general elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, dropping NT$0.032 to close at NT$33.461.
A total of US$820 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$33.493 and hit a low of NT$33.405.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT WANTS VOTE ON SUNGSHAN AIRPORT BILL IN FOUR MONTHS

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) threatened Tuesday to put to vote a bill regarding opening Sungshan Airport in Taipei to flights to Macau and Hong Kong if all parties at the legislature fail to come up with an agreement on the issue after four months of negotiations.

Speaking at a news conference, Tina Pan Wei-kang, a whip of the KMT legislative caucus, said that the KMT will seek to force the bill through the Legislative Yuan with a vote if the various parties fall short of an agreement on the issue in four months -- a grace period requested by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , out of national security concerns.
Pan said that the KMT will do its best to negotiate with other parties to have the bill clear the Legislative Yuan -- an issue beneficial both to the people and the country, she claimed.
It is a waste that the airport in Taipei has not been fully used, as the airport only serves 285 flights per day compared to its full daily capacity of 595 flights, KMT lawmaker John Chiang said.

More than two million passengers from the greater Taipei area would be able to use the domestic airport in Taipei to fly to China, Hong Kong and Macau after it is opened to serve that end, Chiang said.

Chiang put forth a petition endorsed by 116 legislators from various political parties, including 13 from the ruling DPP, to the Executive Yuan last month, demanding that the government permit Sungshan Airport to operate flights to Hong Kong and Macau.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PAN-BLUE' LAWMAKERS AGAIN BLOCK KEY GOVERNMENT BILLS

TEXT.P: Lawmakers of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) blocked the U.S. arms purchase and other major government bills at the legislature's Procedures Committee Tuesday, triggering a ruling party legislator's call on the opposition to show some modesty.

Kuan Pi-ling of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), which was trounced in Saturday's local government elections, said the "pan-blue alliance" won 660,000 more votes than in the previous election while the "pan-green" camp of the DPP and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) won 30,000 more.

This means that KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou got a better score in his "entrance exam" than President Chen Shui-bian in his "mid-term" test, but the difference was just 630,000 votes, and the winner should be a bit humbler, she said.
Humility, apparently, was not in the opposition's vocabulary, as "pan-blue" lawmakers continued to refuse President Chen's nominations for the Control Yuan.

The "pan-blue alliance" legislators also killed off a DPP proposal to invite the president to make a national security report to the legislature, knowing he would use the opportunity to lobby for his government's military weapons procurement bill.

Also blocked from being put on the legislative agenda were 20-some other DPP-proposed bills, including amendments to the referendum law, a statute on political parties' "ill-gotten" assets, and compensations for victims and bereaved families involved in the Feb. 28, 1947 incident.
Among the blocked bills was a TSU proposal that calls for the legislature to set up a "files studying committee" to tackle party assets that had been obtained through dubious means.

What the DPP and KMT caucuses did agree to tackle at the Dec. 9 legislative meeting was amendments to the banking law concerning the excessively high interest rates charged by banks on credit cards and the issue of many young people overusing their credits, failing to clear their debts and becoming so-called "slaves to credit cards."

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP WILL DECIDE ON MERGER WITH KMT BEFORE END OF YEAR: PFP LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: The People First Party (PFP) will decide before the end of the year whether to merge with the Kuomintang (KMT) , or just keep cooperating with the party, PFP legislative caucus whip Daniel Y. C. Huang said Tuesday.

Speaking at a news conference at the Legislative Yuan, Huang said that the issue has dragged on for a long time and that the Dec. 3 election results showed that the public wants the "pan blue alliance" to keep the ruling party in check.
"Now is the time to settle [the merger] issue," he added.

Most PFP lawmakers are in favor of giving the party leadership 15 days to come up with concrete suggestions on the issue, and support the idea of the party dealing with the matter through a democratic process.

PFP Chairman James Soong will put himself above the fray to help forge a consensus within the party, but the opinions of individual lawmakers will be fully respected, Huang said, adding that if the PFP opts for a merger, it may take from three to five months to accomplish this through party-to-party negotiations.
As to the question of when Soong plans to meet with KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou, Huang said that Soong can meet Ma any time, any place.

The "pan blue alliance" of the KMT, the PFP and the New Party won 16 out of the 23 city mayor and county magistrate posts up for grabs in the weekend elections, while the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) won only six, all in southern Taiwan. The Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), the DPP's ally in the "pan green" camp, did not win any of the posts.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER TO STAY ON FOR TIME BEING

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Tuesday that he offered his resignation to President Chen Shui-bian twice but then decided to stay on after the president conveyed to him that stability must be the top priority at this stage.

The premier made the remarks to reporters during a visit to Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng to discuss matters concerning bills and government budgets. This was Hsieh's first visit to the legislature since the ruling Democratic progressive Party's crushing defeat in Saturday's local elections in which the DPP managed only six out of 23 seats up for grabs, while the main opposition Kuomintang took 14 seats.

Hsieh, who assumed the premiership in February, said that a Cabinet reshuffle is necessary in the wake of the major setback. "The scale of the reshuffle will be decided by the president based on considerations of the overall situation, " he added.
If the president thinks that a major reshuffle is needed, and even that the premier needs to be replaced, that "will be all right with me," he said.
Hsieh further said the DPP should seriously engage in self-examination following its major setback in Saturday's elections.

Noting that some people within the party have claimed that combining the three sets of elections into one was one of the main reasons for the DPP's poor showing Saturday, Hsieh said that he, as premier, is willing to take responsibility as it was the Executive Yuan which made the decision to combine the elections in order to reduce costs.

Combining the three local elections into a single day's vote is generally considered to favor the KMT because of its traditional grassroots support at the local level. Getting its supporters out on the same day should have had a multiplier affect for the KMT candidates' chances of winning.
However, the president's major concern at the moment is maintaining stability, and he will listen to views from all sides before making any decisions, Hsieh said.
"We can't let defeat in the elections turn into defeat for Taiwan or for Taiwan's economic fundamentals, " Hsieh stressed, adding that "we still have to continue getting things done every day."

DOC.HEADLINE: INCOME TAX LAW REVISED TO HIKE STANDARD DEDUCTION FOR MARRIED COUPLES

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan passed an amendment to the Income Tax Act Tuesday to increase the standard deduction for married couples filing their income tax jointly from NT$60,000 to NT$76,000.
The hike is retroactive to Jan. 1, 2005. The actual deduction will be NT$88,000 after it is adjusted in accordance with the rise in consumer price index.
The amendment was aimed at making the deduction for married couples equal to double that of single taxpayers, which currently stands at NT$38,000.

According to opposition Kuomintang Legislator Fei Hung-tai, who initiated the amendment, if the sum of the standard deduction for two single persons is higher than that for a married couple, it will penalize people who get married, which would not help the government's goal of increasing the country's fertility rate.

Last week, Premier Frank Hsieh also announced that the standard deduction for married couples will be raised to NT$88,000, as part of the government's measures to relieve the tax burden on taxpayers to stimulate consumer spending.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN URGED TO JOINTLY INVEST IN INDIA OR SOUTHEAST ASIA WITH TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun on Tuesday urged Japan to jointly invest in India or Southeast Asian countries with Taiwan to reduce the two countries's dependence on the Chinese market.

Yu made the appeal while receiving on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian a Japanese delegation, headed by Akio Kousai, which was here to attend the 33rd East Asian Economic Conference to be held in Taipei Wednesday.

Yu noted that although Taiwan and Japan have not maintained diplomatic ties for years, both countries are each other's important partner in economic, cultural, scientific, political and security aspects.

Noting that trade between Taiwan and Japan reached US$56.8 billion last year, accounting for 15 percent of Taiwan's total foreign trade, Yu said Japan is now the third-largest trade partner for Taiwan.

In addition, Yu added, the Japanese government offered Taiwanese tourists permanent visa-free treatment starting from this September. So far this year, the number of Japanese tourists traveling to Taiwan has topped one million in November, while the number of Taiwanese travelers visiting Japan is expected to reach 1.4 million soon.

In February, the United States and Japan decided to make Taiwan a security concern for both countries, Yu said, stressing that these things taken together are evidence that there exists a solid partnership between the two countries.
However, at a time of China's rapid economic rise, Taiwan and Japan are facing severe challenges, Yu noted, and suggested that both countries strengthen cooperative ties in diverse aspects.

According to Yu, he suggested to the then-Japanese minister of Economy, Trade and Industry Shoichi Nakagawa during his April visit to Japan that both countries cooperate under the framework of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum and the World Trade Organization by jointly investing in India or Southeast Asian countries, such as the establishment of industrial zones, as part of their global investment deployment, because this can also help them reduce investment risks and over-dependence on the Chinese market.

Yu also urged both countries to resolve their own problems so that they can sign a free trade agreement (FTA) as soon as possible, which will greatly help strengthen bilateral economic and trade exchanges in the future.
For his part, Kousai said that the East Asian Economic Conference has been held annually since 1973, with the meeting being organized alternately in Taipei and Tokyo.

At Wednesday's conference, the delegates of both countries are expected to exchange views on general economic development in East Asia, in addition to the economic and trade problems between Taiwan and Japan, Kousai said, expressing hope that the conference will result in more bilateral cooperation projects between Taiwan and Japan.

Concerning Japan's economy, Kousai said that Japan has seen growth in domestic investment, housing construction and private consumption recently and is expected to see booming exports in the future, despite some unstable factors outside the country, including high oil prices on the international market.

DOC.HEADLINE: MA SAYS HE HAS NO INTENTION TO BE DPP GOVERNMENT'S NEXT PREMIER

TEXT.P: Ma Ying-jeou, chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , said Tuesday that he will not consider serving as the next premier in the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government.

He made the remarks to news media after a Taipei City Council meeting when asked about suggestions that he may be the ideal person to be the next premier, now that the DPP government may have to reshuffle its Cabinet because of its humiliating defeat in the "three-in-one" local government elections last weekend.
KMT candidates and their "pan-blue alliance" allies have been elected mayors and magistrates in 17 cities and counties against six for DPP candidates.
Ma, who is also mayor of Taipei, explained that he has promised to his constituents in Taipei that he will finish his two terms totaling eight years as Taipei mayor until the end of next year.
"I don't like to leave things I have committed to half-done, " he said.

The KMT chairman pointed out that the KMT does not by itself enjoy a majority in the legislature and must rely on the cooperation from the People First Party (PFP) caucus and independent legislators to form a coalition to ensure a majority.
However, he said, it would be meaningless to discuss the idea of the DPP government appointing a premier from the "pan-blue alliance," because the DPP ruled out this possibility long ago.

Ma said it was deplorable that the DPP has ignored the constitutional spirit of the nation's "double government chief" system, which means that when the ruling party does not have a majority in the legislature, it should adopt a Cabinet system by allowing the largest opposition party or the coalition with the majority of seats to form the Cabinet.
Only when the ruling party enjoys a majority in the legislature, can it practice the presidential system, allowing the president to appoint the premier, who will form his Cabinet, he added.

Ma explained that when switching to the Cabinet system, the president should let the majority party in the legislature select the premier and form the Cabinet, while the president himself only plays the role of announcing the appointment.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKER URGES GOVERNMENT TAKE OVER KAOHSIUNG MRT CONSTRUCTION

TEXT.P: A legislator of the opposition Kuomintang urged the government to take over the Kaohsiung rapid transit railway construction project after a major accident triggered concerns over public safety.

On Monday, a massive earth collapse resulting from water seepage occurred at a Kaohsiung MRT line construction site. It took Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) workers over 10 hours to fill a crater measuring around 50 meters by 30 meters with several thousand cubic meters of concrete and soil. It was estimated that some NT$500 million (US$14.94 million) are needed in the efforts to repair the damage.

The accident was the eighth major construction mishap of the MRT project, and most of the accidents involving public safety have occurred on the project's Orange Line that cuts through a sandstone layer of earth.

Legislator Pan Wei-kang said the Kaohsiung rapid transit railway project needs to be entirely reviewed and examined, suggesting that the Democratic Progressive Party government take over the project out of public safety concerns.

Meanwhile, several lawmakers of opposition parties urged Premier Frank Hsieh, who farmed out the construction of the Kaohsiung MRT lines during his tenure as mayor of the southern city, to make a public explanation of the latest accident, with some demanding for the premier's resignation to shoulder responsibility.
Hsieh said he has instructed the Ministry of Economic Affairs to address the problem.

Asked if he will visit the scene of the collapse, Hsieh said: "If it's necessary." He said he hasn't yet decided whether to go and that he believes for the time being it's better for the authorities in charge of the project to take care of the aftermath.

DOC.HEADLINE: NCC MEMBERS SELECTION HEARINGS OPEN TO PUBLIC

TEXT.P: The National Communications Commission's (NCC) members review committee announced Tuesday that its hearings scheduled for three days starting on Dec. 9 will be open to the public.

People interested in watching the question-and-answer sessions can register to attend, not at the hearing room, but at an adjoining room to watch a live broadcast. Registration starts before the hearings begin at 9:00 a.m. Friday through Sunday.
The final list of successful candidates will be sent to the Executive Yuan for final approval by the premier.
Political parties have named 11 members to the review committee, who will vote on 18 nominees, 13 of whom will become NCC members.

To be successful, nominees must win more than 60 percent of the review committee ballots. If fewer than 13 pass that threshold in the first round of balloting, a second vote will be held to choose those who get more than half of the votes.

Of the 11 review committee members, four -- Wu Ching-hsiung, Chang Chin-fu, Feng Chien-san, and Lu Shih-hsiang -- were recommended by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) ; four -- Wang Chung-yu, Shao Yu-ming, Tsai Hsun-hsiung and Hsueh Hsiang-chuan -- by the opposition Kuomintang (KMT); two -- Yin Nai-ping and Lee Tung-hao -- by the People First Party (PFP); and the other one, Chen Yi-shen, by the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU).

They will choose 13 among Liu Yiu-li, Chang Tien-chin, Lu Chung-chin, Shih Chun-chi, Hsu Sung-ken, Lee Tzu-yuan, Hsieh Chin-nan, Wu Chung-chi, Liu Tzung-teh, Lin Tung-tai, Shih Shih-hao, Su Yung-chin, Lin Yi-ping, Hsu Ching-chi, Liu Kung-chung, Chen Ming-hsien, Weng Hsiu-chi and Chen Ming-hsiang.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S CROSS-STRAIT POLICY NOT TO CHANGE AFTER ELECTIONS: MAC HEAD
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 5 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Visiting Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu said Monday that Taiwan's cross-strait policy will not be swayed by the outcome of the just-concluded local elections which saw the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) suffer a crushing defeat.

On President Chen Shui-bian's remarks prior to Saturday's elections that if the "pan-blue alliance" of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) won by a landslide, cross-strait policy might be tightened, Wu said that one should know the background of Chen's remarks.

Wu said that a lot of people had expected cross-strait policy to be relaxed and bilateral relations improve after the "pan-blue alliance" won the legislative elections in late 2004. But in fact, China passed an Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan in March. China also feted Lien Chan, then KMT chairman, and James Soong, PFP chairman, in the following two months and continued to ignore the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), Wu said, resulting in the retrogression of cross-strait relations. Chen's remarks should be read in this context, he said.

Asked whether cross-strait policy will change in the wake of the DPP's drubbing in the elections, Wu said that "from the angle of the government, it will not change, " adding that these are local elections and not a referendum on cross-strait policy.
The government is promoting and will continue to promote its cross-strait policies, Wu said.

He said that a planned national economic planning development conference will probably review some cross-strait trade policies, and if some consensus is forged, the government will surely follow through.

He noted that the government is currently promoting consultations with Beijing on fully opening the nation to Chinese tourists, and cross-strait charter flights. Future consultations could cover both sides joining hands to crack down on crime, financial supervision, and protecting Taiwan businessmen's investments, Wu said.

Some Americans asked him while he was in the States whether the government will continue to promote a full opening to Chinese tourists to Taiwan. Wu told them that Taiwan has continued to promote the policy since its partial opening to Chinese tourists in Jan. 2002.
Wu said that Chinese National Tourism Administration Director Shao Qiwei's visit to Taiwan in late October was a "positive development in this respect."

DOC.HEADLINE: TARGETS OF WATER INSPECTIONS TO BE EXPANDED TO HOUSING COMMUNITIES

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) will expand the targets of its water inspections to include housing communities with more than 100 households and food courts at department stores starting next year, officials said Tuesday.

Of the reservoirs and water storage tanks at 11,094 nurseries, schools, hospitals and government agencies sampled by the EPA this year, 2 percent contained amounts of chlorine residues, E. coli and coliform bacteria that are higher than the acceptable levels. It was lower than the 5 percent of last year.

According to Yuan Shao-ying, deputy director of the EPA's Department of Environmental Sanitation and Toxic Substance Management, most of the contaminated reservoirs and water storage tanks are located underground, which makes it very easy for rain water, sewage and oil to flow in or infiltrate from cracked reservoir walls.

In addition, mixing tap water with underground water and allowing water reserves to last longer than two days will also make the chlorine residues fade away and cause the multiplication of bacteria, Yuan said.

To better protect the quality of drinking water, the EPA will funnel an extra NT$10.5 million to expand the inspections to food courts at railway stations, airports, MRT stations, hotels, department stores and shopping malls as well as housing communities with more than 100 households next year, Yuan said.
The EPA is expected to sample 12,000 establishments from this category, he said.
He suggested that people clean or maintain the reservoirs or water storage tanks at their homes every six months to ensure the safety of drinking water.

As chlorine residues will be eliminated after water is treated, water should be covered and stored in tightly sealed containers, he said, adding that drinking water should be finished in a couple of days to maintain its freshness.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE BUST FRAUD RING, ARREST 13 SUSPECTS

TEXT.P: Detectives from the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB), working with public prosecutors, conducted simultaneous raids in Taipei, Taoyuan, Miaoli and Taichung Tuesday, arresting 13 fraud suspects on charges of cheating a number of banks in Southeast Asia out of more than NT$10 million.

A CIB spokesman said the operation was launched after a task force spent four months tracing the suspects, including Wang Fang-chu, who was in charge of loan affairs at the Taipei branch of the Bank of East Asia of Hong Kong, and two of his accomplices.

The police found that from July last year, the fraud ring began to collect the information of dozens of customers from the National Credit Card Center in Taipei, change the addresses of their accounts, apply for new credit cards and debit cards, and then give them to other members in the ring to withdraw cash from banks in various Southeast Asian countries.
The suspects also managed to go through complicated application processes and get loans on credit from banks, using the identities of their victims.
During Tuesday's operation, police took away large amounts of transaction documents as evidence.
The suspects will be referred to the Public Prosecutor's Office on charges of theft, forgery and fraud.
CIB detectives are still trying to find out whether there are more accomplices still at large.

DOC.HEADLINE: IT'S 'PIG'S BLOOD CAKE,' NOT 'CHU HSUEH KAO'

TEXT.P: Foreigners visiting Taiwan's night markets might have to point and mime less to get the food they want after vendors bone up on common "marketplace" English from a new booklet published by the Ministry of the Economic Affairs.
The pamphlet will include 1,000 words in both Chinese and English covering food, apparel, cosmetics as well as everyday items, along with 168 practical conversations for the marketplace.
For example, the pamphlets will include "oyster omelet" and "pig's blood cake" to describe two traditional local delicacies.
As night markets are one of the favorite spots for foreign tourists, the pamphlet will also help foreign visitors learn a bit of the local language to make their experience in Taiwan more fun.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE NEWSPAPERS CONCERNED OVER POLITICAL DEVELOPMENTS IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Two Japanese mass-circulation newspapers -- Asahi Shimbun and Mainichi Shimbun -- published editorials Tuesday featuring concerns over Taiwan's political changes in the wake of its just-concluded local elections.

Results of the Dec. 3 "three-in-one" elections, which led to a shift in the country's political landscape, could have a significant impact on the region and on cross-Taiwan Strait relations, the newspapers said.

The Asahi said the elections were regarded as a precursor for the 2008 presidential election. The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) suffered a setback by grabbing only six out of the 23 city and county government seats while the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) took 14.

The Asahi editorial stated that the DPP's defeat was mostly attributed to a series of corruption scandals involving high-ranking officials close to President Chen Shui-bian, Chen's poor performance in dealing with economic and home affairs, and voters' discontent with Chen's China policy.
It said most Taiwan voters hope that the current cross-strait state will be maintained and that Taiwan and China will cooperate with each other in economic development.
The Mainichi Shimbun said it expects China to boost its efforts to unify with Taiwan now that the KMT has won the local elections.
China's future moves are expected to have a big impact on Taiwan's politics, the daily said.

A day earlier, another influential Japanese newspaper, the Nihon Keizai Shimbun, suggested in an editorial that the Japanese government pay close attention to the KMT's future moves, since the party's election victory has given a lift to its leader Ma Ying-jeou's chances in the 2008 presidential election.
It is also significant that Ma has been tough toward Tokyo on issues concerning territorial disputes between the two countries, the newspaper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE PASSES ACCESS TO GOVERNMENT INFORMATION LAW

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan passed the Access to Government Information Law Tuesday under which all government information must be made accessible except for national secrets, professional secrets, privacy information and intellectual property rights that must be protected.

Based on the principles of sharing information and government transparency, the government has taken reference from the examples of Sweden, Canada, Japan, the United States and other countries when drafting the law.
The law states that its purposes are to protect people's right to know, to share government information and to increase the people's understanding of public affairs.

Under the new law, which replaces the Administrative Information Law, the government must take the initiative in editing, indexing and filing all treaties, correspondence with foreign countries, laws, administrative decisions, administrative reports, budgets, research papers, procurement contracts and meeting records.

All the information must be categorized by subject, title, indexes, storage of original files, and periods to be kept on file within three months of being obtained, and then published in government publications or on government Web sites to facilitate public access.

All citizens of the Republic of China, including those living overseas, and all companies and groups registered in the country, as well as foreigners whose native countries do not prohibit ROC citizens from applying for access to their government information, can apply to gain access to the information.
The applications must be decided within 30 days after being presented and applicants can appeal if their requests are turned down.

Not included in the accessible government information are national secrets and information which, if made public, would endanger lives or interfere with criminal investigations. But when public interests are involved, even this type of information must be made accessible on certain conditions.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2005 EUROPEAN FILM FESTIVAL KICKING OFF NEXT FRIDAY

TEXT.P: The 2005 European Film Festival will be held in Taipei's Majestic Theater from Dec. 16 to 19, showing 10 recent award-winning films each from different countries.

The 2005 European Film Festival is co-organized by the European Economic and Trade Office (EETO) , the representative office of the European Commission in Taipei, in association with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), the Taipei City Government's Cultural Affairs Department and coordinated by Infine Art and Culture Exchange.

Since 2003, the European Association of Film Festivals based in Brussels, Belgium, launched the "Windows on Europe" project aimed at promoting the new generation of talented young European directors worldwide. The project selected more than 200 films from all over Europe.
The 10 films, featuring a wide range of topics such as human nature, love, desire and morality, revealing European cultural character, will be shown at the Majestic Theater in the Hsimenting area.

Tina Chen Tzu-ming, an official of the Cultural Affairs Department said while most people here are influenced by the culture and ideas from the U.S., Japan and Korea, Europe still has its growing influence in the world.
"Through foreign movies, we can more directly have an idea of what other people think," she said.

The opening ceremony of the film festival is scheduled for Thursday Dec. 15 at the Red Theater Playhouse at 2: 30 p.m. Prominent guests from the EETO, MOFA and Taipei's Cultural Affairs Bureau are awaited.

The 10 films are produced in Italy, Slovenia, Germany, Sweden, Finland, Ireland, Belgium, Netherlands, the United Kingdom and Hungary. Being in different languages, they are subtitled in English and Chinese.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CHAIRMAN OPEN TO PFP-KMT MERGER: PFP SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong is open to a proposed merger between the PFP and the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , and a meeting between the two parties' chairmen would be the sooner the better, PFP spokesman Hsieh Kung-ping said Tuesday.
Hsieh made the announcement in a news conference held at the PFP headquarters.

The PFP will set up a task force responsible for discussing the issue with the KMT, to be led by pro-merger lawmakers including caucus whip Daniel Y.C. Huang, Lin Yu-fang and Sun Ta-chien, Hsieh said, adding that the two parties should open talks on concrete issues such as personnel placement and legal affairs.

The PFP spokesman called on the KMT to quickly come up with feasible measures to help with the merger, and he asked the KMT to swiftly arrange a meeting between Soong and KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou to allow them to exchange opinions and ideas on the issue and on continued bipartisan cooperation at the Legislative Yuan.

Calls have been mounting for the two parties to merge in the wake of the Dec. 3 local elections. While the KMT overwhelmed the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , the PFP's poor showing reflects the fact that it has come to the point of becoming a marginal party on Taiwan's political map.

The PFP splintered from the KMT in 2000 following the presidential election of that year, but the two parties and the New Party jointly formed the pro-unification "pan blue alliance" against the pro-independence "pan green camp" of the DPP and the Taiwan Solidarity Union prior to the 2004 presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, CHINA SEEM ON PATH OF INTERIM AGREEMENT: U.S. ACADEMIC
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 5 (CNA) (By Olive Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan and China seem to be treading on a path of a so-called "interim agreement" on improved bilateral ties, a China expert claimed Monday.

Giving a keynote speech on cross-Taiwan Strait relations at the Elliott School of International Affairs at the George Washington University, Dean Harry Harding said Taiwan and China seem to have moved toward a path of an "interim agreement, " as both sides have taken certain measures or been forced to do so to improve two-way ties.

In view of the opposition Kuomintang's (KMT) big win in Taiwan's Dec. 3 local government elections, Beijing will not make trouble across the strait but instead will be willing to wait patiently until 2008, when the KMT is expected to win back power in next presidential election, he speculated.

After more than one year of confrontation since March 2004, when President Chen Shui-bian decided to hold a controversial public referendum along with the presidential poll and repeatedly called Taiwan an independent sovereignty, Taiwan-China ties have stabilized as both sides have sought not to step over the line drawn by the other side and with the U.S. ready to step in in the event of a potential conflict, according to Harding.
Internal and external exchanges have made cross-strait relations more amenable, he added.

Beijing offered a series of overtures to Taiwan after the KMT and People First Party chairmen visited China in spring this year, while Taiwan also moved toward further opening up to China on the tourism, academic, cultural and trade fronts.

According to Harding, various Chinese officials visiting Washington, D.C. last week told him that Beijing will put aside the unification issue while focusing on containing Taiwan independence at present. To some extent, Beijing is willing to hold talks with Chen's administration, he claimed.

The "interim agreement" to which he referred would be an accord signed by Taiwan and China under which Taiwan would not declare formal independence in exchange for a guarantee of no military attack by China during the next 30-50 years.
The interim agreement proposal was initiated by Kenneth Lieberthal, a scholar at the University of Michigan, to help Taiwan and China prevent a war.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT-CPC ECONOMIC FORUM IN TAIPEI STILL ON SCHEDULE

TEXT.P: An opposition Kuomintang official said Tuesday that the KMT's decision to hold an economic and trade forum with the Communist Party of China in Taipei remained unchanged despite reports that the venue may be shifted to Hong Kong.

Chang Jung-kung, deputy executive director of the KMT's Policy Committee, made the remarks following reports that a visit to Hong Kong planned for Wednesday by Lien Chan, the KMT's honorary chairman, is aimed at discussing with Chinese officials whether the venue for the forum can be shifted to Hong Kong after the Taiwan government rejected last month an application by Chen Yunlin, director of China's Taiwan Affairs Office, to come to Taiwan in December for the forum.

The forum would be the first of its kind between the KMT and the Communist Party of China (CPC) in more than 50 years after the CPC defeated the KMT in a civil war in China that caused the KMT to flee to Taiwan in 1949.
The reports said Lien will meet Chen and Hong Kong Special Administrative Region Chief Executive Donald Tseng in Hong Kong.

Chang reaffirmed that the KMT still maintains its decision to hold the forum in Taipei and expressed the hope that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will realize the new mainstream public opinion and political environment after its dismal performance in the Dec. 3 local government elections, and will adopt a more popular economic and trade policy toward China.

Chang also urged the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) , which is responsible for Taiwan's China policy, to reconsider its rejection of Chen's application and those of other Chinese officials invited by the KMT to come to Taiwan for the forum, claiming that by doing so it would help stabilize cross-Taiwan Strait ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: CREDIT CARD BALANCE TOPS NT$450 BILLION AS OF OCTOBER

TEXT.P: The credit balance of credit card services provided by local banks amounted to NT$453.9 billion (US$13.59 billion) at the end of October, accounting for 7 percent of the total consumer loan balance, according to a report released Tuesday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
The figure compared with NT$425 billion at the end of 2004 and NT$186.3 billion at the end of 2000.
The balance of consumer loans provided by local banks totaled NT$6.49 trillion at the end of October, up 10.7 percent from the NT$5.86 trillion posted at the end of 2004.
The consumer loans include housing loans, loans for home renovation, credit cards, workers' welfare loans and car loans.
Housing loans increased from NT$2.65 trillion at the end of 2000 to NT$3.87 trillion at the end of October, accounting for 59.6 percent of consumer loans.
Loans for home renovation totaled NT$716.2 billion, accounting for 11 percent of consumer loans.
Workers' welfare loans amounted to NT$162.2 billion, accounting for 2.5 percent of consumer loans.
Car loans increased from NT$109.5 billion at the end of 2004 to NT$138.2 billion at the end of October, accounting for 2.1 percent of consumer loans.
Other consumer loans, including cash cards, accounted for 17.7 percent, with their total amount registering NT$1.14 trillion at the end of October.

A Texas judge dismissed one charge against Representative Tom Delay on Monday but let stand two more serious charges, complicating DeLay's hopes of regaining his post as House majority leader when Congress resumes in January. The judge, Pat Priest of San Antonio, handed DeLay and two co-defendants a partial victory in dismissing charges of conspiracy to violate the election code, but left standing charges of money laundering and conspiracy to launder money against all three. The decision moves DeLay and his co-defendants, the Republican fund-raisers John D. Colyandro and James W. Ellis, a big step closer to facing trial - perhaps as soon as January - on felony charges that carry long prison terms and fines.

Anthony S. Fauci, an AIDS research pioneer who runs the infectious-diseases institute within the U.S. National Institutes of vaccine or medicine, has been playing an usual role since the terror attacks of 2001, by supporting by supporting start-up companies with NIH grants and contracts. His belief: Market forces alone won't provide the medicines Americans need for protection against bioterrorism. By doing so, he is drawing his share controversy. DOC.HEADLINE: CLA TO SUBSIDIZE FAMILIES HIRING LOCAL CAREGIVERS

TEXT.P: Taiwan families hiring local caregivers to look after sick or elderly family members will be paid a subsidy of NT$5,000 to NT$10,000 per month for up to a year, according to a draft plan unveiled Tuesday by the Council of Labor Affairs.

While the subsidy for families requiring caregiving services eight hours per day will be NT$5,000 per month, that for people requiring caregiving services for 12 hours per day will be NT$10,000 per month, according to the plan.

Employers will only be eligible for the subsidy if they hire licensed caregivers recommended by local governments and if the caregivers work for at least eight hours a day, 22 days a month, with the term of employment lasting at least one month.
However, the employers will not be subsidized if they hire their spouses or relatives for the job.
The policy is aimed at encouraging the hiring of local caregivers, who are more expensive than foreign caregivers.

From Jan. 1, Taiwan families that intend to hire foreign caregivers to take care of sick or elderly family members will have to first pass an assessment by medical institutions proving that their wards require 24-hour care.

Local social service authorities will then help these families look for local workers who are willing to accept the jobs. A family will only be permitted to hire a foreign worker if no local worker can be found to fill the position.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1.7 JOBS PER JOB-SEEKER FROM JANUARY TO OCTOBER

TEXT.P: A total of 841,000 job openings were available at government-run employment agencies in the first 10 months of this year, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) reported Tuesday.
With the number of job seekers totaling 487,000 during that period, this translates into 1.7 jobs per person.

The DGBAS report shows that the number of employers and job seekers registering with government-run employment agencies increased by 7.5 percent and 9.5 percent, respectively, compared with the same period of last year. However, the jobs available to each job seeker was lower than the 1.8 during the year-earlier period.
Most of the openings -- accounting for 374,000 -- were for workers with a senior high school diploma.
A total of 403,177 job seekers were hired from January to October, up 78.6 percent from the same period of last year, according to the DGBAS statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAMKANG UNIVERSITY PROVIDING EXTRA ENGLISH LEARNING FACILITIES

TEXT.P: Tamkang University (TKU) in the northern township of Tamshui has prepared an "English Corner" and a "Readathon" Web site aimed at improving their students' English ability, Wan Tung, the school's general secretary said Tuesday.
TKU started as a vocational school specialized in English teaching more than five decades ago. It is now one of the most populous Taiwan universities.

Wan said that knowledge of the English language is an important element to internationalization and one of the most important goals in the school's three primary targets along with information and planning for the future.
According to Wan, the "English Corner" provides TV series' in English as well as 52 satellite channels. It is aimed at improving students' listening and speaking abilities.
Students can also have direct conversations in English with other students pursuing Masters degrees in the English Literature Department.
The "Readathon" Web site provides online English articles and news on fashion and entertainment to arouse students' interest in the English language.
To date, there are about 100 TKU abroad on short term study programs that last about a year. Wan said that TKU aims to increase the number 10-fold by 2010.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WELCOMES TALKS WITH CHINA ON DIRECT AIR TRANSPORT LINKS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 6 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: A high-ranking Taiwan official said Monday that the opening of direct air transport links across the Taiwan Strait is government policy and that Taiwan welcomes talks without preconditions with China in this regard.
Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu made the remarks during a meeting with Taiwanese reporters.
Wu claimed it is wrong to think that his council has been impeding the implementation of direct transport links across the Taiwan Strait.
A Cabinet evaluation report unveiled Aug. 15, 2003 clearly explained the government's positive stance regarding the opening of direct transport links between the two sides of Taiwan Strait, he said.

To reach the goal, the government has been promoting cross-strait charter flights for passengers during the Lunar New Year holiday as a prelude to the full opening of regular direct transport links, according to Wu.
However, China has no intention of negotiating with Taiwan's Democratic Progressive Party administration in this regard, so that only charter flights between the two sides can be discussed, Wu noted.

Wu went on that the opening of cross-strait passenger charter flights for the 2005 Lunar New Year has seen efforts from the government to secure the flights, and negotiations for similar charter flight services for the 2006 holiday have also been completed.

Both sides of the Taiwan Strait have been negotiating alternative measures, such as talks on cross-strait cargo and passenger charter flights, before the full opening of the direct transport links, Wu said, expressing hope that the talks will soon bear fruit.
"If China is willing to negotiate with us on the issue of direct transport ties without any preconditions, we would absolutely welcome it," Wu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SETS SIGHTS ON MERGER WITH PFP BY YEAR-END

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Yin-jeou would like to meet with People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong before Dec. 14 to discuss a merger of the two parties and hopefully combine them before the end of the year, KMT spokeswoman Cheng Li-wen said Monday.
Cheng said the KMT has long been looking forward to such a merger, which was one of the goals laid down by the party's Central Standing Committee last year.

The unification of the two parties is not only the wish of the two parties' authorities but also the sincere expectation of their supporters and the KMT will do its best to make it happen, the spokeswoman went on.

Noting that the PFP suggested earlier the day a meeting between Ma and Soong for this purpose, Cheng said Ma hopes the meeting will take place before Dec. 14 in light of the fact that Soong is set to make an overseas trip after Dec. 14.

In a move matching the PFP's formation of a panel in charge of talks with the KMT in this regard, Cheng said Ma has asked KMT Vice Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung to lead a task force to deal with the PFP panel. Also, Cheng said, the KMT will line up a meeting between the PFP panel and Ma as soon as possible.
In order to unify the two parties, Cheng said, the KMT will treat the PFP with the highest regard and hopefully the merger can be completed before the end of this year.
The PFP, set up in 2000, is a splinter of the KMT, with its founder James Soong a former KMT secretary-general and its members former KMT members.
However the PFP's strength declined after the 2004 presidential elections in which Soong teamed up with then-KMT Chairman Lien Chan only to be defeated by President Chen Shui-bian.

The party is now facing the risk of being sidelined after the Dec. 3 local elections in which it won only one magistrate seat -- in Kinmen -- out of 23 openings up for grabs, and that only thanks to the courtesy of the KMT, which refrained from naming its own candidate in that county.
Many PFP lawmakers have called for a merger with the KMT, which won 14 seats in the Dec. 3 race and is on the way for a showdown with the DPP in the 2008 presidential race.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Dec. 7, or the seventh day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1783: William Pitt, known as "Pitt the Younger," is made British prime minister and chancellor of the exchequer at the age of just 24. He accomplished the Act of Union between Ireland and Britain but was unsuccessful in his efforts at achieving Catholic emancipation.
1808: James Madison is elected the fourth president of the United States. His presidency was marked by the War of 1812.
1858: The French and Spanish announce a blockade of the port of Taku near the Chinese city of Tientsin prior to an Anglo-French expedition against Beijing which saw the burning of the Imperial Summer Palace by invading troops.
1887: The first U.S. hospital for cancer patients is inaugurated in New York.
1902: Thomas Nast, an American political cartoonist who was born in Germany in 1840, dies at the age of 62. He was the first to depict the Democratic Party as a donkey and the Republican Party as an elephant.
1917: U.S. President Woodrow Wilson declares war on Austria.
1941: Japanese planes bomb the American naval base at Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, killing 2,400 men and destroying many aircraft and battleships.
1949: The government of the Republic of China moves its seat of power to Taipei.
1951: The Communist Chinese launch the "three antis campaign" -- anti-corruption, anti-extravagance, and anti-bureaucracy.
1971: An unmanned Soviet space capsule sends back radio and television signals from Mars.
1973: The Asian Vegetable Research and Development Center formally opens in Shanhua, Tainan County.
1974: A three-month exhibition of Chinese products is opened in Taipei by Economics Minister Y.S. Sun. The exhibition has 10 pavilions with 859 showrooms and 465 retail booths.
1975: U.S. President Gerald Ford delivers his "New Pacifism" speech in Hawaii.
1975: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo announces the ROC government's plan to build Asia's most modern farm villages under the first Six-Year Economic Development Plan beginning in 1976.
1975: Indonesian troops enter East Timor as civil war breaks out after the Portuguese, rulers of East Timor for three centuries, leave the colony.
1978: Japanese Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira forms a new Cabinet.
1982: Robbers make away with more than NT$14 million from an armored truck of the United World Chinese Commercial Bank in Taipei.
1984: The Legislative Yuan passes the Special Education Law after its third reading.
1985: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces the severing of diplomatic ties with the Republic of Nicaragua.
1986: The new Taipei City Zoo is inaugurated in the Taipei suburb of Mucha.
1988: A massive earthquake claims over 100,000 lives in Soviet Armenia.
1989: Lithuania abolishes the constitutional guarantee of Communist Party supremacy and legalizes the multiparty system.
1993: Ivory Coast President Felix Houphouet-Boigny, Africa's longest-serving ruler, dies.
1996: The space shuttle Columbia and its crew return safely to earth after ending the longest space shuttle flight ever at nearly 18 days.
1999: Premier Vincent Siew accepts the resignation of Cabinet member Peng Tso-kwei as chairman of the Council of Agriculture and appoints Ling Shiang-nung to fill the vacancy.
2000: Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan appeals to the government of France for judicial cooperation between the two countries to help in the investigation of kickback allegations surrounding the ROC Navy's purchase of six Lafayette-class frigates some 10 years earlier.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is indeed a pleasure to acquire knowledge and, as you go on acquiring, to put into practice what you have acquired. A greater pleasure still is when friends of congenial minds come from afar to seek you out because of your attainments."
2001: The opening ceremony of the 2001 Austronesian Cultural Festival is held at Peinan Park in Taitung City, with famed singer Chang Hui-mei giving a performance.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH TO HOLD MEETING TO DISCUSS U.S. REQUEST TO LIFT BEEF IMPORTS BAN

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) will convene a meeting later this month to discuss a request by Washington for Taiwan to lift its ban on U.S. beef imports, a DOH official said Wednesday.

Chen Lu-hung, director general of the DOH's Bureau of Food Safety, said that the United States has submitted a report confirming the safety of its beef via the American Institute in Taiwan, the de facto U.S. embassy in Taiwan in the absence of diplomatic ties between the two countries, and expressing the hope that Taiwan will re-open to U.S. beef imports.

Chen said the experts taking part in the meeting will assess the risk of bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE), or mad cow disease, cases in the United States as well as the safety of U.S. beef before deciding whether to lift the ban.

The participants of the meeting will review the report by the AIT as well as domestic studies and express their own views, Chen said. If the experts are satisfied that U.S. beef is indeed safe, then Taiwan will re-open to imports, he added.
Taiwan first banned imports of U.S. beef, live cattle and all related products in December 2003 after the discovery in Washington State of a single BSE case, the first U.S. case of mad cow disease.

Taiwan purchased US$325 million-worth of U.S. beef and beef products in 2003 and was the sixth-largest importer of U.S. beef before imposing the ban. Taiwan lifted the ban on U.S. boneless beef from animals under 30 months of age on April 16.
However, Taiwan reimposed the ban on June 25, one day after a second BSE case in the United States was confirmed by a British laboratory.

The Straits Times: Landmark pact boosts links with Vietnam.
Singapore and Vietnam yesterday signed a landmark agreement that will boost business between the two countries across a rang of fields, including aviation, port development, telecoms and banking.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Kelantan state's government may change after BN won by-election.
The Barisan Nasional (BN) has wrestled this state constituency from Islamic party of Malaysia (PAS) by a narrow margin of 129 votes, and the victory signals a significant shift in the political landscape of Kelantan.
That's meaning the Kelantan state's government may change any time after PAS governed Kelantan 15 years.
BN candidate Hanafi Mamat was declared the winner at 9.22pm yesterday securing 7,419 votes against Pas candidate Hanifa Ahmad's 7,290. Independent candidate Datuk Ibrahim Ali, the third contestant, garnered a mere 414 votes.
The result has placed the PAS-led Kelantan Government in a very delicate situation as its representation in the 45-seat State Legislative Assembly has been reduced further and it is now hanging on by a mere seat. The equation now is BN 22 and PAS 23.
BN wins but Hanafi's majority less than 2%; recount today from 10am.
