DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN CALLS FOR PARTY-TO-PARTY TALKS ON FORMING NEW CABINET

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou called for President Chen Shui-bian Wednesday to consult with the KMT before asking a KMT heavyweight to form a new Cabinet.
Ma made the call following the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) defeat in last weekend's local elections.

Ma said that he has no idea whether President Chen will ask Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin -pyng, a KMT heavyweight, to form a new Cabinet as the media has speculated, but he added that if that is the case, the matter should be discussed between the DPP and the KMT in line with the constitutional spirit of the "double government chief" system.

According to the "double government chief" system, if the ruling party does not have a majority in the Legislative Yuan, it should allow the majority party or coalition in the legislature to form the Cabinet.

The media reported Wednesday that after three days of "soul searching, " Chen may ask Wang to form a new Cabinet. A Cabinet reshuffle is more than likely following the DPP's defeat in Saturday's "three-in-one" elections in which the KMT and its "pan-blue alliance" allies won 17 of the 23 city and magistrate posts up for grabs and a majority of the council township chief elections.
Ma pointed out that five and a half years ago, President Chen's approval ratings rose to a record high after he appointed Tang Fei -- a KMT stalwart -- to the post of premier.

However, Tang ended up serving only five months before being sacked by Chen, Ma noted, attributing Tang's record-short stint to the absence of party-to-party consultations prior to Tang's appointment.

Ma said that in order to prevent Wang from becoming another Tang, the president should arrange for party-to-party talks for the possible appointment of a "pan-blue alliance" politician to form the next Cabinet in line with the spirit of the Constitution.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO SUBSIDIZE TUNA FISHERMEN AFFECTED BY ICCAT RULING

TEXT.P: The Fisheries Administration will provide a subsidy of NT$5.97 million (US$178,742) per fishing vessel affected by the quota cuts in Taiwan's bigeye tuna fishing in the Atlantic, officials announced Wednesday.

The International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna (ICCAT) decided last month to cut Taiwan's bigeye tuna fishing quota from 14,900 tons in 2005 to a mere 4,600 tons for the coming year because of overfishing by Taiwan fishing vessels.
As a result, 42 fishing vessels specializing in catching big-eye tuna in the Atlantic will not be able to operate during 2006. Only 15 Taiwan vessels will be allowed to continue fishing.
Fisheries Administration officials said they will submit the list of these 15 vessels to the ICCAT by Dec. 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'THREE-IN-ONE' ELECTIONS SAVE NT$280 MILLION: PREMIER

TEXT.P: The government has saved NT$280 million in election expenses by holding the elections for county and city chiefs, county and city councilors, as well as township and village heads simultaneously Dec. 3, Premier Frank Hsieh said Wednesday.
Hsieh said the "three-in-one" elections also helped enhance voter turnout.

Hsieh pointed out that the turnout rate for the county and city chief elections registered 66.22 percent this year, which was similar to the 66.45 percent four years ago. However, the turnout rates for the county and city councilor elections and township and village head elections registered 66.25 percent and 67.04 percent this year, which were much higher than the 55.59 percent and 57.07 percent in the previous elections, he said.

Hsieh made the remarks in a weekly Cabinet meeting, during which Central Election Commission and Ministry of Justice officials delivered reports on the elections and on the government's achievements in cracking down on vote-buying.
Hsieh said that when investigating alleged vote-buying cases, prosecutors should maintain "a sense of proportion" so as not to affect the outcome of the elections.

Hsieh called the mud-slinging tactics adopted by many candidates during the run-up to the elections practices that corrupted social morality and decayed the foundation of democracy. He ordered the Ministry of the Interior and Ministry of Justice to study the feasibility of amending election laws to raise the penalties for such practices.
Meanwhile, he asked the Ministry of Justice to review if it is reasonable to define offering a gift worth more than NT$30 to voters as an attempt to buy votes.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER TO INVITE TEAM TO VINDICATE HIM IN MRT CORRUPTION SCANDAL

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Wednesday that he will invite a five-man investigation team to vindicate his alleged part in the mass rapid transit construction scandal in Kaohsiung.
The team, to be formed next week, will include private individuals such as academic Chai Sunglin and lawyers C.V. Chen and Wang Ching-feng who according to Hsieh have an image of integrity.

The team will not include members of the "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its ally the Taiwan Solidarity Union, but might have members affiliated with the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party, he added.

The team can conduct a no-holds-barred investigation on all questions concerning him, including whether he has profited from the MRT construction project, whether he violated the law while serving as Kaohsiung mayor, and whether he condoned any unlawful practices during his mayorship, he said.

In addition, he will unveil his personal assets currently in trust, as well as their changes over time, and he expressed the hope that society will give him some time to help the MRT construction system to be launched smoothly.

"If the MRT project continues to be embroiled in controversy, it will have an adverse effect on the construction work and the morale of the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp., which is in charge of its construction," Hsieh said.

The premier made the remarks during the first Executive Yuan meeting following the crushing defeat of the DPP in Saturday's elections. The MRT scandal involving a former top Presidential Office aide was generally considered a major factor behind the major setback.

Hsieh, who was Kaohsiung mayor before he assumed the premiership in February, said that the elections are live-or-die games, but people must work together for a better future after elections or passions incited during the election campaigns will be a negative force in society.
"The ruling and opposition parties, as well as society, must cool down and focus on economic development and public policies," he said.

On controversy surrounding the MRT and himself during the election campaigning, Hsieh claimed that during his 25 years in politics, "integrity" has always been his bottom line and an essential requirement.

"I have maintained a strict discipline upon myself in terms of money," Hsieh said, adding that he has kept a distance from influence pedaling, extracting illegal loans or profiteering since he was first elected.
"I won past elections because the public was positive about my integrity," he said.
But he said that since he served as Kaohsiung mayor seven years ago, he had been investigated several times, although he came out unscathed every time after proving his innocence.
"This was not because the president, or the DPP, or the national security authorities were condoning my wrongdoings, " Hsieh said, claiming that such a practice is "impossible" in the DPP system.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOP ACADEMIC SAYS VOTERS SENT STRONG MESSAGE TO GOV'T IN ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: The head of Academia Sinica, the top research institute in Taiwan, said Wednesday that voters sent a strong message to the administration in the Dec. 3 islandwide local elections and that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) now needs to undergo some self-examination.

Lee Yuan-tseh said that the DPP must indeed engage in some soul-searching following its defeat in the "three-in-one" elections in which the ruling party only won six of the city mayor and county magistrate posts up for grabs while main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and its "pan-blue alliance" allies won 17 posts.
He also suggested that President Chen Shui-bian "seriously think things over" following the strong message sent by voters.

Lee, however, discounted the general view that the election results represent an endorsement of the main opposition party, pointing out that neither the DPP nor the KMT had a support rating above 50 percent prior to the polls.

He said that Taiwan's democracy has progressed by leaps and bounds and that the people's expectations of the government have risen dramatically at the same time, pointing out that the setback for the DPP doesn't necessarily put the KMT in a more ideal position.

Meanwhile, Lee expressed great disappointment with the campaigning ahead of the elections, saying that there was too much mud-slinging and too little debate on policies as well as a lack of clear platforms put forward by candidates from either side.
Nevertheless, Lee added that he's encouraged by the fact that several DPP candidates who lost their races were gracious in defeat by offering their congratulations and blessings to the victors.
As to the future, Lee urged all the people and all the politicians to try to set aside their differences and work together for the sake of the national interest.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE HEAD TERMS RUMOR OF NEW CABINET 'SHEER SPECULATION'

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng described as "sheer speculation" a rumor Wednesday that President Chen Shui-bian is pondering whether to ask him to form a new Cabinet after the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) suffered a punishing defeat in the "three-in-one" elections last weekend.

Media speculation that day claimed that Chen might ask Wang to form the next Cabinet in an effort to defuse confrontation between the ruling DPP and the "pan-blue alliance" led by the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and break the stalemate in the legislature so as to help smooth Chen's and his administration's governance in his last two years in office.
Wang appealed to "pan-blue alliance" supporters to be at ease that he "is not a three-year-old" and that he "has his own stance and judgment."

Nevertheless, he discounted views harbored by some "pan-blue alliance" legislators that Chen, if he were to name Wang as the next premier, would be aiming to use Wang as a pawn to deepen rifts within the "pan-blue alliance, " which is gaining ever-greater influence in Taiwan's political spectrum.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 21 points to close at 6,329.52.
The bourse opened at 6,362.51 and fluctuated between 6,370.82 and 6,290.6 during trading. A total of 1.08 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$112.32 billion (US$3.35 billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 2.3 percent, followed by cement and paper and pulp both at 0.5 percent, and plastics and chemical shares at 0.2 percent.

The other four of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with banking and financial shares moving down the most at 1.2 percent, followed by textile stocks at 0.8 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 0.4 percent, and foodstuff issues at 0.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 619 to 438, with 151 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly lower Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for December moved down 22 points to close at 6,347, with 27,086 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for January dropped 23 points to close at 6,346, with 594 contracts traded, while March futures lost 16 points to finish at 6,346, with seven contracts traded.
June futures moved down 20 points to close at 6,330, with seven contracts traded, while September futures rose 17 points to close at 6,244, with four contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 6,369 for December, 6,369 for January, 6,362 for March, 6,350 for June and 6,227 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly lower.
December TE futures moved down 1.3 points to close at 276.2, with 5,575 contracts traded, while January TE futures lost 1.4 points to finish at 276.1, with 113 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.
December TF futures lost 17.4 points to finish at 904.6, with 4,713 contracts changing hands, while January TF futures moved down 16.8 points to close at 904.2, with 160 contracts traded.
March TF futures moved down 18.4 points to close at 905.2, with one contract traded, while June TF futures lost 22 points to finish at 905.8, with two contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for September.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOVEMBER TRADE SURPLUS EXPANDS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's export trade stood at US$17.17 billion in November, while imports totaled US$15.76 billion, leaving the country with a trade surplus of US$1.41 billion, the Ministry of Finance reported Wednesday.
The November surplus was the second-highest single-month record of its kind since December 2003, ministry officials said.

Cumulatively, Taiwan exported US$172.23 billion-worth of products in the first 11 months of this year, while importing US$167.36 billion-worth of products and services in the same period, the officials said.
As a result, Taiwan posted a trade surplus of US$4.87 billion for the January-November period, marking a decline of 32.7 percent from the same period of 2004, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, gaining NT$0.024 to close at NT$33.485.
A total of US$861 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at NT$33.461 and fluctuated between NT$33.390 and NT$33.490.

DOC.HEADLINE: LICENSES TO BE REVOKED IF FISHING BOATS REFUSE TO RETURN TO PORT

TEXT.P: The licenses of 42 tuna boats ordered to return to Taiwan after the international community's cut in quotas for Taiwan's bigeye tuna catch will be revoked if the ships refuse to return to port, Fisheries Administration Deputy Director-General Sha Chih-i said Wednesday.

Sha said the Fisheries Administration is poised to revoke the licenses and will ask the international fishery community to treat them as illegal, unregulated and unreported (IUU) fishing vessels whose catches will be banned from export.

In addition, Sha said, ship owners who fail to bring their boats back to Taiwan will also face prison terms of three to seven years in line with a special punishment regulation after the measure being drawn up by the administration has been approved at the Legislative Yuan.

He made the remarks after the Fisheries Administration announced earlier in the day that it will subsidize NT$5.97 million (US$178,700) per year to each of the 42 bigeye tuna boats that have been told by the government to halt operations in the Atlantic and sail back to Taiwan as a result of international sanctions due to Taiwan ships' over-fishing in that area.

The administration's subsidies to the fishing vessels have been thoroughly assessed and are open to public scrutiny, although some ship owners are not satisfied with the compensation offered by the government, Sha said.

The International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna (ICCAT) decided in November at its annual conference to slash its annual quota for Taiwan's bigeye tuna catch to 4,600 metric tons in 2006 from the current level of 149,000 metric tons, forcing Taiwan to reduce the size of its bigeye fishing fleet to only 15 boats for the coming year in the Atlantic.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT TO SERVE AS ACTING DPP CHAIRWOMAN

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu was selected to serve as the acting chairwoman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) during the party's first central standing committee meeting since the party suffered a major setback in Saturday's elections. Su Tseng-chang stepped down from the DPP chairmanship to take responsibility in the wake of Saturday's dismal performance by the DPP, which managed to get only six out of the 23 seats up for grabs in the city and county chief elections. In comparison, the main opposition Kuomintang took 14 seats.

Lu said that members of the central standing committee were unanimous in recognizing Su's conscientious stumping efforts in the election campaign and wanted him to stay, but Su was adamant on leaving.
According to the DPP's charter, the acting chairman must organize a by-election for the party's next chairman and the party members will vote for the new leader in January at the earliest.

No-one has yet to come forward to express interest in taking the helm of the party, although some DPP sources said Lu, Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun and former DPP Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung are all suitable candidates.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPERA LEGEND PAVAROTTI TO PERFORM IN TAICHUNG CITY

TEXT.P: Opera legend Luciano Pavarotti is scheduled to fly into the central Taiwan city of Taichung Dec. 11 to perform his last concert of his Last Best Farewell Tour 2005 in Asia, slated for Dec. 14 in Taichung, Taichung Mayor Jason Hu said Wednesday.

Hu was in Taipei Wednesday to invite music and opera fans to travel to Taichung next Wednesday to listen to Pavarotti in his one and only concert to be staged in Taiwan in his 2005 farewell tour, which also includes concerts in South Korea and China.

The Taichung mayor, who has just won re-election, said that so far, about 90 percent of the tickets have been sold. Of the ticket buyers, he said, about 80 percent are Taichung residents and the remaining 20 percent are Pavarotti fans from other cities and counties.
Hu said that Pavarotti knew about his mimicking the maestro as part of his election campaign and that he had been granted permission by Pavarotti himself.

The 70-year-old Pavarotti, widely acclaimed as one of the "three tenors of the century, " said recently that he will retire next year to teach and spend more time with his family, especially his three-year-old daughter, Alice.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Clashes between police and demonstrators in Susa Valley.
Police moved in Tuesday early morning to break up protesters who are seeking to stop the construction of a high-speed train railway linking Turin and the French city of Lyon through the Italian Alpine valley of Susa. Scores of people and police were reportedly injured in the police operation. Interior Minister Giuseppe Pisanu rebutted criticism by denying undue force used against the demonstrators, while opposition union leader Romano Prodi called for not to the use of force.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2006 ECONOMIC GROWTH TO HIT 4.25%: ACADEMIA SINICA

TEXT.P: The Academia Sinica's Institute of Economics forecast Wednesday that Taiwan's economic growth rate will rise to 4.25 percent in 2006, with the international economy expected to restore its growth momentum.

According to Wu Chung-shu, a research fellow at the institute, the growth momentum of the international economy diminished significantly in 2005 because of soaring oil prices and interest rate hikes by various countries to control inflation.
Affected by the shrinking export volume and private investment, Taiwan's economic growth rate for 2005 is expected to fall to 3.83 percent from the 6.07 percent of 2004, Wu said.

Wu predicted that the implementation of minimum income tax rates in 2006 will inhibit domestic demand temporarily. While the growth in private spending is likely to decline to 3.02 percent in 2006 from the 3.08 percent projected for 2005, the growth in private investment is likely to slide to 3.35 percent in 2006 from the 4.08 percent projected for 2005.

Wu said the recovering international economy will help boost Taiwan's external trade, with the export of goods and services expected to rise to 9.87 percent in 2006 from the 6.5 percent of 2005 and imports to expand to 8.79 percent from 5.14 percent.
He predicted that the average prices of oil exports by OPEC countries will rise from US$52 per barrel in 2005 to US$56 per barrel in 2006.
He said the hike in oil prices has not jolted the international economy this year mainly because the impact from the soaring oil prices was partially offset by the low labor costs of China and India.
The average exchange rate of the new Taiwan dollar against the U.S. dollar is likely to adjust from 32.19 in 2005 to 32.68 in 2006, he went on.

The wholesale price index is expected to rise 2.19 percent in 2006, compared with the 0.61 percent projected for 2005. The consumer price index will increase 1.45 percent in 2006, compared with the 2.28 percent projected for 2005, he said.

Meanwhile, he predicted that there will not be a major change in money supply in 2006, since the economic growth rate will only expand slightly next year. The M1B money supply is expected to increase 8.98 percent in 2006, compared with the 7 percent in 2005, while the M2 money supply is expected to increase 6.71 percent in 2006, compared with the 6.19 percent in 2005.

According to Wu, Taiwan's economy in the coming year is subject to uncertainties such as the momentum of international economic recovery, the extent of U.S. economic growth, the domestic political situation, cross-Taiwan Strait trade and economic exchanges and the possibility of avian flu outbreaks.

The launch of cross-strait chartered flight services during the 2006 Chinese New Year holiday and the government's policy of allowing more Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan will be favorable to the country's economic growth because these moves will help lower the unemployment rate and stimulate investment and consumer spending, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Suicide Bombers Kill 36 Iraqi Officers at Baghdad Academy
Powerful explosions from two suicide bombs riipped through the Badhdad's main police academy on Tuesday, killing at least 36 police officers and wounding 72 other people, including an American contractor, according to an Iraqi Interior Ministry official and the American military. The attack was the deadliest in Baghdad in months. It underscores the continuiing vulnerability of the Iraqi forces, even in the capital, as President Bush is under increasing political pressure in the United States to start bringing home some of the 160,000 American troops here.
Wall Street Journal: Lessons of the '30s, Long Study of Great Depression Has Shaped Bernanke's Views
The designated chairman of the U.S. Federal Reserve Ben Bernanke once told his friend "If you want to understand economics, study the biggest calamity to hit the U.S. and world economies." Bernanke's fascination with the Great Depression never abated. He believes that the issues raised by the Depression, and its lessons, are still relevant today, and his interest in the Depression is a guide to the evolution of his thinking. In particular, his groundbreaking research on how mistakes by the Federal Reserve compounded the catastrophe is likely to influence how he steers the economy once he succeeds Alan Greenspan as its chairman early next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Indians Focus on Energy, Aerospace
Indian Prime Minister Manmohan Singh paid a visit to President Vladimir Putin in the Kremlin on Tuesday, sealing aerospace deals and promising to increase energy cooperation.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKERS URGE POLICY DEBATES IN SELECTING NEW CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislators urged Wednesday a truly competitive election by members in selecting the next party chairman and said that aspirants should conduct policy debates.

A by-election is necessary after Su Tseng-chang stepped down from the DPP chairmanship to take responsibility for the major setback of the party in Saturday's elections for city and county chiefs. The DPP took only six out of the 23 seats up for grabs compared with the main opposition Kuomintang's (KMT's) 14 seats.

Legislator Wang Hsin-nan said that while the KMT is already making headway since its party chairman election in August, the DPP is still mired in problems such as "phantom" party members, factional struggles and local chapters that do not always toe the party line.
"The DPP chairman election should not be inferior to that of the KMT," Wang said.
His colleague Huang Wei-cher expressed the hope that chairman aspirants will lay out their visions and conduct policy debates.

Legislator Wang Shu-hui echoed his views, saying that as the party engages in self-examination after its most dismal election performance ever, all aspirants keen on taking the helm of the DPP should state their vision for the party.
Legislator You Ching said the most valuable attribute of the party is its democratic system and that the prospective party chairman must expound clearly on where he intends to lead the party.
There should also be three presentations held in northern, central and southern Taiwan, respectively, by the hopefuls so that the members will have a clear picture of their visions, You said.
The party should also try to retrieve those DPP members who have ceased to communicate with the party, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S ADVISER CALLS FOR POSTPONEMENT ON ECONOMIC CONFERENCE

TEXT.P: Senior Adviser to the President Wu Li-pei said Wednesday he will recommend President Chen Shui-bian postpone the proposed national economic development conference on the grounds that it wouldn't serve the interests of the general public.

In an interview with CNA, Wu said the conference which will be the second of its kind in five years was recommended by the leaders of the country's six commercial and industrial groups which are all keen to explore the Chinese market.
President Chen has promised on Nov. 22 to call for such a conference, and Premier Frank Hsieh said afterward the conference will be staged before the end of the January.
"You can imagine what recommendations those groups as well as their sympathizers in the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) would come up with in the conference." Wu said.

He predicted the second national economic development advisory conference will downgrade itself into an occasion for big enterprises to speak for their own interest and pressurize the government into relaxing restrictions on exchanges with China which he claimed would be to the detriment of the general public.

Unless the conference is postponed, the government will find itself placed between a rock and a hard place because it will either hurt the overall interest of the people by accepting the conference' recommendations as a whole or shot itself in the foot by convening this conference but turning a deaf ear to its conclusions, Wu claimed.

In terms of the country's ties with China, Wu said the president is quite firm in his stance against China, but the country's economy depends on China too heavily which creates an impression that the government is leaning toward China.

Discontent with what they believe as the government's skewing toward China, many pro-Taiwan voters denied the ruling Democratic Progressive Party of their support in the Dec. 3 local government elections and delivered the party a heavy blow, Wu claimed.

Taiwan is really painting itself into the corner by allowing its businessmen invest in China which help China develop into an economic power in the region and compete against Taiwan on the world market.
Pointing to the island's declining exports this year, Wu said that now the chickens are coming home to roost and the government has to address the problem caused by its ill-thought-out China policy.

He disputed businessmen's claims that the government should allow the free movement of goods and capitals in line with the business globalization rather than avoid contacts with China as much as possible, arguing that globalization is more than venturing into China.
Too close trade relations with China will cost Taiwan its economic independence and hinder its chance of globalization, Wu warned.

Instead of calling an national economic development conference, he said the DPP administration should invite academics without political affiliation to debate in public on the county's future and consult them on the economic policy which should take into consideration the general public's interest.
As the ruling party, Wu said. the DPP should give leadership to the country rather than play the opposition's game by echoing its calls for direct transportation links with the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: NANTOU COUNTY GOVERNMENT SOLICITS FOREIGN SPOUSES AS VOLUNTEERS
DOC.DATELINE: Nantou, Central Taiwan, Dec. 7 (CNA) (By Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: The Nantou county government is soliciting foreign and Chinese spouses as voluntary workers to help other foreign spouses adapt to Taiwan society, county government officials said Wednesday.

With the growing number of foreign spouses in Taiwan, mostly from Southeast Asian countries and China, there are more and more problems resulting from them, including their inability to adapt to society, cultural differences and even cases of domestic abuse.
According to statistics compiled by the Nantou county government, the number of foreign and Chinese spouses living in Nantou County as of November had reached nearly 7,000.

Officials of the Bureau of Social Affairs under the Nantou county government noted that once these foreign spouses become "daughters-in-law" of Taiwan, they are responsible for nurturing the new generation of Taiwanese and the government has the responsibility to help them adapt to society as quickly as possible.
The Nantou county government will recruit interested foreign spouses older than 20 to join the volunteer group to offer consultative and translation services to other newcomers.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PAN-BLUE ALLIANCE' LEADERS TO MEET MONDAY

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong will meet next Monday amid expectations that a merger of the two parties is imminent.
Before the meeting of the two leaders of the "pan-blue alliance," Ma will first meet with a five-man PFP team in charge of negotiations on a merger with the KMT.
Asked about possible topics during the meeting, Ma said "anything can be discussed, " including the merger, since the KMT passed a resolution to merge with the PFP last year.

As there will be Taipei and Kaohsiung mayoral elections, as well as city councilor elections of the two special municipalities next year, the PFP councilors have expressed worry about the nominations after such a merger, which Ma said will also be addressed during the meeting.
Ma said that the KMT has a set nomination procedure and that the primary system must continue.

KMT spokeswoman Cheng Li-wen said earlier in the day that Ma and Soong will meet for three hours and that it will be earlier than expected because Soong is scheduled to attend an international conference Dec. 14-18.
The KMT and the PFP control a slim majority between them in the Legislative Yuan, and have joined hands to block many bills initiated by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party in the legislature.

The PFP is a KMT splinter party founded in 2000 after Soong lost his presidential bid by a slim margin. Soong, who used to be the KMT's all-powerful secretary-general, ran as an independent in the 2000 presidential race.
The PFP saw its strength decline after the 2004 presidential elections in which Soong teamed up with then-KMT Chairman Lien Chan, only to be defeated a second time by President Chen Shui-bian.

The party is now facing the risk of being sidelined after the Dec. 3 local elections in which it won only one magistrate seat -- in Kinmen -- out of 23 openings up for grabs, and that only thanks to the courtesy of the KMT, which refrained from naming its own candidate in that county.
Many PFP lawmakers have called for a merger with the KMT, which won 14 seats in the Dec. 3 race and is on its way to a showdown with the DPP in the 2008 presidential race.

DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLIC INVITED TO WATCH SUNRISE ON NEW YEAR'S DAY AT TAIPEI 101

TEXT.P: The world's tallest skyscraper -- Taipei 101 -- is inviting the public to watch the first sunrise of 2006 at its observatory located on the 89th floor, officials said Wednesday.
The activity will be held 4: 30 a.m. Jan. 1, but only 1,010 admission tickets will be available, they said.
The tickets must be purchased in advance and the buyers will be offered a gift box containing a set of commemorative badges and cards on which they can write down their New Year wishes, they said.
While welcoming in the first daybreak of 2006, the visitors will be able to attach their cards on a "wishing tree," they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HONORARY CHAIRMAN ARRIVES IN HONG KONG
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Dec. 7 (CNA) (By M. N. Cheng and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Honorary Chairman Lien Chan of Taiwan's main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) arrived in Hong Kong Wednesday for a four-day visit.
Lien will receive an honorary doctorate in law from Hong Kong Chief Executive Donald Tseng at the Chinese University of Hong Kong Thursday, and the two men are slated to meet for talks Friday.

While answering questions on the Dec. 3 elections from local reporters prior to his departure at Chiang Kei-shek International Airport near Taipei, Lien expressed the hope that the KMT and its "pan blue alliance" ally, the People First Party (PFP), will merge as soon as possible and that the dual-head government system will be implemented in line with the Constitution.

The KMT overwhelmed the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the weekend local elections, re-drawing Taiwan's political map. KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou has been widely tipped by "pan blue" supporters as the sole superstar in the 2008 presidential election.

Public calls have been mounting on a much-expected merger between the KMT and the PFP in the wake of the PFP's poor showing in the elections, the results of which signal that it risks becoming a marginal party in Taiwan politics.

KMT spokeswoman Cheng Lee-wen announced later the same day that Ma is slated to meet PFP Chairman James Soong next Monday to discuss a host of issues related to the KMT-PFP merger after a PFP spokesman said a day earlier that Soong will put himself above the fray and remain fully open to the merger.

The PFP splintered from the KMT in 2000 following the presidential election that year, but the two parties and the New Party teamed up to form the "pan blue alliance" to counter the "pan green camp" of the ruling DPP and the Taiwan Solidarity Union ahead of the presidential race in March 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLIC MANDATE TO DECIDE SOONG'S RUN FOR TAIPEI MAYOR: PFP LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: Whether or not People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong will run for Taipei mayor next year will depend on public opinion, PFP lawmaker Li Hong-jyun said Wednesday.
Li made the remarks while answering questions from reporters after a local newspaper reported earlier the same day that it is "80 percent likely" that Soong will run.

Should Soong run, it would be because the public wants him to, Li said, adding that if elected, Soong would seek to develop the Taiwan's largest city into a world-class cosmopolitan metropolis with a high international profile since it is feared that Taiwan has lost its luster on the world stage.

However, Li said, a public mandate will be the decisive factor in Soong's decision whether or not to run for mayor. There is still one year to go before the election, and Soong has plenty of time to ponder the issue and ready himself for the race, he said.

Calls have been mounting on the PFP to merge with the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) in the wake of the PFP's miserable showing in the Dec. 3 local elections amid grave concerns among PFP supporters that the party might become an outcast in Taiwan's political spectrum.
There have been signs that the two parties in the "pan blue alliance" will work toward the merger, as Soong and KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou are slated to meet on the issue next Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL INDIGENOUS FILM FESTIVAL OPENS DEC. 12

TEXT.P: A film festival on Canada, New Zealand and Taiwan's indigenous peoples will begin Dec. 12.
Thirty-two films will be shown in university auditoriums around the island free of charge until the end of next year.

The non-profit film festival is part of the International Indigenous Creativity Conference. The Council of Indigenous People (CIP) , under the supervision of the Executive Yuan, signed a memorandum of understanding with the Canadian government in 1994 and an arrangement with New Zealand in 2004 to promote indigenous peoples' issues, allowing the three countries to organize the festival.
The festival starts at Chung Yuan University in Chungli City.

From there, the films will travel around Taiwan to Bunun tribes in Taitung, eastern Taiwan, Chiayi University, Pingtung Aboriginal Cultural Park, Shunyi Aboriginal Museum, Hualien Donghua University and Taichung's Providence University.
Other organizations and academic parties interested in showing the films are still trying to get in touch with the authorities concerned.

Director of the General Relations Department of the Canadian Trade Office David Hamilton said during a news conference that the 13 films from his country were selected by the National Film Board of Canada among 450 made during the past 30 years.

"Indigenous peoples' culture is boundless. Canadian indigenous peoples are trying to tell their story to the world through these movies. We hope to bring a new point of view for Taiwanese audiences regarding indigenous peoples' issues," Hamilton said.
Indigenous peoples represent 4 percent of Canada's total population, while Taiwan's aborigines makes up 2 percent of the island's residents.
There are 14 films made by three Taiwanese indigenous directors.

Among the films from Taiwan, one of the most controversial is the one entitled, "What is your real name?" by Mayao Biho. The film talks about the controversy of Taiwanese indigenous people and whether to use their names in their ancestral tongue on identification cards.

"Local regulations have for the last 11 years allowed indigenous people here to use their names in their mother tongue. But as of the end of September, there were only 890 indigenous people who rectified their Chinese name into their "real name." But 65 of these apparently regret having done so, " said Mayao, who also has his mother tongue name on his ID card.
The film director humorously compared the number of people who rectified their name with the number of black-faced spoonbills, a protected migratory bird that overwinters in Taiwan.
"There are also about 800 of them. Last year we were winners because there were more of us than the birds. But this year we lost because there were more than 900 birds," Mayao said.
Mayao said that he was extremely surprised that his film was chosen because the topics he usually tackles are unfriendly to the government.

Two of the Canadian films, "Kanehsatake" made by Alanis Obomsawin and "No Turning Back" from Greg Coyes, report on violent armed conflicts between indigenous peoples and governmental authorities when the native people were striving for the right to own their ancestral lands and to restore their civil rights.

Mayao said that indigenous activities in Taiwan, such as fighting for the right to put their names in their mother tongue, the right to practice their own culture and to own their ancestors' land are mostly following the trend of Canada.
"If they didn't start, the indigenous people here wouldn't be that aware and have a path to follow," Mayao said.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMPORTERS EAGER TO CASH IN ON POSSIBLE NEW ENTRY OF AMERICAN BEEF

TEXT.P: Beef importers, restaurants and steakhouses in Taiwan are eager to cash in on the possible re-entry of U.S. beef now that the government has decided to convene an expert meeting to decide whether to lift the ban on U.S. beef.

Executives of these businesses said Wednesday that once the government decides to allow American beef to re-enter Taiwan, they will immediately launch orders for U.S. beef to serve local customers, who consider American beef their best choice among the various types of beef from around the world.
U.S. beef imports account for more than 20 percent of Taiwan's
total beef imports.

Taiwan banned imports of U.S. beef, live cattle and all related products in December 2003 after the discovery in Washington State of a single case of bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) , or mad cow disease.

The island lifted the ban on U.S. boneless beef from animals under 30 months in April this year, which drew tremendous criticism from opposition lawmakers after a second mad cow disease case was confirmed in U.S. in June. The DOH then again suspended U.S. beef imports on June 25.

Tsai Hui-ju, deputy general manager responsible for public relations of the Grand Formosa Regent Taipei, which made the first importation of American beef in April shortly after the government lifted the ban on U.S. beef the same month, said that the government's short re-opening to U.S. beef earlier this year has made the business in the hotel's steak and tepanyaki grill houses grow by 20 percent to 30 percent. "All our customers prefer American beef, " Tsai added.

Tsai expressed the hope that the government can present clear proof that American beef is safe this time and not re-open the market hastily. "Once the ban is lifted, we are prepared to resume importing American beef."
Lin Shih-chin, chairman of the well-known Noble Family Steak House, said the re-opening of imports of American beef will help reduce their costs in importing beef from other countries.

Lin revealed that ever since American beef was banned in Taiwan in June, the prices of beef from New Zealand and Australia have risen more than 30 percent to 40 percent, the highest during the last 10 years.
Although many people are still worried about mad cow disease, Lin said he has much confidence in the re-entry of American beef, adding that once U.S. beef is back, the customers will all return.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC OFFICIAL IN MANILA URGES CHINA TO STOP BULLYING TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, Dec. 7 (CNA) (By Emerson Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Huang Wei-feng urged China Wednesday to stop bullying Taiwan in the international community.

Huang issued the call after giving a briefing in Manila on the recent cross-Taiwan Strait situation to reporters from major Philippine media outlets, in which diplomats from Taiwan stationed in Manila also took part.

According to Huang, China is way out of line in the way it views Taiwan's pursuit of democracy and freedom as attempts to obtain formal independence. The Republic of China was set up in 1911 and a name change is not an issue for the ROC government now in Taiwan, he said.

Taiwan will not overhaul its China policy after the Dec. 3 local government elections, and China should not continue to squeeze Taiwan's international space by using checkbook diplomacy, he said, pointing out, however, that China's military buildup at a double-digit growth rate is the root cause of the threat to security cross the strait and to the rest of the region.

The MAC vice chairman also called on the member states of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) to support Taiwan to participate in an upcoming ASEAN summit meeting or to include across-strait issues for discussions on the summit's agenda.
Huang made a stopover in Manila on his way back to Taiwan from Indonesia, where he took part in an activity sponsored by the Global Alliance for Democracy and Peace.

DOC.HEADLINE: THERE IS NO TIMETABLE FOR LIFTING OF U.S. BEEF IMPORT BAN: DOH

TEXT.P: A high-ranking official from the Department of Health (DOH) said Wednesday that the government has no timetable regarding the lifting of its ban on U.S. beef.

Chen Lu-hung, director-general of DOH's Bureau of Food Safety, made the remarks in response to reports by evening newspapers that the government may re-open it market to U.S. beef before the Chinese Lunar New Year holiday as the DOH has decided to convene an expert meeting later this month to decide whether to lift the ban on U.S. beef.

Chen said the DOH will convene an expert meeting on Dec. 19-23 to evaluate the safety of U.S. beef, and whether Taiwan will re-open its market to American beef will be decided by the experts participating in the meeting. "There is no set timetable for the re-entry of American beef," Chen added.

However, Chen noted that once the U.S. beef ban is lifted, only boneless beef from animals under 30 months of age and excluding those high-risk parts of the animal such as internal organs, the brain and the spinal cord will be allowed to be imported to Taiwan.
Taiwan banned imports of U.S. beef, live cattle and all related products in December 2003 after the discovery in Washington State of a single case of mad cow disease.

The island lifted the ban on U.S. boneless beef from animals under 30 months of age in April this year, but again suspended American beef imports on June 25 after a second case of mad cow disease was confirmed in the U.S. earlier the same month.

DOC.HEADLINE: JOURNALIST ASSOCIATION SUPPORTS LAW ON INFORMATION RELEASE

TEXT.P: The newly passed Government Information Release Law is an important step on the road to improving Taiwan's freedom of speech and is also a guarantee for the rights of the people, the Association of Taiwan Journalists (ATJ) said Wednesday.
The Legislative Yuan approved the law Dec. 6, which allows people to have more direct access to government information, to be a part of public policy-making and to oversee government operations.

The ATJ said that the law will help differentiate "national security issues" and "freedom of the press issues." The legislature will be in charge of arbitration whenever there is confusion in telling the difference between these two issues.
The ATJ suggested that the government review their regulations on whether the range of definitions of "government secrets" is too wide, a situation that might be in conflict with the new law.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG BOOTH AT UN CLIMATE CHANGE CONFAB DRAWS ATTENTION

TEXT.P: The presence of representatives from Taiwan's southern city of Kaohsiung at the 2005 United Nations Climate Change Conference taking place in Montreal, Canada drew attention because it is one of a handful of cities opening exhibition booths at the venue, officials of the city's department of environmental protection said Wednesday.

Kaohsiung is the first Taiwan city to attend the U.N. conference that opened Dec. 28 and will run through Dec. 9. At the Kaohsiung city booth, complete information on Kaohsiung's efforts can be found regarding air pollution control and the reduction greenhouse gases.

The conference is the 11th session of the Conference of Parties to the U.N. Framework Convention on Climate Change and the first meeting of the parties to the Kyoto Protocol after the treaty came into force in February. Over 10,000 representatives of government, industry, business and the scientific community are at the conference, including a group of Taiwan delegates headed by Wang Chueh, deputy director of the Kaohsiung City environmental protection department.

Kaohsiung, Taiwan's stronghold of the petrochemical and steel industries, has the highest amount of greenhouse gas emissions on the island, with the emission of carbon dioxide accounting for 20.52 percent of the nation's total amount, according to the department.
In 2004, the carbon dioxide emissions per capita in the southern port city reached 34.72 tons, almost a world record, the department officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 12 DOCTORS DISCIPLINED FOR REVEALING TAICHUNG MAYOR'S MEDICAL RECORDS

TEXT.P: Twelve local doctors, including ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Peter Lin, were disciplined Wednesday for revealing Taichung Mayor Jason Hu's medical records.

Lin, a physician-turned-legislator who played a leading role in unveiling Hu's medical records at a news conference ahead of the Dec. 3 local government chief elections in an attempt to thwart Hu's re-election bid, got the harshest punishment, with his licence to practice medicine being revoked.

Under the current rules, Lin can appeal his case to the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) . If the DOH upholds the ruling, Lin cannot apply for a new license within a year, meaning that he will be banned from practicing medicine for one year.

The Medical Doctor Disciplinary Committee under the Taichung City Government in central Taiwan meted out penalties for Lin and 11 other doctors present at the Nov. 25 news conference after a six-hour meeting.
Kao Chia-chun, who arranged for the news conference, had his license suspended for one month, plus he must attend 32 hours of medical ethics courses.
The 10 remaining doctors were given a warning plus mandatory attendance of medical ethics courses ranging from between eight and 24 hours.

Lin Teng-chun, director of the public health department under the Taichung City Government, said even though many of the disciplined doctors didn't speak at the news conference, their presence on the occasion and their failure to prevent Peter Lin from unveiling Hu's medical records constituted a stark violation of ethical rules.
As to the authenticity of Hu's medical records, Lin Teng-chun said that is an issue to be investigated by prosecutorial authorities.
"The medical disciplinary committee is responsible for supervising physicians' behavior, regardless of whether they are legislator or not," he added.

All of the disciplined can appeal their cases to the DOH's disciplinary committee within 20 days. Peter Lin said at the pre-election news conference that he believes Hu's health could deteriorate and affect his mental health, causing him to be unfit to serve as mayor. He further claimed that Hu is troubled by high blood pressure and diabetes and that there is a 70 percent chance that Hu might have a stroke within two years.

Hu reportedly suffered a mild stroke on a trip to the United States in August 2002, but he claims he only felt dizzy and suffered from a severe headache, which forced him to undergo an intensive health-check in the United States.
Hu has insisted that those were only "pre-stroke symptoms," which were not as serious as people thought.

Before becoming Taichung mayor in 2001, Hu was a director of the Government Information Office under the Cabinet, a National Assembly member, a minister of foreign affairs, and a Republic of China representative to the United States.
Despite questions about his health, Hu was re-elected by a landslide.

DOC.HEADLINE: SU RULES OUT POSSIBILITY OF RETURNING AS DPP CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Su Tseng-chang said Wednesday he has no wish to return as party chairman.

Su stepped down from the top DPP post immediately after the party suffered a humiliating defeat in the Dec. 3 mayoral/magistrate elections in which the DPP secured a mere six of the 23 seats up for grabs compared to the main opposition Kuomintang's 14.
Su didn't attend the DPP's weekly Central Standing Committee meeting and instead took a vacation in the northeastern county of Ilan.
Although Vice President Annette Lu came up with a proposal at the DPP meeting that the party central persuade Su to continue leading the party through its current crisis, Su rejected the offer.
Su said he felt ashamed and guilty for the party's resounding defeat. "I want to take a rest and refresh my mind by reading and practicing calligraphy," he added.
At this critical moment, Su said he is hopeful that all DPP politicians can stand united and work even harder to revamp the party through deep soul-searching and self-improvement.
Meanwhile, the DPP Central Standing Committee decided Wednesday to name Lu to serve as acting chairwoman until a new party chairman is elected by all DPP members early next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO FORM PARTY DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) decided Wednesday to set up a party development commission to draw up a comprehensive plan to improve the party following the DPP's resounding defeat in last weekend's local government chief elections.
The decision was made at the party's weekly Central Standing Committee.

During the meeting, party heavyweights spoke their minds on the humiliating defeat. They attributed the major causes to Kaohsiung MRT scandals and the combining of the three grassroots elections into a single day, which they claimed made it easier for the Kuomintang (KMT) to woo voters with illegal cash handouts.

They also said that having the elections together made it easier and cheaper for the KMT to rally their supporters to vote. In a sense, they said, the "three-in-one" elections were fertile ground for the growth of the KMT's "black gold" politics. "Black gold" refers to the corrupt practice of influence peddling and vote-buying.

Another factor was the actions of a few DPP supporters who overstepped the bounds of reasonableness, such as in the case of a party legislator who, along with 11 doctors, revealed what they claimed to be the medical records of Taichung Mayor Jason Hu to try to say that his past history of having a mild stroke made him unfit to run for re-election. A medical review committee has already disciplined all of the doctors and the legislator, who is also a licensed physician.
Moreover, the fact that the party was unable to monitor and rein in these people contributed to the party's image being tarnished in the eyes of the public, DPP heavyweights said.
They also blamed the party's failure to come up with appeals or reform initiatives that could touch voters' hearts in run-up to the elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Dec. 8, or the eighth day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1774: Austria becomes the first nation to establish a state education system.
1889: Jefferson Davis, the first and only president of the Confederate States of America, dies at the age of 81. He was captured by Union soldiers in 1865 and imprisoned for two years. Although indicted for treason, he was never prosecuted.
1907: One of the worst coal mine disasters in U.S. history occurs at Mononagh, West Virginia, killing 361 people.
1911: Mongolia is declared a Russian protectorate.
1917: The Republic of Finland is proclaimed.
1917: The steamship Mont Blanc collides with the steamship Imo in Halifax, Canada, killing more than 1,500 people, injuring 8,000 others, and destroying a large part of the city.
1921: Britain signs a peace treaty with Ireland under which the Irish Free States is established and Ireland accepts Dominion status.
1941: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt appeals to Japan's Emperor Hirohito for peace.
1943: The United States, Britain and the Soviet Union issue the Joint Declaration of the Tehran Conference.
1957: The United States fails in the launching of its first satellite.
1960: Taiwan Province implements the use of media broadcasts for the first time in the history of Republic of China military service in order to muster the required number of reservists.
1971: India recognizes the Democratic Republic of Bangladesh.
1973: The United Nations decides to establish the United Nations University in Tokyo.
1975: U.S. President Gerald Ford arrives in the Philippines for talks on new terms for U.S. air and naval basses in the country.
1975: President Yen Chia-kan receives Mrs. Paul Norman Brown, national president of the American Legion Ladies' Auxiliary, at the Presidential Office.
1979: The Communist Chinese ban the sticking of "big character posters" on Beijing's wall of democracy.
1980: The 1980 Supplementary Parliamentarian election sends 70 members to the Legislative Yuan and 76 to the National Assembly.
1986: Eighty-four members are newly elected to the Legislative Yuan and seventy-three members are newly elected to the National Assembly in the 1986 legislative by-elections. Voter turnout is 65.4 percent of the 11.8 million eligible registered voters.
1988: The ROC Legislative Yuan is paralyzed by fist-fighting, as the chairman for the first time asks police to maintain order.
1989: The worst mass killing in Canadian history takes place when a gunman shoots 13 female students to death at the University of Montreal before killing himself.
1990: President Saddam Hussein announces that all 3,400 foreign hostages held in Iraq since the invasion of Kuwait are now free to leave.
1990: Gen. Hussain Mohammed Ershad steps down at the height of a pro-democracy movement in Bangladesh.
1996: The Legislative Yuan revises the Labor Standards Law so that employees in nearly all industries will be covered by the end of 1998.
1999: The ROC-Japan Economic Conference opens in Tokyo.
2000: The Republic of China's Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs removes restrictions on workers from the Philippines, with the change effective retroactively to Dec. 1.
2000: Salvadoran President Francisco Guillermo Flores Perez arrives in Taipei for an official visit.
2001: Taiwan's two largest opposition parties, the Kuomintang and the People First Pary, decide not to participate in the "national stabilization alliance" that has been proposed by President Chen Shui-bian.
2001: The computer virus "Goner, " first found in the United States, is rampant in Hong Kong with at least 16 companies' computer systems being hit.
Motse's lesson of the day: "When the administration of the ruler does not answer to the desires of the subjects, it shows a lack of understanding of the approvals and disapprovals of the subjects. When there is no such understanding, then the good will not be discovered and rewarded and the bad will not be punished."
