DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SAYS HE WILL TAKE FULL RESPONSIBILITY FOR ELECTION DEFEAT

TEXT.P: After four days of silence, President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that he accepts the people's decision in Saturday's "three-in-one" local government elections and that he will take full responsibility for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) defeat by the main opposition Kuomitang (KMT) in the vote.

The president chose not a live TV broadcast but his "President A-Bian's electronic newspaper" to express his "not good feelings" about a rare crushing defeat for him. He also quoted a Chinese saying that "only those who know shame can be called brave" to show that he will engage in some serious soul searching in an effort to "walk out of the shadows of a big setback."

He emphasized that he will use "the highest and strictest standards" to examine all members in his ruling team, including himself, demanding that they work together to reinstall the government's "reputation of integrity, diligence, and love of our native land, " an effort that he believes will regain the people's trust and support.
In order to regain the people's support, he said, the ruling team must first "listen to their voices and review its image in the minds of the general public."

"There have been many shortcomings that have disappointed the people, " he said, adding that he will face the fact, take responsibility for that, and "thoroughly review and seek ways to make improvements."
"I will respond to the people's expectations of me and of my team with concrete actions." he stressed.

Chen pointed out that "integrity, diligence and love of our native land" has been the unswerving motto of his ruling team over the past five years which, however, some members of the team have failed to achieve, becoming a minus for the team's overall image and saddening him.

He said the people's choice in the Dec. 3 elections of city, county and town government heads and council members "must be accepted by all candidates because we are a democracy. It is that simple. It is the people who are the most powerful; only they are the real masters."
The DPP won only six of the 23 city and county government seats up for grabs, versus the KMT's 14, with the other three going to independents or minor party candidates.

Chen quoted Buddhist Master Sheng Yen, a well-respected scholar-monk, as saying when facing adversity, "we should try to face it, accept it, handle it and then move on." He said these four "attitudes" are good advice.

What is precious about democracy is that no one will be a winner forever and no one will be a loser forever; those who know how to learn from their failures will have a chance to make a comeback, he said.

Trying to be a historian, the president said that history is a mirror that reflects the past in the present and that it also envisions the future from the present. "In fact, the people are even more like a mirror that truthfully reflects the performance of a politician or a political party," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Former president Nair dies.
Former president and veteran union leader Devan Nair died in Ontario, Canada, on Tuesday night of heart failure. He was 82.
His death, which was at 11.30am Singapore time yesterday, came just seven mouths after his wife died of pneumonia in April.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Singapore's former president Devan Nair dies.
Former president Devan Nair died at home in Ontario, Canada on Tuesday night. He was 82.
Singapore's President S R Nathan and Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong sent their condolences to Nair's family last night.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO SHOW MAXIMUM SINCERITY TO REACH MERGER DEAL WITH PFP: MA

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday that his party will demonstrate "the maximum sincerity and the greatest good will" to reach a deal with the People First Party (PFP) on merging the two "pan-blue alliance" parties.
Ma made the remarks in reply to media questions after meeting with a delegation sent by PFP Chairman James Soong, who is scheduled to meet Ma Monday, to explore Ma's ideas about the merger project.

The KMT chairman met with PFP legislative caucus convener Huang Yi-chiao and PFP Legislators Sun Ta-chien and Chang Hsien-yao to discuss the merger plan which Ma said his party hopes to see completed by the end of this year. The KMT's Central Standing Committee passed a resolution on May 19, 2004 approving the plan to merge the KMT with the PFP.

Asked whether the PFP will make the nomination of Sung as the "pan-blue alliance" candidate in next year's Taipei mayoral election one of the conditions of the merger, Ma said that the matter was not raised by the PFP representatives with whom he met.

Ma, whose term as Taipei City mayor will end next year, had mentioned earlier that he has no personal preference regarding who should replace him. He also had said that a candidate should be chosen according to the party's rules, which stipulate that primaries must be held.

Meanwhile, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, a KMT stalwart, reiterated his lack of interest in becoming premier in the event that President Chen Shui-bian decides to reshuffle the current Cabinet led by Frank Hsieh, who has offered to resign in the wake of last week's election defeat suffered by his ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Wang, who lost the party chairmanship race to Ma in July, told KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chan that no one has discussed the matter with him and that he does not intend to become premier. "I simply want to remain as the speaker of the legislature," Wang said.

Meanwhile, in the "pan-green camp, " Vice President Annette Lu said Thursday she's still recovering from the surprise of being catapulted to the post of acting chairwoman of the DPP the previous day and has not thought about whether she will run for the post of chairwoman of the party next year.
If Lu were to run and win, one possible scenario would have her pitted against another Harvard graduate, the KMT's Ma, when the next presidential election rolls around in 2008.

However, Lu advised the media not to speculate about 2008 which she said is still too far off. She pointed out that she hasn't even had a chance to give thought to what the new DPP lineup will be following the party's major setback in the local elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened low and closed lower Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 80.33 points to close at 6,249.19.
The bourse opened at 6,302.08 and fluctuated between 6,223.35 and 6,316.58 during trading. A total of 3.71 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$93.39 billion (US$2.79 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with banking and financial shares moving down the most at 3.3 percent, followed by construction issues at 1.4 percent, textile stocks at 1.1 percent, cement stocks at 1 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 0.9 percent, and foodstuff issues and plastics and chemicals shares both at 0.6 percent.
Paper and pulp issues remained unchanged.
Losers outnumbered gainers 760 to 285, with 161 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: INT'L ELECTION OBSERVERS IMPRESSED BY TAIWAN'S DEMOCRACY: MOFA

TEXT.P: International groups from more than 20 countries who sent representatives to observe Taiwan's "three-in-one" elections said they were impressed by the island's democratic development, citing especially that there were no incidents of violence before, during or after the polls.

Michel Lu, a spokesman of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), made the remarks Thursday when he reported on the findings of the international observers of the just-concluded elections for city and county chiefs, city and county councilors, and village and township heads.
Lu said that the groups were very positive about the deepening of democracy in Taiwan as demonstrated by the successful elections and that they "lauded Taiwan as being an advanced country."

A lot of these observers also expressed concerns about whether there will be any major changes in cross-strait relations in the wake of the elections in which the ruling Democratic Progressive Party experienced a major defeat, Lu said, adding that there are unlikely to be any abrupt changes.

As for the release of the Taichung mayor's medical records during the campaign in an attempt to thwart his re-election bid and as for the distribution of a video disc allegedly defaming the Taoyuan County magistrate for the same reason, Lu said such incidents during the heated campaign gave the observers "novel" feelings. Both incumbents ended up winning their respective races.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: The Moscow Times: Up to 208 People Exposed to HIV Blood in Voronezh Up to 208 people might have accidentally been given blood from an HIV-positive donor in Voronezh, Ekho Moskvy radio and RIA-Novosti reported Wednesday. So far, one woman has tested positive after receiving a transfusion of the infected blood, said the head of the Voronezh regional health department, Mikhail Ivanov, Interfax said. [By Chang Hung-kuang]

DOC.HEADLINE: LONG WORK HOURS AFFECT TAIWAN WORK FORCE'S WELL-BEING

TEXT.P: The Taiwanese are a nation of workaholics, working 2,282 hours a year, or 6.25 hours per day all year round without counting days off, resulting in a whopping 84 percent of them claiming that long hours have negatively affected their health or quality of life.

This is one of the findings by Winner magazine and 1111 Jobs Bank, which jointly surveyed 1,654 people between Nov. 22 and Dec. 5 with a margin of error of 2.4 percent. The results were released Thursday.

Previous surveys have found that 57 percent of Taiwan workers fear death from overwork, that 35 percent of white-collar workers regularly stay late at the office, that high-tech workers have low quality of life in spite of higher income, and that 80 percent of the workers would be willing to accept temporary employment, as temporary staffing has become a trend among local businesses.

In the latest survey, more than 70 percent said they work an average of more than eight hours per day, meaning the extra hours have become routine, with many enjoying fewer holidays than legally allowed.

Of all the respondents, 41 percent said they are concerned about the negative impact of long work hours on their health, 24 percent worry that they are losing their leisure time and 19 percent worry that they are enjoying less time with their families.

As to why they cannot complete their work even with extra hours and days, 26 percent each said their companies are under-staffed and that they simply do not know how to tackle a host of the issues that confront them.
These two complaints were followed by "colleagues not being cooperative enough" (18 percent) and "executives demanding too much from them" (13 percent).

In order to surmount the time pressure at work and increase efficiency, 71 percent of Taiwan workers are coming to rely more and more on the latest gadgets, such as notebook computers and personal digital assistants (PDA) to help improve their time management.

The most popular work assisting device is the notebook, with 48 percent of working people using them, followed by traditional notebooks, used by 22 percent, and PDA cell phones, adopted by 17 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CAN PILOT DEMOCRACY THROUGH HONG KONG, CHINA: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian expressed confidence Thursday that Taiwan will eventually lead democracy to prevail in Hong Kong and China, laying a solid foundation for perpetual peace across the Taiwan Strait.
Chen said that compared with Hong Kong and China, Taiwan is a trailblazer among ethnic Chinese communities in Asia in terms of its democratic development.
"Although China has a strong magnetic effect on the world economy, Taiwan can be an exemplar as a lighthouse of democracy, " Chen said.

The president made the remarks in the latest edition of his online newsletter, in which he commented on the Dec. 4 mass demonstration staged by 250,000 Hong Kong residents demanding universal suffrage to elect the region's chief executive and Legislative Council.
Chen recalled that more than 500,000 Hong Kong people took to the streets July 1, 2003 in protest against a proposed anti-subversion law, which shocked Beijing and drew global attention.

On July 13 the same year, more than 20,000 people protested outside the Legislative Council to ask for a popular election for the chief executive in 2007 and for the Legislative Council in 2008, Chen pointed out.

However, these calls for democracy were negated by the government of the special administrative region, which only agreed to increase the members of the electoral college eligible to elect the chief executive and the seats in the Legislative Council, Chen noted.
"The Hong Kong people are still deprived of the right to elect their chief executive and members of the Legislative Council, which remains democracy in a bird cage," he said.

By claiming that political parties in Hong Kong are not mature enough to handle popular elections, Hong Kong Chief Executive Donald Tsang was using the same excuse that had been employed by the past authoritarian rulers in Taiwan, Chen said.
"Before they actually lose power, no dictators will admit the conditions for democracy are ripe, because they themselves are the biggest barricade to democracy," he said.
According to Chen, democracy is a universal value and a basic right that every person should be entitled to regardless of his cultural background, ethnic identity or religious belief.

While no government should arbitrarily deprive its people of such a right, history has proven that the development of democracy is like drops of water converging slowly to become a big river that flows eventually into the sea -- a course that no-one can block or reverse, Chen said.
The demonstration by the Hong Kong people for universal suffrage also proves that the democratic development of Taiwan is not an isolated case, he said.

He pointed out that in the past, the authoritarian rulers in Taiwan refused to allow the people to be their own masters, on the grounds that the democratic system was incompatible with the Chinese, that people did not have enough education to make democracy work, and that democracy would affect the country's economic development.
"But it has been proven by facts that these lies and excuses could not withstand the test of time," he said.

Citing the Dec. 3 "three-in-one" elections in Taiwan as an example of democracy, Chen said all parties must accept the choices of the people unconditionally because only the people are the true masters of the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, gaining NT$0.016 to close at NT$33.501.
A total of US$920 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.485 and fluctuated between NT$33.390 and NT$33.517.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for December moved down 107 points to close at 6,240, with 34,819 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for January moved down 109 points to end at 6,237, with 1,143 contracts traded, while March futures lost 98 points to finish at 6,248, with 35 contracts traded. June futures moved down 138 points to close at 6,208, with five contracts traded, while September futures moved down 118 points to close at 6,106, with seven contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 6,347 for December, 6,346 for January, 6,346 for March, 6,346 for June and 6,224 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.
December TE futures moved down 4.2 points to close at 272, with 6,381 contracts traded, while January TE futures lost 3.65 points to finish at 272.45, with 142 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.

December TF futures lost 33.4 points to finish at 871.2, with 7,288 contracts changing hands, while January TF futures moved down 32 points to end at 872.2, with 424 contracts traded. March TF futures moved down 37.4 points to close at 868.6, with 10 contract transactions, while June TF futures lost 29.8 points to finish at 875, with two contracts traded. September TF futures lost 28 points to close at 866.6, with one contract transaction.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT-PFP NEGOTIATION MECHANISM FOR MERGER DUE BY LATE JANUARY

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and its "pan blue alliance" ally the People First Party (PFP) agreed Thursday to move toward a merger in two phases, with the first phase slated to be completed by the end of January next year, according to KMT officials and PFP lawmakers.
The conclusion was reached between KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and a five-member task force of PFP lawmakers during a closed-door meeting of more than two hours at KMT headquarters.

The two parties agreed initially to jointly iron out a negotiation mechanism for nominating candidates to run for all levels of public office by the end of January 2006, and for the establishment of a negotiating platform to deal with personnel and legal affairs, members of which will be announced by the two parties' chairmen next Monday following a further meeting, PFP Legislator Daniel Y.C. Huang said.

During the process toward an eventual merger, the two parties will continue collaborating based on the principles of respecting public opinion, building mutual trust, establishing a sound system and sharpening competitive edges, Huang added.
The PFP will carry out the merger with the KMT through a democratic process, and the opinions and options of individual lawmakers will be fully respected, he noted.

KMT spokeswoman Cheng Lee-wen said that future negotiation mechanisms will be clearly laid out after Ma and PFP Chairman James Soong meet Dec. 12, and that officials of the two parties will meet periodically afterwards until the merger has been accomplished.

The two parties in the "pan blue alliance" have accelerated their pace of pushing for a much talked-about merger in the wake of the Dec. 3 local government elections, in which the KMT strongly outshone the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Although Soong has repeatedly claimed that the PFP will walk its own path regardless of pressure from the KMT, the PFP's miserable showing in last weekend's elections has prompted grave concern among supporters that the party might disappear from Taiwan's political map.

The KMT, the PFP and the New Party formed the "pan blue alliance" prior to the presidential election in March 2004, in which the KMT-PFP ticket lost by a razor-thin margin to the DPP ticket that was seeking re-election.

Soong set up the PFP in 2000 after losing his bid for presidency in the presidential race to President Chen Shui-bian in March that year. Soong, who used to be an all-powerful KMT secretary-general, had defected from the party and ran as an independent in the 2000 presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SENDS MISSION TO SAO TOME AND PRINCIPE TO FIGHT CHOLERA

TEXT.P: Taiwan has sent a mission to Sao Tome and Principe to help the African ally control a cholera outbreak that has killed nearly 20 people, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs official said Thursday.

According to Lee Chen-hsiung, director-general of the ministry's Department of African Affairs, more than 1,000 suspected cholera cases had been reported in Sao Tome and Principe as of Dec. 4 since the outbreak first erupted in October, with 60 of the cases having been confirmed.
During a visit to Taiwan in November, Sao Tome President Fradique Bandeira Melo de Menezes requested emergency assistance from Taiwan to contain the outbreak, Lee noted.

In addition to offering US$100,000 in emergency relief aid, the government has also assigned a team of health and environmental protection officials as well as healthcare workers to the African nation, he said.
Sao Tome Deputy Prime Minister Jose Viega expressed his gratitude for the assistance provided by Taiwan during a meeting with members of the Taiwan mission Dec. 3, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO CONVENE MEETING ON PARTY DEVELOPMENT AFTER ELECTION SETBACK

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will convene a meeting to discuss the future of the party's development after its setback in last Saturday's city and county chief elections, a DPP official said Thursday.
The DPP decided at its central standing committee meeting a day earlier that it will set up a party development commission exclusively responsible for the issue.
The date of convening the conference and the formation of the commission will be decided at next week's central standing committee meeting, the official added.

As Su Tseng-chang stepped down from the DPP chairmanship to take responsibility for the party's defeat in last Saturday's "three-in-one" elections, Vice President Annette Lu was named to serve as the acting chairwoman of the DPP during the central standing committee meeting, the first of its kind since the elections, in which the DPP only garnered six of the 23 city mayor and county magistrate posts, far behind the 14 seized by the opposition Kuomintang (KMT).

Some DPP candidates for city mayor and magistrate posts have attributed the party's setback to the combination of three grassroots elections in a single day, which they claimed made it easier for the KMT to buy votes due to its long grip on grassroots constituencies. The KMT ruled Taiwan for more than 50 years until it was defeated by the DPP in the 2000 presidential election.

It is expected that a review of the nomination system for future elections and the interaction between the party and the government will be high on the agenda of the party development meeting, the DPP official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG MAYOR UNDECIDED WHETHER TO SUE 12 DOCTORS

TEXT.P: Re-elected Taichung Mayor Jason Hu said Thursday that he is still undecided as to whether he will sue the 12 doctors who released what they claimed to be his medical records before the Dec. 3 election in an attempt to diminish his chances of winning.

Hu, who looked quite healthy despite reports that he suffered a stroke on a trip to the United States in August 2002, made the remarks when asked to comment on the penalties meted out to the 12 doctors by the Medical Doctor Disciplinary Committee under the Taichung city government's health authorities Wednesday.

One of the doctors -- Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Peter Lin, who played a leading role in disclosing what he claimed were Hu's medical records at a news conference in Taichung -- received the harshest punishment, with his licence to practice medicine suspended for one year.

Another was banned from practicing medicine for one month and ordered to attend 32 hours of re-education classes on medical ethics. The others were given warnings and must attend mandatory classes on medical ethics totalling from eight to 24 hours.
Hu, of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), said he respects the rulings by the city government's health authorities and said he did not interfere in any way in their decisions.

Hu added that the outcome is not yet final, because health authorities at a higher level might still have a say on the issue. He said he will not rule out any possibility at this stage, but will wait and see the final result before deciding whether it is necessary to sue the 12 doctors.

At a press conference at the legislature in Taipei Thursday, Lin challenged the ruling on the grounds that his hospital is located in Kaohsiung and is therefore not under the jurisdiction of the health authorities of the Taichung city government.
He also attempted to defend his integrity, claiming that he was "doing the right thing" by revealing the alleged medical records, as he thought Hu was "not fit" to serve a second term.
The DPP legislator also said that he will push for legislation to require candidates for public office to disclose their health information.
Meanwhile, the KMT legislative caucus urged Lin to withdraw from the legislature's Sanitation, Environment and Social Welfare Committee to avoid a conflict of interests.

Caucus whips pointed out that Lin has another case pending against him. In October the Bureau of National Health Insurance charged that his hospital used forged records of overnight patients to get reimbursements from the bureau.

Asked to comment on the dispute over the ruling by the Taichung health authorities, a spokesman for the Department of Health (DOH) under the Cabinet said the health authority under the Kaohsiung city government will have to either enforce the ruling of the Taichung health authority or hold a hearing of its own to hear Lin defend himself.

The spokesman also said that Lin can appeal his case to the DOH's disciplinary committee within 20 days and that if the DOH upholds the ruling, he will be banned from practicing medicine for one year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN 11TH MOST POPULAR DESTINATION IN ASIA FOR AMERICANS: POLL
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Dec. 8 (CNA) (By S.C. Wu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan would be the 11th most popular destination in Asia for American travelers if they were to choose a place for sightseeing during the first half of next year, according to a recent survey by the prestigious Conde Nast Travelers magazine.

Results of the poll of 29,000 American travelers show that Taiwan is in 11th place after Thailand, Hong Kong, China, Japan, Vietnam, India, Malaysia, Singapore, Laos and Cambodia, but ahead of South Korea, Indonesia, the Philippines, Sri Lanka, the Maldives and Myanmar.

Among the American people who have visited countries in Asia this year, 39 percent of the respondents visited Hong Kong, ahead of 33 percent who opted for China and 29 percent who traveled to Thailand, the poll results show.

Lisa Hughes, an executive at the Conde Nast Traveler research center, attributed Asia's abundant cultural heritages to its appeal for American tourists, evidenced in that as many as 90 percent of the Americans surveyed expressed a willingness to visit Asian countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: 8 OF TAIWAN'S TOP 20 COMPANIES INVESTING IN CHINA: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Eight out of Taiwan's top 20 corporations have investments in China, according to the results of a business survey published Thursday.

Hon Hai topped the list as the largest Taiwan conglomerate maintaining the biggest Taiwan-invested company in China, according to the recent survey jointly conducted by the Taipei-based Commercial Times and the China Credit Information Service (CCIS).

Hon Hai, which is also the largest company in Taiwan, is followed by seven other Taiwan companies that are also among the top 20 companies in Taiwan and the top 20 Taiwanese companies in China. They are: Quanta Computer, Compal, AU Optronics, BenQ, Inventec, Acer and Chunghwa Picture Tubes, in that order, the poll found.
All these eight top-ranking Taiwanese companies are in the high-technology business, the poll found.

Commercial Times and CCIS published a list of the top 1,000 Taiwanese companies in China Thursday after a 10-month survey, the first of its kind. CCIS defines the size of a company by gauging its business turnover, pre-tax net profit, authorized capital, issued shares and net value.
According to the poll, all top 10 Taiwanese companies in China are in the hi-tech sector and 67 of the top 100 Taiwanese companies in China are in the same sector.
However, the poll found that nearly 70 percent of the top 1,000 Taiwanese companies in China are in traditional industries, with the types of businesses varying greatly.

Of them, Cheng Shin Tire, which sells automobile tires under the brand name Maxxis in Taiwan, is one of the Taiwanese companies that relocated their manufacturing operations to China the earliest. Cheng Shin was the 56th-largest Taiwanese company in China in 2004 with annual transactions there totaling 1.944 billion yuan. The company ranked 9th among all Taiwanese companies in China last year in terms of pre-tax net profit.

According to the survey, business transactions of the 1,000 leading Taiwanese companies in China totaled some 733.6 billion yuan (US$22.23 billion) in 2004, roughly equivalent to 25 percent of Taiwan's gross domestic product in that year.
CCIS conducted the survey via telephone and fax between February and November this year and obtained 1,350 valid responses. It had a margin of error of 2 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER PLEDGES TO DO A GOOD JOB

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Thursday that he will try to do a good job as long as he remains premier, amid public speculation that he might be replaced in an upcoming Cabinet reshuffle.

Hsieh offered to resign early this week in the wake of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's drubbing in the Dec. 3 elections for county and city chiefs but was asked to stay on by President Chen Shui-bian.
The premier spoke on the subject before starting a speech on economic issues to members of the European Chamber of Commerce Taipei and the American Chamber of Commerce.
In his speech, Hsieh said Taiwan's economy remains sound, with export orders amounting to US$207.2 billion in the first 10 months of this year, up 18.03 percent from the same period of last year.
While the unemployment rate has fallen, foreign investors have continued to invest in Taiwan's stock market and have made a lot of money, Hsieh said.
He expressed his disapproval of a plan by some legislators to enact a law to control the interest rates on credit cards and cash cards to below 10 percent.

On cross-Taiwan Strait relations, he said that although a more open cross-strait policy is required from the point of view of businessmen, cross-strait affairs also involve other considerations such as national security.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH TO STRENGTHEN ANTI-SMOKING TRAINING FOR CONVENIENCE STORES

TEXT.P: A Department of Health (DOH) official said Thursday that there is still room for convenience store staff to strengthen their techniques for refusing to sell cigarettes to teenagers.

Chao Kun-yu, deputy director-general of the DOH Bureau of Health Promotion, made the remarks after inspecting a training program for convenience store staff to improve their knowledge of the Tobacco Hazard Control Act and to learn techniques for refusing to sell cigarettes to people under the age of 18.

Chao noted that the DOH has presented proposals for an amendment to the Tobacco Hazard Control Act to the legislature for screening, which will include some changes to the way stores are allowed to exhibit their tobacco products.
Once the proposals are approved by the legislature, stores will be prohibited from showing their cigarettes in open shelves and should carry anti-smoking warning signs in their stores.

According to the existing Tobacco Hazard Control Act, people under 18 are prohibited from smoking, while people who sell tobacco products to teenagers under 18 can be fined between NT$3,000 (US$89) and NT$10,000.

The DOH statistics show that as of November, the number of teenagers caught smoking had reached 2,976, while that of stores caught illegally selling cigarettes to teenagers totaled 398, with 44.7 percent of the sales at the five major convenience store chains, followed by betel nut shops and grocery stores.

DOC.HEADLINE: TUNA FISHING OPERATORS WANT NAME LIST PRODUCED BY 'FAIR' SYSTEM

TEXT.P: Tuna fishing operators in the southern port city of Kaohsiung called Thursday for a "fair and just" mechanism for the selection of the 15 fishing vessels that will be allowed to continue fishing for bigeye tuna in the Atlantic.

Tuna boat operators made the appeal to the Fisheries Administration under the Council of Agriculture and the Taiwan Tuna Association as they are preparing to provide a list of names of those allowed to continue operation to the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna (ICCAT) by Dec. 20.

They said they had asked the Fisheries Administration to elaborate on the screening situation, but had yet to receive any response, and expressed the hope that the fishery officials has no preset name list, as this would be "very unfair."

One tuna boat operator noted that a big tuna vessel can cost up to NT$100 million (US$2.98 million) and that sometimes one fishing company is only able to own one fishing vessel. If the vessel cannot continue to operate, then the company faces closure.
Tuna boat operators also complained about the amount of subsidies to be provided by the government for more than 40 soon-to-be-grounded fishing vessels.

The COA decided to subsidize NT$5.97 million for each of the Taiwanese fishing vessels currently operating in the Atlantic Ocean but which will have to return to Taiwan after new catch quotas are put into practice.
Taiwan Tuna Association officials said the subsidies will in no way make up for the losses caused by the quota cut.
Association officials estimated that fuel, loans and crew salaries will cost more than NT$16 million, which is a far cry from the subsidy promised by the government.

The ICCAT decided last month to slash Taiwan's total allowable catch of bigeye tuna for 2006 by almost 70 percent to 4,600 tons from the 2005 quota of 14,900 tons, as a punishment for indiscriminate overfishing.

Taiwan presently has 76 deep-sea fishing vessels specializing in catching bigeye tuna in the Atlantic. In the face of an almost 70 percent quota cut, only 15 of those vessels will be allowed to operate in the Atlantic in the coming year. Twenty of the ships will be used to fish for longfin tuna and the remaining 41 will be taken out of operation.
Fishery authorities estimated that the quota cut will cause a loss of NT$1.92 billion in revenue per year, but the fishing industry claim that the total losses could top NT$10 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CANDIDATE FOR TAIPEI MAYOR ELECTION MUST BE PRODUCED VIA PRIMARY

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) candidate for the next Taipei mayoral election must be produced via party primaries, KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday.

No-one will be exempt from this mechanism, Ma said in response to reporters' questions about an alleged attempt by opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong to enter the Taipei mayoral race.

The reporters asked Ma whether Soong, who has previously served as Taiwan governor and as a KMT secretary-general, should take part in the KMT primaries for a KMT nomination for the Taipei mayoral race if the KMT and the PFP merge in the near future.
Ma said firmly that so long as Soong is a KMT member, he will have to observe the rules of the KMT electoral mechanism.

DOC.HEADLINE: EATING HOT POT AND DRINKING ICE WATER DO NOT MIX: DOCTOR

TEXT.P: Eating hot pot with family or friends is the "in" thing again, with the mercury dropping sharply in Taiwan over the past week, but doctors caution that not knowing how to eat hot pot properly could cause a headache or high blood pressure.

Ho Yi-chen, a doctor at the Department of Family Medicine at the Yin Shu-tien Memorial Hospital, explained at a news conference Thursday that eating hot pot and drinking ice water alternately without at least a three-minute interval could cause the diner to have a spasmodic pain in the head and elevate his blood pressure.
He said he had recently treated a 30-year-old patient who complained about these symptoms after he kept drinking ice water to cool down while eating hot pot.
Dr. Ho said that about 30 percent of Taiwan's population aged 20 and over could have high blood pressure, and that winter is the season when their problems could get worse.

The doctor advised that it is important to keep the internal organs warm during winter and that after eating a hot bowl of soup, a diner should wait at lease three minutes before drinking anything cold.
Ho said that if a diner is struck by a headache after eating hot pot, he should visit a doctor as soon as possible to find out if he has a high blood pressure problem.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN USING GOOD FAITH TO IMPROVE CROSS-STRAIT TIES: MAC CHIEF
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, D. C. Dec. 8 (CNA) (By Olive Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Despite China's incessant attempts to choke off Taiwan in the international community, Taiwan still has the good faith to promote peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said Wednesday.

Wu made the remarks while giving a keynote speech titled, "Taiwanese efforts for Peace and Stability across the Strait" at a seminar sponsored by the Washington-based Center for National Policy -- a non-profit and non-partisan think tank devoted to the transfer of ideas and information from experts to public officials.

Saying that China is seeking to push Taiwan off the world stage with missiles and checkbook diplomacy, Wu pointed out that this Chinese mindset has stirred strong resentment among Taiwan people and have seriously restricted cross-strait relations.
Beijing should take concrete measures to reduce the hostilities felt by the people in Taiwan, he urged.

He claimed that China has often misinterpreted Taiwan's democratization efforts as attempts to pursue de-jure independence, and said that opinion polls have repeatedly showed that most of Taiwan people are in favor of maintaining the cross-strait status quo and would not like to change the country's official title, national flag or territorial boundaries as stipulated in the Republic of China Constitution.

The government on Taiwan is also open to holding political talks with China as long as the Taiwan people reach a consensus on allowing it to do so, he said, adding that Taiwan would not rule out any forms of political relations with China but that it can never accept Beijing's "one China" precondition for opening bilateral talks, he stressed.

The MAC also thanked the United States for its long-standing support for Taiwan and called on Washington to continue persuading Beijing to drop its military intimidation of Taiwan and to resume cross-strait negotiations.
Wu departed for Taiwan Thursday after wrapping up a three-day visit in the U. S. capital.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ENTRANCE INTO WTO CONTRIBUTED 2.2 % TO PER CAPITA INCOME

TEXT.P: Taiwan's entrance into the World Trade Organization (WTO) in 2002 has been positive for the nation's economy, and it has contributed 2.2 percent to Taiwan's per capita income because of increased trade with other nations, an academic said Thursday.

Hsu Tzeung-che, an associate researcher from the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research, made the remarks at a seminar on issues related to the upcoming WTO ministerial meeting in Hong Kong. The seminar was presided over by Ko Cheng-en, president of the think tank.
The Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics has estimated that the per capita income in Taiwan will be US$15,659 this year.

Hsu said that looking at the economic performance of Taiwan between 2002 and 2004, it was better than predicted before joining the WTO, with the gross domestic product (GDP) growth exceeding 3 percent, and the average growth of imports and exports registering 16.63 percent and 12.46 percent, respectively. The jobless rate was more than 5 percent since 2002, but fell to 4.07 percent in October this year.

Though Taiwan's population in the agriculture sector was cut slightly after entering the WTO, the production value of agriculture has increased to NT$600,000 from NT$500,000 per capita due to increased exports of rice and tea.

In terms of individual sectors, Hsu said that the production value of such sectors as automobiles, heavy electric and machinery as well as electronics for local demand has grown, while export sectors such as machinery, electronics and information as well as plastic products have also grown.
Motorcycles, textiles, garments, and food sectors are showing a growth trend after an initial decline.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN DENIES SPECULATION ON A 'PAN-BLUE' CABINET

TEXT.P: Ma Ying-jeou, chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), said Thursday that the KMT has received no proposal from the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government to let the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party (PFP) nominate the next premier and form the Cabinet.

Asked to clarify media reports that the DPP has contacted Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, asking him to be the next premier, Ma said that no one from the DPP government has approached the KMT about the matter, and nor has the KMT made any request to the DPP in this regard.

Ma, who is also Taipei mayor, said the KMT position on the issue is very clear: The KMT is willing to accept such a proposal if President Chen Shui-bian abides by the Republic of China Constitution and allows the government to operate under the "double-government head" system.

He explained that if the "pan-blue alliance" is to form the Cabinet, the premier must be designated by the alliance rather than by the president, who will only announce the appointment in his capacity as head of state.
Pressed again on whether Wang could become the next premier, Ma said what has been said in news report are not necessarily true.
Meanwhile, Wang told reporters that Lien Chan, honorary chairman of the KMT, had queried him twice about the reported DPP proposal.

However, Wang said, his reply to Lien was that no one from the DPP has approached him, that he has no intention of serving as a premier in the DPP government, and that he wants to continue to be the speaker in the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LEADER SHOULD MAKE CLEAR HIS VIEWS ON SOVEREIGNTY: MAC
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 8 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou should make clear his stance on the country's sovereignty and national security if he wants to be the country's leader in the future, a high-ranking ROC official said Wednesday.

Joseph Wu, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), which is responsible for Taiwan's policy toward China, made the remarks after delivering a speech on Capital Hill about Taiwan's efforts in promoting cross-Taiwan Strait peace at the invitation of the Center for National Policy, a Washington-based organization dedicated to policy debate on issues of U.S. national interest.

Wu noted that many important political leaders in Taiwan have stated that Taiwan is a sovereign country with its official name being the "Republic of China, " and only the 23 million people of the island have the right to decide whether to change the political status of the country.

Ma is considered by many to be a serious contender for the next presidential race in 2008. However, Wu added, Ma still has not made public his views on the issues related to Taiwan's sovereignty or national security, which are of great concern to the U.S. government.

It is natural that different political parties have different views on internal affairs, but there should be a consensus within the country regarding issues such as national security, Wu said. He apparently was referring to the arms procurement package from the United States that is still pending the approval of the legislature.

The arms package, which includes eight diesel-electric submarines, a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft and six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries from the United States, has been blocked from being screened in the opposition-controlled legislature.

With the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) dismal performance in last Saturday's city and county chief elections, many are concerned that it will be harder for the arms package to pass the legislature as the opposition "pan-blue alliance" will have a stronger grip on the country's new political panorama.
According to Wu, the DPP government will continue communicating with the opposition parties on the arms procurement budget.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN REMITTANCES INTO TAIWAN HIT RECORD HIGH IN NOVEMBER

TEXT.P: Net foreign remittances to Taiwan's stock market amounted to a record high of US$5.332 billion in November, besting the previous record of US$4.809 billion registered in June, according to tallies released Thursday by the Financial Supervisory Commission's Securities and Futures Bureau.

From Jan. 1 to Dec. 2, foreign investors bought listed shares worth NT$3.289 trillion and sold listed shares worth NT$2.793 trillion in Taiwan, posting a net buying worth of NT$496.2 billion, the tallies show.

During the same period, foreign investors purchased over-the-counter shares worth NT$196.8 billion and sold over-the-counter shares worth NT$135.5 billion, with net buying registering NT$61.3 billion.
Since the government allowed foreign investment in Taiwan's stock market in December 1990, foreign institutional investors had remitted US$100.701 billion net into Taiwan as of Dec. 2.
The total foreign remittances during that period amounted to NT$100.734 billion, including US$33 million remitted by overseas Chinese and foreign individuals.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:

DOC.HEADLINE: RECORD HAUL OF COUNTERFEIT MEDICINES SEIZED

TEXT.P: A big haul of counterfeit medicines -- more than 550,000 capsules and pills with a street value of around NT$300 million (US$9.09 million) -- has been seized in Taipei County, the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) announced Thursday.

The seized counterfeit medicines, including the well-known weight-loss drug Reductil (Sibutramine) and drugs for the treatment of erectile dysfunction -- Viagra and Cialis -- marked the largest seizure of smuggled bootleg medicines in Taiwan in recent years, CIB officials said.

CIB investigators raided a warehouse in Hsichih, Taipei County Wednesday night and seized the drugs, which included 50,000 tablets of the anti-obesity medicine Reductil (Sibutramine), more than 50,000 tablets of Viagra, over 70,000 tablets of Cialis, more than 100,000 tablets of medicine for colds, 20,000 tablets of the gastrointestinal medicine Zantac, 70,000 tablets of controlled hypnotics Stilnox, and some 210,000 unknown pills.
The investigators learned that the medicines were counterfeited in China and smuggled into Taiwan in parcels mailed via either air mail or sea mail.

The police also learned that the drug smugglers have sold the counterfeit medicines at lower-than-normal prices to local pharmacies. For example, they said, a 30-tablet pack of Reductil, worth NT$3,500 over the counter if authentic, was sold for only NT$1,000.

According to Lin Keng-feng, a suspect nabbed during the raid, dealers of these counterfeit medicines have distributed the fake drugs to pharmacies around northern Taiwan, adding that seven out of every 10 pharmacies in northern Taiwan are believed to have sold bootleg pharmaceuticals.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Air Marshals Shoot and Kill Passenger in Bomb Threat
U.S. federal air marshals shot and killed a passenger at Miami International Airport on Wednesday after the man claimed he had a bomb in his backpack and ran from an aircraft. This is the first case of an air marshal opening fire since marshals became a common presence on flights after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.
Wall Street Journal: Storm Front, Local and Federal Authorities Battle to Control Disaster Relief
The power struggle that unfolded in Florida during Hurricane Wilma is shaping a debate about how the country should respond to disasters, both natural and man-made. The big question: Should state or federal authorities be in control of recovery efforts? Giving the debate more urgency are growing concerns about a possible flu outbreak and experts' warnings that next year's hurricane season may be even deadlier than this summer's record-breaking series. The Bush administration says Katrina showed that some states can't deal with large-scale disasters. The Department of Homeland Security, which oversees the Federal Emergency Management Agency, wants to intervene in response efforts and is pressing local officials to vet their emergency plans. It's also looking to equip locally based federal employees with cameras and communications gear to provide Washington with real-time disaster information.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. SHOULD RECONSIDER 'ONE CHINA' POLICY: TKACIK

TEXT.P: The U.S. government's "one China" policy is a failure and the U.S. should reconsider it by having a clear outline of what it wants East Asia to be in the coming decades, John Tkacik, a senior research fellow at the Heritage Foundation, said in Taipei Thursday.

Tkacik, a keen observer on issues concerning Taiwan, China and Mongolia, had a book published Dec. 8 entitled, "Rethinking 'One China,'" aimed at reminding the U.S. government to reshape its policy towards Taiwan.

"The words 'one China' are very easily misunderstood by people who see them. They might think that the U.S. government supports the 'reunification' of China and that Taiwan is part of China, " Tkacik said.
Tkacik considers the "one China" policy a failed one because it is exactly the opposite of the abbreviated name that is used to describe it.

"The U.S. government should clearly explain what 'one China ' is about. The U.S. should recognize the fact that Taiwan is practically a nation, and Taiwan must have a clear idea of the path it wants to take," he said.
Tkacik said that both the U.S. and Taiwan should be stronger in their policy-making, and the U.S. must have a clearer idea on what it wants East Asia to be in the coming decades.

"The U.S. government should make sure what its interests are in Taiwan. It should also clearly define Taiwan's status as to international law. The bureaucracy should consider overall long term interests in East Asia and make sure about its policy toward Taiwan, and promote those interests," Tkacik said.

"If the U.S. doesn't have a policy compass, then every way could be the way. It has to make a decision on what it wants Asia to be. If it does nothing, then I guarantee that Asia will soon be dominated by authoritarian China. At that time, the U.S. might lose control of Asia," Tkacik said.
According to the senior research fellow, Capitol Hill thinks that China is an increasing challenge to the U.S. in terms of economy, trade, military, finance and politics.

"Although the U.S. doesn't support Taiwan declaring independence, it didn't say it opposes it. Following the 1972 Shanghai Comunique, the U.S. government did not recognize Taiwan as part of China, " Tkacik said.
According to Tkacik, Taiwan is the U.S.'s 10th-largest trading partner. If Taiwan were under China, the two countries obviously could not go on with their trade and business, he said.

"Taiwan declaring independence cannot be a reason for war because it would just be words on paper. It will bring no change to the situation because very few countries in the world recognize Taiwan as an independent nation," Tkacik said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOI TO SET UP CAMPAIGN AGAINST DOMESTIC VIOLENCE, CHILD ABUSE

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior (MOI) will set up a special task force to deal with issues regarding domestic violence and child abuse, a senior official said Thursday.
According to the official, Minister of the Interior Su Jia-chyuan made the announcement at an MOI department chiefs meeting a day earlier on prevention of domestic violence and child abuse.
Su said MOI Vice Minister Lin Chung-sen will serve as convener of the soon-to-be-formed task force to better cope with domestic violence and child abuse issues.

The special task force will invite police, civil affairs officials, social workers, educators and public health experts to a brainstorming meeting to discuss effective strategies to rescue domestic violence victims and abused children, Su said.
In addition, Su said, the task force will craft a viable mechanism to encourage reporting of cases involving domestic violence and child abuse.
"We should consider cash incentives to encourage reporting of those cases. It would be worthwhile so long as we can save more young lives and their childhoods," Su said.
Meanwhile, Su said, the MOI will direct city/county governments to push for formation of more civic groups to help with reporting of child abuse and domestic violence cases.
According to MOI tallies, 7,800 cases involving child/adolescent abuse were reported in 2004 and as of the end of September this year, 7,500 such cases had already been reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO KIDD-CLASS DESTROYERS ARRIVE AT SUAO NAVAL BASE FROM THE U.S.

TEXT.P: Two of the four Kidd-class destroyers that Taiwan purchased from the United States in 2003 arrived at the northeastern military base of Suao Thursday.

Republic of China Navy Commander-in-Chief Adm. Chen Pang-chih directed the whole port-entrance maneuvering of the two destroyers, named the Keelung and the Suao, which were delivered to the ROC Navy Oct. 29 from a shipyard in Charleston, South Carolina.

President Chen Shui-bian is expected to travel to Suao in mid-December to officiate at a ceremony marking the commissioning of the two destroyers in his capacity as the commander-in-chief of the ROC armed forces.

Navy officers and seed instructors, as well as repair and maintenance technicians have received training in the United States to prepare for the delivery of the two de-mothballed destroyers, which have also undergone sea trials and weaponry systems tests over the past month, the navy authorities said.
The other two destroyers are expected by March 2007.
Taiwan purchased the four then-mothballed destroyers, built in the late 1970s, at a cost of NT$24 billion (US$0.73 billion) in June 2003.

The navy authorities said that after the two Kidd-class destroyers are commissioned, they will form the outer periphery of a naval defensive fleet, while the Perry-class, Knox-class and Lafayette-class frigates will play an inner circle role.
The Kidd-class destroyers will target enemy planes that have fired missiles, allowing other vessels to deal with the incoming missiles, they said.

Taiwan submitted a shopping list in 2001 that included top-of-the-line U.S. destroyers of the Arleigh Burke-class equipped with the Aegis radar system, but the Bush administration later approved the sale of only the much older Kidd-class destroyers.

The purchase was embroiled in a fierce debate. Opponents of the purchase included members of the legislature's powerful defense committee, which made several attempts to block the sale. Critics cited the age of the ships and their high cost and suggested that Taiwan should push the U.S. to release the Aegis system sooner.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENVOY EXPRESSES THE HOPE THAT ROC PREMIER CAN VISIT FRANCE
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Dec. 8 (CNA) (By Lo Yuan-shao and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Representative to France Yang Tzu-pao on Thursday expressed the hope that France can also welcome a visit by the ROC's premier as it did to Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao.

Yang made the remarks in response to French reporters' questions about his opinion regarding Wen's recent visit to France, in which the Chinese premier placed orders for 150 Airbus jets. France was the first leg of Wen's European trip.
Yang welcomed China's purchase of Airbus planes, saying that at least they are not buying missiles.

Noting that it is a good thing that China intends to join and participate in the international community, Yang said that the latter should allow China to understand that being a superpower comes with many responsibilities, such as environmental protection and treating other Asian countries well, including Taiwan.
Yang also said he hopes that while welcoming Wen's visit, the French government can also extend an invitation to the ROC's premier for a visit.
As Taiwan and France do not have diplomatic relations, most ROC officials' France visits are private in nature..

ROC Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san managed to visit Toulouse, headquarters of Airbus, in June to participate in the delivery ceremony of the fourth of eight A330-300s that China Airlines (CAL) ordered from the airplane giant in his capacity as CAL chairman; Lin later visited his French counterpart in Paris, while the ROC foreign minister, Tan Sun Chen, was allowed to stay at a transit hotel in Paris en route to Africa in July.

DOC.HEADLINE: CIVIC GROUP'S KRTC INVESTIGATIONS WOULD HAVE NO TEETH: PROFESSOR

TEXT.P: Investigation by any civic group into the corruption scandal involving the Kaohsiung rapid transit railway project would be in vain because its members do not have the necessary power under the current law, a university professor said Thursday.
Chai Song-lin, professor at National Chengchi University, said in a statement that without legal authorization to do the job, a civic team is unlikely to achieve results in the investigation.

Chai is one of five civic leaders recommended by Premier Frank Hsien as possible members of a team to investigate whether he played a role in the corruption scandal while he was Kaohsiung mayor before becoming premier.
Other would-be members Hsieh suggested include lawyers C.V. Chen and Wang Ching-feng, both respected for their integrity.

Chai said that even if the named civic team does manage to unearth some truths, the findings may not be accepted by all sectors, because society in Taiwan is divided and people of different political persuasions do not trust each other.

The premier's proposal to form a civic team to conduct no-holds-barred investigations on whether he profited from the construction project, whether he violated the law while serving as Kaohsiung mayor, and whether he condoned any unlawful practices during his mayorship, is seen as a move to clear the shadow over his name and consolidate his position as premier after the ruling Democratic Progressive Party government suffered a humiliating defeat in the Dec. 3 local government elections.

1608: British poet John Milton, writer of "Paradise Lost," is born in London.
1824: Simon Bolivar's forces defeat the Spanish army at Ayacucho, Peru.
1905: France decrees the separation of church and state.
1908: Germany's Bundestag passes the Child-Labor Act, prohibiting the employment of children under the age of 13 years.
1930: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of the Nationalist government, convenes a military meeting in Nanchang, in China's Kiangsi Province, to begin an anti-communist campaign.
1935: Students demonstrate in Beijing to protest against the Japanese invasion of northern China and urge unity to save the nation.
1940: The British 8th Army, better known as the Desert Rats, begin an offensive against Germany's Afrikakorps in North Africa.
1941: China formally declares war on Japan, Germany and Italy.
1949: The Executive Yuan of the Republic of China holds its first meeting after moving its office to Taipei.
1961: Tanganyika declares independence.
1965: The United States provides F-5A Fighters to the ROC.
1972: The Soviet Union and North Vietnam reach an accord on military and economic aid to Hanoi.
1974: Col. Manuel Alfonso Rodriguez, chief of the general staff of the Republic of El Salvador, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1974: Japanese Prime Minister Takeo Miki forms a new Cabinet.
1974: Sheikh Ibrahim Al-Sultan, deputy minister of Foreign Affairs of Saudi Arabia, arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit.
1975: Hammer De Roburt, president of the Republic of Nauru, arrives in Taipei to preside over a ceremony marking the opening of flight services between Taiwan and Nauru.
1975: U.S. Assistant Secretary of State Phillip Habib arrives in Taipei to brief the ROC government on President Gerald Ford's visit to the Chinese mainland. Habib reiterates America's policy of maintaining friendly relations with the ROC.
1976: The U.N. General Assembly calls for a Middle East peace conference in Geneva with the Palestine Liberation Organization participating.
1976: W.W. Kethan, president of the International Softball Federation, arrives in Taipei for an eight-day visit.
1986: The Legislative Yuan of the ROC passes a new income tax regulation raising the income tax deduction for each dependent to NT$30,000.
1986: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo receives Nobutaka Shikanai, president of Japan's Sankei Shimbun.
1987: Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev meets with U.S. President Ronald Reagan in Washington after the signing of the U.S.-Soviet nuclear arms treaty.
1990: Lech Walesa, head of Solidarity, an organization advocating free trade unions, is elected president of the Republic of Poland.
1991: Gorbachev calls the newly formed Commonwealth of Independent States illegal and dangerous.
1992: Britain's Prince Charles and Princess Diana announce they are separating but have no plans to divorce.
1996: The military government closes universities as police chase protesting students through the streets of Rangoon, Burma.
1999: ROC President Lee Teng-hui receives Rotary International President Larlo Ravizza and former Rotary presidents Mat Caparas and Glen W. Kinross at the Presidential Office.
2000: Professor Reuben Jih-ru Hwu of National Tsinghua University is selected a fellow of the Third World Academy of Sciences (TWAS) for his outstanding achievements in chemistry studies.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When directing the affairs of a great nation, a man must be serious in attending to business and faithful and punctual in his engagements. He must study economy in the public expenditure, and love the welfare of the people. He must employ the people at the proper time of the year."

DOC.HEADLINE: YU CAREFULLY ASSESSING WHETHER TO RUN FOR DPP CHAIRMANSHIP: SOURCES

TEXT.P: Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun is "carefully assessing" whether to run for the chairmanship of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, sources close to high-ranking officials and senior DPP members revealed Friday.
The sources said that the secretary-general is expected to make a decision on the matter after he meets with President Chen Shui-bian later in the day.
DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang stepped down after the party was soundly defeated by the opposition Kuomintang in the Dec. 3 "three-in-one" local elections.

Although the DPP's Central Standing Committee has named Vice President Annette Lu as the interim chairwoman of the party, there has been a lot of humming among DPP members about Lu's possible participation in vying for the chairmanship of the party.

Facing this new situation, a group of DPP legislators said in an urgent gathering they held Thursday night that as the ruling party's clean and reform image has been harmed by the Kaohsiung Rapid Transport System scandal and as the party will soon be facing the Taipei and Kaohsiung City mayoral elections at the end of next year, the DPP needs a clean, honest, capable and courageous chairman to change the public's feelings about the party and rebuild morale among its members.
According to the sources, several DPP legislators have advised Yu that he should "attach great importance to the party's fate and interests."
Yu told the lawmakers that he will carefully assess the advice and make a decision after meeting with the president to hear his opinion on the matter, the sources also said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO KIDD-CLASS DESTROYERS ARRIVE AT SUAO NAVAL BASE FROM THE U.S.

TEXT.P: Two of the four Kidd-class destroyers that Taiwan purchased from the United States in 2003 arrived at the northeastern military base of Suao Thursday.

Republic of China Navy Commander-in-Chief Adm. Chen Pang-chih directed the whole port-entrance maneuvering of the two destroyers, named the Keelung and the Suao, which were delivered to the ROC Navy Oct. 29 from a shipyard in Charleston, South Carolina.

President Chen Shui-bian is expected to travel to Suao in mid-December to officiate at a ceremony marking the commissioning of the two destroyers in his capacity as the commander-in-chief of the ROC armed forces.

Navy officers and seed instructors, as well as repair and maintenance technicians have received training in the United States to prepare for the delivery of the two de-mothballed destroyers, which have also undergone sea trials and weaponry systems tests over the past month, the navy authorities said.
The other two destroyers are expected by March 2007.
Taiwan purchased the four then-mothballed destroyers, built in the late 1970s, at a cost of NT$24 billion (US$0.73 billion) in June 2003.

The navy authorities said that after the two Kidd-class destroyers are commissioned, they will form the outer periphery of a naval defensive fleet, while the Perry-class, Knox-class and Lafayette-class frigates will play an inner circle role.
The Kidd-class destroyers will target enemy planes that have fired missiles, allowing other vessels to deal with the incoming missiles, they said.

Taiwan submitted a shopping list in 2001 that included top-of-the-line U.S. destroyers of the Arleigh Burke-class equipped with the Aegis radar system, but the Bush administration later approved the sale of only the much older Kidd-class destroyers.

The purchase was embroiled in a fierce debate. Opponents of the purchase included members of the legislature's powerful defense committee, which made several attempts to block the sale. Critics cited the age of the ships and their high cost and suggested that Taiwan should push the U.S. to release the Aegis system sooner.

DOC.HEADLINE: SELECTION OF NCC MEMBERS BEGINS

TEXT.P: The three-day selection of members of the National Communications Commission (NCC) began Friday with the reviewing process being opened to the public.

Eleven members of the NCC Member Review Committee -- named by parties across Taiwan's political spectrum -- began Friday to interview 18 candidates -- recommended by political parties and the Executive Yuan -- for future nomination to become NCC members.
The 11 interviewers are expected to vote on the last day of the review on the 18 candidates, 13 of whom will become NCC members.
The final list of successful candidates will be sent to the Executive Yuan for nomination by the premier and then to the Legislature for approval.

To be successful, nominees must win more than 60 percent of the review committee ballots. If fewer than 13 pass that threshold in the first round of balloting, a second vote will be held to choose those who get more than half of the votes.
People interested in watching the question-and-answer sessions can do so on close-circuit camera in a room adjoining the hearing room.

The legislative caucuses of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP), who sponsored the NCC organization bill, expressed the hope last month that the NCC could be inaugurated Jan. 1, 2006.

The opposition lawmakers made the call Nov. 10, one day after President Chen Shui-bian promulgated the bill into law. The KMT and PFP lawmakers have touted the enactment as a milestone in the country's history, claiming that it offers the best guarantee of freedom of the press.

Under the NCC law, 15 members will be nominated by the legislature according to the share of seats held by each political party, and the Executive Yuan will recommend three. The commission's 13 members will then be selected from among the 18 nominees by an 11-member review committee, all of them professional experts and scholars recommended by political parties based on proportional representation, through open votes.
