DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HUMAN RIGHTS SITUATION REGRESSES IN 2005: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's overall human rights situation has regressed in 2005, with the judiciary being the only area that meets the benchmark, according to the results of a survey released Friday by the Chinese Association for Human Rights (CAHR).
The survey measured the human rights situation in a total of 10 areas on a five-point scale, with a score of three points or above representing a passing grade.

The judiciary received a score of 3.12 points, the economy 2.91 points, culture and education 2.87, politics 2.81, and treatment of senior citizens 2.86 points, of women 2.78, of children 2.66, of the physically and mentally challenged 2.62, the environment 2.51 and workers 2.41, according to the survey.
CAHR President Lee Yung-jang said the judiciary got the top score because the judicial reforms carried out by the government have won widespread public approval.

On the other hand, the score for treatment of workers was so low because the government has failed to strictly enforce labor protection regulations and because local employers tend to dismiss workers arbitrarily without offering them reasonable compensation, Lee said.

He said the unstable economy in Taiwan and the government's failure to handle the human rights issue positively have caused the country's overall human rights situation to regress compared with that of last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 15.17 points to close at 6,264.36.
The bourse opened at 6,269.94 and fluctuated between 6,233.23 and 6,274.04 during trading. A total of 3.25 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$83.73 billion (US$2.5 billion).

Three of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with banking and financial shares moving up the most at 0.5 percent, followed by machinery and electronics shares at 0.4 percent, and cement stocks at 0.3 percent.

The five other major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff issues moving down the most at 0.8 percent, followed by construction issues at 0.5 percent, textile stocks at 0.4 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.3 percent, and paper and pulp issues at 0.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 561 to 429, with 214 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Metro Board Discussing Ouster of Top Official; Majority Agrees White Should Go, Sources Say.
A majority of Metro board members have become disillusioned with the performance of the agency's top executive, Richard A. White, and have begun closed-door discussions about how to remove him from the job, according to several sources familiar with the talks.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: 31 National Bolsheviks Freed, 8 Jailed
The roars of elated friends, sprays of icy champagne and kisses from young women greeted 31 National Bolshevik activists Thursday afternoon as they emerged from the Nikulinsky District Court. Damp and overcrowded prison cells awaited eight of their less-fortunate co-defendants.

DOC.HEADLINE: KEEP ELECTROMAGNETIC WAVES AWAY FROM SCHOOLS, RESIDENCES: TEPU

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Environmental Protection Union (TEPU) urged the government Friday to enact a law forbidding the installation of electromagnetic-radioactive facilities near schools and residences.
According to TEPU Chairwoman Chen Shu-hua, long-time exposure to electromagnetic radiation can reduce human immunity and lead to cancer.

Inspections conducted by the TEPU recently in more than 10 local schools show that electromagnetic radiation is excessively high in many of these schools because they are located near high-voltage electrical transmission towers, Chen pointed out.

In addition to keeping electromagnetic radiation away from schools and residences, the government should also require electrical appliance manufacturers to label the electromagnetic radiation emission levels of their products, Chen said.

Chao Li-chu, a leading member of a group opposing the installation of underground cables by the Taiwan Power Company in Taoyuan County's Yangmei township, said the company has set up a gigantic high-voltage electrical transmission tower and installed 12 high-voltage underground cables there, which she claimed pose a serious threat to the health of local residents.

Opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union Legislator Lai Hsin-yuan and ruling Democratic Progressive Party legislators Wang Tu-fa and Chuang Shuo-han promised to continue to pay attention to the issue and will help promote a law to regulate electromagnetic emissions.

DOC.HEADLINE: JUSTICE MINISTRY TO REVIEW NT$30 GIFTS AS VOTE-BUYING REGULATION

TEXT.P: The ministry of Justice (MOJ) will review the regulation which stipulates that the distribution of gifts worth more than NT$30 (US$0.89) during election campaign constitutes vote-buying, Justice Minister Shih Mao-lin said Friday.

Shih made the remarks when he and Wu Ying-chao, state public prosecutor-general, were invited by the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union's legislative caucus to report on the crackdown on vote-buying in last Saturday's "three-in-one" elections.
Shih said that whether the feting of campaign staff, as well as the caps or other souvenirs distributed by candidates, constitute vote-buying should be reviewed.
The ministry will take stock of the approach of Japan in reviewing the regulation and add it to the Election and Recall Law, Shih said.

Chen Ding-nan, the vanquished candidate for Ilan county magistrate in the just concluded elections, set the strict regulation that any gifts worth more than NT$30 are regarded as vote-buying when he was justice minister in 2001.
When Chen set NT$30 as the threshold, even some with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party said the amount set would become a "joke."

But the strict regulations seemed to backfire during Chen's own campaign when he was questioned for feting voters, although throwing lavish banquets for constituents during election campaigns are seen as common practice in Taiwan elections.

Shih said that since a crackdown on vote-buying was launched in June, local district courts have handled 13,161 alleged bribery cases. Prosecutors had indicted 22 people involved in the city and county chief elections, 554 people involved in the city and county councilor elections, and 564 people involved in the village and township elections as of Thursday.
During the legislative elections at the end of last year, prosecutors indicted 835 people, and the result this year should be better than the previous year, he said.

Wu said prosecutors will make indictments as long as there is solid evidence, and that this year, they have made progress in the most thorny parts -- vote-buying with cash or candidates directly involved in bribery.
Wu noted that 43 candidates for village and townships were prosecuted, while 69 candidates for city and county councilors were also indicted.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL EVALUATIONS SHOW TAIWAN CORRUPTION WORSENING: KMT HEAD

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou cited foreign evaluation reports Friday showing that corruption in Taiwan has worsened since the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) came to power in 2000.
He said Transparency International published its first annual evaluation report when he was justice minister, ranking Taiwan 25th in terms of government integrity.

In 1996, when he quit the ministerial post, Taiwan's ranking slipped to 29th. After 2000, when the DPP came to power, Taiwan's rankings have ranged between 32nd and 35th, an indication that corruption has worsened, he said.

Ma, who is also mayor of Taipei, told a city government seminar that Hong Kong's Political and Economic Risk Consultancy has also raised Taiwan's "corruption ranking" from 9th in March to 7th in December, basing its rankings on observations by foreign business communities in 12 countries and areas in Asia.

Ma said he cited the foreign evaluations not to criticize the central government but to check the city government he leads, which is "part of the government." He also expressed hope that foreign businessmen can gain a better understanding of government transparency and the business environment in Taiwan.

He said that when he was justice minister, he set a rule banning officials from taking gifts, being treated or lobbying for special interest groups. A gift worth more than NT$3,000 must be returned, and no more than NT$5,000 in gifts can be accepted in a year.
The rule was forwarded to the Executive Yuan under the then-ruling KMT, which ignored it on the grounds that it was "impractical," he noted.
Although the central government refused to accept his recommendation, he took the rule to the Taipei city government when he took over as mayor.

He said corruption was rampant in other Chinese societies like Hong Kong and Singapore before they set up the Independent Commission Against Corruption (ICAC) and Corruption Practices Investigation Bureau (CPIB), respectively.
The situation in those two societies have "entirely changed, " because they were "dead serious about fighting corruption," Ma said.

He said that in his city government, six principles were adopted to fight corruption -- uncovering such practices, handling them decisively, cooperating with judicial authorities in investigations, making public all investigation results, not fearing opening up the cupboard, and never being lenient toward "our own guys."

All these steps, plus good pay scales and strict laws and rules, are aimed at preventing graft and other illegal profit-taking practices so that the government can keep the greatest asset it can have with the people -- trust, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Protesters clash with police again in Susa Valley.
Protesters who are seeking to stop the construction of a high-speed train railway linking Turin and the French city of Lyon in the Alpine valley of Susa lashed with police again Thursday, leaving 15 police and two demonstrators injured. The government criticized extreme antagonists and anarchists from around the nation for the violent confrontation and called an emergency meeting on the issue for Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: R&D SPENDING IN TAIWAN UP 8.3 PERCENT IN 2004

TEXT.P: Spending on research and development in Taiwan totalled NT$260.9 billion (US$7.78 billion) in 2004, an increase of 8.3 percent over the previous year, according to statistics released Friday by the National Science Council (NSC).
The NSC statistics also show that the R&D spending in 2004 accounted for 2.54 percent of the nation's gross domestic product and represented a growth of NT$20.1 billion over 2003.
The number of researchers reached 91,490 in 2004, an annual increase of 7.4 percent, according to the statistics.

Meanwhile, the U.S. government approved 5,938 patents applied for by Taiwanese inventors in 2004, ranking Taiwan fourth in the world, while a total of 12,939 scientific reports written in Taiwan were published in the world's major scientific journals in 2004, ranking Taiwan 18th in the world, according to the Science Citation Index.

DOC.HEADLINE: CERN TO HELP BUILD ASIA'S 1ST COMPUTING GRID CENTER IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Academia Sinica, Taiwan's top research institute, will cooperate with the European Organization for Nuclear Research (CERN) to build a Large Hadron Collider (LHC) computing grid maintenance center in Taiwan that will be the first of its kind in all Asia.

Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tse and CERN Deputy Director Jos Engelen jointly signed a memorandum Friday on the establishment of a Tier-1 LHC computing grid maintenance center to be located in Academia Sinica's Institute of Physics.

CERN is the world's largest particle physics laboratory and the LHC Computing Grid Project is CERN's flagship project. The LHC, currently being built at CERN near Geneva, is the largest scientific instrument on the planet. When it begins operations in 2007, it will produce roughly 15 petabytes (15 million gigabytes) of data annually, which thousands of scientists around the world will be able to access and analyse.
The mission of the LHC Computing Grid Project (LCG) is to build and maintain a data storage and analysis infrastructure for the entire high energy physics community that will use the LHC.

The LHC is a particle accelerator which will probe deeper into matter than ever before. Due to be switched on in 2007, it will ultimately collide beams of protons at an energy of 14 TeV. Beams of lead nuclei will be also accelerated, smashing together with a collision energy of 1150 TeV.

A TeV is a unit of energy used in particle physics. 1 TeV is about the energy of motion of a flying mosquito. What makes the LHC so extraordinary is that it squeezes that energy into a space about a million million times smaller than a mosquito.

Once Taiwan's Tier-1 LHC computing grid maintenance center is established, it will ally with 10 other Tier-1 centers around the world to share and integrate resources and provide services in the high energy physics field. The 10 other Tier-1 centers include Canada's TRIUMF, France's CC-IN2P3, Germany's GridKa, Italy's CNAF, the Netherland's NIKHEF/SARA, Spain's PIC, Britain's RAL, the United States' BNL and FNAL, as well as the NDGF in Scandinavia.

In addition, Academia Sinica is also joining five other centers, including CC-IN2P3, CNAF and RAL, to be jointly responsible for consultation services of the Worldwide LHC Computing Grid (WLCG) , which is a sub project under the LHC Project.

According to S.P. Li, director of the Academia Sinica Institute of Physics, CERN began in 2001 to integrate computing resources from around the world to boost the computing regime of high energy physics.

In the future, the functions of the Tier-1 LHC computing grid maintenance centers worldwide can be further strengthened under the Enabling Grid for E-science (EGEE) project so as to expand computing capabilities to other fields such as digital storage, atmospheric sciences and biological information, Li said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER URGES UNITY FOR VICTORY

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Friday that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) must address the "Ma Ying-jeou phenomenon" squarely, saying that only unity will give the party a chance of winning.

The premier was referring to main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) chairman Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who led the party to a resounding victory in the just-concluded local elections, grabbing 14 out of 23 seats up for grabs in the city and county chief elections, compared with the dismal six seats taken by the DPP.

The premier, in his first remarks about the DPP debacle, said that after Ma took the helm of the party in August, the KMT has integrated smoothly with its ally the People First Party, and that those who identity with the party have also increased in number.
This was a major reason why the KMT fared so well in the elections, Hsieh said.
He said that the leadership of the DPP should realize the "Ma Ying-jeou phenomenon."
He said there should not be too much strife within the party, adding that "one does not necessarily win if there is unity, but one will definitely lose if there is no unity."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SEMICONDUCTOR SECTOR TO GROW 10% IN 2006: ITRI

TEXT.P: Taiwan's semiconductor sector is expected to post a growth rate of 10.1 percent in 2006 compared with the 1.5 percent in 2005, thanks to increased demand, the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) forecast Friday.

Tan Yu-hua, an analyst at the ITRI's Industrial Economics and Knowledge Center (IEK) , pointed out that sales in Asia's semiconductor sector amounted to US$27.3 billion in the third quarter of this year, up 12.1 percent from the previous quarter and up 16.9 percent from the same period of last year.

In Taiwan, the production value of the semiconductor sector rose 18.3 percent from the second quarter to NT$292.5 billion in the third quarter, while the output is expected to further increase 15.4 percent to NT$337.6 billion in the fourth quarter owing to robust seasonal demand, Tan said.

On the packaging and testing industry, Tan said the climate of the industry is improving, with major packaging and testing companies posting significantly better sales in the third quarter compared with the previous quarter.
Meanwhile, the IC design industry is likely to register a growth rate of 19.5 percent in the fourth quarter, Tan said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MIXED ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mixed Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for December remained unchanged at 6,240, with 27,932 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for January moved up 14 points to end at 6,251, with 822 contracts traded, while March futures lost three points to finish at 6,245, with 51 contracts traded. June futures moved up 39 points to close at 6,245, with four contracts traded, while September futures moved down four points to close at 6,102, with 58 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 6,240 for December, 6,237 for January, 6,248 for March, 6,206 for June and 6,106 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly higher.

December TE futures moved up 1.25 points to close at 273.25, with 5,243 contracts traded, while January TE futures gained 0.55 points to finish at 273, with 138 contract transactions. March TE futures moved down 1.7 points to end at 270.3, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for June and September.

December TF futures gained 9.6 points to finish at 880.8, with 4,235 contracts changing hands, while January TF futures moved up 8.8 points to end at 881, with 248 contracts traded. March TF futures moved up 15.8 points to close at 888, with two contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for June and September.

DOC.HEADLINE: RED CROSS WORKER CITED FOR HELPING BRIDGE TAIWAN-CHINA GAP

TEXT.P: Hsu Chin-hsiang, a Kinmen Red Cross volunteer, has been elected this year's "Good Samaritan" for his long-time contributions to the needy in Kinmen, China and Taiwan and will be awarded a Pa-Teh (Eight Virtues) medal in Taipei Dec. 12.
Before his departure for Taiwan, Fujian Provincial Governor Yen Chung-cheng and Kinmen County Magistrate Lee Chu-feng received Hsu Friday and presented him with money to cover his travel expenses.
They said Hsu's humanitarian services have been a big plus in promoting cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges.
Hsu is a founding member of the Kinmen Red Cross Society, which was established in 1990. He has been hired as its secretary general while retaining the title of volunteer.
Over the years, he has helped 579 Chinese in 48 groups return safely to China after they had been caught smuggling, poaching fish, or engaging in other illegal activities by the Taiwan authorities.

He has also helped form emergency medical teams in China, Kinmen and Taiwan so that Taiwan businessmen or travelers with urgent medical needs could receive proper medical attention or return to Taiwan to be hospitalized.
For that work, Hsu often has to visit Xiamen, just across the Taiwan Strait from Kinmen. Many family members and relatives of Taiwan businessmen and visitors are grateful for his assistance.
In Kinmen, he has organized volunteer groups trained to give home care to lonely seniors or disabled people. Other groups are dedicated to comforting and encouraging prisoners.

When the Kinmen Blood Donation Center was established in 1994, Hsu drafted a project to gather donated blood every three months and he has since been the first to donate blood whenever such activities have been staged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRO-INDEPENDENCE DPP STALWART TO RUN FOR PARTY CHAIRMANSHIP

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Trong Chai announced Friday his intention to enter the race for the DPP chairman position.

In a written statement, Chai, a pro-independence DPP stalwart, said that it is his mission to enter the chairmanship race to "safeguard the DPP's founding causes and ensure that the DPP will continue to be in power after 2008."

Noting that he will enter the chairmanship race to "call the people back and let Taiwan's identity stand tall, " Chai attributed the DPP's debacle in the "three-in-one" elections last week to political fallout from a series corruption scandals and the DPP's failure to champion Taiwan's identity.

Chai touted his superb "organizational ability," claiming that if he is elected DPP chairman, he will be able to win back some 600,000 former DPP supporters who turned from the party in the just-concluded elections.

DPP sources said recently that the party will elect a new chairman in January at the earliest, as Chairman Su Tseng-chang, who assumed the post in February this year, stepped down after the party's crushing defeat in the Dec. 3 city and county elections. The DPP managed to take only six seats out of 23 up for grabs, compared with 14 seats taken by the main opposition Kuomintang.

According to the DPP charter, if the incumbent president is a DPP member, he should concurrently serve as party chairman, but President Chen Shui-bian resigned from his post as party head in the wake of the party's lackluster performance in the legislative elections of late 2004.

There have also been rumors that Vice President Annette Lu, Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun and former DPP Legislator Luo Wen-jia, who lost the Taipei county chief election, are also interested in entering the DPP chairmanship race.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, gaining NT$0.016 to close at NT$33.517.
A total of US$613 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.501 and fluctuated between NT$33.400 and NT$33.527.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO DEFEND ITS INTERESTS IN WTO MINISTERIAL MEETING: MINISTER

TEXT.P: Taiwan will defend its interests by asking for more flexibility in lowering its tariffs for various products in the forthcoming World Trade Organization ministerial meeting in Hong Kong, Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh said Friday.

In a news conference called to unveil the government's position on the meeting which is slated to open in Hong Kong Dec. 13, Ho said Taiwan adopts an aggressive opening strategy in the field of non-agricultural products and will call for the adoption by the WTO of a formula under which the higher tariffs a member state employs, the deeper cut in tariffs they should take.
Ho said Taiwan will lower its tariffs in return for easier access to the markets of the United States, Europe, China, Southeast Asia, India and Brazil.
As a result, Ho said, tariffs on products the country can produce at competitive cost, such as musical instruments, dyes, hand tools, sportsware, watches and jewelry will be lowered to zero.

As to the agricultural and fishery products in which Taiwan has difficulty competing with foreign imports, the minister said Taiwan will use its bargaining power to apply for longer periods for lowering tariffs on them.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPECIAL FACILITY SET UP FOR SUICIDE PREVENTION

TEXT.P: A national center for suicide prevention was inaugurated Friday as part of the government's efforts to curb the increasing suicide rate in Taiwan.

According to a survey conducted by the Rheumatology Association (RA) under the commission of the Department of Health (DOH), around 7 percent of Taiwan residents aged above 17 who responded to the poll said they had considered suicide.

A total of 8,835 households around the country apart from the outlying islands were interviewed for the survey over the course of the past year. The results show that around 1.7 percent of the respondents had thought of committing suicide in the past year, some 0.3 percent had planned to take their own lives, and about 0.2 percent had attempted to kill or injure themselves.
The ongoing survey will be completed by next spring.

Lee Ming-pin, the RA chairman who doubles as director of the new facility, said the survey shows there are more female respondents than male who had thought, planned, or attempted to commit suicide, and that there's a trend of decline in the age of the people who have thought about or tried to end their own lives.
Lee suggested humanitarian efforts be made to find out the reasons for the findings.

He announced the opening of the new center for suicide prevention with DOH Minister Hou Sheng-mao, National Taiwan University Hospital President Lin Fang-yu, United Microelectronics Corp. Chairman Robert Tsao, and Taiwan Joint Commission on Hospital Accreditation Chairman Hsieh Po-sheng. The inauguration ceremony was also attended by many representatives of the political, medical and entertainment sectors.

Suicide ranked ninth in Taiwan's top 10 causes of death last year, with over 3,000 people taking their own lives. This year, the suicides of comedian Ni Min-jan and noted psychiatrist Chen Kuo-hua shook society, prompting the DOH to take more action to control suicide.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT-PFP MERGER NOT LINKED TO TAIPEI MAYORAL RACE: PFP LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: A planned merger between the opposition People First Party (PFP) and the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) will not be linked to the Taipei mayoral election slated for next year, PFP lawmaker Sun Ta-chien said Friday.

Sun, one of a five-member task force of PFP lawmakers in charge of holding merger talks with the KMT, said that they made it clear during a meeting with KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou a day earlier that the merger issue should not be linked to the election.

PFP Chairman James Soong has never revealed his intention that he might run for Taipei mayor in 2006 and there should not be speculation over the issue, Sun said. Some newspapers have reported that the PFP lawmakers told Ma in the meeting that Soong would like to take part in the 2006 Taipei mayoral election in accordance with the model on which Ma participated in the race in 1998, he explained.
But Ma was reported as replying that the so-called "Ma model" refers to a negotiation mechanism within the party prior to resorting to party primaries, rather than croynism.
According to Sun, they made the PFP stance clear to Ma that the two issues should be dealt with separately, and that no one mentioned job exchanges during the meeting.

Calls from opposition "pan blue alliance" supporters have been mounting for the two parties to merge after the Dec. 3 local government elections, in which the KMT overwhelmed the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) . The PFP gained only 1.1 percent of the popular vote, prompting deep concern over its possible disappearance from Taiwan's political map.

In response to high public expectations, the five-member PFP task force visited Ma for merger talks Thursday -- a sign that the two parties in the "pan blue alliance" have accelerated their pace of moving toward a merger.

The two parties have initially come to an agreement that they will jointly iron out a negotiation mechanism for nominating candidates to run for all levels of public office by the end of January next year, including the Taipei and Kaohsiung mayor positions, before achieving a full merger by 2007.

Meanwhile, PFP spokesman Hsieh Kung-ping thanked Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng for his concern about the rights and interests of PFP members in the KMT after the two parties have fully merged.

During a meeting Friday, Wang told Ma that the KMT-PFP merger must be carried out with mutual respect and on an equal footing, and he reminded Ma that the newly merged party may have to elect a new leader in the future.
While some PFP lawmakers contended that a new KMT leader should be produced in line with the party's platform, others were reluctant to comment.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING SHOULD ENACT SPECIAL LAW FOR DEALING WITH TAIWAN: KMT HEAD
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Dec. 8 (CNA) (By M.N. Wang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou urged Beijing during a recent interview with Yazhou Zhoukan to enact a special law to deal with the delicate cross-Taiwan Strait ties.

In the weekly's latest edition to be issued this weekend, Ma said that Beijing should draw up a law similar to Taiwan's Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area to handle cross-strait affairs in view of the lack of government-to-government contacts between the two sides.

Saying that he favors the "1992 consensus that allows respective interpretations of the one China" model -- a tacit agreement vaguely reached by officials from the two sides in 1992 in Hong Kong -- to explain Taiwan's sovereignty in its relations with China, Ma pointed out, however, that Taiwan and Beijing differ a lot in their interpretations of the meaning of the so-called "one China."
In line with the Republic of China Constitution, "one China" refers to the ROC, he said, noting that Taiwan cannot accept Beijing's insistence that "one China" means the People's Republic of China.

Now that there is no way to resolve the dispute at present, Taiwan and China should put aside the "one China" controversy, and what counts now is that the two sides should further bolster bilateral cultural and economic exchanges, he said.
The KMT does not favor a permanent split between the two sides of the strait, neither it is the time for discussions on unification, he said.

Ma hailed former KMT Chairman Lien Chan's efforts in advocating a "cross-strait common market" proposal during a landmark visit to mainland China in spring this year, and he claimed that he was surprised that Lien and Communist Party of China General Secretary Hu Jintao were able to forge a common perspective in this regard.

The "cross-strait common market" goal should be well underpinned by a solid base, such as a closer economic partnership arrangement (CEPA) or a free trade agreement (FTA), upon which to build, he said.

Claiming that Lien brought back a lot of assets to Taiwan from mainland China, the KMT incumbent chairman said he is in no rush to visit the Chinese mainland for the time being. Instead, he called for creating positive conditions by both sides to expand two-way exchanges, which he said is the top priority at the present stage.
Although Beijing does not recognize Taiwan as an independent country, he pointed out, it is an undeniable fact that there is an independent government in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAD TO MEET PFP CHIEF DEC. 12

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong are scheduled to meet Dec. 12 in Taipei to discuss ways to promote a merger between the two parties.
Ma and Soong will meet at the Taipei Hero House Friends of Armed Forces Association for three hours of talks, witnessed by the secretaries-general of both parties.
A five-member delegation from the PFP, including PFP legislative caucus convener Huang Yi-chiao and PFP legislators Sun Ta-chien and Chang Hsien-yao, met Ma Thursday to prepare for the meeting.

At the meeting, both sides agreed to first promote cooperation between the two parties prior to the merger, based on the spirit of mutual trust, the establishment of systems and respect for public opinion.
The KMT and the PFP said they are merging in response to strong calls from the public after the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) setback in last Saturday's city and county chief elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIN APOLOGIZES TO TAICHUNG MAYOR FOR DISCLOSING HIS MEDICAL RECORDS

TEXT.P: The doctor who played a leading role in disclosing Taichung Mayor Jason Hu's medical records in an attempt to diminish his chances of re-election in the Dec. 3 local elections formally apologized to Hu at a news conference Friday and wished him "increasingly good health."

Bowing apparently to mounting pressure and condemnation from all sectors for his lack of ethics, Peter Lin, a legislator of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), drove from Taipei to the central Taiwan city of Taichung after failing to reach Hu on the phone.
At the news conference, Hu shook Lin's hand warmly and accepted his apology in a congenial mood.

However, Lin continued to dodge media queries on who provided him with Hu's medical records. Pressed again by reporters after the news conference, he said the records were mailed to his office by an undisclosed source, and that disclosing the information was purely his personal behavior.

Some participants in Thursday's TV call-in programs urged the Cabinet's Taichung office and the National Security Council to clarify whether they played a part in obtaining Hu's medical records from the Taichung Veterans General Hospital.

The dispute arose after the DPP legislator and 11 other doctors appeared at a news conference in Taichung prior to the Dec. 3 elections and released what they claimed was Hu's medical history, insisting that he could be paralyzed by a stroke in the next two years and therefore was unfit to serve a second term.

In a Dec. 7 ruling, the Medical Disciplinary Committee under the Taichung city government's health authority meted out varying penalties to the 12 doctors, with Lin receiving the harshest punishment of revocation for one year of his license to practice. He can appeal his case within 20 days to the Department of Health under the Cabinet.
In their initial reactions to the ruling, all but one of the 12 doctors remained defiant. Their attitudes again met strong criticism from medical circles, the DPP and the opposition parties.

Breaking his silence on the issue, Chen Ding-shinn, dean of the National Taiwan University College of Medicine, said categorically Friday that doctors should not disclose the medical records of any patient under any circumstances, and that the incident shows that education on medical ethics in Taiwan needs to be strengthened.
DPP Legislator Wang Shih-chien was more blunt and said he wanted the 11 unrepentant doctors to stop talking nonsense and accept the ruling if they had any conscience left.

Vice President Annette Lu, who had just taken over as DPP party chairwoman, also said it was extremely inappropriate to disclose someone's medical records, and that she deeply regretted the conduct of the doctors.
Lu said the DPP Central Standing Committee will discuss the issue in its Dec. 14 meeting and decide whether Lin should be referred to the party's Central Advisory Committee for disciplinary measures.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE TO LOSE CITIZENSHIP IF REGISTERING RESIDENCE IN CHINA: MAC

TEXT.P: Any Taiwan citizens who register residence in China or who hold a People's Republic of China passport will lose their Republic of China citizenship, Mainland Affairs Council official (MAC) Vice Chairman Huang Wei-feng said Friday.

Huang was responding to a report published by a Hong Kong daily that Beijing might issue identity cards to Taiwan citizens to replace the travel permits that are presently issued to Taiwanese people traveling to China.

Huang pointed out that the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area forbids Taiwan citizens from registering residence in China or holding a PRC passport.

Anyone who breaks the law will lose their status as a Taiwan citizens and the rights to which Taiwan citizens are entitled, such as taking part in elections, assuming a military position and joining the civil service, Huang noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: 141 IMPORTED PRODUCTS FROM 50 LESS-DEVELOPED NATIONS NOW TARIFF-FREE

TEXT.P: The legislature approved a government proposal Friday to remove tariffs on 141 products imported from Afghanistan and 49 other less-developed countries.
The move responds to a World Trade Organization resolution adopted at the Doha Round of ministerial talks calling for duty free treatment for products exported by less-developed countries.

The Executive Yuan said the WTO follows the definition of the United Nations of less-developed countries -- those whose per capital GDP over the past three years averaged less than US$750, that are short of human resources, or have a fragile economy.

Under the new rule, which passed the Legislative Yuan in a second reading, imports from Angola, Bangladesh, the Republic of Benin, Bhutan, Burkina Faso, the Republic of Burundi, Cambodia, the Republic of Cape Verde, Central Africa, Chad, the Union of the Camoros, Congo, the Republic of Djiboudi, the Republic of Equatorial Guinea and others will enjoy import duty free treatment.

These others are Eritrea, Ethiopia, Gambia, the Republic of Guinea, the Republic of Guinea-Bissau, Haiti, the Republic of Kiribati, Laos, Lesotho, Liberia, Madagascar, Malawi, the Maldives, Mali, Mauritania, Mozambique, Myanmar, Nepal, Niger, Rwanda, the Samoa Islands, Sao Tome and Principe, Senegal, Sierra Leone, the Solomon Islands, Somalia, Sudan, Timur-Leste, Togo, Tuvalu, Tanzania, Uganda, Vanuatu, Yemen and Zambia.
A government proposal that does not concern a budget or amendments to or enactment of a law needs not go through a third reading.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIR LINKS IMPORTANT TO TOURISM BOOM: CEPD CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Convenient air links are vital to the government's bid to boost Taiwan tourism if the country wants to sell its tourist spots to the world, Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Chairman Hu Sheng-cheng said Friday.
Pointing to South Korea as an example, Hu said that Seoul has direct flights to more than 100 cities around the world and that this is the major reason behind South Korea's booming tourism.

Taiwan needs to build a more convenient air transport network to bring in more foreign visitors, Hu stressed, noting that the number of Austrian tourists to Taiwan has more than doubled after direct flights were opened between Taipei and Vienna.
In addition, Hu pointed out that South Korea's popular TV soap operas in the international market also help in its tourism boom.

Last year, over 710,000 local and foreign tourists visited sites in South Korea where various popular TV series were filmed, and the neighboring country provides a good example of how a country's creative industry can benefit its tourism, the CEPA chairman said.
More than 2.46 million foreign visitors traveled to Taiwan for the first three quarters of this year, according to government statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HAS NOT RENEWED APPLICATION FOR CHINESE OFFICIAL'S VISIT: MAC

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) has not seen any new application from the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) on the planned Taiwan visit by a high-ranking Chinese official, MAC vice Chairman Huang Wei-feng said Friday.

Huang was responding to a media report that the KMT has decided to renew its application with the government for the visit by Chen Yunlin, director of China's Taiwan Affairs Office, after the party's overwhelming victory in the Dec. 3 "three-in-one" elections.

The KMT has invited Chen to visit Taiwan to attend an economic and trade forum between the KMT and the Communist Party of China. The KMT had previously filed an application with the Bureau of Immigration for Chen's visit but it was rejected.
Huang said there is no way for him to predict how the government will handle the case since the KMT has not submitted a second application.
However, Huang said, the outcome of the elections will not change the government's policy towards China.
He pointed out that the government has always insisted that cross-strait exchanges be conducted based on the principles of parity, dignity and reciprocity.
The MAC had previously requested consultations with Beijing over Chen's trip, but the request was ignored by Beijing.
Ruling Democratic Progressive Party legislators have said that they would oppose Chen's Taiwan visit unless Beijing invites MAC Chairman Joseph Wu to visit China.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDUSTRIAL GROUPS AGREE TO SAVE ENERGY AND CUT GREENHOUSE GASES

TEXT.P: Seven major industrial associations and the Chinese National Federation of Industries are scheduled to sign an agreement Dec. 26 with the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) to help the nation's efforts to save energy and reduce emissions of carbon dioxide (CO2), MOEA officials said Friday.

The agreement is the implementation of a resolution reached in a national energy conference, which was held by the government in June to concert with the world's efforts to decrease the emissions of greenhouse gases after the international Kyoto Protocol concerning the control of the emissions entered into force in February.

The manufacturers associations in the fields of steel, petroleum, cement, artificial textiles, paper-making, cotton fabrics printing, as well as electrical and electronics production, will sign the agreement, with most of the top 200 industrial leaders in the consumption of energy also to sign.

According to the agreement, members of the associations will begin in 2006 to carry out programs in energy savings and reduction of CO2 emissions and will review the results in 2008. The national federation of industries will assist factories in implementing the agreement, the MOEA officials said.

All relevant authorities including the Industrial Development Bureau and the Bureau of Energy will also provide information, techniques and relevant services to help the sectors improve energy efficiency and begin using environmentally friendly fuels, the MOEA said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2007 LEGISLATIVE ELECTIONS FULCRUM FOR KMT-PFP MERGER: KMT SPOKESWOMAN

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) will fully merge with the People First Party (PFP) after the current legislative term expires in 2007, and it is "too early to talk about a new party chairman now," a KMT spokeswoman said Friday.
Cheng Li-wen made the remarks after KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou called on Legislative Yuan speaker Wang Jin-pyng earlier in the day.
Wang mentioned to Ma during the meeting about the possible re-election of the party's new chairman after a merger, according to Cheng.

In theory, Cheng said, the merger between the two parties will be completed in 2007 due to the consideration of the seats of the PFP legislators-at-large, which are allotted according to the seats a party garners in elections.

To avoid the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the PFP from losing its majority in the legislature, the PFP legislators-at-large will continue to cling to the party until the 2007 legislative elections.

Cheng reaffirmed that after Ma and PFP Chairman James Soong hold a scheduled meeting next Monday to establish a communication mechanism between the two parties, the process of a merger between the two parties can begin.
On reports that President Chen Shui-bian is keen on inviting Wang to serve as premier, Ma and Wang also exchanged views on this matter, Cheng said.
Both agreed that if the president wants to invite someone from the opposition to serve as premier, he should do so through party-to-party consultations.

The president should also turn over the right to name a premier to conform to the dual leadership system of the ROC Constitution. The right to form a Cabinet should also be given to the "pan-blue alliance," which enjoys a slim majority in the legislature.
Ma again invited Wang to serve as the first vice chairman of the KMT, stressing that "Wang is welcome to have the post any time he wishes," according to Cheng.

Wang quit as a KMT vice chairman after he lost to Ma in the KMT chairmanship election in late July, saying that although he had left the post, he will continue to serve the party as a life-long volunteer.

The PFP is a KMT splinter party founded in 2000 after Soong lost his presidential bid by a slim margin. Soong, who used to be the KMT's all-powerful secretary-general, ran as an independent in the 2000 presidential race.
The PFP saw its strength decline after the 2004 presidential elections in which Soong teamed up with then-KMT Chairman Lien Chan, only to be defeated a second time by President Chen Shui-bian.

The party is now facing the risk of being sidelined after the Dec. 3 local elections in which it won only one magistrate seat -- in Kinmen -- out of 23 openings up for grabs, and that only thanks to the courtesy of the KMT, which refrained from naming its own candidate in that county.
Many PFP lawmakers have called for a merger with the KMT, which won 14 seats in the Dec. 3 race and is on its way to a showdown with the DPP in the 2008 presidential race.

DOC.HEADLINE: DRIVERS FAILING TO STOP FOR PEOPLE IN CROSSWALKS FACE FINES

TEXT.P: Drivers failing to stop for pedestrians in crosswalks will now face fines of between NT$1,200 and NT$3,600 (US$108) after the Legislative Yuan passed the third reading of the amended Road Traffic Regulations and Penalties Ordinance Friday.

Also, making a right turn on a red light could cost drivers between NT$600 and NT$1,800, which was lowered from the previous fine of NT$1,800 to NT$5,400 when the infraction was considered equivalent to running a red light.

However, speeders who hope to beat fines by using radar detectors have a new lease on life. Under the old ordinance, drivers found using radar detectors were subject to fines between NT$1,200 and NT$2,400 and had their units confiscated.
The new revisions make using a radar detector legal.

Ironically, another addition to the ordinance provides for a fine of NT$6,000 to NT$20,000 for any motorist who exceeds the maximum speed limit by 60 kph or more. The offender's licence will be revoked on the spot.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW MINIMUM TAX CODE WILL TAX OVERSEAS INCOME IN FUTURE

TEXT.P: The reach of the taxman just got longer as the legislature passed the Basic Income Tax Code Friday that stipulates that overseas income will be subject to taxation in several years.
Commonly known as the "minimum tax code, " the new law requires that a company that earns more than NT$2 million a year will have to pay between 10 percent and 20 percent in corporate income tax.

High-income individuals, meanwhile, are obligated to pay at least 20 percent of their income that exceeds NT$6 million per year. Minister of Finance Lin Chuan said this new provision will affect between 15,000 and 16,000 ROC citizens.
He estimated that the new law, which will go into effect next year, will bring in some NT$11 billion in increased government revenues in the first year.
Another key provision in the new minimum tax code is that non-ROC sourced income, which currently is not taxed, will be counted as taxable income.
This includes income from Hong Kong, Macau and China; this income enjoys an exemption threshold of NT$1 million.

Taxpayers must declare their overseas income, but the "overseas income" clause will not take effect until 2009 or even 2010, as the Executive Yuan has been authorized to decide when to begin taxing overseas income, depending on the nation's economic health.
In order to avoid double taxation, individuals can get exemptions for their income that has been taxed by foreign governments if they produce proof that is certified by Taiwan officials based abroad.

Regarding the so-called "trust and protection" principle that affects tax privileges for high-tech investors, a principle that the Ministry of Economic Affairs has fought hard to retain, the Legislative Yuan consented to the ministry's request.

That means some investors will have 12 more years for which they don't have to be bound by the new tax code if they have already signed an investment contract eligible for tax holidays or other privileges.
The preferential tax treatments are accorded under a government regulation as incentives to investors who put money into some "strategic industries."

The new code stipulates that the economics ministry should review the regulation within one year and seek to stop investors from enjoying both "five-year tax exemptions" and "tax exemptible investments."

DOC.HEADLINE: KEELUNG MAYOR HEEDS MA'S ADVICE AND AGREES NOT TO SETTLE OLD SCORES

TEXT.P: Re-elected Keelung Mayor Hsu Tsai-li of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Friday that he will follow the advice of KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and refrain from punishing those city government officials who had sided with his opponents from other political parties in the election campaign.
News reports in the past few days said Hsu was launching a drive to settle scores with officials who did not maintain a neutral stand in the period leading up to the Dec. 3 election.

Meanwhile, legislators of the opposition People First Party (PFP) -- the KMT's partner in the "pan-blue alliance" -- also complained that at least four department heads of the Keelung City Government were facing possible demotion because they had supported a PFP candidate during the election campaign.
These PFP lawmakers warned that the Keelung mayor's behavior may become an obstacle to the effort between the KMT and the PFP for a merger of the two parties.
Concerned about the post-election developments in Keelung, the KMT chairman, who is also Taipei mayor, spoke to Hsu on the phone and asked him to be "as great as he is tolerant."
Hsu disclosed Friday that he will act according to the KMT chairman's advice and assured Ma that he has no intention of settling old scores after the election.

DOC.HEADLINE: YU SHYI-KUN HAS BACKING OF SOME DPP FACTIONS TO BE NEXT CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Several factions within the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) are backing Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun to be the party's next chairman.

Su Tseng-chang stepped down to take political responsibility for the poor showing of the DPP in the recent elections for local government chiefs. Vice President Annette Lu is currently acting chair of the party.

Among the factions of the DPP, Gao Jyh-peng, the Justice Alliance's secretary-general, and Lee Chun-yee, secretary-general of the Welfare State Alliance, both said Friday that Yu would be a reasonable choice since he is qualified for the post.
According to one of Yu's staff members, Yu will talk to President Chen Shui-bian about the matter.
The DPP's New Tide faction member Lee Wen-chung said that the post of chairman should be open to new blood as well.

"After the defeat in the recent 'three-in-one' elections, the party should give this opportunity to other leaders within the party, or even let the new generation of politicians have a chance. Each candidate should have open debates on their ideas for the party and how to restore its image of integrity and reform," Lee said.
DPP heavyweight lawmaker Trong Chai announced his intention to run for the chairmanship Friday.

Chai pointed out that the DPP lost more than 600,000 supporters compared to the last mayoral and county magistrate elections, which he said was due to the party dropping its previous stance of promoting localization.
"I am good at organization and I am confident I can win back the people's support," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: COSTA RICA INVESTMENT INCENTIVE SIX YEARS, NOT 60: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The Costa Rican Embassy in Taipei Friday corrected a slip of the tongue made by a Costa Rican official last month who erroneously said that Taiwan investors in tourism and hotels could enjoy a "60-year tax-free privilege." The official meant to say a "six-year tax-free privilege."
The official simply misspoke, an embassy official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LEGISLATIVE CAUCUS URGES MORE HOPEFULS TO RUN FOR PARTY CHAIR

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislative caucus said Friday it welcomes more reform-minded party members to run for party chairman.
William Lai, a DPP caucus whip, made the remarks after Trong Chai, a veteran DPP legislator, announced earlier in the day that he is entering the race for the top DPP post.

The DPP is scheduled to hold a chairmanship by-election early next year after Su Tseng-chang stepped down from the post last weekend to shoulder the responsibility for the party's rout in the just-concluded local government chief elections.
Following the electoral debacle, Lai said, the DPP must reform and regroup in order to regain the public's trust. "We must turn challenges into opportunities," he added.
At this critical juncture, Lai said, the party needs a capable leader who can help the DPP get back on its feet.

Stressing that the party has a deep talent pool, Lai said the DPP legislative caucus hopes to see a diverse array of aspirants join the chairmanship race to reflect the party's diversity and vitality.

"Only through a truly competitive democratic election can we choose a new party leader who can win the support and trust of the majority of the public, " Lai said, adding he believes that having hopefuls from various intraparty factions or subgroups enter the race would contribute to the party's future development.

In addition to Chai, several other DPP politicians, including Yu Shyi-kun, President Chen Shui-bian's chief of staff, and Luo Wen-jia, a former legislator who just lost his bid for Taipei County magistrate, are reportedly mulling the possibility of joining the chairmanship race.

Media reports said Vice President Annette Lu, who has been named to serve as the party's interim chairwoman until a new chairman is elected by all party member, is likely to run as well. But Lu categorically ruled out the possibility during an informal meeting with division chiefs at the DPP headquarters. Stressing that she is just a caretaker, Lu said she has no wish to run for the top party post.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE CONSTITUENCIES WORK JOINTLY TO ATTRACT INVESTMENT

TEXT.P: Senior officials of three local governments in southern Taiwan -- Kaohsiung County, Kaohsiung City and Pingtung County -- on Friday held an activity aimed at soliciting investments.

The activity was held at Neimen Junior High School in Kaohsiung County, with the participation of Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) Chairman Hsu Chih-jen, Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing, Kaohsiung City Deputy Mayor Tan Chin-chuan, and Jen Wen-hua, director of Pingtung County's Research, Development and Evaluation Office.

Hsu noted that this was the second time that TAITRA has been commissioned to be responsible for soliciting investments for the three local governments. The first time was three years ago, and the project successfully attracted investments worth NT$120 billion (US$3.58 billion).

Noting that southern Taiwan has a solid industrial base, with plentiful supplies of water and electricity, in addition to its abundant tourist resources, Hsu said the people in southern Taiwan are very friendly and the three local governments boast of very diligent chiefs.
"Kaohsiung County, Kaohsiung City and Pingtung County are hi-tech and have lots of tourist attractions, " Hsu stressed.

According to Yang, the three counties and cities can complement each other economically, as Taiwan's first environmental protection park, a multi-functional economic and trade park, and an agricultural biotech park are all located in southern Taiwan.
Stressing that southern Taiwan has plentiful supplies of water and electricity, Yang said several hot springs hotel construction projects will probably begin next year.

In addition to the Kaohsiung Science Park, Kaohsiung has a solid base in the metal industry, Yang said, adding that once the Taiwan High-speed Railway is completed, northern and southern Taiwan will be better linked.
By that time, travel from the north to the south will be extremely quick, Yang said. He welcomed investments from enterprises in northern Taiwan.
At the event, Jen strongly recommended the fruits from Pingtung County, a traditional agricultural area.
Noting that agriculture and livestock sectors are the two major lucrative industries in Pingtung County, Jen said that the country's first agricultural biotechnology park is located in the county.
Jen stressed that Pingtung County is set to develop itself as a county dedicated to environmental protection, high technology and tourism.

Excited by the large amount of investments they lured from the previous project, TAITRA officials expressed confidence that this project will give a boost to southern Taiwan's economy by offering numerous job opportunities.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT CHARTER FLIGHTS SCHEDULE FOR LUNAR NEW YEAR UNVEILED

TEXT.P: Six Taiwan airlines on Friday announced their schedules for cross-Taiwan Strait charter flights for the 2006 Chinese Lunar New Year holiday, with China Airlines taking the lead by flying the first flight at 7: 45 a.m. Jan. 20 from Taipei to Shanghai.

Unlike the 2005 Chinese New Year holiday, in which six carriers from each side of the Taiwan Strait operated a total of 48 non-stop charter flights between Taipei/Kaohsiung in Taiwan and Shanghai/Beijing/Guangzhou in China for Taiwan businessmen with operations in China, the 2006 Chinese New Year holiday will see the number of flights increase to 72, with each side operating 36 flights.
In addition, the number of destinations in China will be increased to four, with Xiamen in Fujian province being added to the list, while the Taiwan destinations will remain unchanged.

The charter flights for the upcoming Chinese Lunar New Year holiday will operate between Jan. 20 and Feb. 13, with the service extending to all Taiwan residents. The 2006 Chinese New Year's Day falls on Jan. 29.

With domestic airlines attaching much importance to the cross-strait charter flights during the Chinese Lunar New Year holiday, EVA Airways will sent its most popular airplane painted in a Hello Kitty motif to operate the Taipei-Beijing flight Jan. 27.
The flight schedule is pending the final approval of civil aviation authorities from both sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HELPS PANAMA UPGRADE MEDICAL FACILITY WITH ARTICLES FOR KIDS
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Dec. 9 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has been helping Panama, one of its diplomatic allies, upgrade the level of medical treatment and improve people's lives as part of its efforts to reinforce the friendly relationship between the two countries.

On Thursday, Mothers' Day in Panama, the obstetrics and gynecology department of Saint Thomas General Hospital in the capital city of Panama received a batch of Taiwan-donated supplements -- baby clothes and appliances.

Including toys, clothes and shoes, contained in 10 cargo containers, the shipment was donated by the Taiwan government last month. In the upcoming months, more Taiwan donations will arrive in Panama, ROC Ambassador Hou Ping-fu said Friday, noting that besides toys, clothes and shoes, Taiwan will also continue to send wheelchairs.

Saint Thomas General Hospital is Panama's largest medical facility for the poor, which provides free medical treatment for people living in poverty. Its obstetrics and gynecology department building was constructed under financial aid from Taiwan.

A department official said that over 10,000 babies are born at the hospital on average every year, and that most of the mothers come from poor families without insurance, and who were not charged for hospital services.

Hou said that Taiwan believes providing ally countries humanitarian aid helps bilateral relations, and that there are many practicing physicians in Taiwan who are willing to give free medical services to the poor in countries struggling to develop economically.

With several local government chiefs in Panama having applied for the free medical service, he is now making contact with the Taiwan doctors' association to arrange for the service in Panama some time in March and April, the ambassador said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN SAYS NOW IS THE TIME TO TURN OVER A NEW LEAF IN POLITICS

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Friday he is hopeful that Taiwan politics can enter a new phase now that the bitterly contested "three-in-one" local chief elections are over and that the ruling and opposition parties can compete in a decent manner instead of continually trading barbs.

Over the past five years, ruling and opposition camps have become embroiled in a hostile standoff. Ma said that the polarization of politics in the country can now come to an end with the resounding win by the KMT in last Saturday's local chief elections and an era of harmonious co-existence can now begin.
Ma made the remarks at the KMT's Hsinchu City chapter where he thanked party staff for their hard work in helping KMT candidates score victory in the Dec. 3 mayoral and councilor elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Qaeda -Iraq Link U.S. Cited Is Tied to Coercion Claim
The Bush administration based a crucial prewar assertion about ties between Iraq and Al Qaeda on detailed statements made by a prisoner while in Egyptian custody who later said he had fabricated them to escape harsh treatment, according to current and former government officials. The officials said the captive, Ibn a l-Shaykh al-Libi, provided his most specific and elaborate accounts about ties between Iraq and Al Qaeda only after he was secretly handed over to Egypt by the United States in January 2002, in a process known as rendition. The Bush administration used Libi' s accounts as the basis for its prewar claims that ties between Iraq and Al Qaeda included training in explosives and chemical weapons.
Wall Street Journal: Long Well-Known in Europe, Celiac Disease May Affect Up to 3 Million Americans
Only in the past few years has it become evident that celiac disease may be widespread in the United States. A report last year by experts convened by the National Institutes of Health declared that the disease affects 0.5 percent to 1 percent of the U.S. population, or roughly 1.5 million to 3 million Americans. They may have varied symptoms or none at all. The NIH estimate emerged after expatriate European and Australian researchers pushed to study the disease more aggressively in the U.S. Celiac disease, a condition in which so-called gluten proteins in grains such as wheat and barley trigger an immune-system attack on the small-intestine lining, has a clong history in Europe. Doctors there are trained to look routinely for the condition. In the U.S., by contrast, doctors have long assumed the disease was a rare childhood disorder.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Dec. 10, or the 10th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1898: Spain signs treaty with the United States, ending the Spanish-American War and ceding Cuba, Puerto Rico, Guam and the Philippines to the United States in exchange for US$20 million dollars.
1901: The first Nobel Prize presentation ceremonies are held separately in Stockholm, Sweden, and Oslo, Norway.
1902: Construction of the Aswan Dam is completed in the upper section of the Nile River in southwest Egypt.
1911: French scientist Marie Curie wins a second Nobel Prize, becoming the first person to do so.
1929: Chen Tu-siu, one of the Chinese Communist Party's co-founders, issues a statement to party comrades calling Joseph Stalin an opportunist who caused a massive split within the Communist Party.
1936: Britain's King Edward VIII abdicates, becoming the Duke of Windsor. He is succeeded by his brother, George VI.
1941: Japanese warplanes sink the British battleships "Repulse" and "Prince of Wales," killing nearly 800 in the South China Sea.
1948: The Third United Nations General Assembly adopts the Convention on Genocide and Human Rights.
1949: Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek flies from Chengtu, Szechwan Province, to Taipei.
1952: The ROC government drafts its first four-year economic development plan.
1955: Cambodian Prime Minister Norodom Sihanouk arrives in Taipei for a visit.
1959: ROC President Chiang Kai-shek appoints Ku Cheng-kang as the acting secretary-general of the National Assembly.
1960: The ROC establishes diplomatic relations with Gabon.
1973: A five-day Seminar on Agricultural Development with special reference to Taiwan is opened at the JCRR (Joint Commission on Rural Reconstruction) Building in Taipei.
1974: Toshio Urabe, newly appointed chief of the Taipei office of the Japanese Interchange Association, arrives in Taipei to assume his post.
1975: China Petroleum Corporation President Jerome Hu confirms the discovery of undersea oil deposits some 15 kilometers west of central Taiwan.
1975: A 12.5-kilometer section of the North-South Freeway between Chungli and Yangmei is completed. A 42-kilometer section of the roadway is now open to traffic.
1979: Mother Teresa is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for her ceaseless work in helping the destitute.
1979: The Formosa Incident, during which Formosa magazine demonstrators clash with police, occurs in Kaohsiung.
1986: Lee Yuan-tseh is awarded as the co-winner of the 1986 Nobel Prize in chemistry at the Stockholm Concert Hall in Sweden.
1988: Mainland Chinese troops shoot into crowds of Tibetans demonstrating for human rights in Lhasa.
1988: The Indigenous Defense Fighters (IDF), manufactured by ROC aviation experts, are formally named "Ching-kuo" class fighters by President Lee Teng-hui.
1993: African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela says he and South African President F.W. de Klerk are bound by the Nobel Peace Prize they accepted to spend the rest of their lives building a democratic South Africa free of racial discrimination.
1996: The Cabinet-level Council of Aboriginal Affairs is established. The Taiwan Independence Party, which is a Democratic Progressive Party splinter group, is also established.
1999: The first human rights monument in Asia is officially inaugurated, on Green Island off the southeastern coast of Taiwan.
1999: Chen Shui-bian, the presidential candidate of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), formally names Annette Lu as his running mate for the 2000 presidential election.
2000: Under an amnesty decree issued by President Chen Shui-bian, 21 prisoners are released on International Human Rights Day.
2001: Fabrice de Murat, general manager of L'Oreal Taiwan, is re-elected chairman of the European Council for Commerce and Trade (ECCT).
2001: A delegation of high-ranking Taiwan police officers arrive in Beijing for a 12-day visit to the mainland. The delegation is the first of its kind to visit the mainland since the two sides separated following the end of China's civil war in 1949.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A young man, when at home, should be a good son; when out in the world, a good citizen. He should be circumspect and truthful. He should be in sympathy with all men, but intimate with men of moral character. If he has time and opportunity to spare, after the performance of those duties, he should then employ them in literary pursuits."
