DOC.HEADLINE: NEW DPP CHAIRWOMAN TO HEAR VARIOUS VOICES WITHIN PARTY IN COMING DAYS

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu is set to meet with important members of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) over the next few days to hear their opinions, a source close to the party said Saturday.

Lu was appointed interim DPP chairwoman by the party's Central Standing Committee (CSC) after Su Tseng-chang stepped down as chairman to take responsibility for the party's poor showing in the Dec. 3 "three-in-one" local elections.

According to the source, Lu will meet with CSC members and leaders of the party's various factions Sunday and with members of the party's Policy Committee Monday. She will also invite DPP legislators to voice their opinions at a symposium scheduled to be held Monday at the DPP's headquarters to discuss party matters.

The DPP's different factions have voiced different opinions about Lu's appointment as chairwoman. DPP Legislator Lee Wen-chung of the New Wave faction has said that "one should make a correct self-assessment of whether this matter is a good thing or a bad thing."

Meanwhile, voicing his support for Lu, DPP Legislator Lee Chun-yi said that at this crucial moment, the DPP needs a qualified and experienced person to lead the party. "Who is a better choice than Lu?" he asked.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: IR race: Five left as Tabcorp, Wynn drop out.
LAS Vegas' Wynn Resorts and Australia's Tabcorp Holdings have bowed out of the race for Singapore's Marina Bay casino licence, leaving just five contenders.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Wong Kan Seng called on the chinese businessman to adopt balanced employment policy
Race rebellion happen recently in Paris reminds people to care about the harmony among races, Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister Wong Kan Seng said yesterday in 20th anniversary commemoration evening banquet of Singapore Federation of Chinese Clan Associations.
Mr Wang, who is also the Minister of Home Affairs, reminded the chinese businessman do not to make obstacles for minority race, when they employ the staff, by the reason that the job need to speak mandarin.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HOPES TO REINFORCE FRIENDSHIP WITH JAPAN: VICE CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) firmly supports sustainable development in the Republic of China on Taiwan and also hopes that the country can reinforce its friendship with Japan, a KMT leader said in Tokyo Saturday.
KMT Vice Chairman Chiang Pin-kung made the remarks while meeting with local Taiwanese reporters after concluding a four-day visit to Japan.

Chiang, at the head of a 11-member KMT delegation, said that the visit was aimed at explaining such issues as the party's victory in Taiwan's Dec. 3 local elections as well as former KMT Chairman Lien Chan's China visit and new KMT head Ma Ying-jeou's stance on various matters to Japanese political figures and organizations.

Expressing his satisfaction with the visit, the vice chairman also said that during their stay, the delegation met with leaders from both the Japanese ruling and leading opposition political parties as well as a former Japanese prime minister and members of a non-partisan pro-Taiwan organization in order to allay their concerns and clear up any misunderstandings regarding the KMT's stance on certain domestic and foreign policy issues.

Noting that maintaining a peaceful and stable mechanism of development between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait is very important to Taiwan's economy and that more than 85 percent of the Taiwan people favor maintaining the current cross-strait status quo, Chiang said that "these are the policies that the KMT wants to promote" and that "the victory claimed by the party in the local elections reflects the public opinion."

Lien's visit to mainland China in April of this year has been helpful toward reducing tensions between Taipei and Beijing, he further said, adding that it has also been beneficial to Taiwan's economy.

"The KMT also hopes that Japan and China, the two economic powerhouses in Asia, can cooperate with each other as they take on the responsibility of establishing a peaceful and prosperous future in the region," he continued.

Tseng Yung-chuan, a KMT legislator, also said that during the visit, he told members of Japanese political circles why the KMT has blocked passage of the arms procurement bill in the Legislative Yuan, stressing that the KMT only supports "a reasonable arms procurement project" and that its legislative caucus will deal with the matter in a practical way in the wake of the local elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: TEACHING EXCELLENCE PROGRAM TO BE CONTINUED: EDUCATION MINISTRY

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education will provide another NT$5 billion (US$149.25 million) next year to promote teaching excellence at local universities, Education Minister Tu Cheng-sheng said Saturday.
The minister made the remarks while addressing the opening of an international symposium on excellence in teaching held by Soochow University.
Tu pointed out that this year, 13 universities shared the total of NT$1 billion that was earmarked by the ministry to finance the teaching excellence program.

Tu said that the additional NT$5 billion has been included in a special budget proposal which has been submitted by the Cabinet to the Legislative Yuan and that the ministry will accept applications by interested universities as soon as the budget is approved by the legislature.
In principle, he said, all universities that have not obtained funding under a five-year, NT$50 billion higher education subsidy project will be able to apply.
According to Tu, a basic purpose of universities is to teach students, and professors should be serious about their teaching in addition to excelling in research.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHOOSING NEW CHAIRMAN AFTER KMT-PFP MERGER ONLY NATURAL: PFP LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: It is only natural for the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) to elect a new chairman after the two parties merge, a PFP legislator said Saturday.

PFP lawmaker Chang Hsien-yao made the comment while touching on the issue of the two parties' future in a meeting with reporters after he listened to the opinions expressed earlier in the day on the matter by PFP grass-roots supports in Kaohsiung.
According to the legislator, the opinions will be used as a reference by KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and PFP Chairman James Soong who are set to meet Dec. 12 to discuss the merger plan.

The KMT and the PFP might be merged when the next legislative elections in 2007 roll around, Chang said, adding that Ma's campaign for the 2008 presidential election will make him unable to continue to serve as the chairman of the new party that is formed by the merger.
"Therefore, it is natural for the two parties to elect a new chairman after the merger," Chang said.
"Just like two companies or two financial holding firms, it is quite correct for the two political parties to elect new leadership and management after they merge," he added.
Chang further said that the new party can be called the "Kuomintang, " but he added that it should be "a brand new Kuomintang."
Talking about the upcoming Ma-Soong meeting, Chang said that Ma accepted his suggestion that the two chairmen meet in a neutral "third" location.
Talks regarding a merger of the two parties have been stepped up significantly since the Dec. 3 "three-in-one" elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: 83% OF OFFICE WORKERS UNDER FINANCIAL PRESSURE: POLL

TEXT.P: A total of 83.41 percent of office workers in Taiwan are under financial pressure, with approximately 22 percent of these workers having thought about committing suicide, according to the results of a survey released Saturday by an online employment service provider.
The survey was conducted by the 1111 Job Bank between Nov. 18 and Dec. 2 on 1,242 office workers. The survey has a margin of error of plus or minus 2.8 percentage points.

The survey shows that the salary of office workers averages NT$31,231 per month. While 24.64 percent of these workers make NT$20,001 to NT$25,000 per month, 19.97 percent earn NT$15,840 to NT$20,000 per month, and 17.23 percent make NT$25,001 to NT$30,000 per month.
The sources of financial pressure mentioned by the respondents included general living expenses (64.25 percent) , mortgages or rent (39.94 percent), and other liabilities (29.31 percent).
When faced with financial pressure, 51.85 percent of the respondents said they tell their friends, 34.78 percent said they tell their spouses, and 39.61 percent said they deal with it alone.

A total of 21.9 percent of the respondents said they have thought about killing themselves because of heavy financial pressure, compared with 78.1 percent who have not. Meanwhile, 87.76 percent of the respondents said they believe financial pressure is one of the possible causes of depression.

According to data from the Department of Health, 70 percent to 90 percent of Taiwan people who killed themselves had suffered from a mental disease, with depression being the most common. While 75 percent of those who have attempted suicide had visited a doctor within one year of their suicide attempt, 45 percent did so within one month. However, only approximately two percent of those who have attempted suicide had any contact with psychological healthcare workers within one month of trying to kill themselves.

Meanwhile, statistics from the Taiwan Lifeline International show that 8.36 percent of the people who have sought the help of the organization have done so because of financial or career problems, which is the third most common problem after relationship problems (37.5 percent) and mental or psychological problems (28 percent).

DOC.HEADLINE: ANALYST SAYS THERE'S STILL ROOM FOR FURTHER APPRECIATION OF YUAN

TEXT.P: China's adoption in July of a more flexible yuan exchange rate mechanism, bringing a 2-percent appreciation in its currency in the process, has not had a negative effect on the country's economy, showing that there is still room for further appreciation of the yuan, an economist said in a report published Saturday by Taiwan's Ministry of Economic Affairs.

Kao Charng, head of the Hualien-based National Dong Hwa University's College of Humanities and Social Science, conducted an analysis on the factors affecting the value of the yuan after Beijing released in mid-November a report on its currency policy in the third quarter.
The Beijing report cities statistics as showing that China's total domestic output registered growth of 9.4 percent in the first three quarters of the year.
China's exports saw year-on-year growth of 31.3 percent for the first three quarters, with the country registering a trade surplus of US$68.3 billion for the period, the report said.
Meanwhile, foreign exchange reserves rose to US$769 billion by the end of the third quarter, up by US$153 billion in comparison with the level at the beginning of this year, according to the report.

Kao noted that the yuan appreciation led to a loss of some 130 million yuan (US$16.1 million) in trade for the July-October period, but the figure represents only a miniscule 0.013 percent of the total trade revenue of enterprises in China for the period.

Moreover, as nearly half of the enterprises in China had taken precautions, such as boosting production efficiency, upgrading product quality, or maintaining the price value of exports, to cushion the impact of a yuan appreciation, only a handful of companies were seriously affected by the 2-percent revaluation, Kao said.

Furthermore, the Beijing report showed that the revaluation only had a limited affect on foreign trade, with only 6.6 percent of surveyed enterprises choosing to decrease exports and merely 13.7 percent choosing to try to boost sales in the domestic market to deal with the currency appreciation.

However, Kao said, Chinese enterprises don't really have the option to lower their prices to offset the effects of the appreciations in the value of the yuan as their profit margins are already so slim due to intense competition at home. According to a survey by China's central bank, about 85.9 percent of polled enterprises in China said that 3 percent is the maximum amount that they could cut their prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT PAYS RESPECTS TO DEMOCRACY PIONEER

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian paid his respects to the late Huang Hsin-chieh, who was his mentor and a pioneer in Taiwan's democratic development, in the northern Taipei county Saturday.

Accompanied by Huang Tien-fu, the younger brother of the late Huang, and ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Lan Mei-chin, wife of Huang Tien-fu, the president visited Huang's tomb at a cemetery in Pali, Taipei County.
The president, who has yet to make public appearance since the DPP's crushing defeat in the Dec. 3 local elections, kept a low profile during the visit.

After burning incense and bowing before the late Huang's tomb, the president chatted with Huang's family members for 20 minutes, according to Ma Yung-cheng, deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office. The president made no public statement, but he prayed that Huang's spirit will give him strength and guidance to continue on the path of reform, Ma said.

Ma also quoted the president as saying that he couldn't come to Huang's cemetery earlier because he was in southern Taiwan stumping for DPP candidates, so he decided to come on Saturday, which marked the 26th anniversary of the Kaohsiung Incident, generally recognized as an important turning point in the island's transition to democracy, when police cracked down on a peaceful rally to mark Human Rights Day on Dec. 10, 1979.

President Chen said Huang, a former DPP chairman, is the perennial spiritual leader of the party, which stands for the pursuit of the ideals of democracy, freedom, human rights, social justice, protection of the disadvantaged, as well as Taiwan first, Ma said.
The president has engaged in self-examination and reflected upon the domestic situation after the elections over the past week, he said.

On questions regarding the administration's lineup after Su Tseng-chang stepped down as DPP chairman to take responsibility for the party's major setback in the elections and on questions concerning a possible Cabinet reshuffle, Ma said that the president will reveal his ideas after an overall consideration.
Legislator Lan said President Chen has visited the late Huang's tomb every year to pay his respects since Huang passed away on Dec. 30, 1999.

Noting that the DPP is in disarray after the Dec. 3 elections, Lan said, however, that the president shouldn't shoulder the responsibility alone, saying that the president has worked hard enough during the election campaign and that the party should continue on the path of reform.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT HAS NO PLAN TO RUN FOR DPP CHAIRMANSHIP

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu reiterated Saturday that she has no plan to vie for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) chairmanship.

Lu was appointed acting chairwoman of the DPP earlier this week after Su Tseng-chang stepped down from the chairmanship to take responsibility for the DPP's drubbing in the Dec. 3 "three-in-one" elections. The party won only six of the 23 city mayor and county magistrate posts up for grabs in the elections, compared with the 14 won by the opposition Kuomintang.
Lu said that she is taking care of the ruling party temporarily on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian and that it is good that many DPP members have shown an interest in running for the chairmanship.

Lu said that during next week's Central Standing Committee meeting of the DPP, she will put forward a proposal to set up an anti-corruption committee within the party to monitor DPP public office holders and restore the DPP's image as an incorruptible party.

During Wednesday's Central Standing Committee meeting, the DPP is expected to set the date for the chairmanship election, which will probably be held some time before the Chinese New Year holiday at the end of January.

DPP Legislator Trong Chai has announced his decision to vie for the position, while Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun and former DPP Legislator Luo Wen-jia, who lost the Taipei County magistrate election, are reportedly thinking about entering the race as well.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE YUAN APPEALS FOR CONTINUED SUPPORT FOR TAX REFORMS

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan hopes that the public will continue to support tax reforms that aim at an equitable distribution of wealth, Executive Yuan Secretary-General Cho Jung-tai said Saturday.

His remarks came one day after the Legislative Yuan passed the basic tax statute, or the "minimum tax code." According to the bill, a company that earns more than NT$2 million (US$59,700) a year will have to pay between 10 percent and 20 percent in corporate income tax, while high-income individuals will be obligated to pay at least 20 percent of their income that exceeds NT$6 million per year.
The premier expressed his appreciation to the legislature for the passage of the minimum tax code, which he said is a great step toward major tax reforms.

The premier has listed tax reform as one of his major goals since assuming his post in February, Cho said, adding that in order to improve the government's finances, it has for the first time put forward a budget with less spending than the previous year.

Now that the minimum tax system, which takes into consideration economic development, social justice and sustainable development, has received the support of the legislature and the people, the premier is "gratified," Cho said.
Cho noted that South Korea and Taiwan have changed positions in various fields in recent years, although Taiwan's economic development is still superior.

He said that foreign investment in Taiwan has exceeded that of any other Asian country recently, and that the economic fundamentals in Taiwan are still solid, but the people have not acutely felt the improvement in their lives.
"This means that there is great room for improvement in terms of a more equitable distribution of wealth," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE, POLITICAL PARTIES MOST CORRUPT: POLL

TEXT.P: A majority of Taiwan people responding to a recent opinion poll have singled out the legislature as the most corrupt agency in the country, according to the results of a survey released by the Transparency International's Taiwan chapter.

The poll was part of a global survey released by the Berlin-based anti-graft group Transparency International (TI) in celebration of Dec. 9 United Nations Anti-Corruption Day, said Yu Chih-li, chief executive of the TI's Taiwan chapter.

Up to 78 percent of those responding to the Taiwan chapter's survey said they feel that the Legislative Yuan is most corrupt, and 69 percent said political parties are corrupt. The least corrupt institutions cited by local respondents are religious groups, non government organizations and household registration agencies.

Thirty-five percent of those surveyed said they believe that corruption will increase in the next three years, Hsu said. He suggested that the government pushes for law revisions to make senior public officials' assets from unknown sources as incriminating evidence to avert corruption and establish clean politics.
According to TI's 2005 Global Barometer survey, corruption is on the increase in most countries and poor people are often the hardest hit.
Nearly 55,000 people in 69 countries were surveyed for the Corruption Barometer as part of a Gallup poll conducted between May and October 2005.
The poll found a majority of people in 48 out of 69 countries surv eyed thought the problem had got worse over the past three years.

"Today's survey shows that people believe corruption is deeply embedded in their countries, " said TI Chairwoman Huguette Labelle. "When a poor young mother believes that her government places its own interests above her child's, or that securing services like that child's basic health requires a hand under the table, her hope for the future is dampened."

Overall, people rated political parties as the most corrupt institutions. But customs officials were seen as the most corrupt in many Central and Eastern European states while the police and legal systems often came top of the poll in Africa.
The survey also showed paying bribes was not confined to specific regions but was particularly prevalent in Central and Eastern Europe, Africa and Latin America.
Transparency International, a non-governmental group based in Berlin with branches in more than 90 countries, said leaders could combat corruption if they made a determined effort.
A U.N. Convention against Corruption, signed by 137 nations, enters into force on Dec. 14 and the group said systems must be put in place to ensure governments stick to their commitments.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: U.S. Joins Informal Talks on Warming; Other Kyoto Parties Back Stronger Action.
The United States, after fiercely resisting any new international talks to address Earth's warming climate, agreed Friday night to a nonbinding dialogue to respond to climate change as representatives of nearly 200 nations prepared to conclude two weeks of meetings on the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: TEACHERS, RETIRED TEACHERS FROM AROUND TAIWAN STAGE PROTEST IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Thousands of teachers and retired teachers from around Taiwan took part in a parade in Taipei City Saturday to protest against the government's decision to amend the pension payment scheme for retired civil servants, military personnel and teachers.

The National Teachers' Association and a league of retired teachers organized the parade which began at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall complex and ended in front of the Presidential Office on Ketagalan Avenue.

The protestors staged a sit-in in front of the Presidential Office, demanding an apology from President Chen Shui-bian for scrapping the 18-percent preferential interest rate given to retired teachers, civil servants and military personnel as a "campaign tool" ahead of the Dec. 3 "three-in-one" elections.

The protestors also demanded that Examination Yuan President Chu Wu-hsien step down, claiming that he had given false information on the pension payment scheme which led the government to adopt a "tough" stance by making the amendment without taking the lives of hundreds of thousands of retirees into consideration.

The Examination Yuan, which is responsible for the civil service system, adopted a new pension payment plan in early November to cut the "unfair amount" in retirement benefits for teachers, civil servants and military personnel.

Prior to the changes to the pension payment program, some retired civil servant received pensions that were higher than what they earned before retirement, due in part to the preferential 18-percent savings interest rate, according to the Examination Yuan.

In the new pension payment scheme which will soon be put into practice, the retirement income for middle-and lower-ranking civil servants will not exceed 90 percent of their salary at the time of their retirement. For higher-ranking civil servants, the ceiling will be between 75 percent and 80 percent.
The same principle will be applied to retired teachers and military personnel.
The protest organizers said that their pension replacement rate of pre-retirement income has never exceeded 90 percent, rebuking the government for giving what they called "wrong data."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SHOULD CLEARLY DEFINE NATION'S DIRECTION: ADVISER

TEXT.P: The most important thing for President Chen Shui-bian to do now is to tell the people clearly where he intends to lead the country in his remaining two years in office, a senior presidential adviser said Saturday.
Koo Kuan-min made the remarks after calls for President Chen to apologize following the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) humiliating defeat in the Dec. 3 local elections.
"The elections are over, and there is no need for the president to apologize," Koo said.
Wu Li-pei, another senior presidential adviser, echoed Koo's views, saying that "the elections have ended, and now it is time for serious self-examination."

The president's focus in the next two years should be to deliver on his promises made during the presidential campaign, Wu said, adding that this is the only way for him to live up to the expectations of his supporters.

President Chen has often been criticized for wavering in his policies, Wu said, adding, however, that the problem lies not in the president's policies, but in his being too compromising in the people he appoints.
The president's future appointees should not be distributed among the factions, Wu said, but should instead be chosen based on their ability to carry out the policies.

Koo also said that new breakthroughs in the stalled cross-strait term, mainly because of the resounding victory by the main opposition relations are unlikely to be achieved during the remainder of Chen's Kuomintang in the Dec. 3 elections, which Beijing will view as a success in its policy toward Taiwan and will therefore not alter its policy.

On constitutional reform, Koo noted that former President Lee Teng-hui orchestrated six constitutional reforms during his 12 years in office but couldn't achieve a creditable outcome. For this reason, Koo said, Taiwan should craft a new Constitution.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALLIANCE SEEKS TO IMPROVE HUMAN RIGHTS IN NEXT CONSTITUTIONAL REFORMS

TEXT.P: A local alliance promoting constitutional reform unveiled Saturday a list of human rights issues that the group believes should be addressed in the next phase of reforms.

The list, released on Human Rights Day, covers areas such as equality rights, liberty rights, social rights, collective rights, rights of political participation, basic procedural rights, asylum rights for foreigners, and the right to resistance.
Alliance convener Hung Yu-hung said the list was compiled by constitutional law professors based on suggestions put forth by more than 50 member organizations of the alliance.

According to Hung, the sovereignty of the country belongs to all its people, rather than political parties, and the movement promoted by the alliance will provide the people with the chance to think about the direction of national development.
The alliance will try to improve the list and release a second and even third version of the list in the future, he said.

In response, Lee Chun-yi, head of the constitutional reforms office at the Presidential Office, said he welcomes the efforts made by the alliance and hopes that the public will offer their support for the reforms.

Lee said the release of the list indicates that human rights are not sufficiently protected under the existing Constitution and represents the anxious aspirations of private citizens and organizations to make improvements.
In addition, it echoes the idea of developing "a country based upon human rights" by President Chen Shui-bian, Lee said.
Lee said the Presidential Office does not take any predetermined stand towards the next phase of constitutional reforms and will listen to the opinions of the public.
He pointed out that the existing Constitution only covers 14 kinds of human rights, which he said displays a wide gap with most modern constitutions drafted after World War II.
Although seven rounds of constitutional amendments have been launched, none of them have concerned changes to the chapter governing the rights and obligations of the people, he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: HIRING OF FOREIGN WORKERS A TANGLED WEB THAT KEEPS LABORERS OPPRESSEDBy Taijing Wu

TEXT.P: CNA Staff Reporter

Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) Each Sunday afternoon the sidewalk by Saint Christopher's Church on Taipei's Chungshan Road becomes a "Little Manila, " with hawkers selling discount clothing, jewelry, toys and prepaid phone cards amid the titter of laughter and gossip in Tagalog as overseas Filipino workers, mostly women, congregate on their one day off a week.
Joining in the weekly street fair-like atmosphere are a smattering of Thais and Indonesians, adding an exotic aspect to the capital city.
This is the time when caregivers and blue-collar workers can mix and compare notes on the week's goings on. But not everyone has glowing reviews to give.

A Filipina caregiver complains to her friends about the absurd amount of extra time she has to work, before suddenly bursting into tears. Her Thai friend, who works at a construction site, says that his labor management agency forces him to pay excessive broker's fees. Their other friend, a woman, says in a frightened tone that her employer behaves strangely with her when his wife is out of the house.

Roughly 300,000 foreign migrant workers live in Taiwan. Their working conditions are sometimes less than ideal. Stories have surfaced of ill-treatment by their Taiwanese employers or persecution by their management agencies. These people have come from afar, although most of them would rather be in their home countries with their loved ones. But they have chosen to roll the dice in Taiwan in the hopes that the money they earn will provide a better living for those they leave behind.
And they hope that their new employers will treat them with the respect they know they are due.

However, dreams of leading a simple life helping an elderly person or caring for the children of busy Taiwanese parents often turns into a nightmare with foreign workers being mistreated or exploited in inhumane conditions. Some are required to work overtime without additional pay and others must pay unexpected sums to their labor brokers in their home countries or face losing their jobs and being deported.
True, migrant workers have a variety of places where they can work, from Hong Kong to Singapore, and workers have a variety of reasons for ending up in a strange land.

Taiwan's overseas workers often come to the island because of what they perceive as good working conditions and a competitive salary. But although Taiwan was once known for its low-cost labor, the situation now has changed, and tough jobs are reserved mainly for foreign migrant workers where the bottom line is money, with many willing to take on the most dangerous and often backbreaking work -- all to help their families back home.

But many workers and local observers realize that something is wrong with the system of recruitment in Taiwan, not least of which was brought to light on Aug. 21 when roughly 100 Thai manual laborers rebelled against a litany of unfair and inhumane conditions and rioted in the southern port city of Kaohsiung.

One aspect of the system that many point to as being out of sync with established norms is the way the country allows agencies to be the intermediary between an employer and laborers. A lucrative partnership forms between the Taiwanese employer and the agencies of both countries, with the hapless foreign worker left out in the cold, both in terms of workers' rights and financial protection.

In theory, the way foreign laborers should make their way into the country is fairly straightforward. A Taiwanese employer in need of overseas workers contacts a local foreign labor agency after the employer gets the go-ahead from the Council of Labor Affair (CLA) to hire a certain number of foreign workers. That agency then contacts overseas agencies who being the recruitment process.

But in Taiwan, the actual situation is far more complicated. Instead of the employers seeking out agents for their workers, it is the agents who seek out potential employers, with offers of payments to them for each worker that they hire. Labor brokers in Taiwan will even apply to the CLA for workers before even having a place for them to work. Labor brokers in Taiwan are so willing to bend over backwards to entice prospective employers that they will pay them NT$30,000 to NT$50,000 for each overseas worker that they agree to hire through their agency.

These "commissions" are then passed on to the foreign brokers, generally in Thailand, the Philippines or Indonesia, but not after the Taiwanese side doubles the figure. Not to be outdone, the foreign agency then passes this charge on to each worker that wishes to come to Taiwan, but not without increasing the sum further so that the worker, before even leaving his home country, has a debt of about three times the initial "commission" from the Taiwanese broker. By this time the front money has risen to roughly NT$140,000, a small fortune for someone who might make the equivalent of NT$5,000 a month in his own country.

Nevertheless, with an eye on working in Taiwan for a number of years, and thus finally getting back into the black, workers will do whatever they can to raise the money, by borrowing from their families, selling their belongings or giving over their land to their local agent as collateral.
Sometimes the money paid by a foreign migrant worker is split into equal parts, one going to the Taiwanese agency, the other to the foreign one.

Adding more confusion to an already muddy situation is the move by the CLA four years ago to allow employers to withhold NT$4,000 per month from their foreign employees' salaries as "meal expenses." Local agencies were also given the right by the CLA to take from the workers NT$1,800 a month during the first year, NT$1,700 the second and NT$1,500 the third in "broker's fees."
And in a move reminiscent of the saying that there is no honor among thieves, some employers even demand a cut from this money that the overseas workers are forced to pay to their brokers.

Reynaldo Gopez, the labor representative of the Manila Economic and Cultural Office (MECO) , says that the best way to fight this phenomenon is to use direct, country to country hiring, which would cut out labor brokers altogether.

"The Philippine government allows the Filipino agencies to collect one month's salary from a worker once he starts working in Taiwan. But this isn't the way it happens. They in fact collect two to three times this amount, which is more than NT$50,000. It's a big financial burden for our workers since they come to work here because they need money," Gopez says.

"We are actually working hard with the Taiwanese authorities in order to make country to country direct hiring work better and avoid the [current] mechanism with the agencies. But it is hard to make this work properly even though direct hiring was approved eight to 10 years ago. Taiwanese employers are often small- or medium-sized enterprises, and they do not have a department in charge of human resources.

"Since paperwork to apply for one foreign worker is already annoying, the employer requests the agency to deal with the CLA and complete the procedure for him for more workers. This saves him much work, time and money," he said.
However, getting employers to hire directly from overseas is a hard sell given that this would mean the loss of the "commissions" from local brokers.

The Taiwan International Workers' Association (TIWA) advocates direct hiring. Ku Yu-ling, the TIWA's secretary-general says, "The best way to get rid of agencies is for countries to get directly in touch. But the CLA won't prohibit the agencies system."
Ku said that current laws are insufficient to protect foreign workers, and the workers are vulnerable to becoming virtual slaves unless they find a reasonable employer.
In a high-profile attempt to bring this situation to the attention of authorities, the TIWA will hold a rally on Sunday, Dec. 11 at the Taipei Train Station.

"First, we demand the abolishment of the agency system. Second, we request that a worker should have the right to change employers. Third, the limit to how long a worker can stay in the country should be lifted. Fourth, laws should be made specifically for the welfare of caregivers, and finally, foreign workers should have the right to form labor unions," Ku said.

Around 500 foreign workers attended a similar rally held by the TIWA two years ago. Ku said that local workers, foreign brides, employers and above all, white collar foreign workers have been invited to support these less-protected individuals at the rally this year. (End of part 1 of 2)

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN WORKERS BEGINNING TO KNOW THEIR RIGHTSBy Taijing WuCNA Staff Reporter

TEXT.P: Foreign workers are becoming more familiar with their rights in Taiwan, and armed with this knowledge are coming forward and filing grievances with their representative offices, according to a labor representative.

Thai and Philippine representative offices agree that the increase in complaints over the last few years is due to the fact that there are more channels available for workers to make their appeals known.

Reynaldo Gopez, the labor representative of the Manila Economic and Cultural Office (MECO) said, "The complaints and queries we received this year are more than those we received last year. This is because MECO reaches out to get in touch with the workers, and more and more workers are conscious about their rights."

Every week, MECO staff takes the initiative to meet Filipinos at the place they most often frequent on Sundays - St. Christopher's Church on Chungshan Road in Taipei, distributing flyers and talking to them directly. Foreign officials said that this direct contact allows them to have a clearer idea of what the workers' problems are.

"Most Taiwanese employers are reasonable. But there are still problems. In that case, we try our best to reach both the employer and the worker to resolve the problem. If it doesn't work, we follow the procedure and file a plea to the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA)," Gopez said.
Among the numerous problems that foreign workers encounter, the "broker's fee" that a worker has to pay their agency is considered the most controversial.
According to a CLA mandate passed four years ago, employers have the right to withhold NT$4,000 from their foreign workers' monthly salaries to pay for the workers' daily meals.
On top of this is the NT$1,800 broker's fee that a foreign worker has to give his broker each month during his first year of stay. The amount is NT$1,700 the second year and NT$1,500 the third year.

"Normally, these should be separately collected over three years. But unscrupulous agencies often collect them in just 10 months, making a worker pay NT$6,000 per month. This financial burden is too great for them. You can't imagine the burden in the minds of the workers. Many of them borrowed large sums of money in Manila at very high interest [to come to Taiwan]," Gopez said.

Although the Filipino and ROC governments are working on getting employers to use direct hiring, Gopez is still pessimist about it ever happening. The direct hiring program has been available to employers for eight to 10 years, but its effect is not obvious.

For this to work, an employer wishing to hire foreign workers must contact the CLA, which will issue him a permit. With this, the employer then contacts MECO, who will play the role of the middle man that reaches the Philippines Overseas Employment Administration (POEA) in Manila. The POEA then recruits workers locally.
This avoids labor agencies' interference in the process.

"The employer has to choose if he wishes to hire through this channel. We are striving to promote this direct hiring program by letting more and more employers know about it. Most of them are even not aware that such a program exists and the first thing they think about is agencies," Gopez said.
"The Filipino and Taiwanese governments are continuously making efforts to better the conditions of our workers and implement the direct hiring program," he said.

"Unfortunately, you can't really avoid agencies with this approach. Direct hiring is just an alternative. The employer needs a middle man to do all the paperwork with the CLA to apply for a worker. Besides that, the workers' management and discipline is also assigned to the agencies, this explains why agencies cannot be omitted from this circle," he added.

Both Thai and Filipino labor representatives have urged companies in Taiwan to follow the example of Formosa Group's Nanya and Inotera, which hire foreign workers through country to country direct hiring.

"We're trying to convince other companies to follow this example. They don' t withhold extra money from their foreign workers, plus, they feed and lodge them. They have kept their foreign workers from being exploited by agencies. Under this working environment, workers perform better and produce more; most important of all, they do not have this big financial burden," Gopez said.

South Korea, which is currently in need of infrastructure construction, also imports foreign workers from the Philippines and Thailand through a channel similar to country to country direct hiring, which has been shown to be more efficient.

Thai workers are considered to be the most passive and hard-working. Nevertheless, they still rioted on Aug. 21 this year in an incident that attracted international media attention to Taiwan -- a place that so values its human rights and democracy.

Thais are normally able to reimburse their agencies after working one or two years almost for "free, " if they meet a reasonable employer. If their employer maltreats them, they can only try and endure.

If things go very wrong for a worker, he may be sent back home; or sensing the worst, he may abscond. In that case, they will not be able to pay back their agency the large amount of money, which could lead to more problems down the line.

Asoke Srichantr of Radio Taiwan International's Thai Service (RTI) said, "In our daily program, we tell our Thai audience here that they must not run away if they are maltreated by their employers. When they have a problem with their employer, we tell them to cool down and appeal through normal channels.

"Thai workers used to run away most often from factories, as there are more than 80,000 people in the manufacture sector. But now, they are less likely to do so and they are really appreciated among employers for their hard-working attitude," Srichantr said.

Srichantr said that Taiwan has lots of laws regarding foreign migrant workers, but problems mostly lie in language and cultural differences. Added to these two is the unscrupulous exploitation by agencies that makes workers' lives miserable.
The executive director of the Taiwan International Workers' Association (TIWA) , Ku Yu-ling, says that foreign workers lack adequate protection in Taiwan.
"There must be a law for them, and they must be treated as people," Ku said.

DOC.HEADLINE: VEEP CALLS FOR PRIVATE SUPERVISORY ALLIANCE ON KAOHSIUNG MRT

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Saturday she will organize a private supervisory alliance to ensure good quality and safety of the mass rapid transit (MRT) system now under construction in the southern port city of Kaohsiung.

Lu made the announcement while presiding over an informal meeting with members of the Presidential Office Human Rights Advisory Commission to mark the commission's fifth anniversary. Lu concurrently heads the advisory group.

Noting that the Kaohsiung MRT project has been hit by a spate of serious accidents since construction began in 2001, Lu said the planned supervisory alliance will review the MRT railway's design, construction methods and groundwater hydrology at the construction site and come up with improvement proposals.
Lu traveled to Kaohsiung early Saturday morning in the company of a group of engineering experts to inspect an MRT construction site where a serious accident happened Monday.

"Today is Human Rights Day. Public safety is basic human rights. Repeated cave-in accidents at the MRT construction site form a threat to Kaohsiung citizens' human rights. They are entitled to be free of fears," Lu said.
During her inspection tour, Lu said she discovered that the MRT contractor might have misjudged the groundwater hydrology beneath certain construction sites.

To ensure public safety and project quality, Lu said she will form a private supervisory alliance to make an overall technical review and oversee the whole construction process. The alliance will be composed of major civil engineering associations, structure engineering associations, transportation technologists associations, bar association representatives and respected university professors in southern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TUNA SECTOR TO FACE ANOTHER CHALLENGE AT UPCOMING MEETING
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Dec.10 (CNA) (By Neil Lu & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's tuna fishing sector is expected to face another challenge next week following the recent cut in Taiwan's allowable catch of bigeye tuna by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna (ICCAT).

The ICCAT commission recently passed a Japanese proposal to cut Taiwan's total allowable catch of bigeye tuna from the current 14,900 tons per year to 4,600 tons for 2006 in an effort to stem overfishing in the Atlantic Ocean and the Mediterranean Sea.

According to news reports, Japan will submit the same proposal at the upcoming second regular session of the Western and Central Pacific Fisheries Commission (WCPFC) which will be held in Micronesia Dec. 12-16.
Taiwan is scheduled to issue a "national report" on its tuna fishing industry at the upcoming WCPFC session.

New York Times: U.S., Under Fire, Eases Its Stance in Climate Talk
The United States dropped its opposition early Saturday morning to nonbinding talks on addressing global warming after a few words were adjusted in the text of statements that, 24 hours earlier, prompted a top American official to walk out on negotiations. At the same time, other industrialized nations that have signed on to the Kyoto Protocol, a treaty binding them to curb emissions of greenhouse gases, agreed to start meeting to set new deadlines once the existing pact's terms expire in 2012.

DOC.HEADLINE: PENSION REFORM AIMED AT SOCIAL JUSTICE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE

TEXT.P: The government's pension reform program is aimed at achieving social justice and fairness, Presidential Office spokesman Chen Wen-tzung said Saturday.

Chen made the remarks after thousands of school teachers and retired educators took to the streets earlier in the day to protest the government's decision to cut pension perquisites for retired civil servants, military personnel and teachers.

Pointing out that the government has not decided to phase out the 18 percent preferential interest rate for retirees' pension deposits, Chen said what the government intends to do is just to set a ceiling on the postretirement income replacement rates to rationalize the nation's pension system.

Under the existing scheme, some retirees receive more money per month than they actually earned prior to retirement, due mainly to the preferential 18-percent deposit interest rate available to retired civil servants, military personnel and teachers.
"This unreasonable phenomenon should be changed because it has become a bone of contention for the general public and a heavy financial burden for the government," Chen said.

According to a reform scheme adopted by the Examination Yuan, for retirees who have worked as civil servants for 25 years, the postretirement income -- including monthly pension, the preferential deposit interest and year-end bonus money -- will not be more than 85 percent of the pay they were receiving at the time of their retirement. The ratio will be no more than 95 percent for those who have worked for 35 years. Slightly more than 80,000 incumbent and retired civil servants will see their pensions reduced under the new scheme.
In addition to civil servants, the new scheme will also be applied to military personnel and school teachers.
Even after the new scheme is implemented, Chen said the 85-to-95-percent postretirement income replacement rates remain the highest in the world.

"Public opinion poll results have consistently shown that more than 60 percent of local people give a thumbs-up to the new scheme. We hope civil servants, military personnel and school teachers can support this program to uphold social justice," Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA SHOULD BE CONDEMNED IF PROTESTER DEATHS CONFIRMED: MAC

TEXT.P: China should be harshly condemned if media reports about Chinese police shootings of protesters in a Chinese village in the southern province of Guangdong is confirmed, a mainland affairs official said Saturday.
According to foreign wire service reports, Chinese police killed up to 20 people Tuesday when they fired on demonstrators in Guangdong province's Dongzhou township, northeast of Hong Kong.

The reports also quoted villagers as having said that dozens of others were still missing. The villagers had been protesting allegedly inadequate payments for land taken by Chinese authorities for a power plant.

After Tuesday's incident, villagers said a tense standoff prevailed as thousands of troops patrolled the perimeter, and frightened villagers either hunkered in their homes or argued with police over relatives' bodies.

If 20 are confirmed dead, it would be Chinese security forces' deadliest known use of force against civilians since the killings around Tiananmen Square in 1989, and underscore rising tension in rural China over land seizures for projects like factories, power plants and shopping malls.

Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Huang Wei-feng said no government in the world should use brute force against unarmed civilian people. If the report about police shootings of Dongzhou villagers is true, the Chinese government should be subject to the severest censure.
Lin Chong-pin, chief executive of the Foundation on International and Cross-Strait Studies, said the incident signals the graveness of social unrest in China.

Noting that the latest conflict between villagers and police is the result of official corruption, Lin said, Chinese President Hu Jintao should face up to the grim situation squarely. If Hu fails to launch fundamental political reform, he warned, China's future will be doomed.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Dec. 11, or the 11th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1816: The British restore Java, Indonesia, to the Dutch.
1853: Britain annexes Nagpur, one of the leading Mahrata states in India.
1927: The Chinese Communist Party stages a riot in Kwangchow (Canton) which results in massive burning and looting.
1935: The Nationalist government sets up the Hopei-Chahar Political Affairs Commission, with Soong Chih-yuan being appointed as chairman.
1936: George VI becomes King of England following the abdication of Edward VIII.
1941: The United States declares war against Germany and Italy during World War Two.
1951: The Taiwan Provincial Assembly is established, with Huang Chao-chin being elected as speaker.
1961: Two companies of U.S. military helicopters arrive in Saigon on an aircraft carrier, representing the first direct U.S. military support for the South Vietnam regime's battle against communist guerrillas.
1970: Taipei Mayor Henry Kao is impeached by the Control Yuan for breaking the law and for misfeasance.
1972: The U.S. Apollo 17 astronauts land on the moon and begin extensive exploration of the lunar surface.
1973: Maj. Gen. Slade Nash, newly appointed chief of the U.S. Military Assistance Advisory Group, arrives in Taipei to assume office.
1974: The Executive Yuan of the ROC approves the Sino-Ivory Coast Agricultural Development Technical Cooperation Pact.
1974: Ten "outstanding entrepreneurs" of the year are awarded plaques and citations in Taipei.
1976: The opening ceremony of the National Conference on Atmospheric Science is held at the Central Weather Bureau in Taipei with some 100 experts participating.
1976: Eric G. Sandstrong Jr., deputy commander of the Veterans of Foreign Wars of the United States, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1976: Lt. Gen. Kung Ling-cheng becomes head of the National Police Administration and concurrently the director of the Taiwan Provincial Police Department, succeeding Lt. Gen. Chou Chu-tsun.
1977: Kaohsiung County's Hsingta Port, the largest fishing port in Taiwan, is inaugurated and formally opened for use.
1989: Liu Pin-yen, a mainland Chinese writer residing in the United States, arrives in Taipei with his wife for a visit.
1990: Albania announces it will allow the formation of independent political parties.
1991: Leaders of 12 European countries agree to establish a loose federation with a common foreign policy and a single currency by 1999.
1994: Russian troops and armored vehicles roll into Chechnya in a bid to restore Moscow's control over the breakaway region.
1996: Tung Chee-hwa, a shipping magnate, sweeps to victory in the election for Hong Kong's leader-in-waiting to take over when the British colony reverts to Chinese rule.
1998: A Thai Airways Airbus crashes into a flooded rubber plantation, killing 101 people in southern Thailand.
1999: Chinese Taipei wins an across-the-board victory at the Czech Table Tennis Open with both the men and women's teams gaining group singles and group doubles victories.
2000: David Hu, director-general of the South and Central American Affairs Department of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, is confirmed by MOFA to be the new ROC ambassador to Panama.
2001: Newly elected county magistrates and legislators from Kinmen and Matsu meet in Beijing with Li Bingcai, deputy director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under the State Council, to discuss exchanges between the mainland and the two Taiwan-controlled islands.
2001: The Control Yuan, the nation's highest watchdog body, impeaches Ting Yuan-chin, former director-general of the National Police Administration, for filing a fraudulent report on payments for a luxury house.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise man who is not serious will not inspire respect; what he learns will not remain permanent. Make conscientiousness and sincerity your first principles. Have no friends who are not as yourself. When you have bad habits do no hesitate to change them."

DOC.HEADLINE: MA AND SOONG TO MEET MONDAY TO DISCUSS KMT-PFP MERGER

TEXT.P: The leaders of Taiwan's two largest opposition parties -- the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) -- will meet Monday evening in Taipei to discuss how to merge the two "pan-blue alliance" parties and other related issues.

KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and PFP Chairman James Soong are to have a closed-door, three-hour meeting at the Taipei Armed Forces Hero House, with only the secretaries-general of the two parties present to record their discussions.
KMT Secretary-General Chan Chuen-po said Sunday that he and his PFP counterpart, Chin Chin-sheng, will jointly brief the media on the results following the meeting.
The meeting was originally scheduled to take place at KMT headquarters, but the venue was later changed to a neutral place at the PFP's request.

Ma, who is also Taipei mayor, told reporters on a trip to Tainan Sunday that a merger with the PFP was agreed upon by a consensus reached at a meeting of the KMT Central Standing Committee on May 19, 2004, and that he will demonstrate "the maximum sincerity and the greatest good will" during his meeting with Soong.
The KMT chairman added that all topics will be open to discussion at the meeting.

At separate occasions Sunday, the KMT and PFP secretaries-general tacitly acknowledged that the meeting between Ma and Soong might touch upon such sensitive issues as whether an election should be held to elect a new party chairman after the merger and whether Soong should run for mayor of Taipei as the "pan-blue alliance" candidate at the end of 2006.
Chan said it is too early to discuss the issue of electing a new party chairman after the merger because the KMT just elected its chairman in July.
While recognizing the merger as an urgent matter, Chan said the merger must come naturally and at the right time when all the conditions are right.
PFP Secretary-General Chin said the first step toward a KMT-PFP merger will be possible only when the two parties treat each other with mutual respect and good will on an equal footing.
The PFP was founded by Soong in 2000 after he -- a member of the KMT at the time -- ran as an independent in the presidential election that year but failed.

Like the KMT, the PFP is against Taiwan independence and favors Taiwan's eventual unification with China. The party has maintained a close working relationship with the KMT in the legislature, but the relationship has sometimes been strained, especially in election years, because they have to compete for support from the same voter pool.

Prompting the merger is the fact that he PFP has more and more been marginalized as part of the "pan-blue alliance, " and this was underscored in the Dec. 3 elections for local chiefs when the KMT won in 14 of the 23 mayor and county magistrate elections and the PFP managed only one seat.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER RESPONDS CAUTIOUSLY TO LU'S KAOHSIUNG MRT SUPERVISORY PLAN

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh responded cautiously Sunday to Vice President Annette Lu's plan to organize a private supervisory alliance to ensure good quality and safety of the Kaohsiung mass rapid transit (MRT) system, whose construction is suffering both political scandals and cave-ins.

The planned supervisory alliance would review the MRT railway's design, construction methods and groundwater hydrology before coming up with improvement proposals. Lu said Saturday the alliance would also oversee the whole construction process.
Hsieh, who started awarding the building contracts and construction while he was mayor of the southern port city, made two comments Sunday in response to Lu's private supervisory alliance proposal.
First, Hsieh said he welcomed supervision by professionals, even though the Kaohsiung City Government already has a mechanism for that purpose.
He then cautioned that the Kaohsiung MRT issue should not be politicized as he fears political interference of the MRT construction process would affect professionalism.

He said the responsibility for the MRT problems should be shared by "all, irrespective of party affiliation." It should not be shifted to one person alone in an attempt to "kill me with one shot, " he added.
Hsieh made his comments while attending a Hakka festival in Kaohsiung with Lee Yung-teh, chairman of the Hakka Affairs Council, and Yeh Chu-lan, acting Kaohsiung mayor.

In response to reports that his ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , which suffered a great setback in the Dec. 3 local government elections, will form a "political integrity committee" next week to investigate whether Hsieh had been involved in the Kaohsiung MRT troubles, the premier said he was unconcerned.

The Kaohsiung MRT scandal that broke out after Thai workers working on the project rioted in late August was cited by analysts as one of the reasons for the DPP's election fiasco as investigations into it brought to light the involvement of Chen Min-hsien and Chen Che-nan.

Chen Min-hsien became the powerful vice chairman of the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. while Hsieh was Kaohsiung mayor. Chen Che-nan, who hails from Kaohsiung, served as a key aide to President Chen Shui-bian. Chen Che-nan is also suspected of playing the stock market while working at the Presidential Office.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC GROWTH GAP BETWEEN TAIWAN, SOUTH KOREA TO WIDEN: ANALYST

TEXT.P: The economic growth gap between Taiwan and South Korea is expected to further widen next year, tilting favorably toward South Korea, according to an economist.

Chen Hsin-hung, a division director at the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research, made the comment issued in the latest electronic newspaper run by the Industrial Development and Investment Center under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

Citing an assessment by Global Insight, an economic forecasting agency, Chen reported that the gap in economic growth rates between Taiwan and South Korea will broaden to 2.7 percentage points for 2006 from an estimated 0.4 percentage points for this year in South Korea's favor.

Global Insight forecast that Taiwan's and South Korea's economies will grow by 3.5 percent and 3.9 percent in 2005, while its growth rate forecasts for the two economies for 2006 are 3.3 percent and 6 percent, respectively.
Chen ascribed the changes to South Korea's fast technological progress thanks to its innovation and name-building strategies that have led to an advantage in product quality enjoyed by South Korea.

Handsets, LCDs and video games produced by South Korean firms have swept through the entire world, Chen said, adding that its automobiles and home appliances have also begun to win international acclaim.

The South Korean government's effort to promote innovate technologies is the major driving force behind the country's astonishing progress after the 1997 Asian financial crisis, Chen pointed out, noting that its research and development budgets increased by 14.7 percent in 2002.
In the face of China's fast rise, South Korea has made it clear that it will continue investing in hi-tech research and upgrading production efficiency, he said.
In contrast, Taiwan's performance in product quality improvement and branding has been lackluster, he noted.

For instance, he said, South Korea already has its own core technologies to manufacture DRAMs and has seen his handsets sell extremely well around the world, while Taiwan's cell phone makers remain as contractors for foreign conglomerates due to a lack of key technologies.

The big difference lies in the fact that some leading South Korean companies have successfully built their own distinguished names, and this is the leading factor that has driven the two economies to have traveled down divergent paths, he concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN BY-ELECTION DUE BY LATE JANUARY

TEXT.P: The by-election for ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) chairman will be held before the lunar new year, which falls on January 29, 2006, a DPP spokesman said Sunday.

For the time being, the DPP's Central Standing Committee has projected two dates to hold the by-election, and the committee will announce the exact date by Thursday before accepting registrations of candidates wishing to run for the post, the spokesman said, adding that the elected DPP chairman will take over after the Chinese new year holiday season.

Vice President Annette Lu, Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun, former Council for Hakka Affairs Chairman Lo Wen-chia and Legislator Trong Chai have been tipped as potential hopefuls in the race, the winner of which will face challenges from the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) in the 2006 Taipei and Kaohsiung mayor elections as well as the 2007 legislative and the 2008 presidential elections.
Former DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang immediately stepped down following the party's defeat in the Dec. 3 local government elections.
The KMT won 14 out of the 23 city mayor and county magistrate posts up for grabs; the DPP took only six. The KMT also took a majority in the councilors and village and township chief elections.
The KMT's overwhelming win indicates a strong comeback in future elections, in particular the 2008 presidential race, watchers have said.
