DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO DEFEND ITS RIGHTS AT GLOBAL FISHERIES MEETING: OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: Taiwan is ready to defend its rights in the global fisheries community at an international meeting to be held Monday in Micronesia, Fisheries Administration officials said Sunday.

Fisheries Administration Director-General Hsieh Ta-wen, Taiwan's chief delegate, will detail a management program on Taiwan's efforts to regulate its deep-sea fishing industry during the second annual meeting of the Western and Central Pacific Fisheries Commission (WCPFC) in anticipation that Japan will make fresh allegations about Taiwan's fishing practices on the high seas, according to the officials.

Owing to pressure from Japan, which complained about Taiwan's overfishing, the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna (ICCAT) agreed during its Nov. 20 annual meeting to cap the annual quota for Taiwan's bigeye tuna catch in the Atlantic at 4,600 metric tons for 2006 -- a large reduction from the current level of 14,900 metric tons.

As Japan is expected to raise new protests against Taiwan in the Monday WCPFC annual meeting since it already put forth documents last week to a WCPFC committee accusing Taiwan of "fish laundering, " the WCPFC annual conference chair has agreed to allow Taiwan to elaborate on its fishing boat reduction plan to other members in the Monday meeting after Taiwan delegates gave an initial explanation to the chair, the officials noted.

It is expected that the WCPFC will approve resolutions to limit the catches of various types of tuna in its annual conference, forcing members to reduce the number of their fishing vessels, the officials said, stressing that Taiwan must support universal and non-discriminatory rules to protect fishing resources in international waters.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RESEARCHER HELPS DEVELOP WAY TO GROW ARTIFICIAL CARTILAGEBy Staff Writer Maubo ChangWith Photos

TEXT.P: A casual chat and the application of crossover technology were the seeds that grew into a career for Dr. Li Wan-ju, culminating in the discovery of a way to create artificial cartilage, a technique that promises to help millions of patients around the world who suffer from damaged joints.

Currently, for those who have serious joint damage caused by arthritis or injury, physiotherapy or artificial joint replacement are the only options, with replacement surgeries being expensive and painful.

However, a "nanofiber scaffold" developed by Li and his colleagues at the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Maryland has succeeded in generating cartilage that offers a new option for patients.
The story began in 1997, when the Taiwan-born Li was studying for his master's degree at the Biomedical Engineering Graduate School at Drexel University in Philadelphia.
The graduate from Taiwan's Chung Yuan University in Chungli was told by ateacher in a chat that the potential use of a largely-ignored patent from 1938 had not been fully explored.
The patent concerning the generation of a fine fibers produced from a solution of gel-like particles under heavy electrical voltage.

The teacher said the spinning applied in the technique, which produces fibers with diameters measured in nanometers, had been widely used in textile manufacture, particularly in screen-making, but had not been studied for its possible use in medicine, although the fibers the process produces look like collagen fibrils -- analogous to the structures that support cells that produce bone and cartilage.

Li's interest was piqued and he assembled his own equipment with components bought with his own money at a local hardware store and began to electrospin fibers that lasted longer than those in previous experiments.

Lee told the Central News Agency that his preliminary work focused on trying to control the diameter of the fibers he spun until 1998 when he formed fibers with diameters of between 300 nanometers and 500 nanometers and began using them to fabricate scaffolds on which to grow human cells.

His study was presented at the Sixth Annual World BioMaterials Conference in Kamuela, Hawaii in 2000, and has been cited more than 180 times by scientists around the world since it was published in a periodical in 2002.
After entering the doctorate program at Thomas Jefferson University in Philadelphia, Li began to study the ways that cells implanted on electrospun nanofiber scaffolds grow.

His study continued when he joined the National Institutes of Health. He and his colleagues at the center's Cartilage Biology and Orthopedics Branch immersed human mesenchymal stem cells in an electrospun polymer scaffold and induced cells to grow.
Stem cells, derived from the spinal cord, were chosen for the experiment because they can differentiate into a variety of specialized cell types, such as adipose, cartilage and bone cells.

The scaffold is effective because its 700-nanometer diameter fibers imitate the collagen fibrils that support cells in the body. The fine fibers also degrade at an acceptably slow rate. They dissolve slowly enough to give the cells time to secrete collagen which replaces the scaffold.

The difficulty is in balancing the pace that the scaffold degrades with the pace the collagen is produced by the cells. Li and the other team members had preliminary success in testing the tissue-engineered constructs in vivo.
In 2002, Li cooperated with a surgeon at National Taiwan University Hospital in Taipei and cartilage Li produced on the polymer nanofiber scaffold was implanted into the foot of a pig.
Six months after the operation, they cut into the pig's foot and found that the graft had grown as if it were a part of the pig foot, with no rejection at all.

The success of the experiment suggested that patients whose joints are worn out because of age might be treated by being implanted with artificial cartilage rather than having artificial replacements.

Creating cartilage for human beings in the laboratory is still some years down the road, but Li believes this day will come, and even more applications for the technology will be discovered over time.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERIOR MINISTRY'S WEB SITE ANSWERS QUERIES ON NEW ID CARDS

TEXT.P: The public can ask questions about the new ID cards to be issued from Dec. 21 this year through Dec. 31, 2006 by logging on to the Ministry of the Interior's Web site, ministry officials said Sunday.

Minister of the Interior Su Jia-chyuan will publicly display the 21 security and anti-forgery measures contained in the new version of the Republic of China ID cards Tuesday at the Panchiao City Household Registration Office in Taipei county, the officials said.
The current version of ID cards have been in use since 1986, and forgery and counterfeiting have increasingly become more frequent, they noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: SECOND KAOHSIUNG CAVE-IN CAUSED BY IDLE SHIELD MACHINE: KRTC

TEXT.P: The second cave-in Saturday on the city's rapid transit construction site in a week was caused by a shield machine sitting idle too long, the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) said Sunday.

The road cave-in, near Hsinhsing Police Station on Chungcheng Road, started out as a 1.5 meter by one meter depression in the road; later it became a seven meter by five meter hole three meters deep. Another MRT site cave-in happened just one week ago.

Soon after the second incident, the KRTC said a shield machine, which is used to bore the passage for the rail line underground, had passed the site two days earlier. When the cave-in occurred, the machine, 20 meters away, was not working.

After further investigation, the KRTC said Sunday that a shield machine, if idle for too long and then abruptly called into duty, cannot precisely calibrate the amount of earth removed and cement applied. As a result, the road support was not firm, causing the accident, the KRTC said.
The machine had not been in use for a month before it was started on Dec. 8, according to the KRTC.
KRTC Chief Executive Officer Fan Chen-po said engineers will use radar to monitor all the sites to be worked on to ensure road safety.
He also used the second incident as an example to refute calls for a suspension of the construction for safety reasons, claiming that long suspension is in fact counterproductive and increases risk.

The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) legislative caucus said there have been nine cave-ins since 2004 along the MRT lines. It called for the suspension of all construction work pending a safety review report, and said that the work should be taken over by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC).
Chou Yung-hui, an MOTC official, said suspending all construction work is not normal and the MOTC is not responsible for taking over the job.

KMT Legislator Huang Chao-shun, chairman of the party's KRTC Scandal Committee, blamed former Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh for urging the KRTC to move fast on the construction work as part of his campaign to win the ruling party's nomination for president in 2008.

Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) Legislator Luo Chih-ming said legal disputes will arise if the MOTC decides to take over the KRTC's construction job. The MRT is being built under the "build, operate and transfer" (BOT) model.
What is more practical is for the MOTC and the Public Construction Commission to organize a special monitoring team to "strictly oversee the construction," he said.

Tseng Tsan-teng, another TSU lawmaker, said building MRT systems is not difficult at all since the technology has been in place for more than 100 years. However, Tseng added: "If accidents like these happen over and over, I don't think that I'd dare to ride on the Kaohsiung MRT, assuming the project can even be completed."
The TSU's legislative caucus called for a quick fix to all technical problems while "the blaming job can wait."
Premier Frank Hsieh, who visited the site Saturday, said the problem was not serious. "Worse things happened with Taipei's MRT project, and so we don't have to worry too much," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD-RENOWNED TENOR PAVAROTTI TO PERFORM IN TAICHUNG

TEXT.P: World-renowned tenor Luciano Pavarotti, scheduled to arrive in Taichung on a chartered jet Sunday night, has chosen Taichung to conclude the Asia leg of his farewell world tour that began early this year.

The 70-year-old opera legend will be greeted by Taichung Mayor Jason Hu and his wife with flowers at Taichung's Chingchuankang Airport. Hu told reporters Sunday that he has prepared a "mysterious gift" that is expected to leave a deep impression in the opera singer's mind about Taichung.

Pavarotti will sing at the Taichung Stadium on Dec. 14 to an audience of more than 20,000 people. Organizers said nearly all the seats have been sold, with all the seats priced at NT$1,000 and lower sold out.

He will begin with three Neapolitan folk songs, followed by opera songs that have made him famous, including Che Gelida Manina (Your Tiny Hand Is Frozen) from Giacomo Puccini's opera La Boheme (The Bohemian), and Recondita Armonia (Strange Harmony) and E lucevan le Stelle (The Stars were Shining), both from Puccini's opera "Tosca."
The Taichung concert will be Pavarotti's only performance in Taiwan and the last one in his Asia tour, which also includes concerts in South Korea and China.
Pavarotti is widely acclaimed as one of three "tenors of the century." He has said he plans to retire next year to teach and spend more time with his family.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN WORKERS RALLY FOR BETTER WORKING CONDITIONSBy Taijing WuCNA Staff Reporter

TEXT.P: Around 500 foreign workers marched in the rain in a rally Sunday in Taipei demanding that the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) give them better working conditions and employment laws.
There are roughly 300,000 foreign migrant workers from Thailand, the Philippines, Indonesia and Vietnam in Taiwan. They are sometimes reported to be victims of poor treatment from their employers.

The rally, staged by the Taiwan International Workers Association (TIWA), marched from the Taipei Main Station to the CLA offices. The TIWA requested the ROC government to abolish the current broker system, allow workers to form unions, cancel the six-year working right limit, ease the procedure for workers in transferring to other employers and establish laws protecting household caregivers. The last is seen as their main request.

Professor Wako Asato, research fellow of the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science (JSPS) specialized in migration said Dec. 11 that foreign laborers working as caregivers will increase in the coming years.
Asato has observed foreign migrant workers' migration in Japan, Taiwan, Hong Kong and Singapore. Asato explained that Taiwan's need for foreign workers has switched from economic to demographic.
"There is a growing need for caregivers in Taiwan because there are more and more old people. More than half of aged people here are taken care of by foreign caretakers," Asato said.
Asato said that in the past, Taiwan needed large numbers of infrastructure construction workers for economic development, thus it imported foreign migrant workers.
"However, the need for foreign workers has changed. They are now more needed in households because one foreign caregiver costs half the price of a Taiwanese one," Asato said.

Asato suggested redefining foreign migrant workers's role in an aging society, since there are so many foreigners working as caregivers, they should be included in some elderly care system which could protect them from possible exploitation.
Long-time workers' right activist, Father Peter O'Neill from Chungli, a city 70 kilometers south of Taipei, said that caregivers are often work intensively, and are deprived of their own life.
"They sometimes only have two days off a month," O'Neill said.
Father O'Neill said that he intended to bring as many as 350 Thai and Filipino workers to the march, but only 200 came in the end because of bad weather.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLITICAL FORCE SHOULD WITHDRAW FROM PROBE INTO KTRC SCANDAL: MA

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Sunday that no political forces should interfere in the investigation into the corruption scandal involving the Kaohsiung rapid transit railway project.

He made the remarks during a visit to the KMT office in Pingtung County when asked to comment on news reports that Vice President Annette Lu plans to organize a civic alliance to supervise the construction process and ensure safety of the Kaohsiung rapid transit railway system, which has seen nine major accidents affecting public safety since the construction began in 2001.

The KMT chairman, who is also Taipei mayor, said that any investigation into irregularities involving the Kaohsiung rapid transit project should be conducted by public prosecutors only, because civic groups simply do not have the necessary power to do the job.
Ma was in Pintung County to attend a reception to thank local voters for their support for KMT candidates in the Dec. 3 elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNDERGROUND TUNNEL FOR TAIPEI MRT NEIHU LINE COMPLETED

TEXT.P: After more than three years of hard work, engineers and workers have succeeded in boring a four-kilometer tunnel under Taipei's Sungshan Airport and a ceremony will be held Monday to mark a big step toward launching train services of the 14.8-kilometer rapid transit line.

The city's Department of Rapid Transit Systems said the shield tunnel, that passes through the airport, the No. 1 national expressway and the Keelung River, has been an enormous challenge because construction could not affect airport operation.

As a result of the extraordinary control of construction quality, it noted, the tunnel caused a mere 0.3-centimeter subsidence for the airport runway. The special explosion-proof structure of the tunnel further ensures airport safety, the department added.

The Neihu Line was approved by the Cabinet on August 7, 1993 as an elevated medium capacity transit system. Starting from the north end of the Mucha line, just north of Chungshan Junior High School Station, the route runs elevated along Fuhsing North Road and turns right at Mintzu East Road heading for the Sungshan Airport. It then goes underground on the southern side of the airport.

When completed, the route will end at the Nangang Software Park. Its total length will be approximately 14.8 kilometers with 12 stations and one maintenance depot. The construction budget is over NT$6.6 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESSMAN HOSPITALIZED IN KINMEN THROUGH MINI THREE LINKS

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese businessman having cardiovascular problems followed the mini three links from China to be hospitalized in a Kinmen hospital Dec. 11.

Chang Teng-ke, a 34 years old Taiwanese businessman based in Hsiamen, a city in China's south eastern coast, reached Kinmen with the help of Hsiamen and Kinmen's Red Cross. He is supposed to come back in Taiwan for further medical treatment after his situation is stabilized.
In order to seek medical treatment in Kinmen after his cardiovascular problem aggravates, Chang sent a facsimile on Nov. 29 to Kinmen's Red Cross to apply for a special paper to go to Kinmen.
Chang was previously hospitalized in Hsiamen's Chung Shan Hospital.

After reception of the facsimile, Kinmen's Red Cross notified Chang's family and contacted the Chung Shan Hospital in Hsiamen. Red Cross volunteers were sent to Hsiamen Dec.1 to pick Chang up, but his critical health situation at that time did not allow him to be removed.
His blood pressure was too high and stayed in Hsiamen. In the morning of Dec. 10, Chang's family members notified Kinmen Red Cross that his situation was stable.
Chang arrived Kinmen in the morning of Dec. 11 accompanied by Red Cross volunteers.

DOC.HEADLINE: 13 PEOPLE CHOSEN TO SERVE ON NATIONAL COMMUNICATIONS COMMISSION

TEXT.P: Thirteen people were chosen Sunday by a panel as would-be members of the National Communications Commission Sunday.

After a three-day public hearing, the 11-member panel tasked with this selection chose by a 60 percent votes Liu You-li, Wu Chung-chi, Liu Chung-teh, Lin Tung-tai, Shih Shih-hao, Su Yung-chin, Lin Yi-ping, Liu Kung-chung and Wong Hsiou-chi.
In a second round of vote, Lu Chung-chin, Lee Tsu-yuan and Chen Ming-hsien was picked out by a simple majority vote.
Hsieh Chin-nan was chosen, also by a simple majority vote, in the third round of vote.
The Executive Yuan, after being informed by the panel of its decision will seek the Legislative Yuan's approval for the appointments of the 13 people.

Among the 13 people, picked out by the panel from 17 candidates, six were recommended by the opposition Kuomintang, two each by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, the opposition People First Party and the Executive Yuan, and one by the Taiwan Solidarity Union.

KMT Legislator Wang Chung-yu who chaired the candidate reviewing panel said after the selection that the 13 people come from fields of communications, law and telecommunication, adding that the panel's decision has already been relayed to the candidates and will be forwarded to the Executive Yuan as soon as possible.
Once being appointed to the commission, they will be in charge of formulating policies concerning the communications and telecommunication during their three-years terms.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN WORKERS MUST FILE TAX RETURN BEFORE LEAVING TAIWAN

TEXT.P: If you are a foreign worker who has stayed in Taiwan for more than 183 days and are planning to leave the country, the law requires that you file a tax return before leaving.
Doing so may be in your own interest, as in the example the National Tax Administration cited Sunday to explain the details about a tax return.
A foreigner was hired to teach English on a two-year contract but decided to leave for another job after staying in Taiwan 190 days from May to November.
Anyone who has stayed in Taiwan for 183 days or more a year is called a "resident" who must pay tax. If his or her spouse stays, she or he has to file their joint tax return in May next year.
Now this gentleman's employer has deducted 10 percent from his monthly salary as pre-paid income tax, totalling NT$19,032.

According to the government rules, an income tax payer enjoys full deductible amount of NT$75,000 for the 2004 income. He is entitled to other deductibles that are calculated by the percentage of 190/365, which amounted to NT$6,1424.

After deducting NT$6,1424 and NT$75,000 from his total income of NT$190,320, his taxable income is NT$53,209. The tax rate for that level of income is 6 percent, so he needs just to pay NT$3,234 in income tax to the Taiwan government.
Since his employer has deducted NT$19,032 from his pay check, he is eligible for a NT$15,798 refund. In this case, then, it pays to file a tax return.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO NAKED FEMALE FOUND DEAD ON RIVER BED IN HUALIEN

TEXT.P: Hualien police found two naked female corpses on a river bed Dec. 11. The police suspects these two cases to be relevant, and were both strangled before towed to the place they were left.

A first corpse was discovered around six in the morning by an old veteran on the river bed, under the Shueiyuan Bridge in Hualien. A second one was discovered by the police around ten o'clock in less than 100 meters from the first corpse. Both were only wearing underpants.

The police suspects that the two female were first strangled to death, then taken to the river bed and left there. No indication shows that they were sexually assaulted. Both corpses are awaiting the forensic doctor's autopsy report.

According to primary investigation, the first female is about 20 years old. She is 163 centimeters tall and skinny. Trauma is seen on her head, and she also has bone fracture. Forensic doctors said that she was thrown down the bridge after being strangled.
The second female is about 30 years old and she is 155 centimeters high. Obvious trauma marks on her head. Both corpses' neck show obvious marks of strangling.
The police said that these two female were not locals.
A police chief surnamed Chuang said that both cases might be relevant because they seem to have died the same way.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP SHOULD DUMP IDEA OF NEW ECONOMIC MEETING AFTER ELECTION LOSS: LEE

TEXT.P: The Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration should scrap the idea of organizing another national economic development conference in light of its poor performance in the Dec. 3 local government elections, former President Lee Teng-hui said Sunday.

In a news conference called by a pro-independence group, the Northern Taiwan Society, Lee asserted that the message sent out by voters in the DPP's drubbing is to stop the wrongfooted policy of engagement with China in economics, and to focus on Taiwan's identity and the strengthening of the country's defenses.

The proposed national economic development conference may provide local businessmen a springboard to pressure the government to further soften its restrictions on economic ties with China. Given that the DPP is still licking its wounds from the defeat and could cave in to this appeal, the party should just deep-six the whole idea of having the conference, Lee maintained.
At the request of local industrial groups, President Chen Shui-bian promised on Nov. 22 to organize such a conference on an as yet unspecified date.
Lee said, the ruling party lost the elections because it deviated from its core principles and not because of other, unrelated issues.

Noting that the DPP campaigned on a promise to rename the country as Taiwan during the 2004 legislative elections, Lee said the ruling party has disappointed its supporters by never trying to fulfill its promise after the elections.

On the contrary, Lee said, the DPP administration contradicted its promise. Citing as evidence, the former president named President Chen Shui-bian's promises of not altering the country's status quo during his 2000 inaugural speech, and Premier Frank Hsieh's acknowledgement that there is only China according to the country's Constitution.
He urged President Chen to stop flip-flopping on policy towards China and win back the people's confidence by placing a premium on Taiwan's interest while laying down any policy.
In the Dec. 3 elections, the DPP has seen the number of counties and cities it controls decreased from 9 before the elections to six.

New York Times: Military's Information War Is Vast and Often Secretive
The media center in Fayetteville, N.C., would be the envy of any global communications company. In state of the art studios, producers prepare the daily mix of music and news for the group's radio stations or spots for friendly teleevision outlets. The center is not part of a news organization, but a military operation, and the writers and producers there are soldiers. The 1,200-strong psychological operations unit based at Fort Bragg turns out what its officers call "truthful messages" to support the United States government's objectives, though its commander acknowledges that those stories are one-sided and their American sponsorship is hidden.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Dec. 13, or the 13th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1784: Samuel Johnson, British writer and lexicographer known as "Dr. Johnson," dies at the age of 75. The leading literary figure in the second half of the 18th century, he wrote the "Dictionary of the English Language" and "Lives of the Poets."
1797: German poet and critic Heinrich Heine is born in Dusseldorf.
1897: Russian forces occupy Port Arthur on the Yellow Sea.
1904: The first electric train comes into service on London's Metropolitan Railway.
1916: Some 9,000 Austro-Hungarian troops are killed in an avalanche in the Alps.
1918: U.S. President Thomas Woodrow Wilson arrives in France, becoming the first American president to visit a European country.
1921: Britain, the United States, France and Japan sign the Washington Treaty, pledging to respect each others' claims over insular possessions in the Pacific.
1937: Japanese troops occupy Nanking. During the following two months, the aggressors rape and kill some 300,000 Chinese and lay waste to the city in what would become known as the "Rape of Nanking."
1944: A Japanese kamikaze pilot crashes his plane into the U.S. cruiser Nashville, killing 133 crew members.
1955: In the U.N Security Council, China vetoes the admission of Outer Mongolia to the United Nations.
1961: Anna Mary Robertson Moses, known as "Grandma Moses," an American painter noted for her colorful primitive-style paintings of rural scenes, dies in New York at the age of 101.
1963: The Junior Chamber of the Republic of China announces the list of winners of the ten "outstanding youth awards."
1968: The Hsin Hsin Bus Co. is established, becoming the first private bus company in Taipei City.
1972: On the last U.S. mission to the moon, Apollo 17 astronauts unveil a plaque on the lunar surface dedicated to peace.
1974: Malta, the former British crown colony which became an independent country in 1964, changes its form of government to that of a republic.
1976: A four-member Chinese judo team leaves Taipei for Spain to participate in the second world youth judo championships.
1978: The first council meeting of the Organization of African Freedom opens in Abidjan, Ivory Coast.
1982: An earthquake devastates Dhamar Province in Yemen, killing 3,000 people and injuring 2,000 others.
1988: South Africa signs an accord in Brazzaville granting independence to Namibia.
1989: The first Vietnamese refugees are repatriated from Hong Kong, escorted to an airplane at dawn by police in riot gear.
1991: A non-aggression agreement aimed at working toward negotiation of a permanent peace treaty is signed by North and South Korea.
1995: Wei Jingsheng, noted Chinese democracy advocate and a 1995 Nobel Peace Prize nominee, is imprisoned for 14 years for subversive acts.
1996: Ministers and officials from 128 countries, including those from the ROC, adopt a wide-ranging declaration at the end of the five-day World Trade Organization meeting in Singapore.
1999: President Lee Teng-hui reiterates that the "special state-to-state relationship" theory is the Republic of China's basic stance on relations with mainland China.
2000: The Executive Yuan approves a draft of rules governing the implementation of trial transport links scheduled to be established between Taiwan's outlying Kinmen and Matsu islands and mainland China beginning Jan. 1, 2001.
2001: Semiconductor designers from Taiwan meet in Beijing with mainland Chinese high-technology representatives to sound out the possibility of technological cooperation across the Taiwan Strait.
2001: Visiting Sao Tome and Principe President Fradique Banderira Melo de Menezes visits Taichung Port.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If in governing you depend upon laws and maintain order by enforcing those laws by punishments, you can also make the people keep away from wrongdoing, but they will lose the sense of shame for wrongdoing. If, on the other hand, in government you depend upon moral sentiment and maintain order by encouraging education and good manners, the people will have a sense of shame for wrongdoing and, moreover, will emulate what is good."

DOC.HEADLINE: KRTC IGNORED SAFETY ALERTS: PFP LAWMAKERKRTC IGNORES SAFETY ALERTS: LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: The series of cave-ins at Kaohsiung's rapid transit construction sites were partly the result of the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) ignoring its own professional report alerting it to quite a number of missteps, an opposition lawmaker claimed Tuesday.

Chiu Yi, an independent legislator elected in Kaohsiung, quoted a Taiwan Construction Research Institute (TCRI) report, which was completed in May, as saying that underground hydraulic data was not taken into account by designers of the MRT routes and that the quality of construction work was questionable.

The report, which was commissioned by the KRTC, further pointed out that the KRTC had not made a good evaluation of subsidence incidents, had not monitored well the work done by shield machines, and had not been able to prevent water leakage in underground connecting routes.
All these "defective" construction records seem to have originated from a poor building plan and the lack of a geological improvement plan, according to the TCRI report.

The TCRI is a non-profit organization that aims to promote advanced construction ideas and technology and to improve construction standards in Taiwan. It also plays a key coordination role between foreign and local construction agencies.

Chiu said the report had recommended forming an ad hoc group of experts to monitor the whole process of building the Kaohsiung MRT system but the ruling Democratic Progressive party (DPP) opposed the idea.

He said the KRTC has ignored the TCRI's safety alerts and refused to suspend construction work for a comprehensive safety check-up, eventually leading to a series of site cave-ins. Two such incidents occurred within the last week.

DOC.HEADLINE: KEYSER'S GUILTY PLEA WON'T AFFECT TAIWAN-U.S. RELATIONS: REP OFFICE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 12 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin, Jorge Liu and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Representative Office in the United States refused Monday to comment on a case related to the guilty plea made in U.S. federal court by a former ranking U.S. official, stressing that the island's relations with the United States will not be affected by the case.
The office made the remarks after learning that Donald W. Keyser, former U.S. deputy assistant secretary of state, had entered a guilty plea in federal court in Alexandria, Virginia.

Keyser, who was arrested last year by U.S. justice authorities, admitted in court to deliberately concealing from his superiors that he had taken a trip to Taiwan last September and that he had maintained an intimate personal relationship with a female Taiwanese intelligence officer. The former official also admitted that he had taken confidential State Department documents without authorization.
The court document did not mention whether Keyser had passed on classified files to Taiwan.

Even though Stanley Kao, Taiwan's deputy representative to the United States, refused to comment on the Keyser's case, a spokesman of Taiwan's representative office said that relations between the island and the United States will continue to be promoted through the current channels and will not be affected by the case.
David Lee, Taiwan's representative to the United States, is currently in Taiwan to report in person his official duties.

Meanwhile, a high-ranking official of the office who wished to remain anonymous said that he was shocked by Keyser's sudden guilty plea as the former U.S. official had consistently maintained his innocence.

Nevertheless, the Taiwan official said that Keyser's personal relationship with the intelligence officer had nothing to do with their work and did not compromise Taiwan or the United States in any way, adding that Taiwan's National Security Bureau has never requested that its staff do anything in an inappropriate way.

He also said that Taiwan should work to further strengthen its communications with the United States instead of trying to obtain intelligence information from the country, pointing out that the United States is a close ally and that nothing should be done in a surreptitious manner.
Keyser faces a possible prison sentence of up to 13 years and a maximum fine of US$500,000. The federal court is set to issue its ruling on the case Feb. 24.
In the meantime, State Department Adam Ereli said, the department does not want to comment on the case.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUPPORT GROWING FOR ANTI-WTO HUNGER-STRIKING 'RICE-BOMBER'

TEXT.P: A coalition of social and academic groups announced Tuesday they will launch a "save Taiwan's agriculture" campaign in Taipei Dec. 16-17 in support of "rice-bomber" Yang Ju-men who began a six-day hunger strike earlier in the day in a detention center in connection with a World Trade Organization (WTO) meeting in Hong Kong.

Meanwhile, according to the China Times, a major daily in Taiwan, leaders of more than 70 civic and labor groups in Taiwan have arrived in Hong Kong to join a protest by pro-farmer and other groups from around the world to be held at the site of the annual WTO ministers meeting.

Yang's hunger-strike statement, read by professor Fang Sheng-ping of National Tsinghua University, said Yang was staging a 144-hour hunger strike to show his concerns about the state of uncertainty that Taiwan's agriculture sector is facing.
Yang said in the statement that he hopes the WTO ministers meeting will do something to improve farmers' fortunes.

Yang Tzu-chun, an assistant professor at Chinese Culture University and spokeswoman for the support-Yang Ju-men coalition, said the "rice-bomber" was engaging in the hunger strike to protest "the WTO's exploitation of the disadvantaged."
Yang said she is worried that the detention center authorities will force-feed the hunger striker and prevent people from visiting him.
At the Taipei Detention Center, officials have alerted doctors to give Yang "necessary nutrition" and take "necessary steps" to save his life.
Meanwhile, Peng Ming-hui, another Tsinghua University professor, read the three appeals of the coalition:
--The government should help farmers use non-toxic pesticides, fertilizers and technology in farming;
--Stop imports of sub-quality farm products in order to protect Taiwan farmers and consumers;
--Abolish the exploitation mechanism working at the upstream and downstream areas of agricultural production so as to reinvigorate Taiwan's farming industry.

At the coalition's press conference, quite a number of university students wore masks of Yang Ju-men, who is appealing his seven-year sentence, chanting slogans in support of him and of saving Taiwan's agriculture.

Yang was sentenced in the first trial on charges of threatening public security for placing bombs at several public locations. Yang had said he did so in order to raise public awareness of the plight of Taiwan's farmers.
The students pledged to "become more Yang Ju-mens in fighting for the younger generation and for farmers" if the government does not respond quickly to their demands.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER EDUCATION MINISTER RELEASED FROM HOSPITAL

TEXT.P: Former Minister of Education Wu Ching was given a warm farewell party Tuesday at National Cheng Kung University Hospital in Tainan City, southern Taiwan to celebrate his release from hospital after undergoing a successful operation to remove a malignant tumor.
Wu, 70, was admitted to hospital about a month earlier after doctors discovered the tumor in his belly. He was diagnosed as having ampullar cancer. Wu's illness was kept from the public.

The deputy superintendent of Cheng Kung University Hospital, Lin Ping-wen, said Wu has been recovering well since the operation, but he also urged the National Cheng Kung University professor to avoid any heavy physical activity.
Prior to the discovery of the tumor, Wu had been scheduled to head to the United States for a speech tour.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high but closed lower Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 5.11 points to close at 6,261.18.
The bourse opened at 6,270.24 and fluctuated between 6,242.41 and 6,282.23 during trading. A total of 3.44 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$90.28 billion (US$2.7 billion).
Only one of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues moving up at 0.8 percent.

Five of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down the most at 1.1 percent, followed by cement stocks at 0.8 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares, paper and pulp issues and banking and financial shares all at 0.1 percent.
Textile stocks and machinery and electronics shares remained unchanged.
Losers outnumbered gainers 543 to 438, with 226 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: NAT'L APPLIED RESEARCH LAB HEAD CHOSEN AS NEW NCU PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: National Applied Research Laboratories head Lee Lou-chuang has been selected by the Ministry of Education to be the new president of the Taoyuan-based National Central University (NCU), a NCU news release said Tuesday.
The current NCU president, Liu Chuan-sheng, is scheduled to step down from his post in February.
Lee recently received the 2005 Presidential Science Prize, Taiwan's highest honor for academic research, for his prominent achievements in the field of space science research.
Lee will be the sixth president of NCU since it opened in Taoyuan in 1962. The university was originally founded in Nanjing, Jiangsu Province in China in 1915.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Schwarzenegger Declines to Halt Execution of Gang Founder.
Stanley "Tookie" Williams, a gang leader- turned-peace advocate whose cause drew worldwide attention, was set to be executed in San Quentin's death chamber Tuesday morning after Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger denied his last-ditch plea for clemency and the Supreme Court refused to block the execution.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Opposition Union scores another triumph by winning Messina mayor eletion.
Opposition Union candidate Francantonio Genovese won the Messina mayor election Monday by obtaining 54.56 percent of votes in the second-round vote, scoring another victory for the union in local elections prior to the next year's general elections. Genovese defeated his rival from the ruling coalition Luigi Ragno who won 45.44 percent of ballots. After being informed of the triumph, Opposition Union leader Romano Prodi said that "Our spring comes near."

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW LAW ALLOWS FOREIGNERS TO SERVE AS UNIVERSITY HEADS

TEXT.P: The University Law passed third reading in the legislature Tuesday, paving the way for Taiwan's universities to hire qualified foreigners as university presidents, deans and department heads.
The amended law will also allow students to take part in administrative meetings of their universities in order to enhance their educational efficiency.
The amendment was drafted by the Ministry of Education with the view to helping Taiwan's universities to become more competitive in the international arena.
During the past decades, the Republic of China Employment Service Act and the Nationality Law have made it impossible for foreigners to serve as university presidents, deans or department heads.

The amended University Law now stipulates clearly that individual universities may hire qualified foreign academics to fill these important posts through the recommendations of their own screening committees.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CAUCUS TO SET UP PANEL TO REVIEW ELECTIONS SETBACK

TEXT.P: A high-ranking official of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Tuesday that the party's legislative caucus will set up a panel to review the party's failure in last Saturday's city and county chief elections in order to win back the support of the public.

William Lai, a DPP caucus whip in legislature, made the remarks in the wake of the party's setback in last week's elections in which it only garnered six of the 23 city mayor and county magistrate posts up for grabs. The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) won 14 of the posts.
Those present at the caucus's meeting held at the Legislative Yuan included Interior Minister Shih Mao-lin and Investigation Bureau Director Yiia Shan-mao.
Lai said after the meeting that he was glad to see that members of the caucus were demonstrating the spirit of democracy by presenting both criticisms and suggestions regarding the elections.

Noting that democracy, reform, and integrity have been the DPP's core values since its founding, Lai stressed that the party will keep walking along this path, adding that future policies for the country will also be discussed by the panel.

Chao Yung-ching, another DPP whip in the legislature, while hailing law enforcement authorities for their efforts in cracking down on vote-buying and maintaining social order during the campaign period for the elections, expressed the hope that the police and investigation authorities can play a more active role in future elections.
According to Chao, the DPP caucus will put a premium on the intra-ministerial investigations into vote-buying and make the issue "a movement of all the people."

DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLIC REMINDED TO CHECK FOR SAFETY STICKERS ON ELECTRIC PRODUCTS

TEXT.P: The Consumer Protection Commission (CPC) issued a warning Tuesday for people to be wary of products sold without safety inspection stickers after a Taipei City resident was recently injured while using a heating devise he purchased at a night market.

The victim, surnamed Lee, said he bought the warmer for NT$150 at a night market last year. The unit plugs in and warms a small packet of water. Although there was no safety sticker on the warmer and he was not given a receipt and, therefore, could not seek compensation from the manufacturer, he still felt that the case should serve as a warning to others.

Since Nov. 1, all kinds of electric warming equipment, including electric blankets and personal warmers, have to undergo mandatory inspection by the Bureau of Standards, Metrology and Inspection before being placed on the market, CPC officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, dropping NT$0.056 to close at NT$33.498.
A total of US$731 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$33.554 and hit a low of NT$33.455.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for December moved down 32 points to close at 6,241, with 21,926 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for January moved down 26 points to end at 6,250, with 1,128 contracts traded, while March futures lost 28 points to finish at 6,242, with 10 contracts traded. June futures moved down 37 points to close at 6,233, with 12 contracts traded, while September futures moved down 18 points to close at 6,119, with seven contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 6,273 for December, 6,276 for January, 6,270 for March, 6,270 for June and 6,137 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly lower.
December TE futures moved down 0.9 points to close at 273.5, with 5,369 contracts traded, while January TE futures lost 0.7 points to finish at 273.2, with 247 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.

December TF futures lost 1.2 points to finish at 884, with 1,494 contracts changing hands, while January TF futures moved down one points to end at 884, with 138 contracts traded. March TF futures moved down 0.8 points to close at 886, with one contract transaction, while September TF futures gained 0.6 points to finish at 875.8, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for June.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALLOWANCE FOR ELDERLY FARMERS TO BE HIKED TO NT$5,000 PER MONTH

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan passed a revised statute Tuesday to raise the monthly allowance for elderly farmers to T$5,000 (US$149.25) from the present NT$4,000 starting Jan. 1, 2006.
The move to hike the monthly allowance for elderly farmers by NT$1,000 has been stalled in the legislature for some time because of financing problems.

Legislative speaker Wang Jin-pyng invited legislators from across the political spectrum for consultations Tuesday and the revised bill was able to clear the legislature after lawmakers reached a consensus that the central government would shoulder the additional cost of NT$1,000 for each farmer in 2006.

The legislators also agreed that after 2006, the central government and the municipalities will each shoulder half of the costs of the monthly allowance for elderly farmers, while the budgets for elderly farmers in each city and county will be entirely shouldered by the central government.

The legislators also passed a resolution requesting that the government establish a farmers' pension system to take care of elderly farmers in the same fashion as the pension program for retired military personnel, civil servants and teachers, as well as laborers.

The Council of Agriculture said that the number of elderly farmers eligible for the monthly allowance is around 700,000 this year, and the money distributed as of Nov. 30 has hit NT$30.43 billion (US$908.45 million).

The government estimates that there will be 10,000 additional seniors on the roll next year and it has already appropriated a budget of around NT$34.2 billion for the monthly allowance payments. After the hike, the payments will be increased to around NT$42.8 billion, or an additional NT$8.6 billion, which will be entirely financed by the central government.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOI TO RENEW ID CARDS FOR 19 MILLION CITIZENS STARTING DEC. 21

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior will issue new forgery-proof identification cards to approximately 19 million citizens from Dec. 21 until Dec. 31, 2006, ministry officials said Tuesday.
The officials urged the public to renew their ID cards according to the time and venue given them by local household registration offices to shorten their waiting time.

Similar to credit cards in size, the new ID cards will have 21 forgery-proof features, they said. For example, the shape of Jade Mountain and Taiwan as well as the MOI emblem are imbedded images on the card, while a butterfly pattern can be seen by slanting the ID cards.

The name column of the new identification cards will have enough room for up to 15 Chinese characters or 20 Roman letters, which will make it easier for aboriginal people to use their traditional names on their new ID cards, they said.

To make it convenient for the public to renew their ID cards, local household registration staff will collect the photos and deliver the ID cards for disabled people who cannot apply for their new ID cards in person, they said.
Meanwhile, photo-taking services will be provided free of charge to citizens from low or medium-low income families, they added.
According to Interior Minister Su Jia-chyuan, the government has before this renewed ID cards in 1947, 1954, 1966, 1976 and 1986.

The MOI had initially planned to renew the ID cards starting July 1 this year and to require fingerprinting from all applicants, but the plan was postponed until December after some ruling Democratic Progressive Party legislators requested a constitutional interpretation by the Council of Grand Justices over the controversial policy, Su pointed out.
The Council of Grand Justices ruled on Sept. 28 that the fingerprinting policy was unconstitutional, prompting the MOI to drop it.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLARS FROM CHINA, TAIWAN TO DISCUSS FUTURE OF CHINESE CHARACTERS

TEXT.P: Scholars from China and Taiwan will gather in Taipei next April to discuss ways to promote "exchanges" of the simplified and traditional Chinese characters that are used on each side of the Taiwan Strait.

Liao Hsien-hao, director of the city's Department of Cultural Affairs, said Tuesday that some Chinese scholars are calling for "restoring" the use of traditional Chinese characters in China since the historical backgrounds have changed for adopting the simplified characters.

In the face of rapid changes in information technology, he said, both sides of the Strait should take a practical and scientific attitude toward Chinese characters, a key component of Chinese culture.
During the upcoming "Chinese Character Cultural Festival, " he noted, academics will discuss the issue from the perspectives of information dissemination, language teaching and cultural inheritance.
Some attention will be focused on problems with teaching the Chinese characters and difficulties in learning the traditional or simplified Chinese characters, Liao added.

As Taiwan and China develop their own information platforms, efforts could be made to facilitate reading of both styles of Chinese characters by, for example, developing software that can easily "switch" between the two, which would be a big breakthrough in cross-strait cultural exchanges, department officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER SAYS MA-SOONG MEETING WAS PRODUCTIVE

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng Tuesday lauded the historic meeting between the leaders of Taiwan's two largest opposition parties, saying that their pledge to continue cooperating will ensure a majority for the "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) in the legislature.

KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and PFP Chairman James Soong had a four-hour meeting behind closed doors Monday night to discuss a possible merger of the two parties. They told news media after the meeting that the KMT and the PFP will strengthen their cooperation in the run-up to an eventual merger, possibly in 2007.

Asked whether the meeting failed to achieve its intended purpose, Wang said that he felt it was a very good thing for the two parties to step up cooperation because this would ensure that the "pan-blue alliance" will continue to enjoy a majority in the legislature.
Wang, however, declined to comment on a timetable for the KMT-PFP merger, saying that he was not in a position to offer an opinion.

According to the secretaries-general of the KMT and the PFP, who briefed the media Monday night, there are legal problems that need to be sorted out before the merger. They said that one of the conclusions reached at the meeting was that Ma and Soong pledged to maintain the "pan-blue alliance's" majority in the legislature before the final merger.

The merger issue was brought forth again by some PFP legislators after the Dec. 3 local government elections, in which PFP candidates saw an increasing trend of their party being marginalized in Taiwan's politics.
The PFP was founded by Soong in 2000 after he -- a member of the KMT at the time -- ran as an independent in the presidential election that year but failed.

Although the KMT and the PFP have worked closely, as they are both against Taiwan independence and favor Taiwan's eventual unification with China, their relationship has sometimes become strained, especially in election years, because they have to compete for support from the same voter pool.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-U.S. TIES WON'T BE AFFECTED SERIOUSLY BY KEYSER CASE: DIPLOMAT

TEXT.P: An ROC diplomat admitted on Wednesday that the case concerning a former ranking U.S. official, who admitted Tuesday in court his guilt on three charges in connection with Taiwan's intelligence personnel, affects Taiwan-U.S. relations, but the damage is under control.
David Lee, Taiwan's representative to the U.S., made the remarks at the Legislative Yuan. He returned to Taipei from Washington, D.C. to give a report.
Lee said that he believes Donald W. Keyser, former U.S. deputy assistant secretary of state in charge of East Asian affairs, entered a guilty plea in exchange for a reduction in sentencing.
His lawyer must have negotiated with the court, since the U.S. government would not want details of the case to become public to protect state secrets, Lee said.

Keyser, who was arrested last year by U.S. justice authorities, admitted in federal court in Alexandria, Virginia, to deliberately concealing from his superiors that he had taken a trip to Taiwan last September, and that he had maintained an "undisclosed personnel relationship" with a female Taiwanese intelligence officer since September 2002.
The former official also admitted that he had taken confidential documents away from the State Department without authorization. He confessed that his actions had made him vulnerable.
Keyser, 62, was arrested Sept. 15, 2004 as he was delivering documents to two officials of Taiwan's National Security Bureau at a riverbank restaurant in a suburban of Washington, D.C.

Lee said that he had contacted the U.S. State Department many times since Keyser was arrested to declare that the last thing the Republic of China government would do was to illegally collect intelligence on U.S soil.
"So far, the communication channel [between the U.S. and Taiwan] is still open," he noted.
Keyser faces a possible prison sentence of up to 13 years and a maximum fine of US$500,000. The federal court is set to issue its ruling on the case Feb. 24.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOTC REVISING LAW TO ALLOW PRIVATE SECTOR TO RUN AIRPORTS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) is currently revising a law to allow the private sector to run airports, an MOTC official said Tuesday.

Billy K.C. Chang, director-general of the ministry's Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) , noted that some have suggested privatizing airports, as only government agencies or local governments are allowed to run airports under current civil aviation law.
Under a planned revised law, the private sector, including foreign investors, will be allowed to operate airports, Chang said.
He stressed that the revision of the law still must be approved by the Legislative and Executive Yuans.
The CAA estimated that there are currently 18 air terminals in Taiwan, and among them, only CKS International Airport makes money and the others are losing money.

If the private sector is allowed to run CKS International Airport, the CAA estimated that its yearly revenues should reach at least NT$12 billion (US$358.2 million). Among them, NT$6 billion will be given to the CAA to finance the expenses of related agencies. 334433lian Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: JAN.-OCT. TRADE DEFICIT IN FARM PRODUCTS RISES TO US$4.93 BILLION

TEXT.P: The trade in agricultural products saw a deficit of US$4.93 billion in the first 10 months of this year, compared with US$4.47 billion in the same period last year, according to tallies released Tuesday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics.
The trade volume in agricultural products amounted to US$10.73 billion from January to October, up 3.5 percent from the same time last year.
While exports declined 1.6 percent year-on-year to US$2.9 billion, imports increased 5.6 percent year-on-year to US$7.83 billion.
The majority of the exports were aquacultural products and livestock, which amounted to US$2.18 billion and accounted for 75 percent of all exports.
The majority of the imports were crops, which amounted to US$4.64 billion, followed by livestock, which amounted to US$1.61 billion. These two items together accounted for 80 percent of all imports.

The main export destinations of Taiwan's agricultural products are Japan and the United States, but exports to these two countries slid 10.9 percent in the first 10 months of this year compared with the same time last year.

The main import origins are the United States, Australia and Japan, and imports from these three countries increased 8 percent, 13.8 percent and 18.5 percent year-on-year, respectively, in the first 10 months of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESOLUTION PASSED TO CLAMP DOWN ON ILLEGAL FISHING PRACTICES

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan adopted a resolution Tuesday demanding that prosecution and investigation authorities look into the matter of local tuna fishing ships' use of flags of convenience in order to clear Taiwan's name after the country was accused of overfishing and poaching by the international community.

The resolution calls for the authorities to comprehensively investigate all the local fishing boats flying a flag of a third country that have allegedly overfished on the high seas or intentionally under reported their catch.
Ships found to have engaged in such illegal practices must be punished in accordance with the law, including revocation of their fishing licenses, lawmakers said in the resolution.
The resolution was passed at a time when the Western and Central Pacific Fisheries Commission (WCPFC), of which Taiwan is a member, is holding its annual meeting in Micronesia Dec. 12-16.

The WCPFC conference is the second such international fisheries meeting in a month. The International Commission of the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna (ICCAT) held a meeting on Nov. 20 during which it decided to cut Taiwan's annual bigeye tuna catch quota in the Atlantic, from 149,000 metric tons to 4,600 metric tons for 2006, following complaints by Japan about Taiwan's overfishing.
Many in Taiwan's deep-sea fishing sector fear that further punishments may be meted out against the country at the ongoing WCPFC meeting.

The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) introduced the resolution in order to display Taiwan's determination to wipe out illegal fishing practices by local boats in international waters.

The resolution, which calls for a strict crack down on "illegal, unreported and unregulated (IUU) " fishing practices, also urges the government to ensure that the domestic deep-sea fishing industry to abide by the ICCAT decision on reducing Taiwan's bigeye tuna fishing fleet in the Atlantic.
Earnings from illegitimate practices by local fishing boats in international waters must be dealt with in line with international norms, the resolution further urges.

Fisheries Administration officials commented later the same day that what the legislative resolution has pointed out is correct and that the administration has been working on a draft aimed at regulating Taiwan fishing boats' practices on the high seas. Violators could be sentenced to jail terms from three to seven years.
The resolution would compel the government to step up its pace in dealing with the IUU fishing vessels, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CHAIRMAN HEADS FOR PEACE FORUM IN KUALA LUMPUR

TEXT.P: People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong will depart for Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia Wednesday to attend the two-day Perdanam Global Peace Forum to be presided over by former Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad.
Soong is expected to give a speech at the forum slated for Dec. 15-17, in which former heads of state from Australia, Cambodia and Timor will also take part.

Soong said a day earlier that he hopes to use the occasion to speak for Taiwan's participation in a proposed free trade zone to be formed by member states of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) plus China, Japan and South Korea.

The public is hoping for better trade and economic ties between Taiwan and China and the opening of direct air and shipping links across the Taiwan Strait, Soong said Thursday night following a meeting with main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou for talks on a planned merger between the two parties in the "pan-blue alliance."
The PFP and the KMT have been driven by mounting calls to merge after the PFP performed poorly in the Dec. 3 local government elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CARRIERS MAY STOP OVER IN UNITED ARAB EMIRATES: MOFA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's two largest air carriers -- China Airlines and EVA Airways -- have agreed in principle to a government proposal to fly over the United Arab Emirates (UAE) during their passenger flights to Europe, a government official said Tuesday.
Tseng Ching-yuan, director-general of the West Asian Affairs Department under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) , made the remarks during a regular news briefing.

Saying that CAL and EVA Air are willing to work within the government policy to open a representative office in that Middle East county by making a stopover in Abu Dhabi or Dubai during their Europe-bound passenger flights, Tseng noted that the two aviation companies already ply cargo flights to the country.

But Tseng was reserved about when the two Taiwan airlines would begin to stop over in the UAE on their west-bound passenger flights, only explaining that the airlines and the Civil Aeronautics Administration are talking over the issue with the UAE authorities.

Key points to be considered by the two Taiwan carriers include passenger loads and fuel prices, he said, noting that the issue regarding opening a Taiwan representative office in UAE remains under negotiations between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: HSINCHU SCIENCE PARK ADMINISTRATION TO HOLD HI-TECH FORUM
DOC.DATELINE: Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, Dec. 13 (CNA) (By Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: The Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park Administration will hold a forum about the development of the country's high technology Dec. 15-16 at the Ambassador Hotel in Hsinchu.
The forum forms part of the activities to mark the 25th anniversary of the park, the "Silicon Valley of Taiwan."

James Lee, director of the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park Administration, will preside over the opening ceremony on Dec. 15, while Morris Chang, founding chairman of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co., Ltd, and Luis Sanz, secretary-general of International Association of Science Parks (IASP) will be invited to deliver keynote speeches at the ceremony.

Two discussions will be held later that day, with the first regarding the contributions of Taiwan's IC industry to the world and the industry's prospect in the future, in which Tsai Ming Kai, chairman of MediaTek, Inc. and several internationally well-known experts will give speeches.

In the second discussion that day, executives from Taiwan's AU Optronics Corp., the third-largest manufacturer of large-size TFT-LCD panels in the world, and American computer giant Dell will exchange views about the future of Taiwan's flat panel industry.

On Dec. 16, Johnsee Lee, president of Taiwan's Industrial Technology Research Institute, and executives of industrial parks from countries including the United States, Spain and Japan will discuss the influence of science parks on the regional economic development.

In another discussion, Lee and several executives of industrial parks in Sweden, France and South Korea will figure out ways to strengthen international cooperation between science parks around the world.

The Hsinchu Science Park Administration will exhibit innovative products from 30 companies with operations in the park during the forum, and will bestow prizes on Dec. 15 to those outstanding enterprises dedicated to research and development, as well as those that have done well in public safety.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AND CHINA URGED TO INCREASE INTERDEPENDENCE IN TRADE, ECONOMY

TEXT.P: Taiwan and China should strive toward increasing mutual dependency in trade and economy while Taiwan adopts a more open attitude to China, aiming at creating better economic benefit, scholars suggested Tuesday.

The Asia Foundation in Taiwan (AFIT) and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) organized the 2005 International Forum on Prospects in Asia that was held Dec. 13. The forum initiated discussions by scholars coming from the United States, Japan, Indonesia, Hong Kong, South Korea, Singapore and Macau. Talks were about "The Rise of China and the Future of the Asia-Pacific Region."

Professor Ishihara Kyoichi of the Graduate School of Humanities and Social Sciences from Japan's Kobe University said that China has a great influence on Japan regarding economy and trade despite the tense diplomatic relations they currently have.

"Chinese products flow into Japan and cause our small and medium enterprises to go bankrupt and the unemployment rate to rise. But this doesn't interfere in the economic and trade relation between the two countries. Both will strive to deepen cooperation in terms of exchanges on technology and industry in the future, " Ishihara said.

Commenting on coping with China's threat caused by its growing economy, military and political power, Ishihara said, "We have to excel in the high-tech domain and develop each of our small and medium enterprises' characteristics. Each enterprise or industry should have its own specialty."
Ishihara said that with the specialty that each enterprise owns, more economical benefits can be created when conducting exchanges with China.
"Mutual dependency on trade and economy with China is important for both Taiwan and Japan," he added.

"Taiwan should make efforts to change China by increasing exchanges with it in all aspects. China is already following the steps toward a free market, but it is still not democratized. Countries around it such as Taiwan might propose that it should adopt a democratic system as well," Ishihara said.
Ishihara said that in the distant future, the Taiwan-China relationship could become "two countries, one system," then transform to "one country, one system."

Shafiah Fifi Muhibat, a researcher at the Centre for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS) in Jakarta said that the countries of the Association of South East Asian Countries (ASEAN) cope with China's growing power by moving as a group to gather more bargaining power.
ASEAN now counts 10 countries: Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, Cambodia, Laos, Myanmar, Vietnam and Thailand.

"ASEAN does not only see China as a threat. It tries to include it in their framework and they cooperate in terms of economy and security. China is especially interested in security cooperation under the ASEAN Regional Forum (ARF) , and it is aware that ASEAN takes the driver's seat in that domain," Muhibat said.
The ASEAN Regional Forum (ARF) is the principal forum for dialogue regarding security issues in Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA IS LAND OF OPPORTUNITY AND RISKS: MAC

TEXT.P: Investment in China carries both risk and opportunity, Joseph Wu, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council, said Tuesday while promoting a new book on the subject.

The MAC commissioned eight scholars to co-author the new book, which assess the risks in China from the aspects of social stability, business investment, tourism, overseas studies as well as the living environment. The 197-page book is a compilation of 44 articles.

Wu said that as MAC chairman he has the responsibility to remind the public of the inherent social risks in the mainland amid close cross-strait trade exchanges. Taiwan's businessmen have invested billions of dollars in the mainland.
"I'm not deliberately speaking ill of China, " Wu said, adding that the inherent risks in China "have become so big that they are not to be overlooked."
Wu cited the recent shooting of villagers of Dongzhou, Shanwei City in southern Guangdong province by Chinese security forces. The people were protesting construction of a local wind power plant.

A series of local clashes with the authorities in China have highlighted the problems within China, saying that China needs to establish a political system that will make the government accountable to its people, Wu said.
"We have reason to believe that the clashes in Dongzhou were the result of political strife within the Chinese leadership, resulting in a loss of control at the local level," he said.

He cited the statistics revealed in international meetings as saying that similar clashes in China totaled more than 74,000 last year, and a large number of them have had to do with farmland, highlighting the problems within China's system.

Wu also pointed to the recent benzene spill in the Sunghua River in northeastern China, the growing number of AIDS patients as well as the existence of avian flu outbreaks in China to highlight the risks there.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Stanley Tookie Williams, Crips Gang Co-Founder, Is Executed
Convicted killer Stanley Tookie Williams, the Crips gang co-founder whose case stirred a national debate about capital punishment versus the possibility of redemption, was executed Tuesday morning at the San Quentin State Prison. in California. Williams, 51, died at 12: 35 a.m. after receiving a lethal injection, officials said. The case became the state's highest-profile execution in decades. Hollywood stars and capital punishment foes argued that Williams' sentence should be commuted to life in prison because he had made amends by writing children's books about the dangers of gangs and violence.
Wall Street Journal: Global Standoff In Trade Talks, Western Farmers Hold Their Ground
As trade ministers from the 149-member World Trade Organization meet this week in Hong Kong, the bargain is running into resistance from western farmers as well as multinationals - from banks to auto makers. So far, Western farmers are prevailing over the corporate behemoths, even though agriculture accounts for a tiny fraction of economic output in developed economies. The pain for agriculture from any deal would be far more concentrated than the gain for service and manufacturing companies. Farmers, with their very livelihoods at stake, have been far more aggressive and effective in moving to thwart the trade round than the multinationals have been lobbying to advance it.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WATER SUPPLY EXPECTED TO REMAIN STABLE IN FIRST HALF OF 2006

TEXT.P: Water supply is expected to remain stable in the first half of 2006 in Taiwan, in light of the satisfactory water reserves at local reservoirs and water flow in rivers islandwide, Water Resources Agency (WRA) officials forecast on Tuesday.

In the northern region, water supply in the Taipei area will be sufficient, with the reserves at the Feitsui Reservoir currently amounting to 87.47 percent and water flow in the Keelung River maintaining normal levels, the officials said.

The reserves at Shihmen Reservoir, which mainly supplies water to the Taoyuan area, is at 83.83 percent, they said, adding that they expect no water shortages in the spring next year but fear shortages might occur if rainfall fails to appear after March.
Water supply in the Hsinchu area will also be sufficient, as the water flow in the Touchien River is normal and the reserves at the Paoshan Reservoir are at 95.48 percent, they said.
In the central region, the reserves at the Yungheshan, Liyutan, Tehchi, Wushe, Sun Moon Lake Reservoirs are all at more than 70 percent, the officials said.

In the southern region, the reserves at the the Lantan and Jenyi Reservoirs together are at 80 percent; that of the Nanhua Reservoir is at 80 percent; and the reserves at Tsengwen and Wushantou Reservoirs are also at 70 percent, they said.

On outlying islands, there will be no water shortages in Kinmen in the first half of next year, while water supply is a little tight on Penghu, the officials said. However, they said water will be sufficient before March in Penghu and that water treatment at Penghu's desalination plant will be increased in case of a water shortage.
While first-stage water restriction measures have been imposed in Matsu, the WRA will transport water there from Taiwan proper if reserves at local reservoirs drop below 80,000 tons, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FEE TO BE LEVIED ON HOT SPRINGS SUPPLIERS STARTING IN 2006

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs will levy a supply fee on hot springs water suppliers starting Jan. 1, officials said Tuesday.
The supply fee will be NT$9 per ton, but it will be halved to NT$4.5 during the first two years of the policy's implementation, the officials said.

The Water Resources Agency currently only has the records of 245 suppliers, with more than 50 percent of the suppliers who actually make a profit by selling the natural resource to hot springs bathhouse operators yet to be identified, they said. They estimated that the government will be able to collect NT$50 million to NT$60 million in supply fees next year.

Also starting Jan. 1, the ministry will levy a water resources preservation fee of approximately NT$0.5 per cubic meter on water companies, which will be used to maintain 107 restricted water reserve areas islandwide, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAN ARRESTED IN MURDER OF 2 GIRLS IN HUALIEN

TEXT.P: Hualien police have arrested one man accused of murdering a teenaged girl while three of his friends allegedly strangled the girl's friend as she was made to watch her friend's death in an apparent act by a spurred lover.
Police said Tuesday that the three men are still at large.

The bodies of the two girls, aged 13 and 15, were found in a riverbed near the Shueiyuan Bridge in Hualien on Dec. 11 wearing only their underwear. Police originally suspected that one or both of them might have been sexually assaulted, but subsequent investigations discounted this theory.
Police confirmed that the 13-year-old victim, surnamed Lee, was strangled to death as she was made to watch her friend, surnamed Chen, who was hit with a rock wrapped in cloth and then strangled.

According to police, the suspect, surnamed Kuo, 21, was Chen's former boyfriend. Kuo, who confessed to the murder, plotted to kill Chen after her parents strongly opposed their relationship and had him brought up on charges of statutory rape. While the civil side of the case was settled out of court by having Kuo pay NT$100,000 in compensation, the criminal verdict was pending in court.
On Dec. 11, Kuo and his three friends asked Chen to take a walk and talk over the case, as Kuo was hoping that the girl would intervene and end the criminal case against him.
In the end, things did not go Kuo's way and he smashed her in the head with a rock wrapped in an article of clothing, which he then used to suffocate her.
During this, according to police, Chen's younger friend was also strangled by one or more Kuo's accomplices.
The four men then dumped the two bodies in the riverbed.
Police have also yet to recover the murder weapon or the missing clothing.

DOC.HEADLINE: CIVIC GROUPS FORM ALLIANCE FOR ACTION AGAINST CORRUPTION

TEXT.P: Eight civic groups founded the Alliance for Action Against Corruption in Taipei Tuesday and urged the ruling Democratic Progressive Party to institute legal reform, beginning with making the appointment of the state public prosecutor-general subject to approval by the legislature.

The eight civic groups are the Judicial Reform Foundation, the Alliance of Fairness and Justice, the Prosecutors' Reform Association, Transparency Taiwan, Taipei Society, Taiwan Association for Human Rights, the Association for Promotion of Clean Elections and the Chinese Police Administration Research Institute.

Chen Chi-min, convener of the the Prosecutors' Reform Association, said the appointment of the public prosecutor-general by the president should be subject to the approval by the legislature so that the nation's highest law enforcement official may become more neutral when executing his public duties.

As a measure to make him less susceptible to influence from the president, the public prosecutor-general should serve a guaranteed one six-year term, which should not overlap fully with the tenure of the president, Chen suggested.
He urged that all local governments, as well as the central government, should refrain from intervening in any investigation by public prosecutors.

The Alliance of Fairness and Justice pointed out that Taiwan has never seen a Cabinet minister sentenced to jail on charges of corruption, and that really makes people wonder whether it was because the Cabinet is really corruption-free or because police forces have intervened in the judicial process.
