DOC.HEADLINE: NCC MEMBER CANDIDATE WITHDRAWS HIS NAME FROM CONSIDERATION

TEXT.P: Lu Chung-chin, a professor from National Tsinghua University in Hsinchu withdrew his name from consideration Tuesday two days after he was recommended by a panel to the Executive Yuan as one of 13 candidates to serve on the National Communications Commission (NCC).

In a letter to Premier Frank Hsieh, Lu said he regrets that several political parties had packed the list of NCC nominees with their supporters, asking the premier to drop his name from the list of nominees of NCC members to be presented by the premier to the Legislature for confirmation.
An official of the Executive Yuan said the premier has not decided whether or not to ask the panel charged with choosing candidates for the NCC to name another person.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER US DIPLOMAT ADMITS RELATIONS WITH TAIWAN INTELLIGENCE OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: A former senior official at the State Department admitted in court Monday that he had a personal relationship with a Taiwanese woman intelligence official stationed in Washington, D.C.

While pleading guilty to several charges to a court in Alexandra, Virginia, Donald Keyser, former deputy assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs, said he felt sorry for concealing from his superiors at the State Department his trip to Taiwan in 2003 for a secret meeting with Taiwan intelligence official Isabelle Cheng, with whom he said he developed a personal relationship in the course of his official duties in the State Department.
Keyser said he didn't report his Taiwan trip because he didn't want to disclose the extent of this personal relationship with Cheng to others, particularly his wife.

Although the 62-year-old veteran diplomat said he knew his relationship with the 31-year-old Cheng might make him vulnerable to coercion, or exploitation from a foreign government, he claimed no effort to exploit him was ever made.

In his guilty plea, Keyser also admitted that he unlawfully removed classified documents from the State Department but claimed that he didn't disclosed them to anyone, and none of this had anything to do with Cheng.
Keyser who faces up to 13 years in prison, will be sentenced on Feb. 24, 2006.
FBI agents trailed Keyser in the summer of 2004 and found him meeting with Cheng frequently at restaurants around Washington, D.C. and exchanging papers with her.
He was charged with lying about his trip to Taiwan on Sept. 15, 2004 and retired from the State Department 15 days later.

Cheng, who works for Taiwan's National Security Bureau, was called back by Taiwan authorities after the incident. The National Security Bureau has refused to comment on the case from the beginning, and has not disclosed Cheng's whereabouts.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER MEETS SEVERAL TRADE MINISTERS IN HONG KONG
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Dec. 13 (CNA) (By Mandy Wong and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister of Economic Affairs (MOEA) Ho Mei-yueh on Tuesday attended the World Trade Organization (WTO) Doha round ministerial-level meeting in Hong Kong, and exchanged views with ministers of several countries on a variety of topics.

According to ROC Vice Economics Minister Chen Ruey-lung, who also formed part of the ROC delegation, Ho met two of the WTO's deputy secretaries-general -- Harsha V. Singh and Alejandyo JARA -- to exchange views regarding the ministerial meetings scheduled for Dec. 13-18, after arriving in Hong Kong Monday.

Ho and the WTO's two deputy secretaries-general expressed hope that the ministers of WTO member states can reach consensus on agricultural, non-agricultural and service sectors so that the conclusions can be included in the declaration of the Hong Kong ministerial meeting.

At a lunch held after the opening ceremony of the meeting, Ho had the chance to talk with her Canadian and Singaporean counterparts, with Ho exchanging views with the Canadian minister about the further liberalization of Canada's forest products, and discussing with the Singaporean minister the further opening of service industries around the world.
Chen noted that Taiwan, which has just implemented several opening measures of its markets that it promised upon entering the WTO, hopes that it can enjoy more flexible policies given to new members.

According to Chen, all the agricultural product importers of the WTO expressed hope that they can reach consensus as soon as possible to push for agricultural reforms, so that they can complete the Doha round of talks by 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Dec. 14, or the 14th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1783: William Pitt, known as "Pitt the Younger," is made British prime minister and chancellor of the exchequer at the age of just 24. He accomplished the Act of Union between Ireland and Britain but was unsuccessful in his efforts at achieving Catholic emancipation.
1808: James Madison is elected the fourth president of the United States. His presidency was marked by the War of 1812.
1858: The French and Spanish announce a blockade of the port of Taku near the Chinese city of Tientsin prior to an Anglo-French expedition against Beijing which saw the burning of the Imperial Summer Palace by invading troops.
1887: The first U.S. hospital for cancer patients is inaugurated in New York.
1902: Thomas Nast, an American political cartoonist who was born in Germany in 1840, dies at the age of 62. He was the first to depict the Democratic Party as a donkey and the Republican Party as an elephant.
1917: U.S. President Woodrow Wilson declares war on Austria.
1941: Japanese planes bomb the American naval base at Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, killing 2,400 men and destroying many aircraft and battleships.
1949: The government of the Republic of China moves its seat of power to Taipei.
1951: The Communist Chinese launch the "three antis campaign" -- anti-corruption, anti-extravagance, and anti-bureaucracy.
1971: An unmanned Soviet space capsule sends back radio and television signals from Mars.
1973: The Asian Vegetable Research and Development Center formally opens in Shanhua, Tainan County.
1974: A three-month exhibition of Chinese products is opened in Taipei by Economics Minister Y.S. Sun. The exhibition has 10 pavilions with 859 showrooms and 465 retail booths.
1975: U.S. President Gerald Ford delivers his "New Pacifism" speech in Hawaii.
1975: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo announces the ROC government's plan to build Asia's most modern farm villages under the first Six-Year Economic Development Plan beginning in 1976.
1975: Indonesian troops enter East Timor as civil war breaks out after the Portuguese, rulers of East Timor for three centuries, leave the colony.
1978: Japanese Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira forms a new Cabinet.
1982: Robbers make away with more than NT$14 million from an armored truck of the United World Chinese Commercial Bank in Taipei.
1984: The Legislative Yuan passes the Special Education Law after its third reading.
1985: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces the severing of diplomatic ties with the Republic of Nicaragua.
1986: The new Taipei City Zoo is inaugurated in the Taipei suburb of Mucha.
1988: A massive earthquake claims over 100,000 lives in Soviet Armenia.
1989: Lithuania abolishes the constitutional guarantee of Communist Party supremacy and legalizes the multiparty system.
1993: Ivory Coast President Felix Houphouet-Boigny, Africa's longest-serving ruler, dies.
1996: The space shuttle Columbia and its crew return safely to earth after ending the longest space shuttle flight ever at nearly 18 days.
1999: Premier Vincent Siew accepts the resignation of Cabinet member Peng Tso-kwei as chairman of the Council of Agriculture and appoints Ling Shiang-nung to fill the vacancy.
2000: Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan appeals to the government of France for judicial cooperation between the two countries to help in the investigation of kickback allegations surrounding the ROC Navy's purchase of six Lafayette-class frigates some 10 years earlier.
2001: A rehearsal for the formal commission of Taiwan's first F-16 fighter wing is held at Chiayi air force base in southern Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is indeed a pleasure to acquire knowledge and, as you go on acquiring, to put into practice what you have acquired. A greater pleasure still is when friends of congenial minds come from afar to seek you out because of your attainments."

DOC.HEADLINE: SUCCESS OF WEAPONS PROCUREMENT BILL HINGES ON ADMINISTRATION: KMT

TEXT.P: The success of the arms procurement bill hinges on the decisions made by the administration rather than on U.S. opinions, opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Wednesday.

After the bill was once again blocked in the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan Tuesday -- the 41st time since it was presented to the legislature in 2004 -- Ma said that it is unclear whether the Executive Yuan will make changes to the bill or not, but one thing that is clear is that the issue of the NT$480 billion (US$14.55 billion) arms procurment package is a matter for the government to decide on, and not the United States.

Ma made the remarks in reponse to media reports that quoted sources in Washington as saying that the procurement bill for the three major U.S. weaponry items -- six PAC III Patriot anti-missile batteries, eight diesel-fueled submarines and 12 anti-submarine aircraft -- would be more workable and pragmatic if the budget for the whole package were included in the Ministry of National Defense's regular annual budget rather financed by a special budget as proposed by the Democratic Progressive Party government.
The current Executive Yuan-proposed bill calls for the first item to be included in the ministry's regular annual budget and the other two items to be financed through a special budget.

Asked by reporters whether the KMT -- the main opposition party in the Legislative Yuan -- would support the bill if all the items in the package were included in the defense ministry's regular annual budget, Ma said that the bill would be acceptable to all the parties that are currently opposing the bill because of the special budget.

Meanwhile, Ma, who has been advocating a speedy handling of the KMT-held assets issue since he took the KMT helm in August this year, said that the proposed liquidation of the KMT's shares in China Television Co. and the China Broadcasting Corp. as well as other KMT-run companies has been intensely discussed and that the KMT headqurters will inform the public as soon as concrete plans are worked out.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOONG CRITICIZES REMARKS MADE BY PFP MEMBERS WANTING TO LEAVE PARTY

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong on Wednesday criticized what he called the inappropriate remarks made recently by those PFP members who want to leave the party and join the Kuomintang (KMT), saying that they don't have to describe the PFP as such an unbearable party.
The criticism came after several PFP members said Tuesday that if the PFP really wants to merge with its "pan-blue" ally the KMT, it is best to do so as soon as possible.

Soong, who made the criticism prior to his departure for Malaysia to attend a "Global Peace Forum" being held by former Malaysian Premier Mahathir Mohamad, said that the nature of the PFP is quite different from that of the KMT, adding that the PFP is a party that has its own ideas and an insistence on rationality and a "midway concept."
According to Soong, the KMT's rule in Taiwan for nearly 50 years, including the period when Lee Teng-hui was president, had many negative impacts on the island.

He further said that during his meeting with KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou Monday, he mentioned to Ma that certain policies adopted by the KMT during Lee's presidency, including Lee's "state-to-state" theory and the freezing of the Taiwan Provincial Government's operations, contributed to the end of Taiwan's "golden age," and that the KMT should engage in some self-examination regarding these matters.
Soong also said that the two parties should insist on the pathway toward building peace across the Taiwan Strait for the sake of the people's welfare.

Regarding the several PFP members who intend to leave the party, Soong said that leaving earlier or later is not a problem as he already made it clear while meeting with Ma that the PFP and the KMT will do all they can to cooperate with each other in the Legislative Yuan and that, as Ma said, they cannot stop members from leaving the party if they want to do so.

Pointing out that the PFP has more than 80 members working in the Legislative Yuan and in legislative bodies of local governments, as well as many more in the civil service, Soong said that "the PFP must respect their will."
Soong also said that he knows the Taiwan people want to see the PFP and KMT merge as this will give Taiwan better prospects.
He also advised those PFP members who made the "senseless remarks" Tuesday that they should think of the Taiwan people and work to create a better future for them.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER URGES LEGISLATURE TO PASS MAJOR BILLS ASAP

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh on Wednesday urged the Legislative Yuan to pass major bills, including the arms procurement bill, as soon as possible as the current legislative session is set to draw to an end at the end of this month.

The premier made the remarks during a Cabinet meeting, noting that although the legislature has passed several major bills, including a minimum tax system and a revised statute to raise the monthly allowance for elderly farmers, there are still many urgent bills that need to be dealt with.

He cited the long-stalled arms procurement bill as well as the organic bill of the Executive Yuan as examples, saying that if the legislators have different views, they can revise the bills, instead of simply boycotting them.

The arms procurement package -- which includes six PAC III Patriot anti-missile batteries, eight diesel-fueled submarines and 12 anti-submarine aircraft from the United States -- has been blocked in the legislature for more than a year by the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party which holds a slight legislative majority.

Noting that the Legislative Yuan dramatically cut the central government's budgets for next year during its initial review, the premier also asked for consultations between the ruling and the opposition parties to reinstate the budgets so as not to affect the operations of government agencies.

Meanwhile, the premier said that the Cabinet will continue to push for its ongoing reform programs in the wake of the Dec. 3 local elections. The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) suffered a humiliating defeat in the islandwide elections, managing only six of the 23 city mayor and county magistrate posts up for grabs. The KMT won 14 posts.

"There are winners and losers in elections, but the ongoing reforms will not stop as a result of the elections outcome, " Hsieh said, urging the public not to lose faith in the Executive Yuan and the ruling party.

The reform programs promoted before the elections will continue, he said, including the changes to the pension system for retired military personnel, civil servants and teachers, and the crackdown on the illegal practice of retired civil servants including their years serving in the KMT in filing for their pension payments.
Also, although several cities and counties will have new chiefs following the elections, the partnership relations between the central and local governments will remain unchanged, the premier said.

The Cabinet will take the initiative in providing assistance in the implementation of the platforms of newly elected mayors and magistrates if necessary, Hsieh said, adding that the administration should serve the people irrespective of party affiliation.

Hsieh also expressed the hope that the outgoing mayors and magistrates, who now are basically serving caretaker roles following their election defeats, will not make decisions on major development projects.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. WOULD LIKE TO SEE BEIJING OFFICIAL VISIT TAIWAN: ROC REP

TEXT.P: The U.S. government would like to see Beijing's top official in charge of Taiwan affairs visit Taiwan, but it also thinks that the Beijing official should meet with his Taiwan counterpart, Taiwan's representative in the United States said Wednesday.

Fielding questions at a Legislative Yuan Foreign Affairs Committee meeting, David Lee said that as far as he knows, Washington favors a visit to Taiwan by Chen Yunlin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under China's State Council, this month at the invitation of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) for an economic forum between the KMT and the Communist Party of China.

Lee added, however, that U.S. authorities have also hinted that during his visit in Taiwan, Chen should also meet with Joseph Wu, minister of the Mainland Affairs Council, to engage in official dialogue.
Lee further said that it is Washington's set policy to encourage China and Taiwan to engage in peaceful dialogue as part of efforts to address differences between the two sides.
"The U.S. thinks that it would be good if Chen could visit Taiwan, but it would be undesirable if Chen failed to meet with Wu during his visit," Lee said.
Lee said that he conveyed this message clearly to the Democratic Progressive Party government prior to the Dec. 3 "three-in-one" elections, in which the KMT won a sweeping victory.

The KMT has applied to the MAC for a permit for Chen's proposed visit to Taiwan, but the MAC authorities have said that the holding of official negotiations is a precondition to them granting approval.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT SHAPES POSITIVE IMPRESSIONS OF TAIWAN: GALLUP
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Dec. 13 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economic achievements, especially its technological development, may have helped shape positive global impressions of the country, the Gallup Organization said in a report posted Tuesday on its Web site.

The study was conducted by Gallup for the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in New York based on a survey carried out in May and June in the United States, Japan, the United Kingdom, France and Germany. The targets included 1,500 members of the general public and 200 opinion leaders in each country.

Although only 15 percent to 44 percent of the general public in these countries know "some" or "a great deal" about Taiwan, most of them have "very favorable" or "favorable" impressions of Taiwan, the survey shows. In particular, the impressions of Taiwan are "favorable" among 76 percent of the respondents in Japan, 73 percent in the United States and 68 percent in the United Kingdom.
The survey also discovered that the favorability ratings of Taiwan are generally higher than those of China and South Korea, but lower than those of Japan.

The survey indicates that opinion leaders were more likely than the general public to know something about Taiwan and view it favorably, with more than 90 percent of those surveyed in Japan and the United States having a very favorable or favorable impression of Taiwan.

While most of the respondents have obtained information about Taiwan from media sources such as television, newspapers and magazines, 68 percent in the United Kingdom, 58 percent in France and 54 percent in the United States have learned about Taiwan through its products.

The study says that it does not seem likely that the contrast between democratic Taiwan and communist China has boosted positivity toward Taiwan, in light of the fact that only 29 percent of the general public in the United States, 27 percent in the United Kingdom, 23 percent in France, and 33 percent in Germany are aware that Taiwan has a democratic political system.
However, many members of the general public agree that Taiwan is "technologically developed" and "has good food, interesting attractions and beautiful scenery."

By comparison, higher percentages of opinion leaders are aware of Taiwan's democratic status and describe Taiwan as a technologically developed and economically strong country and a good place for business investment, according to the survey.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENVOY EXPECTS PROGRESS IN TRADE TALKS WITH U.S. NEXT SPRING

TEXT.P: Progress in Taiwan's efforts to engage in free trade talks with the United States is expected next spring when the two sides negotiate on a trade and investment framework agreement if Taiwan seriously addresses the various issues of great concern to the U.S. side, David Lee, Taiwan's representative to Washington, said Wednesday.

In a report to the Foreign Relations Committee of the Legislative Yuan, Lee said that Taiwan has to respond appropriately to U.S. concerns about the island's trade practices in an effort to persuade Washington to begin FTA talks.

Noting that the United States is one of Taiwan's most important trade partners, with two-way trade amounting to US$56 billion last year, Lee said a free trade agreement would not only benefit both parties, it would also encourage other countries to follow Washington's lead and conclude similar pacts with Taiwan.

Washington prioritizes the countries with which it wants to engage in FTA talks based on considerations of the country's strategic significance and trade importance to the United States, as well as U.S. public opinion and the country's contribution to advancing the World Trade Organization's Doha round of trade talks.

In formulating its strategy in dealing with the United States on pushing for FTA talks, Lee said Taiwan should take into consideration the effects on Washington's position of Beijing's opposition to such an agreement and of the fact that the U.S. Trade Promotion Act is set to expire July 1, 2007.

Lee predicted that successful talks with the United States on the trade and investment framework next spring will certainly encourage Washington to move on the path toward a free trade agreement with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIX TAIWAN CELEBS TO BE FEATURED IN DISCOVERY CHANNEL PROGRAM

TEXT.P: Six Taiwan celebrities, including world-renowned forensic scientist Henry Lee, will be featured in a Discovery Channel program titled "Portraits Taiwan" which is slated to begin airing Dec. 25, Government Information Office (GIO) officials said Wednesday.

Nearly 100 million viewers around Asia are expected to tune in to watch the program which was produced jointly over the past year by Discovery Channel, the GIO and the magazine Commonwealth. The six celebrities were chosen based on discussions between the three producers as well as on the results of an online public vote.

The six Taiwan individuals, including choreographer Lin Hwai-min, founder of the famous Cloud Gate Dance Group, who was selected as one of Time magazine's "Asian Heroes" for 2005, represent various sectors of Taiwan society and are representative of Taiwan's globalization and its core values, GIO officials said.
Prior to being broadcast on Discovery Channel, "Portraits Taiwan" will be screened at a gathering in Taipei City Thursday, with four of the six Taiwan celebrities expected to be in attendance.
Lin Hwai-min will be featured in the first episode, while Henry Lee will be the subject of the second episode.

The other four celebrities to be featured are Master Cheng Yen, founder of Taiwan's largest charity organization, the Buddhist Compassionate Foundation of Tzu Chi; Liu Chin-piao, founder of Giant, currently the world's largest maker of quality bicycles; the "King of Watermelon" Chen Wen-yu, who has devoted 45 years of his life to developing seeds for quality vegetables and fruits in Taiwan, helping make Taiwan into an agricultural leader in Asia; and pop singer A-mei, who has conquered the hearts of audiences throughout Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: U.S.,Britain hope to begin Iraq pullout in March: report
The United States and Britain are planning a phased withdrawal of their military forces from Iraq as soon as a permanent government is installed in Baghdad, The Times newspaper reported Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened low and closed lower Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 25.83 points to close at 6,235.35.
The bourse opened at 6,272.48 and fluctuated between 6,280.52 and 6,227.35 during trading. A total of 3.41 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$84.73 billion (US$2.56 billion).
Only two of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with cement stocks and foodstuff shares both moving up 0.3 percent.

The other six major stock categories lost ground, with machinery and electronics shares, financial stocks, and construction issues moving down the most at 0.5 percent, followed by plastics and chemical shares at 0.4 percent, and paper and pulp stocks and textile shares both at 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 568 to 435, with 202 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Former banker arrested for alleged association to commit crime.
Former chief executive of Banca Popolare Italiana (BPI) Gianpiero Fiorani, was arrested Tuesday in Milano for alleged association to commit crime. Fiorani, who is a family friend of Italy's central bank governor Antonio Fazio, tried to engineer the failed fraud-surrounding takeover of Banco Antoveneta whose market value was more than three times over that of BPI, blocking an attempt of the Dutch bank ABN AMRO.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: Korea President here today
South Korean President Roh Moo-hyun planes in at 5 p.m. today from Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia to start a three-day state visit to be highlighted by the launching of South Korean-assisted projects and talks with President Arroyo on how to expand bilateral cooperation between their two countries.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Senate to Comelec execs: Resign now
FOR the "egregiously fraudulent" contract for the purchase of P1.24 billion worth of automated counting machines in 2003, the entire Senate is demanding the resignation of all but one of the election commissioners.
The Philippine Star: Senators seek ouster of Comelec officials
The Senate is recommending the sacking of all officials of the scandal-ridden Commission on Elections (Comelec) involved in the bidding process for automated counting machines to ensure clean and honest elections in the country.
The Manila Times: Luisita stock plan good as doomed
THE Presidential Agrarian Reform Council (PARC) executive committee on Tuesday upheld the recommendation of its validation committee to revoke the stock distribution option being carried out by the family of former President Corazon Aquino in Hacienda Luisita in Tarlac.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: Tookie Williams Is Executed.
Stanley Tookie Williams, whose self-described evolution from gang thug to antiviolence crusader won him an international following and nominations for a Nobel Peace Prize, was executed by lethal injection early today, hours after Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger refused to spare his life.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for December dropped 26 points to close at 6,215, with 23,297 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for January moved down 33 points to end at 6,217, with 1,889 contracts traded, while March futures lost 22 points to finish at 6,220, with 35 contracts traded.
June futures moved down 30 points to close at 6,200, with four contracts traded, while September futures dropped 29 points to close at 6,090, with 12 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 6,241 for December, 6,250 for January, 6,242 for March, 6,230 for June and 6,119 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.
December TE futures moved down 2.10 points to close at 271.4, with 4,404 contracts traded, while January TE futures lost 2.05 points to finish at 271.15, with 289 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
December TF futures lost six points to finish at 878, with 1,907 contracts changing hands, while January TF futures moved down six points to end at 878, with 221 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, dropping NT$0.136 to close at NT$33.362.
A total of US$1.04 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$33.498 and hit a low of NT$33.355.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKER OPPOSES EXTENSION OF STATUTE ON TPG STREAMLINING

TEXT.P: A statute concerning the streamlining of the Taiwan Provincial Government should not be extended until the end of next year, since doing so would waste further money, a lawmaker from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Wednesday.

Legislator Wu Fu-kuei and former members of the now-abolished National Assembly Wang Chin-shan and Chuang Sheng-jung, as well as Taiwan Solidarity Union Deputy Secretary-General Liu Yi-teh called a news conference to call attention to the issue after the Executive Yuan asked the Legislative Yuan to extend the statute for another year.
Wu said that the original plan to downsize the Taiwan Provincial Government called for its completion in three stages over a period of two years.

The statute should have become invalid on Jan. 1, 2001 at the latest, Wu said. After that, the organization, functions, and administrative affairs of local-level governments would have returned to normal, in accordance with regulations in the Law on the Local Government System.

But he said that the Executive Yuan has for the sixth consecutive year asked for an extension of the statute, and has continued to appropriate a large sum of money for the Taiwan Provincial Government to continue operations.

He pointed out that since the start of the downsizing project of the Taiwan Provincial Government six years ago, the nation has spent NT$6.3 billion on it and NT$975.63 million for the Taiwan Provincial Consultative Council.

He also said that before the streamlining of the Taiwan Provincial Government, it still had NT$7.6 billion allocated by the central government left at its disposal, but only NT$1 billion is left now, and that no one knows the whereabouts of the remaining sum.
He claimed that the Taiwan provincial government is not really needed and that the purpose of retaining it is simply to arrange people to serve in the posts.

On July 1, 1999, the Taiwan Provincial Government was downsized and divided into six sections, five offices, two committees and 13 affiliated organizations. The 149 administrative units, 36 health care organizations and 170 provincial high schools originally listed under the provincial administration have been re-categorized as units of the Central Government.

Also, 58 organizations were either eliminated or merged. Altogether, 16 former Taiwan Provincial Government departments were transformed into regional offices of the ministries and agencies under the Executive Yuan and three under the Examination Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP HEAVYWEIGHTS PERSUADE LU TO STAY ON AS ACTING PARTY CHIEF

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) heavyweights convinced Vice President Annette Lu Wednesday to stay on as acting head of the party.

Lu was named as the acting chair of the party on Dec. 7 after the former chairman, Su Tseng-chang, quit on Dec. 3 to take responsibility for the party's poor showing in the local elections the same day.

Lu wanted to take a leading role in re-constructing the party after the DPP took only six of the 23 local chief seats up for grabs, but was admonished by the Central Standing Committee, which told her that as a caretaker of the party, her only job was to preside over the election of a new chairman.
Lu took this a sign from President Chen Shui-bian that he disapproved of her doubling as the DPP's acting chief, so she resigned.

Premier Frank Hsieh, a member of the DPP's Central Standing Committee, said at the end of the weekly meeting of the committee Wednesday that Lu had been persuaded by members to withdraw her resignation.
Lu avoided questions from journalists on the subject and only said: "Thanks to the central committee members for their kindly call [for her to stay]."

DOC.HEADLINE: LU THANKS ORGAN DONOR WHILE MAKING VEILED COMMENT ON POLITICAL ISSUE

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu honored the memory of a deceased 18-year-old university student and praised his family Wednesday for showing their "great love" by donating his organs to help others, but apparently couldn't stop from mixing in a bit of politics along the way.

Lu made her remarks after attending the memorial service for Hsiao Chih-chien, a Chinese Culture University student who died Nov. 26 in a traffic accident and became the first organ donor to the Tzu Chi Hospital in Taipei.

At least six people have benefited from operations using Hsiao's liver, heart, kidneys and corneas. His bones are being kept at another Tzu Chi Hospital, ready for marrow transplants for the benefit of more patients.

Lu said Hsiao and his family made the decision out of "compassion and wisdom." On the other hand, she said, "The man in charge -- the one that wields power -- to our regret, has ignored the value of life as he concentrates on immediate power, probably because of short-sightedness."

Lu's remarks taken alone would be nothing short of bizarre, which is why political observers said that she was most likely using not-so-veiled language to take a jab at the current speculation about her relations being somewhat rocky with the president.

Asked by a journalist, "Are you feeling a sense of frustration?" Lu said: "Hsiao's great love and great compassion [to let go of everything] was exemplary; however, I cannot but help feel a strong sense of ridiculousness about the recent political commotion."

Her apparently tense relations with President Chen Shui-bian and other Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) heavyweights in the days leading up to her quitting the post of acting chairwoman of the ruling party have been closely watched by political pundits.
However, in a Wednesday meeting of the DPP Central Standing Committee, Lu agreed to stay on as acting chairwoman of the party, according to Premier Frank Hsieh.

Even opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou came forward to urge the two top leaders to stop issuing statements through the media to criticize each other, claiming that "it is not in the best interests of the country."
Chang Chun-hsiung, a former premier and DPP chairman, said both Chen and Lu are "outstanding political figures" who, he believes, "have the wisdom to solve their problems."
Premier Hsieh said he hopes the ruling party's internal squabbles regarding the acting chairmanship will not affect the ruling team's normal administrative work.

Hsieh also tried to take some pressure off the president, claiming that Lu was not specifically referring to President Chen and could be referring to himself as premier, since the Cabinet leader is also "the man in charge."
Hsieh said all members of the ruling team are reflecting on what they did wrong leading up to the election defeat on Dec. 3, and he would like to thank Lu for her "instruction."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RANKED FOURTH IN U.S. PATENT APPROVALS FOR 2004

TEXT.P: The U.S. government approved 5,938 utility patents applications by Taiwanese inventors in 2004, ranking Taiwan fourth in the world behind only the United States, Japan and Germany, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) officials said Wednesday.

The officials noted that as the United States is the third-largest outlet for Taiwan's exports, Taiwanese inventors have been working actively to apply for patents in the U.S. to protect their intellectual property rights.
According to the National Science Council, the U.S. Department of Commerce approved 181,322 patents in 2004, a decrease of 5,728 over 2003.
Among them, 164,293 were classified as utility patents in which higher levels of technology are involved.
The number of utility patents in the U.S. also saw a decrease of 4,733 over 2003, with American inventors obtaining 84,271, followed by Japan with 35,350, and Germany with 10,779.
Taiwan was ranked fourth with 5,938, an increase of 640 over 2003, followed by South Korea, the United Kingdom, France, Canada, Italy and Sweden.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN REP TO U.S. SAYS TAIPEI MUST DO MORE TO IMPROVE RELATIONS

TEXT.P: Taiwan must do more so that U.S. Congress members can understand the real issues and not be swayed by the intense lobbying efforts by China, ROC representative to the United States David Ta-wei Lee said in Taipei Wednesday.

Reporting to the Legislative Yuan's Foreign and Overseas Chinese Affairs Committee, Lee pointed out that Beijing has been advancing its lobbying efforts towards the U.S. Congress and the public in recent years.

For example, the Chinese Embassy in the United States has assigned staff specifically to contact members of the U.S. Congress, and the National People's Congress of China has also enhanced exchanges with the U.S. Senate and House of Representatives, Lee noted.
In addition, Beijing has also contracted with several U.S. public relations firms to help improve China's image and conduct political lobbying on behalf of China, Lee said.

In terms of cultural and artistic exchanges, he continued, China's Ministry of Culture held a one-month "Festival of China" in October in cooperation with the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington, D.C. to carry out intensive soft and public diplomacy.
According to Lee, Beijing's lobbying efforts have given the people a " romanticized version" of China, something Taiwan ought to be concerned about.
Also in recent years, the United States has been paying extra attention to issues surrounding the rise of China, Lee said.
Although overall relations between Beijing and Washington are getting closer and closer, conservatives and liberals alike are having misgivings about the Chinese Communist regime, he said.

While conservatives are concerned about China's military buildup, the lack of religious freedom in China and its efforts to seek energy sources from other countries, liberals are critical of the lack of transparency in China's system as well as the country's failure to uphold social justice and human rights and to protect the environment, he said.

However, he predicted that bickering will be unavoidable between Beijing and Washington, which will limit the effects of China's lobbying efforts because China is unlikely to improve its major defects in the political, economic and social aspects in the near future.

Under these circumstances, he suggested that Taipei try to enhance its relations with Washington by strengthening the values of democracy and freedom that are shared by Taiwan and the United States, maintaining friendly relations with the U.S. government, reinforcing Taiwan's resolve to defend itself and promoting the signing of a Taiwan-U.S. free trade agreement.

DOC.HEADLINE: AT-LARGE LEGISLATIVE SEATS AN ISSUE WITHIN 'PAN-BLUE' MERGER

TEXT.P: A merger by the two opposition "pan-blue" alliance parties --- the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) --- would not necessarily mean that the number of seats of legislators-at-large would be reduced, KMT Legislator Lee Ching-hua said Wednesday.

Lee said that the Ministry of the Interior has informed him that should a merger take place, the "pan-blue" alliance's at-large seats would not be cut, and the subsidies given to the resulting party can be lumped together. Lee said there should be a good reason to justify opposition to merger.

On the other hand, PFP Legislator Liu Wen-hsiung said that his party would lose seven seats once the KMT and PFP merges unless legislation pending is passed, according to a document the Central Election Commission (CEC) gave the party in June 2004.

The CEC said that the Public Officials Election and Recall Law and a Council of Grand Justice's ruling both stated that if a legislator elected according to the proportional representation system loses his party registration, he loses at the same time his position as a legislator.

But the CEC also pointed out that the Political Party Law which the Executive Yuan proposed to the Legislative Yuan on Sep. 13, 2002, states that in the case of a merger between parties, the legislators elected according to the proportional representation system will not be affected. However, this law has yet to be approved by the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC TO STUDY KMT THINK TANK PETITION ON BEIJING OFFICIAL'S VISIT

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) will study a petition by an opposition Kuomintang (KMT) think tank advocating allowing a top Beijing official to visit Taiwan to take part in an economic conference, MAC Vice Chairman Johnnason Liu said Wednesday.

Saying that the MAC just learned of the petition from the Bureau of Immigration, Liu said that the MAC will give a clear explanation of the issue after having gained a better understanding of the petition submitted by the KMT think tank. The petition asks the government to rethink its decision to disallow Chen Yunlin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under the State Council in Beijing, from coming to Taiwan.

Liu's remarks came after a Taiwan Affairs Office spokesman reiterated at a regular news briefing in Beijing earlier the same day that the KMT and the Communist Party of China (CPC) would hold an economic forum as planned in Taipei and he asked relevant Taiwan authorities to provide necessary assistance.

The KMT and the CPC were slated to hold the economic forum in Taipei on Dec. 15, but Chen's visa application, filed by the KMT, was turned down on Nov. 18 during a screening meeting held by the Bureau of Immigration. Chen is Beijing's No. 1 official responsible for Taiwan affairs.

The KMT-CPC forum would be the first of its kind after Taiwan split from China in 1949 following a civil war. The planned forum was a follow-up activity after former KMT Chairman Lien Chan paid a landmark visit to China in spring this year -- hailed by many as one of the most significant steps toward improving relations across the Taiwan Strait in more than 50 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANDARIN TO PLY CHARTER FLIGHTS FROM TAICHUNG TO MACAU

TEXT.P: Mandarin Airlines will launch its first charter flight from Chingchuankang Airport in central Taichung County to Macau next week, a spokesman for the Taipei-based aviation company said Wednesday.

According to the spokesman, Mandarin will fly a Fokker 100 for the round trip between Taichung and Macau on Dec. 23, paving the way for the aviation company's strategic plan to develop international routes in the Asia-Pacific region from the airport in central Taiwan.

Mandarin has already flown 102 charter flights to Hong Kong, Seoul and Japan from Chingchuankang Airport since October 2004, the spokesman noted, adding that the aviation company hopes to be able to begin providing charter flights on a regular basis from Taichung to Hong Kong and Macau from spring next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINISTER PROMISES FULL INSPECTION BEFORE KAOHSIUNG MRT IS OPENED

TEXT.P: Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san said Wednesday his ministry will carefully inspect every aspect of the Kaohsiung rapid transit system before giving it the go-ahead to open.

"We will also move ahead our schedules for examining the work on the rapid transit routes to ensure that no one will ever have to be concerned about the safety while taking the MRT, " he told lawmakers.

Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Huang Chao-shun asked him during a legislative committee meeting to suspend the construction of the southern port city's MRT lines in the wake of a series of cave-ins.

Lin said the cave-in must be filled in but the building job cannot stop; one reason being that six shield machines were still working on underground tunnels. "If they are stopped immediately, they might sink into the earth," he said.

Huang, not satisfied with Lin's replies, threatened to freeze the NT$70 billion budget earmarked for the remaining work on the MRT project if the Ministry of Transportation and Communications does not halt the construction and begin comprehensive inspections.
Lin said the ministry has already sent a senior technician, Liao Ching-lung, to act as leader of the Kaohsiung City Government's MRT Examination Team, which will monitor the building process.
He pledged to look into all aspects of the MRT system once the construction has been completed as well as do some advance checks to ensure complete safety for passengers.

Huang asked committee chairman Legislator Lin Teh-fu of the People First Party to invite all Transportation and Communications Committee members to inspect the building sites next week along with safety experts and engineering specialists in the company of Lin.
If Lin does not even allow that, the NT$70 billion budget should definitely be frozen, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC GROWTH THIS YEAR ESTIMATED AT 3.8 PERCENT: CEPD

TEXT.P: Economic growth this year should be 3.8 percent, lower than the original goal of 4 percent, the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Wednesday.

The officials attributed the failure to reach the goal to weaker-than-expected exports in the first half of the year, resulting in only 2.73 percent economic growth in the first six months. Economic growth in the latter half of the year should climb to 4.83 percent, they said. The officials also said that the jobless rate should be 4.1 percent this year in the wake of various job-creation programs promoted by the government.

They also said that because of soaring oil prices as well as the the sharp increase of fruit and vegetable prices, the consumer price index increase for this year should reach 2.23 percent, higher than the original estimate of 2 percent.

Looking ahead, the officials said that the economic growth next year will be 4.5 percent, the jobless rate will not exceed 4 percent, and the consumer price index increase should not exceed 2 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIRECT CROSS-STRAIT TRANSPORTATION LINKS MUST PROCEED GRADUALLY: CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that direct "three links" between Taiwan and China should be pursued in a gradual manner, with sea links coming before air links and cargo shipments coming before passenger transportation.
Meeting a group of visitors from the Atlantic Council of the United States, Chen repeated his administration's position with regard to launching postal, air and sea links across the Taiwan Strait.

"If government-to-government negotiations cannot start, and if China insists on dealing with the opposition in disregard of Taiwan's government, it would be extremely difficult to expect any progress [in advancing the 'three links']," he said.

Chen said a breakthrough was reached early this year for charter flights during the lunar new year holidays, but China immediately wanted to follow suit with a proposal for opening up direct air services across the Strait, a proposal that is "regrettable."

He promised that to deal with trade and economic exchanges across the Strait, the government will "do its best in every aspect" in promoting the "three links." However, he stressed that things must go forward gradually.

The reason is that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have a very special relationship, which dictates that Taiwan must not rush in doing many things because it must safeguard its national security and the people's overall interests, Chen said.

Under that logic, he noted, the "three links" must not be carried out without a precedent within the "mini three links" as have been carried out between Kinmen and Xiamen, and full passenger flights must not be provided without a successful experience in charter cargo flights.

He repeated his basic stance on cross-strait affairs -- stand firm but go forward practically. Based on that principle, he said the government will not dance to China's tune because "Taiwan is a sovereign country with its own government whose public authorities must not be downgraded."

DOC.HEADLINE: TUNA ASSOCIATION WISHES TO AVERT DOMINO EFFECT

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Tuna Association does not want to see a domino effect take place at the current meeting of the Western and Central Pacific Fisheries Commission (WCPFC) regarding overfishing by Taiwan's fishing boats, an association spokesman said Wednesday.

Out of a fear that the WCPFC might also sanction Taiwan over its fishing practices in international waters during its current annual conference being held in Micronesia through Friday, the association has thoroughly assessed the situation and has sent personnel to the WCPFC meeting to explain Taiwan's efforts and measures.

Experts at the meeting will immediately relay the latest developments to the association to allow it to swiftly draw up countermeasures amid grave concerns that the WCPFC, of which Taiwan is a member, will also punish Taiwan, following in the footstep of the International Commission of the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna (ICCAT), the spokesman said.

As the Indian Ocean Tuna Commission (IOTC) is slated to call its annual meeting in February next year, the association has repeatedly asked more than 300 Taiwan fishing boats currently operating in the Pacific and the Indian Ocean to be extremely self-disciplined, he noted.

Due to Taiwan's failure to bring its illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing boats under control, the ICCAT decided to impose a cut in its quota for Taiwan's bigeye tuna fish catch by around 70 percent during its annual conference last month, forcing Taiwan to reduce the number of its bigeye tuna fishing boats operating in the Atlantic to 15 for 2006.
The ICCAT punishment is expected to deal a serious blow to the domestic deep-sea fishing industry, which has some 520 fishing vessels operating in the world's major fishing grounds.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO HOLD CHAIRMAN BY-ELECTION JAN. 15

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will hold a by-election Jan. 15 to elect a new party chairman to fill the post left vacant by the resignation of Su Tseng-chang, a party official said Wednesday.
DPP Secretary-General Lee Yi-yang made the announcement after a weekly meeting of the party's decision-making Central Standing Committee.
According to Lee, the DPP headquarters will organize televised debates for all by-election hopefuls.

Candidacy registration will start Dec. 16 and last through Dec. 20. A lot-drawing will be held Dec. 22 to determine the order qualified candidates' names will appear on the ballot, and party members will go to the polls Jan. 15.

Su stepped down from the DPP chairmanship immediately after the party suffered a resounding defeat in the Dec. 3 local government chief elections. Vice President Annette Lu was named to serve as the party's interim chairwoman at last Wednesday's Central Standing Committee meeting. Lu shocked her DPP fellows last Friday by expressing her intention to resign in a public statement.
At the end of the day, Lu changed her mind and agreed to remain on in the interim post at the advice of all Central Standing Committee members.

DOC.HEADLINE: LACK OF SOCIAL LIFE A MAJOR BARRIER TO MARRIAGE: POLL

TEXT.P: With singles numbering more than eight million in Taiwan today and believed to face more difficulties in finding a partner than 10 years ago, the results of a survey released Wednesday showed that the lack of a social life is the biggest barrier to marriage.
Coming in second and third are the high requirements set by singles in selecting marriage partners and their getting older.
The survey was conducted by the SIP singles club, which is made up of single workers at the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park, on 1,200 members between Nov. 1 and Dec. 14.

Other barriers to marriage named by the respondents are the high expectations for partners, high self-esteem, high educational backgrounds, high social status and high probability that one may marry the wrong person.

Also on the top-10 list are the large number of local men looking for wives overseas and businesses moving to China, which lessen the chances of local women finding a husband; and the low emotional intelligence of singles.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEVER USED WOMEN AS BAIT TO OBTAIN INFORMATION: NSB

TEXT.P: Taiwan has not used women as bait to obtain intelligence information, an official of the National Security Bureau (NSB) said Wednesday, because it is "not a permissible practice."

Huang Kuang-hsun, deputy head of the NSC, made the remarks when he and other officials of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) were invited by the legislative caucus of the opposition People First Party to report on a case concerning a former senior official of the U.S. State Department.

Media reports said that Donald W. Keyser, former deputy assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, pleaded guilty Monday after being released in September 2004 and later released on bail to unlawfully removing classified United States documents from the Department of State and to two counts of making false official statements -- concealing his Taiwan trip as well as "close ties of affection" with Isabelle Cheng, an intelligence official of the NSB stationed in Washington, D.C.
Keyser who faces up to 13 years in prison, will be sentenced on Feb. 24, 2006.
FBI agents trailed Keyser in the summer of 2004 and found him meeting with Cheng frequently at restaurants around Washington, D.C. and exchanging papers with her.
He was charged with lying about his trip to Taiwan on Sept. 15, 2004 and retired from the State Department 15 days later.

Huang, who was a former NSB representative to the U.S. before transferring to his present post in August 2005, said that he has reported the case to David Ta-wei Lee, the Republic of China representative to the U.S.
Lee asked him to cooperate fully with the United States to help clarify the case.

Lee, after communicating with the U.S. State Department and lawyers, believed that communication between nations was essential and this is why Taiwan handed over to the U.S. the records of Keyser's talks with Taiwan officials, Huang said.
Huang said that the U.S. only has the information that Taiwan's Representative Office has supplied it.

It is very unlikely that the U.S. court displayed the copies of the top secret documents from Taiwan as reports have said, Huang said, adding that the U.S. has also not taken the initiative to ask Taiwan to supply information.

Hsieh Wu-chiao, deputy director-general of the Department of North American Affairs, said that MOFA's stance is that it is not appropriate for it to comment on the case, which is a judicial case in the U.S.
The bottom line of the ministry is that this entire affair will not be detrimental to bilateral relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: POPE CALLS FOR NUCLEAR DISARMAMENT

TEXT.P: Pope Benedict XVI callled for nuclear disarmament Tuesday, stressing that in a nuclear war there would be no victors, only victims.

In his message for the World Day of Peace, the Pope said that the truth of peace requires that all, whether those governments which openly or secretly possess nuclear arms, or those planning to acquire them, agree to change their course by clear and firm decisions, and strive for a progressive and concerted nuclear disarmament.
The resources which would be saved from the disarmament could then be employed in projects of development capable of benefiting all their people, specially the poor, he added.
Those governments which count on nuclear arms as a means of ensuring the security of their countries are erroneous, he criticized.

The Pope also expressed his worries about a continuing growth in military expenditure and the flourishing arms trade. "How can there ever be a future of peace when investments are still made in the production of arms and in research aimed at developing new ones? " he asked.

It can only be hoped that the international community will find the wisdom and courage to take up once more, jointly and with renewed conviction, the process of disarmament, and thus concretely ensure the right to peace enjoyed by every individual and every people, the Pope noted.

Referring to the terrorism, the Pope condemned the terrorists for their senseless and deadly strategies. Nowadays, he said, the truth of peace continues to be dramatically compromised and rejected by terrorism, whose criminal threats and attacks leave the world in a state of fear and insecurity.

The nihilism and the religious fanaticism or the fundamentalism can inspire and encourage terrorist thinking and activity, he pointed out, adding that despite of their different origins and cultural backgrounds, both show a dangerous contempt for human beings and human life, and utimately for God himself.

In analyzing the causes of the contemporary phenomenon of terrorism, consideration should be given not only to its political and social causes, but also to its deeper cultural, religious and ideological motivations.

The Pope also expressed his support for the creation of an international humanitarian law as a means of limiting the devastating consequences of war as much as possible. "The international humanitarian law ought to be considered as one of the finest and most effective expressions of the intrinsic demands of the truth of peace," he noted.
The Pope urged all Catholics to place themselves at the service of peace in broad cooperation with other Christians, the followers of other religions and with all men and women of good will.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT APPEAL FOR CHINESE OFFICIALS' VISIT TO BE MULLED DEC. 19

TEXT.P: The Bureau of Immigration has received an appeal filed by the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) to allow several Chinese officials to come to Taiwan for a forum in Taipei, and the agency will discuss the issue on Dec. 19, Wu Shieh-yen, deputy director of the bureau, said Wednesday.

A screening committee of the bureau last month rejected the applications made for Chen Yunlin, director of China's Taiwan Affairs Office, and several other Chinese officials, who have been invited by the KMT to visit Taiwan for an economic and trade forum originally scheduled to be held in Taipei on Dec. 15.

The forum would be the first of its kind between the KMT and the Communist Party of China (CPC) in more than 50 years after the CPC defeated the KMT in a civil war in China that caused the KMT to flee to Taiwan in 1949.
The bureau rejected the earlier applications taking into consideration the current cross-Taiwan Strait relations and international practices, an official of the bureau said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING OFFICIAL VISIT UP TO AGENCY IN CHARGE: MAC

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) will respect the due authority's handling of a planned visit to Taiwan by a ranking Beijing official, the Cabinet-level MAC said Wednesday in a statement.

Regarding the Beijing-based Taiwan Affairs Office Director Chen Yunlin's plan to take part in an economic forum in Taipei with main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) officials, the MAC said that it will leave the case to be decided in compliance with the law by the authority in charge.

The Bureau of Immigration under the Ministry of the Interior decided on Nov. 18 to turn down Chen's visa application, filed by the KMT's National Policy Foundation, in a screening meeting out of consideration of the current state of cross-Taiwan Strait relations and international norms.

As Chen's visit to Taiwan would carry a great deal of political connotation, Taiwan had made it clear that official negotiations between the two sides were indispensable to adequately deal with the case, the MAC said.

A Taiwan Affairs Office spokesman called on Taiwan authorities earlier the same day to provide necessary assistance to make Chen's visit possible, as the Communist Party of China (CPC) and the KMT would hold the economic forum as scheduled in Taipei.

A report saying that the forum would be held in another place is incorrect, and Beijing has learned that a KMT thinktank has submitted an admistrative petition asking the government on Taiwan to rethink its refusal of Chen's visit, the spokesman said.

At the head of scores of Taiwan Affairs Office officials, Chen was previously slated to participate in the forum in Taipei on Dec. 15 -- an agreement reached between the KMT and the CPC early this year when former KMT Chairman Lien Chan paid a historic visit to China.
Meanwhile, Bureau of Immigration officials said that they will hold a meeting to discuss the petition on Dec. 19.
The bureau received the administrative petition on Dec. 12, which was filed by the National Policy Foundation on Dec. 7, the officials noted.
KMT Mainland Affair Department Director Chang Jung-kung urged the government to think the issue over now that the Dec. 3 local government elections have ended.

DOC.HEADLINE: TUNA ASSOCIATION ACCEPTS COMPENSATION PROPOSED BY GOVERNMENT

TEXT.P: Officials of the Taiwan Tuna Association said Wednesday that they will bite the bullet and accept the compensation proposed by the government for the tuna fishing boats forced to suspend their operations, although they are not satisfied with the arrangement.

The officials made the remarks following the decision made by the Legislative Yuan that the government should pay each tuna fishing boat which is forced to suspend their operations an annual compensation of NT$7.5 million (US$224,820) , up from the original NT$5.97 million.

The Legislative Yuan made the decision after the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna (ICCAT) decided in its annual meeting in November that Taiwan's bigeye tuna fishing quota in the Atlantic Ocean be cut from 14,900 tons in 2005 to 4,600 tons for next year, under the proposal by Japan who claimed that Taiwanese tuna fishing boats are overfishing.
Under the new ICCAT regulations, only 15 of Taiwan's tuna fishing boats operating in the Atlantic Ocean will be allowed to continue their operations.
An additional 20 of the vessels will fish for longfin tuna instead, and the remaining 42 should suspend operations or have their boats dismantled.
According to the Taiwan Tuna Association, approximately NT$14 million or NT$15 million would be sufficient to compensate the tuna fishing boats affected by the new international regulations.
Huang Chao-chin, chief of Taiwan Tuna Association, said that now that the government has made the decision, boat owners can do little but accept the situation.

Noting that many tuna fishing companies just own one boat each, Huang said the new ruling will affect their livelihood, stressing that it will be the coldest winter ever for the domestic tuna industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LAWMAKERS SHARE DIFFERING OPINIONS ON U.S. MILITARY PROCUREMENT

TEXT.P: The long-stalled U.S. arms procurement package could be put forward in a regular annual military budget instead of a special one, two opposition Kuomintang (KMT) lawmakers said Wednesday.

KMT Legislator Ting Shou-chung said that it would be acceptable for the annual military budget to be increased to 3 percent of GDP, and the planned special military budget for the long-stalled arms procurement package could be integrated into the military's regular budget plan.
KMT Legislator Shuai Hua-Ming said that he would also be happy to see the annual military budget be increased to 3 percent of GDP.
"We have had a shortfall in our annual military budget for a long time. It would have been better if the budget money was spent on national defense rather than on elections," he said.

The U.S. weapons procurement package has yet to even be reviewed in a legislative committee because of opposition by the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party, which has a slight majority in the legislature.

It was reported that the U.S. government is no longer asking that the military procurement pass the legislature as an entire package, adding that Taiwan should increase its annual military budget to more than 3 percent of GDP as a substitute plan.
However, two other KMT legislators, Pan Wei-Kang and Su Chi, were cool about the proposal.
Pan said that it will be up to the Executive Yuan to decide on the ratio of increased spending if the special military budget is to be changed to an annual conventional budget.

Su doubted that the U.S. would interfere that much in Taiwan's internal affairs and he suspects that some people are bluffing on this issue. He said that a U.S. official he met in October this year briefed him on the background of the procurement plan and he thinks that the U.S. respects Taiwan's decision on the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: To Halt Abuses, U.S. Will Inspect Jails Run by Iraq
American military officers will inspect hundreds of detention centers and embed with Iraqi police commando units and other Interior Ministry forces to try to halt widespread abuses uncovered by raids on two Iraqi-run detention centers in Baghdad in the last month, American Ambassador Zalmay Khalilzad pledged Tuesday. he said at a news conference that "over 100" of the 169 detainees whom American troops found on Nov. 15 in an Interior Ministry bunker in the Jadriya neighborhood had been abused, a far higher figure than the Americans had previously disclosed. In the second raid last week, on another makeshift detention center run by a notorious police commando unit, the Wolf Brigade, as many as 26 of the 625 detainees jammed into the overcrowded center had been abused.
Wall Street Journal: Cold War Echo, U.S. Weighs Whether to Build Some New Nuclear Warheads
Some 15 years after the Cold War, and at a time when the U.S. is demanding others restrain their nuclear ambitions, the Bush administration thinks that the U.S. needs new nuclear weapons. With little notice, it has been pressing Congress to fund research into a new generation of nuclear weapons. awmakers have twice turned down proposals to design a new nuclear "bunker-buster" bomb, to blow up buried caches of weapons. But last month, with little debate, Congress approved US$25 million for research into what is supposed to be a sturdier, more reliable warhead than those designed during the Cold War. If the work is successful, the U.S. could someday spend billions of dollars replacing much of the current arsenal.

DOC.HEADLINE: WITH PUBLIC MANDATE, ANY FORM OF CROSS-STRAIT TIES POSSIBLE: CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reiterated Wednesday that with public mandate, the two sides of the Taiwan Strait could develop any form of relations in the future.
Chen made the remarks while meeting with a delegation from the Atlantic Council of the United States.

Reiterating that Taiwan is an independent sovereign state and by no means subject to the jurisdiction of China, Chen said that with the consent of the 23 million Taiwan people, any form of cross-strait ties is possible in the future.
During the meeting, Chen also emphasized the importance of democracy, saying that if Taiwan were to accept the "one country, two systems" formula, it could lose its hard-fought liberal democracy.

Over the past five years, Chen said he has on numerous occasions held out olive branches in hopes of normalizing bilateral ties. Past experiences showed that it's extremely difficult to push for normalization of cross-strait ties, Chen said, because the Chinese people have traditionally attached great importance to the name or designation.

The Chinese government in Beijing would not recognize that Taiwan is a sovereign state officially named as the Republic of China, Chen said, adding that for China, the ROC has been annihilated and Taiwan is part of the People's Republic of China.
Chen said the Beijing cherished "one China" principle is unacceptable because it denies the ROC's continued existence as an independent sovereign country in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO HOLD CHAIRMAN BY-ELECTION JAN. 15(repeat)

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will hold a by-election Jan. 15 to elect a new party chairman to fill the post left vacant by the resignation of Su Tseng-chang, a party official said Wednesday.
DPP Secretary-General Lee Yi-yang made the announcement after a weekly meeting of the party's decision-making Central Standing Committee.
According to Lee, the DPP headquarters will organize televised debates for all by-election hopefuls.

Candidacy registration will start Dec. 16 and last through Dec. 20. A lot-drawing will be held Dec. 22 to determine the order qualified candidates' names will appear on the ballot, and party members will go to the polls Jan. 15.

Su stepped down from the DPP chairmanship immediately after the party suffered a resounding defeat in the Dec. 3 local government chief elections. Vice President Annette Lu was named to serve as the party's interim chairwoman at last Wednesday's Central Standing Committee meeting. Lu shocked her DPP fellows last Friday by expressing her intention to resign in a public statement.
At the end of the day, Lu changed her mind and agreed to remain on in the interim post at the advice of all Central Standing Committee members.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEVER USED WOMEN AS BAIT TO OBTAIN INFORMATION: NSB(repeat)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has not used women as bait to obtain intelligence information, an official of the National Security Bureau (NSB) said Wednesday, because it is "not a permissible practice."

Huang Kuang-hsun, deputy head of the NSC, made the remarks when he and other officials of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) were invited by the legislative caucus of the opposition People First Party to report on a case concerning a former senior official of the U.S. State Department.

Media reports said that Donald W. Keyser, former deputy assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, pleaded guilty Monday after being released in September 2004 and later released on bail to unlawfully removing classified United States documents from the Department of State and to two counts of making false official statements -- concealing his Taiwan trip as well as "close ties of affection" with Isabelle Cheng, an intelligence official of the NSB stationed in Washington, D.C.
Keyser who faces up to 13 years in prison, will be sentenced on Feb. 24, 2006.
FBI agents trailed Keyser in the summer of 2004 and found him meeting with Cheng frequently at restaurants around Washington, D.C. and exchanging papers with her.
He was charged with lying about his trip to Taiwan on Sept. 15, 2004 and retired from the State Department 15 days later.

Huang, who was a former NSB representative to the U.S. before transferring to his present post in August 2005, said that he has reported the case to David Ta-wei Lee, the Republic of China representative to the U.S.
Lee asked him to cooperate fully with the United States to help clarify the case.

Lee, after communicating with the U.S. State Department and lawyers, believed that communication between nations was essential and this is why Taiwan handed over to the U.S. the records of Keyser's talks with Taiwan officials, Huang said.
Huang said that the U.S. only has the information that Taiwan's Representative Office has supplied it.

It is very unlikely that the U.S. court displayed the copies of the top secret documents from Taiwan as reports have said, Huang said, adding that the U.S. has also not taken the initiative to ask Taiwan to supply information.

Hsieh Wu-chiao, deputy director-general of the Department of North American Affairs, said that MOFA's stance is that it is not appropriate for it to comment on the case, which is a judicial case in the U.S.
The bottom line of the ministry is that this entire affair will not be detrimental to bilateral relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Dec. 15, or the 15th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1891: The Bill of Rights, the first 10 amendments to the U.S. Constitution, goes into effect.
1915: Noted Taiwan folklore writer Chung Li-ho is born.
1920: China and Austria are admitted into the League of Nations.
1927: The Republic of China government orders the closure of the Soviet consulate in Shanghai and begins rounding up communists following an attempted communist coup in Canton the day before.
1931: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman and premier of the Nationalist government, retires, citing the interests of party unity as the reason for his move.
1938: The United States agrees to lend US$25 million to China under a Sino-American oil loan agreement.
1944: Chinese expeditionary forces capture Bhamo in northern Burma.
1946: The U.N. General Assembly decides to set up its permanent headquarters in New York City.
1948: France completes the construction of its first nuclear reactor.
1949: The ROC Executive Yuan names Wu Kuo-chen as governor of Taiwan.
1952: Beijing rejects India's plan for a Korean armistice.
1961: The U.N. General Assembly votes against a Soviet proposal to admit Communist China as a member.
1965: The U.S. Mariner spacecraft flies past Venus and relays data about the planet to scientists on Earth.
1966: Walter Elias Disney -- the U.S. animator, showman and film producer known as "Walt" -- dies at the age of 65.
1970: The first Sino-American Conference on Mainland China is opened in Taipei.
1971: The state-run Bank of China becomes a private bank and changes its name to the International Commercial Bank of China.
1972: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with the Malagasy Republic.
1972: The Japanese embassies in Taipei and Kaohsiung are closed.
1973: Tachien Dam, which had been under construction in central Taiwan for four years, becomes operational.
1977: A newly built integrated steel plant of the state-run China Steel Corp. starts operating in Kaohsiung.
1978: U.S. President Jimmy Carter announces that he will establish diplomatic relations with Communist China from Jan. 1, 1979, and break off relations with the Republic of China at the same time.
1978: The "Chang Sheng," the first Taiwan-built 20,000-ton container vessel, is launched in Keelung.
1980: The ROC's Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park is inaugurated.
1988: The U.N. General Assembly overwhelmingly calls for the convening of an international Middle East peace conference.
1993: The ROC Legislative Yuan approves a revision of the University Law, giving more autonomy to colleges and allowing students to participate in meetings related to school affairs.
1995: Beijing sentences Wei Jingsheng, a noted dissident, to 14 years in jail for "conspiring to subvert the government," a move that arouses international condemnation.
1999: The U.S. State Department clarifies its stance on the ROC's bid to join the World Health Organization, saying the U.S. supports Taiwan's "meaningful participation," not its membership, in the body.
2000: Chiang Peng-chien, a member of the Control Yuan and founding chairman of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), dies of pancreatic cancer at the age of 61.
2001: The Second International Bio Science and Technology Exposition opens at the Taipei World Trade Center, with over 300 firms from home and abroad participating.
2001: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan leaves for Japan for a week-long visit, making him the first KMT chairman to visit Japan since the party moved its headquarters to Taiwan in 1950.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Think how anxious your parents are when you are sick, and you will know your duty toward them. The duty of a good son nowadays means only to be able to support his parents. But you also keep your dogs and horses alive. If there is no feeling of love and respect, where is the difference?"
