DOC.HEADLINE: INDEPENDENT LAWMAKER URGES LU TO HONOR HER FIVE COMMITMENTS

TEXT.P: Independent Legislator Chiu Yi on Thursday called on Vice President Annette Lu, who agreed to keep on as acting chairwoman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) a day earlier, to make good on her "five commitments to the people."

Chiu said Lu had promised to the people that she would form a private-sector alliance to investigate alleged corruption in connection with the construction of Kaohsiung's rapid transit system, hold a public hearing on the controversy about "unusual DVDs" allegedly aimed at besmirching Chu Li-lun, the Kuomintang's (KMT's) candidate for Taoyuan magistrate in the Dec. 3 elections, and have the DPP discipline Lin Chin-hsing, a DPP lawmaker who joined a group of medical doctors in making public the medical history of Jason Hu, the KMT's candidate for Taichung mayor in the elections.

Lu has also promised to investigate "stock playing" at the Presidential Office led by former deputy chief of staff to the president, Chen Che-nan, and to handle an alleged vote-buying incident in which DPP candidate Luo Wen-jia's supporters were filmed accepting "fees" on a bus, according to Chiu. Luo was running for Taipei County magistrate.
Chiu said that if the vice president can show courage and competency in honoring all of the five commitments, she will definitely win the public's support.
Lu on Wednesday accepted an invitation from the Central Standing Committee of the DPP to give up her earlier decision to quit as acting chairwoman.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: I was cut corners or Kimura axed contract: Aneha to Diet
Disgrced architect Hidetsuku Aneha told a Diet committee Wednesday that Akira Shinozaka, Tokyo branch manager for Kimura Construction co., specified exactly how much he should reduce the reinforcing steel in the building plans he falsified.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: Death Penalty Moratorium on the Table.
California's state legislators in early January will consider what is likely to be a contentious proposal to postpone executions for as long as three years.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP RULES DON'T BAN ACTING CHAIR FROM RUNNING: DPP SECRETARY-GENERAL

TEXT.P: All eyes are on Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Acting Chairwoman Annette Lu to see whether she runs for the party's chairmanship in the Jan. 15 election.
Precedents suggest that she won't run, but DPP Secretary-General Lee Yi-yang said Thursday that the party's rules do not prohibit an acting chief from doing so.
Lee said that those who are interested in running for the DPP chairmanship must register Dec. 16-20 after depositing a registration fee of NT$1.5 million.

Lee said he believes the upcoming chairmanship election will be a multiple-candidate race, unlike the previous election in January, 2005 when Su Tseng-chang ran uncontested. Su stepped down as chairman after the DPP was defeated in the Dec. 3 local government elections.

Legislator Chai Trong-rong, who is also a DPP Central Standing Committee member, has expressed a definite interest in running, while Legislator Lin Chung-mo has not "excluded the possibility" of joining the race. Another possible candidate, according to media reports, is Presidential Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun, but he has yet to make clear his intentions.

As for Vice President Lu, she has openly said that she has no intention of running. However, many people are not ruling her out as a possible candidate. After all, she had clearly stated Wednesday prior to the DPP Central Standing Committee (CSC) meeting that she would quit as acting chairwoman but then later emerged from the meeting and confirmed that she had accepted the CSC's invitation to stay on in the post.
Lee said the DPP is the most democratic party in Taiwan, noting that it began the tradition of electing a chairman through a direct vote by party members.
Expecting quite a heated race, Lee said the party will hold televised debates to give party members a clear picture of each of the candidates' platforms and personal styles before voting day.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE SECRETARY-GENERAL TO RUN FOR DPP CHAIRMAN: AIDE

TEXT.P: An aide to Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun confirmed Thursday that Yu will quit his current job and run for the chairmanship of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
Yu will tender his resignation to President Chen Shui-bian and announce his candidacy in the coming days, the aide said. Candidates must register between Dec. 16-20.

The aide, who asked not to be named, said Yu made the decision after being persuaded by party heaviwieghts that his personal qualities, including tolerance, will give the DPP a boost at a time when party members are feeling low as a result of the party's recent defeat in the local government elections.

After a lot of thought, Yu has decided to work to rebuild the DPP's image as a party of "political integrity and hard work" that symbolizes the Taiwan people's love of their native land, according to the aide.

Yu, who was the longest serving premier in the Chen Shui-bian government, thinks he is fit to serve in the chairman post which calls for an unselfish dedication to uniting the party in order to push ahead reform programs, the aide said.
The party is scheduled to hold a vote among party members Jan. 15 to elect the new leader. Vice President Annette Lu is currently serving as acting chairwoman of the party.

DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times : Putin Addresses ASEAN Summit
Leaders at the first Association of South East Asian Nations, or ASEAN, summit on Wednesday postponed any decision on letting Russia become a full member of the organization as President Vladimir Putin addressed the gathering.

DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: DNA Tests Exonerate 2 Former Prisoners; Va. Governor Orders Broad Case Review.
Newly tested DNA from rapes committed more than 20 years ago has exonerated two Virginians who had each spent more than a decade behind bars, reigniting a national debate about post-conviction testing of biological evidence.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKER URGES CLOSER LOOK AT UMC'S ALLEGED UNFAIR DISCLOSING OF INFO

TEXT.P: People First Party (PFP) Legislator Christina Y. Liu asked the Taiwan Stock Exchange Corp. Thursday to look into alleged "unfair disclosing of information" by United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC) in Taiwan and in the United States.

Liu said UMC had been asked by the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission to restate its financial reports for 2002-2004 but did not disclose the information to Taiwan investors. "What is the TSE going to do about this?" she asked.
If the TSE does nothing, then it will have a hard time explaining itself to Taiwan investors, she added.
In response, TSE said it will make a decision on the matter within one week.

UMC, the world's second-largest contract chip maker by revenue, had been asked by the U.S. regulator to make adjustments to its earnings reports with regard to non-cash goodwill charges, derivative instruments, and employee stock bonuses.

UMC said before the market opened in Taiwan Wednesday that its financial reports of the previous three years comply with the U.S. Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP) but that there are errors in parts of the footnotes, so the company will restate them.
TSE Vice President Chiu Chin-ting said UMC could have taken greater initiative to make this known in Taiwan earlier and faster. "We will discuss this with UMC," he added.
Market analysts said UMC has confirmed that the changes in the three years' earnings reports will not affect its reports to Taiwan's regulator, nor will they affect future earnings.
However, the analysts noted that UMC had issued press releases only in the United States to explain the matter, without telling Taiwan investors anything about it.

In view of the fact that UMC's ADR (American Depositary Receipts) price fell in the wake of the announcement, which in turn could affect its stock price listed on the Taiwan market, closer scrutiny of UMC's integrity and trustworthiness is warranted, they added.
UMC stock closed at NT$18.10 Thursday, up NT$0.2 from the previous session's close.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO BUILD AIRPORT IN SPRATLYS

TEXT.P: Vice Minister of National Defense Huo Shou-yeh confirmed Thursday that the government will build an airport on one of the biggest islets of the disputed Spratly Islands in the South China Sea.

However, Hou emphasized that the airport to be located on Taiping Island is not intended for military use but instead for humanitarian purposes such as emergency rescue efforts by the Coast Guard for sick or injured sailors or fishermen.
Hou was responding to questions by legislators during a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's National Defense Committee.

Hou said that the plan to build the airport has been proposed by the Coast Guard Administration (CGA) and that the Ministry of National Defense (MND) will assist by sending soldiers there for the construction work.
According to Hou, the airport will only be equipped with simple facilities, including a 1,150-meter runway and a control tower.

He pointed out that the airport will only be capable of handling the takeoff and landing of C130 aircraft, and not other military aircraft, fighters or anti-submarine aircraft, so the airport will not pose any military threat to the surrounding islets.

The Spratly Islands, which consist of more than 100 small islands or reefs surrounded by rich fishing grounds and oil deposits, are claimed either entirely or partially by Taiwan, China, Vietnam, Malaysia and the Philippines.
Taiwan, China, Malaysia, the Philippines and Vietnam have stationed small numbers of military forces on some of the islands.

Expressing his disapproval with the government's plan to build an airport on Taiping Island, opposition Kuomintang Legislator Su Chi said the move is unnecessary because it is likely to trigger an international dispute in light of the sensitive strategic and political implications involving the Spratlys.

Su said he will demand that the MND deliver a special report on the issue to the legislature and that he will also investigate whether the true purpose behind building the airport is different from that stated by the MND and whether the plan is being financed by a secret budget.

During a separate meeting of the legislature's Home and Nations Committee, CGA Director-General Shi Hwei-yow said that it is necessary for the government to build the airport to serve practical needs and to defend Taiwan's sovereignty claim over the Spratlys and its fishing rights in waters near the islands.

Shi pointed out that the government currently has 200 Coast Guard officers stationed on Taiping Island, which is located 861 nautical miles from Taiwan, and that it takes eight days and costs NT$40 million in fuel expenses for the Coast Guard to carry out one resupplying mission by sea between Taiwan and Taiping Island.
Although there is a landing pad for helicopters on the 0.49 square-kilometer Taiping Island, helicopters cannot fly the long distance between Taiwan and the island, Shi said.

He said the plan to build the airport was first included in the Ministry of the Interior's policy guidelines on the Spratlys in 1993, adding that China and Malaysia have competed to build airports on islands or reefs of the Spratlys in recent years to affirm their sovereignty claims.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT'S MA CALLS FOR 'BENEVOLENT COMPETITION' AMONG MAJOR PARTIES

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou Thursday said Taiwan's two major political parties should work to unite their respective members and then engage in a fair competition with each other so that party politics will develop in a healthy environment.
Ma made the remarks while urging President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu to show self-restraint and stop their war of words for the sake of the country.
The nation has been taken aback over the past few days as the two top leaders issued one statement after another taking jabs at each other in the wake of their party's election defeat on Dec. 3.

Some observers, who saw a rare chance of redirecting Taiwan's party politics on the road of healthy development, said if parties can engage in "benevolent competition" in Taiwan, it will also be able to engage in a "benevolent cycle" of interactions with China. Otherwise, they worried cross-strait exchanges will fall into a vicious circle.

Ma said the ruling party has a duty to create a good environment to develop party politics in the nation, and if the DPP leadership does not know the Chinese saying that a harmonious family will thrive and begin to do some real soul-searching about why they failed in the latest elections, people will be disappointed.

He said he would not make any comment on the commotion inside the ruling camp but he noted that the KMT, as the main opposition party, must stand firm and take the initiative in putting forward good policy proposals that, if enacted into law, will benefit all of the people.
Ma stressed that he was not gloating over the ruling party's troubles, adding that he was just making his suggestions in his capacity as an opposition leader and a private citizen.

He made the remarks after attending a meeting of the KMT's legislative caucus, the first such meeting after the elections in which his party won 14 out of 23 county and city government seats against the DPP's six.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 23.12 points to close at 6,258.47.
The bourse opened at 6,240.37 and fluctuated between 6,227.25 and 6,259.21 during trading. A total of 2.92 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$74.34 billion (US$2.24 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues moving up the most at 0.9 percent, followed by machinery and electronics shares at 0.6 percent, cement stocks at 0.4 percent, construction issues at 0.2 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares at 0.1 percent.

The three other major stock categories lost ground, with textile stocks moving down the most at 0.5 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues and banking and financial shares both losing 0.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 555 to 419, with 227 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHIEF HOLDS OUT HOPE OF NEW STRATEGY FOR LEGISLATIVE CAUCUS

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday he expects the party's legislative caucus to take a new strategy during the rest of the legislative session to avoid the repeat of fierce partisan fighting which brought the legislature grinding to a halt.

After a meeting with the KMT legislative caucus in the Legislative Yuan, Ma told waiting journalists that the domestic political landscape is changed somewhat after the Dec. 3 elections in which the KMT won 14 of the 23 posts of county and city chiefs up for grabs, and the KMT caucus should adjust their approach in its dealings with bills at the legislature accordingly.

The KMT chief said he hopes KMT lawmakers will deal with bills on their merits and compete with other parties in the legislature to better serve the people, adding that partisan bickering with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party should be avoided.

Given the party's overwhelming victory in the Dec. 3 elections, Ma said the KMT must live up to the mandate its voters gave them by giving leadership both at the level of the local governments and in the legislature despite the fierce in-fighting in the ruling Democratic Progressive Party after the elections.
He urged the KMT caucus to work together with its political allies in the Legislative Yuan in initiating bills needed by the people and help shape the country's policy.

The priority for the time being, Ma said, is a revision of the act governing the relations between the peoples of Taiwan and the mainland, and the submission of the party's own version of revisions to the pension system for civil servants, including the controversial 18 percent interest rate on civil servants' bank savings.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN CALLS FOR STRENGTHENED UNITY WITHIN 'PAN-BLUE ALLIANCE'

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou Thursday called for strengthened unity within the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party (PFP) , because the alliance's majority in the legislature has become very flimsy after four KMT legislators were elected local government heads in the Dec. 3 elections.
Ma made the remarks at his first meeting with members of the KMT legislative caucus after the KMT's landslide victory over the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the elections.

He said that although the KMT's victory in the elections cost the party four seats in the legislature, the win was worthwhile because the four KMT lawmakers-turned local government heads -- three county magistrates and one mayor -- will have 5.8 million people under their jurisdiction, accounting for 26 percent of Taiwan's population.

The four outgoing KMT legislators who will be sworn in Dec. 20 to assume their new posts are: Chou Hsi-wei, who will become Taipei County magistrate; Liu Cheng-hung, who will be Miaoli County magistrate; Cho Po-yuan, who will serve as Changhua County magistrate; and Huang Min-hui, who will be mayor of Chiayi City.

Ma also said that he agreed with PFP Chairman James Soong in their Dec. 12 meeting that the priorities for "pan-blue alliance" cooperation in the legislature will be to push for legislation to promote people-to-people relations across the Taiwan Strait, seek membership for Taiwan in the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, and introduce a reformed plan to offer a favorable interest rate to retired servicemen, public servants and public school teachers for their pension savings.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Italy central bank governor Fazio under new pressure to resign.
Italy central bank governor Antonio Fazio was under new pressure to resign after a prosecutor of the Milano court placed him together with 36 others under investigation Wednesday for allegedly involved in suspected embezzlements of Banca Popolare Italiana (BPI) . Former BPI chief executive Gianpiero Fiorani, who is a family friend of Fazio, was arrested a day earlier for alleged association to commit crime.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, dropping NT$0.137 to close at NT$33.225.
A total of US$1.15 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at NT$33.362 and fluctuated between NT$33.205 and NT$33.450.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT REITERATES ADMINISTRATION'S CORE VALUES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reiterated Thursday Taiwan's separate identity, democratic reform and clean governance as the core values of his administration.

Speaking to a group of former political prisoners who were jailed during the period of martial law from 1949 to 1987 when the Kuomintang was in power, Chen vowed to stick to the above three principles.

The president, whose Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) performed poorly in the Dec. 3 local government elections, said his whole ruling team, including "the administration, the DPP and myself", should re-examine their performance, learn lessons from the defeat and mend their ways.
However, Chen said, the ruling team will not be daunted by the elections failure and will not deviate from its core values.
Chen said it is the common belief among the 23 million of Taiwan that their country is sovereign and has its own identity separate from that of China.

"Only by stressing Taiwan's identity can we get on our feet, move forward in politics, economy and society, and break the political stalemate with Beijing and look forward to the normalization of ties with China," the president said.

On sticking with democratic reform, the president urged the people in Taiwan not to look down upon the island's hard-earned democracy which serves as a beacon for the mainland Chinese people, noting that U.S. President George W. Bush said in a speech in Kyoto, Japan Nov. 16 that Taiwan can be held up as a model of democracy for China.
Chen also stressed that he won't relax his insistence on clean governance by his administration which he said is one of the most urgent demands of the people.

"There may be some people in the ruling team who had failed to live up to the people's expectations, but the DPP and the ruling team are capable of self-examination and are not afraid of mending their ways by facing up to their mistakes." the president said.
He promised to make restoring the administration's clean image a priority in any Cabinet reshuffle in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for December moved up 55 points to close at 6,270, with 21,871 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for January moved up 53 points to end at 6,270, with 2,267 contracts traded, while March futures gained 45 points to finish at 6,265, with 13 contracts traded. June futures moved up 32 points to close at 6,230, with seven contracts traded, while September futures moved up 19 points to close at 6,100, with six contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 6,215 for December, 6,217 for January, 6,220 for March, 6,198 for June and 6,081 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly higher.

December TE futures moved up 2.8 points to close at 274.2, with 3,750 contracts traded, while January TE futures gained 2.85 points to finish at 274, with 461 contract transactions. March TE futures moved up 6.65 points to end at 273.45, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for June and September.

December TF futures gained one point to finish at 879, with 841 contracts changing hands, while January TF futures moved up 2.2 points to end at 880.2, with 182 contracts traded. March TF futures moved down 0.4 points to close at 879.6, with two contract transactions, while September TF futures gained 5.4 points to finish at 873, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for June.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW BTCO DIRECTOR GENERAL TO ARRIVE IN TAIWAN FRIDAY

TEXT.P: The British Trade and Cultural Office (BTCO) said Thursday that their new director general, Michael Reilly, will arrive in Taipei Friday and will formally take up his post Monday.

Reilly is succeeding Derek Marsh who left the post Dec. 9. Reilly served in posts at the British Embassy in Seoul and Manila, also at the British Delegation to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development in Paris.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEADERS OF DPP AND KMT COULD MEET FOR DISCUSSIONS: MA YING-JEOU

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday he does not rule out the possibility of meeting with Vice President Annette Lu, who doubles as acting chairwoman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
Ma, who concurrently serves as Taipei mayor, made the remarks after attending a meeting of the KMT legislative caucus.

Embroiled in a hostile standoff with the DPP, the KMT and its "pan-blue alliance" ally -- the People First Party -- have used their joint slim majority in the legislature to boycott the DPP administration's policy initiatives at nearly every turn over the past five years. Since Ma took the KMT helm this past August, observers have been watching whether the domestic political impasse can be overcome.

Asked whether he is willing to meet with Lu, Ma said he has not received any information about the prospects for a KMT-DPP meeting. For his part, Ma said he doesn't rule out the possibility of meeting with Lu.

After some twists and turns, Lu will definitely serve as DPP acting chairwoman until after a new party leader is elected in mid-January to fill the post left vacant by the resignation of Su Tseng-chang in the wake of the DPP's humiliating defeat in the Dec. 3 local chiefs elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKER CALLS FOR CONTINUED BAN ON BEEF IMPORTS FROM U. S.

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Legislator Chen Chao-jong asked the government Thursday to maintain the ban on all beef imports from the United States.

Speaking at a news conference at the Legislative Yuan, Chen also asked Department of Health (DOH) officials to sign a four-point pledge vowing not to allow such imports from countries affected by mad cow disease.

Pointing out that more than 60 countries around the world, including Japan and South Korea, have banned U.S. beef imports since the first case of locally acquired mad cow disease in that country in 2003, Chen said that the government still decided to lift the ban on U.S. beef imports in April this year before reimposing it in June after a second case of mad cow disease was detected in the United States.
Chen accused the government of being extremely rash in the decision-making process, totally ignoring professional assessments and lacking risk management.

He suggested that the government, like Japan, send veterinary officials to collect information in mad cow disease affected areas and strictly restrict all beef and beef product imports from affected countries. He also called for a full crackdown on smuggling.

The PFP lawmaker asked the DOH to stand up against political pressure from the United States and evaluate whether to re-open the Taiwan market to U.S. beef based on the principles of "professionalism, safety and health. " He claimed that any person in Taiwan would be entitled to government compensation if they were to develop mad cow disease after eating U.S. beef.
However, no DOH officials signed the four-point pledge whose contents they said lacks a sound scientific basis.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEARLY HALF OF TAIWAN FIRMS SEE NO NEED FOR NEW BLOOD IN SHORT TERM

TEXT.P: Nearly half of all Taiwan companies have no need to recruit new blood in the first half of next year, according to the results of a recent survey.

The results of the survey of 1,405 Taiwan companies conducted by a human resources consultancy firm show that some 46 percent of the companies questioned said that they would maintain their current workforce levels into the first half of next year. About 28 percent said that they would hire more workers over the next six months, while 6 percent said that they would scale back their workforce during the same period.

By sector, financial and real-estate companies will have the strongest demand for more workers for the first six months of next year, followed by those in manufacturing, services, wholesale and transportation, according to the survey. The mining and construction industries will have the lowest demand.

Business owners in Taiwan, the United States, Australia and New Zealand will have greater demand for more workers, while those in Austria, Germany and Italy will see a drop in demand for manpower, the human resources consultancy firm said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CALLS PUBLIC'S ATTENTION TO CHINA'S POOR HUMAN RIGHTS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged the public Thursday not to overly romanticize China's economic growth and overlook Beijing's inferior human rights record while engaging in exchange activities with China.
According to Chen, China has jailed the largest number of journalists, and the recent shooting of protesters by armed police near Shanwei, Guangdong province is definitely not an isolated incident.

"Although it remains unclear as to how many casualties there were, international media generally believes this is the most serious human rights violation in which violence was used openly to crack down on the public since the 1989 Tiananmen Square Massacre, " Chen said.
"This is evidence of China's brutal and unstable nature against democracy and human rights," he added.
Chen said the incident has also raised an alarm for democracies around the world that the rise of China is shadowed by the persecution of human rights and suppression of democracy.

The president was speaking to a group of victims of political persecution during the martial law era who were invited to the Presidential Office to watch a documentary on the so-called "white terror" period.
Chen said economic prosperity and human rights protection should be equally essential.

Taiwan created the world-acclaimed economic miracle during the past authoritarian rule, but behind the splendid economic achievements, many people were leading a miserable life and had to fight the authoritarian rulers with their tears and blood, he said.
He said no civilized society can tolerate such a situation, which became the strongest momentum driving the people in Taiwan to pursue freedom and democracy.

On Dec. 3, the Taiwan people again exercised their right as the masters of the country with their votes, and every individual and political party must accept the outcome of the elections unconditionally regardless of whether they are happy about it or not, he said.

While the elections held regularly in Taiwan are taken for granted by the people here, the right to elect their leaders and representatives remains unreachable to the people in some countries today, he noted.
For example, he said, 250,000 Hong Kong residents took to the streets on Dec. 4 to demand universal suffrage to elect the chief executive and Legislative Council of the Special Administrative Region.

"By comparison, Taiwan's people should feel fortunate and proud to be able to enjoy freedom and democracy, " he said. "The biggest difference between Taiwan and Hong Kong and China does not lie in the extent of their economic development but in the respect paid to the dignity and rights that people deserve," he added.

While the power of the government is derived from the people's approval in Taiwan, the rights of the people are granted by the government in Hong Kong and China, he said, adding that the gap between Taiwan and China will widen further if the situation is not changed.

Having made many economic achievements since adopting a policy of openness in the 1980s, Beijing, however, has not relaxed its suppression against the pursuit of freedom, democracy and human rights by its people, who thus far do not enjoy the freedom to choose their leader or freedom of speech, assembly and religion, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL PALACE MUSEUM VOTED BEST OF TOP 10 MUSEUMS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The National Palace Museum has been voted the best of Taipei's top 10 museums, according to results of a month-long poll announced by the Taipei City Government Thursday.

Altogether, 11,502 votes were collected in the poll, conducted by the city government's Department of Information. The National Palace Museum received 47 percent of the votes, topping all other museums in Taipei. There are more than 80 museums in the city.

The National Palace Museum is often grouped with the Louvre of France, the British Museum and the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York as the four best museums in the world. Its collection of 650,000 items spanning more than 5,000 years consists of Chinese artifacts made of jade, bronze, porcelain, lacquerware and enamel. There are also tapestries, embroideries, many priceless documents, books, paintings and calligraphic scrolls.

Placed second in the poll was the Shung Ye Museum of Formosan Aborigines, which received 37 percent of the votes, followed by the National Taiwan Science Education Center, with 32 percent of the votes.

The rest in the top 10 list from fourth place are the Taipei Fine Arts Museum, the Taipei Astronomical Museum, the National Museum of History, the National Taiwan Museum, the Water Museum, the Postal Museum and the Miniatures Museum of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENGAGE WITH CHINA TO AVOID TAIWAN MARGINALIZATION: PFP HEAD
DOC.DATELINE: Kuala Lumpur, Dec. 15 (CNA) (By Charles Kang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The key to avoiding Taiwan from being marginalized is to engage with China, the head of Taiwan's opposition People First Party (PFP) said in Malaysia Thursday.

Speaking during the Perdanam Global Peace Forum hosted by former Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, PFP Chairman James Soong said that as new economic and political blocs in Asia take shape with China playing increasingly important roles, the only option for Taiwan to avoid being relegated to the sidelines is to improve cross-Taiwan Strait relations.

Taiwan, which has in the past maintained closed economic and trade ties with member states of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), particularly Malaysia, Singapore and Thailand, is finding it has fewer and fewer bargain chips in its maneuvering space in the region after China's rise and the growth of Chinese influence, Soong said.

In the past, Soong said, many Asian countries sought at meetings of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum to engage in bilateral consultations with Taiwan for closer economic and trade ties, but nowadays they have turned to China.

Taking Malaysia as an example, Soong said, when he visited the country two years ago, then-outgoing Prime Minister Mahathir and his deputy, Abdullah Ahmad Badawi, who is now prime minister, both told him that it was impossible for Malaysia to recognize Taiwan or the Republic of China politically, but stressed their hope that Taiwan- Malaysia economic and trade relations would grow.

Given that much has changed over the past two years, Soong said, China has become the world's factory and the world's market and has attracted many Asian countries because of its economy. Malaysia's two-way trade with Taiwan used to be larger than that with China, but now Malaysia is trading with China in volumes much bigger than those with Taiwan now, he added.
This situation is quite worrisome for Taiwan, Soong stressed.

Taiwan will face even more serious problems once the "ASEAN plus China, Japan and South Korea" process is materialized, Soong said, adding that tariffs will be the first problem for Taiwan as all the member states in the new bloc will have duty free privileges. Taiwan's competitiveness will automatically slide since its exported products to the "ASEAN plus three" member states will be much more expensive with tariffs, he said.

Soong maintained that the Taiwan authorities should seek to be on better terms with the Beijing leadership, who, he claimed, told him during his visit in Beijing this past summer that so long as Taiwan does not seek de jure independence, China would allow Taiwan to enjoy "a certain extent of maneuvering space" in the international community.

He called for member states of the "ASEAN plus three" to allow Taiwan to participate in the proposed free trade bloc in a formula similar to that of the World Trade Organization so that Taiwan will not be marginalized in the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FLAT PANEL DISPLAYS INDUSTRY BOOMING: IEK

TEXT.P: The output value of Taiwan's flat panel displays is estimated at NT$840.6 billion for 2005, up by 17.6 percent over the 2004 figure, according to the Industrial Economics and Knowledge Center (IEK) under the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI).

The figure for 2006 is forecast to grow over the NT$1 trillion (US$30.1 billion) mark, beating the government's target of turning the industry into one of Taiwan's hi-tech business with an annual production value over the NT$1 trillion level, ITRI officials said.

According to DisplaySearch statistics, Taiwan's flat panel display industry will see its production volume in the fourth quarter exceed South Korea's level for the first time, giving it the largest share in the world market.

Amid high expectations that the domestic industry will continue expanding, foreign-based material and equipment suppliers are flocking to invest in the science parks in central and southern Taiwan to directly provide local firms with what they need.

With increased integration between upstream and downstream companies at home, the domestic industry is expected to further flourish in 2006 on strong global demand for notebook computers, LCD TVs and portable electronic devices, a DisplaySearch executive said.

Although Taiwan has managed to outshine South Korea in flat panel display production capability, the domestic industry lacks core manufacturing technologies -- a bottleneck that it must overcome, industry sources said.

Experts suggest Taiwan companies build their own distinguished brand names, engage in research and development and improve post-sales services to sharpen their competitive edges in the face of fierce competition from Japan and South Korea.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2005 EUROPEAN FILM FESTIVAL TO START FRIDAY IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The 2005 European Film Festival will be held in Taipei's Majestic Theater Dec. 16-19, showing 10 recent award-winning films, each from a different country.

The 2005 European Film Festival is co-organized by the European Economic and Trade Office (EETO) , and coordinated by Infine Art and Culture Exchange and sponsored by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) as well as the Taipei City Government's Cultural Affairs Department.

Since 2003, the European Association of Film Festivals based in Brussels, Belgium, has launched the "Window on Europe" project aimed at promoting a new generation of talented young European directors. The project selected more than 200 films all over Europe. However, French movies are not on the show list this year.

Director-General of the MOFA's Department of European Affairs Larry Wang Yu-yuan said during a speech at the festival's opening ceremony that more and more people in Taiwan are applying for visas to European countries, which, in a sense, brings Europe closer to Taiwan.
"In the past, it was very difficult to watch European movies in Taiwan. But now, they have become quite popular as the DVDs can easily be bought here," Wang said.

According to Infine Art and Culture, 20 percent to 30 percent of the tickets have already been sold online. "We are targeting a rather young audience aged between 20 and 35. They are more likely to accept these kind of films," a spokesman of Infine said.

The 10 films, featuring a wide range of topics, will be shown in 20 sessions during the four days of the festival. They were produced in Italy, Slovenia, Germany, Sweden, Finland, Ireland, Belgium, Netherlands, the United Kingdom and Hungary. They will be subtitled in Chinese and English.

DOC.HEADLINE: SELECT SEX OFFENDERS ON PAROLE WILL BE FITTED WITH MONITORING DEVICES

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice has purchased hi-tech equipment to monitor and track sex offenders, a ministry spokesman said Thursday.
According to the spokesman, the ministry is slated to fully implement the program in June 2006 to better protect women from sexual attacks.

The 150 sets of devices, which use automatic Radio Frequency IDentification (RFID) that are placed in ordinary objects like a wrist watch or a bracelet, will be the first batch of its kind in Taiwan, the spokesman explained.

A law amendment approved in February this year allows for those convicted of sex crimes to be released on bail or parole if they are wearing RFID monitoring devices under certain circumstances and with a permit granted by prosecution authorities, the spokesman said, noting that a watch-like or bracelet-like object is designed not to label the criminals in public.

The devices are locally developed and the ministry has acquired them through a public bidding process that began in February and wrapped up two days ago, he noted, adding that the products have not yet been mass produced for the time being.

The ministry may also upgrade the RFID equipment by combining GPS technologies, which would enable long distance monitoring. This would first be tested to gauge its effect on human rights and personal safety, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'RICE BOMBER' PLAYED BADMINTON ON THIRD DAY OF HUNGER STRIKE: MOJ

TEXT.P: Yang Ju-men, also known as the "rice bomber" for planting explosive devises around northern Taiwan in protest of rice imports, showed no ill effects Thursday, halfway through his planned six-day hunger strike at the Taipei Detention Center, an official with the Ministry of Justice said.
On the contrary, Yang has been energetic and even played badminton with another inmate Thursday, said Cheng An-hsiung, director-general of the ministry's department of corrections.

Yang chose to begin his six-day hunger strike Tuesday as representatives from the World Trade Organization (WTO) met in Hong Kong to show his displeasure with the WTO's "exploitation of the disadvantaged."
Detention center authorities told Cheng that they are closely monitoring Yang's condition and if necessary, they will force-feed him.

Professor Fang Sheng-ping of National Tsinghua University read a statement by Yang Tuesday that said the 144-hour hunger strike is to show that Yang is concerned about the current uncertainties surrounding Taiwan's agriculture sector.

Yang told detention center authorities Thursday he was only expressing his fear for Taiwan farmers, and did not mean to make trouble for the employees of the detention facility. He also asked that the media not sensationalize his hunger strike.

Yang's supporters announced Tuesday they will launch a "save Taiwan's agriculture" campaign in Taipei Dec. 16-17. Yang was convicted in his first trial on charges of threatening public security for placing bombs at several public locations. Yang admitted to the crime, saying that he wanted to raise public awareness of the plight of Taiwan's farmers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BECOMING BETTER FOR NATIVE ENGLISH-SPEAKING PEOPLE: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's overall living environment for native English-speaking people made progress in 2005, according to results of a survey released Thursday by the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission under the Cabinet.

The survey, conducted for the commission by Shih Hsin University between Sept. 3 and Oct. 31, interviewed 1,098 foreigners living in Taiwan and 1,068 foreigners who were in Taiwan for a short stay. They were questioned about how satisfied they were with various aspects of life in Taiwan during 2005.
Statistics showed that in the view of these respondents, the overall living environment in Taiwan for native English-speaking people during 2005 saw a 12.3 percent improvement over 2004.
Health services topped other areas, with a 17.5 percent improvement compared with last year, followed by shopping, with an improvement of 14.88 percent.

The satisfaction rate for Taiwan's government organizations rose 14.23 percent, while financial organizations saw their evaluation rise 14.1 percent in providing conveniences to English-speaking people.
The survey also showed that some of the general complaints by English-speaking people include taxi drivers being unable to speak English and bus stop signs that do not provide information in English.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PORTRAITS TAIWAN' DOCUMENTARY SHOWCASES TAIWAN'S VIGOR, SPIRIT

TEXT.P: "Choreography is a fascinating adventure. I don't know where it will lead. The Cloud Gate Dance Theatre owes its origin to blind passion."

This is the prologue Lin Hwai-min, founder of the world-renowned dance troupe, gives in an episode of a special series of programs to be aired on the Discovery Channel from Dec. 25 to showcase Taiwan's vigor and can-do spirit.
The film series, dubbed "Portraits Taiwan, " documents prominent figures from Taiwan with funds provided by the Government Information Office (GIO).
Speaking at the series' world premiere at the Sheraton Taipei Hotel, Lin said he hopes that the six-installment series will offer the world a glimpse into the beauty and bright side of Taiwan.
Also present at the ceremony were GIO Minister Pasuya Yao, Discovery Networks Asia Executive Vice President and Managing Director Tom Keaveny, and four of the six celebrities featured in the series.
Yao said the "Portraits Taiwan" project is part of the government's efforts to let the world come to understand that Taiwan is a country full of promise and opportunities.

Moreover, Yao said the project teams the GIO and Discovery Channel to allow for more exchanges between Taiwan's documentary filmmakers and international media. Six teams of local directors, screen-writers and producers were enlisted to produce the films under the Discovery Channel's stringent supervision.

The six outstanding individuals featured in the series represent various quarters of Taiwan society. Lin Hwai-min is featured in the first episode and Henry Lee, a respected forensic scientist based in the United States, is the subject of the second installment.

Lee, who took time out of his busy schedule to return to Taipei to attend the premiere of the series, said he believes the project can help the world see Taiwan's positive side and provide inspiration for young people.

The remaining four parts will feature the success stories of Buddhist Master Cheng Yen, who has led a large army of volunteers to embark on humanitarian disaster relief, education and other charitable missions around the world; Liu Chin-piao, founder of Giant Group, the world's largest maker of quality bicycles; the "King of Watermelons" Chen Wen-yu, who has devoted 45 years of his life to developing seeds for quality vegetables and fruits in Taiwan, helping make Taiwan into an agricultural leader in Asia; and pop singer A-mei, who has conquered the hearts of audiences throughout Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: DRIVER CRASHES INTO BARRIER OUTSIDE PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE

TEXT.P: A man was arrested after he rammed his car into a protective barrier in front of the Presidential Office Thursday.
The incident happened around 4 p.m. Thursday. The man driving on Ketagalan Boulevard tried to go through the barrier guarded by military police, who succeeded in stopping him.
Police said the man was carrying an ROC national flag when he stepped out of the car. Police said they are still investigating the cause of the incident.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DONATES 1,000 BIKES TO POOR IN PANAMA
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Dec. 15 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government has given 1,000 bicycles to Panama to be distributed to disadvantaged children and families, officials from the ROC Embassy in Panama said Thursday.

The first batch of 500 bicycles was delivered to children in La Chorrera City Wednesday, said Hou Ping-fu, ROC Ambassador in Panama, who traveled to the town located in a suburb of Panama City to preside over a ceremony marking the donation of the bikes.
In addition to the bicycles, two 40-ft containers of toys are also on their way to Panama to help poor Panamanian children have a happy Christmas, Hou said.

Ten 40-ft containers of clothes and footwear have been sent from Taiwan to Panama's indigenous people recently, Hou said, adding that altogether, the ROC government will be making relief donations topping 45 40-ft containers this year to needy children and families in Panama.
Most of these donations are made via the Office of the Panamanian First Lady, Hou noted.
Noting that Taiwan-Panama ties are better than ever, Hou said officials of the two countries will engage in trade talks shortly, mainly on Taiwan's imports of beef and related products from Panama.

Hou said that Taiwan imported US$3 million worth of beef and related products in 2005, a volume expected to be increased next year. Taiwan is also discussing importing chicken meat from Panama, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: WCPFC VETOES JAPANESE PROPOSAL TO CUT TAIWAN'S TUNA QUOTA

TEXT.P: The Western and Central Pacific Fisheries Commission (WCPFC) vetoed a Japanese proposal Thursday to cut Taiwan's annual tuna fishing quota in the Central and Western Pacific Ocean, fishery sources said.

After successfully pushing the International Commission of the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna (ICCAT) in mid-November to drastically slash Taiwan's bigeye tuna fishing quota for 2006, Japan proposed a similar cut into Taiwan's 2006 tuna fishing quota in the Central and Western Pacific at the ongoing WCPFC annual meeting in Micronesia Thursday.

"The Japanese proposal was vetoed after our delegates convincingly explained our fishing operations in the region at the WCPFC session, " said Wang Shun-lung, president of the Taiwan Tuna Association (TTA).

According to a survey conducted in 2000, Taiwan had only seven or eight tuna fishing vessels operated in the Western and Central Pacific that year, with a total catch of slightly more than 1,100 tons. The quantity was far less than that taken by American, Japanese and South Korean fishing vessels during the same period.

"Against this backdrop, our delegates stressed that it would be unfair and unreasonable to trim Taiwan's tuna fishing quota in the region, " Wang said, adding that the delegates also took the opportunity to brief other WCPFC member states on Taiwan's fishery resources conservation policies and measures.

In line with the principles of sustainable development and fishery ecology protection, Wang said the annual tuna fishing quota will have to be cut by 15 percent in the future. But the base year for the quota calculation has yet to be determined, he noted.
Wang said the association will see to it that all TTA members fully abide by the quota regulations and other fishery resources conservation norms.

Acting on Japan's proposal, the ICCAT decided to impose a cut in its quota for Taiwan's bigeye tuna fish catch by around 70 percent, from 14,900 tons to 4,600 tons, during its annual conference last month, forcing Taiwan to reduce the number of its bigeye tuna fishing boats operating in the Atlantic to 15 for 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Large Turnout Reported as Iraqis Vote Under Tight Security
Iraqi voters streamed to the polls Thursday morning in nationwide elections as Iraqi leaders predicted that the vote would split almost evenly between secular and Islamist parties and usher in lengthy political maneuvering. The elections, which are expected t o draw as many as 10 million Iraqis to the polls, will be the last formal milestone in the American-backed political process that was devised to foster a democratic government.
Wall Street Journal: Bush Concedes Intelligence Flaws Played Part in War
U.S. President Bush bluntly acknowledged responsibility for leading the country to war partly based on inaccurate intelligence, a nod to critics and the latest move in a new White House campaign to rally public support for American efforts in Iraq. President Bush defended his war policy to an audience at the Woodrow Wilson International Center. He said that "It is true that much of the intelligence turned out to be wrong," adding that "As president, I'm responsible for the decision to go into Iraq." While President Bush has previously conceded such errors and has always taken responsibility for going to war, his comments were unusual for their candid linkage of the two issues, barely a year after a 2004 campaign in which he admitted to no significant first-term mistakes when asked if he had made any.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN'S CHIEF OF STAFF TO RESIGN FROM OFFICE TO RUN FOR DPP CHAIR

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's chief of staff said Thursday he has resigned from office to run for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) chairmanship.
"I have tendered my resignation to President Chen in preparation for the upcoming DPP chairmanship by-election, " Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun said.

After eight days of consideration, Yu said he has made up his mind to run for DPP chairmanship with a strong sense of mission to revamp the party which has been in disarray since suffering a resounding defeat in the Dec. 3 local chiefs elections.
Yu said he welcomes his like-minded DPP fellows to join the race.
With a clean and affable image, some observers said, Yu could be an ideal person to head the DPP at this critical moment. Yu's inclusiveness can help boost intraparty solidarity, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PORTRAITS TAIWAN' DOCUMENTARY SHOWCASES TAIWAN'S VIGOR, SPIRIT(repeat)

TEXT.P: "Choreography is a fascinating adventure. I don't know where it will lead. The Cloud Gate Dance Theatre owes its origin to blind passion."

This is the prologue Lin Hwai-min, founder of the world-renowned dance troupe, gives in an episode of a special series of programs to be aired on the Discovery Channel from Dec. 25 to showcase Taiwan's vigor and can-do spirit.
The film series, dubbed "Portraits Taiwan, " documents prominent figures from Taiwan with funds provided by the Government Information Office (GIO).
Speaking at the series' world premiere at the Sheraton Taipei Hotel, Lin said he hopes that the six-installment series will offer the world a glimpse into the beauty and bright side of Taiwan.
Also present at the ceremony were GIO Minister Pasuya Yao, Discovery Networks Asia Executive Vice President and Managing Director Tom Keaveny, and four of the six celebrities featured in the series.
Yao said the "Portraits Taiwan" project is part of the government's efforts to let the world come to understand that Taiwan is a country full of promise and opportunities.

Moreover, Yao said the project teams the GIO and Discovery Channel to allow for more exchanges between Taiwan's documentary filmmakers and international media. Six teams of local directors, screen-writers and producers were enlisted to produce the films under the Discovery Channel's stringent supervision.

The six outstanding individuals featured in the series represent various quarters of Taiwan society. Lin Hwai-min is featured in the first episode and Henry Lee, a respected forensic scientist based in the United States, is the subject of the second installment.

Lee, who took time out of his busy schedule to return to Taipei to attend the premiere of the series, said he believes the project can help the world see Taiwan's positive side and provide inspiration for young people.

The remaining four parts will feature the success stories of Buddhist Master Cheng Yen, who has led a large army of volunteers to embark on humanitarian disaster relief, education and other charitable missions around the world; Liu Chin-piao, founder of Giant Group, the world's largest maker of quality bicycles; the "King of Watermelons" Chen Wen-yu, who has devoted 45 years of his life to developing seeds for quality vegetables and fruits in Taiwan, helping make Taiwan into an agricultural leader in Asia; and pop singer A-mei, who has conquered the hearts of audiences throughout Asia.
