DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET RESHUFFLE MUST BE IN LINE WITH PEOPLE'S EXPECTATIONS: KMT HEAD

TEXT.P: Speaking on a possible Cabinet reshuffle, Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) needs to think over the matter carefully so that such a reshuffle is in line with the people's expectations.
Ma made the comments in response to media question during a short visit to the offshore island county of Penghu.
He said that in a Cabinet reshuffle, the key is policy, not personnel, stressing that only switching individuals around to new positions won't accomplish anything.

Ma also said that the biggest problem with the DPP's current policy is that it doesn't address the major issues facing Taiwan, such as cross-strait and economic problems. For instance, he said that the lack of a direct transportation link between Taiwan and the Chinese mainland has meant a lost opportunity for Kaohsiung to become a major transit point for mainland Chinese cargo.
He added that if the current administration does not deal with these major issues during its remaining two-and-a-half years in power, Taiwan will be in an even worse position.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRO-INDEPENDENCE LAWMAKER FIRST TO REGISTER FOR DPP CHAIRMANSHIP RACE

TEXT.P: A pro-Taiwan independence legislator became the first person to come forward to register for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) chairmanship by-election set for Jan. 15.

Trong Chai, accompanied by DPP Legislators Wang Hsin-nan, You Ching, Wang Shih-chien and Kao Chien-chih, filled out the registration form and made the required NT$1.5 million (US$44,776) deposit at the party's headquarters.

The by-election became necessary after Su Tseng-chang stepped down to take responsibility for the party's humiliating defeat in the Dec. 3 local elections. The DPP managed to win only six of the 23 city mayor and county magistrate posts up for grabs. The main opposition Kuomintang won 14 posts.
Chai said the DPP suffered the major setback in the elections because it failed to insist on the ideals of "Taiwan first" and "integrity first."
"Both the ruling party and Taiwan face a critical period, " Chai said, pointing out that this is why he has decided to come forward to fight for a better future for Taiwan.

Chai noted that he helped found the World United Formosans for Independence in 1970 which is an organization dedicated to the establishment of a free, democratic and independent Republic of Taiwan in accordance with the self-determination principle of the people, and the Formosan Association for Public Affairs in 1982 which also aims to promote international support for the right of the people of Taiwan to establish an independent and democratic country and to join the international community.

Also, Chai said that during his years as a legislator, he has never used his position for influence peddling or been involved in any corruption, which he claimed makes him "the best qualified to talk about 'Taiwan first' and 'integrity first.'"

He was referring to the corruption scandal regarding the construction of the mass rapid transit system in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan. The involvement of a former ranking Presidential Office aide in the scandal dealt a serious blow to the image of the DPP in the run-up to the elections.

Despite reports that said several DPP heavyweights are keen on running for the party chairmanship, including Yu Shyi-kun, who announced his resignation as Presidential Office secretary-general Thursday in order to join the race, Chai said that he would stick to his decision to run for the post.

Chai also signed a "pledge of self-discipline" for DPP chairmanship candidates that he drafted himself, expressing the hope that all the candidates will sign similar pledges to help make the upcoming election a paragon of clean elections for the party.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT RULES OUT RUNNING FOR DPP CHAIRMANSHIP

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu, who also currently serves as acting chairwoman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , on Friday ruled out the possibility of running for the party's chairmanship in the Jan. 15 by-election.

In a written statement issued from the DPP's Culture and Publicity Department, Lu said that she has never had any intention of entering the DPP chairmanship race but that she is keen on helping DPP members conduct a "fair election with style."

"I am eager to see that via this by-election, the DPP will produce a new leader who is not only capable of leading the party to a rebirth, accelerating democratic reforms and deepening the Taiwan identity, but who is also capable of helping Taiwan meet the challenges brought by globalization," Lu said in the statement.
"During my stint as acting chairwoman, I will strive concertedly with party members to jointly elevate the DPP's discipline, integrity and spirit," she said.

Lu was nominated as the interim party chairwoman during a regular meeting of the DPP Central Standing Committee Dec. 6 after Su Tseng-chang stepped down to take responsibility for the DPP's humiliating defeat in the Dec. 3 city and county chief elections.

Meanwhile, Legislator Trong Chai, who is also a DPP Central Standing Committee member, on Friday registered as a candidate in the by-election and deposited the required registration fee of NT$1.5 million, becoming the first person to enter the chairmanship race, which is expected to be a hotly-contested, multiple-candidate race.

Chai appealed to all DPP members to vote for him, saying that he is the only one capable of leading the DPP to push forward and thrive while maintaining the Taiwan identity and the party's integrity -- two elements whose absence he claimed were the root of the party's defeat in the Dec. 3 local government elections.

Several DPP heavyweights are reportedly interested in vying for the DPP chairmanship post, including Yu Shyi-kun, who announced his resignation as Presidential Office secretary-general Friday in order to join the race.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKER URGES RIGOROUS IMPLEMENTATION OF PET REGISTRATION SYSTEM

TEXT.P: Legislator Huang Wei-cher of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party on Friday urged the government to rigorously implement its registration policy for household pets.

Huang, who called a press conference at the Legislative Yuan to call attention to the problem, said that the government currently only requires pet registration for dogs but that an increasing variety of pets are being kept by Taiwan people, including cats, lizards and snakes.

He expressed concerns that such pets could represent a hole in the public health network, saying that if any such pets are carriers of an infectious disease and are lost by their owners, they could pose a threat to public health.

Noting that currently, the total number of cat owners in Taiwan is not necessarily lower than the total number of dog owners, he also urged the government to require that cat owners register their pets.

In addition, he called for the standardization of the specifications for chip implants for pets, pointing out that the government has given approval to two chip manufacturers to produce such chips but that the specifications of the two firms' chips are not compatible, which he said could pose problems if pets get lost or if owners decide to change their pet registration information.

Speaking at the same press conference, Chu Ching-cheng, a section chief of the Animal Industry Department under the Council of Agriculture, said that around 1.1 million domestic dogs are currently implanted with chips, but he added that the implanting of chips in dogs in rural areas still has to be stepped up.
Chu also said that although cats have yet to be included in the compulsory registration, cat owners are urged to get chip implants for their pets.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO KIDD-CLASS DESTROYERS TO BE COMMISSIONED SATURDAY

TEXT.P: A pair of Kidd-class destroyers purchased from the United States and delivered to Taiwan near the start of this month are scheduled to be commissioned at the northeastern military base of Keelung Saturday, Republic of China Navy sources said Friday.

President Chen Shui-bian is expected to travel to Keelung Saturday to officiate, as the commander in chief of the ROC armed forces, at a ceremony marking the commissioning of the "1801 Keelung" and the "1802 Suao" destroyers.

The "1801 Keelung" and the "1802 Suao, " two of the four Kidd-class destroyers purchased from the United States in 2003, arrived at the northeastern military base of Suao Dec. 8 from a shipyard in Charleston, South Carolina after a month-long voyage which also included logistics stops at U.S. Navy bases in Hawaii and Guam.

ROC Navy authorities said that after the two Kidd-class destroyers are commissioned, they will form the outer periphery of a naval defensive fleet, while the Perry-class, Knox-class and Lafayette-class frigates will play an "inner circle" role. The Kidd-class destroyers will target enemy planes that have fired missiles, allowing the other frigates to deal with the incoming missiles, they said.
Both Capt. Chen Hsin-fa, skipper of the "1801 Keelung," and Capt. Shen Yi-teh, skipper of the "1802 Suao, " have previously served as captains aboard Perry-class frigates.

Navy officers and seed instructors, as well as repair and maintenance technicians had received training in the United States to prepare for the delivery of the two de-mothballed destroyers, which have also undergone sea trials and weaponry systems tests over the past month, the Navy authorities said.
Taiwan purchased the four destroyers, built in the late 1970s, at a cost of NT$24 billion (US$0.73 billion) in June 2003.
The other two destroyers are expected to be delivered by the end of 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA SEEN BY TAIWAN MANUFACTURERS AS MAIN RIVAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan manufacturing companies see their local counterparts and China as their main competitors in both the domestic market and overseas markets, according to the results of a recent survey by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).

Nearly 83 percent of Taiwan manufacturers polled said that their No. 1 competitor in the domestic market is their local counterparts, while 23 percent pointed to China, and 13 percent mentioned Taiwan businesses based overseas, the poll results show. Japan and South Korea are also viewed as rivals in the home market by 7.3 percent and 4.5 percent of Taiwan firms, respectively.

China was considered by 44.6 percent of the Taiwan manufacturing companies as their leading rival in foreign markets, ahead of 27.5 percent which pointed to local counterparts and 21 percent which mentioned Taiwan businesses based overseas. Japan, South Korea, Southeast Asian countries, European countries, North American countries and Hong Kong are also on the list.
The MOEA collected 5,758 valid questionnaires from the Taiwan manufacturing sector, 4.9 percent of which are exporters and 28 percent of which are devoted to business in the local market.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 92.22 points to close at 6,350.69.
The bourse opened at the day's low of 6,293.41 and hit a high of 6,375.33 during trading. A total of 4.46 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$129.98 billion (US$3.92 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with textile stocks moving up the most at 3.77 percent, followed by construction issues at 3.65 percent, foodstuff issues at 1.86 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 1.66 percent, banking and financial shares at 1.55 percent, paper and pulp issues at 1.45 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.8 percent, and cement stocks at 0.45 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 749 to 275, with 184 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEC GROUP OPENS TAIWAN BRANCH

TEXT.P: The NEC Group of Japan has set up a branch in Taiwan, with the aim of grabbing a bigger share of Taiwan's business communications market worth NT$1 billion (US$30 million) per year, an NEC Taiwan executive has announced.

According to the executive, Taiwan has a strong and stable demand for business communications facilities, and the country has sound infrastructure, abundant human resources and a government with liberal economic policies. In addition, Taiwan is also a key manufacturing center of information industry products in the world, with many multinational companies as well as small and medium-sized businesses, he noted.

The NEC Group is a provider of IT network integrated solutions and semiconductor solutions. The opening of the Taiwan branch was NEC's latest business expansion after the group has built a large sales and services network in the United States and Australia.

DOC.HEADLINE: CIVIC GROUPS OPPOSE INCREASING DEFENSE SPENDING

TEXT.P: Two local civic organizations opposing the government's arms procurement plan expressed their objections Friday to a U.S. proposal that Taiwan raise its annual defense spending to 3 percent of gross domestic product (GDP) from the current 2.4 percent.
They claimed the hike in defense spending would encourage an endless arms race across the Taiwan Strait, in which they said "Taiwan would definitely lose."

Reporting to the Legislative Yuan's Foreign and Overseas Chinese Affairs Committee on Wednesday, ROC Representative to the United States David Ta-wei Lee confirmed that Washington has suggested that Taiwan increase its annual defense spending to 3 percent of GDP so as to accommodate the latest arms procurement package from the United States in its regular annual budget.

Legislators from the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , who have been blocking the arms procurement bill mainly because they are against the government's plan to finance the procurement with a special budget, have expressed their support for the U.S. proposal.
However, Huang Kuang-kuo, convener of the Democratic Action Alliance, said he is disappointed that the KMT is ready to "yield to U.S. pressure."
Huang pointed out that Taiwan's annual defense spending as a ratio of GDP is already higher than neighboring South Korea's 2.10 percent and Japan's 2.01 percent.

Chang Ya-chung, convener of the Anti-Arms Procurement Alliance, said that regardless of whether the arms procurement is funded by an annual budget or by a special budget, it is still the "hard-earned money" of the people that will be spent.

Chang accused the United States of asking Taiwan to purchase the P-3C anti-submarine aircraft, Patriot PAC-III anti-missile systems and diesel-electric submarines just to facilitate its own strategic planning in the Asia-Pacific region.
He urged politicians not to fool the people and to instead explain in detail to the public the efficacy of the weapons in protecting Taiwan's security.
Also on Friday, KMT Legislator Hsieh Wen-cheng said it is a good idea to increase the country's annual defense spending to 3 percent of GDP.
Hsieh claimed that the KMT has never objected to the arms procurement and that the party is only asking that the procurement be carried out in a reasonable manner.

Disagreeing with Hsieh, ruling Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Wang Tu-fa pointed out that the KMT and its ally, the opposition People First Party, have on 41 occasions blocked the arms procurement bill from being included in the legislature's agenda in disregard of the fact that China has deployed more than 800 missiles targeting Taiwan.
Wang said Taiwan's defense spending as a percentage of GDP is low compared to China's 4.3 percent, Singapore's 4.9 percent, America's 3.3 percent, and Israel's 8.7 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Iraqis, Including Sunnis, Vote in Large Numbers on Calm Day
Millions of Iraqis cast ballots across this war-torn country on Thursday to elect a Parliament to a four-year term, with Sunni Arabs turning out in what appeared to be heavy numbers and guerrillas staging relatively few attacks. Iraqi officials said that initial indications were that as many as 11 million people cast ballots, which, if the estimate holds, would put the overall turnout at more than 70 percent.
Wall Street Journal: Limited Search As Google Pushes Into China, It Faces Clashes With Censors
Google is rushing to catch up in a bid to remain competitive globally. But the move into China is giving the country's censors and security officials greater potential leverage over Google. Beijing believes that the Internet must be firmly controlled to maintain social stability. It requires Internet companies operating in China to comply with the country's stringent censorship and security laws.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEIHU TECH PARK PLAYS INFLUENTIAL ROLE IN WORLD'S IT INDUSTRY: MAYOR

TEXT.P: The Neihu Technology Park in suburban Taipei has posted total revenues of NT$1.5 trillion (US$45.22 million) so far this year, marking a three-fold increase over the level for the whole of 1999, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Friday.

Thanks to the presence of the park, the population of the Neihu district has been growing, which has in turn led to the establishment of two new schools -- Pinchiang Elementary and Middle Schools, Ma said while addressing the inauguration of new buildings at Pinchiang Elementary School.

The Neihu Technology Park, with more than 7,000 employees at present, generates annual revenues rivalling those of the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park, the Taichung Science-based Industrial Park in central Taiwan, and the Tainan Technology Park in southern Taiwan, Ma said.

Citing Business Week's survey of the world's top 100 businesses in the information technology (IT) sector, Ma said that 15 of the top IT enterprises are based in Taiwan and that three of them have set up their headquarters at the Neihu Technology Park.
This fact proves the park plays an influential role in the world's IT industry, the mayor said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for December moved up 86 points to close at 6,356, with 32,188 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for January moved up 98 points to end at 6,368, with 6,467 contracts traded, while March futures gained 95 points to finish at 6,360, with 46 contracts traded. June futures moved up 105 points to close at 6,345, with 12 contracts traded, while September futures moved up 101 points to close at 6,225, with 21 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 6,270 for December, 6,270 for January, 6,265 for March, 6,240 for June and 6,124 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.

December TE futures moved up 5.05 points to close at 279.25, with 5,437 contracts traded, while January TE futures gained 4.95 points to finish at 278.95, with 1,479 contract transactions. March TE futures moved up 4.2 points to end at 278.2, with three contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June and September.

December TF futures gained 13.2 points to finish at 892.2, with 2,540 contracts changing hands, while January TF futures moved up 12.6 points to end at 892.8, with 716 contracts traded. September TF futures moved up 15.8 points to close at 885.4, with one contract transaction.
No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, dropping NT$0.051 to close at NT$33.174.
A total of US$1.06 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$33.225 and hit a low of NT$33.135.

DOC.HEADLINE: ESLITE BOOKS OPENS TAIWAN'S LARGEST BOOKSTORE

TEXT.P: Eslite Books, which was acclaimed by Time Asia Magazine as Taiwan's best bookstore in its "Asia's Best" issue published Nov. 22, 2004, opened a flagship store in Taipei's upmarket Hsinyi District Friday, hoping for an annual turnover of NT$3 billion (US$90.9 million) in the first year.

Eslite Books founder Wu Ching-yu said during a news conference marking the inauguration of the flagship store that Eslite Books may open up new markets in mainland China in two to three years to allow Chinese readers access to the "jewel in the crown of Taiwan's cultural landscape, " as the chain is called by the Chinese Books Information Network.

The Eslite Hsinyi Store -- the largest bookstore in Taiwan with an area of 3,000 pings (approximately 1,672 square meters) -- is now a new readers' mecca which, as claimed by the owner, provides multicultural, multilingual and multi-purpose reading pleasure.
Eslite -- a 12th century French word for "elite, " was first opened in 1989 by Wu, a rich businessman who had made his fortune selling commercial kitchen equipment.

One of the few bookstores in the world open around the clock, Eslite Books was once acclaimed by the Chinese Books Information Network as a "legend of culture" which has not only attracted readers from around Taiwan, but also devotees from Japan and Hong Kong.

Eslite Books boasts of offering the largest numbers of foreign books in the country along with imported magazines and art books, and also sponsors about 500 readings, discussions and exhibitions a year, fully living up to its fame as "the window of cultures" in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: BIOLOGIST SAYS GOVERNMENT MUST BE ECOLOGICALLY MINDED WITH SPRATLYS

TEXT.P: A local biologist urged the government Friday to strengthen its management of the Spratly Islands to assert its sovereignty claim over the disputed archipelago in the South China Sea.

Jeng Ming-shiou, a research fellow at the Academia Sinica's Research Center for Biodiversity, noted that Taiwan, which currently occupies Taiping Island -- one of the biggest islets of the Spratlys, is the country that first stationed forces in the island group but that the government has done virtually nothing besides that.
Unlike Taiwan, Malaysia has turned Swallow Reef that it occupies into a tourist attraction by developing a holiday resort, desalination plant and wind power plant there, Jeng pointed out.

With the large number of beautiful marine creatures and coral reefs around the Spratlys, the government should value the tourist potential of Taiping Island and conduct a comprehensive environmental impact assessment before going ahead with its plan to build an airport on the island so as not to damage its plants and marine resources.

Vice Minister of National Defense Huo Shou-yeh confirmed Thursday that the government will build an airport on Taiping Island but emphasized that the airport is not intended for military use but instead for humanitarian purposes such as emergency rescue efforts by the Coast Guard for sick or injured sailors or fishermen.

The Spratly Islands, which consist of more than 100 small islands or reefs surrounded by rich fishing grounds and oil deposits, are claimed either entirely or partially by Taiwan, China, Vietnam, Malaysia and the Philippines.
The claimants have stationed small numbers of military forces on some of the islands.
According to Jeng, the government and people of Taiwan have not paid enough attention to the country's maritime sovereignty and the importance of the sustainable development of maritime resources.

For example, Jeng said, the Spratly Islands and Pratas Islands are home to some of the world's most precious and biodiverse coral reefs, but they are very often left out in the government's policy-making process.

He suggested that the government step up its marine life survey in the South China Sea and establish a ministry of maritime affairs to promote cooperation with other countries to conserve the maritime resources in the Spratly Islands.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Prosecutor charges Italy central bank governor Fazio for insider trading.
A prosecutor of the Milano court charged Italy central bank governor Antonio Fazio Thursday for insider trading. According to the indictment, Fazio leaked confidential information on the operation of Banco Antoveneta to former chief executive of Banca Popolare Italiana (BPI) Gianpiero Fiorani who tried to engineer a failed takeover of Banco Antoveneta. Fiorani, who is a family friend of Fazio, was arrested Tuesday for alleged association to commit crime, suspected embezzlement, insider trading and others.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Bush Authorized Domestic Spying; Post-9/11 Order Bypassed Special Court.
President Bush signed a secret order in 2002 authorizing the National Security Agency to eavesdrop on U.S. citizens and foreign nationals in the United States, despite previous legal prohibitions against such domestic spying, sources with knowledge of the program said last night.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG CITY COUNCIL RETALIATES FOR ACTING MAYOR'S NO-SHOW

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung City Council decided Friday to indefinitely suspend future meetings to protest the absence of acting Mayor Yeh Chu-lan at a special session held to review a series of cave-ins at construction sites of the Kaohsiung rapid transit railway project.

Despite being notified about the important meeting in advance, Yeh sent her deputy to the city council's special session Wednesday while she met with foreign visitors, saying that this was the reason why she couldn't make it to the meeting.
In a motion to express their anger at the acting mayor, members of the city council unanimously decided to postpone the next council meeting indefinitely.
The move is likely to affect the city government's budget for fiscal 2006 because the city council is still in the process of screening the city government's budget.
Two serious cave-ins this month at two construction sites in Kaohsiung's city center again prompted public concern about the safety of the Kaohsiung mass rapid transit (MRT) railway system.

The MRT project has had at least nine major accidents since construction began in 2001. Opposition legislators are calling on the Ministry of Transportation and Communications to take over the project and conduct an overall review of its safety.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: The Moscow Times: Beslan Relatives Quiz FSB Official The head of the Beslan crisis headquarters during last year's hostage-taking, Valery Andreyev, took the witness stand in a Vladikavkaz court on Thursday and denied that he was personally responsible for the deaths of more than 330 hostages

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL REVENUES EXPECTED TO SURPASS NT$100 BILLION FOR 2005

TEXT.P: China Airlines (CAL) , Taiwan's largest carrier, is expected to post revenues of over NT$100 billion (US$3 billion) for 2005, making it one of the few profitable carriers in the world, CAL Chairman Wei Hsing-hsiung said Friday.

Speaking at a celebration party marking the carrier's 46th anniversary, Wei said that CAL hopes to post revenues of over NT$120 billion for 2006, although avian flu and fuel prices remain top concerns for the company's operations. He added that the company might not make a profit next year if oil prices maintain at a high level.

In order to maintain its profitability, CAL has adopted various cost-effective measures, including re-routing its Europe-bound and India-bound flights to pass through China's airspace and reducing the number of unprofitable flights, Wei said. CAL and EVA Airways, Taiwan's second-largest carrier, also cooperate in plane maintenance and repairs operations at some foreign airports.

CAL will increase the number of its profitable passenger flights to Hiroshima, Japan to seven per week from January next year, and it has opened all-cargo flights to Vienna, Austria and the Japanese city of Nagoya as well as entered into air mileage program cooperation agreements with three Chinese carriers, he noted.
In an effort to break into the Chinese market, CAL will also kick off a cooperative plan with Yangzijiang Air Express Co. Ltd. next spring, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: AVIAN FLU EPIDEMIC IN TAIWAN COULD SLASH GDP BY 2 PERCENT: ECONOMIST

TEXT.P: If an epidemic of human-transmittable avian flu hits Taiwan, the island's gross domestic product (GDP) could fall up to 2 percent as a result, an economist predicted Friday.

Wang Chien-chuan, a researcher at the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research, said in an article posted on the Web site of the Investment Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, that he based his prediction on the economic impacts caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) cases in 2003.

Should an avian flu epidemic take place on the island, the economic toll would come from the costs of culling poultry flocks and the drop in exports associated with the poultry industry. In addition, monitoring and treating the disease would be costly, not to mention the possibly destructive effect of people being too sick to work.

SARS first came to light in Taiwan in December 2002 and the country was listed as an infected area by the World Health Organization until July 2003. During 2003, the economic growth rate fell by 0.35 percent to 3.24 percent, and Wang predicted that human-transmittable avian flu in Taiwan would negatively impact GDP by two to five times that amount.
Should this be the case, Wang said the country's exports would decline by between US$1 billion and US$5 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WILLING TO TALK WITH CHINA UNDER WTO: ECONOMICS MINISTER
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Dec. 16 (CNA) (By H. M. Chang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is very willing to talk over trade and commerce issues with China on an equal footing under the framework of the World Trade Organization (WTO), Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh said Friday.
Ho made the remarks to reporters following a WTO ministerial meeting in Hong Kong, in which she pronounced a declaration displaying Taiwan's support for a flexible market opening.

As opening markets is the prevailing trend in the international market, Taiwan hopes to hold trade and commerce talks with China, including the establishment of the direct "three links" across the Taiwan Strait as two equal WTO members, Ho said. But she noted that no consensus has been forged in this regard between the two sides.

Speaking at the ministerial meeting, Ho said that Taiwan supports flexible market openings in all sectors to best assist and benefit developing countries and she called for the gradual opening of global agricultural markets.
She also expressed the hope that what was discussed regarding the service sector in this round of meetings could serve as a starting point for future negotiations on the opening of service markets.

Asked about Taiwan farmers' protests outside the WTO ministerial meeting, Ho said that the government respects the people's right to air their opinions and she added that Taiwan will stick to its stance of flexible market openings when it comes to sensitive sectors in the current WTO trade ministers' meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: ABOUT HALF OF PEOPLE POLLED SUPPORT EXPANDING 'MINI THREE LINKS'

TEXT.P: About half of the people answering a recent poll agreed that the existing "mini three links" between Taiwan and China should be expanded in a reasonable manner, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Friday.
This compares with 19. 6 percent who favor a complete opening of Kinmen and Matsu as transit points for people traveling across the Taiwan Strait without setting any restrictions.
While 52. 5 percent of the people think that Taiwan should be in no hurry to expand the links, 20 percent said the links should be expanded immediately.

If the links are opened completely, 50. 1 percent of the people think this will jeopardize national security, and 71.8 percent believe that this will hamper the government's effort to control infectious diseases.
The survey was conducted by National Chung Cheng University for the MAC Nov. 25-27 on 1,118 adults. It had a margin of error of plus or minus 2.93 percentage points.

At present, Kinmen and Matsu maintain ferry services with the Chinese ports of Xiamen and Fuzhou. However, the service is applicable only to local residents of Kinmen and Matsu as well as Taiwan businessmen with operations in China.

Meanwhile, the survey showed that 58 percent of the respondents said the government should allow civil servants to travel to China for sightseeing purposes under certain conditions, step by step. Only 19.9 percent of the respondents think the travel restrictions on civil servants should be lifted entirely and immediately.

While 55.6 percent of the people think it would endanger national security if the travel restrictions are lifted, 66.1 percent believe it is proper to require civil servants and police officers to file applications with the government first before traveling to China to visit relatives or on business trips.

DOC.HEADLINE: PEKING UNIVERSITY PRESIDENT CALLS ON NTU COUNTERPART

TEXT.P: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CAN) Visiting Peking University President Xu Zhihong called on his counterpart at National Taiwan University (NTU), Lee Si-chen, Friday to compare notes on budgets for advanced studies Friday.

In comparing the budgets for advanced studies across the Taiwan Strait, Lee said that if special budgets are not included, the NTU has an annual budget of around 2.8 billion yuan (US$346.81 million), compared with Peking University's two billion yuan. But taking into consideration the standard of living, consumer price index, and the number of enrolled students, NTU's budget is comparatively lower.
Xu noted that China appropriated a special budget of 1.8 billion yuan to Peking University between 1999 and 2001. It has funneled another 1.8 billion yuan into the school between 2004 and 2007.

Amid complaints by some Taiwan universities who have failed to get any funds from the government's "five-year, NT$50 billion" project to upgrade schools to the level of world-class universities, Xu said that Chinese have an entrenched idea of "equality," resulting in complaints by those who have not received additional budgets.
What Peking University does is to prove with substantial results that the money the government has spent was not in vain, Xu said.
This is Xu's first trip to NTU since assuming the post in 1999. Xu also gave a speech at the university.

Xu and his 50-odd delegation came to Taiwan for academic exchanges. In addition to NTU, they also plan to visit National Chung Hsing University, National Tsinghua University, and Chinese Culture University before returning to China Dec. 21.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER DPP HEAD WANTS ROOM FOR NEW GENERATION OF LEADERS

TEXT.P: The current president and vice president, as well as past premiers or party chairmen should not serve as the next Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) chairman so that there can be a new generation of leaders, former DPP chairman Lin I-hsiung said Friday.
Lin, who served as party chairman between 1998 and 2000, made the remarks when he delivered an open letter to DPP members at a news conference.
Lin said that if any of these people intend to run for chairman, "I will do my best to dissuade them. If they persist, I will publish my reasons for trying to talk them out of their decision."

He also said that the next DPP chairman should not run for Taipei or Kaohsiung mayor at the end of the 2006 or be a candidate in the 2008 presidential election because he or she must concentrate on party and election campaign affairs.

"If the way in which the upcoming election for DPP chairman is run or if the party's candidate for the 2008 presidential election does not live up to public expectations, the party may have no more reason to exist, and it has to accept its fate of being annihilated," said the respected former DPP chairman, who in recent years has focused on a nuclear-free Taiwan.

In the letter titled, "Genuine self-reflection will open up a window of opportunity for success, " Lin said the DPP suffered an unprecedented defeat in the Dec. 3 local elections. The DPP managed to win only six mayoral and magistrate seats out of 23 up for grabs, while the main opposition Kuomintang captured 14.

Noting that the DPP is in disarray and Su Tseng-chang stepped down as DPP chairman to take responsibility for the major setback, he offered his ideas on who the next party chairman could be. The party will vote for a new chairman on Jan. 15.
"It is the responsibility of the chairman to focus on party matters as well as campaign preparations for the 2008 presidential election," Lin said.

"Because of this, the person at the head of the party must not be a candidate for Taipei or Kaohsiung mayor in 2006, and he or she should also not run for president or vice president in 2008, " he said.

Lin also said that the term of the new party chairman should run until May 20, 2008 when the next president is inaugurated, and he or she should not leave the post for any other reason than being recalled or in seriously ill health.

Lin's remarks apparently preclude Yu Shyi-kun, secretary-general to the Presidential Office and a former premier, who announced his resignation from the top aide post Thursday to run for the DPP chairmanship.
Lin said that the party must go past the election defeat and seriously reflect on its policies and strategies so that it can make a fresh start and seize the next chance for success.

Moreover, this evaluation of the party must be conducted from the top down, starting with the president, the vice president, past premiers and party chairmen and then to local party leaders, Lin said, adding that they should reflect deeply upon their performance, their words and deeds, and put down their conclusions and views in writing.

A team of fair-minded people will then assess the reports and give their comments to the DPP's Central Standing Committee, which will then invite those who submitted the reports and those who assessed them to explain their respective views before making an overall finding.
"If there are major flaws in the party machine, then all ranking party members should apologize to grassroots supporters and the public," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WILL ALLOW U.S. BEEF IMPORTS TO RESUME AFTER SAFETY ASSURED
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Dec. 16 (CNA) (By Semy Chen & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: When Taiwan is completely sure that U.S. beef is safe for consumption, it will re-open its markets to imports, Taiwan's economics minister said Friday.

Ho Mei-yueh made the remarks on the sideline of the sixth ministerial meeting of the World Trade Organization (WTO) , which is being held at the Hong Kong Convention Center Dec. 13-18, after Japan announced it would lift its ban against the import of U.S. beef a few days ago.

Ho said it is only a technical problem to re-open Taiwan to U.S. beef, noting that the Department of Health will use an open and transparent procedure for testing and examining to ensure that beef from the United States is absolutely safe, and that no new cases of mad cow disease, or bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) , have appeared in the U.S. since its second case of the disease in June.

Japan re-opened its market for the import after ensuring the safety of U.S. beef following strict tests and examinations, Ho said, adding Taiwan is conducting similar tests. Japan was the world's largest market for U.S. beef, which was closed in 2003 after the U.S. discovered a single case of mad cow disease.
After negotiations lasting two years, Japan decided on Dec. 12 to resume imports of U.S. beef from cattle aged under 20 months.

Taiwan, listed as the world's sixth-largest U.S. beef market, banned imports of U.S. beef, live cattle and all related products in December, 2003 after the discovery in Washington State of a single case of mad cow disease. In April this year, it lifted the ban on U.S. boneless beef from animals under 30 months of age, but again suspended American beef imports on June 25 after a second case of mad cow disease was confirmed in the U.S. earlier the same month.

U.S. Secretary of Agriculture Mike Johannes, who is now in Hong Kong attending the WTO meeting, on Friday urged Taiwan, South Korea, China, Hong Kong and Singapore to follow Japan and lift their bans on U.S. beef as soon as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI TO HOLD INTERNATIONAL FORUM TO HELP ENHANCE ITS CREATIVITY

TEXT.P: The Taipei City Government will hold a two-day international forum on "Creative City: The Birth of Creativity" from Saturday at the Chinese Culture University's international conference room in Taipei in an attempt to encourage the development of creative and cultural industries in Taiwan's largest city.
The forum is organized by the city government's Department of Cultural Affairs and is co-sponsored by the British Council.

In addition to local academics, five experts from the United Kingdom, including former British Culture Secretary Chris Smith, will be invited to speak at the forum. They will offer the United Kingdom's experiences in developing creative industries.
The discussions at the forum will cover five major areas: national policies, city planning, education, alternative cultures, and science and technology.

Liao Hsien-hao, head of the Department of Cultural Affairs under the Taipei City Government, acknowledged at a news conference Friday that in promoting cultural industries, Taiwan has often neglected creativity, which should be at the core of these industries.
He said that the Taipei City Government will try to provide a friendly environment for creative industries to develop in the city.

The emerging creative industries have become an increasingly central element of contemporary economies, making use of information technology. They cover areas such as design and fashion, film and video, publishing, arts and crafts, music, software, TV and radio, and the performing arts.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALMOST 3 PERCENT OF TAIWAN PEOPLE ARE ILLITERATE

TEXT.P: Just over 510,000 people in Taiwan 15 years old and over are illiterate, 2.84 percent of Taiwan's total population as of the end of last year, an official with the Ministry of Education said Friday.

The official at the ministry's Social Education Department said an overwhelming majority of the illiterate are elderly citizens who grew up during Japanese colonial rule or the early years of the Kuomintang administration.

Noting that Taiwan's illiteracy rate remains higher than the internationally acceptable norm of 2 percent, the official said the ministry continues to promote various adult education programs to address this problem.

Apart from elderly illiterate citizens, the official said a new group of the illiterate is being seen. They are the ever-increasing foreign spouses of local citizens. Illiterate foreign spouses are not included in the illiteracy tallies until they obtain Taiwan citizenship.

In the future, he said, the ministry will put more emphasis on organizing adult education programs for illiterate foreign spouses through cooperation with city and county governments and private non-profit foundations.

DOC.HEADLINE: THAI TRADE OFFICE TO FORWARD FALUN DAFA'S LETTER TO THAI GOVERNMENT

TEXT.P: The Thailand Trade and Economic Office (TTEO) in Taipei received a letter from the Falun Dafa Association in Taiwan requesting them to protect human rights.
The TTEO said Friday that they will forward the letter to the Thai government.

Around 20 members of the Falun Dafa Association in Taiwan held a small protest at the TTEO Friday afternoon to urge the Thai government to respect the human rights of some Falun Dafa members who were allegedly shooed away by Thai police during a peaceful lie-in protest in front of the Chinese Embassy in Bangkok.
The TTEO said that the Falun Dafa members who handed their request letter to a Thai official were very polite and peaceful.

Chang Ching-hsi, a professor at National Taiwan University's Department of Economics and the leader of the protest, said that their only request is that the Thai government protect human rights, and that Falun Dafa followers should not be persecuted in Thailand.
The protest lasted around 15 minutes, according to the TTEO.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC OFFICIAL CALLS FOR REGULAR TOURIST VISITS BY CHINESE TO KINMEN

TEXT.P: China should allow its citizens to regularly tour Taiwan's outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu via the "three mini links" as a way to promote cross-strait exchanges, Vice Chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council Liu Te-shun said Friday.
A news reports said that Beijing will allow 600 citizens to visit Kinmen for sightseeing during the 2006 New Year holiday.
The report said that Chinese authorities have planned Kinmen tour packages for Jan. 1-3.
Calling for regular tourist visits by Chinese people to Kinmen and Matsu, Liu said limiting the number of tourists and restricting the time they can visit does little to boost cross-strait exchanges.

China did not allowed people from Fujian province in southern China to make sightseeing visits to Kinmen and Matsu until September, 2004. In December that year, only 55 Chinese tourists visited Kinmen because of China's reluctance to encourage tourist visits to Taiwan.
Taiwan has since 2003 prepared Kinmen to receive about 600 Chinese people per day. However, this year the outlying island has only seen about 300 Chinese tourists on average per month.

DOC.HEADLINE: GERBER'S CARROT BABY FOOD IN TAIWAN DECLARED SAFE

TEXT.P: The Department of Health Friday declared Gerber's baby carrot food in Taiwan's stores safe after tests conducted by the Bureau of Food and Drug Analysis showed that the cadmium content in the product is well below the maximum allowed level.

Four days ago, the health department ordered that all carrot baby food in jars produced by Gerber's Products Co. of the United States be removed from shelves in Taiwan's stores after news reports said that 300 cases of Gerber's Stage One pureed carrots in Israel were found to contain 30 to 40 times more than allowed levels of cadmium.

Tests done by the Bureau of Food and Drug Analysis showed that Gerber's Stage Two carrot baby food -- for babies who are six-month-old or over -- sold in Taiwan has a cadmium level of 0.013 ppm, much lower than the safe standard of 0.1 ppm.

Chen Lu-hung, a senior DOH official in charge of food sanitation, confirmed that Gerber's carrot baby food sold in Taiwan is not only different from that in Israel, which is for four- to six-month-old babies, but also from a different origin.

The official also said that sales of the Gerber product in Taiwan can resume immediately after the health department rescinded an order that all carrot baby food by Gerber be tested at Taiwan's ports of entry for cadmium levels.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SUCCEEDS IN PROTECTING PACIFIC TUNA FISHING RIGHTS

TEXT.P: Taiwan has succeeded in protecting its bigeye tuna fishing rights in the Central and Western Pacific at a just-concluded regional fishery meeting, the Fisheries Administration under the Council of Agriculture (COA) said Friday.

According to a resolution adopted at the Dec. 12-16 annual conference of the Western and Central Pacific Fisheries Commission (WCPFC) in Micronesia, the bigeye tuna fishing catch for each member state or non-member cooperative partner for the next three years (2006-2008) should be capped at the average of their catch between 2001 and 2004.
COA officials said this means that Taiwan will be able to catch up to 15,000 tons of bigeye tuna in the region annually in the next three years, more than Taiwan's 2004 tuna catch in the region.
"The WCPFC conference decision is favorable to us, " a Fisheries Administration official said.
Taiwan's delegation to the 2005 WCPFC conference was headed by Hsieh Ta-wen, director of the Fisheries Administration.

The delegation was originally afraid that Japan might propose a drastic cut in Taiwan's bigeye tuna fishing quota in the Central and Western Pacific following its success in having Taiwan's quota in the Atlantic slashed to a mere 4,600 tons for 2006 from this year's 14,900 tons.

To avert any possible domino effect, the delegation took pains to explain Taiwan's strenuous efforts at protecting fishery ecology and its marine resources management achievements before the formal onset of the conference.
"Our delegation also made it clear that we would not accept any resolution specifically targeting Taiwan but would support universal and non-discriminatory resolutions, " the official said.

Japan proposed at the WCPFC meeting that the bigeye tuna fishing quota for the coming three years be capped at the 2000 catch. Such a proposal was unfavorable to Taiwan because Taiwan only had seven or eight fishing vessels operating in the region that year, with a total catch of about 7,000 tons. Fortunately, the Japanese proposal was vetoed.
It was also decided at the WCPFC meeting that the catch ceilings for other tuna species, such as longfin tuna, for the coming three years should not exceed each member state's 2004 catch.
The participants also discussed many practical law enforcement measures, including monitoring systems for fishing boats and observer dispatch programs, to better conserve fishery resources.
The fishery official said local fishing vessels should refrain from all illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing activities to ensure the fishing industry's sustainable development.

Acting on Japan's proposal, the ICCAT decided to impose a cut in its quota for Taiwan's bigeye tuna fish catch by around 70 percent, from 14,900 tons to 4,600 tons, during its annual conference last month, forcing Taiwan to reduce the number of its bigeye tuna fishing boats operating in the Atlantic to 15 for 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN TO MAKE MAJOR POLICY SPEECH SATURDAY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will deliver a major policy speech while presiding over the commissioning ceremony for two Kidd-class destroyers at a naval base in the northern port city of Keelung Saturday, government sources said Friday.

Chen is expected to touch on Taiwan's political situation after the Dec. 3 local government chiefs elections in which the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) was soundly beaten, winning only six out of the 23 seats up for grabs, the sources said.
In his speech, Chen will recount China's relentless expansion of its military might and explain in detail a new way of thinking and vision for Taiwan's national security.

Chen will also reaffirm the government's established policy on the long-stalled arms procurement plan under which the military wants to buy three big-ticket weaponry items from the United States -- eight diesel-electric submarines, six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft.
The two Kidd-class destroyers -- the "1801 Keelung" and the "1802 Suao" -- purchased from the United States, were delivered to Taiwan early this month.

President Chen will officiate at the commissioning ceremony in his capacity as the commander-in-chief of the ROC armed forces. Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Frank Hsieh, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng and many senior military officers will attend the ceremony.

Navy staff and seed instructors, as well as repair and maintenance technicians had received training in the United States to prepare for the delivery of the two de-mothballed destroyers, which have also undergone sea trials and weaponry systems tests over the past month, naval authorities said.

With a full displacement of 9,783 tons, the Kidd-class destroyers are the largest warships in the country's naval fleet. Equipped with many advanced weaponry systems, the new destroyers are expected to help upgrade the Navy's defense capability.

Taiwan purchased four Kidd-class destroyers, built in the late 1970s, at a cost of NT$24 billion (US$730 million) in June 2003. The other two destroyers are expected to be delivered by the end of 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SEEKS TO BECOME ASIA'S HIGH-TECH RESEARCH CENTER BY 2010

TEXT.P: Taiwan has planned a national project to develop the island into a high-tech research and manufacturing center in the Asia-Pacific region by 2010, President Chen Shui-bian said on Friday.
Chen unveiled the plan at the award presentation ceremony for two recipients of the 2005 Presidential Science Prize, which was held at the Presidential Office.

To achieve the goal of building Taiwan into a "technology island" in its efforts to maintain and boost economic growth, the government has raised the amount of its 2006 national research and development fund to 3 percent of gross domestic product (GDP).
In the 2006 draft government budget, the fund is listed at some NT$84.3 billion (US$2.54 billion), Chen said.

Two senior fellows from Academia Sinica, Lee Lou-chuang and Chen Chien-jen, received the awards, the country's highest honor for academic research, for their prominent contributions in the fields of space science and public health.

Lee, now head of the National Applied Research Laboratories, has helped Taiwan successfully launch two satellites -- FORMOSAT-1 and FORMOSAT-2 -- for scientific missions since he took over the post of director of the National Space Program Office in 1997.

The FORMOSAT-3, Taiwan's third satellite fabricated under Lee's guidance, is scheduled to take off next year. "Lee has helped Taiwan set up a world-class systems for scientific satellites, " said Academic Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh.

Chen Chien-jen was awarded for his research on arsenic poisoning. For the past 20 years, Chen and his teams have carried out studies involving tens of thousands of Taiwanese who suffer from chronic arsenic poisoning because they drank contaminated well water.

Thanks to his research, a worldwide reference for the safe level of arsenic in drinking water was set up. Besides, the former minister of the Department of Health also led Taiwan people to fight against the islandwide outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) epidemic in 2003.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Dec. 17, or the 17th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1888: The Ching dynasty establishes its Peiyang (northern) navy and appoints Ting Ju-chang as the admiral.
1891: Hu Shih, a noted Chinese scholar who proposed that literature be written in the vernacular language rather than in the classical style, is born in Shanghai.
1902: Classes begin for the first time at National Peking University, China's first university and most prestigious institution of higher education.
1903: American aviation pioneer Orville Wright and his brother Wilbur make the world's first successful sustained flight in a heavier-than-air vehicle, which they invented, flying over sand dunes near Kitty Hawk, North Carolina.
1919: Pierre Auguste Renoir, French impressionist painter whose warm luminous works include "Child with Watering Can" and "Luncheon of the Boating Party," dies at the age of 78.
1925: The Anping Canal in Tainan, southern Taiwan is inaugurated.
1941: Japanese forces invade North Borneo during World War II.
1948: The Dutch attack Indonesia and arrest President Sukarno and other leaders.
1949: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of China announces the severing of diplomatic relations with Burma.
1957: The United States successfully test-launches its first intercontinental ballistic missile.
1967: Australian Prime Minister Harold Holt disappears while swimming at Portsea, Victoria.
1968: The Chinese National Committee of the International Press Institute is established in Taipei.
1971: Pakistan and India end a two-week war over East Pakistan, now Bangladesh.
1971: The International Commercial Bank of China (formerly the Bank of China) is inaugurated, becoming a complete private enterprise.
1973: Luis Alberto Monge Alvarez, Costa Rican speaker of the Chamber of Deputies, arrives in Taipei for a weeklong visit.
1973: Denzo Okubo, president of the Federation of the Japan-ROC Association, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1975: Economics Minister Y. S. Sun and Korean Deputy Premier Nam Duck Woo sign a joint communique calling for further economic cooperation.
1975: A boxing tournament opens at the Tainan City Gymnasium, with boxers from the Philippines, South Korea, Japan and the ROC competing.
1978: More than 5,000 people stage an angry protest outside the U.S. embassy in Taipei.
1979: Tsiang Yien-si succeeds Chang Pao-shu as the secretary-general of the Central Committee of the Kuomintang.
1986: The 1986 Nobel Prize winner in chemistry, Lee Yuan-tseh, a member of the Academia Sinica, returns to the ROC. Lee and his wife are received by President Chiang Ching-kuo on Dec. 18.
1986: New Costa Rican Ambassador to the ROC Ruben Acon Leon calls on President Chiang Ching-kuo to present his credentials.
1989: Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer, who succeeded Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell as commander of the U.S. forces in China during World War II, dies in Washington D.C.
1991: Boris Yeltsin and Mikhail Gorbachev agree to dissolve the Soviet Union and proclaim a new commonwealth on New Year's Day.
1993: Lee Yuan-tseh succeeds Wu Ta-you, becoming the 7th president of the Academia Sinica.
1996: The Ching dynasty's last eunuch Sun Yao-ting dies in Beijing at the age of 93.
1997: A treaty eradicating bribery in international business is signed by the representatives of 34 countries.
1999: Mandarin Airlines, a subsidiary of the Republic of China's former flag carrier China Airlines, opens direct flights between Taipei and Thailand's northern city of Chiang Mai.
2000: Ten king penguins from the United States arrive in Taipei. They are introduced into Taiwan by the Taipei Zoo.
2001: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan meets with about 100 party representatives from Japan's Tokyo and Yokohama areas over a dinner in Tokyo.
2001: Five Japanese Lower House members belonging to the ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) arrive in Taipei for a three-day visit at the invitation of the ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
Confucius: "A wise man will not make himself into a mere machine fit only to do one kind of work. A wise and good man is one who acts before he speaks, and afterwards speaks according to his actions. A wise man is impartial, not neutral. A fool is neutral but not impartial."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN APPROVES YU'S RESIGNATION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian approved his chief of staff's resignation Friday to facilitate the latter's campaign for the chairmanship of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

"This is my last work day at the Presidential Office now that the president has approved my resignation, " Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun said while meeting with a group of aboriginal children who came from central Taiwan for a Taipei study tour.
Yu said he bade farewell to President Chen at noon. "President Chen gave me his best wishes and encouragement, and we also exchanged views on the domestic political situation," he added.
Yu, a former premier, said he will hold a news conference Sunday to formally announce his DPP chairmanship bid.

On former DPP Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung's dissuasion of the DPP "old guard, " including president, vice president, present and former premiers and former chairmen, from joining the race for the next DPP chairman, Yu said his bid for the DPP leadership post is mainly for party revamp and national development, not for personal interests.

The DPP is in tatters following its resounding defeat in the Dec. 3 local chiefs elections. Yu said he is running for the DPP's helm with a strong sense of mission. "I welcomes all like-minded DPP fellows, regardless of their age, to join the race," he added.
Earlier the same day, Legislator Trong Chai registered his candidacy for the upcoming DPP chairman by-election. Chai was the first hopeful to complete candidacy registration.

The DPP is scheduled to hold a by-election Jan. 15 to elect a new chairman to fill the post left vacant by Su Tseng-chang who stepped down after the Dec. 3 elections to take the responsibilities for the party's unprecedented electoral setback.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan newspapers on Saturday are as follows:
The China Times: Mega Holdings pours in NT$10 billion to buy Taiwan Business Bank in bid to become No. 1 in banking industry.
The United Daily News: Taiwan's AIDS patients top 10,000; new contractions this year surpass those in Thailand.
The Liberty Times: Former Japanese official: Taiwan Strait security linked to national strengths of Japan and the U.S.

The China Popst: Lu: No plan to run for new DPP leader.
The Tawian News: Lu will not run for DPP chair.
The Taipei Times: Lu confirms she won't run for post.

DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Sunnis Join Millions at Iraq Polls. Iraqis across ethnic and sectarian divides voted in droves Thursday in a high-stakes election that could determine the course of the nation and the outcome of the U.S. effort to promote Western-style democracy in the Middle East.

DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Bush issued order to spy on Americans
U.S. President George W. Bush signed a secret order in 2002 anthorizing the national Security Agency to eavesdrop on U.S. citizens and foreign nationals in the United States, despite previous legal prohibitions against such domestic spying, sources with knowledge of the program said Thursday.

President Arroyo yesterday endorsed in toto for Congress' immediate consideration and appropriate action the final report of the 55-man Constitutional Consultative Commission (Con-Com) which has recommended amendments or revisions to the 1987 Constitution.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Abat, et al. free on bail
A HIGH-SPIRITED Fortunato Abat walked out of the San Juan Metropolitan Trial Court after posting bail late yesterday afternoon. Abat and three other leaders of his "revolutionary transition government" -- former Budget Secretary Salvador Enriquez, former Ambassador Roy Seneres and lawyer Carlos Serapio -- each posted bail of P12,000 and were given their release orders at around 5 p.m.
The Philippine Star: GMA to Senate: Pass terror bill
