: The Straits Times: WTO talks look headed for failure.
The spectre of failure loomed large at the World Trade Organisation (WTO) talks in Hong Kong yesterday, as ministers continued to bicker with no hint of a consensus in sight on freeing up global trade.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Singapore Kandang Kerbau Hospital establishes HIV Women and Children Fund.
Singapore Kandang Kerbau Hospital obtained S$200 thousand donations to establish the HIV Women and Children Fund, and will offer more help for women and children who infects HIV.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE BUDGET TO BE BOOSTED TO 3% OF GDP BY 2008: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: The nation's defense spending will be increased to 3 percent of gross domestic product (GDP) by 2008 as part of the government's efforts to boost Taiwan's defense capability, President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday.

"This is our goal. It is also a key administrative priority which we must do our best to achieve, " the president said while commissioning two Kidd-class frigates for the Navy. The "1801 Keelung" and "1802 Suao" destroyers, named after two northern Taiwan ports, arrived from the United States Dec. 8.
Chen also used the occasion to voice his frustration, again, at the legislature's failure to pass his government's special budget bill for purchasing major weapons from the U.S.

The president said he is concerned that the budget proposal for buying eight conventional submarines, 12 anti-submarine aircraft and six Patriot-III anti-missile batteries has been stalled in the Legislative Yuan for so long. "What will we do if some day other countries decide not to sell us weapons?" he asked.
"This is an issue that everyone of us must think about, " he added.

He said the administration has followed the people's suggestion by shifting some of the special budget for the arms procurement into the defense ministry's regular annual budget, but the legislature still hasn't passed it.
"What should we (in the government) do to satisfy the legislature? Please give me clear instructions so that the executive branch can make changes to the budget plan," he added.
He said the budget bill has been blocked from being put on the legislative agenda 41 times, causing international concerns that Taiwan seems unconcerned about its own defense.

He called on all sectors of Taiwan society to "return to reasonable discussion, " after the heated "three-in-one" local election campaigns, about issues related to national security and peace across the Taiwan Strait.
The legislature should at least allow the National Defense Committee to discuss the arms purchase proposal, he said.

The NT$480 billion budget bill for buying the three major weapons items has been reduced to NT$340 billion for two items, with the third item to be financed by the defense ministry's regular annual budget.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION SHOULD MAKE CLEAR ITS STANCE ON ARMS PURCHASE PLAN: DPP

TEXT.P: A ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislator said Saturday that the opposition parties should express their real stance regarding the arms procurement plan so that the administration can make necessary changes.

Lee Wen-chung, a co-convener of the Legislative Yuan's National Defense Committee, made the appeal following President Chen Shui-bian's remarks earlier in the day that the country's defense spending would be increased to 3 percent of gross domestic product (GDP) by 2008 to boost Taiwan's defense capability.
Noting that President Chen has on many occasions stated his intention to boost the country's defense spending, Lee urged the president to show determination in implementing his promise.

To his understanding, Lee said, if defense spending is to be raised to 3 percent of GDP by 2008, then the annual military budget needs to be increased by NT$50 billion (US$1.49 billion) for each of the next three years, which he urged the government to do.

Lee said that although it is the executive branch's responsibility to list the budget, the opposition parties, which hold a slight majority in the legislature, should state clearly their stance regarding the arms purchase package, namely whether they want it listed in the regular annual budget or scrapped altogether.

The original arms procurement bill called for the purchase of the three items in the package -- -- eight diesel-electric submarines, a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft and six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries from the United States -- to be financed through a special budget.
The Executive Yuan has since made changes to the bill, which now calls for the six Patriot anti-missile batteries to be financed via the defense ministry's regular annual budget.
However, President Chen noted, the opposition parties have continued to block the bill from being placed on the legislature's agenda.

Lee expressed concerns that the fact that the bill has been stalled in the legislature for so long may make it more difficult to convince the United States and other countries to sell the island weapons in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Central bank governor Fazio urged to quit.
Finance and Econimics Minister Giulio Tremonti urged central bank governor Antonio Fazio to step down Friday, suggesting that the government take a step forward if Fazio refuses to take a step backward. Fazio has been accused of being involved in two failed scandal-surrounding bank takeover bids since last summer and was formally charged in Milano by a prosecutor for insider trading. However, Fazio, who enjoys an open-ended mandate, refused to quit and claimed that he has done nothing wrong. Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi said that his Cabinet will discuss the issue in next Tuesday's extraordinary meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: PAN-BLUE TO CONSIDER ARMS BILL IF DEFENSE SPENDING UPPED TO 3% OF GDP

TEXT.P: The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) will consider allowing debate on the administration's major arms purchase bill at the legislature if the administration immediately boosts defense spending to 3 percent of gross domestic product (GDP) , a senior KMT official said Saturday.

Tseng Yung-chuan, executive director of the KMT's Central Policy Committee and party whip at the legislature, said that of the three major items in the arms procurement package, the anti-missile batteries have already been vetoed in a referendum, so the KMT will only consider approving the purchase of the eight conventional submarines and 12 P-3C Orion submarine-hunting aircraft, and only through the defense ministry's regular annual budget.
"The bill must be legal and reasonable, and not a single cent should be wasted," he said.

Sun Ta-chien, deputy convener of the PFP's legislative caucus, agreed that his party will consider allowing the bill to be debated if the administration agrees to list the funding for the purchase of the submarines and anti-submarine aircraft in the ministry's regular annual budget instead of in a special budget.

Sun said the government must also settle the legal issue surrounding the referendum held in conjunction with the presidential vote in 2004, a referendum participated in by less than 50 percent of the eligible voters concerning the nation's anti-missile capability.

The two "pan-blue alliance" lawmakers were responding to President Chen Shui-bian's appeal to the legislature to state clearly what should be done to break the deadlock over the government's NT$480 billion proposal to buy the three defense items from the United States.

Warning that China has been rapidly boosting its military might and that Taiwan must defend its freedom and democracy from being encroached upon by "authoritarian China, " Chen stressed that it's imperative for the legislature to debate issues concerning national security and cross-Taiwan Strait peace and to pass the arms purchase bill before the current legislative session ends in late January.

The president claimed that he was not being "selfish or partisan" in making the appeal, as the purchase plan had been mapped out before 2000, when the KMT was still the ruling party, and delivery of all three items would not begin until after 2008, when he is due to step down. According to the Constitution, a president cannot serve more than two terms.
He also announced that defense spending will be increased to 3 percent of the nation's GDP by 2008 as part of the government's efforts to boost Taiwan's defense capability.

Tseng said the "pan-blue alliance" has neither opposed nor boycotted a proposal to purchase military weapons for truly defensive purposes, adding that what the alliance is against is "senseless use of money like a free-spending prodigal son."
"We have been blocking an unreasonable spending proposal so that the executive branch does not waste the tax payers' hard-earned money," Tseng said.

If recent media reports are correct that both the government and the United States are willing to see the stalemate overcome by means of regular budgets, then the bill will no longer be a "special budget" bill and the legislature's Procedures Committee needs no longer block it, he said.
Rather, it will have to deal with a regular budget bill that contains weapons procurement in the defense ministry's budget, he said.

He called on the government to at once raise defense spending from the current 2.4 percent of GDP to 3 percent of GDP in order to cover the cost of financing the weapons purchases through the defense ministry's regular annual budget. He said he made the call because the year 2008 is quite far off and "uncertainty abounds" from now till that time.

As to the purchase of Patriot III anti-missile batteries, he said there is no reason to list this item in the arms procurement bill since it was voted down in the 2004 referendum. "The KMT caucus has crossed it out from the regular budget," he said.
Tseng assured that his party and the PFP will remain united when it comes to reviewing the arms purchase bill at the Legislative Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICE WORKERS HOPE TO LIMIT DAILY COMMUTING TIME TO 38 MINUTES: POLL

TEXT.P: Taiwan office workers on average hope to spend no more than 38 minutes per day on commuting, and convenience and ticket fares are their main considerations in selecting their means of transportation, according to the results of a survey released Saturday.

The survey was conducted by the online employment service provider 1111 Job Bank on 1,336 office workers Dec. 1-15. The survey is said to have a margin of error of plus or minus 2.7 percentage points.

The survey shows that the most popular form of public transportation among the respondents is the bus, with 53.59 percent of them taking buses regularly, followed by the MRT and the railway, which are taken regularly by 49.25 percent and 32.63 percent of the respondents, respectively.

The purposes of taking public transportation mentioned by the respondents include commuting to work (42.96 percent) , making pleasure trips (36.68 percent) and returning to one's hometown to visit relatives (22.75 percent).

On the main considerations in choosing their means of transportation, 46.26 percent of the respondents mentioned the convenience of their stops, 42.51 percent said the price of tickets, and 35.78 percent mentioned duration of the journey.

While 39.52 percent of the respondents said the longest commuting time they can bear is 21-40 minutes per day, 23.5 percent said they can handle 11-20 minutes, and 21.41 percent said they can bear 41-60 minutes.
Meanwhile, 70.66 percent of the respondents said they know that the high-speed railway system will start operations late next year.

On the effects of the launch of the high-speed railway services, 68.26 percent of the respondents believe that it will narrow rural-urban disparity, 48.5 percent think that will boost the tourism industry and commercial activities along the railway route, and 44 percent believe that will make possible one-day commuting between the northern and southern parts of Taiwan.

Also, 32.63 percent of the respondents said the coexistence of the high-speed railway, the traditional railway and the MRT will form a compact transportation network, 27.99 percent said it will form a mutually beneficial system, and 23 percent said it will lessen the time and space restrictions.

In a separate survey conducted by the 1111 Job Bank on 572 business owners during the same period, 57.69 percent of the respondents said they think the shortening of north-south travel time will help attract more foreign investment and encourage the return of businesses that have moved abroad.
Meanwhile, 70.63 percent of the business owners said they will invest more to expand their business if travel times are shortened.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE URGED TO RESTORE MAC BUDGET FOR 2006

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu called for the Legislative Yuan Saturday to restore the council's budget to maintain normal government operations and as an effort to promote normal cross-Taiwan Strait development.

The bulk of the MAC's budget for 2006 was slashed at a joint meeting of the Legislative Yuan's interior affairs committee and budget committee Nov. 16., with only the funding for the council's personnel salaries being kept intact.

Wu said it is not a reasonable action to wipe a budget listed for government operations. He urged the Legislative Yuan to give the MAC a chance to explain its planned operations in 2006 and to request the funds for these operations.

The opposition "pan-blue alliance, " which holds a slim majority in the Legislative Yuan, engineered the budget cut, saying that it would only restore the budget after five major policy initiatives were implemented.

The initiatives include enacting the revised Executive Yuan Organization Law; setting a timetable for the opening of direct transportation links across the Taiwan Strait; opening Taiwan to Chinese tourists; opening Sungshan and Chingchuankang airports to direct flights to and from Hong Kong and Macau; and implementing direct cross-strait charter flights during the Chinese Lunar New Year.
The legislature is required to finalize screening of the government's 2006 budget bill before its current session ends in late January.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL ENERGY SUPPLIES INCREASE FOR FIRST 10 MONTHS OF 2005

TEXT.P: Energy supplies amounted to 112.57 million kiloliters of crude oil equivalents (KLOEs) for the first 10 months of this year, with locally produced energy increasing 5.5 percent year-on-year to 2.21 million KLOEs, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics reported Saturday.
Imported energy accounted for 110.36 million KLOEs, down 0.1 percent from the same time last year.
Meanwhile, energy consumption amounted to 88.52 million KLOEs for the January-October period, up 2.9 percent from the level for the same period a year earlier.

Of the energy consumed, 45.45 million KLOEs was in the form of electricity, up 4.1 percent year-on-year, and 34.55 million KLOEs was in the form of oil products, up 2.3 percent. The two items together accounted for 90 percent of all energy consumed.
By sector, energy consumption increased 1.7 percent year-on-year in the industrial sector, 2.1 percent in the transportation sector, and 6.1 percent in the household sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAD URGED TO EXPLAIN PARTY'S STANCE ON ARMS PROCUREMENT

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou should spell out his party's position with regard to the arms procurement bill, and President Chen Shui-bian needs to put forward a financing plan for his defense spending proposal, a ruling party lawmaker said Saturday.

Lee Wen-chung, a Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislator, said arms procurement is a complicated issue involving quite a few key players, including Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng. Ma Ying-jeou, as the leader of the majority alliance in the legislature, should put forth a concrete proposal on the issue, Lee added.

The "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and People First Party now only maintains its majority in the legislature by one seat following the departure of four KMT lawmakers to take up their new posts won in the Dec. 3 city and county government elections.

Lee further said that President Chen should figure out ways to realize his proposal to boost defense spending to 3 percent of gross domestic product (GDP) by 2008, which will require an increase in spending of NT$50 billion for each of the next three years.

The president has called on the "pan-blue alliance" to help pass the NT$480 billion arms procurement bill during the current legislative session, which ends in late January. The "pan-blue alliance" has agreed to debate it on the legislative floor if the Chen administration can immediately increase the defense budget from the current 2.4 percent of GDP to 3 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: AWARDS PRESENTED TO BEST ESSAYS ON TAIWAN'S NEWEST IMMIGRANTS

TEXT.P: A non-governmental foundation presented awards Saturday for the 16 best essays in a contest held to increase local people's understanding and knowledge of the life of new immigrants in Taiwan and their own culture.

The 16 essays will be compiled into a book in an effort to raise public awareness of the issues concerning foreign spouses of Taiwan nationals, said Lee Yi-yang, director in chief of the New World Cultural and Educational Foundation.
There are currently over 320,000 foreign spouses of Taiwan citizens, with the new arrivals forming Taiwan's "fifth largest ethnic group," according to Lee.

The other so-called "ethnic groups" mentioned by Lee include Taiwan's aboriginal tribes, the Hakka people, settlers from southern China who arrived in Taiwan during the 16th century, and the mainland Chinese who came to the island at the time of the Nationalist government's relocation to Taiwan in 1949.
He further said the land of Taiwan is owned by all of the five groups of inhabitants, whom he called "assets" of the country in terms of its international competitiveness and progress.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAXATION REFORMS AIMED AT ACHIEVING LOW TAX RATES: MINISTER

TEXT.P: Finance Minister Lin Chuan called for public support Saturday for the government's taxation reforms, stressing that the reforms are aimed ultimately at achieving low tax rates to boost economic growth.
Lin made the remarks while giving a speech at the Chunghua Association of Public Finance, after the government's minimum tax rates policy triggered opposition from the business sector.

The Legislative Yuan last week passed a law which requires companies that earn more than NT$2 million a year to pay between 10 percent and 20 percent in corporate income tax. Meanwhile, high-income individuals who earn more than NT$6 million per year are required to pay at least 20 percent in personal income tax.

Lin pointed out that the government's revenues as a ratio of gross domestic product (GDP) have increased slightly in recent years, with the ratio rising from the 12.3 percent in 2002 to 13.9 percent in 2004, but that it was still lower than the 15.9 percent of the financially tight Japan.
Lin attributed the situation to the eroded tax base.

According to Lin, it is impossible for the government to increase its revenues by simply hiking tax rates. Therefore, the objective of the taxation reforms is to make the tax burden light and allow economic growth to naturally enhance the government's revenues, he said.
Lin said it will be difficult for the government to lower tax rates unless the tax base is expanded.
He noted that the implementation of minimum income tax rates is one of the government's efforts to broaden the tax base and to create a fair tax system.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ID CARDS TO BE ISSUED FROM DEC. 21

TEXT.P: Population administration offices around the country will simultaneously begin issuing the new-version identification (ID) cards to local citizens Dec. 21, the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) said Saturday.
The ministry will hold a ceremony at the Taan District's population administration office under the Taipei City Government on the inaugural day to mark the event, an MOI official said.

During the ceremony, Premier Frank Hsieh and Minister of the Interior Su Jia-chyuan will present one of the new-version ID cards to Sun Yueh, a popular actor-turned-volunteer, to mark the start of issuance, the official said.
His remarks were seen as a response to a newspaper report that Sun would be the first to get the new-version ID card.

"The question of who will get the first new ID card is not an issue, " the official in charge of population affairs said, pointing out that issuing of the new cards will kick off around the country simultaneously.
"Sun's presence at the inaugural ceremony is mainly for publicity purposes," the official added.
Nearly 19 million of the new ID cards will be handed out before the set deadline of Dec. 31, 2006.

According to MOI regulations, local citizens can commission other people to apply for ID card renewal but should pick up their new ID cards in person so that population administrators can verify the authenticity of the photos on the ID cards. Nevertheless, population office staff will offer home delivery services for frail elderly citizens, seriously ill patients and those with major disabilities.
As to whether the president and vice president should personally claim their new ID cards, the official said it's up to local population offices to decide in line with all relevant rules.

"If the local population offices want to offer home delivery services for our head of state and his deputy in consideration of security risks, the MOI will respect the decision. Likewise, if they want our national leaders to pick up their ID cards personally, the MOI will not object," the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S TRADE SURPLUS EXPECTED TO RISE WITH BOOMING EXPORTS: BOFT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's trade surplus is expected to rebound to between US$6 billion and US$7 billion next year with a forecasted 10-percent growth in exports, Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) Director General Huang Chih-peng said Saturday.

According to government statistics, Taiwan's exports totaled US$172.23 billion for the first 11 months of this year, while imports amounted to US$167.36 billion, giving the island a trade surplus of US$4.87 billion for the period, marking a year-on-year decline of 32.7 percent.

Noting that Taiwan actually registered a trade deficit for three of the first six months of the year, the BOFT said that it is possible that the island's trade surplus for the whole of 2005 could be as low as US$3 billion.

Asked by reporters about the rare decline in Taiwan's trade surpluses, Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh said recently that she is not concerned about the trend as it is "just a temporary situation."
Noting that Taiwan has accumulated huge foreign reserves, Ho said it is not necessary for the island to increase significantly its trade surpluses annually.
The public should not overreact to the trade surplus figures and should instead look at the overall trends in the island's trade performance, Ho stressed.

Noting that the island's exports have not shrunk, Ho said the recent decrease in Taiwan's trade surpluses is due to the rise in the total value of imports caused by sharp hikes in oil prices as well as the purchase from abroad of high speed train carriages, machinery equipment and airplanes. She also said that Taiwan people bought nearly US$1 billion in gold in the first 11 months of the year as investment in expectation of surging prices.
Ho noted that if these temporary and unusual factors are excluded, then Taiwan's trade surplus for this year is similar to that of previous years.
Huang stressed that Taiwan's trade and industrial structure are sound and that the decline in Taiwan's trade surpluses is not a long-term trend.

According to Industrial Development Bureau estimates, Taiwan's overall imports will decrease next year as Taiwan can increase supplying DRAM, phone cells and chemical products to its own market, and the island's trade deficit with South Korea is not expected to expand further.

Wu Hui-lin, a researcher at the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER), noted that in international trade, there should be a balance maintained in imports and exports over the long term and that excessive trade surpluses are not healthy, adding that an occasionally shrinkage in trade surplus figures is not necessarily a bad thing.
He urged the public not to overreact to the decline in trade surplus figures, saying that more attention should be payed to whether both exports and imports are registering growth.

To his understanding, Wu said, Taiwan has maintained a vigorous economy, with both its exports and imports growing. He added that the island's trade figures will move in positive directions if the government doesn't intervene.

DOC.HEADLINE: NAMING DESTROYERS AFTER TAIWAN PORTS SIGNIFICANT: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday that the four Kidd-class destroyers purchased from the United States will be named after various Taiwanese ports, which he stressed has significant meaning.

Chen made the remarks after commissioning two of the Kidd-class destroyers for the ROC Navy at a ceremony at Keelung. The "1801 Keelung" and "1802 Suao" destroyers, named after two domestic ports in northern Taiwan, arrived from the United States Dec. 8.
This is the first time that naval vessels have been given names of geographical locations in Taiwan, under the legislature's proposal.

The remaining two Kidd-class destroyers, which are expected to be delivered by the end of 2006, will be named "Tsoying" and "Makung, " which are ports located in Koahsiung and on the outlying island of Penghu, respectively.
Chen stressed that the ships' being named after the four important naval ports in Taiwan has significant meaning in terms of the determination to safeguard the island.
The four Kidd-class destroyers, which the Ministry of National Defense has said will redress the cross-strait military imbalance after 2005, were purchased at a cost of NT$24 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: YOUTH POLICY ADVISORY GROUP ESTABLISHED

TEXT.P: The National Youth Commission (NYC) announced Saturday the establishment of the first youth advisory panel which will participate in the formation of the government's youth policy.

The panel is made up of 21 young people who will represent members of the population in the 12-24 age group in Taiwan to offer their advice to the government, NYC officials said. They were chosen by the NYC from among 242 candidates after a three-month selection process.

Presenting appointment certificates to the panel members, NYC Chairwoman Cheng Li-chiun said the group of young people might not have any prominent family background or outstanding performance in school, but they all have sharp wits and caring minds.

Cheng said the group will be invited to attend the meetings of the Cabinet's youth affairs promotion committee in the future to ensure that the government's youth policy meets the practical needs of the young population.

Among the 21 panel members are Lin Chun, the first children's human rights ambassador who is currently a student at Taoyuan County's Pingcheng Junior High School; Wang Hsien-chung, a student at the Taipei Municipal Ta-An Senior Vocational Industrial School who played a leading role in forcing the Ministry of Education to lift its restrictions regarding student hairstyles this year; aborigine Besu; and Huang Chao-nien, head of National Taiwan University's students' union.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT INCOMPETENCE TOP CAUSE OF DISTRESS AMONG TEENS: POLL

TEXT.P: The government's incompetence is the top source of distress among local teens, a non-profit foundation dedicated to social education and service said Saturday.

According to the results of a "youth misery index" survey, conducted by the Tosun Foundation between September and November, the top five causes of youth distress were all related to the government's inaction or sloppy performance.
The survey found that environmental pollution topped the list in terms of the main causes of youth distress, with a misery index of 79.8 points on a zero-to-100 scale.

Second on the list was domestic political chaos, with a misery index of 75.4 points; followed by inadequate legal protection, with an index of 73.4 points; topsy-turvey educational reform, at 71.4 points; and chaotic traffic, with a misery index of 68.6 points.

The Tosun Foundation has compiled a "youth misery index" annually in terms of youth feelings about five categories of factors -- school environment, family influence, social climate, future prospects and government performance. Five sub-items were gauged in each category.
This year's survey found that poor government performance was the worst cause of youth distress, with the category's overall misery index reaching 73.5 points.
Much to the foundation's surprise, academic workload was not a major cause of youth distress in comparison.
Meanwhile, the average 2005 youth misery index stood at 61.29 points, according to the survey.

For this year's misery index, the foundation sent out questionnaires to 20 selected junior high and senior high schools as well as vocational schools and junior colleges around Taiwan and collected 2,202 valid copies.

DOC.HEADLINE: COUPLE SUSPECTED OF SMUGGLING KETAMINE VIA MAIL ARRESTED

TEXT.P: Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB) officials arrested two people suspected of smuggling drugs into Taiwan by mail in a raid Saturday on an apartment unit in Chunghe City, suburban Taipei
The two suspects were identified as Chen Liang-yu and his girlfriend, Liu Wei-ling, the bureau officials said.

The raid was carried out after inspectors at Taipei customs service discovered some 9,200 grams of Ketamine packed in mail parcels a few days ago. The drugs, sent from Malaysia, have an estimated street value of NT$30 million (US$906,300) , according to the officials.
MJIB officials and customs officers joined forces with police authorities in carrying out the raid after tracking down the location of the intended recipients of the parcels.
According to reports, Malaysia is emerging as a top source of Ketamine smuggled into Taiwan. Ketamine, often used as a "club drug," is being abused by a growing number of Taiwan youths.

DOC.HEADLINE: 53 U.S. CONGRESSMEN URGE RICE TO INCLUDE TAIWAN IN IPAPI NETWORK
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 16 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Fifty-three members of the U.S. House of Representatives sent a joint letter to Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice Friday asking for an explanation why Taiwan is left out of the US-initiated International Partnership on Avian and Pandemic Influenza (IPAPI) network.
The congressmen also urged Rice to help pave the way for Taiwan to be invited to the next full meeting of the IPAPI, scheduled for January 2006 in Beijing.

The letter, initiated by Rep. Robert Andrews (D-NJ) and co-signed by -- among others -- House International Relations Committee chairman Henry Hyde, reads: "We encourage you to work with Taiwan as apart of the international effort to combat the avian flu, despite Taiwan's exclusion from the WHO. Please provide an update on how the Administration has been working with Taiwan in combating the avian flu in the face of its official isolation. We also ask what steps will be taken to ensure Taiwan's involvement in international health cooperation in the future."

Stressing that diseases know no borders, the congressmen said in their joint letter that Taiwan cannot afford to be the missing link in this international battle against the avian flu. "Even more importantly, the global community cannot afford to leave Taiwan out," it added.

The Formosan Association For Public Affairs (FAPA) , a Washington-headquartered non-profit organization to promote Taiwan's cause, said Friday it is unimaginable that with the Avian Flu currently spreading through Asia, Taiwan, being in the heart of the region, is noticeably absent in the related global network.

FAPA president-elect C.T. Lee, a medical doctor, said that saving lives is the sacred duty that every doctor must uphold regardless the patient's sex, religion, race or profession. "The same universality should be applied by the international arena to the case of Taiwan, " he contended.
Urging the international community to stop playing politics over the lives of the Taiwanese people, Lee said Taiwan should have access to all avian flu-related global conferences and networks.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Senators Thwart Bush Bid to Renew Law on Terrorism
The U.S. Senate on Friday blocked reauthorization of the broad antiterrorism bill known as the USA Patriot Act, pushing Congress into a game of brinksmanship with President Bush, who has said the nation will be left vulnerable to attack if the measure is not quickly renewed. With many Democrats and some Republicans saying the bill does not go far enough in protecting civil liberties, the Republican leadership fell short of the 60 votes required to break a filibuster. Now the future of the law, which greatly expanded the government's surveillance and investigative powers in the wake of the Sept. 11 attacks, is in doubt.

DOC.HEADLINE: WVT COLLECTS CHRISTMAS GIFTS FOR POOR CHILDREN

TEXT.P: World Vision Taiwan (WVT) has managed to raise Christmas gifts for more than 60,000 children from impoverished families at home and abroad, a spokesman for the charity group said Saturday.

"Our Christmas gifts collection drive has received an enthusiastic response from local people since the campaign began in November. We have so far collected 62,019 gift items, for disadvantaged children, far outpacing our original target of 55,000," the WVT spokesman said.

According to the spokesman, 39,9953 gift items will be presented to disadvantaged children in Taiwan, and the remaining pieces will be sent to poor children in 11 foreign countries, including Bosnia, Congo, Mongolia, India and Bolivia.

During the past one-and-half-month, the spokesman said, the WVT has also managed to enlist new sponsors for 672 foreign children. The new sponsors will donate a specified amount of money per month to help finance living expense or tuition fees for those children.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSECUTORS ASSOCIATION NIXES 'SPECIAL ATTORNEY' SYSTEM

TEXT.P: A reform-minded prosecutors group voiced opposition Saturday to a proposal to set up a special attorney system to allow for "independent inquiry" into certain controversial cases.

The Prosecutors Reform Association was responding to reports that 44 independent and opposition lawmakers have drafted a statute on the establishment of an "independent attorney system" patterned after the now-defunct U.S. special attorney system.
According to the draft statute, one-third of lawmakers can come up with a motion to appoint a prosecutor to launch an independent inquiry into a special judicial case.

If such a statute were to be enacted, the association said, the so-called "independent prosecutor" would be unable to work independently and without political interference. The system would end up as a tool for partisan grandstanding, the association.

The United States installed a special attorney system for investigating the Watergate scandal back in the 1970s. As the system failed to live up to public expectations, the system was phased out in 1999. The last special attorney, Kenneth W. Starr, spent about NT$1.4 billion in five years from 1994 investigating the Whitewater scandal involving then-U.S. President Bill Clinton, but failed to get any concrete results.

The association said the best way for judicial reform is for the Legislative Yuan to pass a package of law revisions to require legislative approval in the appointment of the nation's top prosecutor and institutionalize a prosecutorial screening body.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR DECEMBER 18 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Sunday, December 18:
10:00, Former President Lee Teng-hui will attend a graduation ceremony for an adult education program at Taan Christian Church in Taipei.
10:00, Former Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun will formally announce his bid to run for DPP chairmanship at a news conference at Grand Hotel.
10:30, Premier Frank Hsieh will attend an award presentation ceremony for outstanding young volunteers at a Wei-Chuan Foods Co. ranch in Yangmei, Taoyuan County.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Dec. 18, or the 18th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1787: New Jersey becomes the third state of the United States.
1825: Tsar Nicholas I succeeds to the Russian throne.
1829: Jean Baptiste Pierre Antoine de Monet Lamarck, one of France's best scientists, dies at the age of 75. His most important work was the study of evolution.
1865: The United States abolishes slavery.
1911: Wu Ting-fang, representative of anti-Ching revolutionaries, holds peace talks in Shanghai with Tang Chao-yi, representative of the Ching government.
1913: Willy Brandt, German statesman and chancellor of West Germany from 1969 to 1974, is born.
1913: Lo Fu-hsing, who participated in Dr. Sun Yat-sen's overthrow of the Ching dynasty and was a leader of the "Miaoli Incident," is arrested by the Japanese in Tamsui.
1927: Chiang Kai-shek, who was appointed commander of the National Revolutionary Army on June 5, 1926, captures Wuhan (Hankow), which had been proclaimed the capital of the Nationalist government by a left-wing group of the Kuomintang on Jan. 1, 1927.
1941: German forces retreat in North Africa during World War II.
1956: Japan is admitted into the United Nations.
1961: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic ties with Upper Volta.
1965: Nine African states break diplomatic ties with Britain over Rhodesia.
1969: Britain formally abolishes the death penalty.
1969: The ROC's first satellite ground station is established, enabling satellite communications with the United States, Japan and Thailand.
1976: Thanat Khoman, former Thai foreign minister, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1980: Soviet Premier Aleksei Nikolayevich Kosygin, who succeeded Nikita Khrushchev but was often overshadowed by the Communist Party secretary, Leonid Brezhnev, dies at the age of 76.
1985: Chang Fu-lin, the first Chinese-American astronaut, flies aboard the space shuttle Columbia.
1987: The Taiwan Provincial Government announces that it will cease to issue lottery tickets starting in 1988.
1987: In South Korea, Roh Ta-woo is declared the winner of the first presidential election to be held in 16 years. However, students riot, claiming electoral corruption.
1987: The "Hai Lung," a submarine purchased by the Republic of China from the Netherlands, arrives in Kaohsiung.
1989: The European Economic Community signs a 10-year trade pact with the Soviet Union.
1991: The first international project to save the world's rainforests is launched when the World Bank, the European Commission, and the Group of Seven leading industrialized nations grant Brazil US$250 million for conservation work in the Amazon basin.
1992: Kim Young-sam, a member of South Korea's Democratic Liberal Party, is elected the country's first civilian president after 32 years of military rule.
1998: Andrew Lavern Smith is put to death in the state of South Carolina, becoming the 500th person to be executed in the United States since capital punishment was reinstated in 1977.
1999: Construction on Taiwan's first national children's hospital, to be operated by National Taiwan University Hospital, is begun.
1999: TransAsia Airways formally opens passenger flight services between Taipei and the Thai island of Phuket.
2000: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC), the world's biggest semiconductor manufacturer, sets a record by delivering the world's first batch of 12-inch wafers ordered by a customer.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian presides over a ceremony marking the commissioning of the nation's first F-16 fighter wing into service held at Chiayi Air Base in southern Taiwan.
2001: The Central News Agency (CNA) and the MiTAC-Synnex Group enter into a strategic alliance to offer speedy corporate news and commercial and industrial information services in Chinese to domestic and global enterprises.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Study without thinking is labor lost. Thinking without study is perilous. To give oneself up to the study of metaphysical theories -- that is very injurious indeed. Shall I teach you what is understanding? To know what it is that you know, and to know what it is that you do not know -- that is understanding."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: EU leaders agree on spending plan
Britain and France bridged old divisions over EU Saturday, with both sides making concessions to secure a deal on a spending plan seen as key to restoring faith in the European Union after a year of setbacks.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Sunday are as follows:
The China Times:
President willing to compromise on arms procurement bill and opposition willing to talk.
The United Daily News:
Beggar spends NT$100 on lotteries which earn him NT$4 million.
The Liberty Times:
Cemetery developer makes away NT$2 billion via fraudulent tomb sales.

President asks Legislature to tell the administration how a new arms procurement bill should be drafted.

The China Post:

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Gov't to Meralco: Pay up
ENERGY consumers will be looking at a considerable reduction in electricity rates if the Arroyo administration opts to convert a P42-billion outstanding debt of the Manila Electric Co. into shares of stock, resulting in government virtually taking control of the Lopez Group-led distribution utility.
The Philippine Star: AFP eyes Christmas truce
The Armed Forces of the Philippines (AFP) is studying proposals for a "short term" truce with the communist New People's Army (NPA) during the holidays.
The Manila Times: Palace defends no-poll proposal
MALACANANG on Saturday defended the report on constitutional reforms submitted by the Consultative Commission amid criticisms that the result was influenced by former President Fidel Ramos, a staunch advocate of Charter change.

DOC.HEADLINE: OBSERVERS TO BE SENT TO 15 TAIWANESE SHIPS OPERATING IN ATLANTIC: COA

TEXT.P: The Fisheries Administration under the Council of Agriculture (COA) will soon dispatch monitors to 15 Taiwan vessels that will continue to operate in the Atlantic Ocean, fishery officials said Sunday.

The officials noted the administration has recently started a training program and the first batch of 15 trainees will be responsible for monitoring the operations of the vessels and the registration of their catches.

The 15 were originally ocean science observers collecting information of ocean resources, the officials said. They are receiving training on fishery management and disciplinary regulations to facilitate their new tasks.

The Fisheries Administration is planning to train another 15 people, hoping to boost the number of observers stationed on the ships to at least 30 so that they could work on a rotational basis, the officials said.

The officials also said that they are now communicating with port countries via the Ministry of Foreign Affairs on arranging the observers to board the Taiwanese vessels either in Las Palmas, Spain, or Cape Town, South Africa.
The first group of 15 observers are expected to board the ships between the end of December and January next year, and they should be able to start work in early 2006.

The observers will monitor the operations of the vessels and check if they have registered their fishery catches according to regulations. They will report the catches daily to the Fisheries Administration, which will in turn report the information to the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna (ICCAT).
The ICCAT last month cut Taiwan's total allowable bigeye tuna fishing quota from 14,900 tons in 2005 to a mere 4,600 tons for the coming year because of overfishing by Taiwan fishing vessels.
The decision was made on the last day of the ICCAT's 19th regular meeting held in Seville, Spain, after Japan proposed a quota cut citing overfishing by Taiwanese vessels.
Most bigeye tunas caught by Taiwanese boats are sold to Japan. The amount exported to Japan in the past two years has exceeded the total yearly catch quota, prompting the overfishing allegation.
Japan has also accused the Taipei government of failing to supervise operations of the tuna-fishing industry, saying mismanagement had led to overfishing.
As a result, 42 fishing vessels specializing in catching bigeye tuna in the Atlantic will not be able to operate during 2006. Only 15 Taiwan vessels will be allowed to continue fishing.

DOC.HEADLINE: YU FORMALLY ANNOUNCES CANDIDACY FOR DPP CHAIRMANSHIP

TEXT.P: Former Presidential Office chief of staff Yu Shyi-kun formally announced his candidacy for the chairmanship of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Sunday.

Yu, a founding member of the DPP, announced his intention to run at a news conference in the Grand Hotel, where the DPP was founded 19 years ago. He stressed that he has already resigned his post as the secretary-general of the Presidential Office and is in the race purely in his capacity as a member of the party.
The DPP chairmanship election became necessary after former Chairman Su Tseng-chang stepped down to take responsibility for the party's humiliating defeat in the Dec. 3 local government elections.

Commenting on remarks by Legislator Trong Chai, an opponent in the race, that Yu should make clear whether he will run for president in 2008 if he is elected DPP chairman, the former Presidential Office chief of staff said that no DPP member should talk about the 2008 presidential race at this crucial juncture.
Chai's remarks echoed an open statement by former DPP Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung that an incumbent DPP chairman should not run for president in 2008.
Yu said that the DPP is facing the most difficult time since its founding, and that the highest interests for the party and the state are his only concern at present.
He added that the voters used their ballots to make the DPP reflect upon itself, and that the DPP must heed the voices of the people and speed up reform.
Yu stressed that the DPP can win back the people's trust and respect only by demonstrating through action that the DPP is a selfless party that can shoulder heavy responsibilities.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOW U.S. ARMS PACKAGE IS FUNDED MAY BE IMMATERIAL: KMT CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Changing the funding method for the administration's U.S. arms procurement bill from a special military budget to a regular Ministry of National Defense budget will not necessarily make the package more acceptable to the opposition- controlled legislature, opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Sunday.

The opposition "pan-blue alliance" legislative caucuses will accept an arms procurement bill only when they consider it to have been drafted after professional assessments and when it genuinely meets Taiwan's defense needs, Ma said.

Ma said that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has "indulged" itself in using the "special budget" plan, a practice that apparently runs counter to the spirit of the nation's special budget law and that was the main reason why the opposition "pan-blue alliance" lawmakers have continued to block the bill.

Ma, however, pointed out that even if the Executive Yuan changes the funding for the three weapon systems -- six Patriot III anti-missile batteries, eight conventional submarines and 12 P-3C Orion submarine-hunting aircraft -- regardless of whether the arms procurement is funded by an annual budget or by a special budget, the DPP government is still not coming to grips with the reason that the opposition is against the bill.

Ma made the remarks in response to President Chen Shui-bian's appeal the day before to the legislature to state clearly what should be done to break the deadlock over the government's NT$480 billion proposal to buy the three defense items from the United States.
Ma said that the opposition parties have never objected to arms procurement, but the "pan-blue alliance" is opposed to "cash-for-friendship" purchase plans.

Under this mentality, Ma said, the country should jointly review what weapon systems are truly needed to beef up Taiwan's defense. Should such a purchase only be confined to those three items as the administration has proposed? Or other weapon systems should also be considered?

Warning that China has been rapidly boosting its military might and that Taiwan must defend its freedom and democracy from being encroached upon by "authoritarian China, " Chen stressed Saturday that it's imperative for the legislature to debate issues concerning national security and cross-Taiwan Strait peace and to pass the arms purchase bill before the current legislative session ends in late January.

"If recent media reports are correct that both the government and the United States are willing to see the stalemate overcome by means of regular budgets, then the bill will no longer be a 'special budget' bill and the legislature's Procedures Committee has no further cause to block it," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN URGES INT'L COMMUNITY TO HELP SAFEGUARD CROSS-STRAIT SAFETY
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Dec. 18 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The international community must play a role to prevent China from internalizing the issue of Taiwan and stop it from attacking the island, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said in a position paper released recently.
The foreign ministry has sent the 10-page paper in English to overseas missions.

The ministry warned that if the international community accepts China's rhetoric that the Taiwan issue is an internal affair, then it will only encourage Beijing to launch an attack against Taiwan, which it said will further endanger the security of the Taiwan Strait and East Asia.
To avoid this, the United Nations must send envoys or inspection groups to assess the security in the Taiwan Strait, and regularly report their finding to the U.N.

In addition, the international community should support Taiwan to join official or "Track II" communication channels -- a proposed communication mechanism that would be in addition to the current channel of Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation and Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait -- to help establish a framework to build confidence between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Lastly, the international community should firmly advocate its stance to solve the Taiwan issue peacefully and categorically condemn the use of force against Taiwan via any means necessary, the position paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MA'S WIN NO SURE THING IN 2008 PRESIDENTIAL RACE: KMT SPOKESWOMAN
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Dec. 17 (CNA) (By Chiang Chun and Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: Victory for main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou in Taiwan's 2008 presidential race is not a sure thing despite the KMT's landslide win in the Dec. 3 local government elections, KMT spokeswoman Cheng Li-wen said in the United States Saturday.

Cheng made the observation while attending a rally with the producer and a co-hostess of a talk show on Taiwan's Videoland OnTV channel at the invitation of supporters of the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party in San Francisco.

In her analysis of the political situation in Taiwan after the KMT's resounding election victory, Cheng cautioned "pan-blue alliance" supporters that it is too early to be complacent about the election results because the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will surely stage a comeback in the 2008 presidential election.

The KMT spokeswoman pointed out that although the DPP suffered a humiliating defeat in the Dec. 3 elections, its candidates still managed to win 41 percent of the popular vote -- only 9 percent less than KMT candidates.

Cheng said it would be wrong for "pan-blue alliance" supporters to believe that Ma could win the 2008 presidential race easily as long as he does not make any serious mistakes in the run-up to the election.

She explained that the Dec. 3 elections were only local ones where "clean government" had been made a central issue, whereas the presidential election will certainly be fought on different fronts, with heated debate on such issues as cross-Taiwan Strait relations.

Cheng added that the Dec. 3 elections were only a prelude to the KMT's "battle of honor, " and that the KMT must rebuild its partnership with the people and manage that relationship assiduously in order to win back the power it has lost as the ruling party since 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN CANDIDATE SAYS HE HAS WHAT IT TAKES TO REFORM PARTY

TEXT.P: Yu Shyi-kun, former secretary-general of the Presidential Office, said Sunday that he has what it takes to get the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) back on track after the party was soundly beaten in recent local elections.

The ruling DPP will elect a new chairman after Su Tseng-chang stepped down to take political responsibility for the party's poor showing in the elections for local leaders. Registration for candidacy for the DPP chairmanship race is Dec. 19-20 and balloting by party members islandwide will be on Jan. 15. The winner will officially be announced Jan. 18.
While officially announcing his candidacy for the DPP's top post, Yu said the recent election results should serve as a wake-up call for the party.

"The DPP did poorly in the recent elections. This means that the people decided to teach the party a lesson so that it learns to be introspective and humble. This is undoubtedly the DPP's most difficult time, " Yu said at a news conference at the Grand Hotel on Sunday.

"The opposition has made considerable progress. Therefore, the DPP will have to accelerate reforms. I don't talk much, but I keep my word. I will prove that I can win back the people's trust and respect with concrete actions," Yu added.
Yu said he chose the Grand Hotel to announce his candidacy because the DPP was officially launched there on Sep. 28, 1986.
However, Yu did not comment on his priorities for party reform and what he would do if elected. "I will make announcements on my policies in the future," he said.
Asked if he would run for president in 2008, Yu replied that no one in the DPP is qualified to talk about this right now.

Some reports have said that former party chairman Lin I-hsiung would also run for chairman, but this would be contradictory to his declaration made on Friday that past chairmen are not fit to run and that the party needs new blood at the top if it is to properly reform.
(By Taijing Wu) EMDITEM/mw

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Both ruling and opposition coalitions urge central bank governor Fazio to quit.
The two polarized major political coalitions are united in forcing central bank governor Antonio Fazio to quit. Vice Premier Gianfranco Fini said Saturday that if Fazio is not to step down, the exeutive branch and parliament should take due decisions, while opposition union leader Romano Prodi said that the opposition will vote for it if a consequent bill is introduced. Fazio, who enjoys an open-ended mandate, is accused of insider trading and of being involved in two failed scandal-surrounding bank takeover bids.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER DPP CHAIRMAN'S LATEST MOVE HAS EVERYONE GUESSING

TEXT.P: Major factions within the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Sunday that they were perplexed as to why former DPP Chairman Lin I-hsiung asked for registration forms for the party chairmanship by-election, which is scheduled to take place Jan. 15.
Lin sent an aide to get the registration forms Saturday. Registration for the new chairman will run until Tuesday.

Lin published an open letter Friday during which he said that those who have served as president, vice president, premier or party chairman are not suitable to serve as the new chairman, and should any of those "old guards" come out, he would "dissuade them in all earnestness." He also said that the new party chairman should not run for Taipei or Kaohsiung mayor in 2006 or for president in 2008.

Legislator Lee Wen-chung of the New Tide faction said that Lin is not fit to run in this election if his criteria are to be followed and speculated that Lin was "obtaining the registration forms for someone else."

Lin has long been reported to be hoping to recruit others to run for party chairman, Lee said, adding that Lin is closely associated with the party and he is worried about the fate of the party after its unprecedented defeat in the Dec. 3 local elections, speculating that Lin is "looking for someone to lead the party forward."
Legislator Gao Jyh-peng of the Justice Alliance said that he "had no idea" why Lin's aide took the registration forms.

Gao also said that Yu Shyi-kun, who stepped down from his post as secretary-general to the Presidential Office to announce his candidacy for party chairman Friday, is unlikely to bow out of the race because of Lin's opposition. Yu was a former premier.
Legislator Huang Wei-cher of the Justice Alliance also said that Lin's move does not mean that he will run himself, and that he "probably is not satisfied with anyone who has come out so far."

Meanwhile, pro-independence Legislator Trong Chai, who was the first to register his candidacy, said he couldn't figure out why Lin would want registration forms with his understanding of the latter's character.
On whether Lin's move aims to embarrass Yu as reports have said, Chai would not give a direct answer.
Chai also challenged Yu to say clearly whether he will run for president in 2008.

Lin, who was at the party helm between 1998 and 2000, has faded from the political scene and has been engaged in working for a nuclear-free homeland since successfully stumped for Chen Shui-bian in the 2000 presidential election. He is highly respected within the party because of his image of integrity.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2005 ENGLISH LIVING ENVIRONMENT CARNIVAL TO OPEN TUESDAY

TEXT.P: The 2005 English Living Environment Carnival will open Tuesday at Taipei 101 -- the world's tallest building -- to show what Taiwan has achieved in the past year in making its environment more convenient and friendly to native speakers of English.

The three-day annual event, now in its third year, will begin at 2 p.m. with a ceremony on Taipei 101's fifth floor to issue citations to those who have made contributions in improving Taiwan's living environment for English-speaking people.

More than 20 government agencies and private organizations, including schools, will have exhibition stalls to display their achievements in responding to the government's call to improve the living environment in Taiwan for English-speaking people.
There will also be stage plays, fashion shows, dances, concerts, lot-drawings, awards for correct answers to questions, and free gifts to visitors.
The plan to improve the living environment for English-speaking people is part of the government's effort to enhance Taiwan's competitiveness in the internal arena.
The plan has set the goals that by 2008 all public signs and important Web sites in Taiwan must be in both Chinese and English and that all pictograms should be internationalized.

DOC.HEADLINE: HALF OF TAIWAN COMPANIES MAINTAIN POOR MANAGEMENT OF FOREIGN WORKERSBy Deborah Kuo

TEXT.P: CNA staff reporter
Taipei, Dec. 18 (CNA) Nearly half of Taiwan's major foreign worker employers poorly manage their foreign staff, a survey conducted by the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs has found.

The labor affairs council conducted the poll of 228 manufacturing and construction companies which are employers of at least 100 foreign workers between mid-September and the end of October, finding that five of the surveyed companies were already closed and 110 companies had violated the current laws governing foreign laborers and related affairs in Taiwan. The rest, or 113 companies, have not violated any laws.

The labor council conducted the poll in the wake of a Thai worker riot at a dormitory at a Kaohsiung MRT construction site in August -- a riot which was considered by political observers as one of the major reasons for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party to suffer a humiliating defeat in the Dec. 3 "three-in-one" local government elections.

It was found in the poll that 54 percent of the major foreign worker employing companies have not maintained efficient and sufficient bilingual signs at their factories or offices -- their fire-fighting equipment and escape exits have signs only in Chinese.

More than 30 percent of the respondent companies maintained filthy living quarters and inadequate public places for the foreign laborers and 20 percent of the respondents had tiny rooms for the foreign workers and their water pumps were not cleaned regularly.
The poll also found that many of the surveyed companies have employed unqualified labor managers and some companies didn't even have any labor management regulations.

After the Kaohsiung Thai worker riot, the labor council authorities promised to revamp the country's foreign labor policy and amend the current foreign labor law to help improve working conditions for the migrant workers -- roughly 320,000 of them, mostly from Thailand, the Philippines, Indonesia and Vietnam.

A Council of Labor Affairs ad hoc group has submitted an 11-point proposal recently on this effort. Main points of the proposal include that the employer is subject to jail terms if the freedom, life or property of the foreign laborers working at his company are threatened or impaired.

The potential foreign worker employer should submit a copy of the company's foreign labor management regulations to the local government for approval prior to hiring any foreign worker and the local government authorities should conduct on-the-spot investigations before granting the approval, according to the proposal.
The current broker system will be revamped too and there will be a mechanism to judge which foreign labor brokers should be sacked or retained based on assessment reports, the proposal says.
The labor affairs community, however, has different opinions about the council's moves aimed at amending the foreign labor law.

However, Chen Su-hsiang, chairwoman of the Taiwan International Workers Association, is doubtful about the labor council's revamp plans, saying that the government is only applying a stopgap measure and a piecemeal solution to a major issue.

Chen added that the government should not treat foreign labor affairs from the angle of "management." Rather, she said, the government should improve Taiwan's foreign workers' policy from the perspective of the foreign workers' needs and rights.

Prof. Cheng Chih-yueh from National Cheng Chi University said that regulations or laws are supposed to be enacted to serve a nation's policy. If regulations or laws are legislated without considering national policies, these laws will run parallel with the intent of the nation's overall wishes.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP FIRMLY OPPOSED TO ANY SPECIAL MILITARY BUDGET: PFP WHIP

TEXT.P: The opposition People First Party (PFP) is firmly opposed to any military procurement plan of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government that would leave the nation's debt to future generations, a whip of the PFP's legislative caucus reiterated Sunday.

Legislator Sun Ta-chien, deputy convener of the PFP caucus in the legislature, said that in view of the nation's serious financial deficits, the PFP will oppose any military procurement plans in the form of special central government budgets.

Sun stressed that the PFP will never accept the plan of the Ministry of National Defense to request a special budget to purchase submarines, anti-submarine aircraft and Patriot anti-missile batteries from the United States.

Sun said that although the defense ministry has decided to include its plan to purchase six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries in a regular fiscal year budget, the PFP is unlikely to consent to this because this particular item had already been vetoed by the people in the 2004 referendum that took place alongside the presidential election.

As for the submarines and the anti-submarine aircraft, Sun said the PFP will agree to proceed with the screening of the procurement plan if the two items are included in a regular budget. However, he added, the PFP is unlikely to take the whole plan as it stands now.

Sun also said that if President Chen Shui-bian is determined to increase the national's military budget to 3 percent of the nation's gross national product, he does not have to wait until 2008, but should begin from next year.

By doing so, the president would have NT$50 billion (US$1.5 billion) every fiscal year for military spending, and this would allow the defense ministry to pay for what it intends to buy in six years, Sun said.

The opposition-controlled legislature has blocked two bills submitted by the DPP government in the past two years seeking approval of a special budget of NT$480 billion to purchase eight diesel-electric submarines, six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft from the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: WIRELESS INTERNET ACCESS SOON TO BLANKET GREATER TAIPEI AREA

TEXT.P: The greater Taipei area will soon be blanketed in wireless Internet access covering 28 square kilometers, making it the largest in the world, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Sunday.
Ma made the announcement at a news conference Sunday at an opening ceremony of an online "brain game contest" at the offices of the Taipei City Government.

"Every city in the world is striving to become a place with as many wireless Internet connection points as possible. In two days, Taipei City will establish a wireless Internet zone that covers 5 percent of the most-populated area. From June or July next year, around 90 percent of these areas will be provided with wireless access," Ma said.

Currently, the 28 square kilometer wireless coverage includes Taipei's eastern sections, Hsimenting, Hsinyi and other areas around Taipei Main Station where 2300 wireless Internet access points are seen.
"In other countries, places where wireless Internet is provided, such as MacDonald's, hotels and schools, are called 'hot points.' But Taipei has already become a 'hot zone,'" Ma said.

He added that all the schools in Taipei City will have wireless access, and that not only will laptop computers, mobile phone and PDAs have access to the Internet, but PDAs will also be provided Internet phone service.

"I was recently exclusively interviewed by the Asian Wall Street Journal and was asked the reason why Taipei should become a 'wireless city' and how it can reach this goal. The reason is simple. It's for Taipei to increase its competitiveness," the mayor said.

"Taiwan is the best computer hardware manufacturer in the world and more than 90 percent of wireless Internet ports are made here. Plus, because of the government's support of such a plan, Taipei is becoming a wireless city," Ma added.
Ma also mentioned that he has used ICQ instant messaging in the past. Now he sometimes uses MSN Messenger.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESIDENTIAL OFFICE CLARIFIES IT DIDN'T INVITE WANG TO FORM CABINET

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office on Sunday clarified reports about inviting Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng to form a Cabinet during a recent meeting with the president.
In a news release, the Presidential Office said that the president did express the hope of inter-party cooperation and reconciliation between the ruling and the opposition parties during the meeting.

For the sake of political stability and harmony, the president is sincere in meeting with main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and exchange views with him on policies and the consultations between the two could be arranged at any time, the news release also said.

The president also expressed the hope that all parties could put aside their differences to push through major bills currently stalled in the legislature, including a major arms procurement package from the United States, in the interests of the nation and the people, it said.

The release was issued after reports said President Chen Shui-bian has invited Wang to form a Cabinet, and that Wang, a former KMT vice chairman, has reported to Ma about the matter. Ma said Sunday that the prerequisite for Wang's serving as premier would be a party-to-party consultation between the DPP and the KMT on the matter.

Ma said that under the current ROC Constitution, the nation should practice the dual-leadership system, and the majority party should form the Cabinet in conformity with democratic principles, although the KMT will not take the initiative in asking to form the Cabinet.

Ma noted especially that the president has constitutional rights regarding cross-Taiwan Strait and diplomatic affairs, but since there is a big difference between the ruling and opposition parties on cross-strait policies, consultations on policy are essential. "If there are no consultations first, no matter who forms the Cabinet, it is bound to fail," Ma said.
Wang also said that President Chen discussed bills, policy and Cabinet formation with him during Saturday's meeting, seeking cooperation between the ruling and the opposition parties.

Wang said President Chen has several options, including having incumbent Premier Frank Hsieh stay on, inviting the main opposition party to form a Cabinet, and finding others within the DPP to from a Cabinet.
"President Chen didn't ask me to form a Cabinet, " Wang said, adding that he was "only one of the possible options."
Wang also said that he recommended Ma to the president to form a Cabinet.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST GROUP OF TAIWAN PILOTS TO BEGIN WORK FOR CHINESE AIRLINES

TEXT.P: Eight Taiwanese pilots will begin their service for Sichuan Airlines in western China Tuesday, the first such group of Taiwan pilots ever recruited by any Chinese air carrier, an executive from the airline told CNA from Chengdu, the capital of Sichuan, Sunday.
Xing Bing, a senior official of the airline said the eight Taiwanese pilots will serve on seven of the carrier's more than 100 routes, including flights to Shanghai and Beijing.
Xing said the airline will introduce the Taiwanese pilots to the public in a reception Monday evening on the eve of their service on the carrier's flights.
She said the eight Taiwanese pilots began their training in Chengdu last September and have secured their licenses to work as pilots on the mainland.
In addition to Sichuan Airlines, local news reports said Shenzhen Airlines in Guangdong, southern China is also trying to recruit pilots from Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WOMEN MUST BE CAREFUL WITH ADS FOR JOBS IN JAPAN: DIPLOMATS
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 17 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan women must be extremely cautious with ads in newspapers touting job opportunities in Japan, many of which are traps set up by human traffickers, diplomats from Taiwan have warned.

According to officials of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in Japan, over the past three years, police in Taiwan and Japan have rescued a total of 100 women, 99 from Taiwan and one from Macau who fell victim to human smugglers and were forced into prostitution across Japan.

The youngest from Taiwan was 19, while the oldest was 53, with many of them in their thirties, the officials said. Police investigations in the two countries showed that many of the Taiwan women were cheated and lured to Japan by false job ads in Taiwan newspapers, and police have found that more and more gangsters and document forgery rings are increasingly involved in luring Taiwan women to work in the sex trade in Japan.

Tipped off by the representative office in Japan, Taiwan police raided a human cargo smuggling group in southern Kaohsiung City in January this year, and another human trafficking organization was busted in central Taichung City in July, the officials said. In addition, they pointed out that a group of human traffickers from Taiwan and Japan was arrested by Japanese police in October in Chiba prefecture.
The three human smuggling groups in Taiwan and Japan were highly connected to gangsters or document counterfeiting organizations, the officials noted.

Most of the Taiwan women tricked into going to Japan are usually forced to work as prostitutes, and their passports are immediately taken away upon their arrival in Japan by human traffickers who keep tight control of their lives, they said, reiterating that Taiwan women must be on high alert when reading classified ads offering jobs in Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT-PFP TALKS TO TEST THE WATER ON WHETHER OR NOT TO MERGEBy Flor WangCNA staff writer

TEXT.P: Talks between the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and its "pan blue alliance" partner the People First Party (PFP) on a planned merger early this month were intended to test the water and to pave the way for future arrangements, according to political commentators.

KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and PFP Chairman James Soong said following the merger talks on Dec. 12 that "the two parties will keep on cooperating in order to maintain the majority at the Legislative Yuan" before a host of legal issues are resolved, but their remarks have actually ruled out the possibility of an imminent merger for the time being, analysts pointed out.

In turn, Ma and Soong came to an agreement to coordinate a mechanism by January next year for nominating candidates wishing to take part in the elections in the coming two years, in particular the legislative elections in 2007, in an effort to maintain a delicate balance between them and allay grave concerns from supporters over the future of the alliance, observers said.
Although the KMT's landslide win in the Dec. 3 local government elections has crowded out the PFP on Taiwan's political map, Ma made it clear that the KMT will not "hold back" from the merger plan.

Ma said last week that the KMT and the PFP will not touch on substantial issues regarding the merger until 2007 as coming together overnight is impossible, but he added that room will be ampler for the two parties to collaborate in future elections.

KMT spokeswoman Cheng Lee-wen said that in theory, the two parties will not be able to complete the merger prior to the 2007 legislative elections out of consideration of retaining a majority at the Legislative Yuan.

On the other hand, opinions are sharply divided within the PFP, given that around 60 percent of PFP lawmakers are wary of a merger with the KMT despite the fact that a five-member task force has been formed to take charge of merger talks.

PFP Chairman Soong and several hard-line lawmakers opposed to the merger have said that they will not return to the KMT should a common ground fail to be found within the party, overshadowing the much-expected merger among supporters of the two parties, observers said.

Meanwhile, it is worth noting whether a PFP national party congress, slated for March next year, will endorse the merger -- a development that analysts said would serve as a key gauge for "pan blue" unity. They noted that the Ma-Soong talks only marked the very first step towards setting up a mechanism for both to deal with each other in view of a lack of mutual trust between the two parties.

After the PFP performed miserably in the Dec. 3 election, the party, a splinter from the KMT formed in 2000, has been driven by "pan blue alliance" supporters to merge with the galvanized KMT, which strongly won over the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, to further secure "pan blue" victories in future elections.
Ma has been tipped as the "pan blue" leader and the first option for the 2008 presidential race following the election win, watchers said.

PFP lawmaker Sun Ta-chien, one of the party's five-member ad hoc team members, contended that a KMT-PFP merger will be the prevailing trend for "pan blue" voters and he called for a quick merger to avert a vicious circle.

Sun said that he understands that some people in the PFP might feel like they are being treated unfairly, and that they are having to deal with a lot of pressure, but he said that the party should be brave and open-minded towards the merger and that the KMT should be sincere for the sake of "pan blue" unity.
PFP lawmaker Lee Chiang-an is also in favor of a merger with the KMT, saying that the party's continued survival is being seriously tested at a time when many supporters have turned to the KMT.
The PFP must not balk at the public mandate regarding its future development, because PFP voters are basic "pan blue" voters, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SATISFIES WITH OUTCOMES OF WTO CONFERENCE: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The conclusions of the World Trade Organization (WTO) ministerial conference which ended Sunday in Hong Kong conformed with Taiwan's expectation, an economics official said here Sunday.
The anonymous official said Taiwan's chief negotiator at the conference, Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh, will return from Hong Kong and give a briefing on it Monday.

Cited a declaration issued by the conference, the official said the WTO has agreed to end all farm export subsidies by the end of 2013 while the developed countries should end their subsidies to cotton exports by 2006.
The Hong Kong declaration also recommended all WTO member states to beginning carry out before next April the agreement reached in the Doha round of talks in 2001.
The official said the elimination of farm export subsidies won't affect Taiwan which doesn't provide subsidies to farm exports.

And Taiwan's worry that the conference could move ahead the deadline for lowering tariffs on goods considered sensitive for political reasons has not taken place, thanks to the efforts of Taiwan's delegation, the official said.
Ho will hold a news conference at the Ministry of Economic Affairs Monday afternoon to report her delegation's works at the WTO conference, the official said.
