DOC.HEADLINE: SPERM TAKEN FROM LATE CAPTAIN TO BE DESTROYED

TEXT.P: The sperm taken from the body of a late Army Captain Sun Chi-hsiang will be destroyed, his elder brother Sun Kui-sheng said in Taitung, eastern Taiwan Sunday.

Sun Kui-sheng said his father Sun Yu-ching has written a letter to Dr. Li Mao-sheng, an obstetrician in Taichung, central Taiwan to destroy the sperm despite the opposition of his late bother's unmarried girl friend Lee Hsing-yu who insisted on bearing her late boy friend a child.

As the legal successor of his late brother, Sun Kui-sheng said his father has the full legal right to determine how to deal with the sperm taken from Sun Chi-hsiang before he died from his wound suffered in an accident in Sept. 7, and Lee is not in a position to interfere with it.
Although Lee loved his later brother, but it doesn't serve the interest of a child conceived with sperm taken from a dead man and born to a single mother, Sun Kui-sheng went on.
Dr. Li confirmed in Taichung Sunday that he had received Sun Yu-ching's letter and would do what Sun Yu-ching says although Lee Hsing-yu has warned him against destroying it.
The doctor took the sperm at the request of Lee Hsing-yu after getting the approval from the health authorities on Sept. 9.

The health authorities was initially reluctant to give greenlight to the sperm-extracting operation because of the vagueness of law about this, but approved it after the Premier Frank Hsieh stepped in.
Sun Chi-hsiang was the commander of a tank company posted in Taichung. He was hit by a tank which lost control while moving onto the back of a flat truck on Sept. 7.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Dec. 19, or the 19th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1036: Chinese poet Su Tung-po is born.
1154: Henry II accedes to the throne of England.
1741: Vitus Bering, the Danish navigator and explorer who in 1728 sailed through the Bering Strait while exploring a route around Siberia to China, dies of scurvy at the age of 60.
1793: French troops under Napoleon Bonaparte capture Toulon.
1842: The United States recognizes the independence of Hawaii.
1932: The third plenary session of the fourth Central Committee of the ruling Kuomintang approves the convening of an assembly that will meet regularly and which will give the public a voice in governmental affairs.
1941: Adolf Hitler dismisses his chief of staff and takes personal command of the German army after military setbacks.
1946: War breaks out in Indochina as Ho Chi Minh's troops launch widespread attacks against the French.
1950: General Dwight D. Eisenhower is named by the North Atlantic Council as Supreme Commander for the Allied Powers, Europe.
1965: Charles de Gaulle defeats Francois Mitterand in the French presidential election runoff.
1969: President Apollo Milton Obote of Uganda is shot and injured. He would later be overthrown by the Ugandan army in 1971.
1972: The Apollo 17 spacecraft splashes down on target in the Pacific Ocean, bringing to an end the United States' Apollo program of landing men on the moon.
1980: The States-General of the Netherlands approves the selling of two submarines to the Republic of China.
1984: Britain and mainland China sign an agreement determining the fate of Hong Kong after a 99-year lease of the territory to Britain expires in 1997. The joint declaration signed by British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and mainland Chinese Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang spells out the terms for Hong Kong's return to Chinese sovereignty on July 1, 1997.
1985: U.S. Sen. Edward Kennedy announces that he will not run in the 1988 presidential campaign.
1988: Indian Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi visits Beijing.
1990: The first stock exchange on the Chinese mainland opens in Shanghai.
1990: Albanian authorities formally recognize the country's first non-Communist party.
1991: Mikhail Gorbachev resigns as president of the United Soviet Socialist Republic, a country that effectively ceased to exist on Dec. 12 of the same year.
1992: The Kuomintang wins 53.02 percent of the popular vote and the Democratic Progressive Party gets 31.03 percent in the elections for the Second Legislative Yuan.
1996: The ceiling on foreign institutional investments on the Taiwan Stock Exchange is raised from US$400 million to US$600 million.
1997: A Singapore SilkAir Boeing 737-300 airliner crashes near Palembang in Indonesia, killing all 104 people on board.
1997: South Korea's newly elected president, Kim Dae-jung, proposes dialogue with North Korea as a step toward reconciliation.
1999: Chen Shui-bian calls on voters to support the DPP's Chen-Lu ticket in the March 18 presidential election and says he will do what he can to finish off the KMT's "black gold" dealings and to distribute the money held by the KMT to the populace.
1999: Macau is formally handed over to mainland China at midnight after 442 years of Portuguese colonial rule.
2000: Peter Banko, managing director Taiwan and country manager of the Bank of America, is elected as the new president of the American Chamber of Commerce (AmCham) in Taipei.
2001: ROC Vice President Annette Lu departs for Gambia to attend the inauguration of re-elected Gambian President Yahya Jammeh Dec. 21 on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian.
Confucius: "Read and learn everything, but suspend your judgment on anything of which you are in doubt; for the rest, be careful in what you say: in that way you will give few occasions for men to criticize what you say. Mix with the world and see everything, but keep away and do not meddle with anything that may bring you into trouble; for the rest, be careful in what you do: in that way you will have few occasions for self-reproach."

The official, who preferred to remain anonymous, said Taiwan's chief negotiator at the conference, Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh, will return from Hong Kong and give a briefing on it Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGED TO TALK WITH DPP MEMBERS BEFORE NAMING NEW PREMIER

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian should first talk with Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) members to seek a consensus on the crucial issue of appointing a new premier, DPP Legislator Trong Chai said Monday.

The pro-independence Chai, who was the first to register his candidacy for the DPP party chairmanship by-election slated for Jan. 15, made the call amid speculation that President Chen may invite a an opposition politician to be premier after the DPP suffered a humiliating defeat in the Dec. 3 "three-in-one" local government elections.

On rumors that Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pygn, an opposition Kuomintang (KMT) stalwart, and even KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou may be on Chen's short list of candidates for premier as an "unavoidable solution, " Chai said it would be unwise for Wang to give up the helm of the legislature for the premiership, a position which Chai called "as dangerous as a time bomb."
As to Ma being a candidate for premier, Chai said that Ma is "utterly distant from the qualities that a premier should have -- integrity and a strong Taiwan identity."

Meanwhile, former Premier Yu Shyi-kun, who also announced recently his bid to run for the DPP chairmanship, warned Monday that it would be a disaster for the country for the sitting Cabinet to be led by an opposition premier.
"An opposition premier would leave the engine of the national apparatus running and leading the nation nowhere," Yu claimed.
Yu also lashed out at Ma for "manipulating" the media to create the impression that President Chen is going to name Wang as the new premier.
The Presidential Office clarified Monday that President Chen had not talked with Wang about naming him as the next premier as Ma had claimed a day earlier.

Wang himself also denied Monday that President Chen had talked with him about his being the next premier. "The president and I talked about matters concerning a Cabinet reshuffle but definitely not about me being a candidate for the post," he stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW DPP CHIEF SHOULDN'T RUN FOR OFFICE WITHIN 3 YEARS: PARTY OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: It is not appropriate for the new chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to run for any government post within three years of assuming the position as the person should first dedicate themselves to establishing stability within the party, a senior DPP member said Monday.
Legislator Chang Chun-hsiung, who has served in the past as premier and as DPP chairman, made the remarks while responding to reporters' questions at the Legislative Yuan.
He said the new DPP chairman should refrain from running for Taipei or Kaohsiung mayor in 2006 or from taking part in the legislative elections in 2007 or the presidential election in 2008.

Chang said he doesn't want to see the chairmanship post used simply as a springboard for individuals seeking more political power, adding that the party will suffer if it has to endure a succession of leadership elections in the short span of three years.

Su Tseng-chang stepped down Dec. 3 as DPP chairman to take responsibility for the party's defeat in the Dec. 3 local government chief elections. Vice President Annette Lu was appointed as interim chairwoman by the party's decision-making Central Standing Committee Dec. 7.
The chairmanship by-election is scheduled to take place Jan. 15.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE DISCUSSION REQUIRED BEFORE CABINET RESHUFFLE: LEGISLATIVE HEAD

TEXT.P: More talks among leaders of the ruling and opposition parties are required before President Chen Shui-bian makes a decision on reshuffling the Cabinet, legislative speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Monday.
Wang made the comments after a closed door meeting with Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou at the former's residence.
Wang said he needs to consult with People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong as well as independent lawmakers in the legislature on a lot of issues.
He further said that Ma has not yet pledged his support for Soong's idea of forming a coalition.

Wang, who met with the president Saturday, echoed a statement released by the Presidential Office on Sunday that Chen sought his advice on a possible Cabinet reshuffle but did not ask him to head the new Cabinet.

The speaker also said Ma would like to talk with the president about the Cabinet reshuffle issue, although the KMT chief said the previous day that "policy should come before the selection of an individual for the premiership."

However, Wang said Ma ruled out the possibility of talks with the president on the administration's arms procurement bill, claiming that it is up to the KMT's legislative caucus how it deals with the matter.
The arms purchase budget bill has been stalled in the legislature since being submitted last year because of the opposition of the KMT and PFP.

Noting that a meeting between the president and Ma would help reconcile the political differences between the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the KMT, Wang said he will do his best to line up a meeting between the two.
He dismissed the significance of his meeting Saturday with the president, pointing out that he often meets with him to exchange views on domestic issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
: The Straits Times: WTO deal sealed after 11th-hour compromises.
Last-minute compromises by World Trade Organisation (WTO) member countries helped seal a deal in Hong Kong late last night that will break down trade barriers in agriculture and help improve the lives of millions in the developing world.
In an agreement hailed as a success of sorts by WTO members, rich countries such as the European Union and the United States agreed to eliminate by 2013 all farm export subsidies which give their farmers an unfair advantage over developing nations.
The Lianhe Zaobao: To eliminate all farm trade export subsidies by 2013, WTO members have some harvests in HK.
Trade ministers on Sunday announced the Ministers' declaration when the 6th World Trade Organisation (WTO) meeting closed. 149 members of WTO have an agreement to eliminate all farm trade export subsidies by 2013.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: WTO okays junking of subsidies
HONG KONG -- The 149-member countries of the World Trade Organization (WTO) agreed yesterday to pursue trade liberalization by eliminating all forms of agricultural export subsidies by 2013, cut industrial tariffs and further liberalize the services sector based on request-offer negotiations through bilateral and plurilateral approaches.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Meralco: We don't owe gov't P42-B
MANILA ELECTRIC CO. is contesting the claim of a top Malacanang official that it owes state-owned National Power Corp. P42 billion, which he wants converted into equity in Meralco to bring down electricity costs.
The Philippine Star: MJ back in Manila
Former Manila congressman Mark Jimenez returned to the country at noon yesterday amid speculation that he will finally support his allegations against former justice secretary Hernando Perez, whom he had accused of extortion in exchange for approval of a contract.
The Manila Times: Breakthrough at WTO
HONG KONG: Trade negotiators reached a breakthrough Sunday on a last-minute deal, likely averting a collapse in talks that could have seriously crippled the World Trade Organization's ability to promote global free trade.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 80.73 points to close at 6,431.42.
The bourse opened at 6,386.36 and fluctuated between 6,374.49 and 6,439.2 during trading. A total of 4.47 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$115.19 billion (US$3.47 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with textile stocks moving up the most at 4.5 percent, followed by construction issues at 4 percent, cement stocks at 3.2 percent, foodstuff issues at 2.6 percent, paper and pulp issues at 1.6 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 1.3 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 1.2 percent, and banking and financial shares at 0.4 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 829 to 238, with 145 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: WTO AGRICULTURE DEAL WON'T AFFECT TAIWAN FARMERS: COA

TEXT.P: The deal made during the just-concluded trade ministers' meeting of the World Trade Organization (WTO) in Hong Kong will not affect Taiwan's agricultural sector, Council of Agriculture (COA) Vice Chairman Lee Chien-chuan said Sunday.
Lee made the remarks after negotiators from the 149 WTO member states approved an agreement on eliminating farm export subsidies by 2013.

Taiwan's agricultural sector will not be affected by the agreement as Taiwan farmers are not subsidized by the government for their exports, Lee noted, adding that farmers in the European Union and the United States will be affected by the deal.

In a related development, Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh, Taiwan's chief delegate at the WTO ministerial meeting, on Sunday urged Taiwan authorities stationed in Hong Kong to work to gain the release of the dozen Taiwan protesters arrested late Saturday by police in a riot against the WTO's trade liberalization policy.
Ho asked personnel at the Chung Hwa Travel Service, Taiwan's service center in Hong Kong, to hire lawyers to help the Taiwan protesters being detained by Hong Kong police.

DOC.HEADLINE: PENGHU PREPARING CHARTER FLIGHTS TO HONG KONG

TEXT.P: The Penghu County Government is planning to launch charter flight services to Hong Kong from early next year in an effort to better link the offshore island county to the rest of the world, a county government spokesman said Monday.

The county government has been working with the private tourism sector to push for the first direct charter flight from Makung, the largest city on Penghu Island, to Hong Kong on Jan. 21-- the fifth such outbound flight aimed at helping the county's tourism, the official said, adding that more charter flights will be introduced between the two destinations in the coming months.

China Airlines, Taiwan's largest carrier, will use a 158-seat passenger jet for the Jan. 21 charter flight. The direct flight will help Penghu tourists save money about NT$6,000 less than first heading to Kaohsiung city for a flight to Hong Kong, he noted.
Local Penghu residents have expressed the hope that regular Makung-Hong Kong charter flight services will be inaugurated to help Penghu open up to the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT SYMPOSIUM ON PLANT MOLECULAR BIOLOGY OPENED IN TAICHUNG

TEXT.P: The fifth cross-Taiwan Strait symposium on plant molecular biology and biotechnology kicked off Monday at the convention hall of Taichung-based National Chung Hsing University (NCHU) in central Taiwan.

Over 90 scholars and experts in the fields of biology and biotechnology from China, Taiwan and Hong Kong are attending the gathering, including seven university presidents, according to the host of the event.

NCHU President Hsiao Chie-fu said that 81 botanists will give reports on their research at the symposium which will run through Dec. 23. This year's symposium is the largest to date in terms of the number of participants, topics of discussion, and research fields, he added.
Hsiao said it is anticipated that the symposium will act to boost exchanges among Taiwan, China and Hong Kong in the fields of plant molecular biology and relevant sciences.

University heads attending the event include Xu Zhihong of China's Peking University, Chen Zhangliang of Beijing-based China Agricultural University, Tang Chunliang of Guangxi University, and Zhen Jinguei of Fujian Agriculture and Forestry University, as well as Hsiao Chie-fu, Lee Ming-jen of National Chiayi University, and Chou Chang-hung of National Pingtung University of Science and Technology.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'TAIWAN FORREST GUMP' SETS OFF ON ROUND-ISLAND CHARITY CYCLING RIDE

TEXT.P: Chang Wen-yen, the first visually-impaired person in Taiwan to finish a 42.195-km marathon unaided, is challenging himself again by going on an ambitious 1,050-km around-the-island cycling journey of charity.

Chang, nicknamed "Taiwan's Forrest Gump" for his perseverance in running, departed from the Taipei City Hall Square Monday on a tandem bicycle with his trainer Wu Hsing-chuan to embark on the 13-day journey aimed at raising funds to help 1,000 families facing severe financial difficulties.

Chang said upon departing on his journey that cycling non-stop for four to five hours every day for almost two weeks straight will be a new and tougher challenge for him as cycling puts much more strain on the spine than long-distance running does.

Wu, who is serving as Chang's eyes on the tandem bike journey, said his task of navigating will be stressful as he will have to rely on his voice alone in giving directions on a trip in which the pair will have to face all sorts of challenging weather and road conditions.

A spokesman for the Chinese Christian Relief Association, which is sponsoring the around-the-island charity cycling journey, said that it is hoped that enough money is raised by the activity to provide each of the 1,000 families with NT$5,000 per month for up to four months to help them tide over their difficulties.
Fifteen other cyclists are also taking part in the 13-day around-the-island activity, including a pair brothers aged 9 and 11, the spokesman said.
Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who greeted Chang at the starting point of the journey, donated NT$10,000 from his own pocket in the hopes that it will encourage others to make donations.

Chang challenged himself in October 2003 by launching an ambitious 1,000-km around-the-island run to commemorate renowned writer Liu Hsia -- a wheelchair-bound activist fighting for the rights of the physically and mentally challenged in Taiwan -- who died Feb. 8, 2003.
Chang completed the run in February 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, gaining NT$0.013 to close at NT$33.187.
A total of US$982 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.174 and fluctuated between NT$33.104 and NT$33.202.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for December moved up 94 points to close at 6,450, with 24,030 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for January moved up 82 points to end at 6,450, with 9,870 contracts traded, while March futures gained 83 points to finish at 6,443, with 75 contracts traded. June futures moved up 90 points to close at 6,437, with 14 contracts traded, while September futures moved up 96 points to close at 6,326, with 10 contracts traded.

- Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 6,356 for December, 6,368 for January, 6,360 for March, 6,347 for June and 6,230 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.

December TE futures moved up 2.95 points to close at 282.2, with 4,549 contracts traded, while January TE futures gained 3.5 points to finish at 282.45, with 2,786 contract transactions. March TE futures moved up 2.25 points to end at 281.15, with one contract traded. September TE futures moved up 7.85 points to end at 279.1, with two contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June.

December TF futures gained six points to finish at 898.2, with 2,742 contracts changing hands, while January TF futures moved up 8.2 points to end at 901, with 1,886 contracts traded. March TF futures moved down one point to close at 892, with two contract transactions, while September TF futures gained 6.4 points to finish at 887.4, with 17 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June.

DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Banker under custody confesses having protection from high-level political and judicial personnel.
Former chief executive officer of Banca Popolare Italiana (BPI) Gianpiero Fiorani has reportedly confessed that he had the protection from high-level political and judicial personnel. Fiorani, who is a family friend of Italy's central bank governor Antonio Fazio, was arrested last Tuesday for alleged insider trading and conspiracy to embezzle.

The Moscow Times: 1,500 Anti-Fascists March in Moscow
One month after far-right nationalists marched through Moscow's city center shouting "Sieg Heil, " at least 1,500 people marched from the same square in an anti-fascist protest on Sunday afternoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER VISITS HOME FOR DISABLED KIDS

TEXT.P: "Peaceful nights and a year of peace," was Premier Frank Hsieh's personal Christmas message in calligraphy Monday to those living at a home for physically and mentally-challenged children.
Hsieh was accompanied by Minister of the Interior Su Jia-chyuan to the Chungho center in Taipei County.
During the visit, the premier sang songs and played with the kids. He said that he is glad to see how much progress Taiwan has made in providing care facilities for these needy children.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW METHOD DEVELOPED TO EVALUATE PROGRESS IN TREATMENT OF LUNG CANCER

TEXT.P: A new method of detecting genetic markers for lung cancer in a person's blood developed by a local research team is being used to better monitor the effectiveness of treatment, a researcher from Academia Sinica said Monday.

At a news conference called by Academia Sinica to unveil the studies and research on the new technique, Pai Guo-neng, a researcher of the Biomedical Institute of Academia Sinica, said the method was developed jointly by himself and his colleagues from the National Health Research Institutes and National Taiwan University Hospital.

Noting that lung cancer is the top killer of women and has been one of the top-10 causes of death of all people in Taiwan since 1982, Pai said the number of local people suffering from this disease is increasing rapidly.

Although medical science has come a long way in recently years, Pai said lung cancer therapy has not seen much progress; most patients are only diagnosed with the disease when it is fairly developed or terminal, only 20 percent of these can be treated with surgery, and only 10 percent to 20 percent of these survive more than five years.

The current method of evaluating the effectiveness of treatment of lung cancer patients is imaging, via simple X-rays or computed tomography (CT), originally known as computed axial tomography (CAT), which uses a large series of two-dimensional X-ray images taken around a single axis of rotation to map "slices" digitally to create a three-dimensional image of the internals organs.
Both of these take time, often weeks, and depend heavily on the experience of the physicians who have to read and interpret the images.
Usually, the evaluation of effectiveness of chemotherapy through imaging takes one or two months, Pai said.

However, Pai said, he and his colleagues have found several genetic markers for lung cancer in a person's blood and have developed a method to measure their numbers through analyzing polymerase chain reactions. This test requires only one milliliter of blood and two or three days.

By comparing the number of genetic cancer markers before and after treatment, Pai said, physicians can accurately evaluate the progress of the treatment even after only two or three days, which enables doctors to modify their course of action quicker in response to the treatment.

Although the method has the potential of being used as a way to diagnose lung cancer, Pai said this could bring rise to confusion since the presence of such genetic markers only indicate the likelihood of cancer, not the actual presence of it.
Pai said the technology has already been transferred to six biomedical technology companies for commercial applications.

DOC.HEADLINE: NON-DPP MEMBER SHOULD BE NEW PREMIER: FORMER DPP HEAD LIN I-HSIUNG

TEXT.P: If President Chen Shui-bian wants to find a new premier, he should look for someone outside the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) -- excluding the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), former DPP Chairman Lin I-hsiung suggested Monday.

Lin, who served as party chairman between 1998 and 2000, made the suggestion in an open letter to the president -- his second in four days. If the president really wants the Cabinet reshuffled and a new premier to give the party a fresh look after its unprecedented defeat in the Dec. 3 local elections, Lin said the president can look for candidates outside the party as long as they enjoy high esteem in society.

With the wisdom of the president, he will find an appropriate person, Lin stressed. Lin explained that all capable men within the DPP have served as premier before, and if the president continues to choose among the DPP pool, it will not give the party a fresh look and will not be helpful to its development.
However, if the president chooses someone from the KMT, the KMT might think it's a gambit to drive a wedge within its party, and DPP members will also be unsatisfied.
Lin reiterated that ranking officials should not run in the by-election for chairman.

He recalled that the public took President Chen to task when he served concurrently as party chairman. The DPP charter stipulates that the president should automatically serve as DPP chairman if the president is of the same party.

Chen stepped down as party chairman after the DPP's dismal performance in the legislative elections in late 2004. For this reason, he said that if Yu Shyi-kun, who quit the post of secretary-general to the Presidential Office, does run as he has announced, DPP members will conclude that this is another of the president's attempts to try to pull the strings from behind the scenes regarding party affairs.

If the president endorses Yu's run it will deal another blow to the party, which is already reeling after its humiliating defeat in the Dec. 3 mayoral and magistrate elections, Lin said. The DPP managed to win only six out of 23 seats up for grabs, while the KMT captured 14 seats.
Lin urged the president to "dissuade Yu from running by all means."

This was Lin's second open letter over the past few days. In the first letter to DPP members last Friday, Lin said those who have served as president, vice president, premier, or party chairman should not run in the DPP chairman by-election, nor should they run in the Taipei or Kaohsiung mayoral elections in 2006, or the 2008 presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAITUNG MAGISTRATE TO BE SUSPENDED UPON BEING SWORN IN

TEXT.P: Wu Chun-li, who won the election for Taitung County magistrate, will become the shortest-serving magistrate in Taiwan's history because he will be suspended immediately after being sworn in Tuesday.

Wu will be suspended because he was sentenced in a second court trial to seven and a half years in prison for involvement in a corruption scandal. The court in the first trial found him guilty and ordered him to serve 13 years in jail.
Ministry of the Interior officials said Monday that Wu will not have the right to appoint a deputy once he has been suspended as magistrate.
Wu can only return to his post if and when a higher court acquits him, they added. It's unclear when a higher court will hand down a verdict.
Deputy Interior Minister Chang Wen-ying said the ministry has asked the Executive Yuan to appoint an acting magistrate for the county.
If Wu resigns, a new election must be held within three months to pick a new magistrate; if by then Wu's verdict still has not been handed down, he will be eligible to run.
If he is found guilty in the third and final trial, he will lose his right to run for any public office, according to the local government law.
The Taitung County Council was informed Sept. 28 by the Ministry of the Interior that Wu would be suspended as magistrate if he ran and won the Dec. 3 election.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FARMERS NEED 'FAIR TRADE,' NOT 'FREE TRADE': 'RICE BOMBER'

TEXT.P: Yang Ju-men, also known as the "rice bomber" for planting explosive devices around northern Taiwan in protest of rice imports, described the just-concluded WTO talks as a "success" for the United States and Europe, but "meaninglessness" for Taiwan, particularly its farmers.

Noting that "WTO meetings make no sense for Taiwan since the Taiwan authorities don't give a damn about the interests of farmers and the younger generation, " Yang said that "all we should pursue is fair trade, not the myth of free trade."

Yang Monday ended his six-day hunger strike at the Taipei Detention Center. A group of his supporters visited him Monday morning and briefed him on the progress in a "Save Taiwan's Agriculture" campaign.
Yang's supporters held the campaign in Taipei Dec. 16-17 and some of them have just returned from the WTO protests in Hong Kong.
According to campaign leader Kuo Yao-chung, a score of Taiwan students also joined the Taiwan protesters in Hong Kong over the last several days, "all of them being inspired by Yang."

Yang said his six-day hunger strike was nothing when compared with the plight of Taiwan's rice farmers. He said he had had only one meal each day for six days all for experiencing the feeling of hunger that many around the globe experience.

Yang was convicted in his first trial on charges of threatening public security for placing bombs at several public locations. He admitted to the crimes, saying that he wanted to raise public awareness of the plight of Taiwan's farmers.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL TAIWAN UNIVERSITY PRESIDENT HONORED BY KANSAI UNIVERSITY
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 19 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Visiting National Taiwan University President Lee Si-chen was awarded an honorary doctoral degree by Kansai University Monday.

Teiichi Kawata, president of Kansai University, conferred the honorary doctoral degree on Lee. Around 150 guests, including Wu Jia-hsyung, head of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Osaka, were on hand to witness the ceremony.

Kawata noted that the school began to bestow honorary doctoral degrees in 2004 to recognize those scholars who have made significant contributions to the academics, culture and human progress. It conferred an honorary doctoral degree on ROC Minister of Education Tu Cheng-sheng in May. Lee was the seventh recipient of the honor.
Lee also delivered a speech on moving toward an elite university, saying that the NTU aims at becoming one of the top 100 universities in the world within five years.
Kansai University and National Taiwan University signed an academic cooperation agreement in 2002, and has had close exchanges since then.

Lee earlier called on Osaka University, exchanging views with its president, Hideo Miyahara. They agreed that the colleges of liberal arts of the respective universities will begin academic exchanges and then expand to research cooperation and faculty exchanges.
Miyahara said that he hopes to visit Taiwan and conduct further consultations on academic exchanges soon.
Lee, who arrived in Japan Sunday, is scheduled to return later Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: WTO DEAL BENEFICIAL TO TAIWAN: ROC ECONOMICS MINISTER

TEXT.P: The agreement reached in the latest trade ministers' meeting of the World Trade Organization (WTO) in Hong Kong will benefit Taiwan industries, Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh said Monday.
Ho made the remarks at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport upon returning from Hong Kong after the six-day meeting concluded a day earlier.

The deal agreed upon by negotiators from 149 WTO members to slash government subsidies for farm exports will not affect Taiwan's competitive edge, as local farmers are not subsidized by the government, Ho said, pointed out that the domestic industrial sector will not be much affected in the initial stage of market opening that will be made in a gradual and flexible manner.

On the other hand, negotiators also agreed on opening global markets to each other for services trade, providing Taiwan companies with greater market access to set up footholds in developed countries, Ho said. This is a great offer for Taiwan manufacturers to upgrade and undergo transformation, she added.

Aside from these deals, developed countries also came to an agreement to remove customs tariffs and quotas for least developed countries, making it much easier for Taiwan enterprises to relocate to those countries, she explained.
Generally speaking, the just-concluded Hong Kong meeting has set a firmer frame towards global market opening, injecting greater momentum for Taiwan businesses in search of new horizons, she said.

However, an academic suggested that the government take precautions against Taiwan's agricultural market opening to the rest of the world now that it will be unavoidable following the WTO's Hong Kong meeting.

Liu Ta-nien, a senior researcher at the WTO center under the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research, said that the government should draft countermeasures as soon as possible to protect Taiwan farmers' interests as member countries will begin discussing slashes in tariff duties for foreign farm imports, in particular fruit and rice, from next year.

Liu prodded the government to overhaul its agricultural policy to focus on value-added output in view of the new situation, and he opined that agricultural issues should be included for discussions in Taiwan's second national economic development conference.

In addition, he urged the government to strengthen bilateral cooperation with individual WTO member states to prevent from being sidelined, but he asked the government to review the question of whether Taiwan has readied itself for such an opening, which might be much wider than the WTO requirements.
Regardless of whether it is a bilateral mechanism or multilateral mechanisms, Taiwan's agriculture has come to a critical point that needs to be dealt with comprehensively and in detail, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DUCK FARMERS IN CHANGHUA COUNTRY SEEKING HUGE STATE COMPENSATION

TEXT.P: More than 20 duck farmers from Changhua County filed a lawsuit with the Taipei Public Prosecutors' Office Monday, seeking NT$2.6 billion in state compensation for their losses caused by environmental pollution which, they claimed, happened mainly because related government agencies neglected their duties.

According to a report issued by the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) last week, a task force formed by government officials and experts has established that pollutants from Taiwan Steel Union Co. were responsible for the high dioxin level that brought one of nine duck farms in the county to ruins. The task force was not sure about the pollution source found at five other duck farms.

The duck farms each had from 3,000 to 10,000 ducks, which were all destroyed together with all the eggs seized by government authorities because they contained high levels of dioxin that would be harmful to human health.
The duck farmers complained that they have been deprived of their livelihood, and that with the Council of Agriculture doling out a monthly subsidy of NT$15,000 apiece, they cannot make a living.

They also charged that the central and local government authorities in charge of environmental protection affairs had neglected their duties because they knew in July 2003 that Taiwan Steel Union was discharging large amounts of dioxin but did not take any corrective measures.

The duck farmers said they want the government not only to compensate their losses, but also to remove the polluted topsoil from their farms, and provide necessary health care to residents in the affected townships.

Meanwhile, Legislator Chen Chao-jung, of the opposition People First Party, urged the Industrial Development Bureau under the Ministry of Economic Affairs not to allow Taiwan Steel Union to resume production. He also wanted government authorities to make sure that the company compensate the losses of its victims.
Taiwan Steel Union has stopped its production under government orders since mid-June, but is doing test runs and requesting permission to resume production.

DOC.HEADLINE: INVESTIGATION TASK FORCE TO BE FORMED OVER NAVY PURCHASE PLAN

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan's National Defense Committee decided Monday to form a seven-member investigative task force aimed at clarifying doubts on the ROC Navy's "Kuang-hua Six" plan to purchase a fleet of fast-attack missile boats.

The ROC Navy's program to build 30 fast-attack missile boats is called " Kuang-hua Six." A prototype has already been built. Test firings with surface-to-surface Hsiungfeng II missiles have been accomplished. The members of the task force are to be chosen according to each party's proportional representation in the legislature.

The legislature's defense committee suspects the procedure of the tender held by the Ministry of National Defense (MND) was defective and is vowing to shed light on it with this investigative task force. A meeting will be held next Monday to determine their working agenda.

The task force will have the right to have access to the official documents related to the "Kuang-hua Six" procurement plan. If needed, it will also have to interview persons involved. It will be led by a convener who is also spokesman.

It has been reported that this purchase plan might be delayed because a private shipyard, Jong Shyn Shipbuilding based in the southern city of Kaohsiung, contested the result of the tender won by the state-run China Shipbuilding Corporation (CSBC).

At first, Jong Shyn's plea was not accepted. But the company further appealed to the Public Construction Commission under the Executive Yuan, claiming that the decision to attribute this ship-building contract to the CSBC was defective.
Following the appeal, the MND assigned the case to the Bureau of Investigation under the Ministry of Justice (MJIB) in October and asked the CSBC to suspend the contract in November.
Still then, the MND's procurement authorities evaluated the CSBC as the best tender following discussions in mid-November.
The platforms to be built under the "Kuang-hua Six" plan are 150-ton fast-attack missile boats that will carry four Hsiungfeng II surface-to-surface missiles.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER INSTRUCTS MAC TO AID ROC PROTESTERS IN HONG KONG

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council will offer aid to any ROC citizens who were among around 900 protesters arrested in Hong Kong during anti-globalization protests at the World Trade Organization (WTO) talks Saturday, Premier Frank Hsieh said Monday.
Hsieh asked MAC officials stationed in Hong Kong to try to secure the release of the detained ROC protesters as quickly as possible within the confines of the law and while observing human rights.
Sources from Hong Kong said that the protesters, coming from all countries around Asia, were arrested after being accused of assaulting and battering Hong Kong police.
The violence is still under investigation. Hong Kong authorities have vowed to prosecute those who attacked police.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HOPES TO BUILD OFFICIAL EXCHANGE MECHANISM WITH MACAU

TEXT.P: Civilian exchanges between Taiwan and Macau have continued to grow since China took over control of Macau from the Portuguese Dec. 20, 1999, but strenuous efforts have to be made to promote bilateral official engagements, the Mainland Council Affairs (MAC) said in a report released Monday.

The MAC issued the report on Macau's current situation in the fields of politics, economy, social development and its relations with Taiwan to mark the sixth anniversary of the sovereignty handover of the former Portuguese colony.

The report said that the government of the special administrative region of China has performed fairly well in ruling the land located on China's southeast coast under the leadership of incumbent Chief Executive Ho Hau Wah.

However, fast expansion of the gambling sector is unbalancing the economy of Macau, while public concerns over social order are emerging after conflicts among casino operators were seen to be increasing.

The report said there have been close personnel exchanges between Taiwan and Macau, with the number of Taiwanese travelers being the third-largest of those of foreigners visiting the former Portuguese colony.

According to statistics of Taiwan's Bureau of Immigration, the number of Taiwanese traveling to Macau from January to November this year was over 1.08 million, posing a year-on-year growth of 18.7 percent.
The number of Macau citizens traveling to Taiwan in the 11-month period was registered at over 17,000, posing a year-on-year growth of 0.8 percent.

The council hopes that the Macau government will take more aggressive actions in the development of official exchanges with Taiwan to push for reciprocal Taiwan-Macau relations by trying to promote functions of institutionalized communication channels between the two sides and open a representative office in Taiwan, MAC officials said.
The ROC government will continue efforts to boost exchanges and cooperation with all sectors in Macau based on existing foundations, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: President Gives Both Reassurance, Warnings on Iraq; 'Victory or Defeat' Are Only Options, He Says.
President Bush last night hailed Thursday's Iraqi elections as a vital step toward stabilizing that nation, but warned that despite the political progress more violence lies ahead as Iraq struggles to establish a democracy amid araging insurgency.

DOC.HEADLINE: APPEAL TO ALLOW RANKING CHINESE OFFICIAL TO VISIT TAIWAN REJECTED

TEXT.P: The Bureau of Immigration on Monday let stand its decision to reject an application for a high-ranking Chinese official in charge of Taiwan affairs to come to Taiwan.

The National Policy Foundation, a think tank of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), originally invited Chen Yunlin, director of China's Taiwan Affairs Office, to visit Taiwan to attend an economic and trade forum slated for Dec. 15.

The forum would have been the first of its kind between the KMT and the Communist Party of China (CPC) in more than 50 years after the CPC defeated the KMT in a civil war in China that caused the KMT to flee to Taiwan in 1949.

However, the Bureau of Immigration rejected the foundation's application for Chen Nov. 18, citing as reasons present cross-strait relations, international practice as well as the desire to improve cross-strait relations.
The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council said that given Chen's political position, prior cross-strait consultations would be needed before the trip would be allowed.
The quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) contacted its China counterpart to exchange views on the proposed trip, but all requests for bilateral communication fell on deaf ears.
The KMT-affiliated think tank then appealed the rejection and the Bureau of Immigration convened another screening meeting Monday.

Wu Hsueh-yen, deputy commissioner of the Bureau of Immigration, said that more than 20 officials attending the screening meeting had not raised different views and decided to let stand the original decision.
On learning that the request was rejected again, a KMT official expressed regret.
But Chang Jung-kung, director of the KMT's Department of Chinese Affairs, said that the party still hopes to sponsor the forum in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP'S WELFARE FACTION VOWS TO DISBAND IF CHAI TAKES PARTY HELM

TEXT.P: The Welfare State Alliance, a major faction within the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), said Monday if Legislator Trong Chai wins the upcoming by-election for DPP chairman it would set an example for other factions and disband.
Chiu Chui-chen, the faction's convener, said the Welfare State Alliance has decided to support Chai's party chairmanship bid.

As Chai, a key member of the Welfare State Alliance, has made "an end to factional politics and infighting within the party" one of his campaign appeals, Chiu said the Welfare State Alliance will take the lead and dissolve if Chai is elected DPP chairman.

DPP members are scheduled to vote Jan. 15 to elect a new chairman to fill the position left vacant by the resignation of Su Tseng-chang who assumed political responsibility for the party's defeat in the Dec. 3 local government chiefs elections.

Chai, who has already registered his candidacy, was quoted as having said at a meeting of the Welfare State Alliance faction earlier in the day that factional politics is very entrenched in the DPP, and this has hindered the party's reforms and ability to transform itself into a highly competitive political force.

"Many foreign political parties also have factions within their ranks, but their factions have never been as institutionalized as those in the DPP. I have long been advocating disbanding intra-party factions as the first step to our party's reinvention and resurrection, " said Chai, a political science professor-turned politician.

DOC.HEADLINE: KEELUNG HOSTING 2005 TAIWAN PHOTOGRAPHIC EXHIBITION

TEXT.P: The 2005 Taiwan Photo Fair opens Tuesday at the Keelung Cultural Center and will run until Jan. 8, 2006.
The annual exhibition, held by the Photographic Society of Taiwan, is co-sponsored by the Cultural Affairs Bureau of the Keelung City Government.
More than 1,000 works submitted by photographers from both Taiwan and other countries will be on display. They cover various aspects of human activities and nature around the world.
The event, now in its 37th year, is held in a different city of Taiwan each year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S OVERALL ECONOMIC INDEX GOOD: PREMIER HSIEH

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Monday that Taiwan's overall economic index is good as real estate prices have shown steady growth, and with the stock market rising and foreign tourist arrivals growing.
The premier made the remarks when he led financial and economic officials to meet with representatives of small- and medium-sized enterprises over afternoon tea.

Some representatives urged the government to allow Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan as well as to open direct trade and transportation links with China. Others pointed out that recent "insider trading" scandal has affected investors's faith in the stock market. Still others pointed out that because of the merger of domestic banks, they are worried whether it will be more difficult for them to get needed loans.

Hsieh noted that cross-strait policy needs constant communications and views from all sides and will not be decided by the premier alone. If a proposed national economic advisory conference is to take place, then cross-strait policy can be discussed.

Vice Premier Wu Rong-i also said that small- and medium-sized enterprises need not worry about getting loans, saying that all banks can provide financing for them and the government also supports small- and medium-sized enterprises.

Susan Chang, deputy head of the Financial Supervisory Commission, also reassured the participants that a revised draft securities transaction law will soon enter its second and third reading in the Legislative Yuan which will effectively handle insider trading cases after it clears the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOLOMON ISLANDS PRIME MINISTER TO ARRIVE TUESDAY FOR VISIT

TEXT.P: Solomon Islands Prime Minister Allan Kemakeza is scheduled to arrive in Taipei Tuesday for a five-day official visit at the invitation of President Chen Shui-bian, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Monday.
During his visit, Kemakeza will exchange views with President Chen on regional issues, bilateral relations and other matters of mutual concern, MOFA officials said.

Kemakeza will also meet with Premier Frank Hsieh, Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen, Council of Agriculture Chairman Lee Chin-lung, Department of Health Minister Hou Sheng-mao and other senior government officials as well as visit major cultural institutions, industrial parks, Kaohsiung Harbor and major medical facilities.
Taiwan and the South Pacific island nation of the Solomon Islands have been cordial since they forged diplomatic ties in 1983, MOFA officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Asking for Patience, Bush Cites Progress in Iraq
U.S. President Bush declared to the nation on Sunday night that the United States was winning the war in Iraq and pleaded with his viewers not to "give in to despair" over a conflict that has cost more than 2,100 American lives and an estimated 30,000 Iraqi deaths. In a 17-minute live televised address from the Oval Office, his first in the formal setting since he announced that he had ordered the Iraq invasion in March 2003, Bush offered a vigorous reaffirmation of an unpopular war and asked his viewers for patience.
Wall Street Journal: Growing Pains To Bag China's Snack Market, Pepsi Takes Up Potato Farming
After concluding a decade ago that Coca-Cola Co. held an insurmountable lead in soft drinks across much of the world, Pepsi embarked on a risky gambit in China and other key markets -- one that relies increasingly on potatoes, not just soda pop. Pepsi decided to build its global presence by dominating snacks and other packaged foods, much as its Frito-Lay and Quaker businesses had helped battle Coke in the U.S. But pulling that off outside North America was far more complicated, ultimately forcing Pepsi to become something it had never intended to be: a farmer. Pepsi has potato farms in inner Mongolia and Beihai on China's southern coast as well as budding programs in Russia, Poland and South Africa. The Pepsi farms illuminate an intriguing new thread in the changing global economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET APPOINTS OFFICIAL TO TAKE OVER 'IN AND OUT' MAGISTRATE

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan has appointed the secretary-general of Taitung County Government as the acting magistrate so that "all business will go on as usual," an official of the Executive Yuan said Monday.

Cho Jung-tai, secretary-general of the Executive Yuan, made the announcement after Ministry of the Interior officials said earlier in the day that magistrate-elect Wu Chun-li will be immediately suspended after being sworn in Tuesday.

Lai Shun-hsien, will take Wu's place until a new magistrate is produced via a by-election, Cho said. Wu will be suspended because of his involvement in a corruption scandal when he was deputy speaker of the Taitung County Council. He was sentenced to 16 years in prison in the first trial in 2002, and communized to seven years in the second trial. Wu appealed and the Supreme Court overturned the verdict of the second trial and return the case for a retrial.

According to the law, Wu will be suspended immediately after being sworn in, Cho said, Lai will take over as acting magistrate because the operations of the Taitung County Government cannot be put on hold. Wu will not have the right to appoint a deputy once he has been suspended as magistrate, interior ministry officials said.
Wu can only return to his post if and when a higher court acquits him, they added. It's unclear when a higher court will hand down a verdict.
Wu's aides said Monday that they have been anticipating Wu's suspension upon swearing in but they were caught off guard when they learned that Wu couldn't appoint a deputy for the post.

The aides said they had expected Wu to appoint his team before receiving the suspension papers, and after his suspension, he would seek to get his conviction overturned. If he was unable to do this, he was going to resign at the most favorable time, and run again in a new election.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LEGISLATOR COMES UP WITH NEW PLAN ON MILITARY PROCUREMENT

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Lee Wen-chung came up with a three-point plan Monday to address a long-stalled arms procurement project.

The U.S. government agreed to sell Taiwan a robust arms package in April 2001, including eight diesel-electric submarines, 12 P-3C Orion anti-submarine warfare (ASW) aircraft and six Patriot PAC-3 anti-missile batteries. The opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan, however, has refused to screen relevant budget plans for the package for the past few years.

According to Lee's new three-point plan, the eight diesel-electric submarines should be financed by a special budget as originally planned to convince the United States to open a new production line to build the submarines.

Lee, a co-convener of the legislature's defense committee, also suggested that the 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft be financed by the Ministry of National Defense's regular budget and the legislature had better pass an increase to the ministry's 2006 budget during its next session scheduled to begin in February.
As for the six Patriot anti-missile batteries, Lee said this can be addressed after the three-year deadline expires in March 2007.
Lee was referring to a clause in the Referendum Law that states that is a question put to national referendum is turned down, it cannot appear in another referendum until after three years.

Lee urged the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People first Party to make a unified response to his new proposal as soon as possible because the United States may change its mind and decline to sell Taiwan the arms if Taiwan continues to drag its feet.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC URGED TO PUSH HK TO RELEASE NTU STUDENT AS SOON AS POSSIBLE

TEXT.P: National Taiwan University President Lee Si-chen said Monday he has asked the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) to consult with the Hong Kong government for an early release of an NTU student who has reportedly been charged with unlawful assembly in the former British colony.

Media reports said Hong Kong police have decided to charge 14 detained anti-WTO protesters with unlawful assembly, including Lee Chien-cheng, a 22-year-old student at NTU's political science department.

Lee Si-chen, who just returned from a visit to Japan where he was conferred an honorary doctoral degree by Kansai University, said NTU's student affairs department has asked the MAC to help push for Lee Chien-cheng's release as early as possible.
NTU authorities will also offer all necessary assistance to the student through every possible means, Lee Si-chen said.

Two other students from Shih Hsin University's Graduate Institute of Social Development were also arrested by Hong Kong police last weekend, but they were later released. One of them already returned to Taipei Monday evening and the other is expected to return Tuesday, school authorities said.

More than 1,000 anti-WTO protesters, mostly South Korean farmers, were rounded up by Hong Kong police Sunday for going on a violent rampage outside a meeting of the World Trade Organization (WTO). Most of them were released as of Monday evening.

DOC.HEADLINE: 43% SEE THEIR WEALTH SHRINK: SURVEY

TEXT.P: More than 40 percent of respondents to a recent survey said their wealth has dwindled over the past year, the GlobalView magazine reported Monday.

According to the magazine's 2005 wealth management survey, 43 percent of those surveyed said their assets have shrunk over the past year, compared to 26.4 percent who said their wealth has increased. Another 24.6 percent said their wealth has remained almost the same.

The survey found that 22.9 percent said their salaries have declined since the new labor pension system was implemented July 1. Only about 6 percent said they have enjoyed a pay raise and 34.2 percent said their salaries have remained unchanged.

"The poll results show that the new 'portable' pension system has to some extent affected employers' willingness to raise wages for their employees and in some cases, wages have even been cut, " an analysts said.
About 30 percent of the respondents said they have lessened shopping to cope with their trimmed income.
On investment, the survey found that an average of 50 percent of mutual funds managers have helped their clients earn money and that overseas funds were the most profitable investment tools.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIME NOT YET RIPE FOR CROSS-STRAIT UNIFICATION: KMT CHAIR
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Dec. 19 (CNA) (By Lillian Lin and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The time is not yet ripe for unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Taiwan's main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou has said in an interview with Newsweek magazine.
Ma, who doubles as Taipei mayor, said while Beijing does not want to see Taiwan pursue de jure independence, it also refrains from pushing for unification at the moment.

For Taiwan, Ma said, the most important thing at present is to maintain the status quo and refrain from provoking Beijing. Taiwan should instead promote cross-strait trade and investment and take steps to ease cross-strait tension, he added.

In the interview with Newsweek correspondent Jonathan Adams, Ma said for the KMT, unification is its ultimate goal. But it doesn't have a timetable for realizing that goal. He said he doesn't think either side is ready for unification. The situation is not ripe yet, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Dec. 20, or the 20th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1852: British troops annex Pegu, lower Burma, during a war with Burma.
1913: Taiwan's North-South Railway Trunk Line is completed.
1921: Mahathir Mohamad, Malaysian prime minister, is born.
1927: Kim Young-sam, former president of South Korea, is born.
1922: Fourteen republics of Russia form the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics.
1924: Adolf Hitler is paroled after serving eight months of a prison sentence after being convicted of high treason.
1928: Britain recognizes the government of the Republic of China.
1941: The Flying Tigers, flown by U.S. Air Force volunteers, shoot down four Japanese planes in their first encounter near Kunming in southwest China.
1944: Young Chinese students begin to enter training camps in response to a call to join the armed forces and fight against Japan.
1945: Soviet troops move an estimated US$2 billion-worth of machinery from Manchuria to the Soviet Union.
1950: Fu Shih-nien, president of National Taiwan University, dies of a stroke at the age of 55. He collapses while answering interpellations at the Taiwan Provincial Assembly.
1968: John Steinbeck, the American novelist who won the Nobel Prize for literature for books such as "The Grapes of Wrath" and "East of Eden," dies at the age of 66.
1960: The Viet Cong, the armed wing of the National Liberation Front, is founded in South Vietnam.
1968: The ROC chooses 26 new members of the National Assembly and the Legislative Yuan from among 52 candidates.
1971: President Agha Mohammed Yahya Khan resigns after Pakistan losses control over East Pakistan, now Bangladesh.
1973: Spanish Premier Luis Carrero Blanco is killed when assassins bomb his car in Madrid, Spain.
1981: The Kuangfu River Tunnel in Taitung is formally open to traffic, becoming the first railway tunnel under a river in Taiwan.
1982: Arthur Rubinstein, Russian-born American pianist, dies at the age of 95 in Geneva.
1986: Some 30,000 students march for democracy through the streets of Shanghai in mainland China's largest demonstration since the Cultural Revolution.
1988: The first batch of five mainland Chinese students, who are studying in the United States, arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1989: Some 12,000 U.S. troops join 12,000 already in Panama to unseat Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega as head of that country.
1991: President Boris Yeltsin announces that Russia wants to join the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO).
1994: Mexico lowers the peso's trading floor, triggering a drastic devaluation.
1997: South Korean President Kim Dae-jung pardons Chun Doo-hwan and Roh Tae-woo, two former military dictators who had tried to kill him when he was a dissident.
1998: Nkem Chukwu of Houston, Texas, becomes the first woman to give birth to eight live babies.
1999: The Wang Kuang-ying Library, dedicated to a public-spirited ROC man who collected garbage for 35 years and used the money he earned to buy books and donate them to the local and overseas institutions, is inaugurated in Taipei.
1999: ROC President Lee Teng-hui tells visiting U.S. Congresswoman Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) that the ROC's ultimate goal of seeking peaceful reunification with mainland China remains unchanged.
2000: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian says when receiving a seven-member Japanese parliamentary delegation that maintaining peace across the Taiwan Strait is in the common interest of the ROC, Japan and the United States.
2001: Twenty-one city and county chiefs from around Taiwan are sworn in at official ceremonies, vowing to better serve the local people and to deliver on their campaign promises.
2001: A consortium of leading telecommunication companies launches services on the Asia Pacific Cable Network 2 (APCN 2), the world's first Asian submarine ring system that comprises 19,000 km of cable connecting mainland China, Taiwan, Hong Kong, Japan, Korea, Malaysia, the Philippines and Singapore.
Confucius: "Now, if in your conversation you give few occasions for men to criticize you, and in your conduct you have few occasions for self-reproach, you cannot help getting preferment."

Wu appealed and the Supreme Court overturned the verdict of the second trial and return the case for a retrial.

According to the law, Wu will be suspended immediately after being sworn in, Cho said, Lai will take over as acting magistrate because the operations of the Taitung County Government cannot be put on hold. Wu will not have the right to appoint a deputy once he has been suspended as magistrate, interior ministry officials said.
Wu can only return to his post if and when a higher court acquits him, they added. It's unclear when a higher court will hand down a verdict.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE HEAD AS PREMIER WOULD POSSIBLY MARK BREAKTHROUGH: DPP

TEXT.P: It could be a breakthrough in relations between the administration and the legislature if Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng were to head the Cabinet, the legislative party whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Tuesday.

Noting that the DPP has long sought a breakthrough in interactions between the administration and the opposition-controlled legislature, Chao Yung-ching said that appointing Wang, an opposition Kuomintang (KMT) stalwart, as premier would possibly mark a turning point in deadlocked relations between the two branches of government.
Chao said that a Wang-led Cabinet would result in much better interactions between the administration and the legislature.

As premier, Wang would definitely have power in policy-making and appointing personnel, Chao said, adding that the KMT-led opposition "pan-blue alliance" should not disregard the DPP's sincerity in this regard.

The DPP legislative caucus head made the remarks amid speculation that President Chen Shui-bian might invite an opposition politician to be the next premier following the DPP's defeat in the Dec. 3 "three-in-one" local government elections.
Wang has denied over the last several days that he is on Chen's short list of candidates for the post.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 50 TAIWAN BUSINESSES SIGN UP FOR TRADE FAIR IN PANAMA
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Dec. 19 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: At least 51 Taiwan businesses will take part in the 24th EXPOCOMER international commercial exhibition to be held March 8-12 in Panama City.
It will mark the 23th year in a row that Taiwan businesses display their latest products at the fair, officials from the ROC Embassy in Panama said Monday.
ROC Ambassador Hou Ping-fu and August Simons, head of the Chamber of Commerce, Industries and Agriculture of Panama, signed a contract Dec. 15 on leasing space at the fair for Taiwan businesses.
Two-way trade between Taiwan and Panama has rapidly expanded since the free trade pact between the two countries came into effect Jan. 1, 2004.
For 2004, trade between Taiwan and Panama, excluding the Colon free trade zone, reached US$32.7 million, representing an increase of 25.28 percent over the 2003 level.

Panamanian exports to Taiwan totalled US$11.06 million in 2004, posting a record-high year-on-year growth of 67.15 percent, while Taiwan exports to the Central American nation hit US$21.63 billion, up 11.05 percent, according to the ROC Embassy.

For the first nine months of this year, two-way trade amounted to US$33.79 million, with Panamanian exports to Taiwan hitting US$14.82 million, up a whopping 112.96 percent over the figure for the same period a year earlier. Meanwhile, Taiwan exports to Panama reached US$18.96 million, up 14.49 percent year on year.

Pointing out that Panama's trade deficit with Taiwan dropped from US$10.57 million in 2003 to just US$4.14 million last year, Hsu Ta-wei, an ROC embassy official in charge of economic affairs, said the free trade accord has done well in eliminating the trade imbalances between the two countries.
At the EXPOCOMER 2005 held March 2-6, Taiwan businesses received contracts totalling some US$4.65 million, with US$8.25 million-worth of follow-up orders, according to the embassy.

At next year's exhibition, Taiwan businesses will mainly show off their high-quality products, including computers and peripheral equipment for computers, communications equipment, electronic products, parts and components for automobiles and motorcycles, bicycles, electric home appliances, sports gear, medical equipment, and processing machines.

Over 500 businesses from 30 nations attended the 2005 Panamanian trade fair, which hosted more than 300,000 visitors. Business deals signed at the exhibition totalled US$97 billion in value, according to EXPOCOMER organizers.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMMIGRATION LAW SHOULD BE REVISED TO STOP HUMAN TRAFFICKING: LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: The immigration law should be revised to strengthen Taiwan's ability to deter the smuggling of people into the country and help stamp out human trafficking, ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Hsiao Bi-khim said Tuesday.

Speaking during a public hearing on Taiwan's immigration law and possible revisions, Hsiao said that although working to eliminate human trafficking is now a worldwide trend and that a recent U.S. State Department report on the problem assessed that Taiwan "does not fully comply with the minimum standards for the elimination of trafficking, " the Executive Yuan-proposed draft amendment to the law does not deal with the issue of trafficking.
Hsiao joined DPP Legislator Chen Chung-hsin and opposition Kuomintang Legislator Wang Yu-ting in calling for the Executive Yuan to pay closer attention to the issue.

According to Su Ching-chao, a deputy director from the Ministry of the Interior's Population Administration Department, the Executive Yuan's draft amendment mainly deals with three issues: namely how to attract foreign professionals to Taiwan to help boost the country's economic and trade development; strengthening the system of interviews and related checks for screening foreigners applying to reside in Taiwan; and simplifying administrative procedures and paper work to protect human rights and make entering and exiting the country more convenient.

Hsiao said it is pitiful that there is not a single word in the draft amendment on eliminating human trafficking. She reminded the Executive Yuan to heed the matter since the U.S. State Department report released this past summer indicated that "Taiwan lacks a comprehensive trafficking law."

The report indicated that Taiwan is primarily a destination for trafficked women and girls, mainly from the China, who are smuggled into the country for the purpose of sexual exploitation. Some trafficking victims from China, Thailand, Cambodia and Vietnam are forced or coerced into the commercial sex trade or lured to Taiwan by bogus offers of employment or marriage.
"Taiwan laws criminalize most forms of trafficking but do not address prevention of trafficking or victim protection, which the authorities nonetheless provide on an ad hoc basis," the report said.

It further said that "Taiwan authorities do not fully comply with the minimum standards for the elimination of trafficking; however, they are making significant efforts to do so. Taiwan authorities have increased efforts to provide protection for trafficking victims. Despite prosecutions of traffickers, there is insufficient protection for trafficking victims, particularly for women and girls from the PRC (People's Republic of China)."

"Foreign victims of trafficking who are not of PRC origin are provided with shelter and counseling and are generally quickly repatriated. But current Taiwan law provides no legal alternative to the return to the PRC of all unlawfully present PRC citizens, including trafficking victims," it said.

On this concern, Ho Sen-kuei, a director with the Bureau of Immigration, suggested that the immigration law be revised to include people from the mainland China area to entitle them to protection for trafficking victims.

Meanwhile, Wu Mei-hung, an official with the Mainland Affairs Council, maintained that the issue of trafficking should be tackled from the angles of prevention, investigation and apprehension, as well as protection.
