DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE RATIFIES TAIWAN-GUATEMALA FREE TRADE AGREEMENT

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan on Tuesday ratified the ROC-Guatemala free trade agreement (FTA) , which will now take effect Jan. 1, 2006 as scheduled.

The agreement was signed by President Chen Shui-bian and his Guatemalan counterpart Oscar Berger Perdomo Sept. 22 during Chen's state visit to the Central American country. Chen had expressed the hope that the FTA would come into effect on the first day of 2006 in line with the implementation of the Central American Free Trade Agreement (CAFTA).
The CAFTA covers the United States, central American nations and the Dominican Republic.

The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) has assessed that the Taiwan-Guatemala FTA will have only a limited impact on Taiwan's agricultural sector because despite the fact the island will open its doors wide to agricultural imports from the country, there will be strict screening and quarantine measures in place.

While signing the pact, Chen said that the FTA will help redress the trade imbalance between Taiwan and Guatemala, which is currently heavily in Taiwan's favor. He further said that Guatemala can use Taiwan as a gateway to explore the wider Asian market while Taiwan can use Guatemala as a springboard into the North American market.

Vice Economics Minister Chen Ruey-long affirmed the pact in November of last year while filing a report on it at the Legislative Yuan, saying that the FTA between Taiwan and Guatemala is expected to boost Taiwan's annual exports by an estimated 5.5 percent to 6 percent.
In 2004, Taiwan exported US$110 million worth of goods to Guatemala while importing US$4.1 million worth of Guatemalan products, according to official statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PAN-GREEN' LAWMAKERS FORCE ARMS BILL ONTO LEGISLATIVE AGENDA

TEXT.P: "Pan-green" camp legislators pulled a fast one on their opposition "pan-blue alliance" colleagues at the Legislative Yuan's Procedures Committee Tuesday by calling for a snap vote on the long-stalled arms purchase bill when some opposition legislators were away at another meeting.

At around noon time, when only five "pan-blue alliance" lawmakers were present at the meeting, one of the 12 lawmakers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), which form the "pan-green" camp, proposed a vote whether to put on the legislative agenda the arms bill and the review of the president's nominations for Control Yuan members.

Committee chairman William C.T. Lai of the DPP ruled that a vote be held immediately to decide on DPP Legislator Hsu Kuo-yung's proposal. By 12: 30 p.m., the committee had voted 12-5 to put the two matters on the legislature's meeting agenda, leaving the five "pan-blue alliance" legislators in a daze.

This was the ruling camp's 42nd attempt to put the NT$480 billion arms purchase budget bill on the legislative agenda. That amount had been cut down from NT$610.8 billion. The funds are for the purchase of eight conventional submarines, 12 anti-submarine aircraft and six anti-missile batteries from the United States.

Huang Yi-chiao, convener of the People First Party's legislative caucus, said Lai did not follow precedent by allowing all members to speak and called a surprise vote when other "pan-blue alliance" members were attending a legislative negotiation session chaired by Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng. "This was a very childish move," Huang said.

Tseng Yung-chuan, executive director of the Kuomintang's (KMT) Central Policy Committee and party whip at the legislature, said Lai's snap vote "meant nothing" except to create legislative turmoil because it did not follow proper and legal procedures and is therefore "invalid and illegal."
Tseng said lawmakers of the "pan-blue alliance" of KMT and PFP, who hold a slim majority, will simply return the two items to the Procedures Committee in Friday's legislative meeting.

He criticized Lai for having acted "in a stupid way" by inciting a ruling-opposition division because the legislature was dealing with the government's overall budget bill, a time that he said calls for harmony, not stand-offs.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAITUNG MAGISTRATE-ELECT NAMES EX-WIFE AS DEPUTY

TEXT.P: Wu Chun-li, the magistrate-elect of Taitung county in eastern Taiwan, named his ex-wife Kuang Li-chen as his deputy magistrate immediately after he was sworn in in a controversial move called invalid by an official administering the swearing-in ceremony.

Knowing that he would be suspended from his post immediately after assuming office Tuesday because of his involvement in a corruption case, Wu divorced his wife Monday in order to sidestep the restriction against a magistrate selecting a relative or spouse as deputy.
Wu asserted the appointment of Kuang before Minister of Council of Indigenous Peoples Walis Pelin, who administered his swearing in, could stop him.
However, Pelin said immediately that Wu's suspension was effective immediately upon his being sworn in to office and that he therefore did not have the right to name any deputies.

Pelin refused Wu's request to have the county's seal handed over to him as a symbol of the transfer of power, saying the Executive Yuan has named the county's chief staff Lai Shun-hsien as the acting magistrate.

The swearing-in ceremony, which took place at the auditorium of the county hall, was packed with Wu's supporters who gave him and his ex-wife a big round of applause when they entered the hall. They also applauded when Wu claimed that he was the magistrate before receiving the interior ministry's notice of his suspension.

Wu, who served as the speaker of the county council before entering into the race for the magistracy, was sentenced in 2003 by the Taiwan High Court to a prison sentence of seven years and eight months for his role in a corruption case in 2000. He has appealed the sentence to the Supreme Court.
The Ministry of the Interior had warned during Wu's campaign for magistracy that he would not be allowed to serve as magistrate even he were to win the election.

DOC.HEADLINE: MA, SOONG TO MEET AGAIN TO DISCUSS POLITICAL SITUATION IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The leaders of Taiwan's two main opposition parties -- the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) -- have agreed to meet again Friday to discuss how to cope with the changing political situation in Taiwan after the Dec. 3 local government elections.

A spokesman for the KMT said the meeting will take place at the Taipei Youth Activity Center, and that KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and PFP Chairman James Soong will meet behind closed doors in the presence of only the secretaries-general of the two parties.

In their previous meeting on Dec. 12 that lasted four hours, Ma and Soong pledged that the "pan-blue alliance" formed by their parties will step up cooperation in the run-up to an eventual merger and push for an early realization of the opening of the direct "three links" -- trade, postal and transportation links across the Taiwan Strait.

The second Ma-Soong meeting in 10 days became necessary after Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng confirmed Monday that President Chen Shui-bian had consulted with him about the possibility of letting someone from the "pan-blue alliance" serve as the next premier and form his Cabinet.

Chen's gesture has been seen as an attempt to alleviate the growing pressure within the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) after the party suffered a humiliating defeat in the Dec. 3 elections. Some analysts believe Chen's plan might be aimed at alienating the KMT if he does not intend to relinquish the power to form the Cabinet to the KMT.

Ma made clear the KMT position Monday that the matter should be settled through party-to-party negotiations, and that the president must let the "pan-blue alliance" designate the premier and appoint all Cabinet members. However, he said the KMT must consult with the PFP and another ally -- the New Party -- and form a consensus on the issue before the "pan-blue alliance" makes the next move.

Meanwhile, Soong confirmed on the outlying island of Matsu that after meeting with Ma Thursday, he will meet with Wang to discuss the president's overture to let the main opposition parties form the Cabinet.
Soong said he believes that it would be "barking up the wrong tree" to ask the DPP government to let the opposition parties appoint the premier and all the Cabinet members.

DOC.HEADLINE: REGISTRATION CLOSES FOR DPP CHAIRMAN BY-ELECTION

TEXT.P: Former Changhua Magistrate Weng Chin-chu signed up Tuesday for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) chairmanship by-election slated for Jan. 15, just before registration for the race closed.
Weng also announced her decision to withdraw from the DPP's New Tide faction, stressing that running for chairman or whoever wins should not be swayed by factional influences.
Weng's registration came one day after former DPP Chairman Lin I-hsiung had paid a visit to her, reportedly to persuade her to run.

However, Weng would not confirm if her decision to join the race was the result of Lin's persuasion. Weng said she knows very well that grassroots DPP members and the public have high expectations for the DPP and she pledged that if she is elected, she will work hard to try to win back public support for the party.
Also, Weng said she will stick to the values of democracy, freedom and dignity that the DPP has been following.
Weng's participation increased the number of registrants to three. The other two are former Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun and DPP Legislator Trong Chai.

The DPP's Central Standing Committee will review the qualifications of the registrants on Wednesday and hold a draw on Dec. 22 to decide the numerical designations of the candidates. The new chairman is expected to take office after the Chinese Lunar New Year holiday in February.
Over the past days, Lin reportedly has actively persuaded several DPP politicians, including Weng, DPP Legislator Hung Chi-chang and former Minister of Justice Chen Ding-nan to enter the race.
Both Hung and Chen said they had no intention of running.
Hoping for a new generation of leaders, Lin has openly expressed his expectations for the next chairman.

According to Lin, the current president and vice president, as well as past premiers or party chairmen should not serve as the next DPP chairman. Lin also said that the next chairman should not run in the 2006 Taipei or Kaohsiung mayoral election or the 2008 presidential election because he or she must concentrate on party and election campaign affairs.

The remarks were believed to be aimed at Yu, a former premier. Vice President Annette Lu has acted as DPP chairwoman after Su Tseng-chang stepped down early this month to take political responsibility for the party's drubbing in the Dec. 3 "three-in-one" elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PASSENGERS MAKE UP BULK OF ARRIVALS AT MACAU AIRPORT
DOC.DATELINE: Macau, Dec. 19 (CNA) (By C.H. Jen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Visitors from Taiwan accounted for over half of all arrivals at Macau International Airport during the first 10 months of the year, according to airport statistics.
The airport registered a total of 3.61 million arrivals for the January-October period, of which 2.12 million, or 59 percent, were from Taiwan, the statistics showed.

The total number of arrivals for the period marked an 18 percent increase over the year earlier figure. The main sources of visitors were Taiwan, China, Thailand, Malaysia and South Korea, in that order. Chinese arrivals amounted to 1.14 million, up 8 percent year on year.
The 2.12 million arrivals from Taiwan represented an increase of 15 percent over the figure for the same period a year earlier.

Meanwhile, the Macau airport handled a total of 201,976 tons of cargo in the first 10 months of the year, 83 percent of which were goods transported between Taiwan and China. Airport authorities have forecast that the airport will handle a record high of more than 220,000 tons of cargo for the whole of 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST THINK TANKS OPTIMISTIC ABOUT TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC GROWTH IN 2006

TEXT.P: Most local economic think tanks are optimistic about Taiwan's economic growth for 2006, believing it could top 4 percent with the expectation of international oil prices leveling and growth of world trade likely to accelerate next year.

Noted economic think tanks, including Academia Sinica, the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research and the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) , have forecast that Taiwan's economic growth will top out between 4.01 percent and 4.5 percent, with the CEPD being the most optimistic about 2006 growth.

CEPD Vice Chairman Yeh Ming-feng said that Taiwan's economic growth in the first half of 2005 was lessened as a result of skyrocketing oil prices and high interest rates. Luckily, Yeh said, growth has rebounded from the third quarter and a better picture is expected to continue throughout the year.

Worldwide, Yeh said, 2006 economic growth is seen to top 7 percent -- better than this year's growth, which is predicted to be around 6.4 percent -- under the anticipation that oil prices will stop spiraling next year.

Domestically, Yeh quoted a CEPD forecast as predicting that Taiwan's economic growth will be 4.5 percent in 2006 as a result of a series of economy-revving measures, including more public construction projects to be launched islandwide.

Liang Kuo-yuan, director of the Palaris Research Institute, predicted that private consumption will be one of the prime movers behind Taiwan's economic growth next year, which is expected to top 4.18 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEARLY HALF POLLED UNSATISFIED WITH HIGHER EDUCATION IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Some 48 percent of the Taiwan people are not satisfied with the country's higher education due to its low quality, in contrast to 24 percent who expressed their approval, according to the results of a recent survey.
About 44 percent opined that it is the government that must assume the task of education reform, while 21.5 percent said that it is also partly the public's responsibility, the survey results showed.

Some 42 percent of the respondents said they want their children to receive their education in Taiwan, but 36.3 percent said that they would prefer to send their kids to study in the United States or Europe if possible.
Nearly 53 percent contended that colleges should focus on professional education, while 15 percent said that higher education should be mandatory.
Meanwhile, 85 percent of those surveyed agreed that college professors should be strict with their students, with older respondents more inclined to agree with this, the poll found.

Most of those surveyed said they expect college students to have a social conscience, good morals and respect for their professors, but some 20 percent expressed the belief that college students nowadays spend much of their time on seeking pleasure and are not fond of studying.
A total of 1,068 Taiwan residents aged over 18 were interviewed in the survey conducted by Shih Hsin University Dec. 3-4. The survey has a margin of error of 3 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Italy's central bank governor Fazio quits.
Italy's central bank governor Antonio Fazio announced in a written statement Monday that he had decided to quit immediately for the sake of the country's and Bank of Italy's best interests. Fazio is under judicial investigation for alleged insider trading and abuse of office in the wake of two scandal-surrounding bank takeover bids earlier this year. Both ruling and opposition politicians weelcome Fazio's resignation.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Old NKF slammed for poor practices.
The former board and chief executive of the National Kidney Foundation (NKF) have been given adamning report card by independent auditors KPMG.
A 322-page report released yesterday described a charity which had moved away from putting patients first to focus instead on major fund raising.
But out of every donation dollar it raised, the auditors found that only 10 cents went to the NKF patient -- not more than 50 cents as former CEO T.T. Durai and the board had claimed.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Old NKF's management malpractice has been exposed.
The independent auditors KPMG announced report yesterday and exposed extravagance, lack of governance at Singapore's National Kidney Foundation (NKF).

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: GMA pays tribute to Davide
President Arroyo yesterday hailed Chief Justice Hilario Davide Jr. as "a paragon of service and honesty" during his nearly 15 years in the judiciary, and said that finding his replacement would be difficult.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Firms go after Meralco
EXASPERATED by the delay in Manila Electric Co.'s refund of P18 billion to private corporations, business leaders are seriously considering the adoption of the Arroyo administration's plan to exchange collectibles for shares in the Lopez-managed utility.
The Philippine Star: Senate won't rush terror bill
The Senate has rejected President Arroyo's call to rush the passage of the anti-terrorism bill in the same way the House of Representatives passed its own version last week.
The Manila Times: Senate refuses to rush terrorism law
SENATORS on Monday rejected President Arroyo's plea to rush approval of the antiterrorism bill "just because US President George Bush had asked her for it."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Bush's Support Jumps After a Long Decline; More Americans Upbeat on Iraq, Economy.
President Bush's approval rating has surged in recent weeks, reversing what had been an extended period of decline, with Americans now expressing renewed optimism about the future of democracy in Iraq, the campaign against terrorism and the U.S. economy, according to the latest Washington Post-ABC News Poll.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Moscow, Dec.20 [CNA] The Moscow Times: UN, EU Aim to Revive Caucasus Economy.
Starting next year, international aid to the North Caucasus will be targeted much more toward sustainable economic and social development in an effort to try to end the volatile and depressed area's dependence on humanitarian aid. [By Chang Hung-kuang]

DOC.HEADLINE: ISSUANCE OF NEW ID CARDS TO BEGIN FROM WEDNESDAY

TEXT.P: Household registration offices around the country will begin issuing the new version of identification cards to local citizens Wednesday.

Premier Frank Hsieh, Minister of the Interior Su Jia-chyuan, and Sun Yueh, a popular actor-turned-volunteer in the promotion of social welfare, will jointly host a news conference at the household registration office of the Da-an district of Taipei to inaugurate the issuance, according to the Ministry of the Interior (MOI).

On Wednesday, not only those who are up for ID card renewal that day can have their new cards, but also people who register their marriage, change their household address, or change their registered name that day are able to receive new ID cards.

The last time ID cards were renewed was in 1986. Customarily, ID cards were renewed every 10 years, and the MOI had intended to renew the cards in 1996, but it was forced to postpone the procedure until this year due to some technique problems and a controversial governmental policy concerning fingerprinting.

The fingerprinting policy led some lawmakers to request a constitutional interpretation by the Council of Grand Justices, which ruled on Sept. 28 that the fingerprinting policy was unconstitutional, promoting the MOI to drop it.

MOI official of population administration, Hsiao Chen-chia, said Tuesday that a color photo taken within the last year, the old ID card and the applicant's chop are needed to get a new card, noting that the applicant is allowed to designate a proxy to apply, but has to pick up the new ID card in person around two weeks after submitting the application.
The public should renew their ID cards according to the time and venue printed in notices mailed to them by local household registration offices to shorten their waiting time, Hsiao said.
Over 19 million new ID cards will be issued until Dec. 31 2006, according to the MOI.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ID CARDS SHOULD HAVE OPTION FOR ANCESTRAL NAMES: INDIGENOUS GROUP

TEXT.P: New ROC ID cards should mean having the option to use one's ancestral name, according to an indigenous group that asked the government Tuesday to make this procedure easier.

A 1994 amendment to the law regarding how names should be displayed on ID cards states that Taiwan's indigenous people can register their ancestral names using their indigenous mother tongue. However, as of September of this year, only 890 people had chosen to use their aboriginal name on their ID cards. Sixty-five of these have already come forward publicly to say that they regret having made the change.

In an attempt to reclaim their ancestral culture, the indigenous group that calls itself the Vine Cultural Association has called on more than 50 of its members to change their Chinese names on their ID cards into their mother tongue at a household registration office Wednesday, the day that the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) will begin to issue the new version of IDs.
"We hoped to convince at least 100 of our members to correct their names, but only a bit more than 50 were willing to do this, " said Mayaw Biho, the head of the association.
Mayaw said he hopes the procedure to change a person's name on their ID card can be simplified.
"For starters, the application time for this ought to be shorten to one day," he said.
The time the household registration office currently needs to change anyone's name takes at least three days to run a check to see if the person in question has a criminal record.

Mayaw explained that a name rectification by an aborigine would be to " correct" their name instead of changing it; therefore, the time spent on investigation into the background of the applicant could be saved, assuming that officials would see the difference between "correcting" a name and changing one.
"Of course the new version of the ID card should have our traditional name on it, and the household certificate transcript modification fee should be waived," Mayaw said.

"The household registration office should be in charge of correcting our names on all other official papers such as driver's licenses, health insurance cards, passports and so on. We'd also like to see the Romanization of our mother tongue name under the Chinese characters on our ID cards," Mayaw added.

Mayaw said that it's a difficult decision for indigenous people to actually change the name shown on their ID cards as society basically frowns on the practice, not to mention the fact that many feel that they will be discriminated against by those who do not understand the meaning of using an ancestral name.

Mayaw gave an example. "An indigenous teacher in eastern Taiwan got very frustrated when a student's parent told the school principal that he didn't want his child to be taught by an aborigine," he said.
Lipay Sinsi, a woman in her 50s, said that it took her about four years to cut through all the red tape to finally get her ancestral name on all her official documentation.
"If I had tried to do it all at the same time, it would have been impossible. So I first corrected my ID card, then the other cards were corrected when they expired," Lipay said.
Ado Kaliting Pacidal, a TV commentator, said that she uses her mother tongue name on her TV programs, but hasn't yet corrected her name on official documents.

"I am going to apply for the new version of the ID card tomorrow. When I was a little girl, I had to be familiar with two names. One used in my family when speaking my mother tongue, especially when my grandparents wanted to tell me intimate things, and the other Chinese one, which was only used at school and on administration forms," Ado said.
Panay Arik, a young woman student in her early 20s, said that she only learned the meaning of the word "Panay" at school when she was 19 years old.

"Panay means 'a stalk of rice.' I did not like the name until I learned its meaning. My parents expected me to be humble when they gave me this name because the more rice on a stalk, the more it bends," Panay said.
A series of TV commercials will be broadcast at the beginning of January next year to encourage more indigenous people to correct their names.

DOC.HEADLINE: HAIR MERCURY LEVELS HIGH AMONG TAIWAN MEAT, FISH EATERS: EPA

TEXT.P: The hair mercury levels among Taiwan people average 2.4 mg/kg, slightly higher than that of Americans and Japanese, according to the results of a survey released Tuesday by the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA).

While the hair mercury levels of people who eat large -- and therefore older -- fishes frequently are six times higher than those who do not eat fish, those of meat-eaters are eight times higher than vegetarians, the survey shows.

However, Wang Cheng-hsiung, deputy head of EPA's Bureau of Environmental Inspection, said the hair mercury levels of Taiwanese are still much lower than the maximum toxicity level of 50 mg/kg stated by the World Health Organization. He urged the public not to panic, although he said it would be best if they could avoid eating large, deep-sea fishes to reduce their mercury intake.

Nearly all fish contain some amount of mercury. Mercury accumulates in the body, so larger, older fish such as shark or swordfish contain the highest amounts and pose the largest threat if eaten regularly.
When you eat fish you absorb over 95 percent of the mercury that they contain.

The survey was conducted on 1,066 people, with the hair mercury levels of men and women averaging 2.92 mg/kg and 1.84 mg/kg, respectively. The figures compared with the 2.5 mg/kg among Japanese men and 1.6 mg/kg among Japanese women and are also higher than the U.S. reference level of 1 mg/kg.

The hair mercury levels found in the samples ranged from 0.12 mg/kg to 18.9 mg/kg. Older people have a higher level than those who are younger, with the levels of those 60 and above being 1.5-times higher than that of people 20 and below.

The survey showed that the mercury levels of the sampled people are related to their dietary habits. The hair mercury levels among meat-eaters average 2.54 mg/kg, compared with 0.32 mg/kg among vegetarians. People who eat a lot of large fishes, such as tuna, swordfish, shark and salmon, have an average hair mercury level of 3.68 mg/kg, compared with 0.55 mg/kg among people who do not eat fish.

Meanwhile, Hualien County residents registered the highest mercury level at 3.09 mg/kg, while Taichung City residents register the lowest at 1.83 mg/kg. By occupation, the mercury levels of dentists, who have regular contact with mercury-containing amalgam, are 1.6-times higher than others.

According to Wang, mercury is a long-lasting, accumulating contaminant, and a content of more than 50 mg/kg in human bodies can damage the nervous system. Pregnant women who eat seafood of high mercury content can cause brain defects in the fetuses, he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC ASSISTING DETAINED TAIWAN STUDENT IN HONG KONG

TEXT.P: Taiwan's representative office in Hong Kong has organized a three-member attorney group to assist a National Taiwan University (NTU) student who has been detained and charged with unlawful assembly in the former British colony, the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Tuesday.

Earlier the same day, the council said, Pao Cheng-kang, Taiwan's top representative in Hong Kong, paid a visit to Lee Chien-cheng, a 22-year-old student at the NTU's political science department who has been in police custody since last weekend for his part in anti-free trade demonstrations during a World Trade Organization (WTO) meeting.
Tsai Jy-jon, director of the MAC's Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Department, said the MAC and Taiwan's representative office have been working in concert to offer Lee all necessary assistance.

According to Tsai, 12 Taiwan citizens along with more than 1,000 other anti-WTO protesters from neighboring Asian countries were arrested by Hong Kong police last Saturday for going on a violent rampage outside a WTO convention hall. Except for Lee, all other Taiwan citizens have been released.

Hong Kong police charged 14 men, including Lee, with unlawful assembly Monday for their role in the anti-WTO demonstrations last weekend and released another 944 people who were detained. Among those being charged were 11 South Koreans, one Japanese, one Chinese and one Taiwanese.

Tsai said Taiwan's representative office in Hong Kong has asked for Lee's release on bail. The Hong Kong court rejected the request on the grounds that Lee has neither any relatives nor a residency permit in Hong Kong, Tsai said.
A Hong Kong court is scheduled to review the case Dec. 23, Tsai said. It remains unclear why Hong Kong police have charge only the 14 men, Tsai said.

A group of NTU students visited the MAC to push for its assistance for their classmate. Tsai assured them that the MAC and the representative office in Hong Kong will do their best to ensure Lee's safety and early release.
If convicted, Lee may face a fine of HK$5,000 (NT$21,500) plus three years in prison, according to the Hong Kong public security statute.

Most of the 1,000-plus people rounded up during the protests, in which activists attacked riot police and sought to disrupt the WTO ministers meeting, were militant South Korean farmers and unionists. Police repelled the demonstrators with batons, pepper spray, water cannons and tear gas. It was the worst street violence in decades in Hong KOng. More than 100 police and protesters were injured.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Transit Union Walkout Follows Collapse of Contract Talks
Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union, which represents 33,700 subway and bus workers in New York, announced its first strike in 25 years this morning after feverish last-minute negotiations faltered over the transportation authority's demands for concessions on pension and health benefits for future employees. New York State's Taylor Law bars strikes by public employees and carries penalties of two days' pay for each day on strike, but the transit union decided it was worth risking the substantial fines to continue the fight for what it regards as an acceptable contract.
Wall Street Journal: Movers and Shakers Five Who Laid the Groundwork For Historic Spike in Oil Market
The oil shocks of the 1970s and 1980s happened for a simple reason: huge and sudden cuts in supply. After supply was restored, oil prices eased. Today's energy crunch -- which has seen oil prices double since 2003 -- is different. Once again, supply shocks have played a role, including those triggered by hurricanes in the oil-rich Gulf of Mexico and the U.S. invasion of Iraq. But the real cause is a profound shift in the global energy system that has been 25 years in the making: The world's thirst for oil has grown faster than the industry's ability to slake it. Decisions of five persons have vital impact on oil price. They include the OPEC Czar, gas guzzler, prophet, Washington warrior, and oil baron.

DOC.HEADLINE: WANG TO URGE SOONG TO LET GO OF OLD GRUDGES

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng said Tuesday that during his meeting with James Soong on Dec. 24, he will urge the chairman of the opposition People First Party (PFP) to stop holding onto past grudges, but instead look forward and work for the highest interests of the nation by responding to the people's expectations.

Answering questions from news media at the legislature, Wang said that he will brief Soong at the meeting about what was discussed between President Chen Shui-bian and himself during their latest consultation.

He said the issues the president discussed with him included the deadlock in the legislature over the two bills about military procurement from the United States; the legislature's reluctance to endorse the nominees named by the president as members of the Control Yuan, the nation's highest watchdog body; cross-Taiwan Strait relations; and the possibility of letting the main opposition parties form a new Cabinet.

Wang did not say what past grudges he will ask Soong to leave behind, but it is widely known that Soong and the president are not on speaking terms because the president has ignored Soong's demand for an apology from the president for making a false claim to the nation that Soong had a secret meeting with Chen Yunlin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office of China's State Council, in the United States early this year.

Soong filed a lawsuit in June against the president, asking for a symbolic compensation of NT$1 for defamation of his reputation. However, in October after the president continued to say that his claim was not without a reason, Soong filed a second suit, increasing the damages he sought to NT$50 million.
While visiting the outlying island of Matzu Tuesday, Soong told news media that he would not be interested in having another meeting with the president.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL TO CARRY FORMOSAT-3 TO L.A. FOR SUBSEQUENT LAUNCH

TEXT.P: China Airlines (CAL) will airlift the newly built FORMOSAT-3 COSMIC satellite and its peripheral equipment to Los Angeles Wednesday.
This is the third time that CAL will have carried a satellite, a spokesman said Tuesday.
The flight will take off at 3: 50 a.m. Dec. 21. It will land in Los Angeles at 11 p.m. Dec. 20 local time.

To insure security during transportation, CAL has sent some of their specialists to the National Space Organization (NSPO) in Hsinchu, around 70 kilometers south of Taipei Dec. 19 to supervise the packaging operation.
After arriving in Los Angeles, FORMOSAT-3 COSMIC will then be loaded on atruck that will take it to Vandenberg Air Force Base where it will be launched.
"COSMIC" stands for Constellation Observing System for Meteorology, Ionosphere and Climate.
FORMOSAT-3 COSMIC weights 1.080 tonnes, but with all the periphery and accessories needed for its transportation and protection, the flight will have to carry 13.791 tonnes.

Two National Science Council engineers will follow the satellite during its trip. CAL said that they are experienced in transporting delicate things such as instrument of extreme precision, artwork and antiques.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONCERNED ABOUT ARMS PROCUREMENT BILL: MOFA

TEXT.P: Washington is concerned about progress in a major arms procurement bill stalled in Taiwan's legislature that would allow billions of dollars in arms purchases from the United States, an official of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday.

Chin Jih-hsin, director-general of MOFA's North American Affairs Department, made the comments to reporters after the bill was finally included on the agenda at the Legislative Yuan by its Rules Committee earlier the same day.

Noting that cross-Taiwan Strait security has always been one of the major concerns of the United States in its relations with Taiwan, Chin said that Washington has repeatedly urged Taiwan to beef up its defense capability to deter China from attacking Taiwan.

But the U.S. side fully respects Taiwan's dealings of its internal affairs, such as when the legislature will approve the procurement package, the purchase items and their value of the major arms procurement package, he noted.

Twelve lawmakers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its ally the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) railroaded the major weapons purchase bill through a Rules Committee meeting earlier that day, in which only five lawmakers of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) were present.
KMT and PFP legislators accused the bill passage process of being flawed and vowed to kill the bill in Friday's legislative session and return it to the committee.

Meanwhile, PFP Chairman James Soong said that it will be harder for the "pan-blue alliance" to maintain its "fragile majority" at the Legislative Yuan in the future as a result of the KMT's faulty election strategy. Four KMT lawmakers have to give up their legislative seats after being elected as local government chiefs in the Dec. 3. elections.
The major arms procurement bill put forth by the Ministry of National Defense (MND) has been blocked at the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan since the middle of 2004.

The bill originally called for procuring eight diesel-powered submarines, six PAC III Patriot anti-missile batteries and 12 anti-submarine airplanes from the United States through a special budget of NT$610.08 billion

The MND later slashed its budget proposal and agreed to finance the purchase of the anti-missile batteries in its annual regular budget to seek legislative support for the bill. But the "pan-blue alliance" still declined to screen it.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAGISTRATES AND MAYORS-ELECT SWORN IN

TEXT.P: The mayors-elect and magistrates-elect of 23 cities and counties nationwide were sworn in Tuesday.

They included several firsts in Taiwan's political history. These are, namely, Su Chih-fen, the first woman magistrate in Yunlin County; Huang Min-hui, the first Kuomintang (KMT) mayor in Chiayi City in more than 50 years; Lu Kuo-hua, the first KMT magistrate in Ilan County in 24 years; Chou Hsi-wei, the first KMT magistrate in Taipei County in 16 years; and Liu Cheng-hung, the first non-Hakka magistrate in Miaoli County where two-thirds of the residents are Hakkas.

Others serving for the first time at their new posts are Cho Po-yuan for Changhua magistrate, Lee Chao-ching for Nantou magistrate, Wang Chien-fa for Penghu magistrate, Chao Chi-hung for Pingtung magistrate, and Wu Chun-li for Taitung magistrate. However, Wu was suspended from his post immediately after assuming office because of his involvement in acorruption case.

The re-elected are Chen Ming-wen for Chiayi magistrate, Lin Junq-tzer for Hsinchu mayor, Cheng Yung-chin for Hsinchu magistrate, Hsieh Shen-shan for Hualien magistrate, Yang Chiu-hsing for Kaohsiung magistrate, Hsu Tsai-li for Keelung mayor, Lee Chu-feng for Kinmen magistrate, Chen Hsueh-sheng for Liangchiang magistrate, Jason Hu for Taichung mayor, Huang Chung-sheng for Taichung magistrate, Hsu Tain-tsair for Tainan mayor, Su Huan-chih for Tainan magistrate, and Chu Li-lun for Taoyuan magistrate.

The KMT won 14 of the 23 magistrate and mayoral seats up for grabs in the Dec. 3 elections, while the Democratic Progressive Party got six. The People First Party and New Party each won one. The other one went to an independent politician.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG AIRPORT SHOULD BE ALLOWED CHARTER SERVICES: MAYOR HU

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu said Tuesday that he has asked the central government to approve the Chingchuankang Airport in Taichung County to ply charter flights between Taiwan and China during the coming Chinese New Year holiday season.
Hu said that he has notified the central government to make this a reality because many Taiwan businessmen with operations in China are from the central region.

President Chen Shui-bian promised to allow the airport to operate direct flights to destinations in China after full air transport links have been opened across the Taiwan Strait, Hu said, adding that before that, the government should consider permitting it to serve cross-strait lunar new year charter passenger flights.

Authorities in Taiwan and China have decided to operate direct cross-strait charter passenger flights during the coming Chinese New Year holiday period from late January to the middle of February in 2006.

But only Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in northern Taoyuan County and Kaohsiung International Airport in the south have been authorized to provide the service in links to four destinations in China -- Guangzhou, Xiamen, Shanghai and Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: SNAP VOTE ON ARMS BILL NOT AIMED AT PROVOKING PARTISAN STRIFE: DPP

TEXT.P: The railroading of two long-stalled bills through the Legislative Yuan's Rules Committee was aimed at spotlighting the opposition "pan-blue alliance's" absurdity and irrationality, not to provoke an interparty stand-off, a ruling party official said Tuesday.

Legislator Ker Chien-ming, who concurrently serves as the head of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) policy coordination department, was referring to a snap vote engineered by the DPP and its "pan-green" ally -- the Taiwan Solidarity Union -- in the legislature's Rules Committee earlier in the day to put two controversial bills onto the legislative agenda.

The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) , which controls a slim majority in the legislature, has blocked the two bills -- a robust arms procurement package and the review of the president's nominations for Control Yuan members -- from being put on the legislative agenda for more than a year.

At around noon, when only five "pan-blue alliance" lawmakers were present at the Rules Committee meeting, one of the 12 "pan-green" lawmakers proposed a vote whether to put the two bills on the agenda for discussion at the legislature's plenary session this Friday.

Committee convener William Lai of the DPP ruled that a vote be held immediately. By 12: 30 p.m., the committee had voted 12-5 to put the two bills on the legislature's agenda, leaving the five "pan-blue alliance" legislators stultified.

This was the DPP's 42nd attempt to put the NT$480 billion arms purchase budget bill on the legislative agenda. That amount had been cut from NT$610.8 billion. The funds are for the purchase of eight conventional submarines, 12 anti-submarine aircraft and six anti-missile batteries from the United States.

Dismissing the DPP's move as childish, "pan-blue alliance" lawmakers have vowed to kill the two bills at Friday's plenary session. They said the DPP's surprise blitz would only worsen the hostility between the ruling and opposition camps.
In response, Ker said the "pan-blue alliance's" stonewalling of the two bills from being rationally screened and debated on the legislative floor is absurd and unconstitutional.
"Our move is only aimed at letting the public understand the severity of the matter," Ker added.

TEXT.P: Former U.S. State Department spokesman Alan D. Romberg is scheduled to visit Taiwan Jan. 6-9 at the invitation of a local academic institution, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Tuesday.

Romberg, who is now director of the East Asia department at the Henry L. Stimson Center, a Washington-based think tank, will attend a seminar on relations across the Taiwan Strait, Taiwan's general political situation and a long-stalled arms procurement package, the official said.
Romberg will also meet with senior ROC government officials during his visit, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO HELP REBUILD UNIVERSITY IN TSUNAMI-HIT ACHE PROVINCE
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Dec. 20 (CNA) (By Charles Kang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will assist in rebuilding a university in the tsunami-hit Ache province in Indonesia, a spokesman for the Republic of China representative office in Jakarta said Tuesday.

Taiwan has donated a large amount of money and relief goods and sent rescue and medical personnel to help with post-disaster rehabilitation programs in Ache, one of the hardest-hit areas in last December's tsunami catastrophe.
As education has played a key role in social development, the spokesman said, the ROC government will help rebuild a university in Ache to allow for its residents to receive a better education.

A team of staff members at the ROC representative office in Jakarta arrived in Banda Ache, capital of Ache province, Tuesday to conduct a field study and initial negotiations with Indonesian officials there, the spokesman said.

Over the past year, many non-government organizations from Taiwan have also sent volunteers to help with post-disaster relief work in Ache. Among them are two Buddhist groups -- the Tzu Chi and the Dharma Drum Mountain foundations.

ROC Representative to Indonesia Lin Yung-lo is scheduled to arrive in Ache Sunday to attend a Buddhist ritual in memory of those who died in the tsunami disaster that rattled a number of Southeast and South Asian countries Dec. 26, 2004.

Lin will also attend a memorial event to be sponsored by the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, Taiwan's largest charity, in Banda Ache. Indonesian President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono will officiate at the memorial service to express his gratitude for Tzu Chi's generous relief aid for numerous Indonesian tsunami victims.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RANKS AMONG TOP IN ANNUAL FREEDOM HOUSE SURVEY

TEXT.P: Taiwan ranks among top in two key indexes -- political rights and civil liberties -- in the "Freedom in the World 2006" survey released by the Freedom House, a U.S. non-profit organization dedicated to promoting democracy and freedom.
Taiwan receives the top score of one point in both the "political rights" and "civil liberties" categories in the Freedom House survey, Government Information Office Minister Pasuya Yao said Friday.

"Taiwan made progress in the political rights category, advancing from a score of two points recorded in the previous year to the top score of one point this time around, " Yao said, adding that the upswing can be attributed to further strengthening and advancement in Taiwan's electoral processes.
According to the Freedom House survey, Yao said, Taiwan has joined 49 other countries, including the United States and Britain, in the top rank in terms of political rights and civil liberties.
In contrast, China continues to rank among the "not free" countries category in the Freedom House 2006 survey.

Since 1978, the Freedom House has unveiled a "freedom in teh world" survey in mid-December annually in terms of two measurements -- political rights and civil liberties. A total of 192 countries around the world were gauged this year. In its "one-to-seven" scale, one point represents most free and seven refers to least free.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Dec. 21, or the 21st day of the 11th month of Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1620: Pilgrims on the ship Mayflower come ashore at Plymouth, Massachusetts.
1804: Mohammed Ali Jinnah, founder and first governor-general of Pakistan, is born.
1817: Governor Lachlan Macquarie formally adopts the name "Australia" for the British colony located on the continent with the same present-day name.
1876: Joseph Stalin, Soviet leader, is born.
1898: Scientists Pierre Curie and Marie Curie discover radium.
1901: The "Ching Yi Pao," a newspaper founded by Liang Chi-chao, who together with Kang Yu-wei initiated a reform movement in 1898, ceases publishing after the 100th issue.
1930: Hwang Thu-sui, Taiwan's first sculptor, dies at the age of 35.
1935: Walt Disney's "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs" premieres in the United States.
1940: F. Scott Fitzgerald, the American author who chronicled the Jazz Age in books such as "Tender is the Night" and "The Great Gatsby," dies at the age of 44.
1945: George Smith Patton Jr., the U.S. general who led the Third Army's sweep across France and into Germany during World War II, dies in a car crash at the age of 60.
1958: Charles de Gaulle is elected president of France after a new constitution is adopted, marking the beginning of the Fifth Republic.
1968: The Apollo 8 spacecraft, as a part of the United States' Apollo program to land men on the moon, is launched.
1971: Hsieh Kuan-sheng, president of the Judicial Yuan, dies in Taipei.
1971: Kurt Waldheim, an Austrian diplomat who later become president, is chosen to be the secretary-general of the United Nations on his birthday.
1972: East and West Germany sign a treaty ending more than two decades of enmity.
1975: The convention of the World Chinese Language Education Association opens in Taipei.
1975: Oil ministers from 12 countries are taken hostage after terrorists raid an OPEC meeting in Vienna, Austria.
1975: The Executive Yuan announces that Taiwan's economy grew by 2.8 percent in 1975, with a GNP of US$14.4 billion and per capita income of US$700.
1988: Soviet cosmonauts Musa Manarov and Vladimir Titov return to earth after a record 365 days in space.
1988: A Pan American jumbo jet crashes in the Scottish border town of Lockerbie, killing all 258 people on board.
1990: The building of the ROC Navy's first missile frigate begins at the Kaohsiung shipyard of the China Shipbuilding Corp.
1991: The ruling Kuomintang wins 71 percent of the vote and 254 of the 325 seats in elections for the Second National Assembly.
1995: Under an agreement signed between Israel and the PLO in September 1995, Israeli troops withdraw from Bethlehem, ending their 28 years of occupation.
1998: Beijing sentences mainland Chinese dissidents Xu Wenli and Wang Youcai to prison terms of more than 10 years each for trying to register the China Democracy Party.
1999: Taiwan is listed as the 12th-most important maritime country in the world for the year.
2000: Taiwan's non-profit Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) announces the development of a commercial software package, dubbed Fast Local Alignment for Gigabases (FLAG), allowing rapid genomic DNA searches and comparisons.
2001: The Legislative Yuan approves an amendment to the Employment Services Act allowing foreign workers to work in Taiwan up to six years instead of three years.
Confucius: "Uphold the cause of the just and put down every cause that is unjust, and the people will submit. But uphold the cause of the unjust and put down every cause that is just, then the people will not submit."

DOC.HEADLINE: V.P. EXPECTS DPP CHAIRMANSHIP ELECTION TO BE 'FAIR RACE WITH STYLE'

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu, who also currently serves as acting chairwoman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), expressed Wednesday her expectation that the upcoming DPP chairmanship by-election will be a "fair race with style."

Lu, who was nominated as the interim party chairwoman during a regular meeting of the DPP Central Standing Committee Dec. 6 after Su Tseng-chang stepped down to take responsibility for the DPP's humiliating defeat in the Dec. 3 city and county chief elections, has ruled out the possibility of her running for the DPP chairmanship.

The vice president made the remarks during a meeting at the DPP Central Standing Committee Wednesday to screen the qualifications of the three candidates -- former Premier and Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun, DPP Legislator Trong Chai and former Changhua County chief Weng Chin-chu.
If nothing unexpected happens, the party chairmanship by-election, slated for Jan. 15, will be a three-way race.

"I am eager to see that via this by-election, the DPP will produce a new leader who is not only capable of leading the party to a rebirth, accelerating democratic reforms and deepening the Taiwan identity, but who is also capable of helping Taiwan meet the challenges brought by globalization," Lu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PEOPLE'S SUPPORT A KEY FOR UNIFICATION: BEIJING OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: A Chinese Taiwan affairs official has said that peaceful unification can only be discussed when it is supported by the Taiwan people, according to a report carried by the Hong Kong-based Wen Wey Po Daily Wednesday.
The official, who wished to remain anonymous, said that the time will be ripe for the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to discuss peaceful unification only when most of the Taiwan people support it.

The report also quoted a Chinese scholar as saying that currently, Beijing no longer wants to talk about a "unification timetable" as it realizes the complications in dealing with work related to the Taiwan issue.
According to the scholar, the main point of China's current Taiwan policy is to prevent the island from moving toward independence.

"This does not mean that Beijing will not push for eventual unification with the island," the scholar said, adding that it "will map out a more systematic, detailed and tolerant scheme for future cross-strait unification."
The remarks by the Chinese official and the scholar were in response to comments made Taiwan's opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou during his Dec. 9 interview with Newsweek magazine.
Ma told the magazine that even though eventual unification is a goal of his party, there has certainly been no timetable set.
Noting that the time is not yet ripe for unification, Ma said that he does not think that neither side is ready to move forward toward unification.
"Currently, China neither works on matters related to unification nor talks about it," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE ARREST THREE SUSPECTED 'SNAKE HEAD' RING MEMBERS

TEXT.P: Police arrested three individuals suspected of being part of a "snake head" ring in three separate raids in the southern port city of Kaohsiung Tuesday night, sources from the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) reported Wednesday.

After receiving a tip, CIB investigators, backed up by Kaohsiung police, arrested a Taiwan man surnamed Yen, a Taiwan woman surnamed Ho and a mainland Chinese woman surnamed Chen at their residences. The three are suspected of having smuggled at least 40 mainland Chinese citizens into the country with forged documents.

In the raids on the homes of the three suspects, police discovered stacks of forged documents and certificates, including bogus marriage certificates issued by local governments in China, entrance guarantees for Chinese citizens, registration forms for immigrants, household registration papers, mainland Chinese residential cards and travel documents.

Yen confessed at the police station that he has worked with an accomplice, surnamed Lee, who remains at large, to help mainlanders travel to Taiwan with forged papers and travel documents with back-up by Yen's Chinese wife in Ningde City, Fujian Province. Each of the illegal mainland Chinese immigrants paid NT$10,000 (US$303) to be trafficked into Taiwan, he further told police.

Meanwhile, CIB investigators have discovered that guarantee papers for more than 40 entrance applications filed by mainland Chinese citizens carry doctored stamps issued by Kaohsiung police between November 2004 and July 2005, meaning that more than 40 mainland citizens entered Taiwan with forged papers during that period.
All three of the arrested suspects said they did not know the current whereabouts of the mainland Chinese citizens that had entered the country using forged documents provided by the ring.

DOC.HEADLINE: REDISTRICTED CONSTITUENCIES EXPECTED BY NEXT NOVEMBER: CEC CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: The Central Election Commission (CEC) will promulgate the newly redistricted constituencies for the next legislative elections by the end of November 2006, CEC Chairman Chang Cheng-hsiung said Wednesday.
Chang made the remarks when he reported to the Home Committee at the legislature on the progress of redrawing constituencies in line with electoral system reforms for legislators.

He noted that according to the constitutional amendment passed this June, the electoral system for legislators will be changed from the current multiple seats per constituency to a "single seat, two votes" format.
In line with the constitutional amendment, the CEC has been commissioned with the task of redistricting the constituencies.

As the issue has been controversial in the experience of many other countries, the CEC formed a task force in July to work out the redistricting principles, which were then sent to municipal, city and county election commissions.
The commissions will work out their draft redistricting plans and hold public hearings in early 2006 and send the results to the CEC in April for reference, Chang said.
The CEC team will hold public hearings by the end of next August and complete a draft redistricting plan by the end of September and then promulgate it by the end of November, he added.

Starting from the seventh legislature to be elected in 2007, the legislative electoral system will be changed, the Legislative Yuan will be halved to 113 seats and lawmakers will be elected every four years. While 73 seats will be elected from regional districts, there will be six seats for aboriginal representatives and 34 seats for at-large and overseas expatriate representatives.

CEC officials have said that the redrawing of the constituencies should be promulgated one year before the term of the incumbent legislators expires, which means it should be announced by Jan. 31, 2007 at the latest.

DOC.HEADLINE: NCC OPERATIONS SHOULDN'T BE AFFECTED BY STATUTE CONTROVERSY: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Wednesday the operations of the National Communications Commission (NCC) should not be affected by the constitutional controversy over the statute which provides for the commission's formation.

Noting that a panel charged with choosing NCC member nominees has agreed to select another nominee to replace Lu Chung-chin, chairman of the Electrical Engineering Department at the National Tsinghua University, who withdrew his name from consideration, the premier lauded the panel's response as positive.

After the final nominee is selected, the premier said he will immediately present the list of all 13 nominees to the Legislative Yuan for confirmation in the hope that the commission can begin its operations as soon as possible.

As to the controversy over the way the nominees were chosen, the premier said it should not affect the operations of the commission even if his administration decides to appeal to the Council of Grand Justices for a ruling on its constitutionality.

The premier was referring to Article 3 of the NCC Organic Law which stipulates that the nominees should be chosen from a pool of candidates recommended by the political parties in the legislature according to the number of legislative seats each party holds.

Hsieh's administration, which considers the provision an infringement on the power of the executive branch, had urged lawmakers from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and its political ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, to block it, only to see it railroaded through the legislature by the opposition.

The lawmakers who had fought tooth and nail in the legislature to try to block the bill have threatened to cut the Executive Yuan's budget unless it turns to the Council of Grand Justices for a ruling to invalidate the provision.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF MOONLIGHTERS MORE THAN DOUBLES IN ONE YEAR

TEXT.P: With a large number of outsourcing jobs being created amid the trend of business streamlining in Taiwan, tallies released Wednesday by a local online outsourcing job bank shows that the number of moonlighters has more than doubled in the past year.
According to Jcase, office workers who accepted second jobs through the job bank increased 2.37-fold from 52,372 in May 2004 to 124,058 in October 2005.

A survey of these workers indicates that 73.02 percent of them are pessimistic about the amount of year-end bonus they will receive and about the prospect of a pay hike this year. While most of them said they will be satisfied if they can get as much as they got last year, many are worried that they will get less or even nothing.
As many businesses have opted to outsource their work in an effort to reduce costs, a wide variety of part-time jobs are now available in the job market, Jcase officials said.

Unlike in the past when most outsourcing work was in the computer, writing and design categories, a lot of new options are being added to the list, which include program planners for year-end or New Year parties, pet sitters, adult story writers, and pornography dubbing actors, they said.

There are also companies looking for moonlighters who will be responsible for answering mobile phones to respond to callers' questions, offer legal counseling or simply chat with the callers, they said.
For those who are good at imitating the voice of popular singers such as Jolin Tsai an Jay Chou, there are jobs for pre-recording ringback tones for mobile phones, they added.
