DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAD INVITES 'THE JUST' TO SERVE ON ANTI-CORRUPTION COMMISSION

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou on Wednesday asked all to recommend qualified persons to serve on an anti-corruption commission that will be formed by the party next week.
Ma expressed the hope that "the just and fair" will serve on the commission so as to help build an "accountable" party system.
The commission will be made up of 11 members, with a maximum of five KMT members, Ma said.
The KMT Central Standing Committee passed the proposal to establish the anti-corruption commission at a regular meeting Dec. 14.

The commission was originally meant to handle complaints about corruption or other unlawful practices by members of the KMT nominated as president, vice president, head of the Executive, Legislative, Judicial, Examination or Control Yuans, or as Examination Yuan or Control Yuan members, grand justices, legislators, city mayors, county magistrates, or city or county council speakers.

However, the KMT Central Standing Committee, after its weekly meeting Wednesday, said that since grand justices, Control Yuan members and Examination Yuan members exercise their rights independently, they are not to be subject to the commission's supervision.

After completing investigations into any complaints, the commission will have the authority to discipline the officials involved, including revoking their nominations or party membership or suspending them, or to issue warnings to the officials or hand their cases over to judicial authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTU STUDENTS STAGE SIT-IN TO CALL FOR LEE'S RELEASE

TEXT.P: Dozens of college students staged a sit-in in front of the main gate of National Taiwan University (NTU) Wednesday to protest the recent arrest by Hong Kong police of NTU student Lee Chien-cheng for alleged unlawful assembly in the former British colony.

The students urged the Beijing and Hong Kong authorities to respect the principles of democracy and human rights and release Lee immediately. They argued that Lee is not violent and was not among the 1,000-strong rioters who were accused of assaulting and battering Hong Kong police during anti-globalization protests at the World Trade Organization (WTO) talks in Hong Kong Dec. 17.
Lee was among 14 protesters from Taiwan, South Korea, Japan and mainland China who were charged by Hong Kong law enforcement authorities after taking part in the WTO protests.
The students said they want the Hong Kong authorities to produce evidence to support their reasons for arresting Lee and keeping him detained.
They also urged the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) to "take immediate actions" to secure Lee's release.

According to NTU students who traveled to Hong Kong with Lee last week and had talked with him before returning to Taiwan Monday, Lee has not been provided with enough warm clothes and has even been stripped of his glasses while in detention.

Meanwhile, according to NTU student leader Hsu Po-jen, the NTU authorities have made three promises regarding assisting Lee. They agreed that an NTU professor, surnamed Huang, will accompany Lee's parents on a visit to Hong Kong to try to secure Lee's release, that NTU will retain Lee's student status during the period of his detention, and that NTU will foot the legal bills for Lee's release if the MAC refuses to pay, Hsu said.
Hsu added that a "Taiwan Conscience" activity to "save Lee" was launched Wednesday and that it will continue through Dec. 23 when a Hong Kong court is scheduled to review Lee's case.

Meanwhile, Tsai Jy-jon, director of the MAC's Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Department, said the MAC and Taiwan's representative office have been working in concert to offer Lee all necessary assistance.

According to Tsai, 12 Taiwan citizens along with more than 1,000 other anti-WTO protesters from neighboring Asian countries were arrested by Hong Kong police last Saturday for going on a violent rampage outside a WTO convention hall. All the Taiwan citizens that were arrested have been released, except for Lee.

Tsai said Taiwan's representative office in Hong Kong asked for Lee's release on bail, but the Hong Kong court rejected the request on the grounds that Lee has neither any relatives nor a residency permit in Hong Kong.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN CHE-NAN REMAINS SILENT AT COURT HEARING ON KRTC SCANDAL

TEXT.P: Former Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Chen Che-nan appeared in court for the first time Wednesday in a corruption case in connection with the construction of Kaohsiung's rapid transit system.
Chen remained silent throughout the hearing while his lawyer claimed the prosecution was wrong to charge him with accepting freebies from a major contractor related to the rapid transit project.
The Huapan Administration Consultant Co. did not treat Chen to two free trips to Thailand and South Korea -- it just "pre-paid" the ticket prices for Chen and others, according to the lawyer.
Still, the prosecutors requested that the court hand down a "severer than usual" sentence on the former senior official for repeatedly violating the law governing graft and corruption.
The presiding judge asked both Chen's lawyer and the prosecutors to supply further evidence to support their claims.

According to the indictment, Chen, his bodyguard Chen Chih-ming, former Vice Chairman Chen Min-hsien of Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) and two others accepted Huapan General Manager Yen Shih-hua and his wife Wang Tsai-pi's return tickets and visited Bangkok, Thailand July 6-9, 2002.
The time coincided with the KRTC schedule to select a contractor for hiring foreign workers working on the rapid transit lines and managing their life in Taiwan, the indictment noted.

From Nov. 1 to Nov. 3, 2002, the two Chens, plus bodyguard Chen and two others, again accepted free tickets offered by Wang Tsai-pi and traveled to Cheju Island, South Korea on a pleasure trip, the prosecution said.
When Chen Che-nan arrived at the court, he told the media that he trusts the judicial authorities. That was the only sentence he uttered throughout Wednesday's hearing.

Also appearing in court were the Yen-Wang couple, former legislator Liu Ping-wei and other defendants. Wang's lawyer accused the prosecution of illegally arresting her and encroaching upon her human rights. She also charged that her statements as recorded in the investigation report were not made out of her own free will.

Retorting her charges, the prosecution said her arrest was made with warrants; the investigation process was legal and tape-recorded; breakfast was supplied when she was in custody -- in short, no violations of her human rights ever occurred.

The KRTC scandal erupted in late August when Thai workers rioted in protest against their inhumane treatment by Huapan Co., bringing to light more corruption suspicions including the contract-awarding practices. Huapan's contract has since been canceled and Chen Min-hsien charged.

In Taipei, Premier Frank Hsieh, former mayor of Kaohsiung, called on the public to "let the justice system do its job." He also welcomed closer supervision of the MRT's construction work to ensure its operation safety in the future.
"And don't just look at the KRTC from negative perspectives. It needs cheering up," Hsieh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANUFACTURING INDUSTRY EXODUS TO CUT TAIWAN FOREIGN INCOME: ECONOMIST

TEXT.P: Taiwan will lose more than NT$2.5 trillion (US$75.14 billion) in foreign income annually if the country's manufacturing industry is allowed to move overseas, a local economist warned Wednesday.

Giving a speech on the challenges and future of the manufacturing industry, Taiwan Thinktank Chairman Chen Po-chih pointed out that many people in the country consider the manufacturing industry a low-value sector and are proposing that the country focus on research and development as well as marketing.

Chen said he agrees that a high-income country should pay attention to research and development and marketing, but this does not mean that the manufacturing sector -- now accounting for 23 percent of Taiwan's economic production and a large share of the country's exports -- can be done away with.
Noting that manufacturing still accounts for approximately 20 percent of the economic production of most developed countries, Chen said Taiwan has no reason to give up the manufacturing industry.

According to Chen, the production lines of the manufacturing industry can continue to stay in high-income countries and will not face competition from countries of low labor costs as long as their products are developed with unique know-how.

For example, he said, although China has the ability to manufacture commercial planes, the country continues to purchase aircraft from Boeing and Airbus mainly because it involve unique know-how in aircraft manufacturing.

With at least one million out of the total of 2.7 million workforce in Taiwan's manufacturing industry being labor-intensive, the exodus of the industry will seriously impact local society and the economy, Chen said.
If the manufacturing industry moves out of the country, it will be difficult for those working in the sector to find other jobs, which will worsen the unemployment problem, he pointed out.

In addition, the financial, transportation and electrical power industries, which mainly serve the manufacturing industry, will shrink significantly if the manufacturing industry no longer exists, he said.

Instead of adopting a laissez-faire attitude toward the manufacturing industry, Taiwan should encourage the manufacturing industry to produce distinctive products to enhance their competitiveness, he proposed.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN DECORATES SOLOMON ISLANDS PRIME MINISTER

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian decorated visiting Solomon Islands Prime Minister Sir Allen Kemakeza in recognition of his efforts in promoting bilateral relations Wednesday.

Kemakeza, who arrived in Taipei Tuesday for a five-day official visit, called on President Chen at the Presidential Office. On hand were first lady Wu Shu-jen, Vice President Annette Lu, and acting Presidential Office Secretary-General Ma Yung-cheng.
The two leaders exchanged views on regional issues, bilateral relations and other matters of mutual concern.
The president later hosted a luncheon for Kemakeza. Also on hand were Premier Frank Hsieh, the first lady, Ma as well as Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen.
Lu didn't attend the luncheon because she had to convene a news conference later to announce the formation of an anti-corruption commission.
Kemakeza will also meet with senior government officials, visit major cultural institutions, industrial parks, Kaohsiung Harbor and major medical facilities.
Relations between Taiwan and the South Pacific island nation of the Solomon Islands have been cordial since they forged diplomatic ties in 1983.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP ANTI-CORRUPTION COMMITTEE BECOMES OPERATIONAL

TEXT.P: An anti-corruption committee under the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) became operational Wednesday immediately after Vice President Annette Lu announced its establishment. The committee is aimed at galvanizing the DPP's image of integrity and discipline.

Lu, who was nominated as the DPP's interim party chairwoman during a regular meeting of the DPP Central Standing Committee Dec. 6 after Su Tseng-chang stepped down to take responsibility for the DPP's humiliating defeat in the Dec. 3 city and county chief elections, said that the DPP anti-corruption committee is open to all people, including non-DPP members, to report their findings about graft and irregularities committed by DPP officials or other government officials.

Noting that integrity and discipline are cornerstones of the DPP, which also helped the party win Taiwan's first peaceful transition of ruling political power in 2000, Lu said that it is regrettable that the DPP did poorly in the Dec. 3 "three-in-one" elections -- a development that can be attributed to a recent string of corruption scandals, including the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. scandal and the "vultures" insider-trading case.

As several officials from the DPP government were allegedly involved in the scandals, Lu said, President Chen Shui-bian has instructed the launch of a campaign against official corruption to regain the public's faith in government.

Attorney Chen Chuan-yueh, who was assigned to head the DPP anti-corruption committee, said that his job is daunting, but he will do his utmost to help discipline wayward DPP members or officials so that the DPP's image of integrity can be regained.
The committee will investigate the president, vice president, the premier, DPP legislators, city and county chiefs and DPP Central Standing Committee members if necessary, Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: FELLOW WOMEN URINATORS UNITE AND STAND UP!

TEXT.P: The shortage of women's restrooms on the campus of National Taiwan University has inspired a school feminist group to urge women Wednesday to stand up for their rights -- literally -- by standing when they urinate.

The group, the Gender Equality Commission, said that standing up while going to the bathroom is a liberating experience and is quicker and cleaner than sitting down, according to Lin Yi-ling, a member of the commission.

She said women have to wait much longer at public restrooms because there are fewer stalls in the women's rooms compared to men's rooms. The line would move faster if women just stood up to urinate and, besides, this would eliminate the problem of sitting down on a dirty toilet seat, she said.

In addition to showing the history of how women have adapted to passing water standing up in different places around the world, kits manufactured in the United States, the Netherlands, Canada, Taiwan and China to help women urinate in a standing position were on display at an activity Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: NGOs Say Amendments Won't Help
Out of 74 pages of amendments to a bill on nongovernmental organizations the State Duma will consider Wednesday, NGOs said only a handful were any help, while the majority made the bill more restrictive..

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, gaining NT$0.06 to close at NT$33.256.
A total of US$776 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.302 and fluctuated between NT$33.251 and NT$33.322.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END HIGHER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 44.05 points to close at 6,471.89.
The bourse opened at 6,442.32 and fluctuated between 6,481.56 and 6,427.86 during trading. A total of 4.38 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$105.2 billion (US$3.16 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with food stuff issues moving up the most at 2 percent, followed by machinery and electronics shares at 0.8 percent, paper and pulp issues at 0.7 percent, banking and financial stocks at 0.6 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.3 percent, and textile issues at 0.1 percent.
Construction issues lost ground, dropping 0.2 percent, while cement shares remained unchanged.
Gainers outnumbered losers 603 to 414, with 186 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for December moved up 36 points to close at 6,469, with 10,999 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for January moved up 39 points to end at 6,482, with 19,993 contracts traded, while March futures gained 41 points to finish at 6,485, with 16 contracts traded. June futures moved up 50 points to close at 6,488, with four contracts traded, while September futures grew 65 points to close at 6,370, with 85 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 6,433 for December, 6,443 for January, 6,444 for March, 6,438 for June and 6,305 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.

December TE futures moved up 1.85 points to close at 283.35, with 2,518 contracts traded, while January TE futures gained 2.2 points to finish at 284, with 4,285 contract transactions. March TE futures moved up 2.2 points to end at 283, with six contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June and September.
December TF futures gained 2.8 points to finish at 898.8, with 1,929 contracts changing hands, while January TF futures grew 3.4 points to end at 900, with 2,235 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO STAY NEUTRAL IN PARTY CHAIRMAN BY-ELECTION: LU

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will be watching the upcoming by-election for a new Democratic Progressive Party chairman, but will remain neutral, Vice President Annette Lu, who is concurrently serving as acting DPP chairwoman, said Wednesday.
Lu said in a DPP Central Standing Committee meeting that President Chen specifically asked her to convey his stance on the upcoming election, which is set to take place Jan. 15.

The president will be impartial to all three candidates for the post -- former Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun, Legislator Trong Chai, and former Changhua County Magistrate Weng Chin-chu -- and will not endorse any of them, Lu said.
Lu also said that as the acting party chairwoman, she will remain impartial so that the election can be held in a "just way with style."

The DPP Central Standing Committee also decided in the meeting to hold two TV debates for the by-election, with the first one in Taipei Jan. 7 and the second one in Kaohsiung with the date yet to be decided.
Meanwhile, DPP lawmakers' reactions to the three candidates were mixed.

DPP Legislator Lee Wen-chung, who is from the New Tide faction of the party, said that he supports Weng "morally, " because Weng projects an image of integrity, which is what DPP members expect in a leader.
Lee said that he expected more people to register for the chairmanship race so that the "democratic, open and pluralistic spirit" of the DPP can be revived.
Legislator Gao Chih-peng of the Justice Alliance said that Weng's running will affect the election result, but the alliance will not endorse a specific candidate.

Yu is said to have the endorsement of two major factions -- the New Tide as well as the Justice Alliance. With his long-term relations with the president, he is also generally considered to have been hand-picked by Chen for the post, although Chen has often vowed neutrality in the election.

Political observers said that they are still watching to see if the race comes down to a battle between Yu and Weng, who apparently came forward at the last minute at the urging of respected former DPP Chairman Lin I-hsiung.
They are also watching if Chai, a long-time advocate of Taiwan independence, will benefit from playing off against Yu and Weng.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUDDHIST MEDICAL DELEGATION HEADS FOR SRI LANKA

TEXT.P: With the approach of the first anniversary of the killer tsunami in South Asia, a Buddhist medical delegation headed to Sri Lanka Wednesday to begin two weeks' service in the affected areas.
The 17-member group of the Dharma Drum Mountain Culture and Education Foundation carried medical supplies and equipment, as well as hundreds of small gifts to be distributed to children.

As medical resources in Sri Lanka are insufficient and health knowledge is lacking, the medical team is planning to go to shelter centers for the affected residents to provide basic medical services and spread public health information.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIST PROPOSES RELAXING CEILING LIMITS ON CHINA-BOUND INVESTMENTS

TEXT.P: A local economist proposed Wednesday that the government relax the ceiling limits on China-bound investments under certain conditions.
Currently, Taiwan businesses are forbidden from directing more than 40 percent of their total investments to China.

According to Taiwan Thinktank Chairman Chen Po-chih, the ceiling limits can be relaxed if the investing businesses are not in debt in Taiwan, if they do not involve in any capital-labor disputes and if their scales of production do not rely heavily on the operations in China.

Chen made the remarks in response to questions from the media. Whether the government will further relax its restrictions on cross-Taiwan Strait trade and economic activities is expected to be a major issue on the agenda of the second national economic development conference slated for next year.

Chen is one of the economists who contributed to the government's "no haste, be patient" policy on investments towards China in the 1990s. He was head of the Council for Economic Planning and Development when the last national economic development conference was held in 2001, during which the policy of "positive opening, efficient management" on cross-strait trade and economic activities was formed.

Chen pointed out that investing in China does not only involve economic aspects but it also concerns national security. Therefore, the government must make careful considerations before further relaxing its restrictions on China-bound investments, he said.

For example, he said, most local notebook computer manufacturers had no plan to set up operations in China when the business sector was discussing whether the government should allow notebook computer-makers to invest in China in the past.

However, the manufacturers later decided to move their production lines to China to reduce their production costs after some businesses had taken the first move to do so without the government's permission, he noted.
As a result, Taiwan's notebook computer sector now posts a gross profit margin of only 4 percent, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLIC HAS LITTLE EXPERIENCE IN COURTS BUT VIEWS THEM WITH SKEPTICISM

TEXT.P: Most people have never been in court, but few have any confidence in the institution, according to a survey released Wednesday.
It found that 80 percent of Taiwan's judges and 60 percent of lawyers and court staff have a good impression of the court, but only 30 percent of the public agree with them.

The survey, done by the Judicial Reform Foundation (JRF), found that 80 percent of lawyers and court staff think that the court is a safe place. However, the same ratio of lawyers said they could be insulted at court and 70 percent thought they could be threatened there. Half of the interviewed court staff members also felt they could be insulted or threatened.

Some 60 percent of polled lawyers and members of the public said Taiwan's courts are partial, favoring in particular the higher echelons of society or those higher in the economic pecking order. More than 70 percent of lawyers said criminal court judges favor prosecutors.

Kao Jung-chih, a JRF Executive Committee member, said that to improve the court's image, people working at the court need to upgrade their feel for the people and enhance their ability to "see and feel like others."
A good judicial system as well as professional and ethical mass media are also needed, Kao added.

Chu Hai-yuan, an Academia Sinica research fellow, said this was the first comprehensive survey about the judicial system, which found that almost 80 percent of the people have never had any experience of dealing with the court and yet they had a poor impression of it.

Chu said one way to improve the judicial authorities' image and achieve "quality trials" is to lay off incompetent judges by legislating a law governing the organization of the courts and professional practices of judges.
The JRF's Chief Executive Kao Yung-cheng said the Judicial Yuan should try to boost people's confidence in the court system because they are all its potential users.
The JRF interviewed 1,068 people, 918 staff members working at district courts, 426 lawyers and a number of judges from Nov. 10 to Nov. 25 this year.

Following the establishment of the Judicial Reform Committee by the government in 1994, a group of reform-minded lawyers, professors and social activists banded together in the belief that judicial reform could not become a reality without the support of the rank and file working within the judicial system.
These lawyers, professors, and social activists therefore formed the Judicial Reform Foundation, which operates independently of the ROC government.

DOC.HEADLINE: PASSAGE OF ARMS BILL KEY FOR U.S., NOT NATURE OF BUDGET: MND

TEXT.P: The United States is looking forward to a quick passage of a major arms procurement bill by Taiwan's legislature, but it does not care about whether it is financed by a regular or special budget, Vice Minister of National Defense (MND) Tsai Ming-shien said Wednesday.

Tsai, who returned recently from the United States where he took part in a Taiwan-U.S. military meeting, made the remarks while giving a special report at the National Defense Committee under the Legislative Yuan.

The MND is willing to find common ground with the opposition on how the budget for the arms purchase package should be earmarked in order not to affect the allocation for other operations despite the fact that President Chen Shui-bian has proclaimed that the country's military spending should be lifted to 3 percent of the nation's gross domestic product (GDP), Tsai said.

The MND submitted the major military procurement bill last year, valued at NT$610.8 billion, to the Legislative Yuan for its approval to procure eight diesel-powered submarines, six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries and 12 anti-submarine airplanes from the United States.

But the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan has repeatedly refused to discuss the bill, questioning the heavy financial burden that Taiwan has to sustain and the country's need to acquire the weapons, although the MND has slashed the spending to NT$480 billion.

The bill was rammed through the Rules Committee a day earlier, in which 12 lawmakers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the Taiwan Solidarity Union voted in favor against five lawmakers of the opposition "pan blue alliance" of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP).

Out of concern over the latest development, members of the Democratic Action Alliance visited the legislative caucus of the PFP Wednesday morning, asking the party never to soften its stance against the major military purchase bill.
Alliance members also urged KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou not to bow to pressure from the United States by agreeing to the MND's 3 percent GDP proposal.
Increased military expenditures would fan an arms race with China, whose military budget accounts for only 0.43 percent of its GDP but is 8.7 fold that of Taiwan's level, they warned.

An adjustment from the current ratio of 2.42 percent in GDP to 3 percent equals a considerable growth of NT$70 billion in cash, which in turn is not a guarantee for peace, they said, noting that a 2.42 percent share already makes Taiwan one of Asia's frontrunners in military spending.

Echoing their comments, PFP legislative caucus whip Daniel Y.C. Huang said that the MND's military procurement bill must be assessed together with the government's finances and the state of cross-Taiwan Strait relations.

The PFP maintains that the military procurement package must not crowd out the government's budgets in other fields and that the government should first do something to bolster cross-strait ties, such as opening up to Chinese tourists and setting up direct transport links.
PFP lawmaker Chao Liang-yen said that she will call a public hearing to gauge public opinion about the 3 percent GDP proposal.

DOC.HEADLINE: ISSUANCE OF NEW IDENTIFICATION CARDS BEGINS

TEXT.P: Household registration offices around the island started to issue the new version of ID cards Wednesday, with Premier Frank Hsieh saying that the new ID cards symbolize the next era for Taiwan.

More than 18 million new ID cards would be issued by the end of next year. The current version was issued in 1986. The new version was scheduled to be issued July 1 this year but was delayed till Dec. 21 due to issues revolving around whether to include the owner's fingerprint. A Council of Grand Justice ruling declared such a requirement unconstitutional.

During a news conference at the Da-an District household registration office, Premier Hsieh said, "The old ID cards have a very deep historical meaning. During almost 20 years, our people have witnessed with this card the country's democratization. That includes using it for presidential elections, electing the last term of National Assembly members, mayoral elections, legislative elections, and have benefited from the national health insurance and many other things."
Hsieh also urged applicants to cooperate as much as possible with the staff of the household registration offices because there are many cards to issue.

"In the past 20 years, the way people look has changed and the ID pictures must be replaced. I believe that the new ID cards mean the start of new era because Taiwan is going to change in the coming 20 years, and we are going to fight for the right to organize the 2020 Olympic Games," Hsieh said.
According to media reports, the procedure to get new ID cards is not complicated and people do not have to wait too long.

Ado Kaliting Pacidal, an indigenous woman who wanted to use her aboriginal name on her new ID card got her wish at Taipei's Sungshan District household registration office in less than two hours, a procedure that used to take twice the time in the past.

On the other hand, Wang Chien-ming, a local man who pitches in the Major Leagues in the United States, whose domicile is registered in the southern city of Tainan, obtained his new ID card with considerable delay due to a computer problem that made him wait for more than an hour.
Wang said that he wants to apply for his U.S. visa with his new ID card before he leaves before Chinese Lunar New Year, which falls on Jan. 29, 2006.
Chou Hsi-wei, the newly elected Taipei County magistrate, reportedly was the first in his county to obtain a new ID card Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN ORDERED TO PAY TOKEN COMPENSATION OVER COUP REMARK

TEXT.P: The Taipei District Court ordered President Chen Shui-bian Wednesday to apologize and pay symbolic compensation to his two rivals in the last presidential election for implying they had attempted to stage a "soft coup d'etat" after last year's divisive election.

According to the court ruling, Chen must pay former Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong NT$1 -- about 3 U.S. cents -- each and publish half-page apologies in three major local newspapers -- the Liberty Times, the China Times and the United Daily News -- for one day.

Lien and Soong ran on a joint ticket in the 2004 presidential election, but lost the race to the incumbents -- President Chen and Vice President Annette Lu -- by a very small margin after an election-eve shooting in which both Chen and Lu were wounded slightly.
Chen accused Lien and Soong at a public occasion in November 2004 of attempting a "soft coup d'etat" after losing the March 20, 2004 presidential election.

Under the constitutional system, the court ruling said, the presidency is a government agency. Therefore, the verdict said, Chen is not entitled to freedom of speech and is obligated to prove the truthfulness of his words.

As Chen was unable to provide concrete evidence to prove there was a coup d'etat in the wake of the 2004 presidential election and that his two opposition rivals were involved in such an event, the verdict said Chen had to apologize and pay token compensation.

Chen's lawyer argued that the president had not been specific in his public remarks, but the court said Chen's statement was apparently insinuating that Lien and Soong were involving in the planning for a "soft coup d'etat."

On Nov. 14, 2004, President Chen said at a legislative campaign rally that Lien and Soong had lobbied senior military generals to either "resign" or "take a leave of absence" in preparation for a "soft coup d'etat" after losing their presidential bid.

Thanks to his efforts to push for de-politicization of the military since he assumed office in 2000, Chen claimed that the Lien-Soong appeal received a lukewarm response and the "soft coup d'etat" didn't happen. Chen's remarks prompted Lien and Soong to file a slander suit against the president late last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: In Final Hours, M.T.A. Took a Big Risk on Pensions
On the final day of intense negotiations, the New York Metropolitan Transportation Authority greatly altered what it had called its final offer, to address many of the objections of the transit workers' union. But then, just hours before the strike deadline, the authority's chairman, Peter S. Kalikow, put forward a surprise demand that stunned the union. Seeking to rein in the authority's soaring pension costs, he asked that all new transit workers contribute 6 percent of their wages toward their pensions, up from the 2 percent that current workers pay. The union balked, and then shut down the nation's largest transit system for the first time in a quarter- century. The pension proposal would have saved the transit authority less than US$20 million over the next three years. It seemed a small figure, considering that the city says that every day of the strike will cost its businesses hundreds of millions of dollars in lost revenues. But the authority contends that it must act now to prevent a "tidal wave" of pension outlays if costs are not brought under control.
Wall Street Journal: Course Corrections, To Cut Prison Bill, States Tweak Laws, Try Early Releases
Many U.S. states are taking steps to reduce its prison population. That has little to do withh any change in tough-on-crime thinking and a lot to do with dollars and cents. Housing criminals is expensive: The average cost was US$22,650 a year per person in 2001, the last year for which figures are available. The two-decade trend of severe penalties has led to a surge in corrections spending. In fiscal year 2006, states are expected to spend US$34.6 billion, up 24 percent from five years earlier, according to the National Conference of State Legislatures. Virginia revised its laws in 2001 to allow prisoners who are at least 65 years old and have served at least five years in prison to apply for parole on the basis of their age. Prisoners who are 60 or older and have served 10 years also may apply to the board. Inmates serving time for capital murder aren't eligible. A state law of Connecticut promotes the release of less-dangerous offenders by letting those accused of minor crimes stay home while awaiting trial.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Spy Court Judge Quits In Protest; Jurist Concerned Bush Order Tainted Work of Secret Panel.
A federal judge has resigned from the court that oversees government surveillance in intelligence cases in protest of President Bush's secret authorization of a domestic spying program, according to two sources.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT DID NOT IMPLY LIEN, SOONG IN COUP REMARKS: AIDE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian was not referring to former Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong when he said some people were attempting to stage a "soft coup d'etat" in the days after he was re-elected by a small margin, a close aide to the president said Wednesday.

Ma Yung-cheng, acting secretary-general to the president, said Chen "has no qualms" about what he said at the time. Ma replaced Yu Shyi-kun after Yu quit the Presidential Office post to run for the ruling party's chairmanship.

Ma made his comments just before a court was to announce its ruling on the slander lawsuit filed by Lien and Soong, running mates who lost the 2004 presidential election by 0.0228 percent of the vote. The court found Chen guilty and ordered him to pay a token NT$1 in compensation to each of the complainants and to publish an apology in three major newspapers in Taiwan.

Ma said when the president made the controversial remarks, protests in front of the Presidential Office had been going on for six or seven days and some of the protesters were uniformed soldiers while some Web sites called on the military and the police to "rise up."

Most precarious was that at that juncture, Beijing issued a statement claiming it would not sit idly by as chaos continued in Taiwan, making people feel that Taiwan's national security was under threat, Ma said.

President Chen was using examples in other countries when he said there were attempts at a "soft coup d'etat" as he tried to remind the people that some people were colluding to act, probably being used by China, to affect national security and to create political turmoil, Ma added.

The court, however, disagreed with Ma's explanation and said in its ruling that the president did imply Lien and Soong when he mentioned that the protests were part of an attempt to gain "personal power."
Judging from the social situation at the time, the court said it was reasonable to infer that the president was implicitly referring to Lien and Soong.
Ma insisted that Chen did not have the slightest compunction about having made the remarks as he "had a lot of understanding" and was not referring to "Mr. Lien and Mr. Soong."

To the media question about the president's "psychological preparedness" for the court ruling, Ma replied that a court ruling could be based on different arguments such as freedom of expression and facts, and he would not make a prediction or a comment.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMOSAT-3 TO BE LAUNCHED IN MARCH 2006

TEXT.P: The newly built FORMOSAT-3 COSMIC satellite will be launched for meteorological observations in March next year from Vandenberg Air Force Base in California.

The satellite arrived at the airport in Los Angeles late in the evening of Dec. 20 local time on a China Airlines flight. "COSMIC" stands for Constellation Observing System for Meteorology, Ionosphere and Climate.
In the following three months, FORMOSAT-3 will be tested at Vandenberg and then placed on the rocket that will take it into space.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAXATION BILL FOR TEACHERS, MILITARY FAILS AT LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: A bill that would revoke the tax-exempt status for elementary and junior high school teachers and the military personnel failed at the Legislative Yuan Wednesday, with lawmakers opting to discuss the bill at a later date.
Opposition "pan blue alliance" lawmakers vetoed the bill 23 to 21 and decided to elaborate on the bill another day following a filibuster at a joint committee meeting.

"Pan blue" lawmakers of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) were sharply alighted against "pan green" camp lawmakers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) over the question of whether teachers and military personnel should be compensated by the government for their taxes paid to the government.

KMT and PFP lawmakers contended that the bill must be made into law with a set of complementary measures to fully compensate income tax paid by teachers and military personnel to the government, while DPP and TSU lawmakers insisted on revoking their tax-free privilege first.
The issue, although a historic remnant, has become one of the major debate points in recent elections as the rich-poor gap is increasingly widening in Taiwan society.

Some 60 members of a group advocating fair taxation voiced their regret after the bill failed at the Legislative Yuan, saying that they will continue seeking public endorsement to hold a referendum on the issue.

The Fair Taxation Alliance said that they will step up their lobbying for public support for the endorsement, a spokesman said, noting that they have so far collected just over 10,000 signatures and that there is still a long way to go to make the 82,360-signature threshold.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO APPEAL 'SOFT COUP D'ETAT' RULING

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday evening that he regrets and will appeal a district court ruling that he should apologize to former Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong for insinuating they were trying to stage a "soft coup d'etat" in the days after losing the 2004 presidential election.
The court ordered the president also to pay NT$1 in compensation to each of the two "pan-blue alliance" candidates who filed a slander suit against him.

In a three-point statement, Chen said that the ruling was "extremely regrettable, " that he will appeal in accordance with the law, and that after filing his appeal, he will present to the court some information that had been kept confidential at the time.
Such information was classified in consideration of the political situation at that time, said the president.
Lien has urged Chen not to appeal. Lien and Soong lost two suits against Chen and the Central Election Commission challenging the validity of his re-election.

DOC.HEADLINE: DECISION ON PANDAS DELAYED UNTIL MORE EXPERTS WEIGH IN: COA

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) said Wednesday that the decision to import pandas will be delayed until experts release their findings on the needs of the animals and whether Taiwan has the appropriate environment to breed them.
The COA made the statement following an audition with the Taipei Zoo and the Leofoo Village theme park located in Hsinchu Wednesday. Both of them have applied to the COA to receive the pandas.
The Chinese government announced that they are willing to donate a pair of pandas to Taiwan following the visit of former Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan to China earlier this year.

During the audition, the Taipei Zoo showed the COA statistics on 39 pandas' births and deaths between Jan. 1, 1993 and Dec. 31, 2004. Among them, seven were exported from China before 1993 and 18 were exported after that, while 14 were born out of China. A total of 11 died during that time. The youngest died at birth and the oldest at 27 years old.

Leofoo Village proposed that the importation of pandas could be dealt with by a Chinese cultural association while the National Pingtung University of Science and Technology could provide them care and help with breeding techniques, according to a mutual contract they signed.
Leofoo also said it can also provide China NT$35 million annually as a "panda protection fund" and NT$18 million as a local panda breeding fund.
The COA said that they need to collect more information before making a decision.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANUFACTURING VITAL TO TAIWAN'S SURVIVAL: INDUSTRY LEADERS

TEXT.P: The government must create favorable conditions to help Taiwan businesses keep their operations at home, in particular the manufacturing sector, as it is key to the country's sustainable growth, business and industry leaders said Wednesday.

Tsai Hung-ming, vice secretary-general of the Chinese National Federation of Industries, called the government's attention to the fact that the manufacturing sector is indispensable to Taiwan's survival because of the many jobs it provides, despite the fact that the domestic economy has increasingly become service oriented.
To be competitive internationally, Taiwan's manufacturing businesses must focus on industrial upgrading and pursue product uniqueness in tune with an unfettered investment climate, Tsai said.

Echoing Tsai's comments, Lo Huei-chia, an executive at the Taiwan Electrical and Electronic Manufacturers' Association, said that building a good environment, including improving Taiwan-China ties, is extremely important to help local companies keep their operations at home at a time when many of them have relocated to China.

Their comments came after Taiwan Thinktank Chairman Chen Po-chih said earlier the same day that Taiwan must develop its own unique and knowledge-based manufacturing industries that are profitable and can withstand trade barriers.

Taiwan's foreign trade would contract by NT$2.5 trillion (US$75 billion) per year should the domestic export-driven manufacturing businesses continue moving out of Taiwan to a point that it loses its importance as the backbone in creating job opportunities for domestic workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PAN-BLUES' HAIL COURT RULING OVER CHEN'S COUP REMARK

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) honorary Chairman Lien Chan hailed a court ruling Wednesday that requires President Chen Shui-bian to apologize to him for implying he had attempted a "soft coup d'etat" after losing last year's presidential election.

"Justice is served, " Lien said after the Taipei District Court ruled earlier the same day that Chen must apologize to Lien and Lien's 2004 presidential election running mate -- People First Party Chairman James Soong -- for implying they had attempted to stage a "soft coup d'etat" in the wake of the divisive election.

The court ordered Chen to pay Lien and Soong each NT$1 -- about 3 U.S. cents -- in symbolic compensation and publish half-page apologies in three major local newspapers -- the Liberty Times, the China Times and the United Daily News -- for one day.

"The ruling is a very nice gift. It is expected to help guide our political culture to develop in a positive direction. I hope it will inspire local politicians to refrain from running off at the mouth and making false accusations," Lien said.
Lien also urged Chen to show full remorse for his unfounded accusation against him and Soong by giving up his right to appeal the case.

Lien and Soong ran on a joint ticket in the 2004 presidential election, but lost the race to the incumbents -- President Chen and Vice President Annette Lu -- by a very small margin after an election-eve shooting in which both Chen and Lu were wounded slightly.

On Nov. 14, 2004, President Chen said at a legislative campaign rally that Lien and Soong had lobbied senior military generals to either "resign" or "take a leave of absence" in preparation for a "soft coup d'etat" after losing the March 20, 2004 presidential election.

Thanks to his efforts to push for de-politicization of the military since he assumed office in 2000, Chen claimed that the Lien-Soong appeal received a lukewarm response and the "soft coup d'etat" didn't happen. Chen's remarks prompted Lien and Soong to file a slander suit against the president late last year.

Under the constitutional system, the court ruling said, the presidency is a government agency. Therefore, the verdict said, Chen is not entitled to freedom of speech and is obligated to prove the truthfulness of his words.

As Chen was unable to provide concrete evidence to prove there was a coup d'etat in the wake of the 2004 presidential election and that his two opposition rivals were involved in such an event, the verdict said Chen had to apologize and pay token compensation.
Lien and Soong commissioned their lawyer, Lee Fu-tien, to issue a joint statement hailing the court's judgment as "fair and impartial."

"Chairmen of the two main opposition parties were accused by the head of state of staging a coup. This is a very serious accusation against any politician, " the joint statement said. "We hope the verdict will send a message to politicians that they can't make groundless accusations."

PFP legislative caucus whip Hwang Yih-jiau said his party welcomes the court ruling. Hwang urged Chen to exercise prudence in making comments and to be a role model so that Taiwan can develop a decent political culture.
KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou, who doubles as Taipei mayor, said he believes that Chen's approval rating will rebound if Chen drops his plan to appeal the case.

"This is the first time that a sitting ROC head of state loses a slander suit. The case involves a very important point that opposition parties' activities should not be regarded as coup d'etat or rebellions," Ma added.
Lien and Soong disputed the 2004 presidential election result, suggesting the president had organized the shooting to win sympathy votes, and alleging irregularities during the voting.

In the wake of the election, "pan-blue" supporters took to the streets in weeklong protests in which sometimes turned violent. Courts at all levels have rejected the two opposition suits challenging the validity of Chen's re-election, and investigators said the most likely suspect in the March 19, 2004 shooting was an unemployed man in his 50s who was unhappy over his economic situation. The man died shortly after the shooting, apparently a suicide.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHIAYI CITY TO HOLD LEGISLATIVE BY-ELECTION MARCH 11: CEC

TEXT.P: The Central Election Commission (CEC) has tentatively decided to hold a by-election in Chiayi City to elect a lawmaker to fill the post left vacant by Huang Min-hui who has been elected mayor of the southern city.
CEC spokesman Teng Tien-you said the proposed schedule will be formalized after being approved by a CEC commissioners meeting later this month.
The CEC will issue a by-election bulletin Jan. 16 and candidacy registration is scheduled for Feb. 10-14, Teng said.

Huang assumed Chiayi mayorship Tuesday, making her the city's first opposition Kuomintang mayor in more than 50 years. According to the current law, a by-election should be held to elect a new legislator to serve out the tenure left by Huang.

DOC.HEADLINE: FARMERS STIPEND TO BE RAISED TO NT$5,000

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Wednesday the central government will revise its 2006 budget plan to finance the increased stipends for elderly farmers.

The revision to the budget bill becomes necessary after the Legislative Yuan passed a resolution earlier this week to raise the monthly stipends for elderly farmers from NT$4,000 each to NT$5,000 from the start of the new year, Hsieh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DONATES CLOTHING TO PHILIPPINES

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government donated US$200,000 worth of new clothing to the Philippines Wednesday to express Taiwan people's love and friendship for disadvantaged Filipinos.

ROC Representative to the Philippines Wu Hsin-hsing presented the donation to the acting secretary of the Philippine Social Welfare and Development Department (SWD) in a ceremony held at the SWD office.
The brand new clothing, including baby wear, children's wear and adult costumes, was shipped to the Philippines in three containers.
All the garments will be distributed to impoverished Philippine families and victims of recent flooding in six central Philippine provinces, Wu said.
Noting that Taiwan and the Philippines are close neighbors, Wu said the ROC government is more than willing to offer humanitarian aid to needy Filipinos.
In December 2004 and February this year, Taiwan donated US$60,000 in relief funds and US$50,000 worth of pharmaceuticals, respectively, to help with post-typhoon relief work in the Philippines.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Dec. 22, or the 22nd day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1895: Using his newly discovered X-ray technology, German physicist Wilhelm Konrad Roentgen photographs his wife's hand to reveal the bones beneath the skin.
1905: The Ching court signs a treaty with Japan in Peking regarding Manchurian affairs, following Japan's victory over Russia in the Russo-Japanese War.
1907: The Ching government sets up the Directorate General of Railways and appoints Liang Shih-yu as the director-general.
1909: Korean Prime Minister Yi Wanyong, who agreed to a merger of Korea with Japan, is badly injured by assassins. Japan took complete control of Korea less than a year later.
1915: China's Ministry of Education sets up a training center to teach the phonetic annotation of the Chinese alphabet.
1936: Noted Chinese writer Yu Ta-fu visits Taiwan
1936: Madame Chiang Kai-shek, accompanied by W. H. Donald and T.V. Soong (Sung Tzu-wen), fly to Xian.
1938: Japanese Prime Minister Prince Konoye lays down a three-point guiding principle for the settlement of the Sino-Japanese conflict and the establishment of a "New Order in East Asia."
1942: U.S. heavy bomber planes bomb Japanese-occupied Rangoon, Burma.
1945: General George Marshall arrives in Chungking as U.S. President Truman's special envoy.
1945: The foreign ministers of the United States, Britain, and the Soviet Union hold a meeting in Moscow.
1961: James Davis becomes the first American soldier to die in Vietnam since America's involvement began in the Southeast Asian country.
1965: President Chiang Kai-shek issues a decree convoking an extraordinary session of the National Assembly in Taipei on Feb. 1, 1966.
1968: North Korea releases 82 crewmen of the U.S. intelligence ship Pueblo at the truce village of Panmunjom, 11 months after their capture off the North Korean coast.
1971: Austrian envoy Kurt Waldheim becomes the secretary-general of the United Nations.
1972: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Australia and New Zealand.
1976: Adm. Soong Chang-chih, chief of the general staff, presents citations to outstanding cadres and political warfare personnel.
1989: Civil war in Romania ends the 24-year-long reign of terror by Nicolae Ceausescu, who flees Bucharest with his wife Elena. Both were later executed.
1990: Lech Walesa becomes Poland's first popularly elected president.
1991: Dissident mainland Chinese astrophysicist Fang Li-chih visits Taipei.
1996: Chiang Hsiao-yung, the third son of late President Chiang Ching-kuo, dies of cancer in Taipei at the age of 49.
1997: Hong Kong authorities decide to destroy all chickens imported from mainland China after three people die of what is thought to be a strain of flu carried by poultry.
1999: Nasir Ahmed Sooro, listed as the world's tallest (236.2 cm) person by the Guinness Book of World Records, meets with the local press as he starts his four-month visit to Taiwan.
2000: The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) says the Republic of China will fully open its livestock products market in 2005.
2001: The Alishan forest railway in Chiayi County, southern Taiwan, which was seriously damaged when Typhoon Nari swept the island in mid-September, resumes service.
Confucius lesson for the day: "Treat people with seriousness and they will respect you. Let them see that you honor your parents and your prince, and are considerate of the welfare of those under you, and the people will be loyal to you. Advance those who excel in anything and educate the ignorant, and the people will exert themselves."

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER CALLS FOR END TO SPECULATION ON NEXT CABINET

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng called on the media Thursday to stop asking him questions about the possibility of him heading the next Cabinet.
He also denied speculation that if he cooperates with the "pan-green" government of President Chen Shui-bian, he will lead 20 "pan-blue" legislators to defect.

Wang is a Kuomintang (KMT) member. The KMT and the People First Party (PFP) form the "pan-blue alliance, " while President Chen's Democratic Progressive Party and the Taiwan Solidarity Union, whose spiritual leader is former President Lee Teng-hui, are grouped in the "pan-green camp."
Wang was replying to media questions at Taipao, Chiayi County where he attended a ceremony on the establishment of sisterhood ties between a local college and two South Korean universities.

Wang said if the rumors about his possible defection to the "pan-green camp" have originated from inside the KMT, it is "these people who are harboring improper ideas and who most need to undergo self-examination."

Wang showed his appreciation for former KMT Chairman Lien Chan for reportedly advising incumbent Chairman Ma Ying-jeou not to drive Wang into a corner by asking whether he will leave the KMT and join the Chen administration.
Lien reportedly told Ma that Wang had already made it clear that he has no intention of becoming premier when Chen reshuffles the Cabinet in the coming weeks.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN CANDIDATE PROMISES TO PUSH FOR RENAMING COUNTRY

TEXT.P: Legislator Trong Chai, one of the three candidates in the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) chairmanship by-election set for Jan. 15, said Thursday he will push for renaming the country and redrawing the country's territorial boundaries if he is elected.

In a brief speech after drawing lots to determine the order of candidates' names on the by-election ballot, the pro-independence lawmaker said the party suffered defeat in the Dec. 3 local government elections because of its failure to emphasize Taiwan's identity and maintain a clean administration.

In order to address the two problems, Chai said he would push for renaming the country as "Taiwan" and redrawing the country's boundaries to include only Taiwan proper and the outlying islands of Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu.
Also, Chai said he would require DPP public officials and lawmakers to entrust their assets to financial institutions and subject the assets to investigation if they increased unreasonably.

In a jab at his leading rival in the race, Yu Shyi-kun, Chai said Yu disappointed him and many of his like-minded DPP members by ruling out the possibility of renaming the country and redefining its territorial boundaries in the country's ongoing second-phase constitutional reform.

Chai was referring to Yu's remarks in a meeting with DPP lawmakers in Taipei three months ago when Yu, who was Presidential Office secretary-general at the time, gave a briefing on President Chen Shui-bian's plan for constitutional reform.

On a sperate occasion in the Legislative Yuan Thursday, Chai also promised to push for a national referendum on the arms procurement budget and for enactment of a bill to force the Kuomintang to return its "ill-gotten assets, " as well as a referendum on the abolishment of elections for chiefs of urban and rural townships.

Flanked by a group of pro-independence activists, Chai said at a news conference that there is no way the United States will help Taiwan to ward off an attack from China if Taiwan has no willingness to defend itself by acquiring the necessary defensive arms.
The budget for the arms procurement has been blocked by the opposition in the legislature for more than one year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ECONOMY IN GOOD SHAPE: VICE PREMIER

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Wu Rong-i said Thursday that Taiwan's economy is in good shape and that the public needs to have confidence in the nation.
Wu made the remarks while delivering a speech in Taichung, central Taiwan at the annual meeting of the Chinese Water Resources Management Society in his capacity as president of the society.
Stressing that Taiwan's economy has rebounded, Wu expressed the hope that people will stop being pessimistic about the nation's economic performance.

Noting that Taiwan's economy began to slow down in May 2000 when the global economy was experiencing a downturn, Wu said that as the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) came to power at that time, some have blamed Taiwan's economic problems on what they call the DPP's lack of talent or incompetence in running the nation.
Wu pointed out that after negative growth in 2001, Taiwan's economy rebounded to show positive growth the following year and has since maintained growth of around 4 percent or above.
"The figures clearly show that Taiwan's economy has rebounded, although some still cling to the old memory of 2001 and continue to be pessimistic about the nation's economy," he said.
"In terms of economic growth, the unemployment rate and the annual increase in the consumer price index, Taiwan's economy is in good shape," Wu said.

Looking ahead, Taiwan's economic performance next year should be even better, Wu said, adding that economic growth should reach 4.5 percent, the jobless rate will likely be reduced to 4 percent, and the annual increase in the consumer price index is expected to be maintained at 2 percent.

The State Duma on Wednesday rushed through a raft of amendments to a bill that would increase state control over nongovernmental organizations and passed it in a crucial second reading, ignoring a wave of protest from Russian and foreign NGOs.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 54.69 points to close at 6,417.2.
The bourse opened at 6,501.37 and fluctuated between 6,504.09 and 6,417.2 during trading. A total of 3.79 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$95.23 billion (US$2.86 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with textile stocks moving down the most at 2.3 percent, followed by foodstuff issues at 1.6 percent, paper and pulp issues at 1.2 percent, banking and financial shares at 1.1 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 1 percent, cement stocks and machinery and electronics shares both at 0.7 percent, and construction issues at 0.5 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 724 to 336, with 153 stocks remaining unchanged.
