DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: Crime in L.A. Drops for 3rd Year in a Row.
The city of Los Angeles is set to close out the year with a drop in crime of roughly 10%-- meeting a goal set by Police Chief William J. Bratton ans solidifying a trend that has brought charge to parts of the city once scarred by violence.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT AIMING AT FISCAL BALANCE BY 2011: FINANCE MINISTRY

TEXT.P: With the government's fiscal status having improved significantly as the economy has recovered, the government will continue financial reforms with the goal of achieving fiscal balance by 2011, Finance Ministry officials said Thursday.

The officials made the remarks in response to a report released Wednesday by the Standard & Poor's Ratings Services, in which Taiwan's sovereign credit ratings outlook remained "negative, " on the grounds that Taiwan's fiscal position is expected to remain "vulnerable to politics and a lower growth trend" and that "fiscal reform measures are still insufficient to address longer-term budgetary pressures."

The officials pointed out that the government has since April 22, 2003 implemented financial reforms consisting of 60 short-term, medium-term and long-term measures, 29 of which have displayed substantial accomplishments.

Thanks to the recovering economy, the government received NT$53.2 billion in excess of the target revenue amount in 2004, the first time since 1999 that the revenues have reached the target, the officials said.

In 2005, the revenues received by the government had accounted for 107.6 percent of the target amount as of the end of November, with approximately NT$110 billion in excess of the target amount expected for the whole year, they said.

The increase in revenues, together with the government's belt-tightening measures, is expected to narrow the 2005 fiscal deficit to NT$125 billion, compared with the NT$274.7 billion previously projected by the government, they said.

As to the budget plan for 2006, which is currently being reviewed by the Legislative Yuan, the growth of the projected expenses is minus 0.5 percent, while the growth of the projected revenues is 5.3 percent, they said.
The decrease in projected expenses and increase in projected revenues have thus controlled the projected deficit below NT$200 billion, they said.

They predicted that government debts payable will amount to NT$3.9 trillion at the end of 2006, accounting for 35.6 percent of the average gross national product (GNP) for the previous three years. This will mean an increase of 1.3 percentage points from the 34.3 percent for 2005, which will be the lowest increase rate in four years, they added.

They continued that the taxation reforms currently being carried out by the government, which include the introduction of minimum income tax rates targeting high-income earners, will help enhance tax fairness and ensure the stability of government revenue.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FRUITS TO HIT BRUNEI MARKETS

TEXT.P: Taiwan fruit exporters have begun to make inroads into Brunei's market, with the first batch of Tungshih, Taichung County mandarin oranges ordered by fruit importers in the Southeast Asian country being shipped Thursday.
Brunei fruit importers have ordered more than 200 metric tons of mandarin oranges from the central Taiwan county.

Liu Hsing-chuan, chairman of Tungshih Farmers' Association in Taichung County, noted that the mandarin oranges cultivated in Tungshih township are well known within and without the country due to their juiciness and sweet flavor.
However, Liu added, Tungshih fruits farmers have been hit hard by the entry into Taiwan of large amounts of foreign fruit in the last few years due to marketing opening.

Taichung County Government and Tungshih Farmers' Association officials began seeking export orders to introduce the township's fruits abroad in 2003, targeting in first phase Asian markets, including Brunei, Singapore, Malaysia and Indonesia.
Liu said the mandarin oranges to be exported abroad have all met Taiwan's sanitary and quarantine requirements.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUAPAN, KRTC RECEIVE 'HITTER AWARD' FOR TRAMPLING HUMAN RIGHTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Association for Human Rights (TAHR) awarded the ignominious "hitter award" to Huapan Administration Consultant Co. and Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) Thursday to underscore their records in trampling Thai workers' human rights.
TAHR President Wu Hao-jen announced the association's "ten-plus-one top human rights stories of 2005" and winners of the "Orz awards for trampling human rights."

Wu said the stories and "awards" are aimed at ensuring the protection of human rights, but he added that this cannot be achieved if the government and society do not stop violating people's human rights.

Huapan and KRTC were not the only ones to receive this year's "hitter award" in the "Orz" category. Formosa Plastics and a few notorious labor brokers were also given the "award" for their role in violating foreign workers' human rights.
Gil Lebria, a Filipino worker who had worked at Formosa Plastics' Mailiao, Yunlin County plant, told his story at the TAHR press conference Thursday.
He said that after he was beaten by the factory's security guards, the management did not send him to hospital. Instead, he and 15 other maltreated co-workers were sent back to their home countries.
It was only with funds donated by civic groups that he was able to file a lawsuit against the security guards who had hit him, Lebria said.

In connection with foreign workers' human rights violations, TAHR presented a "black hand award" to the Council for Labor Affairs (CLA) for its poor foreign workers policy and lousy supervision of their management.

The Department of Health received an "unwashed hand award" for its discriminatory AIDS patients policy that bans them from donating blood and for its failure to educate the public about respecting the medical rights of the disadvantaged.

Police and prosecution authorities as well as the Government Information Office (GIO) received the "cradle-overthrowing hand award" for repressing freedom of speech by cracking down on the publishing of "unusual DVDs" during the Dec. 3 elections and other violations of civil liberties.

Wu said that in Taiwan, there are still quite a few "heavy-handed and totalitarian" policies and institutions. For example, he said, the controversy over relocating a leprosarium in Xinzhuang, Taipei County is a case of a minority group whose human rights were violated when the interests of the minority could not withstand the onslaught of the majority interests.
He said the controversy over fingerprinting all citizens in order to set up a police data bank is an example of the majority interests being encroached upon by an institution.

The TAHR's 10-plus-one top human rights stories were the controversy over fingerprinting, foreign workers policy, domestic violence, infringements on the freedom of speech and thought, the law on assembly, sexual discrimination, banning students from choosing their hair styles and corporal punishment on campus, discrimination against patients of certain diseases, ecological murderers, abolishing capital punishment, and relocation of the Xinzhuang leprosarium.

TAHR is a non-governmental organization committed to securing human rights and preventing human rights violations. TAHR believes that human rights, the rule of law, and democracy are indivisible and interdependent.

TAHR's campaigns have focused on investigating individual human rights cases and assisting victims, monitoring the government's policy-making and development, proposing legal and constitutional amendments so as to meet international human rights standards, and promoting human rights consciousness and education.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for January moved down 52 points to close at 6,430, with 21,977 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for February moved down 55 points to end at 6,431, with 68 contracts traded, while March futures lost 49 points to finish at 6,436, with 31 contracts traded. June futures moved down 49 points to close at 6,425, with 43 contracts traded, while September futures moved down 51 points to close at 6,319, with 55 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 6,482 for January, 6,486 for February, 6,485 for March, 6,474 for June and 6,370 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly lower.

January TE futures moved down 1.8 points to close at 282.2, with 4,733 contracts traded, while February TE futures lost 1.5 points to finish at 282.45, with 15 contract transactions. March TE futures moved up 1.25 points to end at 284.25, with two contracts traded, while June TE futures moved up 2.85 points to end at 284.85, with one contract transaction.
No transactions were recorded for September.
January TF futures lost eight points to finish at 892, with 1,827 contracts changing hands, while February TF futures moved down 7.4 points to end at 893, with eight contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, gaining NT$0.005 to close at NT$33.261.
A total of US$460 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.267 and fluctuated between NT$33.251 and NT$33.300.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEARLY 80% OF HONG KONG RESIDENTS AGAINST TAIWAN INDEPENDENCE: POLL
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Dec. 22 (CNA) (By Lo Kin-fai and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A total of 78 percent of Hong Kong residents are against independence for Taiwan, and 53 percent oppose Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations, according to the result of a survey released Thursday in the special administrative region.
The figures compared with 9 percent who are in favor of independence for Taiwan and 24 percent who are supportive of Taiwan's admission to the United Nations.
The survey was conducted by the HKU Pop Site, an opinion polling Web site run by the University of Hong Kong, on 1,000 Hong Kong residents in early December.
The survey showed that 49 percent of the respondents are confident in the unification of Taiwan and China, while 36 percent have no confidence.
Meanwhile, 46 percent of the respondents think the "one country, two systems" formula could be applied to Taiwan, compared with 34 percent who think it could not.

According to Robert Ting-Yiu Chung, director of the Public Opinion Programme of the site, Hong Kong residents' confidence in cross-Taiwan Strait unification has dropped 19 percentage points over the past three months, down to the level of six months ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN ARRIVALS TO TAIWAN UP: DGBAS

TEXT.P: Foreign arrivals to Taiwan in the first 11 months of this year totaled more than 3.067 million, up 14.7 percent compared to the year-earlier level, according to tallies released Thursday by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

Japanese visitors contributed the largest share of 33.5 percent of the total arrivals, or 1.028 million visits, during the 11-month period, a 28.5 percent growth year on year, DGBAS statistics showed. Visitors from Hong Kong, Macau and those from the United States made up of a combined 60 percent of the total.
Some 1.23 million visitors to Taiwan in the first 11 months came for sightseeing, marking a 34.7 percent increase, while some 877,000 came for business.
In outbound travel, Taiwan people made 7.653 million visits overseas for the same 11-month period, up by 6.1 percent on an annual basis, DGBAS tallies showed.

Taiwan travelers made some 2.603 million visits to Hong Kong, making the former British colony the top destination abroad for Taiwan visitors. Visits by Taiwan people to South Korea increased the most by 23.5 percent for the 11-month period, while those bound for Thailand decreased the most by 36.5 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: ABORIGINAL KIDS IN REMOTE VILLAGES TO GET WIRED

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) and the semi-official Institute for Information Industry (III) Thursday urged the public to donate their used computers to help aboriginal students living in the countryside.

Some 1,600 second-hand computers with Internet access have been sent to children from low-income aboriginal families in remote and mountainous areas in an activity jointly sponsored by the two organizations to bridge the digital divide, EPA officials said.

The computers were re-assembled by III engineers with parts selected out of more than 10,000 second-hand computers donated by 514 private and governmental agencies, the officials said, adding that the III also sent personnel to the communities to help set up the computers and advice the people there how to maintain them.

The officials expressed the hope that they can collect another 3,000 computers to help poor aboriginal kids, and called for public participation to spread their love and caring to help aboriginal kids open a window into the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: MARKET ANALYSTS ADVISE TAIWAN COMPUTER MAKERS TO INVEST IN VIETNAM

TEXT.P: Taiwan computer makers are suggested to shift their attention to Vietnam for the country's potential demand for their products and its cheap labor, according to a recent report by the Market Intelligence Center under the Institute for Information Industry (III).

Currently, Taiwan is Vietnam's largest foreign investor, but Taiwan investments mainly go to traditional businesses, the report said, pointing out that the Vietnamese information and communication technologies (ICT) market actually provides many good opportunities for Taiwan ICT companies thanks to its government's open policies since 1986.

According to the report, it is estimated that demand for desktop and notebook computers in Vietnam next year will reach around 1.13 million units, including some 1.02 million desktop computers and over 100,000 notebook computers -- a combined 21.5 percent growth over the 2005 figure.

At a time when Taiwan computer makers in China are worried about overcapacity since the ICT business has become saturated since 2000, Taiwan companies should consider shifting to Vietnam, where political stability, cheap labor and strong market demand are its advantages, the report said, noting that monthly salaries for Vietnamese workers average NT$2,500, lower than China's NT$4,000 (US$120).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT MEETS SADAHARU OH AND TALKS BASEBALL

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Japan both have a good chance of doing well in next spring's baseball tournament, with Taiwan's fine stable of players and baseball legend Sadaharu Oh managing the Japanese side, President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday.
The president made the remarks when he received Oh at the Presidential Office. Oh was born in Japan to a Chinese father and a Japanese mother and holds an ROC passport.
Oh is scheduled to be the manager of the Japanese team in the upcoming World Baseball Classic, which will be held in Japan, Porto Rico and finally in San Diego, the United States.
Born in 1940, Oh was a former player and manager for Japanese baseball's most famous team, the Yomiuri Giants.
During the meeting, the president said he admired Oh and lauded the many contributions that he has made to the sport, as well as his work to promote closer relations between Taiwan and Japan.
Oh retired in 1980 at age 40 with a world record 868 career home runs.
Oh led the Fukuoka Daiei Hawks to the Japanese championship in 1999 and again in 2003 as manager.
The president noted that since the Taiwan and Japan teams are of similar caliber, their match-ups in the upcoming baseball tournament ought to be interesting to watch.
The World Baseball Classic will be held March 3-20, with 18 teams, including Taiwan, Japan, Cuba, and the United States participating.
The president also said tongue in check that he wondered which side Oh would be playing on when the Japanese team faces Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: 90% OF TAIWAN BUSINESSES TO OFFER BONUSES TO WORKERS IN 2005: POLL

TEXT.P: About 90 percent of businesses in Taiwan will offer year-end bonuses to their workers this year, according to the results of a survey released Thursday by an online employment service provider.

The survey showed that the financial, securities and insurance industries will offer the best bonuses this year, at an average of 2.7 months' salary. The second-best is in the trade sector, which will offer bonuses of 1.83 months' salary on average.
The information technology industry will offer 1.58 months, the construction and real estate industries 1.53 months, and the traditional manufacturing industry 1.51 months.
The survey was conducted by the 104 Job Bank on 1,167 members Dec. 13-16. It had a margin of error of plus or minus 2.87 percentage points.

It was found that 67.1 percent of the companies will vary the amount of bonuses for their workers based on their performance this year, compared with 17.1 percent which will offer the same amount to all their workers.
Meanwhile, 60 percent of the respondents to the survey said they will see how much bonus they get to decide whether to change jobs.

DOC.HEADLINE: YU SAYS IF ELECTED DPP CHAIRMAN HE WILL STRESS COORDINATION

TEXT.P: Yu Shyi-kun, one of the candidates for chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , said Thursday that he will strengthen policy coordination between the DPP and the government once elected party leader.

Yu, who quit his job as secretary-general of the Presidential Office recently to vie for the DPP chairmanship, stressed that the DPP should keep presenting reform projects and make the administration fully understand the direction of the party.

Former DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang stepped down from his job earlier this month to take responsibility for the party's defeat in the Dec. 3 "three-in-one" elections, and Vice President Annette Lu was named to serve as acting chairwoman of the DPP. The DPP won only six of the 23 city mayor and county magistrate posts being contested, far behind the 14 won by the opposition Kuomintang (KMT).
The election for the new DPP chairman is Jan. 15.

Yu stressed that the DPP has played an important role as a reformer during the last 20 years by advocating the lifting of the ban on the formation of new political parties and by pushing for a free press and the direct election of the president. These led to open and fair public elections in Taiwan. The DPP has also made progress in fostering women's participation in politics, he added.

However, Yu added, the party has lost its luster after taking the helm of the country for five years. Chen Shui-bian of the DPP was voted into office as president in 2000, ending the nearly 55-year rule of the KMT.
Yu said many current problems lie in the unclear relationship between the party and the administration. Once elected DPP chairman, Yu stressed that he will re-define this relationship.

Although the DPP has never been dictatorial, Yu said the party should not be limited to just being an "election-driven entity, " stressing that he will strengthen reforms and make the party a kind of think tank for the government.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CHIEF INSISTS ON AGREEMENT WITH CHINA OVER CURRENCY EXCHANGE

TEXT.P: Taiwan will accept nothing less than a bilateral currency clearance agreement with China before it will offer the currency exchange service for the Chinese yuan in Taiwan, Mainland Affairs Council Minister Joseph Wu said Thursday.

Speaking at a joint conference of the Ethnic Committee and the Financial Committee, Wu rejected the idea proposed by opposition lawmaker Christina Liu of setting up a currency clearance mechanism for the yuan with the Hong Kong branch of the Bank of China and starting the exchange services before any clearance agreement is concluded with Beijing.

Wu said an agreement is not only required by law but also necessary for the financial security of the country, noting that billions of yuan could flow into Taiwan once the exchange service begins and it could jeopardize the security of the country's finances if China refuses to clear them.
The clearance agreement is being blocked by Beijing's refusal to talk with Taipei over political differences despite the close trade between the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOVEMBER JOBLESS RATE DROPS TO 3.94 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's unemployment rate fell to 3.94 percent in November, the lowest single-month level for November in the last five years, the Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) reported Thursday.
The number of jobless people decreased to 411,000 in November from 424,000 in October, DGBAS officials said.
The unemployment rate for the 11 months to November was 4.15 percent, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: THOSE USING OLD AND NEW IDS TO VOTE TWICE WILL BE PROSECUTED: CEC

TEXT.P: Those caught trying to use their old and new ID cards to vote twice in next year's elections will face criminal prosecution, the Central Election Commission (CEC) warned Thursday.
The CEC's warning came as the nation began to issue new ID cards Wednesday, or the first renewal since 1986.

The issuing of the new version of the ID cards will run until Dec. 31, 2006, the CEC said, adding that between now and then, there will be a by-election for legislators in Chiayi City, southern Taiwan, and elections for borough chiefs, and Taipei and Kaohsiung mayors and councilors.
As both versions of the ID card will be valid next year, the CEC is devising ways to prevent voter fraud.

The CEC officials said that during the elections, voter name lists will indicate whether a person has had his or her old ID card replaced, and will not give out ballots to those having received their new cards but trying to vote with their old ones.
They also said that if a person loses his or her ID card and later finds it, the ID card should be turned in to authorities, as an ID card that has been reported lost is invalid.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAN ARRESTED FOR COUNTERFEITING NEW VERSION OF CHINESE BANKNOTES

TEXT.P: A 47-year-old man living in Houpi township of Tainan County was arrested Thursday on charges of counterfeiting Chinese banknotes and is being prosecuted.

Tsai Tung-lo, a spokesman for the Tainan County Station of the Bureau of Investigation said that Huang Chao-sheng, who had been convicted of counterfeiting Chinese banknotes in June and sentenced to five years in jail by a district court, was again caught manufacturing the new version of the Chinese currency, which came out in September.

Investigators raided Huang's residence early Thursday and found that he had turned the first and second floors of his home into a money-printing factory and was managing the whole production process single-handedly.

The investigators seized one million yuan in completed fake notes and more than half a million in semi-finished notes. They also confiscated three currency-printing machines, more than a dozen various other machines and computers.
The forged currency -- all 100 yuan banknotes -- bear a strong resemblance to genuine bills, even down to the surface-relief holograms.
Tsai said the fake money was apparently intended to be supplied to buyers from smuggling rings for use during the Chinese Lunar New Year holiday when new banknotes will be in big demand.
This is the first currency-counterfeiting case in Taiwan involving the new 100 yuan Chinese banknotes, which even many people in China have rarely had a chance to see, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA AIRLINES HAS BEST CORPORATE GOVERNANCE IN TAIWAN: EUROMONEY

TEXT.P: China Airlines (CAL) has been rated by Euromoney magazine as having the best corporate governance practices among companies in Taiwan.
The results of the survey of companies in emerging markets worldwide are published in the October edition of the international financial magazine.
Only three Taiwan companies, including the CAL, made it onto the world's top 100 list.
CAL, which ranked 190th in the world and ninth in Taiwan in the 2004 corporate governance survey, has made a big leap this year to rank 66th in the world, 35th in Asia and number one in Taiwan.
The criteria used for the survey included ownership transparency and rights, financial transparency, board structure and process, stakeholder relations, and alignment of managerial interests.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG MAYOR UNDECIDED WHETHER TO SUE PRESIDENT OVER HEALTH REMARK

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu said Thursday he is still undecided as to whether he will sue President Chen Shui-bian for damaging his reputation during campaigning before the Dec. 3 election.

Hu, a member of the opposition Kuomintang, was re-elected despite negative campaigning against him by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , particularly instances where the DPP -- and the president himself -- alluded to the fact that Hu had had a mild stroke previously and wondered if this made him unfit to be mayor.
Hu said that the president is still on his shortlist of people he is considering taking legal action against.
During campaigning for DPP Taichung mayoral candidate Lin Chia-lung, Chen asked Taichung residents to support Lin, since Hu could "drop dead at any time."
Hu said Thursday that Chen's remarks had seriously damaged his reputation and he should file a lawsuit against the president for compensation for the benefit of his supporters.

The point of this, Hu stressed, would be to inspire the country's politicians to refrain from running off at the mouth and making false accusations during campaigning, a time that no one should think of as a "holiday from the law."

During the height of the campaigning, 12 medical doctors in the Taichung area even came forward at a news conference to denigrate Hu's health with what they claimed was Hu's medical records in an attempt to thwart Hu's re-election by saying that he might not be healthy enough for the post.

DOC.HEADLINE: WOMAN'S DREAM OF BEARING HER LATE FIANCE'S CHILD SHATTERED

TEXT.P: A woman's dream of bearing her late fiance's child, using frozen sperm harvested after his death, was shattered Thursday when a clinic in Taichung destroyed the sperm at the insistence of the family of the diseased man, despite the woman's repeated pleas not to do so.

Li Hsin-yu, 29, lost her fiance, Capt. Sun Chi-hsiang, a 29-year-old ROC Army company leader who died in September, in an accident while guiding an armored tank unto a truck. Sun's sperm was harvested 68 hours after his death when health authorities and Sun's family agreed to Li's plea that she wanted to bear Sun's child via in vitro fertilization.

However, last weekend the Sun family notified the clinic where the sperm had been kept frozen that they wanted the sperm destroyed. They also told Li that the Sun family changed their minds and that she should look forward to a new life and leave the past behind.
With lawyers serving as witnesses, an obstetrician removed the 14 vials of sperm preserved in liquid nitrogen at minus 196 degrees Celsius, thus rendering them inert.
Li's wish of keeping one vial of the destroyed sperm as something to remember her late fiance by was flatly rejected by the Sun family.

The Sun family also refused a request from the clinic that they donate the sperm for medical research to examine whether the DNA in the sperm remained intact and whether the vitality of the sperm was affected.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PREPARING FALLBACK DRUG IN FIGHT AGAINST AVIAN FLU

TEXT.P: The Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) announced Thursday that it is working to produce a well-known anti-influenza drug in the fight against avian flu.

Tamiflu, which doctors say could be the most effective treatment against avian flu, was found by a study published in the New England Journal of Medicine to have been ineffectual in four of eight patients treated in Vietnam who died of the disease.
With this in mind, the ITRI is trying to produce a form of Relenza, the trade name of a drug marketed by GlaxoSmithKline, for the treatment of influenza A and B.
Although the World Health Organization (WHO) has said that the apparent resistant to Tamiflu is nothing to be concerned about, the ITRI wants to be prepared.

"Whenever you use any kind of drugs, antivirals or antibiotics, you expect to see resistance develop in organs. Finding some resistance in and of itself is not surprising and is not necessarily alarming, " Keiji Fukuda, an expert at the WHO's global influenza program told Reuters.
The WHO has suggested that Relenza could be one of the drugs effective in fighting avian flu. Hospitals in Germany and the United Kingdom have begun to stockpile Relenza.
Huang Chong-hsiung, a spokesman for the ITRI said the institute is already capable of mastering the technique to produce Relenza as well as its important component, sialic acid.

Huang said the ITRI has been capable of making sialic acid since 1998 or 1999. However, Relenza is less convenient than Tamiflu because it is a powder, and is inhaled. Relenza is not officially available in Taiwan.
Su Shin-san, the head of the ITRI's Biomedical Center, said that the effects of Relenza are similar to those of Tamiflu; if taken within 48 hours of the onset of flu symptoms, it should be effective.

DOC.HEADLINE: DETAINEE'S FRIEND 100% SURE NTU STUDENT DID NOT ASSAULT HK POLICE

TEXT.P: A graduate school student who went with National Taiwan University student Lee Chien-cheng to Hong Kong last week to observe the Asian farmers' protests against the World Trade Organization (WTO) talks in Hong Kong said Thursday that he is 100 percent sure that Lee did not attack police and Lee was not involved in any violent activities in Hong Kong.
Lee, a senior with NTU's Department of Political Sciences, was arrested by Hong Kong police Dec. 18 and later charged with unlawful assembly in the former British colony.

Lee Che-yu, a student with Shih Hsin University's Institute of Social Development, said during an exclusive interview with CNA Thursday that he was with Lee Chien-cheng all the time after they arrived in Hong Kong Dec. 12, and they were there mainly to record how Asian farmers lodged their protests during the WTO meetings until the early morning of Dec. 18.

Lee Che-yu said that Lee Chien-cheng, himself, Kuan Chen-yin, a classmate of his, and Chang Li-pen, a doctorate candidate with Tunghai University, were taking part in a peaceful march near Hong Kong's Victoria Park at noon on Dec. 17.

The police cordoned off the street before they knew it and they were held on the street without any pre-warning. Hungry and without warm clothes, they proceeded to the cordon line in the small hours of Dec. 18 and asked to leave. The Hong Kong police then arrested all of them and whisked them to a police station.

He said that until this day, he still has no idea why the Hong Kong police should have arrested the four of them and for what reasons the Hong Kong police detained and charged Lee Chien-cheng while releasing the other three.

Lee Che-yu said that he guarantees with his life that Lee Chien-cheng was in a peaceful march and was not among the 1,000-strong rioters who were accused of assaulting and battering Hong Kong police during anti-globalization protests at the WTO talks on Dec. 17.

Lee Che-yu added that they had not been offered any help or assistance by Republic of China officials stationed in Hong Kong until they were released and departed the Chinese special administrative district for home Dec. 20.

Meanwhile, opposition Kuomintang Legislator Ting Shou-chung said in Hong Kong Thursday that he visited Lee Chien-cheng at a Hong Kong detention center earlier in the day and believes that an "optimistic result" should be apparent Friday when a Hong Kong court reviews Lee's case.

Ting, a lecturer with the NTU Department of Political Sciences who traveled to Hong Kong Wednesday for a meeting, said that he accompanied Lee Chien-cheng's parents and an NTU professor as well as a couple of Taiwan officials stationed in Hong Kong on a visit to Lee at the detention center Thursday.
Ting said that Lee's physical condition seemed to be good and Lee told him that he did not attack or assault any Hong Kong police Dec. 17.
In the past, the Hong Kong authorities have dealt with protesters or demonstrators by imposing fines or having them do social services.

Lee's arrest in Hong Kong has stirred up indignation among Taiwan's students. Dozens of college students began a sit-in in front of the NTU's main gate Wednesday to protest against the Hong Kong authorities for arresting and detaining Lee. The sit-in has continued for 30 hours as of press time Thursday night.
The students urged the Beijing and Hong Kong authorities to respect the principles of democracy and human rights and release Lee immediately.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOUTH KOREA IS TAIWAN'S REAL RIVAL, NOT CHINA: BUSINESS LEADER

TEXT.P: South Korea, not China, is the leading rival of Taiwan companies, and local businesses should forge cooperative ventures with Chinese enterprises to create a broader footprint, a business leader said Thursday.

Speaking at a seminar at National Taiwan University, Matthew F. C. Miau, chairman of Mitac International Corporation, opined that Taiwan and China should be partners rather than competitors because South Korea is the real adversary.

Taiwan and Chinese businesses should align to take on the challenges from South Korean companies, Miau said, explaining that China can provide a cheap production force for Taiwan to gain handsome orders from big customers.
Miau also urged the government to ease its cap on China-bound investments by Taiwan companies, saying that the current restrictions will only drive domestic businesses into a blind alley.

Taiwan businesses are full of vigor and the government should not restrict their potential and hobble their advantages with unnecessary limits, he said, adding that even Hong Hai Precision Machinery Corp., which is Taiwan's largest company in the manufacturing sector, would find no way out if the government is not willing to remove this roadblock.
This will also drag down foreign investors interested in Taiwan if Taiwan's economy is not perceived as free and open, he contended.
Taiwan companies are now banned from investing more than 40 percent of their capital in China -- a restriction that the business community has repeatedly called on the government to phase out.

In the face of Taiwan's declining exports as a result of local companies' mass relocations to China, sharpening global competitiveness and building up company scales are the two major tasks testing Taiwan businesses, said experts attending a symposium later the same day.
At a time when Taiwan's export sector is increasingly diminishing, it is important that domestic enterprises think of new business directions, experts advised.

Pointing to South Korea as an example, they said that it has surpassed Taiwan in research and development, helping it overtake Taiwan in terms of foreign trade. It enjoys a snowballing trade surplus with Taiwan that has amounted to US$7 billion for the first 11 months of this year.

Although the new Taiwan dollar has slid to about 33.3 against the U.S. dollar to help exporters, economists warned that Taiwan industries would be in greater danger if they fail to improve their competitive edge and do not come up with a visionary business development strategy amid the rapidly changing international situations.
When flagging exports become commonplace, no foreign investors will want to invest in Taiwan, they asserted.

DOC.HEADLINE: MA, SOONG CONTINUE OPPOSING MILITARY PURCHASE AT 'EXORBITANT PRICES'

TEXT.P: The leaders of Taiwan's two main opposition parties reiterated Thursday that while they believe the nation needs to maintain appropriate defense capabilities, they remain opposed to the plan of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to procure weapons at what they said were "exorbitant prices."

Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong reached this consensus at their second meeting since the DPP's humiliating defeat in the Dec. 3 local government elections.
Emerging from the meeting, Soong pointed out that the PFP has been opposed to buying weapons at exorbitant prices for quite some time.

"Why must we spend US$1 billion to purchase submarines from the U.S. that would cost other countries only US$300 million? And why does the DPP government use a special budget to dodge oversight by the legislature?" he asked.

Soong reminded the Americans that if they want to help Taiwan develop its defense capabilities, they should sell Taiwan new weapons, not outdated ones. He added that although Taiwan must demonstrate its determination to defend itself, the United States must also show equal determination to help Taiwan defend itself.

The PFP chairman urged the DPP government to make clear to the people whether it intends to settle the cross-Taiwan Strait issue by war or by peaceful means. "If it is to be settled by war, I would say frankly: 'We are not China's match.'"
Ma said that the nation needs adequate defense capabilities, which do not have to come from the three proposed categories of the procurement plan.

The DPP government has submitted two bills in the legislature seeking approval for a NT$480 billion (US$14.45 billion) special budget to purchase eight diesel-electric submarines, six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft from the United States. However, the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the PFP has blocked the legislation 41 times.

DOC.HEADLINE: AVERAGE SALARY IN FIRST 10 MONTHS DROPS 1.28% FROM LAST YEAR: DBGAS

TEXT.P: The average monthly salary for workers in Taiwan's industrial and service sectors was NT$34,443 in the first 10 months of this year, a decrease of 1.28 percent over the same period of last year, according to a report released Thursday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
The DGBAS statistics showed that the employees in the two sectors had an average monthly workload of 180.6 hours in the first 10 months, a drop of 1.4 hours over the same period of 2004.

A total of 5.92 million people were employed in the industrial and service sectors in the first 10 months of the year, representing an increase of 109,000 employees over the same period of last year, or a 1.88 percent growth.
In October, the employees in the two sectors worked for an average of 179.4 hours, a decrease of 4.7 hours over September and a drop of 3.6 hours over the same month last year.

In terms of salary, the workers in these sectors had an average monthly salary of NT$38,853 in October, a drop of 4.5 percent over the figure registered in the previous month and a decrease of 0.41 percent over the same month last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: AMBASSADORS' WIVES SPREAD HOLIDAY CHEER TO CHILDREN

TEXT.P: Wives of 11 foreign ambassadors stationed in Taiwan visited an aboriginal nursery school in Wulai township in the northern County of Taipei Thursday to offer them their best Christmas wishes.
The group was accompanied by the wife of the ROC's foreign minister and the wife of the newly elected Taipei County magistrate.
The children were given small sums of money in red envelopes, a Chinese tradition, and books and gifts.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENVOY HOPES ROC-JAPAN TIES CAN BE INSTITUTIONALIZED

TEXT.P: ROC Representative to Japan Koh Se-kai said Thursday that he saw an improvement in Taiwan-Japan ties in the last year, but hopes that such relations can be institutionalized in the future.

At a meeting with Taiwanese reporters, Koh noted that the biggest improvement in bilateral ties has been the Japanese government's offering permanent visa-free treatment to Taiwanese tourists starting from this September.

Noting that the number of Taiwanese tourists traveling to Japan is expected to exceed 1.3 million this year, Koh said the number of Japanese travelers visiting Taiwan has topped 1.1 million so far this year.

Although the exchange channels between Taiwan and Japan are not weak, the fact is that they are not institutionalized like the ties between Japan and the United States under a security alliance and the relations between Taiwan and U.S., which are managed by the Taiwan Relations Act, Koh stressed.
Koh said he was happy to see that some Japanese scholars are planning to promote a Taiwan-Japan Relations Act in Japan.

Referring to the Japanese government's move of classifying Taiwanese people living in Japan as China's citizens, Koh said this will not only cause inconvenience to Taiwanese people, but will affect their legal rights.
However, Koh said he has confidence a solution to the problem will be found.
As to the long-term fishing rights dispute between Taiwan and Japan over their overlapping economic zones, Koh urged both governments to seek solutions.

As to the decision by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna (ICCAT) to cut Taiwan's bigeye tuna fishing quota in the Atlantic Ocean from 14,900 tons in 2005 to 4,600 tons for next year, under the proposal by Japan which claimed that Taiwanese tuna fishing boats were overfishing, Koh noted that the solution to the problem lies in the self-control of each country.
He urged fishing boats around the world to respect international regulations to further protect the world's marine resources.

Koh went on to say that with many anti-Japanese protests in China, Japan now has no more illusions about China, as it is now aware that China is not an ordinary country in which Japan can expect changes through long-term engagement.

However, with China's obstruction, Koh said it is impossible to imagine that Taiwan can join the proposed "East Asian Community, " which may include the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, China, Japan and South Korea.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO INCREASE IN FOREIGN LABOR WILL PROTECT LOCAL WORKERS: CLA

TEXT.P: Allowing more foreign workers into Taiwan will not be considered at least for the next six months to protect the interests of domestic workers, Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) Chairman Lee Ying-yuan said Thursday.

Lee was responding to a call made by Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh recently for increasing the number of foreign workers to work in Taiwan's industrial sector, particularly in the "3K" industries -- referring to those sectors where work is "dirty, " "dangerous," or demands "hard labor."

Lee said that 20,000 foreign workers will be allowed to be introduced into Taiwan next year for certain manufacturing jobs in 19 industries to help boost Taiwan industries' international competitiveness. He added that the 20,000-head quota will be allocated in two phases in a ratio of two foreign workers for every three domestic workers in "3K" sectors.
Noting that the 2:3 worker format will be implemented for one year on a trial basis, Lee said that this program is not supposed to be changed at least in the following half year.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEARLY 53 PERCENT OF PEOPLE SUPPORT ARMS PACKAGE: MND

TEXT.P: Over 70 percent of the people support putting the U.S. arms package bill on the agenda of the Legislative Yuan, while 52.8 percent want the country to buy the weaponry, according to Gen. Hu Chen-pu, the head of the General Political Warfare Bureau Thursday, citing a recent poll.
The opinion poll was done by ERA, a Taiwan media group.

Taiwan is planning to acquire from the U.S. an arms package that includes eight diesel-electric submarines, 12 P-3C Orion anti-submarine warfare aircraft and six PAC-3 anti-missile batteries and Patriot missiles.

The ruling party and its ally called a snap-vote on putting the issue on the legislative agenda for review after opposition lawmakers were away at another meeting and did not have their usual majority. The opposition has voted down the request for review 41 times. The opposition is expected to reverse the situation as soon as the next meeting.
"The arms purchase has already become a political issue. Our only hope now is that the people's opinion changes the minds of the legislators," Hu said.

"The Ministry of National Defense has paid a visit to KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou to brief him on the current situation. Sure, we share different points of view, but we are still negotiating. If needed, the defense ministry will find time to give him more briefings," Hu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CENTRAL BANK RAISES KEY LENDING RATES BY 12.5 BASIS POINTS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Central Bank of China (CBC) decided Thursday to raise its key lending rates by a further 12.5 basis points, following a similar increase this past September.
Starting Friday, the CBC discount rate will be raised to 2.25 percent from 2.125 percent, CBC officials said.

Meanwhile, the accommodations with collateral rate will rise to 2.625 percent from the current 2.5 percent, and the accommodations without collateral rate will pick up to 4.5 percent from 4.375 percent.
The hikes will be the sixth round of the CBC key interest rates increases since September 2004, bringing the total cumulative rate hikes since then to 87.50 basis points.

The rate hikes reflected the central bank's stance to return the monetary policy to "neutral" amid an ongoing economic expansion, lingering inflationary pressure and still low real interest rates, CBC officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Transit Strike Into 2nd Day; Stakes Climb
As New York City plunged into Day 2 of the transit strike, the stakes for those on the picket line, businesses and riders spiraled upward yesterday: Gov. George E. Pataki said that there would be no negotiations until the strikers return to work; a judge raised the possibility of sending union leaders to jail; businesses languished and weary New Yorkers grappled with the harsh realities of life without buses or subways. Despite union leader Toussaint's vow not to retu rn to the table until the pension demand was dropped, he and his top lawyers were meeting with state mediators for hours at a time. State mediation could either yield a solution to the differences, or force the two sides to binding arbitration.
Wall Street Journal: Second Chance, Once-Touted Drug For Cancer Finds New Life in China
In the 1960s, pioneer researcher Judah Folkman first came up with the idea of treating cancer by choking off tumors' blood supply. He was largely vindicated in February 2004 when the U.S. Food and Drug Administration approved Avastin, a cancer drug based on this principle. But Avastin is sold by Genentech Inc. Shortly before Avastin's approval, EntreMed, the small company making the drug, gave up on Folkman's own discovery, a drug called endostatin. Today, the entrepreneurial Chinese biochemist believes he has rescued Dr. Folkman's dream. Luo Yongzhang, who teaches in Tsinghua University and owns a company, says an improved version of the drug, developed by his company, has shown promising results in Chinese human trials, and he hopes to bring it to patients in the U.S. Dr. Luo says his new drug, which he calls Endostar, "could be a revolution, and the Chinese government recognizes this." He says his company is in talks with several major U.S. pharmaceutical companies about licensing Endostar, which was approved by Chinese authorities in October, for use in the U.S. He declines to name the companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND TO ADJUST STANCE ON ARMS PROCUREMENT BUDGETING

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) is willing to adjust its budget planning in order to win legislative support for a long-stalled arms procurement project, a senior military official said Thursday.

Gen. Hu Chen-pu, director of the MND's Political Warfare Department, was referring to the military's plan to procure three big-ticket weaponry items from the United States, including eight diesel-electric submarines, a squadron of 12 P-3C Orion anti-submarine warfare aircraft and six Patriot PAC-3 anti-missile batteries.

The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its "pan-green" ally -- the Taiwan Solidarity Union -- called a snap-vote Tuesday on putting the issue on the legislative agenda for review after opposition lawmakers were away at another meeting and did not have their usual majority.

The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) has voted down the request for review 41 times. The opposition is expected to reverse the situation at Friday's legislative plenary session.

The MND originally intended to have all three items financed by a NT$610.8 billion special budget, but later changed its mind and listed the six anti-missile batteries in its 2006 regular budget plan while leaving only the remaining two items in a NT$480 billion special budget plan.
Speaking at a year-end tea party with military journalists Thursday, Hu said the MND is now considering having the P-3Cs included in the military's regular annual budget, too.
Hu said the MND's bottom line is to have the submarines retained in the special budget plan to meet the U.S. requirement. The eight submarines will call for an estimated outlay of NT$299 billion.

"This is our internal plan and we'll further consult with lawmakers from across the political spectrum to better understand their opinions and seek their support for the critical procurement project," Hu said.
According to Hu, the military cannot lump all the three items into its regular annual budget plan because such a practice would drain funds for other military build-up plans.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE MUM ON NEW PROPOSAL FOR CONTROL YUAN MAKEUP

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office kept mum Thursday on an opposition proposal on the makeup of the Control Yuan, the nation's supreme watchdog body.
Under the current ROC Constitution, Control Yuan members are appointed by the president with the consent of the Legislative Yuan.

President Chen Shui-bian referred a list of Control Yuan nominees to the legislature in November 2004. The opposition-controlled legislature had refused to review it. Earlier this week, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its ally called a snap-vote on putting the list on the legislative agenda for review after opposition lawmakers were away at another meeting and did not have their usual majority.

The heads of the two opposition "pan-blue alliance" parties -- Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and People First Party Chairman James Soong -- came up with a proposal for resolving the gridlock after their long closed-door meeting.

They suggested that the Control Yuan seats be filled up with a formula adopted in the formation of the National Communications Commission (NCC) , under which political parties first recommend celebrities to form a screening committee to review Control Yuan nominees to be put forward by political parties in proportion to their representation in the legislature.
Asked to comment on this new proposal, Chen Wen-tzung, director of the Presidential Office's Public Affairs Department, said President Chen would not respond for the time being.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOUTH KOREA IS TAIWAN'S REAL RIVAL, NOT CHINA: BUSINESS LEADER(repeat)

TEXT.P: South Korea, not China, is the leading rival of Taiwan companies, and local businesses should forge cooperative ventures with Chinese enterprises to create a broader footprint, a business leader said Thursday.

Speaking at a seminar at National Taiwan University, Matthew F. C. Miau, chairman of Mitac International Corporation, opined that Taiwan and China should be partners rather than competitors because South Korea is the real adversary.

Taiwan and Chinese businesses should align to take on the challenges from South Korean companies, Miau said, explaining that China can provide a cheap production force for Taiwan to gain handsome orders from big customers.
Miau also urged the government to ease its cap on China-bound investments by Taiwan companies, saying that the current restrictions will only drive domestic businesses into a blind alley.

Taiwan businesses are full of vigor and the government should not restrict their potential and hobble their advantages with unnecessary limits, he said, adding that even Hong Hai Precision Machinery Corp., which is Taiwan's largest company in the manufacturing sector, would find no way out if the government is not willing to remove this roadblock.
This will also drag down foreign investors interested in Taiwan if Taiwan's economy is not perceived as free and open, he contended.
Taiwan companies are now banned from investing more than 40 percent of their capital in China -- a restriction that the business community has repeatedly called on the government to phase out.

In the face of Taiwan's declining exports as a result of local companies' mass relocations to China, sharpening global competitiveness and building up company scales are the two major tasks testing Taiwan businesses, said experts attending a symposium later the same day.
At a time when Taiwan's export sector is increasingly diminishing, it is important that domestic enterprises think of new business directions, experts advised.

Pointing to South Korea as an example, they said that it has surpassed Taiwan in research and development, helping it overtake Taiwan in terms of foreign trade. It enjoys a snowballing trade surplus with Taiwan that has amounted to US$7 billion for the first 11 months of this year.

Although the new Taiwan dollar has slid to about 33.3 against the U.S. dollar to help exporters, economists warned that Taiwan industries would be in greater danger if they fail to improve their competitive edge and do not come up with a visionary business development strategy amid the rapidly changing international situations.
When flagging exports become commonplace, no foreign investors will want to invest in Taiwan, they asserted.

DOC.HEADLINE: MA, SOONG CONTINUE OPPOSING MILITARY PURCHASE AT 'EXORBITANT PRICES'(repeat)

TEXT.P: The leaders of Taiwan's two main opposition parties reiterated Thursday that while they believe the nation needs to maintain appropriate defense capabilities, they remain opposed to the plan of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to procure weapons at what they said were "exorbitant prices."

Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong reached this consensus at their second meeting since the DPP's humiliating defeat in the Dec. 3 local government elections.
Emerging from the meeting, Soong pointed out that the PFP has been opposed to buying weapons at exorbitant prices for quite some time.

"Why must we spend US$1 billion to purchase submarines from the U.S. that would cost other countries only US$300 million? And why does the DPP government use a special budget to dodge oversight by the legislature?" he asked.

Soong reminded the Americans that if they want to help Taiwan develop its defense capabilities, they should sell Taiwan new weapons, not outdated ones. He added that although Taiwan must demonstrate its determination to defend itself, the United States must also show equal determination to help Taiwan defend itself.

The PFP chairman urged the DPP government to make clear to the people whether it intends to settle the cross-Taiwan Strait issue by war or by peaceful means. "If it is to be settled by war, I would say frankly: 'We are not China's match.'"
Ma said that the nation needs adequate defense capabilities, which do not have to come from the three proposed categories of the procurement plan.

The DPP government has submitted two bills in the legislature seeking approval for a NT$480 billion (US$14.45 billion) special budget to purchase eight diesel-electric submarines, six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft from the United States. However, the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the PFP has blocked the legislation 41 times.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPEAKER CALLS FOR NEGOTIATIONS TO AVOID SHOWDOWN ON ARMS BILL

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng called Friday for negotiations between the "pan-green camp" led by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the "pan-blue alliance" led by the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) in order to avoid a showdown vote over the arms procurement bill.

The bill was finally placed on the legislative agenda two days ago when the "pan-green camp" pushed it through the Procedure Committee. It was able to do so because fewer "pan-blue" members were in attendance. Prior to Tuesday, the bill had been blocked by "pan-blue" lawmakers 41 times over the past year.

Both camps have now mobilized their legislators, with the "pan-blue" lawmakers criticizing Tuesday's "surprise attack" and threatening to send the bill back to the Procedure Committee for further screening, in effect killing it. The "pan-green" legislators are mobilizing to try to push the bill through to the first reading at Friday's plenary session.

The two camps exchanged harsh rhetoric during a national affairs forum Friday, with "pan-green camp" lawmakers saying that the opposition is threatening Taiwan's national security by trying to block the bill, and "pan-blue" lawmakers insisting that they would oppose the current "cash-for-friendship" arms package to the end and would only accept a "reasonable" bill.

Legislative speaker Wang, a KMT stalwart, said he keenly hopes that legislators from the two rival camps can negotiate with each other and arrive at a consensus at Friday's session in order to prevent a showdown vote on the arms procurement bill.

The Ministry of National Defense submitted the bill for the purchase of six Patriot III anti-missile batteries, eight conventional submarines and 12 P-3C Orion submarine-hunting aircraft from the United States to the Legislative Yuan last year. The initial price tag was NT$610.8 billion, but the ministry later reduced it to NT$480 billion after the opposition lawmakers rejected the bill.

Meanwhile, KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou breakfasted with members of the legislative caucus of the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union (NPSU) Friday morning in an apparent attempt to seek the support of the independent legislators in the "pan-blue alliance's" bid to block the bill yet again.
Tseng Yung-chuan, head of the KMT Central Policy Committee, said after the breakfast that independent lawmakers will be on the side of their "pan-blue alliance" colleagues to oppose to the bill.
Nevertheless, Lin Ping-kun, the NPSU legislative party whip, was more reserved, saying that "we have our own opinions and judgment" on various bills.

DOC.HEADLINE: PEKING UNIVERSITY TO HONOR FORMER KMT CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Lien Chan, honorary chairman of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , was "elated" to learn that Peking University wants to make him a professor emeritus of the university, Lien's aide said Friday.

Ting yuean-chao, director of Lien's office, made the remarks after Hong Kong-based newspaper Ta Kung Po reported that Xu Zhihong, Peking University president said during his recent call on Lien in Taiwan that the university will present him with the honor at the appropriate time.

Lien, who holds a doctoral degree in politics from the University of Chicago and who taught at National Taiwan University before entering politics, was elated to learn that a prestigious university will bestow the honor on him, Ting said.

Lien visited China in late April in his capacity as KMT chairman. During his visit, he delivered a speech at Peking University and met with Chinese President Hu Jintao, who also serves as general secretary of the Communist Party of China (CPC), marking the first meeting between the leaders of the KMT and CPC since the KMT retreated to Taiwan in 1949 after being defeated by the CPC in Chinese civil war.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESS SOFTWARE MARKET TO CONTINUE GROWING: IDC

TEXT.P: Taiwan's enterprise resource management (ERM) software market posted sales of US$21.1 million in the first half of 2005, up 25 percent compared with the same period last year, the International Data Corporation said Friday.
The IDC forecast that the market will expand at a compound annual growth rate of 4.9 percent to register sales of US$52.9 million by 2009.

IDC Taiwan's software analyst Hsueh Ju-shan said the growth in the first half of this year was mainly boosted by system replacement and upgrading by large-size enterprises as well as the installation of new systems by small- and medium-size enterprises.

By function, fiscal application software seized the largest share of the market during that period, at 25.6 percent, following by asset management software and payroll management software, which took 18.4 percent and 16.2 percent, respectively, Hsueh said.
The assembly and process manufacturing industries had the highest demand for ERM software, with the two together accounting for 62.4 percent of the total sales, Hsueh said.
Small- and medium-size enterprises' demand for ERM software is forecast to continue to increase steadily, and they are expected to become the main clients of software suppliers, Hsueh said.

Meanwhile, she said, the sales of business performance management (BPM) software will surpass those of other application software in the future with enterprises paying more and more attention to performance and procedural management.

The Straits Times: Tamiflu resistance fears grow after two Viets die.
Two bird flu patients in Vietnam died after developing resistance to Tamiflu, the drug that governments are stockpiling in case of an outbreak, a new study has revealed.
Health experts called the development disturbing because the two girls had received early and aggressive treatment with Tamiflu and were given the recommended doses. But a senior World Health Organisation official said yesterday that the signs that the virus may be developing resistance to Tamiflu in some patients are not necessarily cause for alarm.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC HEAD LOOKS FORWARD TO NTU STUDENT'S EARLY RELEASE

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said Friday that he keenly looks forward to a favorable Hong Kong court ruling later in the day which will allow National Taiwan University (NTU) student Lee Chien-cheng to be released immediately.
A Hong Kong court is scheduled to begin hearings at 2 p.m. Friday for 14 people charged in last week's anti-World Trade Organization protests.

Lee, a senior in NTU's Department of Political Science, was among the 14 protestors arrested Dec. 18 and later charged with unlawful assembly. The 14 people charged include 11 Koreans, one Japanese national, and a mainland Chinese citizen. They were all denied bail and ordered detained by a Hong Kong judge. If convicted, they face a maximum prison sentence of five years.

Wu talked with Lee's father, who has traveled to Hong Kong to support Lee, by cell phone Friday and told the senior Lee that the MAC-assigned attorneys have prepared to secure his son's early release.
For his part, Lee Wen-ping said that he greatly appreciates the "timely" assistance of the MAC and its staff posted in Hong Kong.

Lee Che-yu, a graduate school student at Shih Hsin University's Institute of Social Development who went with Lee Chien-cheng to Hong Kong last week to observe the Asian farmers' protests against the WTO talks in Hong Kong said Thursday in an exclusive interview with CNA that he is 100-percent sure that Lee did not attack police and that he was not involved in any violent activities in Hong Kong.

He said that to this day, he still has no idea why the Hong Kong police should have arrested them or why they detained and charged Lee Chien-cheng while releasing the other three Taiwan students who were with Lee.

Lee Che-yu said that he "guarantees with his life" that Lee Chien-cheng only took part in a peaceful march and was not among the 1,000-strong rioters who were accused of assaulting and battering Hong Kong police during anti-globalization protests at the WTO talks on Dec. 17.
Lee's arrest in Hong Kong has stirred up indignation among Taiwan students. Dozens of college students began a sit-in in front of the NTU's main gate Wednesday to protest Lee's arrest and detention.
The students have urged the Beijing and Hong Kong authorities to respect the principles of democracy and human rights and release Lee immediately.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES UP

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange rose Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 95.43 points to close at 6,512.63.
The bourse opened at 6,450.65 and fluctuated between 6,516.11 and w 6,426.23 during trading. A total of 4.24 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$113.97 billion (US$3.44 billion).

Seven of eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction stocks moving up the most at 2.8 percent, followed by machinery and electronics shares at 2 percent, textile stocks at 1.8 percent, cement shares at 0.9 percent, financial issues at 0.7 percent, foodstuff stocks at 0.6 percent, and plastics and chemicals stocks at 0.5 percent.
Paper and pulp shares lost ground, moving down 0.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered loser 752 to 262, with 196 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: COURT HEARING HELD ON THAI WORKERS CHARGED FOR ROLE IN RIOT

TEXT.P: Thai workers and staff members of a Taiwan labor management company all denied the respective charges against them at a court hearing in the southern port city of Kaohsiung Friday.

Thai workers brought in to work on Kaohsiung's rapid transit project rioted in late August in protest against their inhumane treatment by Huapan Administration Consultant Co., which was contracted by Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) to manage their life in Taiwan.
Thai workers Mueangjan Phon, Meemak Saranyoo, Bopribun Suksan, Kaeokone Baeng and others were indicted on charges of causing public danger, theft and impeding the execution of public duty.
Chang Juan-fang, an official of the Thai representative office in Taiwan, observed the hearing.
Hsu Ming-teh, attorney for the Thai accused, told the judges that the prosecution's investigation reports cannot serve as evidence because they were filled with hearsay and rumors.

He noted that the investigators have obtained testimonies mostly from Huapan's management, including a Thai, and that these managers themselves were among the indicted as they were part of the reason for the riot.
Through interpreters, four accused Thai workers denied that they had burned down the security guards' quarters at their dormitory and the management office and set fire to some vehicles.
They also denied hurling rocks at firefighters who were rushing to the scene of the riot. They further denied that they had stolen NT$750,000 (US$22,607) and 600,000 baht (US$14,659) from a safe.
Huapan staff members, including general manager Yen Shih-hua, manager Yang An-chi, Chung Huan-wei, Chen Jui-yuan, Shih Feng-jui, Chen Kuo-an and Lee Yung-ao, were charged with gambling.
Except for Chen Jui-yuan, who admitted to gambling, all of the accused Huapan staff denied the charges against them. Chen is also charged with impeding freedom.

Chen said setting up gambling machines for Thai workers was his "individual" decision. Yen and the other accused Huapan staff members said they did not know anything about Chen running a gambling business at the dormitory.
After the hearing, Yen Shih-hua and Chang Juan-fang hurried away, declining to reply to any media questions.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for January rose 114 points to close at 6,544, with 32,155 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for February moved up 107 points to end at 6,538, with 121 contracts traded, while March futures gained 75 points to finish at 6,511, with 22 contracts traded. June futures moved up 81 points to close at 6,506, with 26 contracts traded, while September futures rose 105 points to close at 6,424, with 50 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 6,430 for January, 6,431 for February, 6,436 for March, 6,425 for June and 6,319 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were all higher.

January TF futures surged 6.4 points to finish at 898.4, with 1,928 contracts changing hands, while February TF futures moved up 8.4 points to end at 901.8, with seven contracts traded. March TF futures dropped 2.6 points to close at 890.2, with one contract transaction.

DOC.HEADLINE: FAPA TO PUSH FOR SIGNING OF FTA BETWEEN TAIWAN, U.S.
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 22 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The head of the Formosan Association for Public Affairs (FAPA) said Thursday that to strengthen relations between Taiwan and the United States, he will start with the promotion of medical and health exchanges and the signing of a free trade agreement between the two countries.
New FAPA President Lee Chin-tai made the remarks in an interview with the Central News Agency.
Lee said that he is scheduled to lead a delegation to visit Taiwan in February 2006. During his stay in Taiwan, he is expected to call on related government officials.

Looking ahead, Lee said that his planned work will include pushing for exchanges of visits by ranking officials of the two countries, including Taiwan's president, premier and foreign affairs minister, the strengthening of military cooperation, the signing of a free trade agreement, and medical and health exchanges.

Among the tasks, the promotion of exchanges of visits by ranking officials will be the most difficult, while the promotion of medical and health exchanges and the signing of the FTA will be comparatively easier, he said.

The FAPA, established in 1982, is a Washington, D.C.-based organization that promotes international support for the right of the people of Taiwan to establish an independent and democratic country and to join the international community.
Lee took over as FAPA president in a national meeting of the organization in Dallas in early December.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL, CHANEL TO HOLD FASHION SHOW IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: China Airlines (CAL) , Taiwan's largest carrier, and Chanel, a world famous haute-couture brand, will jointly hold a fashion show of 2006 spring-summer collection in mid-January next year in Taiwan, a CAL spokesman said Friday.

The fashion show, slated to be held Jan. 13 at a CAL maintenance plant in Taiwan, is especially designed to attract customers in Taiwan, Hong Kong and China, and is expected to bring a large number of fashion celebrities from around the world to Taiwan, the spokesman said.

The fashion show will be the first large-scale catwalk by Chanel in Taiwan, and it will also help sell Taiwan to the rest of the world, he added, noting that guests will be treated to top shelf professional services by both CAL and Chanel during the show.

CAL, Taiwan's largest carrier, is committed to creating value- added services for its customers through hybrid cooperative ventures. The fashion show will be the aviation company's latest such collaboration after its cooperation with ABN AMRO Bank and Connexion by Boeing.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL IDENTITY DISPARITY THREATENS NATIONAL SECURITY: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday that the national identity disparity among the Taiwan people is posing the greatest challenge to the country's security.

According to Chen, only if the people have a clear idea as to who is the country's biggest enemy will they be able to unite their strength to establish a strong national defense system and overcome natural and geographical restrictions to expand the depth of the country's defense strategy.
As long as the national identity disparity is resolved, inter-party disagreements over the government's arms procurement package with the United States will no longer exist, Chen said.

Chen made the remarks during a luncheon with a group of presidential advisers. Earlier that day, legislators of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and People First Party sent the arms procurement bill back to the legislature's Procedure Committee by voting to dismiss Friday's plenary session.

"Pan-blue" lawmakers had barred the bill from being included in the legislative agenda on 41 occasions over the past year. It was finally placed on Friday's legislative agenda -- when it was supposed to go through the first reading -- after the "pan-green" camp pushed it through the Procedure Committee two days ago.

The president said although the Taiwanese identity has become the mainstream value in Taiwan society today, there are still more than 10 percent of the people who identify with the old national identity that considers China to be their mother country.
Chen said the spirit and value of integration of the European Union can be a reference model, but not the only one, for the future development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations.

He said the EU principles of sovereignty, parity, democracy and peace are of great reference for Taiwan and China, pointing out that all EU member nations accept each other as independent sovereign states on equal footing. (By Y.F. Low) ENDTEM/mw

DOC.HEADLINE: NSC HAS FINAL SAY IN EASING CHINA INVESTMENT LIMITS: CEPD

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan is willing to gradually ease the current restrictions on China investments as long as the National Security Council (NSC) agrees, Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Chairman Hu Sheng-cheng said Friday.

Hu made the remarks following a breakfast gathering sponsored by the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce with business community leaders who asked the government to phase out the present limits on investments allowed for Taiwan companies in China in view of a string of incentives recently provided by China.

Claiming that Premier Frank Hsieh has in principle agreed to gradually remove the 40 percent cap on capital investment by Taiwan companies in China, Hu quoted Hsieh as making it clear that it could be possible only after the NSC has fully weighed the issue and gives its approval.

The local business community and economists have repeatedly called on the government to permit Taiwan industries to invest in China freely as Taiwan and China are complementary in taking on aggressive competition from other countries.

Mitac International Corporation Chairman Matthew F. C. Miau called a day earlier for building a partnership between Taiwan and Chinese companies on the grounds that South Korea is actually the No. 1 competitor for both in the global market.
Taiwan companies, though full of vigor, would be driven into a blind alley and would find no way out should the government be unwilling to remove the roadblock, Miau warned.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST TAIWAN COMPANIES RULE OUT SALARY HIKES NEXT YEAR: POLL

TEXT.P: More than 73 percent of Taiwan companies will maintain their current level of salaries for workers, while only nearly 12 percent said that they will raise their starting salaries for new workers, according to the results of a recent survey.

Some 55 percent of the companies surveyed think that their business conditions next year will be more or less the same as this year, while 16 percent are pessimistic about the coming situation, the survey results showed.

About 34 percent of the companies responding to the poll said that they have plans to recruit new blood next year, with those in the media and publishing sectors and those in the information and daily consumer product industries displaying greater demand.

Job opportunities in the manufacturing, real estate and pharmaceutical and biotech businesses have increased more over the past year, while jobs in the insurance and securities sectors have fallen slightly.
The online survey was carried out by the 104 Human Resources Data Bank Dec. 13-16, which collected 1,167 samples. The poll had a margin of error of 2.87 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Reppublica: Candidate for new central bank governor decided.
Vice Prmier and Foreign Minister Gianfranco Fini revealed Thursday that the candidate for the new central bank governor had already been decided. However, he said that the name should not be made public before a reform bill on the central bank's organization is approved by the parliament. It is a minimum due respect for the parliament, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Senate Says No to Arctic Oil Drilling. The Senate on Wednesday blocked a major push to open the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to oil drilling while approving the first significant belt -tightening in federal spending in nearly a decade.
