TEXT.P: CNA WILL SUSPEND ITS CEP SERVICE ON DEC. 25, CHRISTMAS DAY, WHICH IS ALSO CONSTITUTION DAY OF THE REPUBLIC OF CHINA. WE WISH ALL OUR SUBSCRIBERS A HAPPY FESTIVE SEASON.

DOC.HEADLINE: EU FORMULA A NEW PATH FOR CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS: ACADEMIC

TEXT.P: Following a European Union-style formula could be a new way of thinking on the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations, an academic said Friday.

Addressing a forum held at the Presidential Office marking Constitution Day, which falls on Saturday, Chen Ming-tung, formerly a vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, said that seeking co-existence and co-prosperity with China under an EU formula is one of the three policies that the government is following to achieve its strategic goal regarding cross-strait relations -- a normalized cross-strait relationship.

In his speech, entitled "A new mindset of national security for a democratized Taiwan, " Chen said he does not think the sitting administration has maintained "wavering" mainland China policies as criticized by some opposition politicians. On the contrary, he said, the government's strategic goal of cross-strait relations is lucid -- seeking the normalization of relations.

To achieve this goal, the administration has three major policies -- consolidate a national consensus on Taiwan's status, stressing that Taiwan is a sovereign state and its official designation is "the Republic of China"; put forward a cross-strait "co-existence and co-prosperity" vision, borrowing the EU formula as an example to follow; and construct transitional arrangements which will facilitate the materialization of the vision, Chen noted.

The "transitional arrangements" include that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait negotiate over the building of a cross-strait interaction framework for peace and stability; that Taiwan continues to enhance business and trade ties with China on principles of "active opening and efficient management"; that Taiwan helps China accelerate its democratization to solve the cross-strait contradiction at its root, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: FISHERMEN PROTEST EPA REPORT ADVISING PEOPLE TO EAT LESS FISH

TEXT.P: Fishermen in Hualien County are angry about a report issued by the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) last weekend that advises people to eat less large deep-sea fish to avoid high mercury levels in their bodies.

Wang Min-chang, general-secretary of the Hualien Fishermen's Association, said Friday that the report had caused fish prices to plunge, and that the hardest-hit were large deep-sea fish, such as marlin.

He said the report had caused the fish market to become stagnant, resulting in huge losses to fishermen who rely on selling their catches for a living, because even at such low prices, consumers were reluctant to buy.

Wang urged the EPA to provide precise figures and other details about the mercury levels in large deep-sea fish, or the fishermen in Hualien County will not rule out a protest demonstration against the administration.
In Taipei, an EPA spokesman told news media that officials had tried to communicate with representatives of the fishermen after learning of the situation, and had obtained their understanding.
The spokesman said that the EPA report was not targeted at deep-sea fish, but was mainly intended to call people's attention to the problem of mercury pollution.

The EPA report, issued Sunday after a one-year study based on 1,066 samples, showed that the people in Taiwan have an average mercury level of 2.4 milligrams per kilogram in their hair, slightly higher than people in Japan and the United States.
According to the report, Hualien County leads all other 22 counties and cities of Taiwan, with the average mercury content in the hair of its people measured at 3.09 milligrams per kilogram.
The report also said that the average mercury level in the hair of people who have the habit of eating large deep-sea fish is six times that of those who do not eat such fish.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOVEMBER EXPORT ORDERS RISE 24.58% YEAR-ON-YEAR

TEXT.P: Taiwan's export orders in November rose 24.58 percent year-on-year to US$24.61 billion, the second-highest single-month record, owing mainly to the strong demand from the United States and Hong Kong, according to tallies released Friday by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).
Export orders for the 11 months to November amounted to US$231.8 billion, up US$36.51 billion, or 18.7 percent, from the same period last year.

November export orders for information and communications products increased US$1.7 billion, or 43.25 percent, from the same time last year; electronic products rose US$1.3 billion, or 29.9 percent; and electrical equipment jumped US$610 million, or 72.32 percent.

Orders for information and communications products amounted to US$5.63 billion; electronic products amounted to US$5.64 billion; textile products amounted to US$1.05 billion; basic metals amounted to US$1.78 billion; plastic and rubber products amounted to US$1.21 billion; precision instruments amounted to U$1.61 billion; and electrical products amounted to US$1.46 billion.

Orders from the United States totalled US$6.49 billion in November, up US$920 million, or 16.58 percent, from the same time last year. Those from Hong Kong, including China, totalled US$5.73 billion, up US$1.23 billion, or 27.25 percent, year-on-year. Those from Japan totalled US$2.81 billion, up US$670 million, or 31.47 percent, year-on-year. Those from Europe totalled US$4.6 billion, up US$1.07 billion, or 30.43 percent, year-on-year.

According to MOEA officials, 21.64 percent of the exporters surveyed by the ministry expect export orders to further increase in December, 48.38 percent expect the amount to be similar to that of November, and 29.98 percent said the orders will decrease.
They said export orders for the whole of 2005 are expected to increase approximately 20 percent from last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: THINK TANK SEES OPPORTUNITY FOR CHIP INDUSTRY IN SOLAR CELLS

TEXT.P: If the chip-making industry can integrate solar energy to produce highly efficient solar cells, it will help Taiwan reduce its dependency on imported energy, according to a think tank.

Chang Chien-yi, a department director of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER) , said the production process involved in developing low-cost solar cells have many common features as in semiconductor production; in fact, some solar cell manufacturers are studying how to use new chips and related technology to lower production costs.
Therefore, solar energy production can be a new business opportunity for the chip industry, he added.

If the chip-making industry can work well with the "green" energy sector, it will not only open up a new horizon for the industry but also create a great benefit for Taiwan, which is 99 percent reliant on imported crude oil, Chang said.

In a recent report forecasting the industrial trends from now until 2015, TIER said memory chip and computer platform industries seem to be on the decline, whereas bio-tech and Chinese medical equipment are seen as potential areas for growth.
Looking at the coming 10 years, Chang said special attention should be paid to the potential room for development of the semiconductor manufacturing industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: RE-ELECTED CHIEF OF ROC'S SMALLEST TOWNSHIP OFFICIALLY TAKES OFFICE

TEXT.P: The re-elected chief of the smallest township of the Republic of China on Taiwan, who defeated his opponent by a single vote in the Dec. 3 election, received his certificate of election Friday.
Tsai Yuan-cheng, the new head of Wuchiu township, won a second term after he received 157 votes in the election against 156 votes for the other candidate, Chen Hsin-kuo.

Wuchiu township, an administrative area of Kinmen County, is composed of two small islets named Tachiu and Hsiaochiu, totalling 2.6 square kilometers in area. The two islets are located 72 nautical miles northeast of Kinmen Island.
The household registry shows that the township has a population of 500 people, but actually only 50 of them are long-term residents because the others are making a living elsewhere.
Tsai said his priority is to build a wharf on each of the two islets and develop tourism in the same way as Kinmen, so that the township will no longer be so isolated.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION GOING AGAINST THE WILL OF THE PEOPLE ON ARMS BILL: HSIEH
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 23 (CNA) (By Taijing Wu and Mark Wolfe)

TEXT.P: The opposition's vote Friday to end a meeting to discuss the controversial arms bill before it had really even begun goes against the wishes of the electorate and is damaging the efficacy of the legislative body, Premier Frank Hsieh said Friday.

The "green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the Taiwan Solidarity Union pushed the U.S. arms procurement bill through the Procedures Committee Tuesday by virtue of the fact that many opposition lawmakers were attending a different meeting, thus relinquishing their majority.

Since the regulations say that the bill under consideration should be reviewed on the specific day requested, in this case Friday only, the opposition "pan-blue alliance" rallied its forces to the plenary session to make sure that no actual discussions took place.

Lawmakers from the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) proposed that the meeting be dismissed shortly after it started. A vote was taken and the "pan-blue alliance" easily had the meeting ended by a vote of 113 to 100.

Premier Hsieh pointed out that the "pan-blue alliance" had the numbers to first discuss the bill and then vote it down Friday if they had wanted, regardless of what was said during the session, but instead they simply pulled the plug on the whole meeting.

"The legislators in the majority could have easily just voted down the bill, but they chose to cut off discussions of it altogether. This must have been because they know that the public supports the bill and it seems like the opposition was being pressured by an invisible hand," Hsieh said.
Hsieh was referring to a Ministry of National Defense poll released the previous day that indicated that about 70 percent of respondents were in favor of having the bill discussed in the legislature.

The survey also showed that almost 53 percent of the people support the country acquiring the three defense items at issue. The current version of the bill includes eight conventional diesel-electric submarines, 12 P-3C submarine-hunting aircraft and six PAC-3 Patriot anti-missile systems from the United States.
The request for the weapons began in the mid-1990s, when the KMT had ruling power. The U.S. government agreed to the arms package in April 2001.

Cho Jung-tai, a spokesman for the Executive Yuan, said that the leaders of the "pan-blue alliance," KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and PFP Chairman James Soong, are misrepresenting the will of the people by their party's actions.

"The two leaders of the opposition met twice to talk on a number of issues, including the arms bill. The result of all this seems to run counter to the will of the people. The executive branch regrets that this is the way that they want to deal with the issue, " Cho said.

Defending the day's events, Legislative speaker Wang Jin-pyng said that the meeting was ended entirely within the bounds of normal procedure, adding that other sessions in the past had been abruptly ended as well.

Since ending the session effectively sends the bill back to the Procedures Committee, which then must again vote whether to put the bill back on the legislature's agenda for discussion, the arms package is no closer to becoming law than it was over a year ago.
The opposition-dominated Procedures Committee will meet again in four days on Dec. 27.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S CONCERN SHOWS IN TSUNAMI-AFFECTED AREAS IN SOUTH ASIA

TEXT.P: The Red Cross Society of the Republic of China said on Friday that it has put the donations it collected for tsunami relief for South Asia to good use, including a clean water program in Indonesia and a housing reconstruction program in Sri Lanka.
Society officials made the comments in a new conference to report on their relief work as the first anniversary of the killer tsunami approaches on Dec. 26.
The officials said that the society has collected NT$730 million (US$21.79 million) in donations for tsunami relief and that about 97 percent of the money has been earmarked for various projects.
In the next three to five years, the society will promote employment, housing reconstruction and disaster prevention centers in the affected areas.
Society president C.V. Chen said that in view of the unprecedented disaster, the reconstruction work in the affected areas has been proceeding slowly.
Taiwan experienced a massive 7.6 earthquake on Sept. 21, 1999 and knows all too well the feeling of having come through a natural disaster, Chen said.

To help residents in the tsunami-affected areas return to a normal life soon, the Red Cross Society is working on a clean water program in Aceh province in Indonesia, and working with the Buddhist group Dharma Drum Mountain Culture and Education Foundation to build a "Taiwan village" in Sri Lanka.
The first housing complex in the "Taiwan village" was completed in September and has 300 low-income households. It will also build 550 fishing boats.

Hau Lung-bin, secretary-general of the Red Cross Society, also said that the donations from 200,000 people in Taiwan has shown the world that Taiwan is a country that appreciates the kindness it was shown during the Sept. 21, 1999 earthquake and wants to reciprocate.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ENGLISH EDITION OF PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE WEB SITE DEBUTS

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office Friday launched the new and upgraded English version of its Web site at www.president.gov.tw/en.

The new version introduces new sections, including Take a Closer Look at Taiwan, a column translated from the Chinese version, as well as National Vision, National Statistics, Taiwan Directory, Art Gallery, and Tour of the Office of the President and Taipei Guest House.

The home page features images of the presidential building, the office's emblem and the national flag. Besides, images featuring the country's five major festivals -- New Year, Lunar New Year, Dragon Boat Festival, Mid-Autumn Festival and National Day -- will serve to give character to the Web site to highlight Taiwan's unique traditions and customs, according to the office's department of public affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONCE TRAMPLED, TAIWAN IDENTITY WILL BEGIN TO FLOURISH: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Friday deplored the legacy of the Chinese Nationalists, who he claimed were "against democracy and intellectualism, " and said that identification with Taiwan will become deeply rooted in the country over time.
As Taiwan identity grows, it is imperative for the government and people to "actively carry out the spirit of constitutional democracy and to maintain social unity," he said.

Meeting a group of presidential advisers over lunch, Chen said that after the Chinese Nationalist Party or Kuomintang (KMT) lost power in 2000, some people were speaking ill of Taiwan's prospects; and after the KMT lost another presidential election in 2004, voices again appeared that were more in favor of China than of Taiwan.
Those who try to forsake Taiwan suggest their strenuous effort in resisting Taiwan identity, he warned.
Under the jackboot of martial law rule, Taiwan's national identity was clouded as being impractical and was misdirected by the illusory concept of a "greater China," Chen said.
With the progress of the nation's democratization, he noted, people in Taiwan have gradually come to embrace a Taiwan identity that is different from their previous "greater China identity."

He cited a long-term study as saying that in 1996, 41 percent of Taiwan's population thought "this country's territory covered Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu" while 42 percent thought that mainland China was part of their "national territory."
A similar study showed that in 1998, those two opinions were held by 65 percent and 27 percent, respectively; by 2003, the ratio had become 71 percent versus 14 percent, Chen said.

Another study found that in 1996, 73 percent of those polled in Taiwan said Taiwan residents alone have the right to decide their own future, whereas 13 percent said the 1.3 billion mainland Chinese also have the right to help in the decision. Those favoring the right of the Taiwanese to decide Taiwan's future grew to 81 percent in 1998, but still 13 percent thought mainland Chinese should take part in the decision-making.

It is the 13 percent that are worrying Chen. He said 13 percent of the public still insist on keeping their "old national identity" even though Taiwan identity has become a mainstream value in Taiwan.
However, he added, in a democracy, this minority view must be "tolerated and respected."

He said the wheel of history will not stop turning because a minority of the people are obsessed with their ideas of the past. He said he firmly believes Taiwan identity will keep growing while the "old national identity" -- the product of a heavy-handed rule -- will decline.

Because the "old national identity" was a government-inculcated, top-down product, Chen said he will never make the same mistake. Rather, he said, he favors a "healthy and land-linked national identity" which emanates from the heart of the people, from the feelings about and memories of their daily lives -- in short, a down-top process.
The president reiterated that his administration will never change the key policy of pro-actively promoting Taiwan identity.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FIRST NATIONAL WOMEN BASEBALL TOURNAMENT OPENS SATURDAY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's first national women's baseball competition -- the President Cup Women's National Baseball Tournament -- opens Saturday at the Hsinchuang Baseball Stadium in suburban Taipei.
Seven teams will compete in the five-day series, sponsored by the Chinese Taipei Baseball Association.
The seven teams will be divided into two groups in the initial round of the tourney, and the top two winners in each group will compete round-robin with the other teams.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S., CHINA AND VIETNAM LARGEST VEGETABLE EXPORTERS TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Vegetable and fruit imports to Taiwan amounted to near 700,000 tons in the first 11 months of this year, with the United States, China and Vietnam being the largest sources of the imports, according to statistics released Friday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

Around 311,000 tons of fresh, frozen and dried vegetables were imported to the island in the period from January to November, posing a year-on-year rise of 34.8 percent. Some 72,000 tons of the imports were cabbages, cauliflowers and broccoli while 64,000 tons were various dried beans.

The largest vegetable supplier was the U.S., which shipped 84,000 tons of vegetables to Taiwan in the 11-month period. China ranked the second-largest, and Vietnam third. The DGBAS said a significant year-on-year growth of 66.8 percent was recorded in terms of imports from Vietnam.

The import of fruits and nuts reached 388,000 tons during this period, posting a growth of 22.2 percent over the level of last year. Apples and pears took the lion's share of the imports with 130,000 tons, the tallies showed, noting that the U.S. was the largest source of the fruits and nuts, which shipped 145,000 tons to Taiwan from January to November.

DOC.HEADLINE: DETAINED TAIWANESE STUDENT FREED IN HONG KONG

TEXT.P: National Taiwan University (NTU) student Lee Chien-cheng, who protested against World Trade Organization (WTO) meetings in Hong Kong, was freed on bail Friday after a few days in detention and return to Taiwan in the evening.
Lee was among the 14 anti-WTO protesters from Taiwan, South Korea, Japan and China who were charged by Hong Kong law enforcement authorities after taking part in the WTO protests.

NTU President Lee Si-chen expressed his gratitude to the NTU alumni association president of Hong Kong who had written letters to the judge. Hong Kong's NTU alumni association communicated with Hong Kong legal authorities and sent food and clothes to the detained student.
NTU President Lee said that the NTU alumni association had a great influence over this case, which resulted in the NTU student being the only one to be allowed to leave Hong Kong.
Lee said that he is not sure whether the student really violated Hong Kong law, but he affirms the student's action in expressing his disagreement toward the WTO and his concern for society.
He added that it is normal for youngsters to act against authority.
The student will have to fly back to Hong Kong for trial on Dec. 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOVEMBER MANUFACTURING PRODUCTION INDEX HITS NEW HIGH

TEXT.P: Taiwan's manufacturing production index hit a new high of 144.41 in November, increasing 10.01 percent from the same time last year, the Ministry of Economic Affairs reported Friday.
The industrial production index was 140.80 in November, up 9.03 percent year-on-year.

For the 11 months to November, the industrial production index posted 130.09, up 2.75 percent from the same period last year. The manufacturing production index register 132.78, up 2.49 percent year-on-year.

In addition to the 10.01 percent increase seen in the manufacturing sector, the production of the water, electrical power and fuel sector rose 5.27 percent in November. However, the production of the mining and quarry sector dropped 14.26 percent, and that of construction sector fell 8.27 percent.

Of the manufacturing sector, the production of the information technology and electronics industries increased 22.3 percent in November from the same time last year; that of the chemical industry rose 5.6 percent; and that of metals and mechanical industries decreased 2.01 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: COUNTY, CITY CHIEFS SUPPORT "VIOLENCE-FREE CAMPUSES' CAMPAIGN

TEXT.P: Administrators of 21 counties and cities around the country all gave their full support Friday to a campaign launched by a group of non-governmental organizations to build campuses with love, instead of punishment.

The county and city chiefs, led by Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, endorsed a statement, titled "Campuses Of Love, No Violence, " for the campaign, according to a news release from the 21st Century Education Association, one of the civilian groups dedicated to the promotion of love-based education.

The administrators promised to make efforts during their tenures to persuade teachers to imbue their students with love, instead with the whip, and to guide their students to learn in a positive and active manner, the news release said.

DOC.HEADLINE: EU PRINCIPLES APPLICABLE TO CROSS-STRAIT TIES: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday that the four key principles observed in the integration of the European Union can be followed in the development of relations across the Taiwan Strait.
Chen made the remarks while hosting a luncheon at Taipei Guest House in honor of all Presidential Office advisers.

Echoing a proposal by former Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Chen Ming-tong that EU-style integration can provide inspiration for future development of cross-strait relations, President Chen said the four principles adopted in the process of EU integration -- sovereignty, parity, democracy and peace -- can be applied to resolving cross-strait disputes and problems.
First of all, Chen said EU countries respect each other as independent sovereign states. This principle allows EU member states to integrate to the extent that they have reached today.

Second, Chen said, all EU member states, regardless of their size, treat each other in line with the principles of parity and equality. None of them denigrate any other member state as a local government, he added.
Third, Chen said, the principle of democracy and free will should be respected in cross-strait engagements.
Fourth, Chen said, any cross-strait disputes should be resolved only by peaceful means.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: With Deal Reached, Normal Commutes Return
Thousands of New York City transit workers put down their picket signs and streamed into bus depots and railyards last night to restart the nation's largest transit system, after leaders of their union agreed to a tentative framework for a new contract and ended a 60-hour strike that hobbled the city. Transit officials said they expected the system to come haltingly back to life last night but be running at nearly full capacity by this morning's rush. Despite the end of the strike, a final settlement of the dispute remains to be reached. But officials hinted that in exchange for the union's ending the strike, the authority would significantly scale back or even abandon its insistence on less-generous pensions for future workers. In return, the union would consider having its members pay more for health insurance.
Wall Street Journal: Second Opinion, Study Tied Pollutant to Cancer; Then Consultants Got Hold of It
During China's Cultural Revolution 40 years ago, a city doctor named Zhang JianDong was banished to the countryside of northeastern China. He found that a giant smelter was spilling large amounts of chromium waste into the groundwater. After spending the next two decades treating and studying the residents of five villages with chromium-polluted water. In 1987, he published a study saying they were dying of cancer at higher rates than people nearby. In America, regulatory agencies began citing it as evidence that a form of the metal called chromium-6 might cause cancer if ingested. Then in 1997, Dr. Zhang, in retirement, appeared to retract his life's work. A " clarification and further analysis" published under his name in a U.S. medical journal said there was no cancer link to chromium in the villages after all. This new conclusion, like the earlier one, soon found its way into U.S. regulatory assessments, as evidence that ingested chromium wasn't really a cancer risk. Yet Dr. Zhang didn't write the clarification, judging by voluminous testimony and exhibits in a lawsuit in a California state court. The court papers indicate that the second study was conceived, drafted, edited and submitted to medical journals by science consultants working for the lawsuit's defendant, a utility company being sued for alleged chromium pollution. Regulators in California after investigating the second Zhang report, have concluded it is dubious. They have reverted to the original dark view of chromium-6 and are moving to propose a strict limit on it in ground water. The action could ultimately require a costly cleanup, because a third of wells tested in the state exceed the envisioned limit. Costs would grow if other states followed California's lead.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR DECEMBER 24 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Saturday, December 24:
09:10, Premier Frank Hsieh will attend an athletic meet at the Taipei Track and Field Stadium to mark the 88th anniversary of National Taipei College of Business.
13:20, President Chen Shui-bian will attend a children's party to be held at the Presidential Office to mark the end of the year.
15:00, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou will attend an activity at Taipei Fine Arts Museum to mark the museum's founding anniversary.
19:00, Acting Kaohsiung Mayor Yeh Chu-lan will attend a Christmas concert to be held at the plaza in front of the Kaohsiung City Concert Hall.

DOC.HEADLINE: DETAINED NTU STUDENT RETURNS HOME

TEXT.P: Lee Chien-cheng, a National Taiwan University (NTU) student who had been detained in Hong Kong on illegal assembly charges returned to Taiwan late Friday after being freed on bail earlier the same day.

Lee, accompanied by his father, arrived at Kaohsiung International Airport in southern Taiwan around 10 p.m. He was under heavy policy escort to avoid media exposure. His father thanked local people for their concern about Lee's situation. They were quickly whisked away in a taxi.
NTU authorities asked the media to refrain from bothering Lee as he is on bail in court proceedings. Lee is required to fly back to Hong Kong Dec. 30 for trial.

Lee was among the 14 anti-World Trade Organization (WTO) protesters who were charged by Hong Kong law enforcement authorities over holding an illegal sit-in on a major thoroughfare after violent riots last weekend.

Lee, a senior at the NTU's Department of Political Science, was released on a HK$2,500 (US$320) bail. As he was allowed to return to Taiwan for exams, he was required to have a guarantor pay a cash surety of HK$100,000 on his behalf, in addition to bail.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Dec. 24, or the 24th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past.
1491: Ignatius Loyola, Spanish founder of the Jesuit order, is born.
1524: Vasco da Gama, the Portuguese explorer who discovered the sea route to India around the Cape of Good Hope, dies.
1814: The War of 1812 between Britain and the United States ends with the signing of the Treaty of Ghent.
1851: Fire destroys part of the Capitol building in Washington, D.C., and the whole of the Library of Congress.
1905: Howard Hughes, American billionaire industrialist and film producer, is born.
1908: French President Armand Fallieres opens the first international aviation show in Paris.
1914: The first German bomb lands on British soil.
1919: Wealthy U.S. merchant John D. Rockefeller donates US$100 million for charitable use.
1921: Mahatma Gandhi is sworn in as chairman of India's Congress (I) Party, on a platform of non-cooperation.
1937: Japanese forces capture Hangchow in eastern China.
1943: President Roosevelt appoints Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower as supreme commander of the Allied Expeditionary Force preparing for the invasion of France.
1945: Pope Pius XII promotes Republic of China Bishop Tien Keng-hsin of Chingtao to cardinal, making him the first cardinal in East Asia.
1951: Libya declares independence.
1967: Communist China conducts its seventh nuclear test, detonating a small device in northeastern China.
1976: Takeo Fukuda organizes a new Japanese Cabinet.

He should be diligent in virtue and learning in order to profit from their lessons and example. In this way, he may become a man of real culture."

DOC.HEADLINE: 2006 JOBLESS RATE TO FALL BELOW 4 PERCENT: CEPD

TEXT.P: Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) officials expressed confidence Saturday that Taiwan's unemployment rate will decline below 4 percent in 2006.

The unemployment rate for the 11 months to November this year registered 4.15 percent, and that for the whole of 2005 is estimated at 4.1 percent, according to the Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics.
CEPD officials said although the unemployment rate is unlikely to fall below 4 percent this year, it is expected to continue to fall with the help of the government's measures to promote employment.
They pointed out that 9.93 million people were employed from January to November this year, up 157,000 from the same period last year.

Compared with the same time last year, the percentage of employed people in the agricultural sector decreased to 5.97 percent; that of the industrial sector increased to 35.76 percent; and that of the service sector rose to 58.26 percent, they noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION LEADERS EXPRESS CONDOLENCES TO CHINA'S LATE NEGOTIATOR

TEXT.P: The chairmen of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) expressed their condolences to the family of Wang Daohan, China's top negotiator with Taiwan, Saturday.

Both KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and PFP Chairman James Soong paid tribute after China's official Xinhua News Agency confirmed that Wang, chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), died in a Shanghai hospital at the age of 90 earlier in the day.

Ma said Wang played a pivotal role in the development of cross-strait relations, adding that with his "mild, rational and creative temperament, " he helped bring bilateral relations to a peak with his meeting with C.F. Koo, the late Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) chairman from Taiwan, in Singapore in 1993.

The Koo-Wang meeting was considered a major breakthrough in cross-strait relations as it marked the first high-ranking contact between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait since the KMT forces retreated to Taiwan nearly five decades earlier after being defeated by the Communist Party of China in a civil war in 1949.

The meeting opened up regular dialogues between the SEF and ARATS in the following years, although the communications between the two semi-official bodies came to a stop after former President Lee Teng-hui defined cross-strait relation as "special state-to-state" in nature in 1999.
Asked whether the KMT will send an envoy to attend the funeral of Wang, Ma said that the party is considering the matter and should do so.

PFP Chairman Soong expressed the hope that there will be others in China that carry the same weight as Wang, considered to be a mentor of former Chinese leader Jiang Zemin, who will be able to help promote bilateral relations.
Wang sent envoys to attend the funeral of Koo, who died in Jan. 3 this year three days before his 88th birthday.
Former KMT Chairman Lien Chan and Soong called on Wang during their visit to China early this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS

La Reppublica: Berlusconi confirms vote on April 9.
Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi confirmed Friday at his year-end news conference that the parliament would be dissolved on Jan. 29 to allow general elections on April 9. He confidently said that his center-rightist coalition will win the elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR MORE POPULAR THAN EVER: SURVEY

TEXT.P: After seven years in office, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou's performance rating remains high, with a survey released Saturday showing that 80 percent of the citizens in the capital support him.
The survey, conducted by the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission under the Taipei City Government Dec. 15-19, received 1,113 valid responses from Taipei citizens over 20 years of age.

Ma, who also serves as chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , is one of the most popular politicians in the KMT and is considered the party's most likely contender in the 2008 presidential race.

According to the survey, more than 70 percent of the respondents were satisfied with Ma's administrative performance, the quality of life, and the city government's efforts in protecting the environment, while about 60 percent were satisfied with cultural activities, social order and public construction projects.
It was the first time in a number of years that more than 80 percent of the respondents expressed satisfaction at the quality of life in Taipei City. The exact figure was 80.2 percent.

Ma's promotion of the EasyCard, which integrates transport fares including MRT, buses and parking fees, won him acclaim, followed by charging garbage fees to be based on plastic bags, a move that reduced waste and encouraged recycling, and the construction of a sewerage system.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF CHAIRMAN HOPES TO GO TO SHANGHAI TO ATTEND WANG'S FUNERAL

TEXT.P: Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chang Chun-hsiung has offered to visit Shanghai to pay his last respects to Wang Daohan, the late chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) , SEF officials said Saturday.
The SEF and ARATS are semi-official organizations set up by Taipei and Beijing, respectively, to handle cross-strait affairs in the absence of official ties.
ARATS notified SEF Saturday that Wang had passed away in Shanghai that morning, and the SEF later replied to extend its condolences on Wang's death, SEF officials said.
Meanwhile, Chang also sent a letter to Wang's son, Wang Yu, to offer to attend Wang's funeral, they said.
The heads of SEF and ARATS have traditionally acted as negotiators on behalf of their governments.

Chang's predecessor, Koo Chen-fu, who died in January this year, held ground-breaking talks with Wang in 1993 in Singapore, signing four agreements on cross-strait technical affairs and establishing an institutionalized channel of consultations between the two sides.

However, Beijing suspended the dialogue first in 1995 to protest against then-President Lee Teng-hui's U.S. visit and later in 1999 against Lee's remarks which defined cross-strait relations as those between two countries.
Beijing has not resumed the dialogue with Taipei during the past five years since the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party came to power.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Alito Urged Wiretap Immunity; Memo Offers Look at Nominee on Privacy.
Supreme Court nominee Samuel A. Alito Jr. once argued that the nation's top law enforcement official deserves blanket protection from lawsuits when acting in the name of national security, even when those actions involve the illegal wiretapping of American citizens, documents released yesterday show, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC EXPRESSES CONDOLENCE OVER DEATH OF CHINA'S CHIEF NEGOTIATOR

TEXT.P: Officials of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) on Saturday expressed condolence over the death of Wang Daohan, China's chief negotiator with Taiwan, who died earlier in the day.
Chinese authorities confirmed Saturday that Wang, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), died at 7:00 a.m. Saturday in Shanghai, at the age of 90.

Noting that with the death 11 months ago of Taiwan's chief negotiator with China, Koo Chen-fu, former chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , MAC officials said Wang's death on Saturday represented a further loss to both sides of Taiwan Strait.

Stressing that the negotiations framework laid by Koo and Wang is a fine asset for both sides of the Taiwan Strait, MAC officials urged Chinese authorities to fully understand the importance of cross-strait reconciliation and negotiations, and work more for peace and bilateral development across the Taiwan Strait in the future.
The SEF was founded in February 1991, and China followed suit by establishing ARATS in December of the same year, with Wang as president.
With concerted efforts, Koo and Wang had a historic meeting in Singapore in 1993 after a hiatus of formal contacts between Taiwan and China for more than four decades.

At the Singapore meeting, Koo and Wang signed four agreements, laying the framework for institutionalized negotiations between the two intermediary bodies and creating a new era for cross-strait negotiations on an equal footing.
In 1998, Koo and Wang met in China for more talks, which laid the framework for cross-strait reconciliation.
However, Beijing unilaterally cut the formal contacts between the two bodies in 1999, when then-ROC President Lee Teng-hui defined cross-strait ties as "state-to-state" relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA TO EXPAND GROWING OF BIOMASS CROPS IN 2006

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) has designated 2,000 hectares of fallow farmland for the growing of biomass crops including canola, soybeans and sunflowers next year, officials said Saturday.
The farmland will be located in Yunlin, Chiayi, Tainan, Kaohsiung and Pingtung, and the crops will be used for the production of biodiesel, they said.

While only 90 hectares of fallow farmland in Ilan, Yunlin and Tainan were selected this year to grow the crops on a trial basis, the COA decided to expand the size to 2,000 hectares next year after the trial was successful, they said.
They pointed out that farmers growing biomass crops will receive a subsidy of NT$60,000 per hectare from the government.

With approximately 240,000 hectares of fallow farmland available every year in Taiwan and international oil prices remaining high, it would be good if Taiwan could start developing alternative energy sources, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROFITS FOR STATE-RUN ENTERPRISES EXCEED NT$20 BILLION OVER 11 MONTHS

TEXT.P: Pre-tax profits for seven state-run enterprises amounted to NT$20.67 billion (US$623 million) over the past 11 months, far exceeding the target of NT$7.65 billion for the year, according tallies released by the Commission of National Corporations under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

Of the seven enterprises, Taiwan Power Co. had a profit of NT$3.59 billion; Chinese Petroleum Corp, NT$12.65 billion; Taiwan Sugar Corp., NT$2.62 billion; Taiwan Water Corp., NT$1.16 billion; China Shipbuilding Corp., NT$717 million; Tang Eng Iron Works Co., NT$1.16 billion.
The remaining enterprise -- Aerospace Industrial Development Corp. -- suffered a deficit of NT$1.22 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: PEOPLE WILL HAVE FINAL SAY ON CONSTITUTIONAL REFORMS: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The people will decide the direction constitutional reforms must take and the government has no preconceived notions on the matter, the director of the constitutional re-engineering office at the Presidential Office said Saturday.
Lee Chun-yi made the remarks after a civic group said that the current governmental system is so chaotic that it is seriously undermining the government's efficiency.
The 21st Century Constitutional Reform Alliance said that the future governmental system could be presidential or parliamentary, but it will vehemently oppose a dual-leadership system.
Lee said that the suggestions by the alliance are valuable and he encouraged others to come forward and make their voices heard as this is the best way to build a national consensus.
Although the ROC Constitution has been amended seven times since the lifting of martial law in 1987, many questions remain unresolved.

He cited as examples lawmakers' boycott of the reading of administrative reports by the premier in the Legislative Yuan, the long-stalled screening of nominations for Control Yuan members, the opposition party's proposal to revive the right to endorse the premier who has been appointed by the president, and the ruling party's proposal that the president should take the initiative to dissolve the legislature if the opposition's boycotting renders it ineffective.

The nature of the system of government is crucial and must be addressed in the next phase of constitutional reforms; however, Lee stressed that the administration does not have a hidden agenda as to what sort of result should come out of these reforms. This, he said, will be at the discretion of the people.

Whether to adopt a three-branch or five-branch governmental system, a presidential or parliamentary system, or to move toward a dual leadership system that clearly defines the rights and responsibilities of the two leaders will be up to the people to decide, Lee added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO POWERFUL NATIONAL DEFENSE, NO STABLE CROSS-STRAIT TIES: DPP CAUCUS

TEXT.P: Taiwan must have a credible defense or there will be no stability in cross-Taiwan Strait ties, a high-ranking ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) official said Saturday.

Chen Chin-jun, a caucus leader of DPP in the legislature, made the remarks after the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) on Friday again blocked the screening of the arms procurement package from the United States, which was put on the legislative agenda several days ago.

The arms procurement package, which has been prevented from even being discussed in the legislature 42 times by the "pan-blue alliance, " includes eight diesel-electric submarines, a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft and six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries.
Although the pursuit of stable cross-strait ties has been the DPP's long-term goal, the relations between the two sides have not been largely controlled by Taiwan, Chen noted.

For example, Chen added, Taiwan's proposal of giving marine transportation precedence over air links between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, with cargo shipments coming before passenger transportation, has not received a positive response from China, not to mention the numerous Chinese overtures that have been aimed at downgrading Taiwan to a Chinese local government.

With China's enactment of the Anti-Secession Law earlier this year, which legalizes an attack on Taiwan should the island seek formal independence, Chen said it indicated a certain level of hostility in China toward Taiwan.

Under the circumstances, if Taiwan does not maintain a powerful deterrent force, there will be no stable cross-strait ties, Chen stressed, urging the "pan-blue alliance" to support the arms purchase bill.

Meanwhile, PFP Chairman James Soong and Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, who is a KMT member, met earlier in the day to discuss politics, including the arms procurement bill and the possible formation of a joint Cabinet.
Both Soong and Wang believe maintaining stable cross-strait relations is the key issue that affects Taiwan's political stability and its economic development.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CELEBRATES CHRISTMAS EVE WITH CHILDREN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian invited hundreds of school children to the Presidential Office Saturday to celebrate Christmas.
The Christmas eve party took place at the Presidential Office courtyard which was decorated with colorful Christmas trees, lights, wreaths, ribbons and many other festive items.
In a brief speech, President Chen offered his best wishes to all children around the country. He then placed a giant string of tinfoil stars on a Christmas tree to add fanfare to the gathering.

Chen also demonstrated his turkey-cutting skills, wrote the Chinese words "peace and felicity" on a giant-size traditional snack known as a "sun cake, " painted gingerbread Christmas trees and made chocolate-coated fruit bars to entertain the kids.
Since assuming office, Chen has invited children each Christmas eve to the Presidential Office to show his love and concern for the nation's younger generation.

DOC.HEADLINE: WANG DAOHAN'S DEATH WILL NOT AFFECT CROSS-STRAIT TIES: EXPERT
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Dec. 24 (CNA) (By Chou Hui-ying and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The death of Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) President Wang Daohan symbolizes the end of a generation but will not mean any changes in present or future cross-strait relations, a Chinese scholar said Saturday.

Wang died Saturday morning in Shanghai, more than 11 months after that of Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation. As leaders of the semi-official organizations set up by Beijing and Taipei, respectively, to handle cross-strait affairs in the absence of official ties, Wang and Koo acted as chief negotiators on behalf of their governments and held ground-breaking talks in 1993 in Singapore.

Wang Jianmin, a research fellow on Taiwan studies at the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, said the function of ARATS will not change because of Wang's death and that the organization remains Beijing's contact with Taipei.

"The Koo-Wang talks were something that happened many years ago, and Wang can be said to be a figure of a past generation, " he said. "His death will not affect cross-strait relations at present or in the future."
As for Wang's successor, the scholar predicted that it will take some time for Beijing to find a successor because it is not easy to find someone who has the qualifications Wang possessed.
Zao Zhizhou, another Chinese scholar specializing in Taiwan studies, said Wang's successor must be someone who enjoys high esteem and has the ability to deal with cross-strait issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING NOT IN A HURRY TO NAME NEW ARATS HEAD: EXPERT

TEXT.P: China is not in a hurry to look for a successor for Wang Daohan, who as chairman of the semi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) acted as Beijing's chief negotiator with Taipei, in light of the interruption of cross-strait dialogue at present, a Chinese scholar said Saturday.
Wang died Saturday morning in Shanghai, more than 11 months after the death of Koo Chen-fu, Wang's counterpart from the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation.

Yang Jian, deputy secretary-general of the Center for Taiwan Studies at the Shanghai Academy of Social Sciences, said Beijing is not likely to make a quick decision on the choice of Wang's successor, as the operations of ARATS are mainly taken care of by its deputy chairman, Li Bingcai.

If Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government adopts a pragmatic attitude on its cross-strait policy, the dialogue between SEF and ARATS may be resumed before the 2008 presidential election, Yang said, adding that only then will Beijing start to consider naming a new ARATS chairman.

According to Yang, cross-strait disagreements over the "one China" principle and the "1992 consensus" remain the main obstacles to the resumption of cross-strait dialogue, and whether the deadlock will be broken will depend on whether the DPP government will make any compromises on these issues.
Yang said the next ARATS chairman should be someone who is devoted to cross-strait affairs and who has good understanding of international and cross-strait situations.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LAWMAKER ANNOUNCES BID TO RUN FOR KAOHSIUNG MAYOR

TEXT.P: Legislator Huang Chao-shun of the main opposition Kuomintang announced on Saturday her bid to run in the Kaohsiung mayoral election in late 2006.

Huang has become the first to publicly announce her bid for the head of the second-largest city in Taiwan. Huang, a three-time Kaohsiung City councilor and has served as a legislator for three consecutive terms, said her campaign theme will be to build a maritime city of "health and integrity."
She will soon release a white paper on city affairs and establish a city affairs monitoring committee.

Huang noted that the scandal surrounding the mass rapid transit construction project and the repeated construction incidents have dealt a blow to the image of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party as well as the dignity of Kaohsiung residents.
Huang, who graduated from Kaohsiung Medical University, said this is why she wants to focus on a healthy city with the priority on clean air and water as well as smooth traffic and social order.
She also said that integrity is the bottom line of a civil servant and her motto during her 23 years in politics.

As several KMT members have shown an interest in running for Kaohsiung mayor, the party will have to decide on the final candidate either through coordination or through a primary, which will also include a public opinion poll.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO DEFINITE WORD ON SEF CHIEF ATTENDING WANG DAOHAN'S FUNERAL
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Dec. 24 (CNA) (By Chou Hui-ying and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: China is studying the offer by Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chang Chun-hsiung to visit Shanghai to pay his last respects to Wang Daohan, the late president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).
Wang passed away early Saturday in a Shanghai hospital at the age of 90.

In addition to Chang, main opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou also expressed the hope to send envoys to attend Wang's funeral, but officials from Beijing's Taiwan Affairs Office of the State Council only responded by saying that they would have to "ask ARATS."
Meanwhile, in Taipei, opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong is "studying cautiously" whether to attend Wang's funeral, his aides said.

They cited Soong as saying that over the past dozen years, the relations between both sides of the Taiwan Strait were the smoothest between 1992 and 1993, when Wang and Koo Chen-fu, Chang's predecessor, played pivotal roles in the communications between the two sides.
The SEF and ARATS are quasi-official organizations set up by Taipei and Beijing, respectively, to handle cross-strait affairs in the absence of official ties.

Soong thinks that after the passing of Koo and Wang, cross-strait relations will face the challenge of the new era, and he hopes that a pragmatic communication platform will be established soon to stabilize cross-strait relations, the aides said.

Koo and Wang held ground-breaking talks in 1993 in Singapore, reaching agreements on cross-strait technical affairs and establishing an institutionalized channel of consultations between the two sides.

However, Beijing unilaterally suspended the dialogue channel to pretest against then-President Lee Teng-hui's remarks in 1999 that cross-strait relations are "special state-to-state" in nature. The dialogue channel has yet to be resumed.
Senior officials from ARATS arrived in Taipei early this year to attend a memorial service for Koo, who died on Jan. 3.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP AND MAJOR POLITICIANS AFFIRM WANG DAOHAN'S CONTRIBUTIONS

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Saturday expressed its condolence over the death of Wang Daohan, China's chief negotiator with Taiwan, while affirming his contributions in maintaining peace across the Taiwan Strait.
Wang, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) , died at 7: 00 a.m. Saturday in Shanghai at the age of 90.
In a news release, the DPP hailed Wang for promoting cross-strait negotiations and exchanges by setting aside the controversial disputes between the two sides.

After the historic meeting between Wang and Koo Chen-fu, former chairman of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , in Singapore in 1993, the first of its kind after a hiatus of formal contacts between Taiwan and China for more than four decades, Wang maintained a positive attitude toward Taiwan's democratic development and respected the island's diverse opinions, according to the release.

At the Singapore meeting, Koo and Wang signed four agreements, laying the framework for institutionalized negotiations between the two intermediary bodies and creating a new era for cross-strait negotiations on an equal footing.
In 1998, Koo and Wang met in China for more talks, which laid the framework for cross-strait reconciliation.
However, Beijing unilaterally cut the formal contacts between the two bodies in 1999, when then-ROC President Lee Teng-hui defined cross-strait ties as "state-to-state" relations.

The DPP hopes that there will be someone like Wang from ARATS to work with the SEF in the future to contribute to the peace, stability and welfare of the people between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, the release added.

Meanwhile, several opposition Kuomintang (KMT) figures, including KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and honorary Chairman Lien Chan, as well as family members of Koo, who passed away in January this year, all expressed their condolences over Wang's death.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONTROL YUAN GRIDLOCK MAY BE RESOLVED: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER

TEXT.P: The issue regarding the Control Yuan lineup may be addressed in the next legislative session as President Chen Shui-bian plans to come up with a new nomination list, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng predicted optimistically Saturday.
Wang, an opposition Kuomintang (KMT) heavyweight, made the remarks after a closed-door meeting with James Soong, chairman of the KMT's "pan-blue" ally -- the People First Party (PFP).
Under the current ROC Constitution, Control Yuan members are appointed by the president with the consent of the Legislative Yuan.

President Chen referred a list of Control Yuan nominees to the legislature in November 2004. The opposition-controlled legislature had refused to review it. As a result, the nation's supreme watchdog body has been standing empty since the tenure of previous Control Yuan members expired early this year.

There were reports earlier this week that the two "pan-blue" parties had a new proposal for the Control Yuan makeup. They reportedly suggested that the Control Yuan seats be filled up with a formula adopted in the formation of the National Communications Commission (NCC) , under which political parties first recommend celebrities to form a screening committee to review Control Yuan nominees to be put forward by political parties in proportion to their representation in the legislature.
However, Wang said PFP Chairman Soong told him during their meeting earlier in the day that the NCC formula proposal was broached by KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou.
Wang said both he and Soong agreed that the president's Constitution-enshrined power to nominate Control Yuan members should be respected and observed.

"Since the Constitution has clear provisions for Control Yuan nominations, it's unrealistic to demand the enforcement of an NCC-formula. What Soong and I advocate is that the president draws inspiration from the NCC spirit and handle Control Yuan nomination through a just and transparent mechanism," Wang explained.
To the best of his understanding, Wang said President Chen is mulling to refer a new Control Yuan nomination list to the legislature for approval.
"I think the legislature is likely to deal with the Control Yuan nomination issue during its next session to be opened in February, " he added.

Wang said he met with President Chen for one and a half hours a week ago to exchange views on a range of critical policy issues, including relations across the Taiwan Strait, the Control Yuan nomination issue and the long-stalled arms procurement project.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER LOOKS FORWARD TO ATTENDING WANG'S FUNERAL

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Saturday if opportunity presents itself, he will be more than willing to travel to Shanghai to attend the funeral of China's top negotiator with Taiwan on behalf of the government.

Wang made the remarks after learning that Wang Daohan, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), died in a Shanghai hospital early Saturday at the age of 90.
Asked whether he is likely to pay the last tribute of respect to Wang Daohan on behalf of the Republic of China government, Wang Jin-pyng said this is a good idea.
"If I can go there on behalf of the government, it would be a plus to the development of cross-strait relations, " the legislative speaker said.

Wang Daohan, a one-time Shanghai mayor and mentor to former Chinese President and Communist Party chief Jiang Zemin, was instrumental in starting rapprochement between China and Taiwan -- political rivals since the end of the Chinese civil war in 1949 -- in the early 1990s.

He and Koo Chen-fu, the late chairman of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), held landmark talks in Singapore in 1993, after Beijing and Taipei agreed to their own interpretations of the "one China" principle in what is known as the 1992 consensus.

Koo died of cancer this past January at the age of 87. ARATS sent a contingent to Koo's funeral earlier this year. Koo's successor Chang Chun-hsiung said he hopes to attend Wang's funeral if Wang's family allows.

"We express deep condolences on the death of Wang Daohan, especially since Wang did all he could to improve cross-straits relations and boost exchanges across the Strait. We deeply regret his death," Chang said.
SEF and ARATS are quasi-official organizations authorized by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Dec. 26, or the 26th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1792: Charles Babbage, British mathematician and inventor of the first computer, is born.
1797: John Wilkes, British political reformer noted for his published attacks on George III and for his support of the rights of American colonists, dies at the age of 70.
1890: Heinrich Schliemann, the German archaeologist who discovered the ruins of ancient Troy and excavated Mycenae, dies in Naples, Italy, at the age of 58.
1893: Mao Zedong, chairman of the Chinese Communist Party who proclaimed the establishment of the People's Republic of China in 1949, is born in Hunan Province.
1908: American boxer Jack Johnson defeats world heavyweight champion Tommy Burns at Rushcutter's Bay in Sydney, Australia, with a dazzling display of fighting skills, becoming the first black boxer to win the title.
1912: Mackay Memorial Hospital is inaugurated in Taipei.
1914: The United States pays back the remainder of a large sum of indemnities, totaling $11 million, that China was forced to pay in the signing of the Treaty of Peking in 1901.
1916: Tsai Yuan-pei becomes president of National Peking University.
1938: Chiang Kai-shek reiterates China's determination to carry on the war of resistance against Japan and charges that a recent statement by Japanese Prime Minister Prince Fumimaro Konoye clearly reveals Japan's intention to conquer China.
1941: The Unites States declares Manila an open city as Japanese forces approach.
1943: The British Royal Navy sinks the mighty German battle cruiser Scharnhosrt, making the sea lanes of the North Sea safer for Allied convoys.
1971: Sixteen U.S. veterans of the Vietnam War seize the Statue of Liberty in New York harbor to dramatize their anti-war stance.
1972: The Association of East Asian Relations of the Republic of China and the Interchange Association of Japan sign an agreement in Taipei to establish offices in each other's country.
1972: Harry S. Truman, U.S. president between 1945-53, dies in Kansas City at the age of 88.
1974: Hironori Ito, former director of the Taipei Office of the Japanese Interchange Association, returns to Japan for a new assignment.
1975: The Legislative Yuan passes the Radio and Television Act.
1976: The 11th Convention of the Committee on Constitutional Research of the National Assembly opens at the Taipei City Auditorium.
1976: A two-day discussion on the electronic calculator opens at National Taiwan University.
1985: The Futehkeng landfill formally opens in Mucha, Taipei.
1989: Nobel Prize-winning Irish dramatist Samuel Beckett dies in Paris at the age of 83.
1999: Vice President Lien Chan chooses the Taiwan black bear as the one animal most representative of wildlife indigenous to Taiwan.
1999: The China Democracy Party, banned by Beijing a year earlier, issues a bold call to end one-party rule, challenging both the Communist Party's constitutional hold on supreme power and the Beijing regime's threat to use force to reunify Taiwan.
2000: Kuomintang heavyweight John Chang says in Xiamen that the purpose of his ongoing visit in mainland China is to promote the development of Taiwan-funded companies and to establish a bridge of communication with related mainland officials.
2000: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung presides over the inaugural ceremony of an administrative coordination center on the frontline island of Kinmen for managing affairs related to the "mini three links."
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A gentleman never competes in anything he does, except perhaps in archery. But even then, when he wins he courteously makes his bow before he advances to take his place among the winners; and, when he has lost, he walks down and drinks his cup of forfeit. Thus, even in this case of competition, he shows himself to be a gentleman."

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICERS REPORTEDLY PLANNING TO QUIT KMT OVER STALLED ARMS BILL

TEXT.P: An unknown number of military officers have reportedly written a letter to the Ministry of National Defense saying that they are planning to quit the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) in anger over the long-stalled arms procurement bill, local newspapers reported Monday.

Lawmakers of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and People First Party, which together hold a slight majority in the Legislative Yuan, have blocked the bill from being put on the legislature's agenda for over a year.

KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Monday morning that he has read the reports about the letter and has also heard that the letter to the defense ministry carried no signatures. Ma said he will gain a better understanding of the matter before making any further comment.
Ma, who doubles as Taipei mayor, said that the KMT has made its stance on the arms procurement bill very clear, stressing that Taiwan needs to maintain sufficient military strength to defend itself.

The Ministry of National Defense submitted the bill for the purchase of six Patriot III anti-missile batteries, eight conventional submarines and 12 P-3C Orion submarine-hunting aircraft from the United States to the Legislative Yuan last year. The initial price tag was NT$610.8 billion, but the ministry later reduced it to NT$480 billion after the opposition lawmakers rejected the bill.
Noting that the KMT has never objected to arms procurement, Ma said that the KMT is opposed to "cash-for-friendship" purchase plans or "unreasonable" procurement plans.

"No military members, regardless of their political affiliation, should support an arms procurement bill if it is not drafted based on professional assessments and if it cannot genuinely meet Taiwan's defense needs," Ma said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND RESPECTS SERVICEMEMBERS' 'PERSONAL' DECISIONS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) said Monday it has no opinion about media reports that an unknown number of military officers are planning to quit the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) in anger over the long-stalled arms procurement bill.

Officials from the Military Spokesman's Office said that the military's stance of remaining neutral and firmly observing the nationalization of the armed forces in accordance with the Constitution definitely will not change.

Against this backdrop, they said, the defense ministry will respect any "personal" decisions that the military officers make and will not intervene in matters pertaining to any military servicemember's personal political affiliations.

They said that since the Republic of China armed forces was nationalized, no political activities have been allowed in the barracks, meaning that the defense ministry has maintained a hands-off attitude toward military servicemember's personal political stances.

The MND officials, however, lamented that lawmakers of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and People First Party, which together hold a slight majority in the Legislative Yuan, have blocked the arms procurement bill from being put on the legislature's agenda 42 times since last year.

Quoting a recent public opinion poll, the officials said that over half of the people support the arms procurement bill for the purchase of six Patriot III anti-missile batteries, eight diesel-powered submarines and 12 P-3C Orion submarine-hunting aircraft from the United States, and that more than 70 percent of the respondents think that the Legislative Yuan should debate and pass the bill as soon as possible.
Therefore, they said, the servicemember's alleged protest against the opposition "pan-blue alliance's" blocking of the bill is in line with mainstream public opinion.

KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Monday that the KMT sincerely hopes to communicate with those servicemembers who wrote the letter to the defense ministry in order to talk to them about their positions on the stalled arms procurement bill.

Ma noted, however, that the KMT has no way of contacting them because the letter did not contain any signatures. He added that they are welcomed to come forward and talk with KMT officials about their grievance.
Ma, who doubles as Taipei mayor, said that the KMT has made its stance on the arms procurement bill very clear, stressing that Taiwan needs to maintain sufficient military strength to defend itself.
Noting that the KMT has never objected to arms procurement, Ma said that the KMT is opposed to "cash-for-friendship" purchase plans or "unreasonable" procurement plans.

"No military members, regardless of their political affiliation, should support an arms procurement bill if it is not drafted based on professional assessments and if it cannot genuinely meet Taiwan's defense needs," Ma said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 22.14 points to close at 6,534.77.
The bourse opened at 6,565.67 and fluctuated between 6,573.97 and 6,530.76 during trading. A total of 4.48 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$110.99 billion (US$3.35 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 4.3 percent, followed by plastics and chemicals shares at 0.7 percent, textile stocks and paper and pulp issues both at 0.5 percent, and machinery and electronics shares and banking and financial shares both at 0.3 percent.
The two other major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff issues moving down at 0.8 percent and cement stocks losing 0.3 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 572 to 478, with 162 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP TO ORGANIZE GROUP TO ATTEND LATE ARATS HEAD'S FUNERAL IN SHANGHAI

TEXT.P: The opposition People First Party (PFP) will organize a group to visit Shanghai to pay the party's last respects to Wang Daohan, China's top cross-strait negotiator, who passed away Saturday at the age of 90, a PFP spokesman said Monday.

Hsieh Kung-ping said that it is still unclear whether PFP Chairman James Soong will personally lead the PFP delegation to Wang's funeral scheduled to be held at a funeral parlor in Shanghai Dec. 30. The decision will be made after consultations with Wang's family, Hsieh said.
Soong met with Wang at his Shanghai residence during a visit to China in May this year.
Members of the PFP delegation will also include several PFP legislators, Hsieh added.

Key figures of the Beijing leadership are expected to travel to Shanghai to attend the funeral for Wang, the late chairman of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), a quasi-official intermediary body responsible for negotiating with Taiwan in the absence of formal ties between the two sides. ARATS's Taiwan counterpart is the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF).

Both SEF Chairman Chang Chun-hsiung, a legislator-at-large of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, and Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, a stalwart of the opposition Kuomintang, have offered to visit Shanghai to pay their last respects to Wang Daohan, a senior Communist Party of China member who had been Shanghai mayor in the 1980s.

Chang's predecessor, Koo Chen-fu, who died in January this year, held ground-breaking talks with Wang Daohan in 1993 in Singapore, signing four agreements on cross-strait technical affairs and establishing an institutionalized channel of consultations between the two sides.

However, Beijing suspended the dialogue first in 1995 to protest against then-President Lee Teng-hui's U.S. visit and later in 1999 against Lee's remarks which defined cross-strait relations as those between two states.
Beijing has not resumed the dialogue with Taipei during the past five years since the pro-independence DPP came to power.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAX BURDEN FOR BUSINESS SHOULD NOT GO UP TOO SHARPLY AT ONCE: MINISTER

TEXT.P: Economics Minister Ho Mei-yueh said Monday that tax incentives for high-tech investors should not be restricted after the minimum tax code has been adopted because imposing these two measures at the same time would increase the financial pressure on them.

A government plan to claw back tax incentives for high-tech investors has angered industry leaders, including Chairman Morris Chang of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. and Robert Tsao of United Microelectronics Corp., who lashed out against the government for trying to "take two layers of skin" off them.

They have demanded that the government change the law encouraging people to invest in certain "strategic" industries rather than taking back some incentives by administrative decree. The Ministry of Finance and the Ministry of Economic Affairs have not reached a consensus on this issue.

Under the government plan, investors will be given an option to choose between a five-year tax holiday or a tax exemption on certain amounts of their investment. The minister said these two preferential treatments have stood together for 30 years, and if investors are to choose only one of them, the law should be amended.
She noted that her ministry will put forward an amendment proposal within one year in accordance with a Legislative Yuan request.
The "minimum tax" code, which goes into effect next month, requires that a company whose annual earnings exceeds NT$2 million pay between 10 percent and 20 percent in corporate income tax.
Ho said since the new tax code has added tax burden on corporate leaders, the burden will get heavier if the measures on tax holidays and tax deductibles are to be revoked.

She suggested that a "right time" be chosen to restrict both tax benefits for businesses that have been lured into making new investments in "emerging" strategic industries because of the government offer.
She admitted that the government has given quite a number of incentives to investors, incentives which she claimed have brought benefits to the country.

For example, she said that last year, government revenue went up by NT$130 billion (US$3.93 billion) due in part to a whopping 28 percent increase in private investment. This year, private investment rose only nine percent over last year.

Some firms paid less than five percent of their earnings in income tax previously; if the tax rate jumped to more than 10 percent all of a sudden, it would not be "very appropriate, " the minister said.
While some people think that business enjoys too many tax benefits, some of the benefited companies have been "the pride of Taiwan" that she said have also given an impetus to investing in Taiwan.
Such companies should be cheered rather than discouraged during certain stages of their development, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MERGER TO CREATE NEW SECOND LARGEST UNIVERSITY IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Two universities in Taichung are expected to merge by August 2007 to become the second largest university in Taiwan in terms of enrollment, behind only National Taiwan University in Taipei City.

National Chung Hsin University and National Taichung University, formerly known as National Taichung Teachers College, have agreed to a merger at the recommendation of the Ministry of Education, and they are now working toward this goal.

However, the two sides have not yet agreed on a new name for the university following the merger, although ministry officials have suggested that the expanded university be named "Taichung Chung Hsin University."

The merger is expected to create a university consisting of 10 colleges with some 22,000 students, replacing National Cheng Kung University in Tainan City that has 18,000 students, as the second largest university in Taiwan, but its enrollment will be second to that of National Taiwan University, the country's top university, which has about 30,000 students.
