DOC.HEADLINE: TSU LAWMAKER BLAMES GIO HEAD FOR MEDIA REFORM BILL FAILURE

TEXT.P: Legislator Tseng Tsahn-deng on Monday blamed Government Information Office (GIO) Minister Pasuya Yao for the failure in having the government, political parties and military meet the Dec. 26 deadline for withdrawing from the media.

Tseng, an opposition Taiwan Solitary Union (TSU) lawmaker, is the person who was assigned to organize negotiations between the ruling and opposition parties in an attempt to pass the media reform bill.

With the legislature failing to pass the bill in time for the GIO to release state-controlled shares in two terrestrial television companies -- the Chinese Television System (CTS) and Taiwan Television Enterprise Ltd. (TTV) -- the government's check for carrying out President Chen Shui-bian's directive that all government agencies, political parties and military units relinguish control of news media by the end of this year has bounced.

Tseng said four rounds of talks on the draft statute have taken place among all the party caucuses at the Legislative Yuan. In the first three rounds of negotiations, consensus was reached on parts of articles in the bill, including the one regulating the formation of a special team, to be formed based on the proportion of seats each party has in the legislature, to review the sale of state-owned stakes in the two terrestrial television stations.

However, Yao overturned the decision to organize the team based on proportional representation in the fourth round of inter-party talks, making it impossible to pass the bill ahead of the deadline stipulated in the Broadcasting and Television Law, Tseng noted.

Despite the fact that the GIO did not deliver the bill to the Legislative Yuan until October, severely restricting the amount of time to review the bill, the legislators were still able to overcome some of their differences to form a consensus, Tseng said, adding that "the Legislative Yuan has done its duty."
Tseng claimed he thinks the GIO has "never been sincere nor active" in pushing for the withdrawal of the government, political parties and military from the media.
He stressed that he will ask Yao to accept the parties' consensus on the bill before he tries to organize a new round of talks.

On Sunday, chairmen and general managers of both the CTS and TTV, as well as directors and supervisors representing the government's stakes in the terrestrial TV stations, resigned en masse to show support for the government's media reform bid.
Outgoing CTS General Manager Chiang Hsia said Monday that for the time being, the company can do noting but wait and see because there is now no law regulating its management.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S LAWS NOT THE MAIN OBSTACLE IN DIRECT LINKS: MAC OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: There is more to opening direct transportation links with China than simply revising laws, Vice Chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Johnnason Liu said Monday.

Liu made the remark in response to a call the previous day by opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou that he would work with his political ally, the People First Party, to pass the necessary legislation to pave the way for direct transportation links with China. Liu said negotiating with China on the technical details of the links is the real sticking point, not any current restrictions imposed by Taiwan's laws.
Liu was referring to Beijing's refusal to talk with Taiwan on anything because of political differences.

The MAC vice chairman said the Executive Yuan is pushing for the links " step by step" in the hope that they will come about without endangering Taiwan's security, debasing its status as a state or compromising its national dignity.
Liu also said that before any such links are opened, a comprehensive analysis must be done on what the impact would be on Taiwan's economy.

The council has been looking into the feasibility of the issue since the summer of 2003 when both sides allowed a limited opening of charter flights across the Strait during the Chinese Lunar New Year. The flights did not take place the next year, but were resumed in 2005. Taiwan has also shown its willingness and flexibility to reach out to China as evidenced by the streamlining of cargo shipments between Taiwan and China.

However, to expand on this would require negotiations with Beijing, who has been firm in its resolve to give Taiwan the cold shoulder on any discussions if they are not tied to a capitulation on its "one China" policy.

Liu pointed to such issues as how the links would be framed - as domestic routes, international, or some creative blend of both that would satisfy both sides - the laws that would have to be crafted to encompass the many facets of direct links, and the flags to be flown on cargo ships - not to mention whether the ROC national flag would be acceptable to China on any vessel.
These matters can't be resolved by Taiwan alone, he said, adding that they would have to be agreed upon before Taiwan could formulate its own laws that would fit a future reality.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT FIRST VICE CHAIRMAN TO ATTEND TOP CHINA NEGOTIATOR'S FUNERAL

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Monday it will send its first vice chairman, Wu Poh-hsiung, to pay the party's last respects to Wang Daohan, China's top negotiator with Taiwan.
"KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou has assigned Wu to attend Wang's funeral on behalf of the party," a KMT spokesman said.

Wang, whose official title was president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), died in a Shanghai hospital Saturday at the age of 90. His funeral is scheduled to take place in Shanghai Dec. 30.

Wang, a one-time Shanghai mayor and mentor to Jiang Zemin, former Chinese president and Communist Party chief was instrumental in starting rapprochement between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait in the early 1990s.

He and Koo Chen-fu, the late chairman of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), held landmark talks in Singapore in 1993, after Taipei and Beijing agreed to their own interpretations of the "one China" principle in what is known by some as the "1992 consensus, " although many in Taiwan believe that no such consensus ever existed.

Koo died of cancer this past January at the age of 87. ARATS sent a contingent to Koo's funeral earlier this year. Koo's successor, Chang Chun-hsiung, said he hopes to attend Wang's funeral if Wang's family allows it.

"We express our deep condolences on the death of Wang Daohan, especially since Wang did all he could to improve cross-strait relations and boost exchanges across the Strait. We deeply regret his passing," Chang said.
The SEF and ARATS are quasi-official organizations authorized by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.
Beijing unilaterally suspended regular ARATS-SEF dialogue in mid-1999 when then-ROC President Lee Teng-hui redefined cross-strait ties as a special "state-to-state" relationship.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASKING PRESIDENT TO QUIT DPP NOT CONSTRUCTIVE: LEGISLATOR

TEXT.P: Asking President Chen Shui-bian to quit the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) would not be a smart move in terms of helping bail the party out of its current political difficulties, DPP Legislator Trong Chai said Monday.

Chai, one of the three candidates in the DPP's Jan. 15 chairmanship by-election scheduled after Su Tseng-chang stepped down to take responsibility for the DPP's humiliating defeat in the Dec. 3 local government elections, said that blaming President Chen for the party's failure at the polls is "simplifying a major issue" and that it is not constructive in terms of tackling the difficulties that the party is now facing.

Chen Ou-po, chief of the DPP Ilan Chapter, reportedly wrote President Chen over the weekend to ask him to quit the party as a gesture to take responsibility for the DPP's poor showing in the local elections, in which the ruling party won only six of the 23 city mayor and county magistrate posts up for grabs. The opposition "pan-blue alliance" led by the Kuomintang won 17 of the posts.
Chai called for every DPP member to "conduct in-depth soul-searching" on the question of why the party lost so badly in the elections.

He attributed the DPP's defeat mainly to two factors -- shaky grass-roots organizations and a recent string of corruption scandals, including the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. scandal and the "vultures" insider-trading case.

He also called for the DPP policy makers to incorporate the heads of the DPP's local chapters into the DPP Central Standing Committee so that local party organizations can work in tandem with officials in the upper levels of the party's hierarchy.

DOC.HEADLINE: 6 ENERGY-CONSUMING INDUSTRIES PLEDGE TO CUT CARBON DIOXIDE EMISSIONS

TEXT.P: Six high energy-consuming industries associations signed an agreement Monday, pledging to voluntarily conserve energy and cut carbon dioxide emissions.

The voluntary agreement comes in the wake of the Kyoto Protocol going into effect Feb. 16. Countries that ratified the accord are committed to reducing their emissions of carbon dioxide and five other greenhouse gases.

Under the auspices of the Industrial Development Bureau and the Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFI) , the associations representing the petrochemical, cement, pulp and paper, steel, man-made fiber, as well as the fabric or piecegoods printing, dyeing and finishing industries joined the Ministry of Economic Affairs to sign the agreement.

A total of 125 manufacturers from the six industries signed the agreement, pledging to voluntarily cut carbon dioxide emissions starting next year based on the 2004 levels. Under the agreement, the companies are expected to conserve a total of 1.39 million KLOE (kiloliters of oil equivalent) and cut their carbon dioxide emissions by 4.02 million tons by 2008.

Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh noted that the Taiwan Electrical and Electronic Manufacturers Association (TEEMA) had wanted to enter into the agreement, but due to the fact that the manufacturers of the TEEMA release other greenhouse gases in addition to carbon dioxide and that the board of directors of the TEEMA has yet to approve the matter, the association will sign the agreement later.

CNFI Deputy Chairman Chen Wu-hsiung said the signing of the agreement demonstrates that the industries are willing to make efforts to cut greenhouse gas emissions and are determined to do their part to safeguard the environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: RECYCLABLE ENERGY TO TOP SCI-TECH DEVELOPMENT PROJECTS IN 2006

TEXT.P: The government will put recyclable energy at the top of a key science and technology development project in 2006, Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh said Monday.
She said the government will use research and development (R&D) support, tax incentives and energy procurement policy to encourage the development of emerging energy sources.
She made the remarks while attending a function where the business sector signed a paper on saving energy and making voluntary cuts to carbon dioxide emissions.
A government bill encouraging the development of recyclable energy such as solar and wind power as well as bio-mass diesel has been sent to the legislature for deliberation, she pointed out.
She noted that under the bill, the government will offer supports for developing LED (light-emitting diode) and photovoltaic technologies.

The project will involve her ministry's Bureau of Energy, Industrial Development Bureau, Department of Industrial Technology and such state-run enterprises as the Chinese Petroleum Corp. and Taiwan Power Company.
The project will be further explained at the ministry's year-end news conference Tuesday, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CENTER TO ASSESS COLLEGES AND UNIVERSITIES LAUNCHED

TEXT.P: An assessment center to grade the nation's colleges and universities was launched Monday after one year of preparations.

Minister of Education Tu Cheng-sheng, in attending the launch ceremony, said that with the trend of globalization, Taiwan's colleges and universities have to compete with top-notch universities in the world.

The assessment center therefore aims at ensuring the high quality of colleges and universities as well as collecting assessment information, hoping to establish a professional and systematic assessment mechanism.

This will be the first semi-official professional assessment institution, with the Ministry of Education (MOE) contributing NT$15 million (US$447,760) and the 153 colleges and universities of Taiwan contributing NT$100,000 each.

The first task for the center will be to assess the teaching level of the departments and graduate schools of the universities. The assessment will target the departments related to education, fine arts and physical education in the first year, and the departments and graduate schools will first make self-assessments next March and then the center will make on-site inspections of their schools and conduct second reviews in the second half of 2006.
Center chairman as well as former President of National Sun Yat-sen University Liu Wei-chi said that the assessment will produce three results -- pass, fail or inconclusive.

Those departments or graduate schools that are listed as inconclusive will not be able to increase recruitment or apply to increase graduate schools, while those who fail will have to cut the number of student recruitments.
In addition, those departments or graduate schools graded inconclusive or failing will have to receive followed-up assessments in the future.
If they still fail the followed-up assessment, they will be banned from recruiting more students.

DOC.HEADLINE: TZU CHI GIVES SOME TSUNAMI SURVIVORS NEW HOMES

TEXT.P: A year after the devastating tsunami that killed hundreds of thousands of people, the reconstruction work undertaken by Taiwan's Tzu Chi Foundation has enabled many survivors to look forward to the new year with a solid roof over their heads, a Tzu Chi official said Monday.
The foundation has finished construction of 500 houses in Banda Aceh, Indonesia and 649 houses in Hambantota, southern Sri Lanka -- both hit hard by the tsunami.
The official said Tzu Chi volunteers rushed to the disaster-hit areas almost immediately after the Dec. 26, 2004 earthquake that triggered the tsunami and promised to build 3,700 houses in Indonesia.
So far, 500 of the 700 houses to be built in Panteriek, Banda Aceh, a village which was almost leveled by the tsunami, are done and 120 families have already moved into the houses, the official said.
Meanwhile, 649 houses have been built in Hambantota, Sri Lanka and have been given to survivors of the tsunami via a draw. New owners will move in and usher in the new year in their new houses.
The officials said each 120 square meter house built by the foundation has two bedrooms, one living room and one bathroom.

DOC.HEADLINE: PEOPLE IN TAIWAN RETIRING YOUNGER: DGBAS

TEXT.P: People in Taiwan are retiring younger, according to information released Monday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting, and Statistics (DGBAS).
The DGBAS report shows that employees in the industrial and service sectors in Taiwan who applied to retire in 2004 were 54.9 years old on average, lower than the 55.7 a year ago.
The DGBAS published the report after nearly six months of compiling and analyzing data gathered from a survey on retirement that it conducted in March on employees from over 9,000 companies.
The survey showed that about 63,000 people retired from work in the industrial and service sectors last year.

Some 32 percent of the retirees were over 60, down from the 74.12 percent in 1991, while 51.73 percent of those who retired in 2004 were between 50 and 59, posing a significant rise in comparison with the level of 21.77 percent in 1991.

The 50 to 59 age group made up the bulk of retirees in the industrial and service sectors, the report said, noting there were more people aged 40 to 49 choosing to retire, with 15.19 percent of the 2004 retirees in this age group, up from the 10.55 percent a year ago.
The report attributed the trend to an increase of corporate mergers in recent years. Many of these companies offer preferential deals to encourage workers to retire.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: A Wave of Memories; After a Year, People in Nations Hit by the Indian Ocean Tsunami Struggle to Move On, but Thoughts of Those They Lost Intrude.
Flowerpots have begun to brighten porches here. Fishermen are back at sea. Eighteen people in this seaside village have remarried, and seven women are pregnant.

DOC.HEADLINE: BCC, TWO OTHER KMT MEDIA SOLD TO CHINA TIMES GROUP FOR NT$9.3 BILLION

TEXT.P: The Kuomintang (KMT) sold its Broadcasting Corp. of China (BCC) and two other media to the China Times group for NT$9.3 billion (US$280 million), including NT$5.3 billion in debt, it was announced Monday.

KMT Deputy Secretary-General Chang Che-chen said a contract for the sale of BCC, China Television Co. and the Central Motion Picture Corp. were signed with a holding company owned by China Times Group Chairman Yu Chien-hsing Dec. 24 and stock transfers were completed Monday.
The transaction was worth NT$4 billion, with the buyer committing to take over the NT$5.3 billion debt incurred by the three media companies.
Chang said the KMT received NT$5.8 billion from the deal, which will be used to pay debts and lay off party workers.

The Central Daily News and the Chinese Daily News, two daily newspapers owned by the opposition party's assets holding company, were not included in the deal because the buyer was not interested. The KMT then bought the two dailies for NT$300 million.
He acknowledged that implementing the deal would not be an easy task as lawsuits are still being fought in court to settle disputes about the some of the lands under BCC's name.

As Monday was the deadline agreed upon by the ruling and opposition parties for political parties, the government and the military to give up control of their media holdings, Chang said the KMT has honored its commitment.
"We have not reneged on our word. We have shown the greatest determination to reform," Chang told the media at a news conference.

He pointed to the government-owned Taiwan Television Enterprise and Chinese Television System to jeer at the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's failure to honor its own word to relinquish control of media holdings.

DOC.HEADLINE: DISPUTE CONTINUES OVER WHO IS TAITUNG COUNTY'S ACTING MAGISTRATE

TEXT.P: The dispute over who is the legitimate acting magistrate of Taitung County is continuing after an official designated by the Ministry of the Interior as acting magistrate was sworn in Monday to replace the newly elected magistrate suspended by the ministry on the grounds that he has been convicted of corruption.

Lai Shun-hsien, secretary-general of the Taitung County Government, was sworn in Monday afternoon as the acting magistrate despite protests from more than 100 supporters of Wu Chun-li, who had been suspended by an executive order from the interior ministry as soon as he took his oath of office on Dec. 20.

Under police protection, Vice Interior Minister Chien Tai-lang presided over the swearing-in ceremony and witnessed the handover of the county's seal to Lai. He expressed satisfaction that the necessary procedure was completed so that the county government could become functional again. He said that Lai will be acting magistrate until a new magistrate is produced through a by-election.

However, Wu's ex-wife, Kuang Li-chen, who had been designated by Wu as deputy magistrate on Dec. 20 -- the day after their divorce became effective -- insisted that she should be the legitimate acting magistrate even if the ministry's order to suspend Wu was effective. She vowed that she will continue to perform her duties at the county government and receive visitors as usual in her capacity as deputy magistrate regardless of Lai's so-called takeover.
The ministry, on the other hand, contended that Wu had no right to designate his ex-wife as a deputy because he had been suspended as soon as he was sworn in.

Meanwhile, Wu was seeking legal recourse against the interior ministry. He filed a lawsuit Monday morning with the Public Prosecutors Office in Taitung County, accusing interior ministry officials of committing forgery.

He claimed that the executive order declaring his suspension reached him by e-mail on Dec. 19, while its date of issue in the document was Dec. 20, the day of his swearing-in. This means that he was suspended even before he could take the oath of office -- an apparent violation of the Administrative Procedure Act.

Later Monday afternoon, Wu flew to Taipei and filed a second lawsuit with the Taipei High Administrative Court, seeking an injunction that the interior ministry be stopped from executing the order to suspend him.

Wu explained that the court sentence that convicted him was about his involvement in a corruption scandal while he was deputy speaker of the Taitung County Council and should not apply to his new post. Furthermore, he added, the ministry did not give him any opportunity to present his side of the argument before having him suspended, and the executive order was not presented to him personally and, therefore, should not be considered as effective.

Wu was sentenced to 16 years in prison in the first trial in 2002. The sentence was reduced to seven years in the second trial. After he appealed, the Supreme Court overturned the sentence in the second trial and returned he case for a retrial.
The interior ministry has indicated that Wu can only be restored to his post if a higher court acquits him from the corruption charges.
It remains to be seen how Lai could make the Taitung County Government function because most members of the county council have openly declared that they want no one else but Wu to be the magistrate.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT HAS CONTINGENCY PLANS AGAINST AVAIN FLU: MAC

TEXT.P: The ROC government has contingency plans in place to deal with any outbreaks of bird flu in Taiwan, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Monday.

The MAC said that although Chinese authorities are making public their statistics on the disease, their actions are still too slow, and neighboring countries as well as international organizations have concerns about whether the numbers being released are accurate. The MAC is urging China to accelerate their response time.
The Department of Health (DOH) reported Monday on its efforts to monitor what is going on in China and the policies that Taiwan should adopt to prevent the disease from coming to the island.

According to the DOH report, the Office International des Epizooties (OIE) has now pinpointed 33 places in China where the H5N1 virus has been discovered since January 2004. According to the report, the first H5N1 virus found in a person in China this year was in Hunan province. There have been six cases of human infections in China; two of them have died.
The DOH suggested that new vaccines and medicines should be introduced while the island strengthens its umbrella of protection against the virus.

Infected birds must not be brought into the country, inspection and quarantine mechanisms should be established, communities must be properly educated about the disease and health care facilities should be prepared for the worst, the DOH said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOME COLLEGES DESERVE FUNDS FOR DISTINCTIVE PROGRAMS: LEE YUAN-TSEH

TEXT.P: Some universities that have distinctive research programs but are excluded from the government's five-year, NT$50 billion (US$1.49 billion) subsidy program for local colleges and universities deserve part of the funds, the head of the nation's top research institute said Monday.

Lee Yuan-tseh, president of Academia Sinica, cited the examples of Chung Yuan Christian University's excellent research on membranes, National Taiwan Normal University's education information center, National Chung Cheng University's Taiwan culture center and Taipei Medical University's stroke prevention center.

He said that these universities deserve some funds from the program to ensure the further development of their research. He made the remarks when he was asked to comment on the recent protest by a ranking official of National Chung Cheng University for being shut out of the program aimed at helping 12 select universities raise their level to that of international standards.
"It is inappropriate for a ranking official to stage a sit-in in front of the building of the Ministry of Education," Lee said.
He noted that the number of colleges and universities in Taiwan have ballooned over the past decade, but although the quantity has increased, the quality hasn't.

He cited those research-oriented universities as examples, saying that the top seven such universities recruit only 12,000 students a year, or just 4 percent of those who took part in the university entrance examination, which he said is too few.

He expressed the hope that the government will appropriate NT$10 billion a year to upgrade 12 colleges and universities that are included in the program, hoping that the number of recruitments can reach 10 percent of those who take part in the entrance examination.
Old and dilapidated classrooms or out-of-date equipment should also be phased out so as to be at the same level of the elite schools in the world, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI 101 TO RING IN NEW YEAR WITH FIREWORKS

TEXT.P: Taipei City will usher in the new year with a brief but breathtaking fireworks display launched from the world's tallest building -- Taipei 101.
The spectacle will be carried via live video feed to screens in other cities around the nation.
The firework show this year will be divided into 12 parts and will last just over two minutes. During this time, 8,101 fireworks will be set off.
It is estimated that around 100 million people around the world will witness the new year fireworks carried live by such networks as CNN, NHK, APTN and CCTV.

The Taipei 101 Observatory on the 89th floor will be opened on Jan. 1 from 4: 30 a.m. to 8: 30 a.m. to allow 1,010 people to see the first ray of sunlight of the new year from a unique vantage point. Tickets for this activity will be sold till Dec. 31, or until they are sold out.
The MRT will be operational all night, except the Hsin Peitou Line and the Hsiao Pitan Line.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW NANTOU MAGISTRATE TO TURN OFFICIAL RESIDENCE INTO ART CENTER

TEXT.P: New Nantou County Magistrate Lee Chao-chin has decided not to move into his official residence after taking office last Tuesday; instead, he will turn it into a "literary saloon."

Lee plans to make the quiet and exclusive residence into an exhibition site for art work with a coffee shop, according to Chen Chen-sheng, Nantou County Government's new cultural chief, Monday, adding that Nantou residents will be able to tour the official residence and appreciate the works displayed for free.
Lee said his home in Chunghsing New Village is not far from the county government building, and this was why he decided not to move in.
This will save decoration expenses and provide a literary space for residents. It will also attract visitors and can serve as a good place to display agricultural exhibitions.
The official residence is a two-story building, covering around 411 square meters.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEDIA WATCH GROUPS BLAME POLITICIANS FOR MISSING REFORM DEADLINE

TEXT.P: Media Watch and two other civic groups blamed both the ruling and opposition parties for failing to honor their own words to give up control of media holdings by the Monday deadline.

Media Watch, Campaign for Media Reform and the Association of Taiwan Journalists issued a joint statement Monday saying the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has failed to make good on President Chen Shui-bian's promise to reform government-owned media, such as Taiwan Television Enterprise (TTV) and Chinese Television System (CTS).

President Chen has lost credibility because he pledged during his 2000 campaign to make TTV and CTS publicly owned companies, a promise he reiterated in his recent National Day speech, said the statement.

The three groups also criticized Premier Frank Hsieh's proposal to put government stock in the two companies in a trust, an idea that the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) also suggested for its so-called "ill-gotten assets."
It's ironic that the DPP, which vehemently opposed the KMT's idea, should have come up with the same idea to handle the public assets under its control, they said.

They went on to lambaste previous and current Government Information Office chiefs since Chen took power in 2000, because all of these GIO heads have made grandiose promises to make good on the DPP government's commitment to relinquish control of media holdings.

Media reforms have turned out to be empty words because the legislature failed to amend the law governing the transfer of government stock in the two companies by the Dec. 26, 2005 deadline. The three media watch groups urged lawmakers to pass the amendment by Dec. 30.

Neither has the KMT, which owned China Television Company (CTV) and Broadcasting Corp. of China (BCC), shown any sincerity in playing its part in the reform plan because it delayed to the very last moment selling these two media groups, plus the Central Motion Picture Company, to the China Times Group for NT$9.3 billion, said the statement.

The top management of CTV and BCC remained unchanged with the sale, indicating that the KMT has also failed to honor its word that political parties, the government and the military should give up manipulation of the media, according to the statement.
It blamed KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou for allowing the sale to be negotiated behind closed doors, triggering protests by the employees of the affected media.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO HELP BUSINESSES GO 'GREEN' IN LINE WITH EU REGULATIONS

TEXT.P: The government will help 320 small- and medium-sized businesses next year improve their environmental protection so that their products will be acceptable to markets in the European Union (EU) , the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Monday.

The EU will follow the Restriction of Hazardous Substances (RoHS) from July 1, 2006, which requires all manufacturers of electrical and electronic equipment to have their products be free of lead, cadmium, mercury, hexavalent chromium and polybrominated diphenylethers.

The Small and Medium Enterprises Administration (SMEA) under the economics ministry pointed out that the government will help the country's small- and medium-sized enterprises build up the required management capacities, and team up with other, bigger enterprises as well as the international Green Supply Chain to meet the requirements of the EU.
The SMEA said that small- and medium-sized enterprises can consult the economics ministry online to familiarize themselves with the EU's regulations.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Courts Criticize Judges' Handling of Asylum Cases
U.S. Federal appeals court judges around the nation have repeatedly excoriated immigration judges this year for what they call a pattern of biased and incoherent decisions in asylum cases. Citing cases from around the country, the court wrote of "a disturbing pattern" of misconduct in immigration rulings that sent people back to co untries where they had said they would face persecution. The harsh criticism may stem in partt from a surge in immigration cases before the federal appeals courts. Immigration cases, most involving asylum seekers, accounted for about 17 percent of all federal appeals cases last year, up from just 3 percent in 2001. In the courts in New York and California, nearly 40 percent of federal appeals involved immigration cases.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FIRST ANTI-NARCOTICS MUSEUM TO OPEN DEC. 27

TEXT.P: Taiwan's first anti-narcotics museum will open to the public after President Chen Shui-bian officiates at an inaugural ceremony Tuesday.

The museum, built at a cost of about NT$10 million, is housed in the head office building of the Bureau of Investigation in Hsintien, suburban Taipei, and aims to educate the public, especially school children, about the harmful effects of substance abuse.
On display will be facts about how the nation has fought against narcotics, beginning with the Opium War of 1839-42 in the Ching dynasty up until today.

In one corner of the museum is a complete set of machines and equipment for manufacturing amphetamines and the tools used by drug traffickers and smugglers, such as shoes with the soles hollowed out and drug balls in plastic or condoms to be swallowed by "mules."
Also on display is a range of narcotics seized by law enforcement officers, including heroin, cocaine, ecstasy and cannabis.

Visitors can use touch screens to activate the light and sound system and feel what it is like in a dimly lit night club where people who have taken ecstasy are dancing to loud music amid the smell of marijuana.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP SLAMS KMT CHIEF OVER SALE OF ILL-GOTTEN PARTY ASSETS

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lambasted opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou Monday over the sale of three controversial KMT-controlled news media to a conglomerate led by China Times Group Chairman Yu Chien-hsin.

"By selling off the party's three ill-gotten news media, Ma has once again broken his promise of disposing of the KMT's assets in accordance with the law and the principles of fairness and justice by 2008," DPP Secretary-General Lee Yi-yang said.

The KMT announced earlier in the day that it had sold its controlling shares in the Broadcasting Corp. of China (BCC) , China Television Co. (CTV) and the Central Motion Picture Corp. (CMPC) to the Yu-led holding company for about NT$9.3 billion.

Claiming that the KMT took over BCC from the Japanese Broadcasting Association at the end of Japanese colonial rule, Lee said the KMT was not entitled to sell off the company and should instead have returned it to the national coffers.
Noting that CTV and CMPC were established with earnings by KMT's ill-gotten businesses amassed during its 55 years in power, Lee said the KMT should also have returned them to the public coffers.

Regrettably, Lee said, the KMT has on the one hand blocked the enactment of a statute requiring the return of ill-gotten party assets to the national coffers, and on the other "secretly" sold off its ill-gotten assets to resolve its financial woes.
Lee also branded Ma as a liar, claiming that Ma, who doubles as mayor of Taipei, has backed off from his promise to reform and fairly and justly deal with the KMT's ill-gotten party assets.

"Judging from the KMT's selling of a plot of land in suburban Taipei and the three news media outlets since Ma took over the helm of the KMT in August this year, I don't think Ma will ever be willing to honor his promise of reform," Lee added.
Under a law revised two years ago, Monday was the deadline for Taiwan's political parties, the government and the military to divest themselves of their investments in television and radio stations.
"The KMT has honored its previous promise of pulling out of media operations, " said KMT spokeswoman Cheng Li-wen, who termed the move "a milestone in Taiwan's democratization."

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO HEAD ASKS KMT SPOKESWOMAN TO WITHDRAW FROM HOSTING RADIO PROGRAM

TEXT.P: The spokeswoman of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) should stop hosting a radio program, Government Information Office Minister Pasuya Yao said Monday.
Yao was referring to Cheng Li-wen, who hosts a weekday show.
He noted that a revised law governing broadcasting and television stipulates that political parties, the government and the military should be divested of media holdings as of Dec. 26, 2005.
Yao expressed the hope that all politicians exercise self-discipline, saying that even if the law has grey areas, they should abide by public ethics.
Yao reminded KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou that he should regulate those around him, singling out Cheng as violating the spirit of non-interference in the media by political parties.
He said that political figures who are advocating a free and independent media but are at the same time manipulating the media are "despicable."

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST WOMAN TO BE PROMOTED TO COMBAT STATUS GENERAL

TEXT.P: A woman will be among those promoted to the rank of general on Jan. 1, 2006, the Ministry of National Defense announced Monday.
She will be the first major general to be commissioned in a combat capacity. Several other women have been generals, but they were all in non-combat commissions.
Seven soldiers will be promoted to lieutenant general or vice admiral, and 37 to major generals or rear admirals, the ministry said.
Minister of National Defense Lee Jye will preside over the promotion ceremony Dec. 29, with President Chen Shui-bian in attendance in his capacity as commander-in-chief of the ROC armed forces.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR DECEMBER 27 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Tuesday, December 27:
10:00, President Chen Shui-bian will attend a graduation ceremony for a Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau staff training program.
14:00, Vice Minister of the Interior Chang Wen-ying will attend an award-presentation ceremony in honor of those who have contributed to public interests.
14:50, President Chen will attend an academic award presentation ceremony at Taiwan Cement Co. Building in Taipei.
15:00, The Ministry of Foreign Affairs will hold a year-end news conference at its press center.
16:00, President Chen will receive a delegation of board members and teachers of three Chinese schools in Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPECIAL LIAISON TEAM IN PLACE FOR CROSS-STRAIT CHARTER FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: The government has formed a special liaison task force to ensure smooth proceeding of charter flight service across the Taiwan Strait during the upcoming Chinese New Year holiday, a Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) official said Monday.
MAC Vice Chairman Liu Teh-hsun made the remarks while briefing the press on the preparations for direct cross-strait charter flights for Taiwan citizens during the Chinese New Year holiday.

A total of 72 flights jointly operated by six carriers from each side of the Taiwan Strait will be available from Jan. 20 through Feb. 13, with each side operating 36 flights. Chinese New Year Day falls on Jan. 29. The destinations will include Shanghai, Beijing, Guangzhou and Xiamen in China, and Taipei and Kaohsiung in Taiwan.

As of Dec. 22, Liu said five Taiwan carriers -- China Airlines, EVA Airways, UNI Airways, Mandarin Airlines and Far East Air Transport -- have applied to operate a total of 30 cross-strait flights during the holiday period. The Civil Aeronautics Administration has not yet approved any of the applications, Liu said, adding that no mainland Chinese airline has filed applications.

Although local carriers' flight schedules have not yet been finalized, they have accepted reservations since early this month, Liu said, adding that the ticket prices for direct cross-strait charter flights will be higher than those via a third place.

During the holiday period, Liu said all relevant government agencies have assigned staff members to handle emergencies and a special liaison task force has been in place to deal with cross-strait charter flight affairs.

The MAC has also asked the Council of Agriculture and the Department of Health to prepare publicity materials to prevent invasion of avian flu virus and other contagious diseases during the holiday charter flight period.

The service target for the upcoming cross-strait charter flights will be expanded to cover all Taiwan residents with valid exit/entry permits issued by the governments on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

During the 2005 Chinese New Year holiday, six carriers from each side of the Taiwan Strait operated a total of 48 non-stop charter flights between Shanghai/Beijing/Guangzhou in China and Taipei/Kaohsiung in Taiwan exclusively for Taiwan businessmen operating in China, commonly known as "taishang," and their families.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Dec. 27, or the 27th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1571: Johannes Kepler, German astronomer and mathematician, is born. Considered the founder of modern astronomy, he formulated three laws to clarify the theory that the planets revolve around the sun.
1822: Louis Pasteur, French chemist and bacteriologist who founded modern microbiology, is born. He invented the process of pasteurization and developed vaccines for anthrax, rabies and chicken cholera.
1831: Under the command of Capt. Robert Fitzroy, the Royal Navy's HMS Beagle sets sail from Devonport, England, on a five-year voyage of scientific exploration around the world.
1927: Leon Trotsky, Russian revolutionary theoretician, is expelled form the Soviet Communist Party for his opposition to the authoritarianism of Stalin and for his emphasis on world revolution.
1945: The International Monetary Fund is set up in Washington, D.C.
1949: Republic of China government troops evacuate Chengtu, the capital of Szechwan Province.
1949: Ahmed Sukarno, leader of the Indonesian Nationalist Party, returns to Batavia (Jakarta) after A.H.J. Lovink, representative of the Netherlands government, signed a protocol transferring sovereignty to an Indonesian delegation.
1958: More than 10,000 Tibetans die in armed resistance against Communist Chinese atrocities.
1959: Japanese Prime Minister Shegeru Yoshida visits Taipei.
1969: Egypt, Sudan and Libya agree to the formation of a political, economic and military alliance.
1972: Lester Pearson, the former Canadian prime minister who won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1957 for his part in settling the Suez crisis in 1956, dies at the age of 75.
1972: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Chad.
1975: Ten people are honored by the Young Entrepreneurs Association in Taipei for their inventions.
1975: The First International Children's Camp opens for two days of activities sponsored by the Camping Association of the Republic of China.
1975: The ROC's Vocational Assistance Commission for Retired Servicemen announces it had given aid to 251,563 former servicemen as of the end of November.
1976: Jacques Baumel, member of the National Assembly of France, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1976: Dr. Charles E. Bishop, president of the University of Arkansas, and Rev. Malcolm Carron, president of the University of Detroit, arrive in Taipei for a weeklong visit.
1978: Some 10,000 people demonstrate at the airport when a delegation led by U.S. Deputy Secretary of State Warren Christopher arrives in Taipei for talks after the United States severed diplomatic relations with Taipei in favor of Beijing.
1979: Afghan President Hafizullah Amin is executed by the Soviets. Babrak Karmal, a former deputy prime minister in exile in Czechoslovakia, is installed in his place.
1980: Twenty-two supplementary members are elected to Taiwan's Control Yuan from among 54 candidates by members of the Taiwan Provincial Assembly, the Taipei City Council and the Kaohsiung City Council.
1987: The Taiwan Provincial Government issues its last lottery tickets.
1995: France stages the fifth in a series of nuclear weapon tests in the South Pacific.
1999: Vice President Lien Chan expresses his appreciation to Chinese-Japanese baseball star Sadaharu Oh for his active efforts after the devastating magnitude 7.3 earthquake hit Taiwan Sept. 21.
2000: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou says that the current political instability mainly results from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's failure to respect the Republic of China Constitution and its "one China" spirit.
2001: The National Taiwan Museum in Taipei represents an exhibition introducing the achievements of the late Dr. Joseph Needham (1900-1995) and the British scholar's contributions to Chinese and world civilization.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Gentlemen, why should you be concerned at your present want of official position! The world has long been without the order and justice of good government; now God is going to make use of your teacher as a tocsin to awaken the world."
