DOC.HEADLINE: NO CHANCE OF ETC SYSTEM FOR FREEWAYS BEING INAUGURATED JAN. 1: MOTC

TEXT.P: The electronic toll collection (ETC) system for freeways will not be able to be inaugurated next month as the operator has claimed, Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san said Tuesday.

Lin's remarks at the Institute of Transportation under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) came as the FETC, a subsidiary of the Far Eastern Group which will operate the ETC system, recently published advertisements saying that the system will be inaugurated Jan. 1, 2006.

He noted that there are currently around 8 million vehicles in Taiwan, but car owners are reluctant to install the on-board unit (OBU) for the automatic toll-ticketing system because of its high price. Only slightly more than 2,000 vehicles have been equipped with OBUs so far, he added.
In addition, there will be at least four toll lanes reserved for OBU-equipped vehicles, raising concerns that this will lead to long lines in lanes for vehicles not equipped with OBUs.

Some legislators have also voiced concerns that the price for installing the OBU is unreasonable, asking that the Taiwan Area National Expressway Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications re-screen the price structure, Lin said.
He added that the bureau will have the final say on the price of OBU installation and the date of the ETC's inauguration.

Meanwhile, Lin said that it might be difficult to open the Hsuehshan Tunnel at the end of this year as scheduled. He said that the MOTC is currently dealing with some of the flaws and deficiencies found in the second inspection of the 13-kilometer tunnel, the centerpiece of the 34-kilometer of the Peiyi Freeway linking Taipei with Ilan.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEALTH INSURANCE FOR INMATES NECESSARY: MOJ

TEXT.P: Officials from the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) said Tuesday that it is necessary to provide national health insurance coverage to prison inmates.

MOJ officials have been in contact with their Department of Health counterparts for discussions on technical problems pertaining to the issue, said Wu Yu-ming, a commissioner with the MOJ's Department of Corrections.

A group of legislators urged Tuesday that the country's prison inmates, numbering about 50,000, be allowed to join the national health insurance program in a bid to better protect the prisoners' human rights.

Legislators Lin Kuo-ching, Lu Tien-lin, Huang Wei-che and Huang Shu-fen from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party jointly held a press conference Tuesday, calling for the immediate implementation of new health regulations to make inmates eligible for national health insurance coverage.
Lin said it is ridiculous that while Taiwan calls itself "a country of human rights, " its 50,000 inmates are excluded from the national health insurance program.

He noted that mainland Chinese spouses of Taiwan citizens are entitled to join the national health insurance program and that even illegal immigrants from China are provided with free health care based on humanitarian considerations.

Hung Pi-lan, an official from the Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI) who attended the press conference, said that the Executive Yuan instructed in November 2004 that relevant agencies should begin to study the issue pertaining to national health insurance coverage for inmates.

The Department of Health authorities have since convened several meetings with MOJ officials and conducted surveys on the matter, but the prisoners have still not been provided coverage as several technical problems remain to be tackled, Hung said.

These problems include the support of medical and law enforcement personnel, whether and how medical doctors and nurses should be dispatched to prisons, and how prisoners should pay their national health insurance premiums, he added.
According to Hung, the government will have to subsidize the health program with an additional NT$700 million (US$21.2 million) a year if coverage is provided to the 50,000 inmates.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO CHINESE OR HONG KONG FUNDS BEHIND BUYER OF KMT MEDIA FIRMS: MA

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou denied Tuesday that the buyer of the three KMT news media companies was financed with capital from China or Hong Kong.

Ma said that he had asked Chang Che-shen, director of the KMT Administrative Management Committee, about the allegations that the party has sold the three companies to a Cayman Islands-registered holding company which may have investment from China, and that he was told by Chang that China Times Group Chairman Yu Chien-hsin has invested in the company and that there is no Hong Kong capital or Chinese capital involved in the purchase.

Government Information Office Minister Pasuya Yao called for the KMT to "give the public an explanation" about the sale of its controlling shares in the Broadcasting Corp. of China (BCC) , China Television Co. (CTV) and the Central Motion Picture Corp. (CMPC) to the Yu-led holding company for about NT$9 billion (US$272.73 million).

Ruling Democratic Progressive Party Legislators Huang Shih-chuo and Lo Chih-ming accused the KMT at a press conference Tuesday of selling the KMT's three news media organizations to an offshore holding company that might be invested in by foreign companies.

Huang questioned whether the China Times Group had the financial viability to make the NT$9 billion purchase, pointing out that the group recently shut down its China Times Evening News because of financial difficulties.

Lo quoted other media reports as saying that Hong Kong's Li Ka Shing Group secretly financed the China Times Group in its purchase of the three KMT companies and that Chang's recent trip to Hong Kong proved the relationship.
On this allegation, Ma said that Chang did visit Hong Kong recently but that the trip had nothing to do with the purchase of the three media firms.

As to the issue of the KMT still being the major shareholder in the Central Daily News and the China Daily News, Ma said that the KMT will "keep on trying" to deal with these assets as soon as possible.
Under a law revised two years ago, Monday was the deadline for Taiwan's political parties, government and military to divest themselves of their investments in television and radio stations.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG CUSTOMS EQUIPPED WITH NEW CUTTERS

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung Customs Office (KCO) was equipped with three new revenue cutters Tuesday as part of the central government's program to renew the cutter fleets at all the customs spots around the country, KCO officials said.

A delivery ceremony was held at the shallow-water wharf in Kaohsiung Harbor. KCO Director Yu Chao-shun said the new cutters will be used to patrol waters in an around the harbor to safeguard the security of the trading outlet.

Each of the new revenue cutters is 20 tons in weight, 15.7 meters in height, with an average draft of two meters. With a seven-person capacity, the boat features a top speed of 22 knots and is equipped with a state-of-the-art global positioning system and a satellite emergency position-indicating radio beacon (EPIRB).

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 3.18 points to close at 6,531.59.
The bourse opened at 6,539.29 and fluctuated between 6,570.42 and 6,505.46 during trading. A total of 4.75 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$113.22 billion (US$3.42 billion).

Three of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with cement stocks moving up the most at 2.1 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues at 0.2 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares at 0.1 percent.

Four of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down the most at 1.8 percent, followed by textile stocks at 1.2 percent, banking and financial shares at 0.6 percent, and foodstuff issues at 0.5 percent.
Machinery and electronics shares remained unchanged.
Losers outnumbered gainers 624 to 421, with 165 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: ETC OPERATOR FRUSTRATED SYSTEM CAN'T BE INAUGURATED JAN. 1

TEXT.P: The chairman of the operator of an electronic toll collection (ETC) system for highways slated to be inaugurated Jan. 1 said Tuesday that he is frustrated that the system's scheduled start date has been postponed.

Douglas Hsu, head of the FETC, a subsidiary of the Far Eastern Group, made the remarks after Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san announced the postponement earlier the same day.
At issue are complaints about the high price of installing an on-board unit (OBU) in cars to use the automatic toll-ticketing system. The price currently stands at about NT$2,200 (US$65.67).
Lin said the Taiwan Area National Expressway Bureau under the ministry will have the final say on the OBU price tag and on the start date for the ETC system.
Hsu presided over a ceremony held at National Taiwan University's sports stadium to announce that the FETC is ready to inaugurate the system.

Dressed like the head coach of an American football team, Hsu said the ceremony means that the company has accomplished the task that it was commissioned by the government to do, adding that the company has given "a New Year's present to the public."

Hsu insisted that the company will not budge on the price for installing an OBU, pointing out that the company is not forcing anyone to buy one. "Some people like the convenience that the OBUs will provide and wouldn't mind even paying NT$5,000 to NT$10,000, " he said.
Hsu added that he couldn't say when the ETC system would be inaugurated, pointing out that "the government has too many other considerations."
However, Chang Yung-chang, president of the FETC, said that the company has applied to the MOTC to begin using the system on a trial basis at some busy freeway toll booths on Jan. 1.
There are currently around 8 million vehicles in Taiwan, but it is estimated that only a little more than 2,000 vehicles have been equipped with OBUs so far.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEDIA WATCH GROUPS DEMAND APOLOGY FOR MEDIA REFORM FAILURE

TEXT.P: Media watch group leaders on Tuesday urged the ruling and opposition parties to make an apology for failing in their task of having the government, political parties and military withdraw completely from media operations by Monday's deadline.

Media Watch Chairman Kuan Chung-hsiang, Campaign for Media Reform convener Wei Ti, and Association of Taiwan Journalists President Lu Tung-hsi, as well as Hung Chen-ling, assistant professor at National Taiwan University's Graduate Institute of Journalism, made the call at a news conference held at the Legislative Yuan.
Kuan indicated that President Chen Shui-bian made a promise to reform government-owned media firms during the 2000 presidential campaign and reiterated the promise in his recent National Day speech.

Now "the check has been bounced" since the government has failed to divest itself of its investments in media firms by the stipulated deadline of Dec. 26, Kuan said, adding that Chen should offer an explanation for the failure.
Kuan also lambasted the Executive Yuan for "playing an old army game" of blaming the legislature as the culprit for the media reform failure.
Kuan drew a comparison between the Executive Yuan's large-scale efforts to promote the arms procurement bill and what he called its reluctance to give up its media holdings.

At the news conference, the three media watch groups issued a joint statement saying that media reform has turned out to be "empty words" because the legislature failed to amend the law governing the transfer of government stakes in two terrestrial TV stations, Taiwan Television Enterprise and Chinese Television System, by the deadline. They urged lawmakers to pass the amendment by Dec. 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING MUM ON TAIWAN'S OFFER TO PAY RESPECT TO LATE ARATS CHIEF

TEXT.P: Beijing continued to keep Taipei guessing Tuesday on whether it will allow Chang Chun-hsiung, chairman of the Taipei-based Strait Exchange Foundation (SEF), to attend the funeral for the late Wang Dao-han, who headed the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS).

Three days after Taiwan's chief mainland affairs official Joseph Wu said Chang would like to visit Shanghai to pay his last respects to Wang, Beijing officials have still not responded, although Beijing's Xinhua news agency quoted members of Wang's family as saying the previous day that Wang had told them before he died that his funeral should be as simple as possible.

"That means only a few of Wang's intimate relatives and close friends will be allowed to pay their last respects at his funeral, " Xinhua said, adding that "not all of Wang's friends and representatives of some institutions would be invited."
This has been viewed by some in Taiwan as a veiled rejection of Chang's attendance at the funeral which is to be held in Shanghai on Jan. 30.
Beijing stopped all contact with Taiwan in 1999 after then-President Lee Teng-hui characterized cross-strait ties as "state-to-state relations."

As ARATS Vice Chairman Sun Yafu and Secretary-General Li Yafei had visited Taipei Feb. 3 to pay homage to Koo Cheng-fu, the chief of SEF who died Jan. 3, political analysts believe Beijing will allow SEF officials below Chang's rank to attend Wang's funeral.

DOC.HEADLINE: DONATED ORGANS OF EXECUTED BROTHERS HELP EIGHT PATIENTS

TEXT.P: Two Kaohsiung brothers executed Monday for homicide helped eight patients with organ donations Tuesday which they had agreed to prior to their executions.

Lin Meng-kai and Lin Hsin-hung, who were sentenced to death for murdering one man and critically injuring another four years ago, signed organ donation consent forms prior to their execution at a prison in Kaohsiung County.

Their bodies were sent to three medical centers around Kaohsiung Monday night, where a heart, a liver, four kidneys and two corneas were removed and successfully transplanted into eight patients in operations performed the next day.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAD REFUTES CHARGE OF SELLING NATION'S ASSETS TOO CHEAPLY

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou on Tuesday denied charges that his party sold three media outlets too cheaply that should have gone to the national coffers.
Taiwan Solidarity Union, a minor opposition party, said the KMT has undersold "the property of the people of Taiwan."

Yu Shyi-kun, who is running for chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , said that by selling the party's shareholdings in China Television Co. (CTV) and two other companies, Ma has "pocketed a huge sum of cash, while winning the reputation as a reformer."

Ma responded by saying that "they are again trying to divert attention," this time from the fact that the DPP had failed to act on its promise to give up its shareholdings in two government-controlled TV stations by the stipulated deadline of Dec. 26, 2005.
In contrast, the KMT has completed all legal steps for getting rid of its shares in CTV, the Broadcasting Corporation of China and the Central Motion Picture Company by Monday night, Ma said.
"We have done this to show the people that we're not just paying lip service to reform," he said.

Although DPP-appointed top managers at Taiwan Television Enterprise (TTV) and China Television System (CTS) have quit, this is not the point, Ma said, noting that the DPP pledged to turn the companies into independent firms.

As to DPP criticism about the price of the KMT's sale of its holdings in the three media firms -- NT$9.3 billion, including NT$5.3 billion debt -- Ma said he was quite surprised to hear the criticism.

Ma said that both sides had many factors to consider before deciding to make the deal and that he would not call it an "under sale." The KMT is responsible for the pensions and severance pay for nearly 1,000 party workers, a financial burden that no other political parties have, he noted.

He called on all sectors of society to keep urging all parties and the government to give up their shareholdings in media outlets and stop making excuses or adopting "attention diverting" strategies to cover up their failure to honor their own words.

As to Government Information Office Minister Pasuya Yao's accusation that KMT spokeswoman Cheng Li-wen has violated the "spirit of withdrawing from media" by hosting a weekly radio talk show, Ma said he "definitely will look into the matter."
Both the ruling and opposition parties had agreed that political parties, the government and the military should "withdraw their influence from the media" by Dec. 26, 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, gaining NT$0.034 to close at NT$33.132.
A total of US$717 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's low of NT$33.102 and hit a high of NT$33.145.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for January moved down 11 points to close at 6,567, with 23,749 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for February moved down 17 points to end at 6,563, with 108 contracts traded, while March futures lost one point to finish at 6,579, with 17 contracts traded. June futures moved down 10 point to close at 6,550, with 24 contracts traded, while September futures moved down 17 points to close at 6,440, with 26 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 6,578 for January, 6,580 for February, 6,580 for March, 6,560 for June and 6,457 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly lower.

January TE futures moved up 0.45 points to close at 290, with 4,243 contracts traded, while February TE futures lost 0.05 points to finish at 289.25, with 29 contract transactions. March TE futures moved up 0.8 points to end at 291, with two contracts traded, while June TE futures moved up 1.85 points to end at 290, with three contract transactions. September TE futures lost 1.65 points to end at 282.95, with two contract traded.

January TF futures lost 6.4 points to finish at 896.2, with 1,701 contracts changing hands, while February TF futures moved down four points to end at 899.6, with 15 contracts traded. March TF lost 9.4 points to finish at 895, with 11 contract transactions, while September TF futures moved down 15.8 points to close at 890, with seven contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOO'S WIDOW TO ATTEND LATE ARATS CHIEF'S FUNERAL IN SHANGHAI

TEXT.P: The widow of Taiwan's late chief negotiator with China, Koo Chen-fu, will go to Shanghai Wednesday to attend the funeral of Wang Daohan, the president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), a source close to the Koo family said Tuesday.
Cecilia Y. Koo will be accompanied by her secretary and a one-time close aide to her late husband. Her son, Koo Cheng-yun, who heads Taiwan Cement Corp., will also attend, the source said.
Wang died in a Shanghai hospital Saturday at the age of 90. His funeral is scheduled for Dec. 30.

Besides the Koo family members, former executive officials of the Taipei- based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , which the late Koo Chen-fu headed until his death this past January at the age of 87, will also fly to Shanghai to attend Wang's funeral. They include Chiu Chin-yi, Chiao Yen-ho and Lee Ching-ping.

Wang, a former Shanghai mayor and mentor to Jiang Zemin, former Chinese president and Communist Party chief, was instrumental in starting rapprochement between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait in the early 1990s.

He and Koo held landmark talks in Singapore in 1993, after Taipei and Beijing agreed to their own interpretations of the "one China" principle in what is known by some as the "1992 consensus, " although many in Taiwan believe that no such consensus ever existed.
The SEF and ARATS are quasi-official organizations authorized by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.
Beijing unilaterally suspended regular ARATS-SEF dialogue in mid-1999 when then-ROC President Lee Teng-hui redefined cross-strait ties as a special "state-to-state" relationship.

DOC.HEADLINE: CALL GOES OUT FOR BLOOD DONORS IN EASTERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Blood Donation Center is sending out an urgent call to civic-minded people in the Hualien area to donate blood, as supplies in the eastern part of the island are dangerously low.

Citing statistics prepared by its Hualien office, which provides blood to hospitals in eastern Taiwan, the center said there are only 37 bags of type O blood, 133 bags of type A, 121 bags of type B and 12 bags of type AB in stock in Hualien, only a two-day supply. The small amount of type O blood is particularly worrying as it is the " universal donor" type.
Wang Yun-lung, the director of the blood center's Hualien office said blood supplies are usually tight in the winter but the current shortage is more serious than in the past.
In order to replenish the blood reserves, Wang said his office will organize seven blood donation drives in January.
Wang said his office used to depend heavily on donations from soldiers and students, but since schools and the military have stopped giving these people time off to donate, supplies have been tight.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA STUDYING FEASIBILITY OF BRINGING IN FOREIGN FARM WORKERS

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture said Tuesday it was studying the feasibility of importing foreign workers to work in the nation's farming industry.
Council Chairman Lee Chin-lung said he will discuss the idea with Council of Labor Affairs Chairman Lee Ying-yuan Wednesday.
The council is looking into the possibility of making up for labor shortages in certain agriculture sectors. Once a decision has been made, it will "phase in" importation of foreign farm workers.
A limited number of foreign farm workers will be brought in on the principle of "supplementing Taiwan's work force in limited sectors of the farming industry," according to Lee.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOUTHERN TAIWAN TO HAVE WORLD-CLASS CONCERT HALL, THEATERS

TEXT.P: The government will build an arts and cultural center in a 66-hectare park bordering Kaohsiung City and Kaohsiung County at a cost of NT$8.36 billion (US$252.6 million) that will have a world-class concert hall and two opera theaters.

The Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development approved a plan Monday to build the "Weiwu Camp Arts and Cultural Center, " using funds from a special budget for the government's 10 New Major Construction Projects.

The Weiwu Camp, bordering eastern Kaohsiung, the second largest city in Taiwan, and Fengshan city in Kaohsiung County, used to be Republic of China Army barracks, but the military began moving out last year.
When completed in 2009, the arts and cultural center will have a 2,300-seat concert hall, along with an opera theater that seats 2,000 and a smaller theater with a seating capacity of 1,000.

Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsin said Tuesday that while the construction of the park and the arts and cultural center is under way, he wants some parts of the vast green pasture to be open to the public for leisure activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: VOTE-BUYING STILL A COMMON PRACTICE: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday that despite the government's efforts over the past five years, vote-buying is still a common practice, and the just concluded "three-in-one" elections were worse than last year's legislative elections.

President Chen made the comments when he attended the commencement ceremony of newly recruited agents of the Bureau of Investigation under the Ministry of Justice after their completion of a training program.
Noting that the government has done a great deal to crack down on election bribery since 2000, the president lamented that old habits die hard, and the public is still looking for better results.

"There is great room for improvement, " Chen said, adding that vote-buying is still rampant and the practice was even more serious in the Dec. 3 elections for city and county chiefs, city and county councilors, and village and township chiefs than last December's legislative elections, which he said poses a threat to the healthy development of Taiwan's democracy.

Since it is difficult to obtain solid evidence of vote-buying, the president urged law enforcers to look closely at people who tread on gray areas of the law to strengthen the government's credibility and authority.
The president said that prosecution and investigation officials must work actively to forestall any irregularities in the March speaker and deputy speaker elections for city and county councils.
Before attending the ceremony, the president also toured the newly inaugurated anti-narcotics museum.
The president visited a section of the museum dedicated to simulating what it's like to be in a club where drugs like ecstasy and marijuana are used.

The museum, built at a cost of about NT$10 million (US$298,500), is housed in the head office building of the Bureau of Investigation in Hsintien, suburban Taipei, and aims to educate the public, especially school children, about the harmful effects of substance abuse.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA TO RETHINK PLAN TO CUT PREFERENTIAL CORPORATE TAX TREATMENTS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs will further study if it is necessary to reduce the preferential tax treatment for the industrial sector following the introduction of the minimum tax rate system, Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh said Tuesday.

According to Ho, the main purpose of offering preferential tax treatment to the industrial sector is to boost its development, but before making any changes, the government needs to consider if the industries are being given sufficient time to adapt to the changes.
Ho said she was very happy that the Ministry of Finance (MOF) had agreed to postpone the plan to cut the preferential tax treatment.

Ho was commenting on the MOF's decision to delay a plan to revise a bylaw of the Statute for Upgrading Industries to reduce the preferential tax treatment for emerging industries that have strategic importance, amid strong opposition to the planned revision from the hi-tech industrial sector.

Currently, strategic industries enjoy tax deductions of up to 50 percent on their investments in machinery and equipment for industrial upgrading. These industries also enjoy tax exemptions for five years on their profits.

To avoid a double incentive, the MOF has proposed changing the bylaw, for implementation next year, in such a way that these industries could only enjoy one of the preferential treatments, instead of both.
The plan was strongly objected to by the industrial sector, especially with the minimum tax rate system set to take effect starting Jan. 1.

The Legislative Yuan on Dec. 9 passed a law which requires companies that earn more than NT$2 million a year to pay between 10 percent and 12 percent in corporate income tax. Meanwhile, high-income individuals who earn more than NT$6 million per year are required to pay at least 20 percent in personal income tax.

DOC.HEADLINE: 688 FINALISTS IN CALLIGRAPHY CONTEST TO COMPETE ON NEW YEAR'S DAY

TEXT.P: The final round of Taoyuan County's fourth national calligraphy contest will take place on New Year's Day, with 688 finalists competing in the Taoyuan County Stadium.
These finalists, who excelled in preliminary contests that lasted more than two months, range in age from seven to 81.
They will be divided into seven age groups and demonstrate their calligraphic skills by writing Spring Festival couplets on red paper.
The annual national event is held by the Cultural Affairs Bureau of the Taoyuan County Government.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO TO PUSH FOR PROBE INTO KMT'S SALE OF MEDIA OUTLETS

TEXT.P: The Government Information Office (GIO) will ask the Ministry of Economic Affairs and national security agencies to probe into the opposition Kuomintang's (KMT's) recent sale of three news media outlets to determine whether any Chinese capital was involved, the GIO head said Tuesday.

GIO Minister Pasuya Yao said that the buyer -- a venture company invested in by a Cayman Islands-registered holding company which is in turn invested in and run by the China Times Group -- will also be asked to produce documents on its capital and financial structures to determine whether it is financed by any capital from China or overseas.

The KMT announced a day earlier that it has sold its controlling stakes in the Broadcasting Corp. of China (BCC), China Television Co. (CTV) and the Central Motion Picture Corp. (CMPC) to the China Times Group-run holding company for about NT$9 billion (US$272.73 million).

Yao reiterated that according to Taiwan law, terrestrial television companies must be 100-percent Taiwan owned and operated, meaning that no mainland Chinese or foreign investors are allowed to own shares in them.

Opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union Legislators Huang Shih-chuo and Lo Chih-ming accused the KMT at a press conference Tuesday of selling the KMT's three news media organizations to a buyer that is possibly backed with capital from China or other foreign countries.

Huang questioned whether the China Times Group had the financial viability to make the NT$9 billion purchase, pointing out that the group recently shut down its China Times Evening News because of financial difficulties.
Lo quoted other media reports as saying that Hong Kong's Li Ka Shing Group might have secretly financed the China Times Group in its purchase of the three KMT companies.
Under a law revised two years ago, Monday was the deadline for Taiwan's political parties, government and military to divest themselves of their investments in television and radio stations.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE MINISTRY COOL ON IDEA OF TURNING OLD DESTROYER INTO MUSEUM

TEXT.P: Acting Kaohsiung Mayor Yeh Chu-lan will continue lobbying the Ministry of National Defense to allow a WWII-era destroyer that has been decommissioned by the ROC Navy to be converted into a museum, an official of the Kaohsiung City Government said Tuesday.
The 3,480-ton "Shen Yang" destroyer was brought into service in the ROC Navy on Oct. 1, 1977. However, it was first commissioned in September 1945 by the U.S. Navy and christened "Power."

The ROC Navy decommissioned the vessel this year and had planned to scupper the ship to create an artificial home for sea life, but lawmakers felt that as the oldest operational Gearing-Class destroyer in the world, it should remain intact.

The defense ministry agreed to have the ship berthed in Kaohsiung Harbor, but has been cool to the idea of opening it as a tourist attraction. The Kaohsiung City Government has requested an annual budget of NT$15 million to operate and maintain the ship-turned museum.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOP PROSECUTOR QUITS AFTER PRESIDENT'S COMPLAINTS ABOUT VOTE-BUYING

TEXT.P: State Public Prosecutor-General Wu Ying-chao announced on Tuesday that he was resigning to take responsibility for not stamping out vote-buying in the just-concluded "three-in-one" elections.

Wu's decision to resign came after President Chen Shui-bian's remarks earlier in the day that bribery is still rampant despite the government's crackdown efforts over the past five years and that vote-buying in the Dec. 3 elections was even more serious than in the legislative elections in late 2004.
Wu presided over a review meeting Tuesday in Wulai, Taipei County on the results of anti-graft efforts in the run-up to the Dec. 3 elections.

In a statement issued later by the Supreme Prosecutor's Office, Wu said prosecutors put in long hours and had actually done quite a lot to stop vote-buying, but they were nevertheless severely criticised and misunderstood.
As of Dec. 26, prosecutors have filed charges in 750 bribery cases and prosecuted 2,511 people, Wu said, adding that whether in terms of cases or anti-bribery campaigns, they have set new highs.

But regrettably, some people and civic groups don't see the positive side of their efforts, Wu said. As the leader of all prosecutors, Wu said he felt uneasy and was deeply worried about the situation.

"I feel that it is incumbent upon me to step down to preserve the positive results that we have achieved and to stop the misunderstandings that many people have on the nature of our work and our successes. The independence and credibility of prosecutors must not be distorted," Wu said.

Wu, 66, said that he has worked in the judiciary since 1956, as a judge, a prosecutor and the head of the Prosecutors' Office, and he has made his mark in the battle against "black gold, " or dirty politics.
Wu was named by President Chen to take over the post from Lu Ren-fa in Sept. 1, 2004. Reactions about his appointment were mixed at the time.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Nomination of central bank governor should avoid political intervention, says Confindustria head.
Confindustria president Luca Cordero di Montezemolo said in a written statement that the nomination of new central bank governor should be free of political intervention in order to avoid veto and counter-veto campaigns which will deal another blow to the national credibility. He therefore suggested that the nomination would not be made in a hurry, but with a consensus of the two camps.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: A Political Debate On Stress Disorder; As Claims Rise, VA Takes Stock.
The spiraling cost of post-traumatic stress disorder among war veterans has triggered a politically charged debate and ignited fears that the government is trying to limit expensive benefits for emotionally scarred troops returning from Iraq and Afghanistan.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDUCATION REFORMERS CALL FOR END TO PHYSICAL PUNISHMENT

TEXT.P: Members of several civic groups devoted to education reforms urged lawmakers Tuesday to include a clause supporting "zero tolerance of physical punishment of children" in the Education Basic Law.
The members made the call one day before the Legislative Yuan's Education and Culture Committee is set to review draft amendments to the law.
Shih Ying, a leading member of the Humanistic Education Foundation, said giving up physical punishment does not mean giving up on disciplining children.

Instead, the purpose of banning physical punishment is to encourage teachers to make more effort on education and to think how to educate children with more reasonable and efficient methods, Shih said.
Huang Yu-chi from the Parents Society of Overseas Students argued that physical punishment is violence and that a civilized country should not allow violence in education.

According to data from the Humanistic Education Foundation, 101 countries around the world have banned physical punishment of children in school, and more than 20 have implemented a comprehensive ban on physical punishment.

In Taiwan, more than 90 civic organizations, 60 academics led by Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh, and 21 local government heads led by Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou have signed to support the campaign to end physical punishment.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Iraq Vote Shows Sunnis Are Few in New Military
An analysis of preliminary voting results released Monday from the Dec. 15 parliamentary election suggests that in contrast to the remarkable surge in Sunni Arab participation in the political process, the Sunnis still have comparatively little representation in the Iraqi security forces. The indication is troubling because Sunni Arabs, who are about 20 percent of Iraq's population, came out in greater numbers largely as a response to the recent domination of the government by Shiites and Kurds. In particular, Sunni Arabs say they fear that the security forces will be used against them.
Wall Street Journal: Playing Detective, At Medical Journal, Editor Finds Truth Hard to Track Down
In 1992, the British Medical Association's flagship journal published a study led by Indian doctor Ram B. Singh with a striking finding: Heart-attack victims who ate more fiber, fruits and vegetables for a year cut their risk of death during that period by almost half. A year later, Richard Smith, the journal's editor, received two letters questioning the findings. What followed was an extraordinary inquiry stretching over a dozen years and 5,000 miles. Along the way, Dr. Singh contended that termites had eaten crucial data and Dr. Smith spent four years begging a busy statistician to deliver a report. Finally this July, the journal, called BMJ, lowered the boom. Editors said they had "reasonable grounds to doubt the validity of the 1992 paper" and published an article calling the data in another paper submitted in 1994 " either fabricated or falsified." The long investigation points to a problem in medical research: While prestigious journals act as gatekeepers, awarding legitimacy to some papers and withholding it from others, they have little power to detect or investigate questionable findings. The outside experts who review articles before publication often fail to catch faked results.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD TO ENCOURAGE INVESTMENT IN DEEP-SEA RESOURCES

TEXT.P: The government has chosen Hualien and Taitung in eastern Taiwan to develop deep-sea resources, hoping to attract private investment of in excess of NT$10 billion (US$298.5 million) over the next five years, the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Tuesday.

Noting that Taiwan is surrounded by water, CEPD officials said that to develop Taiwan's distinctive deep sea resources, the council has formed a task force to provide a favorable investment environment.
They said that eastern Taiwan has a superb geographical environment, and that water resources will become an emerging star industry after tourism in Taitung and Hualien.
Products developed from the sea could represent a production value of around NT$18.9 billion every year.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOI ACTS TO REVIEW PRE-SCHOOL PROGRAM FOR KIDS OF FOREIGN MOTHERS

TEXT.P: A two-day seminar on the theory and practice of pre-school education for children born to foreign mothers began Tuesday in Pingtung, southern Taiwan under the sponsorship of the Ministry of the Interior's (MOI) Children's Bureau.

Bureau Director-General Huang Pi-hsia said that with the number of newborns to foreign mothers increasing in recent years, the country faces the challenge of how to give day care services and provide pre-school education to the children of the so-called "new immigrants," who are mostly from South Asia and China.

Last year, the bureau began an experimental program targeting kids born to foreign mothers, Huang said, explaining that the program is aimed at reinforcing Chinese-language skills for the children in their pre-school education.

Huang said attracted by effective results of the program, some 38 organizations in the pre-school education sector from 19 counties and cities around the country have applied for the government's financial assistance to adopt the program.
According to MOI statistics, one of seven newborns in the first 10 months of this years were born to foreign mothers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TOPS ASIA IN GERMAN iF PRODUCT DESIGN AWARDS

TEXT.P: Taiwan manufacturers won 63 iF Product Design Awards in Germany, surpassing Japan and South Korea to become Asia's big winner, according to the Industrial Development Bureau Tuesday. The two Asian neighbors won 45 and 43 awards, respectively.
Only host Germany won more awards than Taiwan in the design world's Oscar, which drew the participation of 1,952 products from 37 countries.
Taiwan's BenQ Corporation snatched 13 awards, placing third after Samsung of South Korea and Philips of the Netherlands in company rankings.
Another shining Taiwan company was DUCKIMAGE, a design company that won 10 awards in the Hannover, Germany, international forum.
Altogether, 688 products were given the coveted iF seal of design excellence. Of which, 50 gold award or "design Oscar" winners will be announced at CeBIT in March, 2006.
Since 2004, the bureau has been assisting Taiwan manufacturers to participate in product design competitions abroad.
In 2005, 105 Taiwan products won key awards at five major international competitions, including the Reddot Award in Germany, the IDEA Award in the U.S. and the G-Mark in Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMS PACKAGE PIVOTAL TO TAIWAN-U.S. RELATIONS: FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: The arms procurement package pending in the Legislative Yuan is a decisive factor in future Taiwan-U.S. relations, Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen said Tuesday.
Chen made the remarks at a year-end ministry news conference Tuesday.
"Taiwan-U.S. relations have improved quite a bit this year and there is no reason to foresee a negative change. U.S. President George W. Bush's speech in Kyoto last month is evidence of this.

However, subtle changes are not easy to detect and a key unresolved issue is the U.S. arms purchase package. If it clears the legislative floor, it will show Taiwan's determination to defend itself," he said.
Chen said he thinks opposition leaders will eventually make concessions and that this January is the best time to observe their behavior in this regard.
"There is a limit to boycotting the arms deal. If it goes too far, the people will express their disagreement. Politicians should take into account these possible consequences," Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSUNAMI RELIEF AFFECTS LOCAL GROUPS' FUND-RAISING: POLL

TEXT.P: Fund-raising programs of many local public-interest groups have been affected by the massive post-tsunami relief campaign, United Way Taiwan (UWT) said Tuesday.

Quoting tallies compiled by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, a UWT spokesman said annual philanthropic donations in Taiwan amount to NT$40 billion. After a devastating tsunami hit South and Southeast Asian countries on Dec. 26, 2004, Taiwan citizens donated about NT$5 billion for various relief programs in the hardest-hit regions.

According to a survey conducted by UWT between June and July this year, the spokesman said, 60 percent of local public-interest groups surveyed said tsunami-related relief efforts have affected their fund-raising drives.
About 10 percent of the respondents said the philanthropic donations they received after the tsunami disaster have declined by more than 31 percent from their previous level.
The UWT distributed questionnaires to 1,444 public-interest groups which have received its financial aid over the years and received 415 valid replies.

In addition to the tsunami factor, the spokesman said, a domestic economic slowdown and the public's increasing reluctance to donate have also contributed to difficulties in public-interest groups' fund-raising.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT PLEDGES NOT TO GIVE UP ON DEMOCRACY, FREEDOM

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday that democracy, freedom and human rights are goals that he will never give up as the leader of the country.

Chen expressed the hope that Taiwan will keep pace with the rest of the world in terms of its development in democracy, freedom and human rights so that the world will take pride in Taiwan's achievements.
The president made the remarks while receiving managers of three schools for Taiwanese expatriate children in Japan.
Chen said the Taiwanese expatriates in Japan are heroes who have contributed to the close relations between Taiwan and Japan despite China's suppression of Taiwan.
Citing official data, Chen said visitor arrivals from Japan are expected to top 1.1 million this year, while Taiwan visitors to Japan are expected to exceed 1.3 million.
Bilateral trade is expected to top US$60 billion this year, with Japan becoming the country with which Taiwan has the highest unfavorable trade balance, Chen noted.

Meanwhile, Chen said, Taiwanese expatriates in Japan have actively promoted academic and cultural exchanges between both countries, which he said have seen the number of Japanese high school students studying in Taiwan increase to 3,452 this year from 1,640 in the past.
In addition, the Taiwanese expatriate school in Yokohama has admitted 15 percent of its student body from around the world, playing an essential role in connecting Taiwan to the world, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: VIENNA ORCHESTRA'S NEW YEAR'S CONCERT TO BE BROADCASTED IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: The Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra's annual new year's concert will be broadcasted live at a plaza near Kaohsiung's Love River on Jan. 1 at 8: 30 p.m., Kaohsiung City officials announced Tuesday.
The concert was first held in 1941. This year, well-known Taiwanese cellist Chang Chen-chieh will be playing.
The Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra's new year concert is one of the most important annual events in classical music and over one billion people around the world will be listening.
Music from Mozart to Strauss will be played this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUYER OF KMT MEDIA MUM ON WHETHER CHINESE CAPITAL INVOLVED

TEXT.P: The China Times Group, which bought three media outlets from the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , declined to comment Tuesday whether mainland Chinese capital had been involved in the purchase.

The group acquired the KMT's shares in the Broadcasting Corporation of China (BCC) and two other media outlets for NT$4 billion and agreed to take over their total debts of NT$5.3 billion in a deal that was completed Monday.
The Government Information Office demanded to know if Chinese capital had been involved in the transaction.
In reply to reporters' questions, China Times' Editor in Chief Huang Ching-lung said, "No comment." He suggested that they turn to the KMT for an answer.
KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou told reporters that there was no Hong Kong or "so-called Chinese" capital involved.
Chang Che-chen, KMT deputy secretary, who has been in charge of negotiating the deal, said the China Times Group had told him that there was "absolutely no foreign or Hong Kong capital" involved.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOW TOP PROSECUTOR IS FIELDED IS KEY QUESTION: WU YING-CHAO

TEXT.P: State Public Prosecutor-General Wu Ying-chao said Tuesday that he chose to resign now because it will make more room for the executive and legislative branches to engage in rational discussion on how the nation's top prosecutor should be fielded in the future.

Wu made the remarks in an interview with CNA after tendering his resignation earlier in the day -- apparently in response to a complaint by President Chen Shui-bian that vote-buying had become more serious in the run-up to the Dec. 3 local government elections, compared with the legislative elections in 2004.

He said that actually the idea of quitting crossed his mind a week ago, and that he hopes the ruling and opposition parties can have rational discussions on whether a nominee named by the president in the future for the post of public prosecutor-general needs the approval of the legislature.

Currently, a nominee for the post is named by the minister of justice and appointed by the president, without consent from the legislature. Opposition legislators have complained that as a political appointee with no clearly defined term of office, the public prosecutor-general is susceptible to influence from the president and the premier.

The "pan-blue alliance" of the two main opposition parties -- the Kuomintang and the People First Party -- have introduced legislation through their legislative caucuses, seeking to make the public prosecutor-general an independent post with a clearly set term of office, so that he or she will be armed with the necessary power to investigate and prosecute wrongdoings by the president and the premier.
A spokesman for the Presidential Office said late Tuesday that President Chen will consider the matter after receiving Wu's resignation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TVBS IS BEST-KNOWN TV STATION IN TAIWAN: POLL

TEXT.P: The TVBS cable station is the best-known television station in Taiwan, according to the results of a survey released Tuesday by a market research company.
The survey was conducted by InsightXplorer in cooperation with Ipsos Taiwan in October on 1,620 people. It had a margin of error of plus or minus 2.48 percentage points.
The survey showed that the familiarity of TVBS tops other competitors among residents in northern Taiwan, men, and Internet users.
The China Television Company performs the best among terrestrial TV stations, having the highest recognition among residents in central Taiwan and people between 15 and 19 years old.
Formosa Television (FTV) came in third in terms of its overall ranking, but its recognition is highest among residents in southern Taiwan, women, and older people.
Sanlih Entertainment Television is best known among young people between 10 and 14 years old.
While the Eastern Broadcasting Company has the second-highest recognition among Internet users, FTV is the best known among non-Internet users.
Meanwhile, the Apple Daily is the best known newspaper among residents in southern Taiwan, and the China Times is the best known among residents in northern and central Taiwan.
The Apple Daily is also the best known among people between 10 to 24 years of age, while the China Times and United Daily News are best known among older people.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIR FORCE INSTALLS DIGITAL RADAR SYSTEM

TEXT.P: A new digital radar system was inaugurated at an ROC Air Force base in the northern county of Taoyuan Tuesday.
It was the first of 10 digital radar systems to be installed at major air bases around the country under a radar upgrading plan, code-named "An-Lei."
Air Force Commander-in-Chief Gen. Liu Kuei-li, Air Force Operations Commander Lee Kuei-fa and Communications and ATC Wing chief Liu Hsi-lieh jointly presided over the inauguration ceremony.

Addressing the ceremony, Liu Kuei-li said the inauguration ushers in a new era in the Air Force's flight control, marking the replacement of the conventional analog radar with an advanced digital radar system.
With the new radar equipment, the air force's top commander said warplane flight control will be safer and more efficient.
Under the "An-Lei" program, two more new digital radars will be installed and seven existing analog radars will be upgraded to the same functional levels by the end of 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR DECEMBER 28 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Wednesday, December 28:
09:00, The Executive Yuan will hold a weekly meeting at its head office.
10:00, The ruling Democratic Progressive Party will hold a seminar on the challenges and strategies for constitutional reform.
13:30, The Taiwan Research Institute will hold a seminar on financial issues.
15:00, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng will invite party whips from across the political spectrum to consult the NCC issue.
16:30, The Ministry of Finance will hold an year-end news briefing.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEGOTIATIONS WITH SOMALI REBELS ENTERING FINAL STAGE: MOFA

TEXT.P: All the three Taiwan fishing vessels and their crew that have been held by Somali rebels since this past August remain safe and negotiations for their release have entered a final stage, Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen said Tuesday.
Speaking at a year-end news conference, Chen said the two sides are now negotiating how the ransom money can be remitted their captors.
According to Chen, Somali rebels released a Kenya freighter in late November, but they still hold hostage six foreign vessels, including the three Taiwan tuna fishing boats.

Over the past four months, Chen said staff members from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs's West Asian and African departments have kept close contact with the ship owners and family members of the detained crew.

"We have made every possible effort to push for an early release of the three ships and their crew. Negotiations have reached a decisive stage. We are talking about how to remit ransom money to Somali rebels," Chen said.
He also urged local fishermen to refrain from operating in waters that have been declared as "dangerous."

Noting that the government has long warned local fishermen not to operate in waters adjacent to Somali which has long sunk into anarchy, Chen said the government has spent a lot of resources trying to rescue the three abducted ships and their crew in the past four months.
The ships had three Taiwanese captains and 45 international crew members, including 14 Indonesians, 13 Chinese, 12 Filipinos and six Vietnamese.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SHOULD HAVE DONATED CTV STAKES TO DA-AI TV: DPP

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) should have donated its stakes in China Television Co. (CTV) to Da-Ai Television run by the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation instead of selling its holdings to a private business group, the legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Tuesday.

To meet the Dec. 26 deadline for the government, military and political parties to pull out of media operations, the KMT announced Monday it has sold its stakes in CTV and two other media outlets -- the Broadcasting Corp. of China (BCC) and the Central Motion Picture Corp. (CMPC) to a holding company led by China Times Group Chairman Yu Chien-hsin for about NT$9 billion.
Claiming that the KMT has improperly obtained the three media outlets, DPP legislative whip William Lai said it's a shame for the KMT to sell these ill-gotten party assets.
"It should have returned them to the national coffers or at least donated them to public-interest groups," Lai said.

The Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra's new year concert is one of the most important annual events in classical music and over one billion people around the world will be listening.

Air Force Commander-in-Chief Gen. Liu Kuei-li, Air Force Operations Commander Lee Kuei-fa and Communications and ATC Wing chief Liu Hsi-lieh jointly presided over the inauguration ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Dec. 28, or the 28th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1836: Spain recognizes Mexico's independence.
1856: Thomas Woodrow Wilson, American statesman and Democratic president (1913-21), is born.
1881: China's first telegraph line linking Tientsin and Shanghai is made available for public use.
1908: The most violent earthquake ever recorded in Europe destroys the city of Messina in Sicily, killing more than half of its 150,000 inhabitants and causing a giant tidal wave.
1912: City-run streetcars in San Francisco, California, begin operating.
1919: Feng Kuo-chang, a warlord who led the Chihli faction of the powerful Peiyang army during the first decade of the Republic of China, dies in Peking (Beijing) at the age of 62.
1923: Alexandre Gustave Eiffel, the French engineer who designed the 300-meter-high Eiffel Tower for the Paris Exhibition of 1889, dies at the age of 91.
1931: The ROC government is reformed, with Lin Sen made chairman.
1945: The Big Three Foreign Ministers' Conference in Moscow announces agreements on the establishment of a Commission and Allied Council for Japan, the ultimate establishment of a free Korea, and the withdrawal of Soviet and U.S. troops from China.
1950: Mainland Chinese troops cross the 38th parallel in Korea.
1962: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs declares that the border agreements signed between the Beijing regime and Outer Mongolia and Pakistan are illegal and non-binding for the Republic of China.
1966: Mainland China detonates its fifth atomic bomb.
1968: The ROC opens a telecommunications satellite earth station on Yangmingshan.
1971: Grand Justice Tien Chun-chin is appointed as president of the ROC's Judicial Yuan.
1972: The Republic of China's Embassy in Tokyo and the consulates-general in Osaka, Yokohama and Fukuoka are formally closed.
1974: The Republic of China-Bahamas Cultural and Economic Association is inaugurated in Taipei.
1974: The Republic of China suspends diplomatic relations with Gambia following the latter's recognition of the Peiping (Beijing) regime.
1976: The millionth visitor of the year to the Republic of China, Wilhelm Mulmann, professor of sociology and anthropology at the University of Heidleberg, Germany, and his wife are welcomed by officials of the Tourism Bureau.
1976: Education Minister Y.S. Tsiang presents a gold medal and citation to Yen Tjing-ling, board chairman of the Yue Loong Motors Co. Ltd., for his contribution to an industrial research center at National Taiwan University.
1987: The Development Bank of Shenzhen, the first private share-holding bank on the Chinese mainland, is inaugurated.
1988: The first instance of a baby born with Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS) in Taiwan is recorded.
1993: A plane belonging to mainland China's Fujian Airlines is hijacked to Taiwan by Luo Chang-hua and his wife Wang Yu-ying in the 10th hijacking of the year.
1995: In Beijing, judges reject an appeal by dissident Wei Jingsheng, upholding his 14-year sentence on charges of trying to overthrow the Beijing government.
1995: Beijing names the committee responsible for steering Hong Kong through its transition from British colony to Chinese Special Administration Region in 1997.
1999: Taiwan changes the name of its representative office in Macau from Taipei Economic and Cultural Office to Taipei Economic and Cultural Center, Macau.
2000: The Formosa Plastics Group presents its first sedan -- the Formosa Magnus 2.0 -- which was manufactured via technical cooperation with South Korea's Daewoo Group.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Possession of power without generosity; courtesy without seriousness; mourning without grief -- I have no desire to look at such a state of things."

The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Wednesday are as follows:
