DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: RP, Korea sign labor accord
The Philippines and South Korea have agreed to enhance bilateral cooperation to gradually increase the number of skilled overseas Filipino workers (OFWs) deployed to Korea, the Department of Labor and Employment (DoLE) said yesterday.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: 4 GIs charged with rape
Olongapo Prosecutor Prudencio Jalandoni and Assistant Prosecutor Raymond Viray yesterday filed rape charges against four of the original six American suspects and their Filipino driver, and demanded custody of the Americans and their detention in an Olongapo jail.
The Philippine Star: 'Let people decide on no-el'
In the wake of the controversy generated by the proposal of the presidential consultative commission to scrap the 2007 elections, con-com secretary general Lito Monico Lorenzana called yesterday for sobriety and said approving this proposal is up to the people.
The Manila Times: 'Poll officials can be charged now'
SENATE Minority Leader Aquilino Pimentel Jr. on Tuesday reiterated that top officials of the Commission on Elections (Comelec) involved in the P1 .3-billion poll automation contract, which has been called the"Comelec modernization scam, "can be charged and prosecuted without being first impeached and found guilty by Congress.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Second crash search yields fifth fatality
Acting on reports three people were still unaccountable for in Sunday's deadly train derailment, authorities resumed their search of the wreckage Tuesday and found psrt of another body, bringing the death toll to five.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: State's Tobacco Revenue Surges.
As an epidemic of tobacco tax evasion drains state treasuries across the nation, California is defying the trend with aggressive, hightech enforcement that has cigarette tax revenue surging. State officials are reporting an increase of tens of millions of dollars in tabacco taxes for the first time in years.

DOC.HEADLINE: PENSION REFORM EXPECTED TO BE IMPLEMENTED FROM FEB. 1: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Wednesday that the government's pension reform program is expected to be implemented beginning Feb. 1, 2006, if the reform scheme is passed by the Examination Yuan in time.

Speaking at the last Executive Yuan meeting of the year, Hsieh said that the pension reform program should be implemented as soon as possible to help achieve social justice and fairness as President Chen Shui-bian has advocated.

Under the existing scheme, some retirees receive more money per month than they actually earned prior to retirement, due mainly to the preferential 18-percent deposit interest rate available to retired civil servants, military personnel and teachers.

"This unreasonable phenomenon should be changed because it has become a bone of contention for the general public and a heavy financial burden for the government, " President Chen said earlier this year.

According to a reform scheme adopted by the Examination Yuan, for retirees who worked as civil servants for at least 25 years, the post-retirement income -- including monthly pension, the preferential deposit interest and year-end bonus money -- will not be more than 85 percent of the pay they were receiving at the time of their retirement. The ratio will be no more than 95 percent for those who worked for at least 35 years.
Slightly more than 80,000 current and retired civil servants will see their pensions reduced under the new scheme.
In addition to civil servants, the new scheme will also be applied to military personnel and school teachers.

Looking back on the past 11 months, Hsieh said that the Executive Yuan's administrative operations could be described in one sentence: Economic growth has staggered forward while reform has continued amid controversy.
He said that despite a year that featured high oil prices, the avian flu threat, and disturbances arising from Beijing's passage of an anti-secession law, Taiwan's economy still managed to grow.
Despite pessimism at some points during the year, the economy's performance has turned out to be "not bad at all," he added.

The premier said there are several points worth celebrating, including the fact that the unemployment rate dipped to a five-year low, per capita income exceeded US$15,000, the central government's tax revenues has topped NT$100 billion (US$3.03 billion) and the real estate market experienced moderate growth, to name a few.

As to the reform programs the government has been pushing, Hsieh said that it is normal that reforms are sometimes controversial and that history shows that not all reforms are successful. Nevertheless, he said that it is laudable that despite some controversy, Taiwan has been able to march forward and make breakthroughs in reform.

DOC.HEADLINE: CSBC ORDERS STAND AT US$2.68 BILLION

TEXT.P: The China Shipbuilding Corp. (CSBC) said in a report it issued Wednesday that the company currently has orders totalling more than NT$90 billion (US$2.68 billion) to build vessels.
The written report was presented by the CSBC to the Science and Technology Committee of the Legislative Yuan which is set to review the CSBC's budget for next year.
The brisk business will help the company continue its efforts to improve its financial structure and promote its privatization, the CSBC report said.
The CSBC said that it currently has orders worth NT$78.32 billion to build 51 commercial ships and orders worth NT$12.61 billion to build 30 military vessels.
It has therefore listed its post-tax profits at NT$285 million for 2006, up 17.28 precent from the figure for 2005, mainly because of increased business.

Following on the heels of the hot demand seen in 2003 and 2004, orders for new ships reached a peak in May 2005, with orders and prices for new vessels declining in the latter half of the year, the CSBC said.
Looking ahead, the company said that most market research reports have not been optimistic about the period to the end of the first quarter of 2006, the company said.

The report said that because of steep competition and a slump in vessel prices, the company suffered heavy losses in 2000 and then launched a "rejuvenation program" in 2001, under which one first-grade department and 50 second-grade units were phased out and 2,280 staff members were axed, while those who stayed on took a 35-percent pay cut.

Besides the downsizing move, the CSBC has also adopted many other measures to cope with cut-throat competition in the sluggish global shipbuilding market which have greatly improved the financial situation of the company.
The company said that it has registered profits every month since 2001 and that its competitiveness is on par with Japan's and South Korea's shipbuilding industries.
The ships designed and built by the company have also won recognition in the international community, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF 'VIETNAMESE BRIDES' DECLINES DUE TO INTERVIEW SYSTEM
DOC.DATELINE: Ho Chi Minh City, Dec. 28 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The number of Vietnamese women marrying Taiwan men plummeted this year, mainly because of the resumption of the individual interview program by the Republic of China government, a liaison source said here Wednesday.

Due to the regulation that Vietnamese women planning to marry Taiwanese men are required to visit the Taiwan liaison office in Ho Chi Minh City or Hanoi to be interviewed individually, the number of Vietnamese woman marrying Taiwan nationals declined by 70 percent to 3,461 in the first 11 months of this year from 12,202 in 2004, said Chen Shan-lin, representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Ho Chi Minh City.

The ROC government withdrew the individual interview regulation in 1999 and allowed potential "Vietnamese brides" to be interviewed in groups, resulting in a record high 13,863 marriages between Vietnamese women and Taiwan men that year.

The figure averaged 12,000 annually between 2000 and 2004, Chen said, adding that the Taiwan office in Ho Chi Minh City approved a total of 90,215 Vietnamese women to go to Taiwan after marrying Taiwan citizens between 1995 and November 2005. The total number exceeds 100,000 if the approvals issued by Taiwan's liaison office in Hanoi are included, he added.

Under the individual interview system, the average period between a Vietnamese woman filing an application and departing for Taiwan is about eight months, Chen said, adding that the average wait for an interview in Ho Chi Minh City is about six months due to the large number of applicants.

Consequently, marriage brokers have since this year begun to encourage potential "Vietnamese brides" to submit their applications in Hanoi instead of Ho Chi Minh City to accelerate the process, Chen said, noting that the average wait for an interview in the Vietnamese capital is only between one and two months.

According to Chen, potential "Taiwan husbands" usually fly into Vietnam on the weekend where arrangements are made for them to meet with their potential brides. If the couple hit it off, they usually get married Saturday or Sunday and then jointly file applications with the Taiwan offices in Vietnam for entrance into Taiwan Monday or Tuesday.

About half of the Taiwan men marrying Vietnamese women are between 30 and 40 years old, while about 23 percent are aged between 41 and 50. By comparison, some 77 percent of the Vietnamese women marrying Taiwan men are between 20 and 30 years old, while some 14 percent are under the age of 20.

Nearly 67 percent of the Taiwan men marrying Vietnamese women have a junior high school level education, and about 20 percent have a senior high school education. By comparison, 63 percent of the Vietnamese women have an elementary school education, and 28 percent have a junior high education, according to Chen.

DOC.HEADLINE: CRIMINAL CASES INVOLVING FOREIGNERS UP 50% IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: There were 1,659 criminal cases involving foreigners in Taipei from January to November 2005, up 50 percent from the same period last year, according to tallies released Wednesday by the Taipei City Government.
In the 11 months to November, 193.75 out of every 10,000 foreigners were involved in a criminal case, representing an increase of 44.59 cases year-on-year.
There were 83,031 foreigners residing or staying for a short term in the capital city as of the end of November, down 5.88 percent compared with the same time last year.
A total of 56,959, or 69 percent, of the foreigners had right of residence as of the end of November, 72 percent of whom were women.

By nationality, Vietnamese and Filipinos were the two largest groups of foreigners as of the end of November, but their numbers decreased by 13.82 percent and 3.12 percent, respectively, compared with the same time last year.
The number of Indonesians residing in Taipei increased 63 percent, and that of Americans rose 5.14 percent.
Foreigners staying for a short term in Taipei City totaled 26,072 as of the end of November, down 21 percent from the same time last year.

As of the end of November, 3.17 out of every 100 residents in Taipei City were foreigners, which was 0.19 less than at the same time last year but was higher than the figure of 1.55 in Kaohsiung City and 2.1 for the entire Taiwan area.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ECONOMIC GROWTH TO HIT 4.04 PERCENT FOR 2006: THINK TANK

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy is forecast to expand 4.04 percent in 2006, with the performance of many sectors expected to improve, the Taiwan Research Institute reported Wednesday.

Researchers from the think-tank's Division of Business and Administration said that Taiwan is expected to post economic growth of 3.78 percent for this year mainly as a result of the export trade sector's mediocre performance.
For 2006, they said, economic growth is forecast to be higher as consumer spending rebounds and imports and exports of goods and services increase.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA HELPING SCAVENGERS ADJUST TO NEW GARBAGE ASSORTMENT PROGRAM

TEXT.P: About 1,500 people around the island making a living as scavengers are being helped by a program set up by the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) to help them adapt to the new garbage assortment program, an EPA official said Wednesday.

In anticipation of the negative effect on the scavengers' livelihood of the administration's decision to expand the compulsory garbage assortment program from several metropolitan areas to the whole country Jan.1, the official said the EPA came up with the program to cushion the impact on scavengers.
Under the program, the EPA official said, part of the local governments' revenues from selling recyclable material has been used to buy tricycles or pushcarts for scavengers to ply their trade.

Also, the official said, the local governments' garbage collecting teams have offered safety training programs to scavengers and enlisted their help in gathering recyclable materials in alleys and lanes located far from the regular routes of garbage trucks.

Citing the Taichung City Government's program as an example, the official said that scavengers there were given certificates, badges and jerseys after completing the city government's training program and that these individuals are now allowed to enter official buildings and apartment buildings to collect recyclable materials rather than being confined to searching through garbage bins located on the streets.
The official said the EPA is also seeking donations from private firms to buy pushcarts and tricycles for scavengers.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Enron Executive Agrees to Plea Deal; Prosecutors Gain Witness Against Lay and Skilling.
Enron Corp.'s former chief accountant agreed to plead guilty today to criminal conduct that preceded the company's collapse into bankruptcy, according to sources familiar with the negotiations, sealing a deal that gives prosecutors another key witness against former chief executives Kenneth L. Lay and Jeffrey K. Skilling on the eve of their fraud trial.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Surprise simulated attacks on MRT and buses.
Singapore is mounting its biggest civil emergency exercise some time next month, with simulated attacks on the public transport system.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Singapore will hold a big emergency exercise for MRT, bus bombings.
Singapore's civil emergency agencies are going to test their readiness to respond to multiple bomb attacks at MRT stations and bus interchanges next month.
A major exercise will be held over the weekend in the first two weeks of January next year, but the public will not be told in advance of the exact date, time and the venues.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF CHAIRMAN'S OFFER TO ATTEND WANG'S FUNERAL DECLINED

TEXT.P: Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chang Chun-hsiung's offer to visit Shangahi to pay his last respects to Wang Daohan, the late chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARTAS), has been declined, a SEF official said Wednesday.

You Ying-lung, SEF secretary-general, said the SEF had asked its Beijing counterpart the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) to respond quickly to its offer Tuesday and that the ARATS replied on Wednesday by declining the offer.

The ARATS also quoted Wang's family as saying that they want "as simple a funeral as possible" and regret that they cannot "invite all the good friends of our father and representatives of the organizations to Shanghai for the funeral."
You said that Chang "will respect the wishes" of Wang's family by not attending the funeral, adding that he will pay his respects at a later time when the chance arises.

Chang sent a letter of condolence to Wang Daohan's son Wang Yu upon learning the news of his father's death Saturday. In the letter, Chang affirmed Wang's contribution to cross-strait relations and expressed the hope that Wang's family could inform him of the funeral time so that he could go pay his last respects in person.
The SEF and ARATS are semi-official organizations set up by Taipei and Beijing, respectively, to handle cross-strait affairs in the absence of official ties.

Reports said that Chinese leaders will attend Wang's funeral scheduled for Dec. 30 and that representatives from Taiwan will include family members of Koo Chen-fu, late SEF chairman and predecessor of Chang, those who were involved in the "Koo-Wang" talks in Singapore in 1993, former ranking officials of the SEF, as well as representatives from the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang, People First Party and New Party.
When Koo passed away in January, Wang sent two ranking ARATS officials to Taipei to attend Koo's funeral.

Koo and Wang signed four agreements on cross-strait technical affairs during the 1993 Singapore talks, which paved the way for the later institutionalized channel of consultations between the two sides.
But the cross-strait dialogue was suspended in mid-1999 after then-President Lee Teng-hui's remarks defining cross-strait relations as "special state-to-state" in nature.
Beijing has not resumed the dialogue with Taipei during the past five years since the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party came to power.

DOC.HEADLINE: POST-SESSION BUYING OF TSMC SHARES SETS NEW RECORD

TEXT.P: Foreign investment houses bought NT$120.1 billion (US$3.63 billion) in Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. (TSMC) stocks after the market closed Wednesday, a record post-session transaction volume that caught the attention of investors.

The institutional buyers purchased 1,927,811,000 shares of the world's leading contract chip-maker at NT$62.3 per share, setting a record high in a post-session transaction of a single company's stocks.
TSMC said it was looking into this "unusual situation."
The company's stocks opened at NT$62.5 and closed at NT$63.5, down NT$0.3 from the previous session.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEEDS TO RESUME TALKS WITH CHINA TO GET INITIATIVE: KMT

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Wednesday that Taiwan needs to take several steps, including resuming dialogue, signing a peace accord and expanding economic and trade exchanges with China, in order to gain the initiative in cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
During an interview with the Voice of America, Ma said he will deal with cross-strait relations based on the principle of "Taiwan first."

Ma proposed that Taiwan seek to resume talks with China as soon as possible and sign a peace accord that covers the establishment of a military confidence-building mechanism to avoid a cross-strait military crisis.

In addition, Taiwan should expand its economic and trade relations with China, especially lifting its ban on direct cross-strait transportation, business and postal links, so that Taiwan businesses can reach their market and obtain raw materials faster, Ma said.
"Only if Taiwan adopts a more open policy will the country enjoy the opportunity to secure the initiative in cross-strait relations, " Ma said.

He said more Chinese citizens should be allowed to visit Taiwan to give them a better understanding of Taiwan's democracy and economic prosperity, which he said will help build up friendship between the people of the two sides and avoid the outbreak of war.
"Taiwan's national security must not depend solely on weapons but on working toward a cessation of cross-strait hostility through political, cultural and artistic means," he said.
Ma said people of this generation should manage the cross-strait political dispute properly, although they may not have the ability to solve the problem.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dropped against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, losing NT$0.025 to close at NT$33.107.
A total of US$990 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.163 and fluctuated between NT$33.1 and NT$33.17.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 7.19 points to close at 6,524.4.
The bourse opened at 6,492.8 and fluctuated between 6,530.02 and 6,479.34 during trading. A total of 3.88 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$97.5 billion (US$2.9 billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with paper and pulp stocks moving down the most at 0.4 percent, followed by construction issues and machinery and electronics shares both at 0.2 percent, and textile issues at 0.1 percent.
Three of the major stock categories gained ground, with cement issues moving up the most at 1.2 percent, followed by foodstuff shares at 0.2 percent, and banking and financial stocks at 0.1 percent.
Plastics and chemicals shares remained unchanged.
Losers outnumbered gainers 627 to 423, with 156 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for January moved down 17 points to close at 6,550, with 19,686 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for February moved down eight points to end at 6,555, with 112 contracts traded, while March futures lost 24 points to finish at 6,555, with 61 contracts traded. June futures dropped 25 points to close at 6,536, with 28 contracts traded, while September futures slid 11 points to close at 6,430, with 35 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 6,567 for January, 6,563 for February, 6,579 for March, 6,561 for June and 6,441 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly lower.

January TE futures moved down 1.7 points to close at 288.3, with 3,558 contracts traded, while February TE futures lost 1.4 points to finish at 288.5, with 28 contract transactions. September TE futures lost 2.35 points to end at 283, with one contract traded.
No transaction was recorded for March and June.

January TF futures gained 1.2 points to finish at 897.4, with 1,103 contracts changing hands, while February TF futures remained unchanged at 899.6, with 25 contracts traded. March TF lost 1.8 points to finish at 896, with one contract transaction, while September TF futures moved up 4.2 points to close at 890.4, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for June.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT INTROSPECTIVE SINCE LOCAL ELECTIONS SETBACK

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that he has been introspective over the past several weeks in the wake of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) defeat in the Dec. 3 local government elections and has been pondering delivering an important speech to the country on Jan. 1, 2006.

Chen denied that he has been left a "lame duck" as some opposition politicians have claimed and that instead, he has been thinking deeply about the reasons behind the DPP's poor showing in the "three-in-one" elections.
The president further said that his forthcoming New Year's address will be more significant than his inauguration speeches in 2000 and 2004.

Chen made the remarks outside the National Taiwan University Hospital where he received his regular annual health check-up. Medical professionals at the center gave the president high marks for his health.

Nevertheless, Chen said that he "stumbled and fell" upon the DPP's humiliating defeat in the latest elections, in which the ruling party won only six of the 23 city mayor and county magistrate posts up for grabs. The opposition "pan-blue alliance" led by the Kuomintang won 17 posts.

Despite the setback, Chen stressed that he has not been defeated. Instead, he said, he has become even stronger, living up to his being "the Son of Taiwan" -- who becomes more resilient and stronger after his arms are broken.
He offered his appreciation to "everybody" for helping him to avoid becoming "lame" after the elections.

Meanwhile, he declined to answer reporters' questions as to whether he will try to retain State Public Prosecutor-General Wu Ying-chao who offered to resign Monday to "make more room for the executive and legislative branches to engage in rational discussion on how the nation's top prosecutor should be fielded in the future."

Wu offered to resign apparently in response to a complaint by President Chen Shui-bian that "vote-buying had become more serious in the run-up to the Dec. 3 local government elections, compared with the legislative elections in 2004."

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA'S ADOPTION OF ANTI-SESSION LAW TOP 2005 CHINA NEWS STORY: CNA

TEXT.P: The Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan and the appreciation of the Chinese currency were the top two news stories out of China, according to a straw poll by senior editors at Taiwan's Central News Agency.

The Chinese National People's Congress passed the law on March 14, 2005, threatening the "use of non-peaceful means" against Taiwan should it move formally toward independence. The law, which aims at deterring independence and promoting unification, drew immediate condemnation from Taiwan and the international community.

Pressured by the United States and European countries, China announced the appreciation of the yuan in July by 2.1 percent and replaced its fixed peg to the U.S. dollar by linking it to a basket of foreign currencies.

The third top story was China's latest manned space flight with the launch of the Shenzhou VI Oct. 12. The two astronauts aboard the spaceship returned triumphantly to earth after completing several experiments in space.

The fourth top story was Chinese National Congress appointing President Hu Jintao as chairman of the Central Military Commission in March, making him the paramount leader in control of the party, the government as well as the military.

The fifth top story was both sides of the Taiwan Strait reaching an agreement on "two-way, non-stop and multiple-point" charter flights during the Chinese Lunar New Year holidays in 2005, the first two-way direct flights across the Taiwan Strait after a hiatus of 56 years.

The sixth and the seventh top stories were the face-off between China and Japan over the exploitation of oil in the East China Sea and the increasing worries by the World Health Organization after several outbreaks of avian flu in China. Taiwan also heightened its alert in view of the close personnel exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait and China's lack of transparency in reporting disease outbreaks in the past.

China's huge foreign currency reserves was the eighth top story. Its foreign currently reserve topped US$913 billion, surpassing Japan to become the country with the largest foreign currency reserves.

The six-party talks with the mediation of China resulted in North Korea agreeing to give up the development of nuclear weapons. China emerged as the biggest winner in the talks after it proved it could play a major role in international affairs.

Rounding out the top-10 was China's two-pronged carrot-and-stick approach toward Taiwan. China has on the one hand tried to intimidate Taiwan with the Anti-Session Law, but on the other tried to woo the people of Taiwan and Taiwan businessmen with several incentives, and has given the red-carpet treatment to pro-unification opposition leaders from Taiwan, trying to drive a wedge between the people of Taiwan.
The 10-top news stories were determined as of events that took place previous to Nov. 30, 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW LABOR PENSION SYSTEM TOP 2005 TAIWAN STORY: CNA

TEXT.P: The adoption of the new labor pension system was selected by senior editors from the Central News Agency in a straw poll as the year's top Taiwan news story.
The July 1 implementation of the new labor pension system, which will affect 3.16 million or 60 percent of Taiwan's workers, topped the list of significant domestic news for 2005.
Second was the precedent-setting direct charter flights across the Taiwan Strait during the Chinese Lunar New Year holidays, a service that was reinstated after a 56-year hiatus.

The third was Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan's historic visit to China in May, which led to China's goodwill gestures to Taiwan, such as offering Taiwan two pandas as gifts -- which Taiwan has yet to accept -- importing Taiwan fruits at zero-tariff and allowing Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan.

Fourth was the scandal revolving around the construction of Kaohsiung's mass rapid transit (MRT) system, a scandal that surfaced after Thai laborers working on the project rioted in late August in protest against their inhumane treatment by a local manpower management company.
In connection with the MRT scandal, Council of Labor Affairs Chairwoman Chen Chu and acting Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chi-mai resigned.

The MRT scandal story was followed by the passing of a set of constitutional amendments that included raising the bar for future changes to the ROC Constitution, cutting the number of seats in the legislature by approximately half and extending lawmakers' terms of office to four years. Lawmakers will also be elected under a new system called "single constituency with two votes."

Sixth on the list was the landslide victory of Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou as the first directly elected chairman of the Kuomintang (KMT) . He defeated Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng in the race.
Ranked seventh was the legislature's passing of the controversial bill concerning the organization of the National Communications Commission (NCC).

Eighth was the Executive Yuan cutting the budget for purchasing three major military weapons from NT$610.8 billion down to NT$340 billion, and yet the government still could not win the KMT and People First Party's (PFP) support for the bill at the legislature.

Ninth among the top 10 was the two major opposition parties - the KMT and the PFP -- losing a court battle in which they claimed that President Chen Shui-bian's election in 2004 was invalid and that the Central Election Commission oversaw an invalid presidential election.

The election story was followed by another election story -- the first-ever "three-in-one" elections on Dec. 3 that the government said saved the nation NT$600 million by electing city, county and town chiefs and council members simultaneously instead of holding the elections separately.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Moscow, Dec 28 [CNA] The Moscow Times: Illarionov offers to Leave Kremiln.
Andrei Illarionov, the president's maverick economic adviser, said Tuesday that he did not like the direction the state was headed and had submitted his resignation. [ By Chang Hung-kuang]

DOC.HEADLINE: BIRD FLU OUTBREAKS TOP INTERNATIONAL NEWS STORY FOR 2005: CNA

TEXT.P: Here are the top 10 international news stories for 2005 selected by the Central News Agency in a straw poll by its senior editors as of Nov. 30, 2005.
1) Bird flu broke out in parts of Asia and Europe, with the World Health Organization issuing a world alert on the disease.
2) International oil prices once skyrocketed to US$70 per barrel from the US$49 per barrel in early 2005.
3) Pope John Paul II died in April 2005, German Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger was elected the 265th pontiff, Benedict XVI.
4) Terror activities dominated many parts of the world, with terror bombings resulting in severe casualties reported in England, Indonesia and Egypt.
5) Deadly earthquakes devastated Iran, Japan, Indonesia, Turkey and Pakistan, with the Pakistan-administered region of Kashmir seeing the highest fatalities at more than 70,000.

6) A record 23 named Atlantic hurricanes were formed up to the end of October, which included Katrina that made landfall in the southern part of the United States, killing more than 1,000 people in New Orleans and leaving more than one million homeless.
7) The Kyoto Protocol aimed at controlling greenhouse gas emissions was ratified by 141 countries around the world and took effect on Feb. 16, 2005.
8) China enacted the Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan, meeting a chorus of condemnation from the United States, Japan and the European Union.
9) The treaty establishing a constitution for Europe was voted down by France, the Netherlands and Poland in popular referendums.
10) Israel completed the evacuation of settlers from the Gaza Strip and parts of the West Bank, signifying a major step forward for the establishment of a proposed Palestinian state. (By Y.F. Low)/mw

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Defense Lawyers in Terror Cases Plan Challenges Over Spy Efforts
Defense lawyers in some of the United States' biggest terrorism cases say they plan to bring legal challenges to determine whether the National Security Agency used illegal wiretaps against several dozen Muslim men tied to Al Qaeda. The lawyers said in interviews that they wanted to learn whether the men were monitored by the agency and, if so, whether the government withheld critical information or misled judges and defense lawyers about how and why the men were singled out. While some civil rights advocates, legal experts and members of Congress have said President Bush did not have authority to order eavesdropping by the security agency without warrants, the White House and the Justice Department continued on Tuesday to defend the legality and propriety of the program.
Wall Street Journal: Different Agenda, Latest Answer To Mideast Crisis: Fix the Economy
James Wolfensohn, the former head of the World Bank, who is now a top diplomat in the Gaza Strip region charged with fixing the beleaguered Palestianian economy, has helped resolve border disputes, found funding for a sea port and safeguarded a chunk of the region's agricultural industry by rounding up a group of private investors, including himself. Wolfensohn is betting that the Middle East conflict needs not only a political settlement but also an economic one. Prosperity, he believes, will blunt the appeal of extremism and give Palestinians a stake in building a new state after years of nearly continuous violence. He has one eye supporting the efforts of Palestinian moderates in January's parliamentary elections. The other is on fashioning an economy that could underpin any resolution for the long term.

DOC.HEADLINE: LABOR COUNCIL SPELLS OUT STANCE ON IMPORTING FARM LABOR

TEXT.P: Job opportunities for local farmers are the top concern of the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) , although the Council of Agriculture (COA) is assessing the country's need to import foreign laborers to work in the domestic agriculture sector, CLA Chairman Lee Ying-yuan said Wednesday.

Speaking at a legislative committee while answering questions from lawmakers who expressed their doubts about the proposal of the Council of Agriculture (COA), Lee said that the COA is still studying the possibility of introducing migrant workers to Taiwan's agriculture sector based on the situation in the domestic labor market in line with a quota management system.

Before responding to the COA's initiative to import foreign workers to help improve a labor shortage in local farming villages, the CLA will stick to its stance that Taiwan workers' rights and interests must not be affected, he insisted.

During the legislative committee meeting, some lawmakers said that they were highly skeptical about how the CLA would manage to follow its own quota restrictions as it has decided to open the domestic labor market wider to foreign workers at a time when there are already some 320,000 alien laborers in Taiwan.

The CLA decided last month to allow up to 20,000 alien laborers to be imported into certain "dangerous and dirty" manufacturing industries over a six-year period from January next year. The council has estimated that the number of foreign workers in Taiwan may increase by 5,000 to 10,000 in 2006.

Lin Chi-chang, secretary-general at the Yunlin Farmers' Association in central Taiwan, voiced his opposition to the idea of importing alien farmers, and urged relevant government agencies to seriously consider if this is the best course of action.

Arguing that the government must not harm local farmers by importing foreign farmers now that Taiwan farmers already earn less than workers in other sectors, Lin urged relevant authorities to be mindful of serious consequences if it goes through with the plan.

Despite the fact that the government claims that it would only "phase in" foreign farmers to "complement" Taiwan's aging agricultural population, he cautioned the government against a possible know-how exodus after migrant farmers return to their homelands.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAMES SOONG DOES NOT SUPPORT 'GRAND COALITION' WITH DPP: KMT

TEXT.P: People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong does not support the idea of forming a "grand coalition government" with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , according to Kuomintang (KMT) Secretary-General Chan Chun-po Wednesday.

KMT spokeswoman Cheng Li-wen quoted Chan as saying at the party's Central Standing Committee meeting that the media was "exaggerating" when they reported that Soong and Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng were "inclined toward" the idea of forming a grand coalition government with the DPP.
Soong has also made it clear that he does not support the idea, Chan said, noting that Soong asked PFP Policy Center Director Chang Hsien-yao to state his position on the matter.

Wang has been touted as a potential candidate to replace Premier Frank Hsieh when President Chen Shui-bian reshuffles his Cabinet, probably in January. Such a move has been anticipated after Chen's DPP was resoundingly defeated in the Dec. 3 local government elections.
If Wang leaves the KMT to serve in the DPP government, the "pan-blue alliance's" slim majority in the legislature will become even thinner.

Therefore, when Wang and Soong met last Saturday, observers were curious as to what they were discussing. One of their "consensuses, " according to media reports, was that if Chen asks the opposition parties to form the Cabinet, the concept of a "grand coalition" can be considered.
However, Wang told the media that if the president is interested in having opposition members in his Cabinet, he should talk to KMT Chairman Ma.

During the party's Central Standing Committee meeting Wednesday, Cheng said Ma told the members that KMT and PFP, which form the "pan-blue alliance, " that they now only have 110 seats in the 220-seat Legislative Yuan, so it is becoming ever more imperative for the alliance to stand firm.
The 225-seat legislature was reduced to 220 seats after four KMT lawmakers jumped into the local government race and won and a DPP lawmaker was put to jail.

Ma said he has met with Soong twice after the Dec. 3 elections, and "my feelings got better each time" as both parties have been cooperating well at the legislature with regard to such critical issues as the arms purchase budget and the president's nominations of Control Yuan members.
He said that at a time when people are fed up with political fighting at the legislature, only "reasonable debate" of real issues will win public support.

He also said Taiwan society now needs "peace and quiet" rather than verbal attacks between opposing political camps. For that reason, he said honestly carrying out the Constitution in "spirit" is more important than talking about another round of constitutional amendments.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BEST TO MAINTAIN STATUS QUO ACROSS TAIWAN STRAIT: KMT HEAD

TEXT.P: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CAN) It is best for Taiwan to maintain the status quo across the Taiwan Strait given the U. S. efforts to play a "balancing role" in the region, prime opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou told the Voice of America in a Dec. 26 interview.

As Taiwan would be the most possible cause for war between the United States and China, it is best for Taiwan to keep the current cross-strait situation stable in the interests of all parties concerned, Ma said.

When China is increasingly rising as a world power and posing greater challenges to the United States, Ma said, Taiwan has a vital leverage in the cross-strait situation that is underpinned by the "one China" policy of the United States.

Playing a "balancing role" in tune with its "one China" policy is a move intended to observe Washington's overall military strategy in East Asia that will help the United States maintain friendly relations with both China and Japan -- the United States' strategic emphasis in the region, Ma said.

When the United States seeks to engage China through its "one China" policy, it is trying to minimize the damage to a democratic and open Taiwan by playing the "balancing role" to serve both sides that remain divergent over independence or unification for Taiwan's future, Ma pointed out.

Under such circumstances, Taiwan has to maintain the present cross-strait status quo by not clamoring for imminent unification with China nor seeking a perpetual split from it, he contended, noting that this will best serve Taiwan's interests and those of other parties.

Ma, also mayor of Taipei, took over the KMT's chairmanship in August this year through a historic direct vote among party members. He has widely been assumed as the most likely contender from the opposition "pan blue alliance" to run in the 2008 presidential race since leading the alliance to win 16 seats of the 23 local governments in the Dec. 3 elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAMPUS CORPORAL PUNISHMENT TO BE OUTLAWED

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan's education and culture committee passed a proposal Wednesday to include a ban on campus corporal punishment into the Basic Education Law.

The committee passed draft revisions to Articles 8 and 15 of the Basic Education Law that will protect students from corporal punishment. According to the draft revisions, teachers and students can also seek legal remedies if their rights are infringed by school authorities or administrative agencies.
Opposition Kuomintang Legislator Hung Hsiu-chu said the draft revisions are mainly aimed at reminding teachers to manage or control their emotions and refrain from resorting to corporal punishment.

"Times have changed. School teachers should not adopt corporal punishment that could leave not only physical wounds but also mental scars, " Hung said. Nevertheless, Hung said, the revised bill has not proposed any compensation for students who have been hit by teachers in spite of the corporal punishment ban.
It remains unclear when the legislature will complete the third reading of the bill.
Vice Minister of Education Chou Tsan-teh said the Ministry of Education has consistently opposed campus corporal punishment.
"More explicitly banning corporal punishment of students complies with the education ministry's longstanding policy and signifies respect for students' basic human rights," Chou said.

In line with the legislature's move to outlaw campus corporal punishment, Chou said, the education ministry will step up a publicity campaign to remind teachers that corporal punishment of students could make them liable to penalties prescribed in relevant criminal and civil laws.
Chou said the ministry will also compile class management reference materials into teachers' school curricula to instill a zero-corporal punishment concept into would-be teachers.
Meanwhile, the Humanistic Education Foundation, which has long been advocating a ban on campus corporal punishment, said the new law is the best new year's gift to students around the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: NORTHERN TAIWAN SOCIETY URGES MND TO CLOSE LI-MING FOUNDATION

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) should immediately close the Li-ming Cultural Enterprise Foundation without any litigation so that NT$4 billion in its stakes in Chinese Television System (CTS) would not be embezzled, the Northern Taiwan Society said Wednesday.

The Li-ming Foundation is an organization under the MND that invests in the Chinese Television System. Recent debates on the government, military and political parties pulling out of media operations have brought up this issue. The deadline set by the authorities concerned for the pull-out was Dec. 26.

During a news conference at the Legislative Yuan Wednesday, the Northern Taiwan Society said the stakes of the CTS which the Li-ming Foundation retains are not privately owned, bought by retired military officers, as they used to claim. Instead, they are issued from the national defense budget in an indirect way; therefore, the shares they own are considered public stakes.

The Northern Taiwan Society made the statement after the Li-ming Foundation said it would not donate its CTS stakes to facilitate the task of political parties, government and military giving up control over media.

The Northern Taiwan Society said that the Li-ming Foundation was established in order to create the CTS later. But now CTS is going to turn into a public service television station, the purpose for such a foundation to exist is gone, and the MND should order to have it closed at once.

Huang Guangqin, a well-known journalist who attended the news conference said that the Li-ming Foundation is a problem created during the Kuomintang (KMT) administration and left till now, and that KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou is responsible for this case according to ethics.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE COMMITTEE AGREES ON BILL TO WIPE OUT HUMAN SMUGGLING

TEXT.P: Taiwan made the first move Wednesday toward incorporating global efforts to crack down on human trafficking after lawmakers agreed to add a draft revision to the immigration law to specifically serve that end.

Lawmakers at the Home and National Affairs Committee under the Legislative Yuan agreed unanimously to add a new chapter to the law based on a consensus that Taiwan must clearly underscore its resolve to better protect human rights to the international community at a time when the country has increasingly been used as a human cargo transshipment hub by cross-border criminal organizations.

The bill clearly stipulates what is called "human trafficking, " which includes abusing victims sexually or profiteering from their work, or forcing others to do something against their will through blackmail, threats, sexual assault, drugs, illegal monitoring, scams or hypnosis.
Trans-border activities covering recruitment, transportation, smuggling, hiding or transferring of human cargo are also defined as "human trafficking" in the bill.

Hsiao Bi-khim, a legislator of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party who initiated the bill, said that Taiwan has for some time been scolded by the international community for failing to set up a supra-ministerial network to help human trafficking victims.

Human traffickers pose a serious threat to the wellbeing of all mankind, Hsiao said, pointing out that their activities are closely related to criminal rings and public health, among other issues. Studies show that human smuggling has fast become an issue that also has an impact on the diplomatic and foreign affairs of a country, she noted.

The new bill, Hsiao said, would allow for the establishment of an exclusive government unit to protect the rights and safety of international human cargo victims in Taiwan, and it will also help the government better cope with future tasks.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP FORMS TASK FORCE TO ENSURE CLEAN ELECTIONS FOR COUNCIL SPEAKERS

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) decided Wednesday to form a special supervisory panel to prevent its members from getting involved in vote-buying in the upcoming elections for speakers and deputy speakers of city/county councils.
The DPP's Central Executive Commission (CEC) approved the decision to form a seven-member supervisory panel at its weekly meeting.

According to the decision, the DPP caucuses in various city/county councils should send all of their proposals regarding the council speaker and deputy speaker elections to the Central Executive Commission for approval and no DPP councilor would be allowed to support candidates with shady links with organized crime or suspicious involvement in election bribery.

Speaking at the CEC meeting, Vice President Annette Lu, who concurrently serves as DPP acting chairwoman, urged all domestic political parties to refrain from nominating any candidate with "black gold" criminal records to run for city/county council speakership.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW MEASURES TO TAKE EFFECT FROM JAN. 1

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior (MOI) announced Wednesday a number of new measures to take effect from Jan. 1, including requiring naturalization applicants to produce proof of basic Chinese language ability and civics knowledge.

Starting Jan. 1, foreigners seeking Republic of China citizenship must either present documents proving their basic language ability and civics knowledge or take tests to be held four times a year by the ministry.

The MOI already unveiled the criteria to measure the language ability and civics knowledge of naturalization applicants in November. The criteria was formulated in accordance with a May 20 amendment to the Nationality Law, which requires naturalization applicants to have a basic language ability and civics knowledge.

The documents submitted by the applicants should prove that they have studied in a school in Taiwan for at least one year or have taken a course provided by the government for naturalization applicants.

For foreign spouses and foster children of ROC nationals and foreigners 65 and above, they need to prove that they have taken the course for more than 100 hours. Other foreigners need to take the course for at least 200 hours.

Foreigners who do not want to take the course can take part in tests to be held every January, April, July and November starting next year, with the candidates allowed to take a written test or an oral test in Mandarin, Taiwanese, Hakka or aboriginal languages.

In the test, the applicants will need to answer 20 questions selected from a database comprising a total of 200 questions. While foreigners 65 and above have to get at least 50 percent to pass the test, foreign spouses and foster children of ROC nationals have to get at least 60 percent, and other foreigners have to get 70 percent.
The MOI has posted all the test questions and their answers on its Web site and has also compiled them in a booklet.

From the start of 2006, conscripts on alternative military service will be discharged from the military six months ahead of their original schedules as the mandatory military service period has been cut short.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Dec. 29, or the 29th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1808: Andrew Johnson, the 17th president of the United States, is born. He took over as president after Abraham Lincoln was assassinated.
1857: British and French troops take Canton, southern China.
1911: Dr. Sun Yat-sen is elected the first president of Asia's first democratic republic -- the Republic of China.
1921: The United States, Britain, France, Italy and Japan sign the Washington Treaty to limit naval armaments.
1924: John Davidson Rockefeller, an American oil magnate who amassed a great fortune through the Standard Oil Company, donates US$1 million to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York.
1928: Chang Hsueh-liang pledges allegiance to the national government, thereby leading to the unification of China.
1931: The national government is reorganized, with Lin Sen as the new chairman.
1934: Japan renounces the Washington Treaty limiting naval armaments.
1938: Wang Ching-wei, who deserted the ROC government and left Chungking for Kunming on Dec. 18, issues a statement in Hanoi, Vietnam, advocating the termination of the War of Resistance against Japan and seeking peace with Japan.
1940: German bombers inflict the greatest damage on London since the Great Fire of 1666.
1948: The Executive Yuan appoints Chen Cheng as governor of the Taiwan Provincial Government.
1953: The Legislative Yuan revises the quorum for the National Assembly from the original one-half (1,523) to one-third (1,015) of the total number of members.
1968: The Yangtze River Bridge near Nanking, built by the Communist Chinese, is inaugurated.
1975: Some 100 scholars from Taiwan and abroad attend the Conference on Population and Economic Development. President Yen Chia-kan addresses the opening ceremony.
1980: Hsieh Kuo-cheng, Taiwan's so-called "father of baseball," dies at the age of 69.
1981: U.S. President Ronald Reagan announces a program of economic sanctions against the Soviet Union because of its alleged role in the imposition of martial law in Poland.
1981: Lee Tien-hui, who earned a mainland scholarship to study in the United States, defects and holds a press conference in Taipei.
1984: India's Congress-I Party, headed by Ragiv Gandhi, wins a landslide victory in India's general elections.
1986: Harold Macmillan, British politician, dies at the age of 92. As prime minister, he presided over the break-up of the British Empire.
1989: Vaclav Havel, a dissident Czechoslovakian philosopher, becomes the first elected non-Communist president without opposition.
1989: Thousands of Vietnamese refugees battle with riot police in Hong Kong.
1994: The first squadron of Ching-kuo indigenous defense fighters is officially commissioned, upgrading the combat ability of the ROC Air Force and demonstrating the initial results of local research and development.
1995: The Executive Yuan approves revised regulations governing the establishment of the Central News Agency.
1996: A peace accord is signed between the Guatemalan government and guerrilla leaders, ending 38 years of civil conflict and bringing Central America's last remaining and longest civil war to a close.
1999: Former ROC Minister of Education Lin Ching-chiang dies of respiratory failure at the age of 60.
2000: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung says that the government plans to spend NT$65.5 billion to create a total of 290,000 job opportunities within a year.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is the moral life of a neighborhood which constitutes its excellence. He is not an intelligent man, who, in choosing his residence, does not select a place with a moral surrounding."

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION MEASURES SET TO START JAN. 1

TEXT.P: Several new environmental protection measures are set to take effect Jan. 1, including the comprehensive implementation of compulsory garbage separation.
The garbage separation policy, which has been in place in some cities and counties since early this year, will be expanded to all areas around the nation at the start of the new year.

According to the policy, people are required to separate their garbage into three categories -- ordinary garbage, recyclables and food scraps -- before taking it out to the garbage truck. Garbage that is not properly separated will be rejected, with offenders facing a fine of between NT$1,200 to NT$6,000.
During the first three months after the policy's implementation, offenders will not be fined but will be given advice and told to separate their garbage properly.
Also starting next year, motorists who fail to send their motorcycles for regular emission inspection will be fined NT$2,000 and forbidden from renewing their vehicle registration.

From Jan. 1, all filling stations around the nation will be required to install gas collection facilities to lower the concentration of benzene and volatile organics in the air to protect workers' health. Violators can be fined up to NT$1 million.

Meanwhile, industries will need to pay sewer surcharges every six months starting July 1. The surcharges will be calculated according to the chemical oxygen demand (COD) and suspended solids (SS) levels in their waste water, with NT$12.5 payable per kilogram of COD and NT$0.62 payable per kilogram of SS.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT OFFERS LEADERSHIP ADVICE TO NEW GENERALS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Thursday urged military officers to be generous and humble in victory and to engage in self-examination in defeat.
Chen made the remarks while presiding over a commissioning ceremony for officers promoted to the rank of general. Also attending the ceremony was Vice President Annette Lu.
The president said that the art of leadership in the military is to inspire courage, resist pressure, win the hearts of the soldiers, and achieve victory based on lessons learnt from previous defeat.

He also affirmed that to maintain the integrity of the nation's sovereignty is the core value of national defense, adding that despite close trade and economic exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, one must not forget the risk of possible war if the nation has insufficient defense capabilities.

He also said that the nation's effort in upgrading its national defense is "by no means an arms race, " and that increasing defense spending will not squeeze spending on social welfare programs or undermine the promotion of public welfare.
The president also said that if the long-stalled arms procurement bill is not passed, this will raise doubts in the international community about Taiwan's determination to defend itself.

The bill for the purchase of six Patriot III anti-missile batteries, eight conventional submarines and 12 P-3C Orion submarine-hunting aircraft from the United States has been blocked from being put on the legislative agenda for over a year by lawmakers of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party, which together hold a slim majority in the legislature.

Chen stressed that the strengthening of national defense is not to serve as a pawn for any other country, adding that the nation wants to prevent war but that it will stand up for itself if war is brought upon it.
"We must be well prepared so as to effectively counter a possible invasion from China, " the president said, affirming that "we must keep national security in our own hands."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 51.13 points to close at 6,575.53.
The bourse opened at 6,549.72 and fluctuated between 6,600.12 and 6,546.75 during trading. A total of 5.35 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$152.47 billion (US$4.62 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp issues moving up the most at 1.9 percent, followed by machinery and electronics shares at 1 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.7 percent, banking and financial shares at 0.6 percent, foodstuff issues and textile stocks both at 0.4 percent, and cement stocks at 0.3 percent.
The other major stock category lost ground, with construction issues moving down at 0.7 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 656 to 371, with 187 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RAILWAY ADMINISTRATION TO SEE US$295.52 M. LOSSES IN 2006

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Railway Administration (TRA) reported Thursday that its losses for 2006 will reach NT$9.9 billion (US$295.52 million).

Taiwan Railway Administrator Hsu Ta-wen made the remarks when he reported on the TRA's budget for 2006 at a meeting of the Transportation Committee of the Legislative Yuan, which is reviewing the budget for next year.

The projected losses mark an increase over losses for 2005. Hsu attributed the increase to the high-speed railway, which is scheduled to be inaugurated Oct. 31, 2006, as well as rising interest rates.
Although the high-speed railway will operate for only two months next year, the TRA stands to lose NT$3 billion on its western routes alone in 2006.

The TRA is scheduled to propose to the Ministry of Transportation and Communications a reasonable price scheme after the Chinese Lunar New Year, which falls on Jan. 29. Under the scheme, short-distance fares will be raised while long-distance fares will be lowered to increase the railway's competitiveness, Hsu said.

The TRA reported that revenues for 2006 will be NT$22.59 billion, up NT$655 million from the previous year, while expenditures for 2006 will be NT$32.49 billion, up NT$855 million from the previous year, showing that expenditures will outpace revenues.
Legislator Yeh Yi-chin of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party criticized the TRA, saying that its daily losses have increased to NT$20 million from NT$3 million in the past.
Her colleague, Kuo Mei-cheng, also said that the TRA is "beyond repair, " criticizing its frequent train schedule changes -- 13 times a year.

Hsu replied that the TRA has been burdened with accumulated debts, interest payments, and its need to act along with national policy, saying that its main operations are making money, only the personnel and pension payments as well as interest payments are too high.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOVEREIGNTY IS BASIS OF TAIWANESE NATIONAL IDENTITY: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: National sovereignty has replaced race, lineage and culture to become the basis of national identity by the people of Taiwan over the last 20 years, President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday.
Chen said that 20 years ago, the people of Taiwan were split on whether their country was "Taiwan" or "China." Today, nearly 90 percent of the people identify with Taiwan, Chen claimed.
Chen made the comments in the latest edition of his online newsletter, in which he mentioned the renewal of national identification cards that started Dec. 21.
"Regardless of sex, origin, ethnic background, color or religion belief, whoever possessing an ID card is a member of the big family of Taiwan and a citizen of the same country," Chen said.
The ID cards also represent the rights entitled to by all citizens, who are all "Taiwanese" on equal footing, he said.

To put it simply, Chen said, so-called "nationals" refer to people who hold the ID cards, and "domestic history" and "domestic geography" refer to the history and natural environment of the area where the ID cards are used as a document of identification.
"I believe every person who has this ID card will agree with this definition," he said.

Chen noted that during the past 400 years, several groups of immigrants have come to Taiwan and formed the country's four major ethnic groups -- aborigines, Hoklos, Hakkas and mainlanders -- and that the country has in recent years also seen the participation of many foreigners who are married to Taiwan citizens.
Chen said these pluraristic ethnic and cultural features are important assets of Taiwan that have become a positive, "soft power" of the country.
Taiwan's individuality will be displayed and a new Taiwanese identity will be shaped through the exchanges of different ethnic and cultural heritages, he said.
