DOC.HEADLINE: NTU STUDENT RETURNS TO HONK KONG FOR TRIAL

TEXT.P: Lee Chien-cheng, a National Taiwan University (NTU) student who was detained in Hong Kong Dec. 17-23 on illegal assembly charges, flew back to Hong Kong again Thursday for trial.

Lee, who returned to Taiwan Dec. 23 after being freed on bail earlier the same day, was accompanied by his father and an official from the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) -- Taiwan's top mainland China policy planner -- on his trip to Hong Kong for the trial scheduled to open at 2 p.m. Friday.

At the Kaohsiung airport prior to their departure, the senior Lee thanked the MAC again for its assistance after the incident, and expressed the hope that the Hong Kong court will give his son a favorable ruling Friday and allows him to be released immediately without any charge.

Lee was among the 14 anti-World Trade Organization (WTO) protesters who were charged by Hong Kong law enforcement authorities over holding an illegal sit-in on a major thoroughfare after violent riots Dec. 17. The other people charged include 11 South Koreans, one Japanese, and a mainland Chinese citizen. If convicted, they face a maximum prison sentence of five years.

Lee, a senior at the NTU's Department of Political Science, was released on a HK$2,500 (US$320) bail. As he was allowed to return to Taiwan for exams, Lee was required to have a guarantor pay a cash surety of HK$100,000 on his behalf, in addition to bail.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOP PROSECUTOR SAYS HE IS DETERMINED TO QUIT HIS POST

TEXT.P: State Public Prosecutor-General Wu Ying-chao said Thursday that he is determined to resign and will not change his mind even if President Chen Shui-bian wants him to continue serving in his present post.

Reporting to the legislature's Judiciary Committee, Wu said that he has not yet tendered his written resignation to the minister of justice because he has been busy attending meetings over the past two days.

The top prosecutor announced on Dec. 27 that he would resign shortly after President Chen complained in a speech that vote-buying had become more serious in the run-up to the Dec. 3 local government elections, compared with the legislative elections in 2004.

Questioned by legislators on the Judiciary Committee about why he wanted to resign, Wu said it could not be attributed to any single reason, but had to do with his plan to retire and the fact that his resignation now would make more room for the executive and legislative branches to engage in rational discussions on how the nation's top prosecutor should be fielded in the future.

Asked if his decision to resign had to do with pressure from the president, Wu said that this was not the case because at the time when he announced his decision, he was not aware of what the president had said earlier in the day.
He reiterated that he actually had thought of quitting more than a week ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSUMER CONFIDENCE DOWN IN DECEMBER: POLL

TEXT.P: Taiwan's consumer confidence index declined to 72.17 in December, down 1.94 points from the previous month's level, according to the results of a survey released Thursday by National Central University's Research Center for Taiwan Economic Development.

While five out of the six indicators used for the survey fell in December, the "timing for buying durable goods in the next six months" saw the greatest rate of decrease, losing 3.95 points from November to stand at 112.95.
Coming in second is the "timing for investing in the stock market in the next six months, " which dropped 3.7 points from November to 66.7.
The "domestic economic outlook in the next six months" registered 60.35, down 2.15 points from the previous month.
The "employment opportunities in the next six months" stood at 79.1, down 1.85 points from the previous month.
The "family financial status in the next six months" lost 0.85 points from November to stand at 60.8.
The only indicator that rose in December was the "domestic price level in the next six months," which gained 0.85 points from November to 53.1.
The survey was conducted Dec. 18-22 among 2,246 adults around Taiwan via telephone, with a margin of error of plus or minus 2.1 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ADVENTURERS TO RETRACE ZHENG HE'S VOYAGE

TEXT.P: A wooden boat modeled on the one used by Chinese mariner Zheng He (1371-1435 AD) is being built and should be ready to set sail next July to retrace his adventurous voyage, the head of a Taiwanese adventure group said Thursday.

Hsu Hai-peng, president of the Society of Extreme Exploration, said since July, he has shuttled between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait around 30 times, trying to find a suitable shipyard to build the boat.

Hsu said that he was glad that not only has he solicited funds, he has also found a shipyard in China that is willing to build the Chinese-style wooden sailboat, which will be 16 meters long and 3.8 meters wide.

On Sept. 21, Hsu said an anonymous person agreed to pay all the expenses to build the boat, and the U.S. cosmetic company Kiehl's also pledged Thursday to give NT$1 million for the training cost of the sailors on board.

He said that the boat is expected to be built early next year, and that seven sailors are now being trained for the trip. His alma mater, National Ocean University, has also agreed to provide technical assistance.
The building of the boat is expected to be completed next March and the boat will then encircle Taiwan in one week for good luck.
The recreated wooden boat is scheduled to disembark from Taichang, Jiangxu province in China in July on its trip of 33,900 nautical miles.

Huang Ling-hsiao, who has been selected to serve as the captain of the adventurous journey, said that the operation of the boat is similar to a modern sailboat, but since the craft is of ancient design, they have to learn old techniques.
He stressed that the most perilous place is the South China Sea during a tropical storm, saying that unforeseen problems could arise several times a day.

While Columbus sailed to the Americas on the Santa Maria in 1492, Zheng He, a eunuch , was sent by Emperor Yungle from China to many places throughout the South Pacific, the Indian Ocean, Taiwan, the Persian Gulf and distant Africa in seven epic voyages from 1405 to 1433, some 80 years before Columbus's voyage.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO HEAD'S 'AMPHIBIAN' METAPHOR IRKS KMT SPOKESWOMAN

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) spokesmwoman has taken umbrage with Government Information Office Minister Pasuya Yao calling her a "political and media amphibian" for hosting a radio show in conflict with the required separation between politics and media, and announced Thursday she will sue him.
Yao said Wednesday that Cheng Li-wen was crossing the line by hosting weekday radio show in her capacity as a prominent KMT official.
Yao repeated that a revised law governing broadcasting and television stipulates that political parties, the government and the military should be divested of media holdings as of Dec. 26, 2005.
Yao claimed that Cheng would lose the lawsuit because "I only speak the truth." He said she should "stop annoying the country with her poor show."
Meanwhile, when he was asked about Cheng's being an "amphibian," a straight-faced Ma Ying-jeou, the KMT chairman, said that he would have to look into the matter before commenting.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW MAP SHOWS LOCATION OF USED BOOKSTORES IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: A Taipei bookseller released the first map for used book stores in the capital city on Thursday.

According to Tai Li-chen, owner of the Mollie Used Book House, the map is available for free at the store, and customers who request the store to collect used books at their homes will also be offered a copy of the map.

Since there are few used bookstores and many people have no idea that there are bookstores that collect used books, the map can be a guide for both book lovers and those who are trying to clean out the old books in their homes, Tai said.
Meanwhile, from now until Jan. 25, the store will donate NT$1 per book collected to a social welfare organization, Tai said.

She said the store, which raised NT$200,000 for the Sunshine Social Welfare Foundation in a similar campaign last year, is prepared to donate the funds raised this year to a Taipei organization assisting the rehabilitation of mental patients.
People who wish to sell their used books to the store are urged to call the store at (02) 2369-2780 or 2368-2238 or visit its Web site at www.mollie.com.tw.

DOC.HEADLINE: GRADUATE STUDENTS PETITION FOR BETTER STIPENDS

TEXT.P: A dozen graduate student representatives from nine universities, including National Taiwan University (NTU) , petitioned the Ministry of Education (MOE) Thursday about the paltry stipends they currently receive.
The students asked the MOE to raise the stipends for graduate students and address the issues of different amounts of stipends for different departments and graduate schools.
Stipends are often given to graduate students for doing largely symbolic jobs for the school, such as light administrative work.

Chang Yuan-hsiu, the head of NTU's Graduate Student Association, who initiated the petition, said that several surveys have shown that 60 percent of graduate students receive less than NT$3,000 a month, while around 75 percent of the graduate students felt the money is not enough, and are hoping for between NT$5,000 and NT$10,000 per month.
The graduate students who are studying for Ph.D. degrees are hoping to get between NT$10,000 and NT$20,000 per month, Chang said, citing the surveys.

Chen Teh-hua, the MOE's official in charge of advanced education, said the ministry will base stipends on schools' development and the financial situation of the students to encourage colleges and universities to adjust the way they distribute the money for graduate students.

The ministry will also ask universities to actively help graduate students serve as research assistants to their schools or the National Science Council, hoping to help them upgrade their research, teaching and administrative capabilities and solve their financial problem as well.

DOC.HEADLINE: BONE MARROW TRANSPLANT HELPS VIETNAMESE SURGEON GET NEW LEASE ON LIFE

TEXT.P: A Vietnamese neurosurgeon, who suffers from acute myeloid leukemia, a rare type of cancer, has been given a new lease on life after receiving chemotherapy and a transnational bone marrow transplant at National Taiwan University Hospital (NTUH).

Huynh Thanh Thuan, a 27-year-old neurosurgeon at Vietnam's Cho Ray Hospital, was discharged from NTUH Thursday after attending a celebration party marking the first successful transnational bone marrow transplant at the hospital.

Huynh was diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia early this year. He first received chemotherapy at Blood Transfusion Hospital in Ho Chi Minh City in southern Vietnam. The medical team treating Huynh suggested that he receive a bone marrow transplant; otherwise, he could die.

Accompanied by his fiancee, Huynh came to Taiwan in April to seek the possibility of a bone marrow transplant. In two weeks after his arrival, the Buddhist Tzu Chi Stem Cell Center in the eastern city of Hualien managed to find a partial match from a Taiwan bone marrow donor.
As their HLA antigens were not fully compatible, Huynh underwent chemotherapy for four months before receiving an unrelated transnational bone marrow transplant at NTUH in August.

According to Tzu Chi data bank tallies, the bone marrow matching rate among Chinese people is about 60 percent. Huynh, a non-Chinese, was lucky to be able to find a match from a Taiwanese donor in such a short period of time.

Even though their HLA antigens were only 60 percent compatible, physicians at the NTUH blood cancers department said the success rate of such a bone marrow transplant could be more than 50 percent with the use of new anti-rejection drugs.

Huynh and his fiancee are scheduled to return to Vietnam in mid-January. NTUH physicians said they will cooperate with Blood Transfusion Hospital in Ho Chi Minh City in follow-up for Huynh by e-mail. Huynh will be monitored for the next five years.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: U.N. Observer in Baghdad Calls the Voting Valid
The United Nations stepped into the controversy over the Iraqi parliamentary election on Wednesday, declaring publicly that the results of the voting on Dec. 15 appeared valid, even as the vote tally continued here. Craig Jenness, a Canadian who led the United Nations' election coordination effort in Iraq, said his agency believed that the elections "were transparent and credible." He added that although all complaints must be weighed thoroughly, "we at the U.N. see no justification in calls for a rerun of the elections."
Wall Street Journal: Generation Gap, In Aging Japan, Young Slackers Stir Up Concerns
Japan, which has long prided itself on its unbeatable work ethic, faces a troubling trend: the swelling ranks of young slackers. Spurred by a more casual attitude toward work and a tendency to hold out for dream jobs, an estimated 640,000 unmarried Japanese between ages 15 and 34 had dropped out of the work force or failed to enter at all last year. This is up from 400,000 in 1993, the first year for which Japan's Labor Ministry has figured. The government calls these e slackers NEET, or "not in education, employment or training" -- a term first used in the United Kingdom in the late 1990s. Japan, which started labeling NEETs last year, uses the term specifically for young people who have given up looking for a job and often get financial support from their generous parents. They are not considered unemployed since they are not actively looking for a job. The phenomenon has shocked Japan because the nation considers its highly trained, hard-working labor force to be its most valuable resource. As a result, the NEET issue has set the nation abuzz.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: The Fast Rise and Steep Fall of Jack Abramoff; How a Well-Connected Lobbyist Became the Center of a Far-Reaching Corruption Scandal.
Jack Abramoff liked to slip into dialogue from "The Godfather" as he led his lobbying colleagues in planning their next conquest on Capitol Hill. In a favorite bit, he would mimic an ice-cold Michael Corleone facing down a crooked politician's demand for a cut of Mafia gambling profits: "Senator, you can have my answer now if you like. My offer is this: nothing."

DOC.HEADLINE: FOLK GROUP THE BROTHERS FOUR IN TAIWAN FOR NEW YEAR'S EVE CONCERT

TEXT.P: The Brothers Four, the famous American folk group that has delighted millions of music lovers for more than 40 years, arrived in Taipei Thursday for two concerts and to spend New Year's Eve with fans in Taiwan.
This is the group's second visit to Taiwan. Their previous performances were at the end of 2003.
The group will perform in two concerts Dec. 30-31 at the Novel Hall for the Performing Arts in Taipei.
The concert on Dec. 30 will begin at 7:30 p.m., while the one on Dec. 31 will start at 9:45 p.m. and last until after midnight, so that the group and the audience can usher in the new year together.
Organizers said the Brothers Four will play well-known classics, such as "Yellow Bird," "Try to Remember," "Greenfields," "500 Miles," and "Lemon Tree."
The Brothers Four has gained fame since the early 1960s and have played thousands of college concerts in the United States and toured dozens of foreign countries.
As pioneers in the musical movement which came to be know as "folk revival," the Brothers Four is one the few groups from those times still performing today.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER PROMISES TO ACCELERATE ESTABLISHMENT OF NCC

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan speaker Wang Jin-pyng promised Thursday to help accelerate the confirmation by the legislature of the name list of the National Communications Commission (NCC) members presented by the Executive Yuan.

The Executive Yuan referred the name list, containing 13 candidates, to the Legislative Yuan Thursday for confirmation in anticipation that the commission can be established formally and become operational soon.
Wang said that the approval should come before this legislative session concludes on Jan. 13.
The nomination list was prepared by a panel charged with choosing candidates to serve on the NCC in accordance with the NCC Act promulgated Nov. 11.

The Executive Yuan forwarded the name list to the Legislative Yuan for confirmation despite the fact that one of the 13 candidates -- Prof. Lu Chung-chin with National Tsinghua University in Hsinchu -- had withdrawn his name from consideration more than two weeks ago after he was recommended by the panel to serve on the NCC.

In a letter dated Dec. 12 to Premier Frank Hsieh, Lu said he regrets that several political parties had packed the list of NCC nominees with their supporters, asking the premier to drop his name from the list of nominees of NCC members to be presented by the premier to the Legislature for confirmation.

The 13 candidates were selected from among 18 nominees -- who were put forward by the legislature according to the share of seats held by each political party and the Executive Yuan -- by the 11-member review panel, all of them experts and scholars recommended by political parties based on proportional representation, through an open vote.

The legislative caucuses of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP), who sponsored the NCC organization bill, expressed the hope last month that the NCC could be inaugurated Jan. 1, 2006.

Opposition lawmakers made the call Nov. 10, one day after President Chen Shui-bian promulgated the NCC bill into law. KMT and PFP lawmakers have touted the enactment as a milestone in the country's history, claiming that it offers the best guarantee of freedom of the press.

DOC.HEADLINE: ID CARD ISSUANCE GOING SMOOTHLY WITH ONLY A FEW HITCHES

TEXT.P: The issuance of new ROC ID cards is going well, except for a few instances of people submitting the wrong size photos, an official said Thursday.

New ROC ID cards began to be issued Dec. 21. The new forgery-proof cards should foil attempts by illegal Chinese immigrants from claiming benefits from Taiwan through the use of fake cards. The current version of ID cards is very low tech and can easily be copied.
"The program to issue new cards is proceeding smoothly, with the only real hitch being that some people are coming in with passport-size photos that are too small," the official said.

Regulations say that the ID photo must be in color and have been taken within the last year. It should be 4.5 by 3.5 centimeters with the applicant's face between 3.2 and 3.6 centimeters from the top of the head to the chin.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATOR CHIU YI TO SUE SENIOR PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Independent Legislator Chiu Yi said Thursday he will sue Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Ma Yung-cheng for defamation.

At a news conference in the legislature, Chiu said Ma had told a meeting of the legislature's Finance Committee earlier Thursday that the information Chiu publicized to show that Ma might have profiteered through illegal insider trading on the stock market was "stolen and incorrect."

At the meeting, Ma and officials from the Financial Supervisory Commission under the Cabinet were summoned to clarify speculation that senior officials at the Presidential Office were involved in stock transactions and insider trading.

Chiu presented detailed information at the meeting and claimed that Ma, with an investment of NT$3.36 million, had made a profit of NT$3.15 million through the trading of seven different stocks in a matter of only six months between July 2003 and January 2004, prompting speculation about his involvement in insider trading.
Ma countered that Chiu should not have made a "unilateral interpretation" based on information that was "stolen and incorrect."
At the news conference Thursday afternoon, Chiu pointed out that Ma is not a legislator and therefore cannot speak with impunity.
He said he will sue Ma for slander and will ask for NT$3.16 million in damages.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO ADVOCATES CTS MOVE TO SOUTHERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Relocating the Chinese Television System (CTS), one of the five terrestrial television channels in Taiwan, to the southern part of the island would more evenly distribute TV media, Government Information Office (GIO) Minister Pasuya Yao said Thursday while calling on Legislative Yuan speaker Wang Jin-pyng for his support of the idea.

Friday the Legislative Yuan will screen a statute on the disposal of public stakes in terrestrial television stations, and Yao is advocating that CTS be moved to southern Taiwan to help balance information access and cultural development between the north and the south, as the south has always lagged the north in this regard.
Yao and Wang did not reached any consensus on the issue.

Members of the legislative caucus of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) claimed that negotiations between the "pan-green" camp led by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the KMT-led opposition "pan-blue alliance" would be a better solution to the matter and a showdown vote would be the last thing that the KMT would like to see.

KMT Legislator Hung Hsiu-chu said that the GIO should not manipulate the issue via a populist mindset. Instead, she said, the government should canvass suggestion from the perspectives of professionalism and business development.
Some 150 CTS staff members will protest at the Legislative Yuan Friday to vent their anger with the GIO idea, the CTS labor union announced Thursday.
Union members said that the GIO's decision is a reckless one, which would not only infringe upon the rights of CTS workers, but will also drain television news assets and waste taxpayers' money.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST WOMAN COMBAT-STATUS GENERAL SPECIALIZES IN FOILING HACKERS

TEXT.P: The nation's first woman combat-status general is an electronic communications expert, particularly in information technology (IT) hardware and anti-virus computer software.

Chai Hui-chen, division chief at the Ministry of National Defense's Communications and Electronics Department, is among the 44 senior military officers to be promoted to the rank of general Jan. 1, 2006.

A graduate from National Taiwan University's Horticulture Department, Chai didn't start her military career until after she was admitted into National Defense Medical College's Graduate Institute of Biochemistry. She later obtained a Ph.D. in computer science from Syracuse University in New York State.
After serving at electronic communications centers at various military units, Chai was promoted to her current post in July 2004.

In the face of China's rapid electronic warfare arsenal buildup, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) has stepped up electronic warfare combat preparedness with a view to establishing a three dimensional safety dragnet to maintain smooth communications and command operations, troop mobility and military barracks security. With her superb IT expertise, Chai has played an important role in this process, military sources said.

In recent years, Chinese have frequently tried to hack into the ROC government and military's Web sites. Chai has often assisted government agencies in strengthening their firewalls to protect their communications systems and data banks, military sources said. Chai once said confidently that Chinese hackers' attacks had provided good opportunities to practice skills to protect the military's communications and command systems.

The MND held a commissioning ceremony for the 44 soon-to-be generals at the Armed Forces Officers' Club in Taipei Thursday, with Minister of National Defense Lee Jye presiding. Both President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu attended the promotion ceremony.
Chai was decorated with the major general rank badge by her husband and daughter at the commissioning ceremony.
Seven officers were conferred with the rank of lieutenant general or vice admiral, and 37 were promoted to major generals or rear admirals.

Addressing the commissioning ceremony, President Chen said in his capacity as the commander-in-chief of the nation's armed forces that Chai's promotion signifies the military's efforts to substantiate gender equality in the military.
Among those promoted to the rank of lieutenant general was Ho Yung-chien, the head of the president's security detail.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN TO OUTLINE TOP NATIONAL GOALS IN NEW YEAR ADDRESS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday he will outline Taiwan's ultimate national goals in his New Year address.
The announcement was released in an article published in the president's online newsletter.

Chen wrote in the article that his New Year address to be delivered Jan. 1 will detail national development directions and top goals in various dimensions, including relations across the Taiwan Strait, economy and domestic affairs.

The New Year address will stress that democratic Taiwan will continue growing and thriving and will never fade away, Chen wrote, adding that in the upcoming new year, Taiwan will take its own path even more steadfastly than before. Chen said his New Year address will be even more important than his two inaugural addresses.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEARLY 50% SUPPORT CTS RELOCATION TO SOUTHERN TAIWAN: POLL

TEXT.P: Nearly half of respondents to a recent opinion poll have thrown their support behind the proposed relocation of Chinese Television System (CTS) to southern Taiwan, the Government Information Office (GIO) said Thursday.
The GIO commissioned a private public opinion research group to survey local people's attitude toward the proposal to have a public-service terrestrial television headquartered in southern Taiwan.

GIO Minister Pasuya Yao brought up the proposal amid recent debates over the Dec. 26 deadline for the government, political parties and military to divest themselves of stake holdings in local news media outlets.

The government has decided to relinquish its control of two terrestrial TV companies -- Taiwan Television Enterprises (TTV) and CTS to meet that requirement. In the process, Yao said the GIO will push for CTS to become a wholly public-service media outlet and relocate its headquarters to southern Taiwan to balance regional media industry development. For decades, all of the country's terrestrial TV stations headquartered in Taipei.

Of the 1,072 valid samples collected in the survey, 46.4 percent said it is "very appropriate" or "appropriate" to have a public-service terrestrial TV station headquartered in southern Taiwan, while 28.5 percent thought otherwise.
As to where the relocated terrestrial TV should be headquartered, 47 percent chose Kaohsiung City/Kaohsiung County.

The poll also found that local people were divided over the main opposition Kuomintang's sale of its controlling shares in three media outlets -- China television Co. (CTV) , Broadcasting Corp. of China (BCC) and China Motion Picture Co. -- to a holding company led by China Times Group Chairman Yu Chien-hsin. The KMT claimed that the sale signifies its respect for the Dec. 26 pull-out deadline.

While 31.9 percent of the respondents gave a thumbs-up to the KMT-China Times Group deal, 34.6 percent disagreed with the dealing. Nearly 60 percent said China Times Group is obliged to expound on the source its capital to buy the three controversial KMT media outlets.

DOC.HEADLINE: CTS STAFF PROTEST RELOCATION TO SOUTH IDEA

TEXT.P: Nearly 100 staff members of the Chinese Television System (CTS) lodged a protest with the Legislative Yuan Friday against the Government Information Office's (GIO's) idea to relocate CTS, one of the five terrestrial television channels in Taiwan, to the southern part of the island.

The Legislative Yuan is supposed to screen a bill on the disposal of public stakes in terrestrial television stations Friday, and GIO Minister Yao has advocated that CTS be moved to southern Taiwan to "help balance information access and cultural development between the north and the south, as the south has always lagged behind the north in this regard."

Yao called on Legislative Yuan speaker Wang Jin-pyng Thursday to seek Wang's support for the idea in the hopes that an article stipulating CTS's relocation to southern Taiwan within five years will be included in the proposed bill.
Yao and Wang reportedly did not reach any consensus on the issue.

Venting their anger with the GIO idea, CTS labor union members called the idea "reckless, " claiming that implementing it "would not only infringe upon the rights of CTS workers, but would also drain television news resources and waste taxpayers' money."

Union leader Chu Chun said that the GIO has no right to make laws as it wishes. The GIO is "throwing live fish into the desert" by asking that the CTS be relocated to the south without heeding professional assessments or the "TV industry's business ecology, " he claimed.

Chu said he hopes that agreements reached between management and labor will be included in the bill on the disposal of public stakes in terrestrial television stations so that the rights and interests of TV workers can be protected.

He also suggested that the CTS relocation issue be discussed after the television company's share transfer is completed, adding that he hopes the new CTS management will consult everybody via public discussion forums in handling the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SPOKESWOMAN TO DEAL WITH RADIO TALK SHOW HOST ISSUE SOON: CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Friday that KMT spokeswoman Cheng Li-wen will deal shortly and in an appropriate way with the issue of criticism arising from her "crossing the line" into media and that he respects whatever decisions Cheng makes on the matter.

Ma made the remarks after the recent quip about Cheng, director of the KMT Cultural and Communication Affairs Department, by Government Information Office Minister Pasuya Yao that she is a "political and media amphibian" for hosting a radio show in conflict with the required separation between politics and media.
Yao said Wednesday that Cheng was crossing the line by hosting the weekday radio show in her capacity as a prominent KMT official.

The GIO head reiterated that the revised law governing broadcasting and television stipulates that political parties, the government and the military should withdraw from all media operations as of Dec. 26, 2005.
Taking umbrage with Yao's quip, Cheng said Thursday she may consider suing Yao for slander.
Cheng, nevertheless, said late Thursday night after consulting with Ma that she will quit her radio host job after the Chinese New Year, which falls on Jan. 29.
On Cheng's latest statement, Yao replied Friday by asking: "Should she continue to annoy the country with her poor show for so long?"

Noting that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) already tackled the politics-media separation issue one-and-a-half years ago, Yao criticized the KMT for lacking sincerity in dealing with the issue.
Meanwhile, KMT Legislator Wu Yu-sheng supported the idea of Cheng quitting her radio host job the sooner the better, stressing that "one cannot eat one's cake and have it too."
Stressing that he bears no grudge against Cheng, Wu said Cheng's "crossing the line" has tarnished the image of the KMT as well as of the party's chairman.

On Friday, DPP Secretary-General Lee Yi-yang lashed out at Ma for "condoning" Cheng's actions, saying that Cheng's doubling as a radio host is tantamount to a "political party manipulating the media."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: Gov. Wants to Drop Big Hike in College Fees.
Offering an unexpected election-year gift to 650,000 California students and their parents, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger will ask the Legislature to cancel a hefty fee increase scheduled for next year at the state's public colleges and universities, administration officials said Wednesday.

The Straits Times: SIA urged to hive off some units.
Minister Mentor Lee Kuan Yew is persuaded that once-rocky relations between the five unions and management of Singapore Airlines (SIA) have improved, but he wants them to keep at it.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE TAIWAN WOMEN BUYING CONDOMS FOR PARTNERS

TEXT.P: With education on safe sex seeming to be more effective among women than among men, market surveys show that the number of women buying condoms for their partners is catching up to the number of men buying condoms.

Condom sellers noted that Taiwan produces at least 250 million condoms per year for export and domestic consumption and that a survey by ACNielsen also indicates that condom sales are rising at an annual rate of 10 percent to 20 percent in Taiwan, making condoms the consumer product with the second highest growth rate after chewing gum.

According to the condom company Durex, condoms sales are highest around Valentine's Day, with sales being 20 percent to 30 percent higher than usual and convenient stores being the main sales outlets.
The Christmas holidays and holidays that last more than two days are also occasions when condoms sell good, the company said.
Although female condoms became available in Taiwan a few years ago, consumer response has been lukewarm at best, with male condoms still making up the vast majority of sales around the country.

Nevertheless, when it comes to condoms, the buying power of women is on the rise. According to the Japanese condom maker Okamoto, only 20 percent of condom purchases in Taiwan in the 1990s were made by women, but the figure has risen to 40 percent today.

Obstetrician and gynecologist Lee Chao-hsi, who is also a lecturer on sex education for youths, observed that female students are usually more active in asking questions about sex during his lectures given to high school and university students.
In addition, the publicity campaign on using condoms as a method of contraception and venereal disease prevention appears to be more effective toward women than men, Lee said.

As shown by data from the Bureau of Health Promotion, 75 percent of women in Taiwan between the ages of 20 and 40 have contraceptive needs, while 89 percent of married women use condoms as their method of birth control.

In light of the rise in condom sales to women, more and more condom products are coming with cute packaging, such as in the form of golden coins, lollipops, dolls or gift baskets, to cater to women's preferences.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 27.19 points to close at 6,548.34.
The bourse opened at 6,589.84 and fluctuated between 6,600.17 and 6,548.34 during trading. A total of 507 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$133.55 billion (US$4.07 billion).
Only one of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up 1 percent.

The seven other major stock categories lost ground, with paper and pulp issues moving down the most at 1.4 percent, followed by cement stocks at 1 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.8 percent, banking and financial shares at 0.7 percent, textile stocks at 0.6 percent, foodstuff issues at 0.4 percent, and machinery and electronics shares at 0.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 623 to 455, with 147 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT HONORS WINNERS OF FILIAL PIETY AWARDS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian presented awards to the seven winners of this year's Filial Piety Awards in Tainan County, southern Taiwan Friday.
President Chen lauded the seven winners, aged between 10 and 77, all of whom were honored for devotedly taking care of their parents despite facing economic hardships or physical challenges.

Speaking at the event, Chen said that he has attended every Filial Piety Awards presentation ceremony since becoming president because he believes filial piety is the very basis of all virtue and helps stabilize the family, society and the country.

Chen also expressed his respect for Wu Hsiu-chi, the late Tainan business tycoon who established the Filial Piety Awards. "Wu's contribution has benefited Taiwan society and people by making the country a better place to live in," the president said.
Each of the seven award winners also received NT$300,000 (US$9,090) in cash.

DOC.HEADLINE: 15 OBSERVERS LEAVE FOR ATLANTIC TO MONITOR TAIWAN FISHING OPERATIONS

TEXT.P: Fifteen observers departed Taiwan for Spain and South Africa Friday to board and monitor 15 Taiwan vessels operating in the Atlantic Ocean, the fisheries administrator said.

Addressing an event marking the relaunch of Taiwan's bigeye tuna fishing in the Atlantic Ocean after the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna (ICCAT) cut Taiwan's total allowable bigeye tuna fishing quota and slashed the number of Taiwan vessels allowed to operate in the Atlantic in November, Hsieh Ta-wen, director of the Fisheries Administration under the Council of Agriculture (COA) exhorted the owners and operators of the 15 vessels as well as the 15 observers to do their duties to reflect Taiwan's resolve to help maintain fishing order in that part of the world.
Protecting deep-sea fishery resources and maintaining sustainable fishing operations is not just the government's responsibility but also the responsibility of the private fishery sector, Hsieh said.

More Taiwan fishing vessels will be allowed to return to the Atlantic Ocean only if the ICCAT decides in its annual meeting to be held in November 2006 that Taiwan has done a satisfactory job in curbing its "overfishing" and helping the fishery resources replenish, Hsieh noted.
The ICCAT cut Taiwan's total allowable bigeye tuna fishing quota from 14,900 tons in 2005 to a mere 4,600 tons for the coming year because of alleged overfishing by Taiwan fishing vessels.
The ICCA also ruled that out of the 60-strong Taiwan bigeye tuna fishing boats, only 15 will be allowed to continue their operations in the Atlantic Ocean for the following one year on a trial basis.
The decision was made on the last day of the ICCAT's 19th regular meeting held in Seville, Spain, after Japan proposed a quota cut citing overfishing by Taiwanese vessels.

The 15 observers, who were originally ocean science observers collecting information on ocean resources, will be responsible for monitoring the operations of the 15 Taiwan vessels and the registration of their catches.

The observers will monitor the operations of the vessels and check if they have registered their fishery catches according to regulations. They will report the catches daily to the Fisheries Administration, which will in turn report the information to the ICCAT.

The Fisheries Administration is planning to train another 15 people in order to boost the number of observers stationed on the ships to at least 30 so that they can work on a rotational basis, Hsieh said.
Most bigeye tuna caught by Taiwanese boats are sold to Japan. The amount exported to Japan in the past two years has exceeded the total yearly catch quota, prompting the charge of overfishing.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Mario Draghi named new Bank of Italy governor.
The Italian government named Mario Draghi Thursday as new Bank of Italy governor with a six-year term beginning from Feb. 1 of the next year. The 58-year-old famous international banker and economist won an unanimous support from both the ruling and opposition camps. He is expected to rebuild Italy's credibility that was tarnished after a banking takeover scandal that forced Draghi's predecessor Antonio Fazio to step down.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, dropping NT$0.058 to close at NT$32.850.
A total of US$1.23 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$32.919 and hit a low of NT$32.795.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for January moved down 10 points to close at 6,595, with 19,675 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for February moved down 35 points to end at 6,580, with 170 contracts traded, while March futures lost 25 point to finish at 6,585, with 133 contracts traded. June futures moved down 35 point to close at 6,569, with 18 contracts traded, while September futures moved down 30 points to close at 6,460, with 25 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 6,605 for January, 6,615 for February, 6,610 for March, 6,604 for June and 6,490 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.
January TE futures moved down 0.5 points to close at 289.9, with 4,081 contracts traded, while February TE futures lost 0.7 points to finish at 290, with 20 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for June and September.

January TF futures lost 7.8 points to finish at 894, with 1,756 contracts changing hands, while February TF futures moved down 5.4 points to end at 896.4, with 31 contracts traded. March TF lost 3.6 points to finish at 900, with two contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for June and September.

DOC.HEADLINE: STATUE OF LIMITATIONS PAST ON RECOVERING KMT-SOLD LAND: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The properties that the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) sold recently could be construed as having once belonged to the government, but the statue of limitations on their recovery has long since expired, Vice Minister of Finance Lee Jui-chang said Friday.

In a briefing to the legislative caucus of the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), Lee said the real estate occupied by the Central Motion Picture Corp. (CMPC) and Broadcasting Corporation of China (BCC), the two companies sold by the KMT, was either transferred to the party without cost by the KMT government when the island was handed over to the Republic of China by Japan at the end of World War Two or was purchased by the party afterward with money provided by the government.

However, since the property has been registered as belonging to the two companies for many decades, the government has no right to reclaim the plots as the statue of limitations of 20 years has long since run out, Lee said.

The land in question has been in the news since the KMT sold it along with the China Television Co. to a private investment company on Dec. 26, a move criticized by the TSU as a KMT attempt to dump its "ill-gotten assets."

On the same occasion Friday, Government Information Office Minister Pasuya Yao told the TSU legislative caucus that his office has asked the Jung Li Investment Company, the buyer of the three KMT media outlets, to explain how it financed the purchase since the company only has registered capital of NT$400 million. Yao said he would like to find out if hidden foreign investors were part of the deal.
Foreigners ownership of local media is forbidden by law.

DOC.HEADLINE: GENDER RIGHTS GROUPS CALLS FOR ABOLITION OF OBSCENE PUBLICATIONS LAW

TEXT.P: Members of several Taiwan gender rights groups announced Friday their plan to form an alliance to promote the abolition of Article 235 of the Criminal Code, which bans the sale, circulation and public display of obscene publications.
They said as part of their efforts to achieve their goal, they will request an interpretation by the Council of Grand Justices on the constitutionality of the article.

The groups led by the Gender/Sexuality Rights Association of Taiwan (G/S RAT) made the move after the owner of the country's first gay bookstore, the Gin Gin Bookstore, was convicted by the Taiwan High Court on Dec. 2 of obstructing public morality for importing a gay sex magazine from Hong Kong, based on Article 235 of the Criminal Code.

The gender rights activists claimed that since a clear definition of "obscenity" is lacking in the article, judges are free to decide what constitute obscenity and expect the public to have the same feeling as them, a situation which they said is unconstitutional.
The conviction of the owner of the Gin Gin Bookstore is one of the events on the 2005 top-10 list of sex rights violations compiled by G/S RAT. It took third place on the list.

Topping the list was the implementation of a rating system for Internet content. Coming in second was police raids of bookstores, book rental stores and video rental stores as part of their enforcement of a publication rating system.
In fourth place was the release of a draft by the Department of Health on the health standards of blood donors, under which male homosexuals and sex workers are forbidden from donating blood.
Fifth place was held by Li Hsin-yu's failed bid to bear her late fiance's child using frozen sperm harvested after his death, owing partly to a ban by health authorities.

In sixth place was the Department of Health's policy of defining condoms as a kind of medical supply that can only be sold at licensed stores, a practice which G/S RAT says may lower the accessibility of condoms in the market and hamper AIDS prevention.
In seventh place was an amendment that exempts the OEM production of pornographic VCDs for export from obscenity charges, which G/S RAT says obviously discriminates against local consumers.
In eight place was immigration authorities' denying the entry of a Chinese woman who is married to a Taiwanese man in Kaohsiung City, on the grounds that she had worked as a prostitute before.
In ninth place is social affairs authorities' publication of the name of the parents of a minor girl in Kaohsiung County for allowing the girl to work as a scantily dressed betelnut seller.

Rounding out the list was a senior high school girl who was asked by her school to prove that she had some problem with gender identification if she continued to refuse to wear a skirt during a class on the hospitality industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INAUGURATES ENGLISH-LANGUAGE WEB SITE FOR BIRD WATCHERS

TEXT.P: The International Taiwan Birding Association opened an English-language Web site Friday to help the world understand Taiwan's conservation efforts with regard to wild birds and to invite bird lovers to join guided tours to watch Taiwan's endemic bird species.

The Web site (www.birdingintaiwan.com) has a detailed description of some 15 bird species endemic to Taiwan, along with pictures. There is also an art gallery where bird-loving photographers have displayed hundreds of pictures they have taken of birds in Taiwan.
Some foreign bird lovers who joined birding trips to Taiwan in the past three years have contributed to the Web site by recording their experiences in articles and pictures.
There is also information about the next two birding tours, with one of them scheduled for May 1-13, 2006, and the other for Nov. 6-15, 2006.
According to tourism officials, February, May and November are the best months for bird-watching in Taiwan.

The Web site is co-sponsored by the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, the Council of Agriculture under the Cabinet, the Wild Bird Federation of Taiwan and the Changhua Wild Bird Society.

At a news conference held to inaugurate the Web site, Hsu Wen-sheng, director of the Tourism Bureau, pointed out that Taiwan has more than 500 bird species, including 15 precious endemics and 69 sub-endemics.
Among the species endemic to Taiwan are such highly treasured birds as the Formosan Magpie, Mikado Pheasant and Swinhoe's Blue Pheasant.

Hsu said that Taiwan has attracted more than 80 groups of bird lovers since it began to organize birding tours three years ago, and that at least 20 more groups are scheduled to take birding trips to Taiwan during 2006.

He cited figures to show that the number of foreign visitors who traveled to Taiwan during 2005 is expected to surpass 3.35 million, higher than the Tourism Bureau's target of 3.25 million. He said a major factor for the success is that Taiwan is free of the avian flu virus.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC WOMAN PILOT UNDER REVIEW AS HUSBAND WORKS AS PILOT FOR CHINA

TEXT.P: The Air Force General Headquarters (AFGH) said Friday it will consider whether to adjust the job of a woman ROC Air Force pilot whose husband has joined rival China's Sichuan Airlines as a pilot.
According to media reports, Lee Chi-hsiang, a former ROC Air Force pilot who once helped train Taiwan's first batch of women pilots, is now working for Sichuan Airlines.

The reports further said Lee's wife, Maj. Wu Wen-ying, is an ROC Air Force pilot on active duty responsible for special flight missions, mainly carrying the vice president, premier and high-ranking military officers (of lieutenant-general rank or higher) on domestic inspection tours.
The reports have resulted in some people questioning the propriety of the arrangement out of national security concerns.
In response, AFGH officials said the air force has a well-founded evaluation system to measure its aviation staff, with a particular emphasis on security checks.
Throughout her service in the air force, the officials said, Wu has lived up to the requirements in all aspects, including flight skills.
As to whether to transfer Wu to another post, the officials said the AFGH will make a comprehensive review before coming to a conclusion.
The officials also said Wu's husband retired from the military in 1995 after 12 years of service with the air force. Lee was not qualified for a life-long pension payout, according to the officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: RUNWAY ON DISPUTED ISLAND NOT FOR MILITARY PURPOSES: FOREIGN MINISTRY

TEXT.P: Taiwan has made it clear to Vietnam that its construction of a runway on an island in the South China Sea is not for military purposes, Michel Lu, a spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, said Friday.

Lu said Taiwan's representative to Hanoi, Huang Ju-li, had relayed this message to the Vietnamese Foreign Ministry Thursday afternoon, adding that the runway on Taiping Island, which is an islet of the Spratly Islands, is meant for medical airlift purposes and for the defense of Taiwan's waterways.

He made the remarks in response to a statement issued earlier in the day by the Vietnam foreign ministry, in which Hanoi asked Taiwan to stop building the runway, calling it a violation of Vietnam's sovereignty.
The Spratly Islands are claimed by Vietnam, Brunei, China, Malaysia, the Philippines and Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET TO EXPAND DOMESTIC DEMAND TO BOOST ECONOMY IN 2006

TEXT.P: With Taiwan's economic growth rate expected to register 5.28 percent in the final quarter of this year, the Cabinet will continue to expand domestic demand to stimulate economic growth in 2006, officials said Friday.

The officials pointed out that the country's economic growth rate increased from 2.49 percent in the first quarter of this year to 4.38 percent in the third quarter, which they claimed was the result of various measures taken by the Cabinet to boost the economy.

In addition, the unemployment rate between January and November of this year registered 4.15 percent, with that for November falling to 3.94 percent -- the lowest single-month level for November in five years, they noted.

They said the government's bid to strengthen the social security network has narrowed the wealth disparity in the country, with the wealth owned by the richest families in Taiwan being 6.03 times that of the poorest families in 2004, down from a high of 6.39 times in 2001.
In terms of the achievements in reforming the financial system, the non-performing loan ratio of domestic banks declined from 11.27 percent in 2001 to 2.8 percent in October 2005, they said.

Meanwhile, foreign remittances into Taiwan's stock market amounted to US$104 billion as of the end of November 2005, and the stocks held by foreign investors accounted for 28.88 percent of the total stock market value at the end of November 2005, compared with just 6.7 percent at the end of 2004, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG LEONG GROUP OF SINGAPORE INVITED TO BUILD HOTEL IN TAICHUNG

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu said Friday that he has invited executives of the Hong Leong Group of Singapore to visit Taichung in May 2006 to study the feasibility of building a "six-star" tourist hotel.

Hu, who just returned to Taiwan from a trade-promotion trip to Singapore, told news media that while in Singapore, he had met with executives of the Hong Leong Group and invited them to come to Taichung in May to see the investment climate in Taichung first-hand.
He said the Taichung City Government is willing to play a mediating role to help Hong Leong find an ideal plot of land in the central Taiwan city for the construction of the hotel.

Hu, who has just begun his second four-year term as Taichung mayor after winning re-election in early December, quoted figures to show that Taichung's hotels recorded a room occupancy rate of 86 percent for the first 10 months of 2005, higher than the 82 percent for hotels in the capital city of Taipei.
This means that there is still room for Taichung to add a few more luxury tourist hotels, he added.

The mayor also said that in addition to promoting trade with Singapore, he had used his trip to observe Singapore's cultural establishments, its management in public housing and its experience in tourism promotion, because Taichung can benefit by learning from Singapore.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC URGES CHINA TO EASE PRESS CONTROLS

TEXT.P: Chinese authorities should ease press controls in response to the increasingly vocal appeal for journalistic freedom in China, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said Friday.

Wu made the call amid foreign wire service reports that about 100 Beijing News reporters walked out Friday in protest at this week's dismissal of the daily's top editor and his two deputies, the latest victims of China's strict press controls.

Speaking during a year-end informal meeting with local journalists covering the MAC and cross-Taiwan Strait affairs, Wu said major international media watch groups have been sounding the alarm regarding China's media development since September 2004 when the Chinese Communist Party propaganda authorities began to tighten internal press controls.

Despite Chinese Communist authorities' ever-stricter censorship, Wu said he has seen Chinese media professionals' courageous struggle for a freer hand in news reporting. In some cases, Wu said, disgruntled mainland media staff have gone on strike in protest.
Wu urged Beijing authorities to face up squarely to their journalists' call for freedom of the press in line with the mainstream trends in the world community.
He also expressed his hope that China opens its door to the free flow of correct and objective information about Taiwan to boost mutual understanding of the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

According to Wu, the MAC has publicly welcomed several regional Chinese media outlets to post reporters in Taiwan to facilitate cross-strait journalistic exchanges. However, Beijing authorities have so far banned press staff from those newspapers from working in Taiwan.

As to when the MAC will again allow two Chinese official mouthpieces - the Xinhua News Agency and the People's Daily -- to post reporters in Taiwan, Wu said it will hinge on when Beijing allows its people to browse two Taiwan online newspapers -- the China Times, chinatimes.com, and the United Daily News, udn.com. The MAC withdrew permission last year for reporters from the two media organizations to be posted in Taipei in protest of their misleading and biased reports about Taiwan.

Meanwhile, Wu said the MAC will handle the Hong Kong-based Phoenix Satellite TV's application to beam its broadcast into Taiwan in a positive manner. Once the screening is finalized, Wu said he is hopeful that Phoenix can objectively broadcast Taiwan-related news events and other relevant information to various corners of China.
Foreign wire service reports said the editor in chief of the Beijing News, Yang Bin, was abruptly removed two days ago without any official explanation.

Friday's acts of defiance by journalists were the latest in a long struggle between the Chinese Communist Party, which tries to control information, and China's newspapers and magazines, which want to attract readers and revenue with bold reporting, the reports said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER DISSUADES LOCAL FARMERS FROM FOCUSING EXPORTS ON CHINA

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Friday Taiwan farmers should focus their export promotion activities on advanced countries instead of China where bogus Taiwan agricultural products are rampant.
Hsieh made the appeal during an inspection tour of a vegetable planting technology and marketing strategy study center in Taipao, Chiayi County in southern Taiwan.

The premier said Taiwan's agricultural exports to China have declined because of the runaway commercial counterfeiting there. Bogus Taiwan brand-name products, such as Alishan tea, Luku tea and Chuchi pears, have flooded markets in many parts of China.
"Most of the bogus farm produce originates in Hainan Island in southern China. Taiwan should negotiate with China over the issue and ask China to crack down on this agricultural piracy, " Hsieh said.
With their superb farming technology and fine product quality, Hsieh said, local farmers should focus their marketing efforts on making inroads into advanced countries to increase their income.

In the process, Hsieh said the government will offer all necessary assistance. "All local farmers should have trust and confidence in the government's commitment to helping them tap major markets around the world," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SAMPLE WRITTEN DRIVER'S TEST ONLINE IN 5 ASIAN LANGUAGES

TEXT.P: The Motor Vehicle Office under the Taipei City Government announced Friday that its Web site will carry sample questions for written driver's tests in five Asian languages from Jan. 2 to help immigrants in Taiwan prepare for their tests.

A spokesman for the office said that the examples of test questions will be available in Japanese, Vietnamese, Indonesian, Thai and Khmer to help new immigrants who speak these languages as their mother tongues to familiarize themselves with the written tests.

He said that a lack of opportunities to practice with sample questions was the main reason why only about 30 percent of immigrants from Japan, Vietnam, Indonesia, Thailand and Cambodia have passed the written tests in their own languages.

The spokesman suggested that immigrants who want to take the written test before applying for a driver's license should go to the Web site of the Motor Vehicle Office and practice first in order to be better prepared for the real test.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO REASON FOR OPTIMISM ABOUT CROSS-STRAIT TIES IN NEAR TERM: MAC

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said Friday he sees no reason to be optimistic about a thaw in the political impasse across the Taiwan Strait in the near future.

Judging from China's continued campaign to debase the Taiwan government by aligning with Taiwan's pro-unification opposition parties, Wu said during a year-end informal meeting with local journalists covering MAC and cross-strait affairs that improvement in cross-strait ties is doubtful, at least in the short term.
Wu cited two disappointing instances to back his pessimistic view about the prospects for breaking the lingering cross-strait political impasse.

In mid-November, Wu said, China blocked Taiwan health officials from attending a global meeting in the southwestern Chinese city of Kunming on avian flu prevention. Although three Taiwan academics were allowed to attend, Wu said, they were deprived of the rights to speak at the occasion.

Equally frustrating was China's blunt snub of an offer by Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chang Chun-hsiung to attend the funeral of Wang Daohan, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), Wu said.
Wang, China's top negotiator with Taiwan, died in Shanghai last Saturday at the age of 90. His funeral was Friday.

Noting that Taiwan allowed two Chinese officials to attend the funeral of the SEF's founding chairman, Koo Chen-fu, earlier this year, Wu said China's snub of Chang's offer manifests China's reluctance to treat Taiwan on an equal footing.
Despite China's unfriendliness, Wu said the Taiwan government will continue to pursue cross-strait reconciliation, cooperation and lasting peace.

DOC.HEADLINE: HK TRIAL DELAY REGRETTABLE: MAC

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) expressed regrets Friday over a Hong Kong court decision to delay a trial of suspects arrested during an anti-World Trade Organization (WTO) riot earlier this month.

The 14 suspects, including Lee Chien-cheng, a National Taiwan University (NTU) student, were rounded up after a mob of protesters broke through a police line Dec. 17 and tried to storm a WTO meeting. The demonstrators fought with police until they were subdued with tear gas.

All of the suspects were released on a HK$2,500 (US$320) bail Dec. 23 and Lee was the only one allowed to return to Taiwan after a guarantor paid a cash surety of HK$100,000. Lee, accompanied by his father, flew back to Hong Kong Thursday to stand trial.
A Hong Kong prosecutor in charge of the case announced Friday that the proceedings would be postponed until Jan. 11 to allow for more time to prepare the case.
MAC officials said they hope the Hong Kong judicial authorities can speed up court proceedings and acquit Lee as soon as possible. Any further delay would seriously affect Lee's study, they added.
Many of the protesters were South Korean farmers who said the WTO was trying to break down trade barriers that protected their markets from unfair foreign competition.
Those arrested were charged with taking part in an illegal assembly, punishable by up to five years in prison.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: G.I.'s to Increase U.S. Supervision of Iraqi Police
American commanders are planning to increase significantly the number of soldiers advising Iraqi police commando units, in part to curtail abuse that the units are suspected of inflicting on Sunni Arabs, a senior commander in Iraq said Thursday. Under the plan, the number of advisers working with the Iraqi units would be greatly expanded. The advisers themselves would be under the command of American officers. American advisers now accompany commando units as part of the vast effort to train and equip security forces to take over the fight against the insurgency and to maintain order. But the number of advisers is relatively small: currently, groups of about 40 American soldiers each are attached to seven of the nine special Iraqi police brigades.
Wall Street Journal: Policy Woes, China's Workers See Thin Protection In Insurance Plans
More than two-thirds of China's 1.3 billion people have no health insurance at all, and many cannot afford any medical care. But under China's pay-as-you-go health-care system, even those with insurance are often forced to make agonizing decisions about whether they can afford treatment for serious illness. Problems with insurance coverage have become a crisis for China's growing urban middle class, eating into support for the ruling Communist Party. As recently as the late 1970s, the Chinese government controlled all hospitals, employed all doctors, and offered almost universal health-care coverage. In the cities, the state provided insurance to civil servants, factory workers and their families. Collective farms provided care in the countryside. But the entire system began breaking down in the early 1980s as market-style reforms led collective farms to disband and money-losing factories to close. Tens of millions of workers were left without jobs or insurance.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR DECEMBER 31 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Saturday, December 31:
10:00, Premier Frank Hsieh will preside over a news conference on the Executive Yuan's administrative achievements in December.
19:30, Premier Hsieh will attend an outdoor party in Kaohsiung to celebrate the advent of 2006.
22:05, Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu will take part in a special BBC-BCC hotline talk show.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Dec. 31, or the first day of the 12th month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1799: The Dutch Administration in Batavia (now Jakarta) takes over the Dutch East India Company's territories in Indonesia.
1879: Thomas A. Edison, American inventor, demonstrates for the first time his electric incandescent light at Menlo Park, New Jersey.
1880: George Marshall, U.S. Army general and statesman, is born. As secretary of state, he devised the Marshall Plan for post-war economic recovery in Europe.
1909: The Manhattan Bridge, a two-section suspension bridge, is opened to traffic in New York.
1915: Yuan Shih-kai, who promised to establish a republican government when he assumed the provisional presidency of the Republic of China, orders the restoration of the imperial system, with himself on the throne, beginning from 1916.
1919: The United States, Britain, and Japan sign an agreement on East Siberia.
1924: Dr. Sun Yat-sen, who had fallen ill earlier, arrives in Peking from Tientsin to hold talks with Tuan Chi-jui, provisional chief executive of the Peking-based government. While in Peking, Dr. Sun succumbed to liver cancer and died on March 25, 1925.
1946: U.S. President Harry S. Truman officially proclaims the end of World War II.
1946: Chiang Kai-shek reiterates the government's policy of continuing attempts to settle disputes with the communists by political means.
1946: Chang Hsueh-liang, the commander of the Northeastern Army who played a key role in the kidnapping of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek in Xian, is escorted to Taiwan and put under house arrest at the Chingshang hot spring in Hsinchu. The Xian Incident was a severe setback to Chiang's efforts to subjugate the communists.
1956: President Sukarno proclaims a state of siege in Sumatra, Indonesia.
1964: President Sukarno threatens to quit the United Nations if Malaysia is given a seat on the Security Council.
1971: Kurt Waldheim of Austria takes over as the United Nations secretary-general after U Thant retired.
1975: More than 1,600 foreign students present an autographed album to Premier Chiang Ching-kuo at a year-end meeting.
1976: Education Minister Y. S. Tsiang hosts a dinner to honor foreign students and visiting professors at the Chientan Youth Activity Center with more than 1,000 students and teachers from 30 countries attending.
1977: Cambodia breaks off diplomatic relations with Vietnam and suspends all air services between the two countries.
1979: The Sino-U.S. Mutual Defense Treaty against the Chinese communists in the area is ended.
1983: The United States deploys Cruise missiles and Pershing II missiles in Britain and West Germany.
1985: The Taipei World Trade Center is inaugurated.
1988: Indian Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi and Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto sign the first agreement between India and Pakistan in 16 years, agreeing not to attack each others' nuclear facilities.
1991: All senior delegates to the ROC's First National Assembly, Control Yuan, and Legislative Yuan retire from office.
1996: Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong submits his resignation to Premier Lien Chan.
1997: Mohammed Rafiq Tarar becomes the ninth president of Pakistan.
1998: Finance ministers of the European Union announce definite rates for converting the currencies of the 11 nations due to launch the single euro currency on Jan. 1, 1999.
1999: President Lee Teng-hui calls for increased constructive dialogue between the two sides of the Taiwan Straits on an equal footing so as to contribute to peace and stability in the Asia-Pacific region.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian calls on Beijing leaders to try to break through the existing cross-strait stalemate with open-mindedness and forward-looking vision so as to jointly establish a mechanism for permanent peace and political integration of Taiwan and the mainland.
2001: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) issues operational certificates to seven financial holding companies, the first batch of its kind in Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only men of moral character who know how to love men or to hate men. If you fix your mind upon a moral life, you will be free from evil."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: U.S. to Restrict Iraqi Police. After a series of prison abuse scandals that have inflamed sectarian tensions, U.S. officials announced plans Thursday to rein in Iraqi special police forces, increasing the number of American troops assigned to work with them and requiring consultations before the Iraqis mount raids in Baghdad.
