DOC.HEADLINE: International Headline News
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Exchange chief lauds performance, cites difficulties
The Tokyo Stock Exchange held a ceremony Friday to mark the end of the year's trading, with Dai Tamesue, the bronze medal winner in the men's 400-meter hurdles at the International Association of Athletic Federation World Championships in August, cheering on the ceremoony.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Office of charities watchdog to be strengthened.
The office of the Commissioner of Charities looks set to be beefed up to regulate charities more effectively.
This could take the form of a commitee advising the Commissioner, Dr. Vivian Balakrishnan said yesterday.
The office, now filled by the Comptroller of Income Tax, Mr. Moses Lee, should be structured to allow representation from the public.
The Lianhe Zaobao: The public will be able to participate more in supervising charities: Vivian.
The public can play the more important and more positive roles in supervising charities, and impels the improvement and development of local charities, said Vivian Balakrishnan, the Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports (MCYS).

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: Filipinos welcome the New Year
Millions of Filipino families are ready to welcome 2006 with optimism at midnight when the entire country will resonate with the crackle of firecrackers, the ringing of church bells and the booming of improvised PVC cannons to signal the arrival of the New Year.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: SUBIC RAPE CASE, Arrest of 4 US servicemen pressed
LAWMAKERS scored the special treatment accorded four US Marines charged with raping a Filipino woman who are now "detailed" at the Joint US Military Assistance Group (Jusmag), an office within the US Embassy compound in Manila.
The Philippine Star: Palace wants Cha-cha plebiscite in early 2006
Malacanang is bent on holding a plebiscite early next year to ratify a new Constitution.
The Manila Times: Govt winning war on rebellion, terror
GOVERNMENT forces continue to gain the upper hand in the campaign against Islamic militants and communist guerrillas in 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT, KMT CHAIRMAN TO ATTEND NEW YEAR'S FLAG-RAISING CEREMONY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian and other high-ranking officials as well as opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou will participate in a flag-raising ceremony early Sunday morning to mark the first day of the new year.
The ceremony, which is set to be held at 6: 30 a.m. at the plaza in front of the Presidential Office, is jointly being organized by six leading industrial and business associations.
Vice President Annette Lu and Premier Frank Hsieh are also expected to take part in the ceremony, according to the organizers.

At the ceremony, the 20 winners of this year's Presidential Education Awards will lead the crowd in singing the national anthem. The flag-raising ceremony will be followed by a series of performances.

People wanting to attend the ceremony will be allowed to enter the plaza from 5: 30 a.m. Organizers also reminded the public that all items not related to the event, such as political party flags, leaflets, banners, microphones or articles that could effect public order, will not be allowed onto the plaza.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER A THIRD OF TAIWAN PEOPLE CONSIDER THEMSELVES POOR: SURVEY

TEXT.P: More than 30 percent of the Taiwan people consider themselves to be part of the "poor class" of society, according to the results of a recent survey by a local magazine.

According to the survey published in the latest edition of Global View Monthly, 33.9 percent of the people feel they belong to the lower class of society, while 56.7 percent said they consider themselves to be "middle class."

Meanwhile, the survey also found that 86.9 percent of the respondents feel that the rise in cost of living is outpacing the increase in their salaries, while 63.3 percent said their economic situation has gotten worse over the last three years.

Sheng Chin-jen, a professor in Soochow University's Department of Political Science, said the fact that over a third of the people consider themselves to belong to the lower class is "a very terrible result." He added that if another 10 percent of those who consider themselves to be middle class start viewing themselves as part of the lower class, then "Taiwan will become a poor country."

Sheng further said that "although the survey only focused on the subjective perception of one's economic standing, 'poverty' to a certain degree represents dissatisfaction with the current situation in society."

Among the respondents who believe their standard of living will get worse in the future, the main concerns mentioned were political instability, cost of living increases, declining income, their children's education, and fear of being laid off, in that order.
The telephone survey, conducted on 1,094 local residents over the age of 20 between Dec. 5-6, has a margin of error of plus or minus 3 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOTEL OCCUPANCY RATE HITS 71.3% FOR JAN.-OCT.

TEXT.P: Taiwan's hotel occupancy rate for the first ten months of this year was 71.3 percent, up 9.7 percentage points over the same period in 2001, according to tallies released recently by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

While the occupancy rate of international hotels increased 10.6 percentage points from 2001 to stand at 72.6 percent for the January-October period, that of ordinary hotels rose 4.9 percentage points to 63.8 percent.
DGBAS officials said the hotel occupancy rate for the whole of 2005 is expected to reach a record high.

DGBAS data showed that Taiwan's hotel occupancy rates maintained at more than 60 percent in 2001 and 2002 but declined to 56.4 percent in 2003 because of the SARS outbreaks. In 2004, the government's measures to boost the tourism industry successfully increased visitor arrivals by 31.2 percent, with the hotel occupancy rate jumping to 66.2 percent.
Up to the end of October 2005, there were 88 hotels with 21,898 rooms, including 62 international hotels with 18,903 rooms and 26 ordinary hotels with 2,995 rooms, according to the DGBAS.
The average hotel rate has remained at above NT$2,900 per night over the last five years, with the exception of 2003 when the rate dropped to NT$2,763 per night.
The average hotel rate in the first 10 months of this year amounted to NT$2,994 per night, up 1.5 percent compared with the same period in 2001.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO ANNOUNCE WHETHER TO RESHUFFLE CABINET IN DUE TIME: HSIEH

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will announce in due time whether there will be a reshuffle of the Cabinet after considering the overall situation, Premier Frank Hsieh said Saturday.
The premier made the remarks at a press conference held to report on the Cabinet's performance in December.

He said the president has the constitutional right to name a premier to form the Cabinet. He added that in the wake of the Dec. 3 city and county chief elections in which the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) suffered a humiliating defeat, he has offered to step down in response to the latest mandate of the people, and the president will make a final decision on the matter.
The DPP managed to win only six out of the 23 city mayor and county magistrate posts up for grabs in the Dec. 3 elections, while the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) won 14 posts.
He said that the president is listening to views from all sides, adding that he believes that the president will make an announcement in due time.

Analyzing the landscape of the legislature after the elections, the premier said that if the KMT and the People First Party merge into one party, the new party will command a majority in the Legislative yuan.

Under this scenario, even though his serving as a premier is constitutional, his political legitimacy will be challenged, Hsieh said. However, if the two opposition parties don't merge, then the DPP will be the largest party, and it will be both constitutional as well as politically legitimate for a DPP member to head the Cabinet, he added.
The premier said that even if the DPP is the largest party, the Cabinet will still be relatively weak as the ruling party doesn't command a majority in the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: The DeLay-Abramoff Money Trail; Nonprofit Group Linked to Lawmaker Was Funded Mostly by Clients of Lobbyist.
The U.S. Family Network, a public advocacy group that operated in the 1990s with close ties to Rep. Tom DeLay and claimed to be a nationwide grass-roots organization, was funded almost entirely by corporations linked to embattled lobbyist Jack Abramoff, according to tax records and former associates of the group.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ECONOMY TO IMPROVE IN 2006: MINISTER

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh expressed confidence Saturday that Taiwan's economy will be better in 2006, for which the Cabinet has set the goal of achieving economic growth of 4.5 percent.

During a news show on Taiwan's economic situation and outlook aired by the Chinese Television System, Ho said many people were not optimistic about the country's economic performance this year mainly because of the soaring international oil prices.
However, Ho said, the government's decision to not raise electricity rates and to keep oil price hikes at a reasonable level has effectively maintained consumers' spending power.

Exports for the whole of 2005 are expected to amount to between US$188 billion and US$190 billion, up from the US$174 billion registered in 2004, Ho said, adding that the trade surplus is expected to reach US$6 billion for 2005.

Refuting public criticism that Taiwan's industrial sector is hollowing out, Ho said the number of factories in Taiwan has increased by 10,000 this year, with the number of people employed at plants rising by 56,000.

She further said that workers in the manufacturing sector totalled 2.72 million, equal to the peak level registered between 1986 and 1989, and that the unemployment rate also dropped below 4 percent in November, which she said proves that Taiwan's industry has not been hollowed out.
She said the manufacturing industry and service industry will be the "dual engines" driving Taiwan's economy in the future.
According to the minister, Taiwan should not rely solely on exports in the future but should establish its own brands and distribution channels.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN AFFIRMS SPOKESWOMAN'S DECISION TO QUIT RADIO HOST JOB

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou on Saturday affirmed the KMT spokeswoman's decision to quit her radio talk show host job near the end of next month, although he added that it would be better if she quit earlier.

Ma made the remarks after attending a ceremony marking the opening of a new branch of the Taipei Municipal Library. KMT spokeswoman Cheng Li-wen announced earlier the same day that she would quit her radio host job at the UFO Network Broadcasting Co. on Jan. 29.

Cheng made the decision following recent criticism by Government Information Office Director-General Pasuya Yao about a representative of a political party being involved in the media. KMT Legislator Wu Yu-sheng also said that Cheng's controversial double role might be harmful to the KMT's image.
According to the revised law governing broadcasting and television, the government, political parties and the military were to have withdrawn from all media operations by Dec. 26.

Cheng began hosting the talk show at the invitation of Jaw Shau-kong, chairman of the UFO Radio Station, when she was a member of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party. Cheng kept the job after becoming the KMT spokeswoman a few months ago.
Commenting on Wu's statements that Cheng should quit the talk show host job, Ma said that the legislator only wants to protect the image of the party.
Ma further said that Cheng is "as good as her word" on her promise to quit the talk show host job.
Admitting that it would be better if she were to quit at an earlier date, Ma, nevertheless, said that Cheng's decision is "appropriate and wise" and lives up to his expectations of the spokeswoman.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDICTMENTS BROUGHT IN 60% OF FINANCIAL CRIMES CASES SINCE LATE 2002

TEXT.P: Indictments have been made in 84 out of the total of 126 cases involving major financial crimes between Nov. 1, 2002, and Dec. 16, 2005, according to data released Saturday by the Ministry of Justice (MOJ).
Of the 84 indicted, 39 have been convicted, the data showed.

The 126 cases included 57 scandals involving 32 financial institutions which the Cabinet's financial rehabilitation fund stepped into to put in order; 58 cases were referred by the Ministry of Finance's (MOF's) Bureau of Monetary Affairs for investigation; and 11 cases were referred by the MOF's Securities and Futures Commission for investigation.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Crime Numbers Keep Dropping Across the City
Crime has fallen across New York City for the 17th consecutive year, with subway crime down by more than 5 percent from last year and the number of recorded murders virtually certain to be the fewest in any single year since 1963, new Police Department statistics show. As of yesterday, there had been 537 killings in the city, according to the department's latest marking-period reports that are issued weekly. That is down from 566 in the same period last year. And it is down from 649 in all of 2001, when joblessness surged, anxiety from Sept. 11 was present and a budget crisis prompted a reduction in numbers of city police officers. In that year, some citizens and criminal justice experts predicted a bottoming out of the crime downturn as the police force took on new counterterrorism responsibilities.
Wall Street Journal: Still to Come... Center Stage in '06: Natural Gas, Iran, New Cancer Tests
In a half-dozen or so different realms, Wall Street Journal reporters took a shot at identifying a few jolts that might lie ahead in the new year. Cancer Testing: There is possibilities to reveal certain cancers much earlier than current screening tests such as colonoscopies and mammograms. Global Threats: Not that Iraq doesn't present enough problems, but America's biggest international worries in 2006 just might come from elsewhere: Latin America or Iraq's next-door neighbor Iran. Energy: Alongside Big Oil, expect to see Big Gas.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC GROWTH EXPECTED TO REACH 4.5 PERCENT FOR 2006: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Saturday that the nation's economy has registered growth for each quarter this year and estimated that the growth will reach around 4.5 percent next year.
The premier made the remarks in a press conference to report on the Cabinet's performance in managing the economy for this year.
He forecast that the jobless rate in 2006 will be around 4 percent and that consumer prices will increase by about 2 percent, with both figures being better than those for this year.

After a series of measures implemented by the government to stimulate the economy, Hsieh said, economic growth rose from 2.49 percent in the first quarter to 4.38 percent in the third quarter. Economic growth in the fourth quarter is forecast to hit 5.28 percent, he added.

He further said that the average unemployment rate for the first 11 months of this year was 4.15 percent and that the jobless rate for November was 3.94 percent, or the lowest level in the past five years.

The total number of employed hit 10.02 million in November, up 1.6 percent, or 154,000, over the figure for the same month a year earlier, which he said indicated that the various measures adopted by the government have borne fruit.
On the topic of financial reform, he said the overdue loan ratio continued to drop this year, falling to 2.8 percent in October from 11.27 percent at the end of 2001.

The premier also noted that net foreign capital inflows have increased dramatically, rising to US$100.04 billion in November of this year from US$80 billion at the end of 2004. The ratio of foreign capital in the Taiwan stock market rose to 28.88 percent in November, up by 6.7 percent from the figure at the end of 2004.
Hsieh said that these figures show that the nation's economy is improving, adding that "the public should have confidence in themselves."

He also said that after careful assessment and calculation of the profits of the Chinese Petroleum Corp., gasoline prices are unlikely to be hiked before Chinese New Year, which falls on Jan. 29, despite the fact that world oil prices have topped US$60 per barrel.
"This will help stabilize consumer prices before the Chinese New Year," he added.
As to whether gasoline prices will be adjusted after the Chinese New Year, he said that this will hinge on whether international oil prices continue to climb.

DOC.HEADLINE: 75% OF OFFICE WORKERS THINKING ABOUT SWITCHING PROFESSIONS: POLL

TEXT.P: Seventy-five percent of Taiwan office workers are thinking about switching professions, according to the results of a survey released Saturday.
While 54 percent of the people who have this idea said they will find a new job, 24 percent said they will start their own business.

The survey was conducted by the monthly magazine Smart in cooperation with the online employment service provider 1111 Job Bank on 1,896 office workers 20-50 years old between Dec. 6-20. The survey is said to have margin of error of plus or minus 2.3 percentage points.

On the reasons for wanting to switch professions, 54 percent of the respondents mentioned the low incomes in their current professions; 34 percent mentioned a lack of interest or sense of achievement; and 27 percent pointed to the bad outlook of the professions that they are in now.
In terms of what field they want to enter, the top-five mentioned by the respondents were the high-tech, tourism, trade, optoelectronic communications, and service sectors, in that order.

Among those who wish to start their own businesses, 31 percent said they want to start an online business; 27 percent want to open a coffee shop; 26 percent would like to work at home; 16.51 percent want to open an organic and health food store; and 13.76 percent want to open a fashion boutique.

However, fewer than 5 percent of the respondents wishing to start a business said they are able to raise at least NT$2 million in start-up funds, while approximately 60 percent said they have less than NT$500,000 at their disposal for such a venture, and nearly 30 percent have no more than NT$200,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL CAMP FOR YOUNG PHYSICS AMBASSADORS OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: A five-day international camp for young physics ambassadors opened at Tamkang University in the northern county of Taipei Saturday.
The 100 young physics ambassadors taking part in the camp are young students from 17 countries in Europe, North America and Asia, according to Tamkang University Secretary-General Wan Tung.

The camp has been organized by the National Science Council, the Ministry of Education, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Physical Society of the Republic of China and Tamkang University to mark the 100th anniversary of the publication of physics master Albert Einstein's theory of relativity and to nurture youths talented in physics, Wan said.

During the camp, Douglas D. Osheroff, a professor at Stanford University who won the Nobel Prize in physics in 1996, will be on hand to deliver a speech. Also, the young physics ambassadors will present their new research papers on physics, Wan said.
At the conclusion of the camp, a certificate presentation ceremony will be held in recognition of the young physics ambassadors' outstanding achievements, Wan added.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO STEP UP ASSISTANCE TO HOMELESS

TEXT.P: With the number of homeless people increasing every year, the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) is working on a draft plan to step up assistance to them, including providing them with temporary shelter and medical services, a ministry official said Saturday.

Tseng Chung-ming, deputy director of the Department of Social Affairs, said the department recently invited representatives from local governments for a meeting to solicit their views in mapping out a draft plan on dealing with and assisting the homeless, adding that he hopes the plan can be put into practice next year.

Tseng said that the plight of the homeless raises special concern in the cold winter months. According to the plan, when the mercury dips below 10 degrees Celsius, local governments and private groups will activate a "concern mechanism, " with hot meal stations set up immediately and temporary shelters opened to them.

For those vagabonds who are willing to stay at the shelters to be set up under the plan, local governments will assess their job skills and provide them with individual counseling, group support, and house renting information. The homeless individuals will be allowed to stay in the shelters for up to six months and ask for an extension, if necessary, during their transitional period.
For those homeless who fall sick, the local government will foot their medical bill or work with the private sector to share the burden.

For those vagabonds whose identities are established during hospitalization, the local government of the vagabond's domicile will be notified so that it can contact family members as soon as possible to shoulder half of the medical bill.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEARLY 7,000 STUDENTS TAKE PART IN TAIWAN-JAPAN EXCHANGE PROGRAM

TEXT.P: A total of 3,502 Taiwan students and 3,207 Japanese students have taken part in education exchange visits between the two countries this year, with the number of participants being more than double that of last year, the Ministry of Education (MOE) said Saturday.

The ministry began the program of overseas education tours for senior high school students five years ago. It set up the Taiwan International Association for Education Tours in 2004 to promote the exchange program, which mainly focuses on exchanges with Japan at present.

In 2004, 34 groups comprising 1,342 students from 49 schools in Taiwan headed to Japan to visit various Japanese schools and experience Japanese culture and life. In the same year, 1,609 Japanese students made similar tours to Taiwan, MOE statistics showed.

MOE officials said such exchange activities will help broaden the students' horizons and build up the friendship between Taiwan and Japan, adding that they hope local students will also visit other countries in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Reppublica: President Ciampi receives new central bank governor Draghi.
President Carlo Ciampi received newly appointed Bank of Italy Governor Mario Draghi Friday at the presidential office. The meeting was described as cordial, but no content of the conversation was released. After the meeting, Draghi told reporters that he will be sure in the central bank in January after completing a certain thing.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER TAKING GEPT DOWN AFTER EDUCATION MINISTRY CHANGES RULES

TEXT.P: The number of people who have registered to take the General English Proficiency Test (GEPT) basic level test scheduled for next year is far lower than the number who took the test this year, mainly as a result of the Ministry of Education (MOE) changing the rules to bar those who are 12 years old or under from taking the test.
The Language Training & Testing Center (LTTC), the sponsor of the GEPT, said that only around 103,000 people have registered to take the test scheduled for January.

With the nation gripped by English mania, the number of people taking part in each of the two GEPT basic level tests last year exceeded 120,000, with 124,000 taking the first test and nearly 130,000 taking the second test. The LTTC officials noted that those aged 14 or under made up a third of the total last year.
The officials said that they even observed some parents taking their kindergarten-aged children to write the test.
The MOE announced in March that starting from next year, those who are 12 or under will not be allowed to register to write the GEPT.

Education officials said that the decision was made in view of the fact that the GEPT is not designed for those under the level of junior high school, adding that the ministry is concerned that some young children might lose interest in learning English if they do poorly on the test.

DOC.HEADLINE: MATSU ON HIGH ALERT AFTER ANOTHER AVIAN FLU DEATH REPORTED IN CHINA

TEXT.P: The outlying island of Matsu has continued to tighten its contagious disease preventon amid reports of a third human avian flu death in China earlier this month, a local health official said Saturday.

According to foreign wire service reports, a 41-year-old woman in Sanming, Fujian Province, died of avian flu infection Dec. 21, becoming China's third human fatality from the H5N1 strain of bird flu.

Liu Tseng-ying, director of Matsu's Health Bureau, said if any cases of human-to-human transmission of the avian flu virus are reported in Fujian, which lies a stone's throw away from Matsu, he will advise the central government to suspend the direct "mini three links" between the two sides.

The "mini three links" refer to direct trade, mail and shipping links between Taiwan's two frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu and Fujian's Xiamen and Mawei, which have been in place since the beginning of 2001.

"In view of our geographic proximity to Fujian, we have had a cmprehensive avian flu prevention network in place since this summer, with all county government departments and health care units required to cooperate closely in disease monitoring, reporting and prevention," Liu said.
Moreover, Liu said the county's epidemic control center has three months of preventive medical supplies, including face masks, thermometers and protective gowns, in stock.
Health monitoring and customs inspection at the harbor for the "mini three links" services have also been stepped up to detect potential avian virus carriers and deter poultry smuggling, Liu said.
China's latest human bird flu case -- the seventh this year -- comes after two fatalities from the virus in Anhui province in eastern China.
World Health Organization (WHO) experts also believe a 12-year-old girl in the southern province of Hunan very probably died from bird flu in November, but China does not include her in its tally.

Beijing's official Xinhua news agency did not offer any details of the latest victim's work or background; nor did it say how she may have contracted the H5N1 virus. Previous infections have involved people who had close contact with poultry.
The WHO and other international health bodies have called on China to pass on animal samples of the bird flu virus for testing, which China has not done.
"It means that there is a question mark that hangs over the progress of the virus in China, " Roy Wadia, the WHO's Beijing-based spokesman, was quoted as having said Friday.

The WHO has said it was unclear why China was not sharing the virus samples, but said it had not seen evidence of a SARS-style cover-up. Some information has been shared this year, but only on paper, Wadia said.
China agreed earlier this month to share virus samples isolated from human bird flu cases.
"It's certainly a situation where the viruses need to be shared and not only shared but shared in a timely and consistent manner, " Wadia said.
The new outbreak showed how difficult the monitoring of bird flu was in China, he added.
"If the animals in the area were sick and dying, and if they were dying in small numbers, it might have been very difficult to identify that as an outbreak," Wadia said.

"It just shows you that anything can happen at any time. It's a very unpredictable situation, whether on the human side or the animal side, " he said, adding it was too early to say if the WHO was considering sending a mission to Fujian.

DOC.HEADLINE: LU HOPES TO SERVE AS BRIDGE BETWEEN RULING, OPPOSITION PARTIES

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu on Saturday expressed the hope that she can serve as a bridge to promote harmony between the ruling and the opposition parties in her upcoming meeting with Ma Ying-jeou, chairman of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT).
Lu made the remarks while speaking about an annual meeting of the Harvard alumni association set for Jan. 6 which will serve as a venue for her to meet with Ma.
Lu, who concurrently serves as the acting chairwoman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, said that President Chen Shui-bian has encouraged her to have dialogue with Ma.

Ma holds a doctoral degree in law from Harvard University, and Lu also pursued graduate studies at the prestigious school before returning to Taiwan in 1978 to devote herself to the democratic development of the nation.

Lu said that at the alumni meeting, she will first give a 10-minute talk, and Ma will then also talk for 10 minutes, adding that there will be a question-and-answer session for those attending the meeting following a 30-minute dialogue.
On exchanges between the ruling and the opposition parties, Lu said that the new DPP chairman, who will be elected Jan. 15, will engage in party-to-party negotiations.
President Chen will be in charge of major policies, she said, adding that she herself will try to serve as a bridge to promote inter-party harmony.

DOC.HEADLINE: BURKINA FASO HONORS KIND-HEARTED TAIWAN PHYSICIAN

TEXT.P: Lien Chia-en, a young Taiwan doctor, has become the first foreign youth to have received a prestigious national medal from the West African state of Burkina Faso.

Jacques Sawadogo, the Burkina Faso ambassador to the Republic of China, conferred the medal to Lien in a ceremony held at Grand Formosa Regent Hotel in Taipei Friday in recognition of his contributions to the African state while performing alternative military service there.

Lien, a graduate of National Yang Ming University's medical school, helped heal the sick and clean up the countryside in Burkina Faso during his 20-month compulsory alternative military service starting in October 2001.

In addition to working with the ROC medical mission stationed in Burkina Faso, Lien mounted a clothes-for-garbage drive to help the people and environment of Burkina Faso that had turned him into something of a legend on the Internet. He solicited Taiwan people for donations of unwanted clothes on the Internet. At the end of the day, he received over 1,500 bags of clothes from people around the world who learned of his drive on the Internet.

Many Taiwan citizens responded to Lien's drive, which was launched by himself and a Christian group in Burkina Faso to help rid the countryside of discarded plastic garbage bags that posed a danger to cattle and other animals. People who gathered and handed in such plastic waste were given a bundle of the donated clothes in return for their efforts.

Lien returned to Taipei after ending his mandatory alternative conscript service. In March 2004, he and his newly-wed wife flew to Burkina Faso for another year of volunteer service. During the period, he helped raise funds to build an orphanage and taught the locals to run the orphanage. He also offered medical services for Burkina Faso citizens.

Speaking at the decoration ceremony, Amb. Sawadogo said this is the first time that his country has conferred the prestigious medal to a young foreigner. Traditionally, he said, the medal was only awarded to his nation's political heavyweights, celebrities and influential foreign figures.

Lien, who is now working at Veterans General Hospital in suburban Taipei, said he appreciates the honor the Burkina Faso government has conferred upon him. Actually, Lien said he has learned a lot during his four-year work in the African state, including tropical medicine and French.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS DIVIDED OVER 'HOKLO COUNCIL' PROPOSAL

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan's education and legal affairs committees will hold a joint meeting Monday to screen a draft bill initiated by a Non-Partisan Solidarity Union (NPSU) legislator to set up a "Hoklo Affairs Council" under the Executive Yuan.
The draft bill, broached by NPSU Legislator Yen Ching-piao, has received the endorsement of more than 60 lawmakers from across the political spectrum.
Hoklo, a sub-ethnic group in Taiwan, accounts for about 70 percent of the Taiwan population.

Yen said the proposed council is expected to come up with effective measures to preserve and promote traditional Hoklo culture and language. Now that the Executive Yuan has set up special councils to handle Hakka and Aboriginal affairs, Yen said, a similar council should be established to deal with Hoklo affairs.

Although his proposal has received support from 60-plus lawmakers, many other legislators have questioned the propriety of creating such a body at a time when the Executive Yuan is pursuing a smaller and leaner government.
Opposition People First Party Legislator Lee Yung-ping said she sees no need to set up such a council since Hoklo is the largest ethnic group in Taiwan.

Opposition Kuomintang Legislator Wu Chih-yang and ruling Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Hsu Kuo-yung echoed Lee's view, saying that the existing Council for Cultural Affairs can carry out tasks regarding preservation and promotion of Hoklo culture and language.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S NEW YEAR ADDRESS TO FOCUS ON CROSS-STRAIT TIES: WANG

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Saturday he believes that President Chen Shui-bian's New Year address will focus on relations across the Taiwan Strait.
Wang made the forecast while attending a New Year's Eve party organized by the opposition New Party.
Wang said local people, political analysts in particular, can scrutinize differences between Chen's 2005 and 2006 New Year messages.

For his part, Wang said he looks forward to seeing resumption of regular dialogue and exchanges between the two quasi-official intermediary bodies -- Taipei's Straits Exchanges Foundation (SEF) and Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).
"If the two bodies can resume dialogue, negotiations for opening direct cross-strait shipping and air links would be able to make headway," Wang said.

President Chen has said on several occasions that he will outline Taiwan's top national goals in his upcoming New Year address. including relations across the Taiwan Strait, economy and domestic affairs.

The New Year address will stress that democratic Taiwan will continue growing and thriving and will never fade away, Chen said, adding that his New Year message will be even more important than his two inaugural addresses.
